column2: Roland Hayes, tenor, was presented a scroll of honor by Mayor Wagner in a short ceremony in the Mayor's private office at City Hall yesterday.
The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange elected Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower a public governor of the exchange yesterday.

THE team-of-four contest for the Curt H. Reisinger Trophy, one of the two principal events in the Eastern States Championships being played at the Statler-Hilton Hotel, began last night with sixty-four teams.
"WHEN I grow up I'm going to be a great cook," an nounced Deidre Gould, age 5, as she pounded herbs in a mortar.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Tuesday, May 29--Israel's Supreme Court unanimously rejected today Adolf Eichmann's appeal against his death sentence for a major role in the mass murder of 6,000,000 Jews.
WASHTNGTON, May 28 (AP)--President Kennedy signed a bill today under which the Government will acquire the Orphan Mine on the south rim of the Grand Canyon in Arizona.

Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, Inc., declared a quarterly dividend of 30 cents a common share yesterday and an extra of 10 cents a share, both payable on June 30 to stockholders of record of June 15. The company which did not pay an extra last year, had previously paid 25 cents quarterly.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 28 --The engagement of Miss Wendy Gail Schneider, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. A. David Schneider, to Jerry A. Blum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron L. Blum of Hartsdale, has been announced by the future bride's parents.
Special efforts should be made to preserve the culture and language of Puerto Rican children living in the United States, two visiting educators from the island urged yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 28--A modified version of President Kennedy's controversial publicworks spending bill was approved by the Senate today against nearly unanimous Republican opposition.
BELFAST, Ireland, May 28-- Viscount Brookeborough, Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, defended tonight the record of his Government in handling economic problems.

BERLIN, May 28--The United States, Britain and France called on the Soviet Union today to stop East German guards from firing into West Berlin and to take precautions to preclude further bloodshed along the Berlin wall.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI)--The Navy has installed a television camera and hydrophones on the ocean floor in the Florida Staits to study the activities of marine animals that interfere with sound detection equipment.

The Universal American Corporation announced yesterday that it would offer to purchase 100,000 shares of the common stock of the Bohn Aluminum and Brass Corporation at $37.50 a share. The offer will be good from Friday until 5 P.M. on June 15.

A man an dwoman were arrested by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday and charged with being involved in a series of jewel burgularies from several fashionable East Side apartments.

WASHINGTON, May 28-- The United States was reported today to have lost all confidence in Gen. Phoumi Nosavan, Defense Minister and Deputy Premier of the Royal Laotian Government, but officials continued to deny that pressure had been applied to oust him from the pro-Western regime.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., May 28--Ernst von Lengerke, a retired business man and widely known sprotsman and wildlife enthusiast, died yesterday in Dover General Hospital, after a brief illness. He was a resident of Stag Lake, Andover.
The fast-growing field of discount retailing, which has been hard-pressed to find management personnel, is trying a new approach by sending potential store managers to school.

At 10:55 last night, Stefan Redl's left hook cut through cigar smoke, Tony Fortunato ducked, a man yelled, "Mark him up, Steve--break his nose," a bell rang three times and St. Nicholas Arena ended its fiftysixth and final year as one of New York's great adult evening education centers.

Two Government witnesses, both lawyers, contradicted each other yesterday in the Federal Court trial of State Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh and two other men on charges of bribery in a bankruptcyfraud case.
The doctoral programs to be offered by the City University for the first time this fall will be on a university-wide basis, Dr. Mina Rees, Dean of Graduate Studies, announced yesterday.

PARIS, May 28--A French general disclosed tonight he was retiring from the army rather than pick the firing squad for the execution of a fellow general who served as second in command of the terrorist Secret Army Organization in Algeria.
LOS ANGELES, May 28--Officials have begun testing exhaust-control devises in the latest step in California's drive to curb automotive fumes.
DEVON, Pa., May 28--The Professional Horsemen's Association' Trophy at the sixtysixth annual Devon horse show was won tonight by Uncle Max.
Yesterday was a day of mob psychology in the stock market. Profits that had snowballed over the months melted away as if it were a hot July day.

The maple trees on Sedgwick Avenue between Van Cortlandt Avenue and West 238th Street and the wild cherry trees on Merritt Avenue between Light and East 233d Streets may mean very little to most New Yorkers, or even to the rest of the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) --New York led all cities in the nation in the number of person skilled in non-negligent manslaughter cases during the first three months of the year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

WESTVILLE, Conn., May 28 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Burnham of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Ann Burnham, to Ronald Lloyd Friedland. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Friedland of Maplewood, N.J.

SANTA CLARA, Calif., May 28--The Rev. Bernard R, Hub-' bard, scientist and explorer who was known as the Glacier Priest, died today of a stroke in his quarters at the University of Santa Clara. His age was 73. He had headed the university's Geology Department since 1926:
Mayor Wagner received yesterday the Distinguished Service Award of Dan Tallon Post No. 678 of the American Legion.

MADISON, Wis., May 28 (AP)--Gov. Gaylord Nelson announced his candidacy today for the Senate seat held since 1938 by Alexander Wiley. He asserted that the office required "more leadership and more imagination."

WASHINGTON, May 28-- The Labor Federation began today an attempt to mediate the dispute between the Seafarer's International Union and the National Maritime Union over which should represent the unlicensed seamen on the MooreMcCormack Lines' thirty-four Atlantic and Gulf coast ships.
LISBON, Portugal, May 28-- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar said today that both the United States and the Soviet Union were busily "banning wars that do not exist and stimulating those that do."
SAN FRANCTSCO, May 28 --"Smear," "smear tactics" and "who smeared you ?" became increasingly frequent allusions today as the California gubernatorial primary campaign entered its final full week.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 28 --Jim Turnesa and Mal Gruber of Ryewood won the Westchester County Golf Association's pro-amateur tournament today With a best ball 30, 35--65 at Rockrimmon Country Club.
Roy Hamey, the Yankee general manager, arrived here today to learn how things were going in these rather trying times for the world champions.
The two paramedics who jumped 1,000 feet into the Atlantic to aid Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter said yesterday that they would gladly leave earth-orbiting to someone else.

TORONTO, May 25 (Canadian Press)--Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., had consolidated dollar earnings in the year ended Dec. 31 of $16,797,000 (U.S.), or 97 cents a share, compared with $16,880,000 and 98 cents in 1960.
The mutual funds said they were doing yesterday what they had always promised to do in a disastrous market break--buy.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 28-- A fundamental disagreement has arisen between the United States and South Vietnam over the application of American aid to the counter-insurgency drive.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 28-- The Mayor of Saigon was asked today to rule on the morality of square dances sponsored by the United States Embassy.
Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, expressed opposition yesterday to a Congressional bill that would increase postal rates for newspapers and magazines.
A series of fourteen double bills of Warner Brothers films from the Nineteen Thirties will be presented for the next two weeks at the New Yorker Theatre, Broadway and Eightyeighth Street.

LAKE SUCCESS, L.I. May 28--Professional engineers at seven Long Island plants of the Sperry Gyroscope Company tonight rejected the International Union of Electrical Workers as their bargaining agent in a close vote.

CHICAGO, May 28 (UPI)-- Glen Hobbie shut out the Milwauke Braves for eight innings today, then survived a ninthinning rally to give the Chicago Cubs a 2-1 victory. It was Hobbies first triumph after six defeats.

Daniel R. and Herbert B. Platzner of the Platzner-Zuckerman Company, industrial realty investors, have contracted to buy the four-story industrial building at 401 East 163d Street, the Bronx. The property is being sold for all cash by Henry Hirschbein subject to a net lease of the building held by Mr. Hirschbein.
Two lawyers pleaded guilty yesterday to unlawfully soliciting clients, commonly known as ambulance chasing, and received six-month suspended sentences.
WASHINGTON, May 28-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk and the French Ambassador, Herve Alphand, met privately for two hours today in an effort to improve United StatesFrench relations.

TRENTON, N.J., May 28 (AP)--A reduction of $320,430 annually in rates of the Elizabethtown Gas Company of Elizabeth N.J., will become effective July 1, the State Public Utility Commission announced today.

GENEVA, May 28--The United States proposed today that all members of the United Nations undertake to aid space vehicles or astronauts in distress and to return to the launching countries any that are forced to land elsewhere.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 28 --Mr. and Mrs. William Thomas Welch of Garden City and Lexington, Ky., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Welch, to Richard Sheldon Tully, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Tully of Bronxville, N.Y.
MOSCOW, May 28--Premier Khrushchev acknowledged today that the United States had achieved "notable successes" in space but he challenged its claims to greatness in the kitchen.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 28--Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph A. Prosswimmer have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Prosswimmer, to Lawrence E. Conroy. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Conroy of Portland.

Allegheny Power System, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for twelve months ended April 30. Operating revenues rose to $168,356,139 from $158,597,135 a year ago. Net income of $23,035,012, equal to $2.47 a share, compared with $21,798,644, or $2.35 a share on fewer shares, in the twelve months ended April 30, 1961.
Walter R. Miller, president of the East Brooklyn Savings Bank, was elected president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce yesterday at the annual meeting at the St. George Hotel.
CHICAGO, May 28 (AP)-- There were only two small gains at the close of the Board of Trade today as grain prices turned sharply lower.
PARIS, May 28--Stock exchanges in Western Europe continued their downward movements today, partly in response to what has been happening in Wall Street.
Markets Commissioner Albert S. Pacetta said yesterday that he would propose stringent regulations to prevent the cheating of consumers by operators of cash registers in some stores and supermarkets.
The nation will observe Memorial Day tomorrow with a request from President Kennedy that Americans reserve an hour of their time to pray for a world of peace.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York announced yesterday that it expected its current fund-raising campaign to bring in more than $20,000,000 by the end of the fiscal year on June 30.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 28 (Reuters)--United States helicopters rushing Right-Wing Laotian troops to Houei Sai were fired on today from an outpost taken by pro-Communist forces, United States military sources reported tonight. There was no immediate report of any casualties.
Bert Lahr, the comedian, has established in a Federal court that an entertainer has a right to sue for damages for the unauthorized use of his style or vocal delivery.

PRINK HILL. THE deal with the Gulf Oil Corporation is off, Readers of this column on May 1 may recall that R. W. Maxwell, exploration manager for Gulf Oil, has proposed leasing my land for ten years to drill for "oil, gas, asphalt, sulphur and all other minerals and substances, similar and dissimilar," including diamonds and gold.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he was probably the Democrat most capable of defeating Governor Rockefeller in the state election this fall but that he still would not run.

TOKYO, May 28-Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin, the Soviet Union's first astronaut, said today that he had been in radio contact with the ground on his orbital flight except for a short time when he was near his landing.

A year ago, Abraham A. Ribicoff warned social workers that the nation's welfare program was "drifting." He told them last night that the course had shifted toward a positive program of public welfare.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Vice President Johnson wrote a "Dear Billie" letter to Billie Sol Estes before he took office.

WASHINGTON, May 28--The foreign policy of the Kennedy Administration, in several instances of which West New Guinea is the latest, has amended the finding in Proverbs XIII (15) that "the way of transgressors is hard." The amendment is that the United States will not make at all hard the way of transgressors to annexation by force when they wear the label of "neutrals" in the cold war.
The Canadian dollar closed at 9.1766 cents yesterday, un changed from Friday, on the New York foreign exchange market.

WHITE PLAINS, MAY 28-- Westchester County political leaders were linked to the awarding of lucrative concessions at Playland Amusement Park in Rye without competitive bidding today by witnesses at a public hearing in the County Office Building here.

RICHMOND, Va., May 28-- The engagement of Miss Barbara Thalhimer to Stanton L. Oppenheimer Jr. has been announced by Miss Thalhimer's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William B. Thalhimer Jr. The future bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Oppenheimer of New York.

MIAMI, May 28--Premier Fidel Castro has given the Cuban Committee for Liberation of Prisoners of War a week to pay the ransom of $2,500,000 it promised for the sixty ill and wounded prisoners who came to the United States in April.
The Lincoln Center Repertory Company decided yesterday not to await the completion of its permanent home, the $8,200,000 Vivian Beaumont Theatre.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) --The Supreme Court refused today to review the conviction of Dave Fass, a storekeeper of West New York, N.J., for violation of the New Jersey Sunday Closing Law.

RED BANK, N.J., May 28-- Mrs. Viola V. Jardine of 19 Alston Court, a water-colorist who had taken part in Monmouth County Republican activities, died Saturday ate Riverview Hospital. Her age was 78. She was the widow of Thomas V. Jardine.

Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes said last night the city's budget provided only $9,000,000 for traffic control, "its most serious problem," and allotted hundreds of millions to other city departments.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 28-- Walter P. Reuther suggested a five-point program of priorities for the nation today.

FRANKLIN, Tex., May 28 (AP)--The grand jury trying to decide whether the death of a Department of Agriculture official was murder or suicide accepted today a curtailed Government report on Billie Sol Estes' cotton allotment deals.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., May 28 --Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Henry Hamann have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joanna Foss Hamann, to Gordon Hutchins Shaw, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Keith Shaw Jr. of Concord, Mass.
Joseph Papp's Shakespearean troupe played in Central Park yesterday to a small but significant audience-the fund raisers who made free Shakespeare possible in New York.
Employment in New York State rose to 7,320,000 last month, for the highest April total in the state's history, Industrial Commissioner Martin P. Catherwood reported yesterday.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., May 28 (AP)--No one will be prosecuted for the salt poisoning of six infants at Binghamton General Hospital, authorities said today.

MADRID, May 28 (AP)-- A back-to-work movement in Spanish mines and factories expanded today in the wake of a charge by Generalissimo Francisco Franco that Soviet subversion and hot-headed Roman Catholic priests had played major roles in the strikes.

The last place ink a democracy to expect or tolerate restriction of the thinking process is in a university or a college. Yet the censorship of ideas in such educational institutions is not rare, as is evident from a report of the Committee on Civil Rights of the New York County Lawyers'
BEDFORD, N.Y., May 28-- Mrs. Aida de Acosta Breckinridge, executive director of the Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration for its first ten years, died yesterday in her home on Baldwin Road. Her age was 80.
The game of billiards to many people conjures up images of dimly-lit pool rooms inhabited by the inevitable blue-jawed pool sharks.

The State Supreme Court trial of John Henry Faulk's "blacklisting" suit was interrupted at the start of its sixth week yesterday while the judge told the jury that the defendants must try to prove the truth of a publication already ruled libelous.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The American labor movement began a fund-raising campaign today to help the Algerian labor movement.
The appointment of Dr. Willard W. Blaesser as dean of students at City College was announced yesterday by Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of the college.
ALBANY, May 28--A preliminary study of the high cates that a high percentage of those who quit school have a family history of either crime or welfare dependency.

Production of steel eased still further last week. The week before tonnage had fallen below 60 per cent of capacity for the first time in more than a year, to an operating rate of 57 per cent. In the latest week, the eighth in succession in which there was a week-to-week decline, the rate fell to 56.5 per cent.
RICHMOND, Va., May 28 (UPI)--Two Negroes graduating from the Virginia School of Medicine have been excluded from term-end social activities because of "traditions," a faculty member said today.

LOS ANGELES, May 28-- The ticker got so far behind on New York Stock Exchange quotations today that the Pacific Coast Stock Exchange closed, two hours later, without knowing the closing prices in New York.
Shares on the New York Stock Exchange lost $20,800,000,000 of values yesterday in the widest one-day drop since 1929.
PITTSBURGH, May 28 (AP) --Harvey Haddix limited the St. Louis Cardinals to six hits and scored two runs himself tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Cardinals, 3-1.

KANSAS CITY, May 28-- The Yankees' hopes of repairing their fortunes at the expense of the Kansas City Athletics ended in a washout tonight when rain, after two stabs, succeeded in cutting short the opener of a two-game series.

No statesman today plays his cards closer to his chest than Generalissimo Franco. A few days ago he made his first public reference to the strikes that have been plaguing Spain for an astonishing six weeks. Nothing the Caudillo said sheds any light on the situation in Spain or on his plans for the present or future.
MOSCOW, May 28--The Soviet Union announced today the launching of the fifth instrumented satellite in its current space exploration program.
The Medical Society of the County of New York reaffirmed its opposition to the King-Anderson bill on medical care for the aged in a resolution at it annual meeting last night.
Five men, including a stockbroker and a banker, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges involving a scheme in which investors lost $1,300,000.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 28 (AP)--Miss Hope Littleton of Cheverly, Md., a secretary at the Navy's Bureau of Ships in Washington, was named today as the Naval Academy's color girl for June week exercises, which begin Friday.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 28 (AP)--Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said tonight that the market drop in no way approached a calamity.
The accelerating tempo of trans-Atlantic passenger shipping brought five ocean liners and 3,000 inbound passengers to docks on the upper West Side yesterday.

Four men have been named co-chairmen of the Greater New York Anti-Communism Rally to be held in Madison Square Garden on June 28. The rally will be under the sponsorship of Dr. Fred C. Schwarz's Chirstian Anti-Communism Crusade.

Opening dates for the program of free attractions to be given at the Kate Wollman Rink in Prospect Park were announced yesterday by Kenneth N. Whitlock, founder and executive producer. The series will begin July 8 with a Civil War Centennial presentation.
Investors are puzzled and confused over the market's drastic declines in recent days. As a result, many have sold part of their holdings in the last week or so while others are standing pat.

Cotton futures were 5 to 30 cents a bale off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The market opened quiet, with no sales made on the opening call, and later prices held a narrow range, 10 cents up to 25 cents a bale off. The break in the stock market seemed to check interest somewhat.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 28 --The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed a complaint in Federal District Court today alleging segregation in Rochester public schools. The complaint listed white families among its sponsors.
The power of mass transportation to shape the character of metropolitan areas was stressed here yesterday at an all-day forum attended by 150 planning and transit representatives:
WASHINGTGN, May 28--A relatively obscure House subcommittee began peeking into the nation's grain storage bins six years ago and concluded that their administration left something to be desired.

LONDON, May 28 AP1-- Terry Downes of Britain, a former co-holder of the world middleweight title, has a fractured left hand and will be unable to box Sugar Ray Robinson of New York in London June 26, Downes' manager, Sam Burns, said today.

In a move designed to change the distribution pattern for motion pictures in the New York area, United Artists yeterday announced plans to open its future productions in more than ten suburban theatres simultaneously with their Broadway and East Side premieres.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 28 --The Suffolk Board of Supervisors appropriated $3,385,000 today for new construction and the expansion of existing countty buildings.
LONDON, May 28--Prices continued to decline on the stock market today in the face of pessimistic news from the board rooms.

MANCHESTER, England, May 28 (Reuters)--Brian Statham of Lancashire rocked the touring Pakistan Cricket team by taking five wickets for 54 runs today at Old Trafford. The Pakistanis were dismissed for 260.
LUXEMBOURG, May 28 (UPI)--The European Coal and Steel Community Authority announced declines in both coal and iron ore production during April.
MOSCOW, May 28--Benny Goodman and his nineteen-piece orchestra arrived here today for a six-week tour of the Soviet Union under a cultural-exchange agreement with the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 28-- The Government's short term borrowing costs declined fractionally on ninety-one day and 182-day treasury bills marketed this week.

CATHERINE and Sam Ogust cannot offer a woman an island as a refuge from summer heat, but in their new shop they are doing their best to bring a bit of Polynesia to the United States. For several years the couple have run the Penthouse Gallery, which carries oriental fashions.

The ticker tape made its own headlines yesterday for anyone who could read the symbols, and there were plenty of sadhearted readers. T (for American Telephone) crossed the tape at 100 on a hundred-share trade. In other transactions, it sold even lower. It was down more than eleven points.
A DAY Camp where octogenarians go swimming and nonagenarians folk dance and do calisthenics will soon begin its second season in Mount Kisco, N.Y.
PIERMONT, N. Y., May 28 --The Rev. Albert Ohse, who retired three years ago as rector of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church in Sparkill, died last night in his home on Route 9W. His age was 68,
The over-the-counter market, just like the market for listed stocks, yesterday took one of its worst trouncings in years.

Committee members have been announced for the twelfth annual Belmont Ball, to be held in the Man o' War Room of the Aqueduct Racetrack on June 8. For the third successive year United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, Inc., and the National Museum of Racing at Saratoga Springs, N.Y., will benefit from the event.
HONOLULU, May 28 (UPI)--Don Newcombe, the former major league pitching star, signed today to hurl for the Chunichi Dragons of Japan's professional Central, League.

"Most of our calls tomorrow will be in two directions--to out-of-town finance companies and factors and to non-purpose borrowers," a Wall Street banker said yesterday after one of the biggest selling waves in stock-market history.
Post position No. 9, a starting slot in the second tier, will have little adverse effect on Lehigh Hanover in the William H. Cane Pace Thursday night at Yonkers Raceway.
PARIS, May 28 (AP)--Topseeded Rod Laver and the American doubles team of Jon Douglas and Frank Froehling won today in a rain-shortened program at the French tennis championships.

PARIS, May 28--When Laszlo Papp of Hungary won the European middleweight boxing championship at Vienna twelve days ago, he cried from the ring: "My real career starts today." Then he went home to Budapest and sent notices to prominent bosing promoters here and else
Roosevelt Brown, a sixtime all-pro tackle, signed yesterday for his ninth National Football League season with the New York Giants.
The establishment of two additional day schools for maladjusted boys has been recommended by Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools.
CINCINNATI, May 28 (AP ) --Joey Jay knocked in four runs with two singles and a hommer tonight and put down a last-ditch stand by the Houston Colt '45s as the Cincinnati Reds scored a 9-6 victory.

WASHINGTON, May 28-- House investigators disclosed today that an official of the Department of Agriculture questioned Billie Sol Estes' "heavy indebtedness" two years ago in connection with Federal bonding of his grain storage operations.

Malcolm Scott Carpenter is being honored in Boulder, Colo., not merely because he was born in Boulder, but because the people of Boulder, as of other American cities, respect a man who can do any useful thing he sets out to do. Mr. Carpenter is in the tradition of the pioneers of a century ago who scrawled on the canvas sides of their prairie schooners the motto, "Pike's Peak or Bust," and hardly ever busted.

Shortly after five o'clock on an average day most employes of brokerage firms have joined the surging and amorphous crowds of homeward-bound subway strap hangers. Yesterday was somewhat different although--thanks to this mechanical age--not as different as in 1929.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) --The National Labor Relations Board ruled 3 to 2 today that it would deny a petition for a bargaining right election by either party to a labor contract during the term of the contract.
The Kingdom of Norway is looking to Wall Street for $25,000,000.
MOSCOW, May 28--The Soviet Foreign Ministry announced today the release of a West German couple sentenced last November to prison terms on espionage charges.
CHICAGO, May 29 (AP)-- Grain futures were traded over a broad range today and finished strong to easier on the Board of Trade after pulling out of an early sharp setback.
Final plans for the proposed twenty-block $180,000,000 West Side Urban Renewal project adjacent to Central Park were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

PARIS, May 29--The SEATO Alliance, originally patched together as a device to prevent communism from overrunning Southeast Asia, is now falling apart. Southeast Asia is not going to disintegrate perforce but, if it is saved, it will be saved by the U.S. and not by SEATO.
Cotton futures were unchanged to 50 cents a bale off yesterday no the New York Cotton Exchange.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI)--Republicans renewed attempts today to blame President Kennedy for the stock market decline. They said in effect that he had persecuted business.

SEATTLE, May 29--On the face of it, Seattle would appear to be an unlikely locale for a festival devoted to the music of Anton von Webern. The composer's native Vienna, or avant-garde musical centers like Cologne, Donauef Chingen or the electronic music laboratory of Columbia University are the places that might spring to mind.
LUBBOCK, Tex., May 29--In the heart of the West Texas cotton and grain country and on the northern fringes of the oil country, brokerage houses are packed, but there is little selling of stocks.
A LIFETIME fisherman of the Battenkill--a river shared by New York and Vermont--sat in a restaurant near Arlington, Vt., a few days ago and talked like a bitter man.

THE audience at Carnegie Hall last night for the Project Hope benefit was the beneficiary of some spectacular and beautiful musicmaking. It is to be regretted that the hall was only half full, because of the worthiness of the cause and the high level of artistry displayed.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)--The White House announced today the appointment of Lieut. Gen. John K. Gerhart as chief of the North American Air Defense Command.

The celebrated stock option plans of American Telephone and Telegraph Company and International business Machines, providing a stake in the business for everyone from president to telephone operator, have built-in protection against losses.

TODAY'S fare in the Eastern States Championships, being played at the StatlerHilton Hotel, is a two-session contest for mixed teams-offour. In this class of competition each pair must consist of one man and one woman. The two sessions will begin at 1 and 7 P.M.
Following the pattern set by the stock market, commodity futures fell sharply in early trading, but rallied to close near the highs of the day in activity on the New York markets yesterday.

PARIS, May 29 (UPI)-- Neale Fraser and Roy Emerson joined a fellow Australian, Rod Laver, in the men's singles semi-finals today and Australia also placed Margaret Smith and Leslie Turner in the women's semi-finals of the French tennis tournament.
PARIS, May 29--A gas and electricity strike reduced power output in France by 65 per cent today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 29 (AP)--Two House-approved bills to reapportion the Maryland Legislature were cleared by a Senate committee tonight. They included controversial amendments that seemed certain to provoke bitter floor fights.
WASHINGTON, May 29-- President Kennedy proposed to Congress today a program of tax incentives to encourage small and medium-size donations to finance Presidential election campaigns.

TOKYO. THERE is probably no city in the world today with a more fascinating and varied cuisine than Tokyo. In the Imperial, perhaps the city's most famous hotel, guests can dine on smorgasbord or sukiyaki.

FRANKLIN, Tex., May 29 (AP)--United States Attorney Harold B. Sanders turned, over a full report on Billie Sol Estes' cotton dealings today to State District Judge John M. Barron. He said the judge could give the report to a Robertson County grand jury at his discretion.

DETROIT, May 29 (UPI)-- The Detroit Tigers collected fifteen hits, including four home runs, to back up Don Mossi's seven-hit pitching today in a 12-4 victory over the Baltimore Orioles. The homers by Dick Brown, Rocky Colavito, Norm Cash and Chico Fernandez enabled the Tigers to win their third straight game and ninth in their last eleven.

DEVON, Pa., May 29--Grey Aero, the 1961 New York National champion, leaped into open jumper contention in the sixty-sixth annual Devon Horse Show tonight when the gray gelding took the sweepstake event.

The two most renowned commemorative addresses in history are no doubt that ascribed to Pericles, nearly twenty-three centuries ago, speaking over the dead of the first war with Sparta, and Abraham Lincoln's at Gettysburg.

MANCHESTER, England, May 29 (Reuters)--Despite a bright opening stand of 110 runs between Ijaz Butt and Imtiaz Ahmed for the Pakistanis, the cricket tourists' game against Lancashire here today fizzled into a tame draw.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29-- A complete revision of the record book may be necessary after tomorrow's classic 500-mile race on the two-and-a-half-mile Indianapolis Speedway. Such a prediction was made this afternoon during the traditional
TELEVISION took another giant step toward ma turity last night, as Channel 5's "Festival of Performing Arts" devoted its final musical program to the artistry of Pablo Casals.
AN expert recently reviewed some of the contradictory advice on child-rearing with which parents have been beseiged during the last five decades and came up with advice of his own:
Dr. C. Frederick Pertsch, the city's Deputy Superintendent of Schools for instructional affairs, said yesterday he would retire next Feb. 1.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 29 (AP)--The world soccer championship opens tomorrow, with Brazil favored to retain the crown it won in 1958.

Orange County, Calif., borrowed $8,620,000 for flood control yesterday at 3.39 per cent. The money was raised through a sale of serial bonds due 1964 to 1996 to Security First National Bank and associates. The group reoffered the bonds to yield 1.90 to 3.75 per cent.
CHICAGO, May 29 (AP )-- John (Buck) O'Neil was signed as a Chicago Cub coach today, becoming the first Negro to hold such a position in the major leagues.

LISBON, Portugal, May 29 The Portuguese Communist party recently began an active campaign to assume the leadership of various political groups opposed to the thirty-four-yearold regime of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar.

SO, you would like to find another really readable and entertaining novel? You realize, of course, that you're being pret ty unreasonable? Several such novels have been published this year and you ought to be grateful for those. But if you insist and refuse to read another dreary, solemn, symbolical or sensational novel I thinly I can...

WASHINGTON, May 29-- The Communications Workers of America announced today that it had reached agreement at Cleveland with the Ohio Bell Telephone Company on wage increases averaging 9.38 cents an hour for the 15,500 employes of the company represented by the union.
The nation's war dead will be honored today with a series of ceremonies and parades across the land.

ALGIERS, May 29--A spokesman for the Algerian nationalists in Algeria charged today that the Right-wing Secret Army Organization was seeking a way out of "its impasse" through "any sort of accord with the National Liberation Front."

WASHINGTON, May 29-- House investigators were told today that a Texas accountant had destroyed the working papers from which he prepared a financial statement to enable Billie Sol Estes to remain eligible for the storage of Government-owned grain.
KANSAS CITY, May 29-- The Yankees admittedly are hurt by the absence of Mickey Mantle. And today they fairly groaned with the pain of it as they bowed to the Kansas City Athletics, 2 to 1.

WALTER ALSTON and his Dodgers were mighty glad to see New York yesterday morning. It was not nostalgia that made them so eager. It was the prospect of getting some sleep. The refugees from Brooklyn had been riding the transcontinental airlines all night after playing a floodlight exhibition game--of all things--in far away Spokane--of all places.
Four window cleaners lost their lives early yesterday when their scaffold plunged nineteen floors down the side of the Equitable Building.
GENEVA, May 29--The Soviet Union reneged today on a five-day-old agreement with the United States on a declaration condemning war propaganda.
Project Fishbowl, to begin in about two days, will probably be the most widely observed scientific experiment in history.
A vice president of the board of trustees of Beth-El Hospital has resigned, accusing the struck nonprofit institution in Brooklyn of pursuing "antilabor policies."

The University of Washington's undefeated varsity eight and Pennsylvania and Cornell, the two most favored Eastern crews, will row in close proximity in the sixtieth regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association. The races will be held June 16 on Onondaga Lake at Syracuse.
WASHINGTON, May 29-- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved unanimously today the modified plan for delegating some of its duties to give it more time for policy matters.

Negotiations for the release of prisoners captured in last year's invasion of Cuba remain open and the terms unchanged, the Cuban Families Committee for Liberation of Prisoners of War said here yesterday.

The Vietnam International Control Commission's finding that North Vietnam is guilty of subversion and covert aggression against South Vietnam has caused an outburst of indignation in Hanoi and Peiping.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 29--The chief of the South Vietnamese General Staff said today that the Vietnamese Air Force had bombed the headquarters of Nguyen Don. "general" of the Communist guerrilla forces in the central highlands.

WASHINGTON, May 29 AP) --An Agriculture Department spokesman said today the head of the South Dakota Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Office and a member of the State Stabilization and Conservation Committee had resigned under pressure brought by the department.

CENTERVILLE, Iowa, May 29 (UPI)--One of the forty-five persons who plunged to death in an explosion-ripped Continental Airlines jet a week ago was disclosed today to have been facing an armed-robbery charge in Kansas City.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., May 29 --President Kennedy celebrated his forty-fifth birthday tonight at a quiet family dinner party after a busy day considering the problems of the stock market, defense and campaign spending.
CONAKRY, Guinea, May 22 --West Germany, which is making a major effort in Guinea, exported more goods to Guinea in 1961 than any other Western nation.

NEW ORLEANS, May 29 (AP)--A New Orleans investment house offered today to buy a majority of the stock of the Times-Picayune Publishing Company in behalf of Samuel I. Newhouse, publisher of a group of newspapers.

The "most encouraging' recent development in the promotion of waterfront safety has been the growing recognition that labor's responsibility in preventing accidents is as great as management's, Alexander P. Chopin, chairman of the New York Shipping Association, declared yesterday.
Stocks made a strong recovery yesterday, reversing the downward trend of six successive days and wiping out 60 per cent of the Monday losses, which were the greatest since 1929.
NEW DELHI, India, May 29--The "cold war" between Communist China and India brought trade between the two countries through Tibet to a virtual end today.
ROME, May 29--Premier Amintore Fanfani today filled two vacancies in his threemonth-old Cabinet.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 29--The Israeli Cabinet met in a special session this afternoon to discuss the Supreme Court's rejection of Adolf Eichmann's appeal against his death sentence.
A 26-year-old Scottish carpenter who flew to Canada two years ago seeking a new life flew home to Scotland last night in a coma from which he may never recover.

No share of listed stock ever goes to bed an orphan; for every seller there must be a buyer--instantly. Any examination of who lost and who gained --or hopes to gain--in a debacle like that of Monday and yesterday morning must consider one side as well as the other.

The celebrated Vienna State Opera is being invited to appear at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts during the New York World's Fair in 1964.

In preparation for further talks with Soviet Russia, Secretary Rusk is trying to restore a semblance of a united Western front that now appears to be in greater "disarray" than ever. He seeks to mediate between the European Economic Community, Britain, the Commonwealth and the neutrals.
WASHINGTON, May 29--President Kennedy was 45 today, just old enough to be a little disillusioned but not yet old enough to be either discouraged or serene.

The City Council adopted a record expense budget of $2,784,731,222 yesterday for the fiscal veer starting July 1.
President Kennedy, whose wealth is estimated in the millions of dollars, is one of seven beneficiaries of two irrevocable multimillion-dollar trust funds established by his family in 1926 and 1936.

Investors Stock Fund, Inc., had sizable gains in net assets and shares outstanding for the six months ended April 30, according to the semi-annual report released yesterday. Net assets rose to $993,527,761 from $978,730,731 on Oct. 31, 1961, end of the fiscal year.
The strike of the Seafarers International Union against Moore-McCormack Lines yesterday forced the luxury liner Brasil to cancel a cruise.

The ups and downs of Wall Street led broadcasters to deploy their news staffs on the economic beat yesterday.

YONKERS, Wednesday, May 30--Several hundred spectators staged a riot last night at Yonkers Raceway. One man was injured when he was struck by the starting gate as he walked out on the track. Four persons including the injured man, were arrested.

The 663 Fifth Avenue Service Corporation, which provides stenographic, telephone and other office services for small tenants and representatives of large corporations, has leased a floor in 663 Fifth Avenue near Fifty-third Street. Paul Bresalier of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., was the broker in the lease.
ROME, May 29--Attilio Piccioni, who was named Foreign Minister of Italy today, is that comparative Italian rarity, a self-made man.
Corlears Junior High School on the lower East Side held its fourth annual art festival yesterday in the school's sundrenched playground.

WASHINGTON, May 29-- United States labor, business and Government will start an extensive program next month to assist the trade unions of Latin America.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29-- What looked like the nation's biggest picnic began on the streets of Indianapolis today. Thousands were enjoying a long wait in parked automobiles outside the Speedway grounds.

Harold S. Prince, sponsor of two current hits, "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum" and "Take Her, She's Mine," intends to continue as a director. Early this year he made his directorial debut when he was called in to whip "A Family Affair" into shape for another management.

WASHINGTON, May 29--President Kennedy conferred today with economic officials of the Federal Government about the stock market and decided that no special action by the Government was called for at this time.

A survival of the Old West passed away yesterday when former Senator Henry Fountain Ashurst of Arizona died at the age of 87. Senator Ashurst went to the Senate in 1912 immediately after the admission of Arizona as a state; and along with him to Washington went Arizona's new Representative Carl Hayden today the dean of the Senate.
LONDON, May 31--The Bank of England announced today the release of one-third of the special deposits it has required English clearing and Scottish banks to hold.
Prices of high-grade debt securities fluctuated narrowly yesterday as the bond market passed a day of comparative inactivity.
NEW DELHI, India, May 31 Defense Minister V.K. Krishna Menon acknowledged today for the first time that India was considering purchasing supersonic MIG jet fighters from the Soviet Union.
PARIS, May 31 (AP) AllAustralian finals in men's and women's singles were assured today although darkness halted a match between Neale Fraser and Rod Laver in the French tennis championships.
Film executives, always alert to the effects of publicity on the public image of a movie star, recently started a quiet test of the box-office status of Elizabeth Taylor.

A mother of three children was advised yesterday that she had a legal right to seek $2,000 in damages because her home had been destroyed by fire while two Long Island volunteer fire departments argued over jurisdiction.

LUBBOCK, Tex., May 31 (UPI) Coleman McSpadden, an indicted associate of Billie Sol Estes, invoked the fifth amendment ninety-four times today at a Federal Court hearing attended by most of his 750 creditors.
BUENOS AIRES, May 31? Argentina's Central Bank declared today in its annual report that the country now had no other choice than to "pause" in its ambitious economic development program.

The postal rate bill which has passed the House of Representatives and is now before the Senate deserves broader public discussion than it has received to date. There is little argument about the need to increase postal rates to some extent and thus to reduce the Post Office Department's persistent and large deficit. But there are at least two features of the legislation which passed the House last January that deserve reconsideration.

While most women are concentrating on their summer wardrobes, America's designers are busy showing fall clothes. These collections, this country's equivalent of the Paris openings in July, will continue through the middle of June. They attract store executives and buyers from all over the country to Seventh Avenue, New York's...
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 31 Parliament approved a law last night empowering the Minister of Information to close for five days any newspaper deemed to have libeled a foreign chief of state.

OTTAWA, May 31 (Canadian Press) An 11 per cent gain in exports was offset by a 15.2 per cent rise in imports to give Canada a $72,900,000 trade deficit in the first quarter of 1962, against $17,500,000 in 1961.
MEMPHIS, May 31 (Ap) Arnold Palmer, the favorite, slipped well back in the pack that trailed Gay Brewer Jr. today in the opening round of the $40,000 Memphis open golf tournament.

THE basic material of "The Cats' Pajamas," the new revue with The Stewed Prunes, more formally known as Richard Libertini and MacIntyre Dixon, is rather nebulous if not intangible. Yet, it keeps you chuckling, smirking or tittering.

At long last the Senate will consider a bill to correct a glaring inequity in the 1958 Military Pay Act, which provided less retirement pay for personnel retired prior to 1958 and more for those who retired afterward.

WASHINGTON, May 31 President Kennedy announced today a $12,600,000 mass social experiment on the Lower East Side of New York. It is part of a program designed to strike eventually at the roots of the national juvenile delinquency problem.

GENEVA, May 31 Harry J. Anslinger, United States Narcotics Commissioner, said here today that Communist China and Cuba were obtaining badly needed foreign currency by traffic in narcotics. The Chinese Communists are also using narcotics for subversive purposes, he said at a news conference.
LONDON, May 31 The way is open for negotiation of a solution of the problem of Britain's entry into the European Economic Community, Edward Heath told the House of Commons today.

WHITE PLAINS, May 31 Representative Edwin B. Dooley testified today that the County Executive of Westchester was a "profound fabricator" and a "great dissimulator." He said later that he considered a dissimulator a person who hid under false appearances.
WASHINGTON, May 31 The Pentagon is studying whether certain troop units can be rotated in Europe on short tours without their families, Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today.
Despite strong volume in sugar and cocoa futures, commodities were generally quiet in narrow trading on the New York markets yesterday as most traders concentrated on the rising stock market.
Most over-the-counter houses that make markets in stocks for their own accounts were especially hard hit by Monday's sharp drop.

United Shareowners of America, a non-profit stockholder group, spoke out about the stock market yesterday through two of its officials. Charles E. Wilson, former chairman of General Electric Company, said the stock market "acted like a man who gets on the golf course and gets a heart attack." The patient recovers, he said, but needs some "basic help."
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 31 (AP) The Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and Hungary gained narrow victories today as the first round ended in the World Soccer Cup championships.
The Astor Hotel was accused in State Supreme Court yesterday of helping itself to sixtyfive pounds of caviar from the private stock of the Shah of Iran.

ROME, May 31 President Guido Carli of the Bank of Italy urged yesterday the abandonment of Government restrictions on the freedom of Italian citizens and foreign residents to invest in foreign stock markets.
Organization plans and the initial faculty for what it is hoped will be one of the world's foremost biological research institutes were announced yesterday.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday its plans for the first distribution of its holdings of General Motors Corporation stock under the court order earlier this year that ended the Government's thirteen-year antitrust suit against the $4,500,000,000 chemical company.

WASHINGTON, May 31 A New Orleans marching band, led by a sashaying marshal resplendent in glittering red and pink ribbons, swung past the White House this morning blaring out "When the Saints Come Marching In" to mark the opening of the First International Jazz Festival.

SURBITON, England, May 31 (AP) Carole Caldwell, 18year-old tennis player from Santa Monica, Calif., downed Ethne Green of New Zealand, 6 3, 6 4, today in the quarter-finals of the Surbiton tournament.
The Board of Education agreed last night to accept $100,000 in restitution from six plumbing contractors under indictment for allegedly defrauding the school system.
MIAMI, May 30 An increase in sabotage in Cuba is believed to be an important factor in the accelerated decline of the island's economy during the last few months.
The Board of Education agreed last night to accept $100,000 in restitution from six plumbing contractors under indictment for allegedly defrauding the school system.
MIAMI, May 30 An increase in sabotage in Cuba is believed to be an important factor in the accelerated decline of the island's economy during the last few months.
WASHINGTON, May 31 The nation's employment situation improved slightly in May.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 31 Here among the highestpriced actors in the world, a theatre sponsored by Actors Equity has not received financial support from one movie or television star.
YONKERS, May 31 Ranger Knight, with Clint Hodgins whipping him home, stormed through the stretch for a goingaway triumph in the $117,540 Cane Pace tonight at Yorkers Raceway.
WASHINGTON, May 31 The discovery of a chemical agent in normal tissue that inhibits the growth of healthy cells, and certain cancers, was reported at a scientific meeting here today.
Social work is not dealing effectively with some of the major problems of the day because it has its own problems, a representative of the Ford Foundation said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 31 The Federal Reserve Board today reported the condition statement of weekly reporting showed the following principal changes for the week ended May 23:
GREENWOOD, Miss., May 30 The Billie Sol Estes case, a liability for the Kennedy Administration nationally, has become its chief asset here in a key Congressional race.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 31 Communist guerrillas raided a leprosarium in the central highlands last night and kidnapped three American missionaries.

WASHINGTON, May 31 The White House said today that it had canceled its subscriptions to The New York Herald Tribune to "diversify" President Kennedy's reading and not because of any "argument" with that paper.

Decrescit studium linguae Latinae in ludis publicis Novi Eboraci. Alibi tamen in patria nostra paulo in ludis superioribus crescit. Quid accidit urbi nostrae? Cur aegrotavit hoc studium urbe in nostra?

ALGIERS, May 31 As terrorism here fell well below the daily level of the last two weeks, three steps were taken today in the direction of reconciling the European and Moslem communities of this violent land.

AMATEUR and professional fishermen are now pulling in big hauls of blowfish from the waters off Long Island. Not many years ago, that fish would have been tossed back into the water as unfit for eating. However, New Yorkers have come to appreciate its firm, white flesh.
CHICAGO, May 31 (UPI) Floyd Patterson will defend his world heavyweight championship against Sonny Liston Sept. 25 in Comiskey Park, home of the Chicago White Sox, it was announced today.
A substantial tightening of teacher-training standards for New York State's elementary schools was announced by the Board of Regents yesterday.
LONDON, May 31 A notebook containing some unpublished poetry by Percy Bysshe Shelley will be sold here at auction July 2.
Fifteen years of flight ended for Adolf Eichmann near Buenos Aires on May 11, 1960, when he was seized by Israeli undercover "volunteers."
The mutual funds appraised their busiest week ever yesterday and liked what they saw.
Two policemen were hurt yesterday when a taxi stolen by a woman passenger rammed their radio car in a Harlem chase.

GENEVA, June 1 (AP)--The Soviet Union has promised not to increase its lead and zinc exports to the West this year--to help the world major producers ease the mar ket glut. Soviet delegate Sergei Shivaev told a meeting of the twenty-three-nation lead and zinc study group yesterday that the Soviet foreign trade organization would not increase its exports of the two metals to the West above the 1961 level.

CHICAGO, June 1 (AP)-- Wheat futures extended their unusual harvest-time advance on the Board of Trade today with gains running to a cent a bushel. Other grains lost further ground in the final munutes and finished weak. Soybeans closed mixed with new-crop months firm.
Mrs. Florence Krasme Shapera of 737 Park Avenue, the wife of Archie Shapera, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. Her age was 57.
Horse racing shifted from frenetic Aqueduct to idyllic Belmont yesterday. The difference was only a few miles and a few minutes as the railbird flies, but the change was dramatic.
CHICAGO, June 1--Albert Beck, Professor of Music at Concordia Teachers College in River Forest, was found dead, apparently of natural causes, in his apartment yesterday. He was 68 years old.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., June 1--The anxieties of Wall Street were almost--but not entirely --forgotten at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, where members of the Bond Club of New York today celebrated their annual field day.
WASHINGTON, June 1--Following is the text of a report by the Federal Radiation Council, on the health implications of fall-out from nuclear weapons testing through last year:

The Rev. Walter E. Besiegel of 120 Ramble Road, Great Kills, S.I., former president of the Staten Island Council of Boy Scouts, died Thursday of a heart attack in Utica, N.Y., where he was serving as a supply pastor. He was 76 years old.
A cooperative development in Rego Park, Queens, contains some one-bedroom apartments with space that can be converted to a second bedroom to meet the possible needs of a growing young family.

Mrs. Eva Greenstein Newman, president of Eva Hat Shop, 796 Madison Avenue, a women's hat designer, died Thursday in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 61 years old and lived at 203 West Eighty-first Street.

Americans are too pessimistic about the state of the world, and their own achievements in it, Harlan Cleveland, Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, said here yesterday.
John M. Bailey, the Democratic national chairman, suggested last night that Governor Rockefeller had shown racial prejudice in opposing a Federal department of urban affairs.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 1-- National leaders of the American Veterans Committee urged President Kennedy today to issue a new Emancipation Proclamation on Jan. 1, 1963, the 100th anniversary of President Lincoln's historic proclamation.

PATERSON, N.J., June 1-- The head bookkeeper in the Clifton Department of Public Works, who is also the Passaic County American Legion Commander, has been indicted on a charge of having forged twentynine payroll checks.
BERLIN, June 1 (AP)--East German border guards shot and wounded a teen-age West Berlin girl on the border tonight, the West Berlin police reported.
Last month 14,093 pints of blood were given to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. This compares with 12,596 in April, and 13,513 in May, 1961.

James J. Tormey urged yesterday, in response to Attorney General Robert K. Kennedy's application for orders to ten alleged Communist party members to register under the McCarran Act, that citizens write or wire the President and Attorney General demanding a stop to such proceedings.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 1--S. Leon Schinasi, president of a business-management and brokerage concern at 120 Central Park South in New York, died of a heart attack today at his summer home. He was 34 years old.

CHICAGO, June 1--Dr. Robert A. Arens, who established the X-ray department at Michael Reese Hospital and was chief radiologist there for forty years until he retired in 1955, died yesterday in Downey Veterans Hospital. He was 72 years old.
Twenty-five per cent of New York City families seeking middle-income apartments may move to the suburbs within two years, a survey has indicated.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., June 1 (AP)--Francis V. du Pont, who died in Baltimore on May 20, provided in his will for the Sea Scouts and an annual Independence Day celebration in Cambridge.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 10 cents off to 15 cents a bale up yesterday.
DELAWARE, Ohio, June 1-- Dr. Elden T. Smith was named president of Ohio Wesleyan University today.

Dr. William Mather Lamson of 555 East Ninth Street, Brooklyn, who retired in 1941 as an engineer of the Board of Water Supply, died on Wednesday in the home of a daughter, Mrs. Ruth Lines, in Manhasset, L.I. He was 91 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 1-- Dutch and Indonesian diplomats may meet here again within a week or ten days to complete preliminary talks on a settlement of their countries' dispute over Netherlands New Guinea.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) --The Navy said today that one of its patrol planes photographed a Soviet merchant ship on May 16, but that this occurred outside Cuban territorial waters.

HONOLULU, June 1 (UPI) --The planned explosion early tomorrow of the United States' first rocket-borne high-altitude nuclear bombs over Johnston Island in the Pacific touched off protests around the world today and a scramble for high ground spectator seats in Hawaii.

The Allied Stores Corporation, which includes Stern's and Gertz in its chain of more than seventy-five stores, reported yesterday increased sales and earnings for the three and twelve months ended on April 30.
Yesterday wasn't the hottest June 1 in recent history, but it was hot enough to soften asphalt and dampen brows.
WASHINGTON, June 1--The District of Columbia got the news today that stand-up drinking will be legal here in another month.

The New York Federation of Reform Synagogues will mark its twentieth anniversary Monday at the annual meeting of its Assembly of Delegates. The dinner meeting will be held at 7 P.M. in the House of Living Judaism, 838 Fifth Avenue.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 1 --Officials here agreed today to change the site of a projected low-cost housing development after the State Division of Housing charged that the project would have been segregated.
Whey the policy-making board of the National Council of Churches convenes here next Thursday it will be asked to authorize a nation-wide study conference on issues of church and state.
Stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange closed sharply lower last month although closing prices were well above the low levels of the month.
American Export Lines increased the size of its cargo fleet yesterday by 33 per cent in a series of transactions that also added some $4,000,000 to the company's annual subsidy earnings.
EASTON, Pa., June 1--Edward J. Fox Jr., an Easton lawyer and past president of the Pennsylvania Bar Association, died last night at Sea Island, Ga. He was 63 years old.
Indianapolis, Ind., is planning the sale of bond issues totaling $8,100,000 on June 21.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 1 --One of the most important phases of thoroughbred horse racing, and one seldom seen by the public, is the expert observation of horses in training.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy yesterday praised ahe members of the force who solved the case of the two detectives slain by hold-up men in Brooklyn. But he rebuked those who had forced the prisoners to be photographed.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) --The Government said today that it would seek to prosecute again six men whose contemptof-Congress convictions were reversed by the Supreme Court two weeks ago.
LONDON, June 1 (Reuters)-- Portugal will file a request Monday for negotiations toward a link with the European Economic Community, a Portuguese Embassy spokesman said tonight.

Dr. W.J. Kolff and his collaborators in Cleveland have succeeded in fashioning a plastic device driven by compressed air which has kept dogs alive and alert for more than a day. Dr. Kolff has suggested that we begin thinking about the possibilities of replacing defective hearts in humans with artificial pumps. Revolutionary vistas for increasing average longevity are opened by this prospect.
NAHA, Okinawa, June 1--The Soviet Union has nuclear-powered submarines operating in the Pacific, Vice Admiral John S. Thach, commander of the Anti-Submarine Defense Force in the Pacific, said today.
The value of both new stock and bond offerings to the public here in May fell belowe the level of May, 1961, and the preceding month.

Bonds called for redemption in May before maturity totaled $28,803,000. This was the smallest monthly refunding since November, 1961, when $26,984,000 in bonds was called. Prepayments aggregated $57,107,000 in April and $107,780,000 in May of last year.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., June 1--Mrs. Ann Jones Ogilvie of West Hartford and Elmer Reid Stephens of Brookfield Center were married here this afternoon in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church. The Rev. Harold Hand Donegan performed the ceremony.
NEW DELHI, India, June 1 --The Indian Government charged today that border negotiations between Communist China and Pakistan were part of Peiping's "aggressive designs" against India.
SANTIAGO, Chile, June 1 (AP)--Trainers and coaches worked today to get their bruised and battered players into shape for the week-end's games in the world soccer championship.
Three students at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism yesterday received the Pulitzer Traveling Scholarships for 1962.
Representative Abraham J. Multer and an association of home owners in the Manhattan Beach section of Brooklyn voiced opposition yesterday to a proposed extension of Manhattan Beach.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 1 (UPI)--A seventy-foot tall advertising balloon tore loose from its moorings today and sent two youths soaring to an altitude of 11,000 feet before they were able to turn down the balloon's air heater.

Pedestrian happenstance acquired epic proportions at the Polo Grounds last night whenever Willie Mays was even casually involved. In the eyes of his roaring admirers, the mere presence of the 5-foot-11-inch outfielder dwarfed the main reason for the occasion--a ball game between the San Francisco Giants and the Mets.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., June 1--Mrs. Theodore Francis Drury has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jane Ellis Drury, to David Fachler Rick. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. James Rick 3d of Reading, Pa.
Railroad management and labor were reported yesterday to be near an agreement on wage increases for 500,000 off-train employes.

EIGHT teams, survivors in the field of sixty-two teams that began play Monday night, entered the quarter-final round of the Reisinger Cup team contest in the Eastern States Championships last night. The tournament is being played at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.

For several months the head of Harvard University's Division of Geological Sciences has been trying in vain to persuade the Government that he may have an effective way to detect underground nuclear explosions.
MOSCOW, June 1--For scores of Russian children, Benny Goodman became today for a few tuneful moments the Pied Piper of Red Square.
The recent wild gyrations of the stock market will not have any effect on the capital investment plans of the Ford Motor Company, Henry Ford 2d, chairman, said yesterday.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 1--The Citizens Committee Against Discrimination in Urban Renewal here charged today that city officials were neglecting the residential needs of Negroes in the redevelopment of old areas.
The postponement of new capital issues because of Monday's stock market break lightened the schedule of securities underwriting set up for next week.
Nine-year-old Roger Guzman was killed in Brooklyn yesterday by a police car in which two patrolmen were responding to a call for help.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, June 1--A second Peace Corps team of thirty-one members surprised Malayan reporters at Kuala Lumpur Airport today by greeting them in Malay. They learned a working knowledge of the language in a three-month course at Northern Illinois University.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) --A former high-ranking Federal official dismissed last fall over a gambling episode has been rehired for the Alliance for Progress program.
Mrs. Walt Whitman Rostow, wife of President Kennedy's Deputy Special Assistant for National Security, was elected yesterday to a four-year term as an alumnae trustee of Barnard College.
Bank clearings in the twentysix leading cities of the nation totaled $23,897,533,000 in the holiday week ended on Wednesday, Dun and Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

FEW guests look forward with pleasure to a dinner that is to be served buffet style. Quite justifiable groans are likely to greet the prospect of juggling a food-laden plate on the knees or of dining from one of those wobbly trays on legs to which some hostesses resort.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI)--The Federal Government is making a flanking attack on discrimination against minority groups in housing.
WASHINGTON, June 1--Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota proposed an immedi ate cut in income tax rates today to stimulate the economy and restore confidence in the stock market.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, June 1 (Reuters)--Demonstrators against South Africa's "sabotage bill" carried cardboard effigies of four hanged men on a main street here as the bill went before a committee of the House of Assembly.
Motion-picture trade circles showed interest yesterday in the story published in The New York Times regarding the response to revival showings of films featuring Elizabeth Taylor.
WASHINGTON, June 1-- Rail freight loadings last week were slightly above the level of a year earlier, but were off a bit from those of the preceding week of this year.

WASHINGTON, June 1--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Casey of Clinton, Mass., and this city have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Dudley Casey, to Pedro Pablo Kuczynski Godard. He is the son of Dr. Maxime Kuczynski of Lima, Peru, and the late Senora Kuczynski.

The Sunbeam Corporation increased its sales and earnings by 10 per cent for the two months ended May 31 over the 1961 period, Robert P. Gwinn, president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting in Chicago yesterday.

The man who died in Ramle, Israel, Thursday night was an accessory before the fact in the murder of 6,000,000 people. He worked with passionless efficiency under the orders of his official superiors. He told his official inferiors where to go and what to do. All along the line, from the first knock on the door at midnight to the final terror of the gas chamber, there was a careful precision in what was done.

MANILA, June 1--Tempers are cooling off a little here after the flare-up of antiUnited States feeling a few weeks ago. It started when the American Congress rejected on May 9 a Philippine claim of $73,000,000 as part of the bill for damage inflicted in World War II.

MIAMI, Fla., June 1 (UPI)-- A plaque was unveiled at Miami International Airport today honoring Amelia Earhart on the twenty-fifth anniversary of her take-off from here on a tragic around-the-world flight.

Angry Greenwich Village residents threw a legal roadblock yesterday in the way of part of Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes' plan to alter lower West Side traffic patterns starting tomorrow morning.
ROME, June 1--Pope John XXIII said today that Roman Catholics were committed to strive to translate the social teachings of their Church into the laws of their countries.
Record world production of man-made fibers was predicted for this year by Col. T.F. Davies, president of the International Rayon and Synthetic Fibers Committee.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 1 (AP)--Rear Admiral Frank B. Miller, Fleet Air Commander of the Naval Air Base here, died yesterday in Balboa Hospital of a heart attack.

In the wake of this week's shattered stock prices, Wall streeters began to sweep up the statistics. Harold Clayton, analyst for Hemphill Noyes Co., has figured that eight wellknown stocks dropped $31,000,000,000 from their 1961-62 high price to their lows this week. The eight: American Telephone, ...
BONN, Germany, June 1-- Chancellor Adenauer said today that the threat from the East was continuing "with undiminished sharpness, especially for the German people."
Dr. Leonard W. Larson, the president of the American Medical Association, reaffirmed his support of a program of voluntary, health insurance for the aged in a speech here last night.
LONDON, Saturday, June 2 --Many Britons prominent in the fields of art, journalism, and television were among those chosen today for Queen Elizabeth II's birthday honors list.

The Inter-American University of Puerto Rico, whose student body grew from 555 to 4,000 in seven years, announced yesterday that scholarships would be offered to Puerto Rican youths living in New York City.

AFTER forty-four years in and out of courtrooms-- the last fifteen on the bench and previously as a lawyer-- Federal Judge Leo Frederick Rayfiel assumed the role of witness in a trial for the first time yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 1-- Three American-Jewish educators reported today that political instability and economic distress had thrown Jewish education in Western Europe and North Africa into "a state of emergency."

In Central Synagogue here yesterday afternoon, Miss Jane Deborah Rachel Cohn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Arthur Cohn of New York and Milford, N.J., became the bride of David Robert Waldbaum. He is the son of Mrs. Serena Waldbaum of Om aha and Sidney Waldbaum of Grand Island, Neb. Rabbi David J. Seligson performed the ceremony.
National Securities and Research Corporation reported yesterday a decline in net assets for the year ended April 30.
Senorita Maria Isabel Davila of New York and Bogota. Colombia, and James Rumrill Hammond Jr. plan to be married this July in Bogota.

Ten picturesque and historic houses lining Macdougal Alley will be open to the public on Wednesday from 4 to 7:30 P.M. Refreshments will be available and fortunes will be told. Admission is $2.50, which will go to the Greenwich House Camp Fund. The tour will start at the entrance to the alley, which is between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas near Eighth Street.

KINGS POINT, L.I., June 1-- House flags of shipping companies, bunting and flowers enhanced by a crystal chandelier will provide a gay setting next Saturday in O'Hara Hall, gymnasium of the United States Merchant Marine Academy, for the Kings Point Ball.

WASHINGTON, June 1--The General Services Administration, custodian of the Government's stockpile of goose and duck feathers, said today that the Defense Department was about to call up about 650 tons of feathers. This will reduce the stockpile to the defense objective of 8,800,000 pounds, or 4,000 long tons.

WHERE, people are asking in Wall Street again, are the customers' yachts? A good antidote to that doleful cry is to read Ludwig Bemelmans' diverting account of his uproarious Mediterranean yachting experiences, "On Board Noah's Ark."*
CAIRO, June 1--Several hundred students and teachers at the ancient University of AlAzhar were repulsed today in an attempt to storm the offices of the Cairo newspaper Al Ahram.

CALCUTTA, India, May 26-- After six months of sporadic but continual armed actions, the Nepalese rebels appear to be pausing to take stock of the situation. But the lull is expected to be only temporary.
The regional head of the Federal Aviation Agency declared yesterday that continued community pressures to halt aircraft noise could drive aviation out of New York.
FORT LEE, N.J., June 1--A three-day dedication of the new Jewish Community Center at 1449 Anderson Avenue here began tonight with a religious service.

HAVANA, June 1 (Reuters) --Premier Fidel Castro spoke to two Western newsmen for about an hour and a half in a Havana bar early today, declaring that he was "very worried" about the possibility of a United States move against Cuba.

WASHINGTON, June 1--The National Labor Relations Board decided today that it did not have jurisdiction in a case involving a foreign-flag ship owned by a United States company because the vessed did not call at United States ports often enough to show "substantial ties to the commerce of this nation."

MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 1 (UPI)--Norman G. Levine, of New York, national president of B'nai Zion, announced today that fraternal Zionist organization would build a $2,000,000 low-cost housing project for elder persons.

JERSEY CITY, June 1-- Edward J. Florio, ex-convict, and former union boss of the Hoboken waterfront, died today at Pollak County Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 317 Washington Street, Hoboken.
LAKEHURST, N.J., June 1-- Capt. Roland F. Stultz became commander of the Naval Air Station here today in a changeof-command ceremony.

SUMMER is here, and the time of the slightly soggy gallerygoer is at hand. But some bright, unwilted art is still on view, although the standard throughout the city at the moment is subject (like the stock market) to sudden, wide fluctuations.
WASHINGTON, June 1-- The Pentagon announced today the first Federal construction plans for fall-out shelters.
LONDON, June 1--John Masefield, Britain's Poet Laureate, celebrated his eighty-fourth birthday today by lunching with old friends and making resolutions which, he said, "I'm afraid I shan't keep."
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI)--It is no longer going to be so easy for an enemy agent to get a list of United States defense plants.

The official seal of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations depicts the hands of two workers clasped in friendship across the face of the globe. The federation and its affiliates have been doing a good deal lately to give substance to this symbol.

Volume on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday dropped to the lowest level since Thursday, May 24, and brokers found a little more time to eat lunch. Many shifted lunch time back to noon from after the close of the market.
A purportedly close associate of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba was sentenced to fifteen years in prison yesterday by Federal Judge John F. X. McGohey.
PALM BEACH, Fla., June 1 (UPI)--A fifty-five-gallon drum of potentially explosive metallic sodium was found bobbing in the surf today near the oceanfront estate of President Kennedy's father.
Two apprentice iron workers apparently drowned yesterday when they fell into the Harlem River and were swept away.

The city's leading department stores, which usually report on their sales at the end of each month, declined yesterday to disclose figures for May because of the strike by drivers for the United Parcel Service.
The Department of Health warned 130 families living in the Howard Beach section of Queens yesterday that their privately owned water mains were in danger of becoming polluted with sewage.
