Production of lumber in the country totaled 245,891,000 board feet in the week ended May 26, according to reports received yesterday from regional associations.
ALONG with a few bright spots in the diminishing returns of a waning season, a number of surviving exhibitions can bear having attention drawn to them again.
ALBANY, June 1 (AP)--The State Government spent $2,365,049,746 in the fiscal year that ended March 31 and wound up with a surplus of $1,208,193. State Controller Arthur Levitt reported today.

PARIS, June 1--The essence of French differences with what de Gaulle calls the "Anglo-Saxon" nations is nuclear and almost everything else stems from this. The General bitterly resents his exclusion from the atomic club by two allies who ignore the fact that France has conducted five successful tests and refuse him aid.
Growing trees may have nostalgic value in Brooklyn, but when one threatens to interfere with parking space, the cry goes up, "Plant it some place else."

PARIS, June 1 (AP)--Rod Laver, the Australian champion who is aiming for a sweep of tennis' big four tournaments, took another step toward the goal today by defeating his countryman, Neale Fraser, in the semi-finals of the French championships.
GENEVA, June 1--Jerzy Szapiro, Warsaw correspondent of The New York Times from 1927 through 1939, died here today after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 1 (AP)--Elmer Brown, president of the International Typographical Union, and all his Progressive party running mates won re-election to top offices in the I.T.U. on May 16, the official count showed today.

The Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts is well on its way to becoming the most handily wired cultural complex of its kind for speeding the unobtrusive broadcast of its shows by radio and television.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP)--A new political biography of Senator Barry Goldwater, Arizona Republican, pictures him today as believing he would have a good chance of winning the Republican Presidential nomination in 1964. And it suggests he might make the attempt if the party's prospects look bright.

SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras, June 1 (Reuters)--A state of emergency was proclaimed here today because of an epidemic of typhoid fever. More than sixty children died in the last week. All primary schools were closed.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 1-- One hundred and fifty-six Lebanese, fifty-four Syrians and twenty Palestinians went on trial today before a joint military-civilian tribunal on charges of attempting to overthrow the Lebanese Government last New Year's Eve. Seventy persons also are being tried in absentia.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP)--A Federal grand jury indicted the Johns-Manville Corporation, the Keasbey and Mattison Company and five of their executives today on charges of violating the antitrust laws.
WASHINGTON, May 30--In the debate over medical care for the aged, Americans have begun asking questions of their own.
CARACAS, Venezuela, June 1 (AP)--President Romulo Betancourt says foreign-owned oil companies will not be nationalized but they must use more Venezuelan administrators and technicians.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP)--The onrushing Los Angeles Dodgers took both ends of a twilight-night double-header tonight from the Philadelphia Phillies, 11--4 and 8--5. The victories extended their winning streak to thirteen games and moved them into a first-place tie, with the San Francisco Giants.
BOSTON, June 1 (AP)--An optimistic report came today from the hospital room of Everett Knowles Jr., the 12year-old boy whose severed right arm was sewed to his body last Saturday.

Mrs. Margaret Burnham De Silver of 70 East Tenth Street, a leader in civil liberties and aid to refugees, died yesterday in New York Hospital. She was 72 years old and the widow of Albert De Silver, who was a member of the law firm of Reynolds, Richards McCutcheon.
The Rev. Dr. William Edgar Gilroy, an editor of religious publications and a columnist, died Wednesday of pleurisy in his home, 46 Morton Street, Newton Centre, Mass. His age was 86.
LOS ANGELES, June 1--The world champions Yankees made their first appearances in the magnificent Chavez Ravine stadium tonight, and they made it an eventful evening.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 30--Jamaica is approaching independence with a sober demeanor that masks considerable self-confidence.

YONKERS, June 1--Outstanding trotters continue to be hard to come by this season. Good quality trotters haven't been plentiful in recent years, and the ranks this season have been even thinner than ever.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., June 1 (AP)--The director of the Veterans Administration Hospital here said today that almost all its employes were Negroes, but he insisted that white doctors and other staff members were welcome.

Juvenile delinquency is at last going to be attacked in the way that promises most success: applying the resources of private and Government agencies in a coordinated effort focused on a small area where conditions are the worst.
A plan to reduce the cost of major home improvements by having the owner perform part of the labor himself has been introduced by a contracting concern serving the New York metropolitan area.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 1 --Eric Frank's Cinder Man beat the odds-on favorite, Green Ticket, in the $15,000 Sword Dancer Purse at six furlongs as Monmouth Park opened its fifty-six-day race meeting today.
AUSTIN, June 1--The Texas Democratic gubernatorial primary campaign wound up today amid vituperation and lastminute television appeals.
DETROIT, June 1 (AP)-- Jim Perry retired the first sixteen batters and allowed only four hits tonight as he pitched the first-place Cleveland Indians to a 7--1 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

WASHINGTON, June 1--An inventor in Virginia has made it possible for man to speak simple words to machines and be understood. He hopes it will soon be practical not only to give orders to a lathe but to dictate to a teletypewriter.

GREETING passers-by in the window at Wilburt, Inc., is a battalion of wooden soldiers from Denmark. These sturdy, eight-inch figures are modeled after the Royal Tivoli guards of Copenhagen. A decorative addition to a bar, playroom or nursery, the soldiers start at $3 and go up to $5.25 for a drummer

Trading in coffee and cocoa futures led activity on the New York markets yesterday in a generally dull day for commodity trading. Evening-up before the week-end and continued trader interest in the stock market kept commodities quiet.
The International Basic Economy Corporation of New York, an investment and development concern, elected yesterday the following directors:

WASHINGTON, June 1--A Senate investigation of stockpiling practices turned into a heated partisan issue today with former President Dwight D. Eisenhower defending his own Administration and, in particular, his first Secretary of the Treasury, George M. Humphrey.

BRUSSELS, May 31--Brussels is concerned about such questions as whether the applicants to become charwomen at the Foreign Ministry must pass examinations in both Flemish and French. But, frequently nowadays, the city pauses to notice that it is also the de facto capital of Europe.

NEW works by six local composers were presented late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall. The composers were Ernest Lubin, Keith Robinson, Eda Rapoport, Carl Bowman, Paul Knopf and Norman Bloom.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI)--The space agency reported today that its 458-pound Orbiting Solar Observatory, had stopped sending useful information after eleven weeks of "near perfect operation."

OTTAWA, June 1 (Canadian Press)--Canada's foreign exchange reserves dropped by an unusually large $116,000,000 in the first two days of May before the dollar was devalued and fixed. Since then they have increased by $14,000,000, a finance department report showed today.
East Germany has apparently asked West Germany for almost a billion dollars' worth of aid in the form of coal, machinery, food and drugs.
HAMPTON, Va., June 1 (AP) --Five of America's seven astronauts today finally got to see the Distinguished Service awards "presented" to them several months ago by Virginia's lower peninsula.

WASHINGTON, June 1--Fallout from nuclear tests through 1961 may result in forty deaths a year from bone cancer and leukemia in the present population of the United States and cause serious genetic defects in 110 children of the next generation, the Government estimated today.
An agreement on new contract terms covering 12,000 bricklayers in the city and part of Long Lsland has been reached, union and industry sources announced yesterday.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 1 (AP)-- Maj. Bob White zoomed at 3,750 miles an hour to a height of 129,000 feet in the X-15 rocket plane today in a test of the craft's re-entry performance.
Union Theological Seminary announced yesterday that Mrs. Lewis J. Sherrill, widow of the former head of its Religious Education Department, would become Dean of Women Students on July 1.
VOGHERA, Italy, June 1-- The death toll in a train crash here early yesterday morning rose to sixty-three today with the death in a hospital of a seriously injured woman.
MOSCOW, June 1--The Soviet Government undertook today an intensive propaganda campaign to sustain the morale of the Soviet people in the face of the steep rise in the prices of meat and butter.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 1 --John C. Burgard, a retired West Coast insurance man, died here yesterday at the home of his son, Peter. He was 72 years old.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 1 --Dr. Lee H. Bristol Jr., was inaugurated as the third pressident of Westminster Choir College today during the school's thirty-third annual commencement exercises in the Princeton University Chapel.

ALGIERS, June 1--Algiers relaxed today as the Rightwing Secret Army Organization called a halt to the terrorist killing it has carried on here for the last ten weeks. The truce was scheduled to last until Sunday night at least.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 1--The Right Rev. James P. DeWolfe, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, will dedicate the Rebecca Bolling Littlejohn Memorial and the new parish house at St. John's Church here tomorrow.

Australia plans to borrow $30,000,000 in the United States about June 20 in order to finance public works. The plans were the subject of a registration statement filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Morgan Stanley Co. was named manager of the financing, which consists of twenty-year bonds

CHICAGO, June 1--Mrs. Sara Carroll Field, the wife of Stanley Field, chairman of the Chicago Natural History Museum and chairman of the executive committee of Marshall Field Co., died today at their home in suburban Lake Bluff. She was 84 years old.
Seven new films made by students as part of their curriculum at New York University have been made available for public circulation for the first time through the university's film library.

As heavy trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange subsided yesterday, a significant show of strength became visible in the market for United States Government securities, especially those of intermediate term.

IF Persian poufs become popular in home decorating in the next few years, Tom Lee may be partly responsible. Mr. Lee, an industrial and interior designer, recently returned from Teheran where he is completing the interiors of the Royal Tehran Hilton.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) --The Commerce Department said today that it was expanding the list of items that can be exported only with Government permission.

WASHINGTON, June 1-- After an opening day of varied and relatively adventurous events that included a symphonic jazz concert in Constitution Hall, a jazz ballet and a New Orleans parade passed the White House, the first International Jazz Festival plunged to dismal depths tonight.
Two men were shot and captured last night after they attacked a detective posing as a narcotics addict on the lower East Side. Two other suspects were also captured.

Federal Judge Leo F. Rayfiel testified yesterday that State Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh, an old friend, had spoken to him about the case of a man coming up for sentencing on a criminal charge the next day.
WASHINGTON, June 1-- Jack Romagna, who has been taking down the words of Presidents since 1941, was dismissed today as the official White House stenographer.
PATCHOGUE, L.I. June 1-- John Vredenburgh Van Pelt architect and former dean of the College of Architecture Cornell University, died in Brookhaven Memorial Hospital on Wednesday. He was 88 years old.
MURMANSK, U.S.S.R., June 1--The captain of the Soviet atomic ice breaker Lenin said today that his ship had the ability to reach "any point in the frozen Arctic Ocean at any time of the year."

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 1--The voting yesterday in Northern Ireland's general election for a new Parliament left the political mixture about the same as it was in the Parliament dissolved May 9.

For Wall Street the week that began with a bang went out with a whimper. Stocks moved little yesterday but moved lower. Volume was heavy but smaller than that for any other day this week and more stocks fell than rose.

Twenty-five years ago next month the Jewish Community of Berlin held a farewell meeting to honor a young rabbi whose courage was an inspiration to others. It caused his expulsion by the Nazis from Germany.

BIRMINGHAM, England, June 1 (Reuters)--Pakistan faces a tremendous task to avoid defeat by England in their first test here. When bad light stopped play half an hour early today, Pakistan was 149 runs for five wickets in reply to England's 544 for five declared.

FORT WORTH, Tex., June 1 (AP)--Ben Hogan, who won the United States Open golf championship four times, and Willie Turnesa, who captured two United States Amateur crowns, withdrew today from the 1962 United States Open qualifying field.
MEMPHIS, June 1 (AP)-- Scowling over his putts, Gary Player shot a 4-under-par 66 today to take the lead in the $40,000 Memphis open golf tournament.
Nathan E. Posner, a rareviolin collector and dealer, died yesterday at Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 80 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 1--Ten months before he was shot to death, a Department of Agriculture employe made a report cautioning against the type of deals Billie Sol Estes worked out to gain Federal cotton allotments.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) --Charges that nine major ice cream manufacturers engaged in unfair competition were dismissed today by the Federal Trade Commission.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 1-- Vietnamese military patrols searched the highlands of southern Darlac Province today for three American missionaries captured Wednesday night in a raid by Communist guerrillas on a leprosarium near Banmethuot.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., June 1 --The marriage of Miss Patricia Maxwell Roberts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Roberts, to Richard Henry Pemble 2d, took place here this afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Josephine E. Pemble of Burlington, Iowa, and the late Richard Henry Pemble.

The caution flag flew yesterday for mutual funds. Selective buying on the market grew more selective. The land-office business they had done in selling shares on Tuesday and Thursday turned quiet. CHICAGO, June 1--Clarence E. Cross, a retired bank executive, died early yesterday morning in his home in suburban Park Ridge. He was 69 years old.

MIAMI, June 1--The use of a fourth man in the crews of jet airliners has burdened the airline industry with $25,000,000 to $30,000,000 in extra operating costs over the last three years, Robert F. Six, president of Continental Airlines, said today.

Reisinger Cup, both scheduled tonight at the StatlerHilton Hotel, the former at 7 o'clock and the latter at 8.
The John Hay Whitney Foundation announced yesterday the award of Opportunity Fellowships to forty-five persons from twenty-three states and United States possesions.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, June 3 Prime Minister Cheddi B. Jagan is under pressure to decide whether to expel the Home Affairs Minister, Balram Singh Rai, from the ruling People's Progressive party.
In his book "The Great Crash," John Kenneth Galbraith told of the mountain of paperwork the stock exchange community faced during the 1929 market debacle.
PITTSBURGH, June 3 Demand for steel appeared to have strengthened somewhat last week.
A major program designed to improve the flow of traffic in Lower Manhattan went into effect yesterday.
Moves involving two District Attorneys in this city stirred refresh interest yesterday in the Democratic quest for a candidate for Governor.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 3 President Romulo Betancourt tonight openly accused the Communist party and the Marxist-oriented Movement of the Revolutionary Left of in volvement in the revolt at Puerto Cabello.
SANTIAGO, Chile, June 3 (UPI) Colombia rallied and tied the Soviet Union, 4 4, today in World Soccer Cup competition and Mexico and Switzerland were eliminated from the championships.

BOSTON, June 3 (UPI) Adlai E. Stevenson declared today that "the road to peace in this fearful generation is the road to an open world." The chief United States representative to the United Nations spoke at commencement exercises at Boston University, at which he received an honorary degree.
The Board of Education is going to give a second chance to youngsters who quit high school and then realized they had made a mistake.
VIENTIANE, Laos, June 3 Anxiety deepened today over the fate of four British subjects in territory in southern Laos held by the Pathet Lao proCommunist guerrillas

MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 3 (AP) Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said today that American foreign aid should be withheld from the United Arab Republic until President Gamal Abdel Nasser ended political and economic boycotts of Israel.

LEONIA, N.J., June 3 Dr. Ten Eyck Elmendorf of 396 Park Avenue, a New York pediatrician for forty-four years, died of a heart attack Friday night in Bergen Pines Hospital, Paramus. He was 81 years old.

MONTE CARLO, June 3 Bruce McLaren of New Zealand, driving a V-8 Cooper Climax, won the 195-mile Grand Prix de Monaco today by 1.3 seconds. He finished about sixty feet ahead of Phil Hill of Santa Monica, Calif., who drove a Ferrari.

MR. AND MRS. DEL R. PAIGE Mr. Paige, 61 years old, a partner in the accounting firm of Ernst Ernst, was president of the Atlanta Art Association. He was also chairman of a citizens' advisory committee named by the city government last year to study the development of a performing ...

LOS ANGELES, June 3 This being the time of season in baseball when they start separating the men from the boys, the Yankees decided today they had better separate the Los Angeles Angels from whatever thoughts of grandeur they may have entertained.
America of Rio de Janeiro made its debut here yesterday in the International Soccer League and became a leading candidate for the First Section title by beating Hajduk of Yugoslavia, 3 2.
Many individuals who "dislike" and "mistrust" God received a faulty education during their childhood, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken told worshipers yesterday in Riverside Church.

AFTER the intermission of Roland Hayes' concert at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, the audience rose and sang a heartfelt "Happy Birthday" to the 75year-old tenor. This was not the only tribute paid him, for he was presented with the first Armistad Award by the American Missionary Association.
The salaries of internes at Montefiore Hospital will be doubled, the hospital announced yesterday. The Bronx institution also listed increases almost as great for resident doctors.

WASHINGTON, June 3 A State Department advisory committee recommended today that the United States give greater support to the International Atomic Energy Agency in promoting and safeguarding the global development of nuclear power.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 3 (UPI) Apparently fewer than half of Bolivia's 2,600,000 voters balloted today for half of the country's seventy-six-member Chamber of Deputies and a third of the forty-five-member Senate.
BERLIN, June 3 East German border guards seized a French motor boat near the East-West border this afternoon and arrested the six French soldiers aboard. No shots were fired in the incident.
Compiled by Congressional Quarterly.
Fur-trimmed coats and suits and imitation fur coats, with an emphasis on mink, continued heavily in demand last week, resident buying offices here reported.
DALLAS, June 3 Conservatives maintained their grip on the Texas Democratic party yesterday, overcoming liberal challenges in four major state primary races.

Central Synagogue was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Dorothy Rosalind Sokolsky, daughter of George E. Sokolsky, the syndicated columnist, and Mrs. Sokolsky of 300 West End Avenue and Sandisfield, Mass., to Donald Martin Feuerstein. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris M. Feurstein of Chicago.

PARIS, June 3 As if by the wave of a magic wand, Britain and the United States last Thursday increased each other's gold and foreign exchange reserves by $50,000,000. They did it by swapping each other's currencies, with each currency counted as reserves by the other.
ZELAZOWA WOLA, Poland, June 3 There cannot be much that is more nostalgic and quintessentially Polish in Poland than the Sunday mornings in this village about thirty miles from Warsaw.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) The director of the United States Information Agency said today that he hoped to obtain increased approriations in each of the next several years and strengthen his staff with peace Corps graduates.

VENICE, Italy, May 27 Coatings of plastic are in store for the four gold-plated bronze horses atop the facade of St. Mark's Basilica. The horses are being damaged by the corrosive action of airborne sulphur fumes, and the authorities hope the coating will protect the ancient bronzes.

The Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra conducted by David Randolph presented a concert at Carnegie Hall last night that had as its major offering Brahms' "Ein Deutsches Be quiem," Op. 45. Also on the program was Beethoven's "Egmont" Overture. The more than hour-and-thirty-minute Brahms work was separated between the third and fourth movements by the intermission.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 3 Technical assistance to Africa administered by the United Nations doubled last year, the Bureau of Technical Assistance Operations reported today.

THE decline of interest among collectors for old master prints has led to their general withdrawal from the public market. They are now concentrated at sources known only to the specialist and to the museum curator. Considering the wealth of accomplishment and historical importance of this field, its going underground represents a substantial loss.
DETROIT, June 3 (AP) The domestic automobile industry produced 673,187 passenger cars in May, a figure surpassed in only six other months since the auto was invented.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, June 3--Paul Keres of the Soviet Union strengthened his lead in the Candidates' Chess Tournament today by defeating his countryman Mikhail Tal on the black side of a Ruy Lopez in forty-one moves. Fine combinative play by the Estonian grand master netted two pawns and a superior position in the sixteenth-round game.
Midway through the children's concert in Carl Schurz Park yesterday three 10-year olds, in white starched dresses and Alice-in-Wonderland hairdos, were overheard discussing the day's proceedings.
GENEVA, June 3 The Swiss markets reflected last week the wild gyrations of the New York Stock Exchange. Panic selling on Tuesday was followed by just as great a scramble in the opposite direction.
A 43-year-old woman was killed accidentally yesterday when a policeman fired two warning shots during a knife fight between two men outside her apartment house at 46 East Ninety-eighth Street.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 3 (AP) Informed sources said today that guided missiles and additional modern jet bombers were expected soon from the Soviet Union to bolster Indonesian forces girding for a showdown with the Netherlands over Netherlands New Guinea.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) Building contractors urged President Kennedy today to warn construction unions that their demands in many areas were threatening to unbalance the nation's economy.
Two recent surveys and two new books should provide substance for mutual fund backers, particularly in light of last Week's frenzied activity.
DETROIT, June 3 (AP ) The Detroit Tigers, aided by the relief pitching of Ron Nischwitz, beat the Cleveland Indians, 8-6, today for their twelfth victory in fifteen games.

RANGOON, Burma, June 3 Burma has decided to terminate her malaria-eradication program under the United Nations Children's Fund, She has requested officials of the fund and the World Health Organization to withdraw an offer of $1,000,000 for malaria operations in Burma in the 1963 fiscal year.

NODA, Japan. JAPAN, with its rickety build ings in the center of Tokyo cheek-by-jowl with a resplendent new hotel called the Okura, is a classic study in twentiethcentury contrasts. And in few places is the contrast more apparent than at the centuries-old soy sauce factory in this town about twenty miles from Tokyo.
BAD HERSFELD, Germany, June 3 (Reuters) East Germans started work today on a "Berlin-type wall" along part of the East-West German border near here, the West German police said.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
ELAINE LEVINE is playing the part of Pygmalion in her new shop, called Galatea, where she is hoping to transform the wardrobes of young working women.
Respect for other persons' beliefs is neded to maintain democracy, Senator Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, said last night.

The study of the Rev. Nathan A. Perilman at Temple EmanuEl was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Louise Carole Mintz to Dr. Abraham Sunshine. The Rev. Jacob Polish of Forest Hills, Queens, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Rabbi Perilman.
Supporters of the Rev. Dr. Stuart Hamilton Merriam, ousted minister of the Broadway Presbytertian Church at 114th Street, have started "a defense fund" to help the clergyman regain his pulpit.

OF the 1,600,000 marriages expected to take place in the United States this year, almost two-fifths of the brides and one-eighth of the grooms will be teen-agers, according to the Population Reference Bureau of Washington.

HONG KONG, Monday, June 4 (AP) A Chinese refugee family bound for Chicago received today its United States entry documents the first to go under President Kennedy's emergency Chinese refugee entry program.
The toll of 130 lives in the jet crash in Paris yesterday was the highest ever incurred in a single-plane disaster, and it was the sixth airplane accident in history to cause more than 100 deaths.
MIAMI, Fla., June 3 Capt. Charles H. Ruby, National Airlines jet pilot, was elected president of the Air Line Pilots Association today.

MOSCOW, June 3 (UPI) The International Olympic Committee will hold a ceremonial opening of its fifty-ninth annual meeting tomorrow night, with the question of political interference in sports expected to top the agenda when the committee gets down to business Tuesday.
Cotton prices in the domestic market continued to move in a relatively narrow range last week, reflecting the absence of any new developments important enough to influence trading substantially.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on a United Na tions Capital Development Fund Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.
Jordan S. Ofseyer did a repeat performance yesterday afternoon in a familiar costume.
MADRID, June 3--Generalissimo Francisco Franco presided here today over the most impressive display of Spanish armed strength seen in recent years.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 3 A prosecutor in the Eichmann case was arrested today on charges of "impersonating a lawyer."

The cactus of political satire is sprouting from coast to coast. A dominant feature of Manhattan's night life for some time, it is putting down its roots more firmly and becoming more prickly every day.
THE man's umbrella is far from being an open and shut case. Buffeted by the storms of domestic prejudice and foreign competition, the bumbershoot may at last be seeing the rays of sunlight.
CLEARWATER, Fla. June 3 --Brig. Gen. Robert W. Marshall, New York National Guard, retired, died Thursday at MacDill Air Force Base. His age was 78.
WASHINGTON, June 3 The latest uprising in Venezuela by Leftist opponents of President Romulo Betancourt was not viewed here today as a major threat to his regime.
With its swept-back wings and underslung engine pods, the Boeing 707 and its variants have become the most common jet planes on the world's airlines.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 3 --Robert Stern and his Beach Point Yacht Club race committee did about everything today except manufacture a breeze as the second in the club's series of Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regattas was canceled.

GAMBIER, Ohio, June 3 (AP) James Reston, the Washton correspondent of The New York Times, told Kenyon College's class of 1962 today that they were more justified in laying plans for a world at peace than their parents were twentyfive years ago.
The Atlas Corporation announced over the week-end the acquisition of about 75 per cent of the Uranium Reduction Company and was negotiating to purchase the rest of the outstanding stock.

Borough President John T. Clancy's decision last week to seek the Democratic nomination for Surrogate of Queens this year is drawing attention again to the peculiar role of the judiciary in Democratic politics in New York. It is a role that helps account for the dearth of outstanding candidates for this
The Ford Foundation, which has invested large sums to aid conductors, concert soloists, composers and opera singers, has now awarded $99,600 to assist choral directors.

The city's Housing and Redevelopment Board has completed preliminary plans for the establishment of a $63,800,000 residential community on a 150acre site fronting on Jamaica Bay in the Paerdegat Basin section of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, June 3 After four days of blowing and thumping, the first International Jazz Festival came to an end tonight with a jazz liturgical service by Edgar Summerlin. It was commissioned for the festival and was performed at the Church of Epiphany.
"WHAT a show this has been," said Alvin Dark yesterday. "It has been tremendous."

ATLANTA, June 3 Shocked disbelief followed by mourning swept Atlanta today with the news that many of its cultural leaders had died in the crash of an Air France jetliner in Paris. Not since 119 died here in the Winecoff Hotel fire of 1946 has this city suffered a comparable disaster.

The San Francisco Giants bade a reluctant farewell to their old Polo Grounds playpen yesterday after scoring their fourth straight victory over the Mets. This, coupled with the defeat of the Dodgers by the Phillies, increased the Giants' National League lead over Los Angeles to two and a half games.

PITTSBURGH, June 3 (AP) The Houston Colts swept a double-header from the Pittsburgh Pirates today, taking the first game. 10 6, and the second, 10 3. It was the first double-header defeat for the Pirates this season. The loss in the first game snapped a seven-game Pittsburgh winning streak.

CHICAGO, June 2 (AP) Selling pressure continued almost without let-up in most grain futures pits this week and all but wheat and July rye finished well below the ranges of the week before on the Board of Trade.
FRAMINGHAM, Mass., June 3 The annual dog show and obedience trial of the Framingham District Kennel Club today crew 1,103 dogs representing more than ninety breeds or varieties.

Haunted by the ghost of executed Premier Menderes, Turkey is going through a crisis of the parliamentary regime restored only six months ago following the military revolt of 1960. Premier Inonu, the "grand old man" of Turkish politics who was called to office to heal the nation's wounds, is trying to overcome the crisis
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 3 (UPI) Most of the Israelis who wrote to President Itzhak Ben-Zvi on Adolf Eichmann favored sparing Eichmann's life.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 3 A few months ago Damazin in the Southern Sudan was non-existent. Today it claims two distinctions. It is not only the newest town in the country, but also the most modern.
The National and American Broadcasting companies reaffirmed yesterday what they called their long-standing policy of nondiscrimination in the use of Negro actors on television.
Five pickets were arrested yesterday after a scuffle during a union organizing demonstration at Beth-el Hospital in Brooklyn.

LOS ANGELES, June 3 For twelve voting hours on Tuesday, a vigorous, dapper, 73-year-old man will hold an unusual distinction. He will be the only member of the John Birch Society with an outside chance of winning a Democratic party nomination to Congress.
WARSAW, June 3 An episcopal letter of the Roman Catholic Church, published over official objections, called upon Poland's Christians today to fast and to pray that atheists return to the faith.
Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, has urged officials of the International Longshoremen's Association to back him in his dispute with the Seafarers International Union.

DALLAS, June 3 John Bowden Connally Jr., who won the Democratic nomination for Governor of Texas yesterday, has become one of the most controversial political figures in a state where politics is total war.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 3 About the only thing the second and final day of the New York Yacht Club's 108th annual regatta proved today was that Billy Luders of Stamford, Conn., could take the best and the worst of wind conditions and win.
DORTMUND, Germany, June 3 Chancellor Adenauer told his party today that "the Adenauer era has not ended yet."
James Felt, chairman of the City Planning Commission, predicted yesterday a gradual rise in controlled rents over a long period of years.
There is "no single best way of teaching children to read," a policy conference of reading experts said today.
PARIS, June 3 One hundred thirty persons were killed today when an Air France Boeing 707 jet crashed and burned while taking off from Orly Airport for New York.
ATLANTA, June 3 (AP) The three small children of Mr. and Mrs. E.M. Bevington have one parent alive today their father because their parents made it a policy never to fly together.
A growing number of advertisers that have long sponsored radio and television shows are now beginning to sponsor books.
Teachers in the City University of New York will get $3,000,000 in salary increases for the coming school year, Gustave G. Rosenberg, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 3 Congress will return from a long Memorial Day vacation this week to attack a heavy backlog of work.

Beatrice Lillie has selected her next show, "Captain Isabelle." Absent from Broadway since she followed Greer Garson in "Auntie Mame" in 1958, Miss Lillie is planning to return here in December in Franklin Lacey's new musical.

MEMPHIS, June 3 (AP) Lionel Hebert threw the $40,000 Memphis open golf tournament into a three-way tie today by missing a three-foot putt on the eighteenth hole. Then he beat Gary Player and Gene Littler in a sudden-death play-off with a 30-foot putt for a birdie on the first hole.

SERQUIGNY, France, June ,3 Whatever emerges from the de Gaulle-Macmillan colloquy, the shape of Europe will ultimately change. This is true whether Britain succeeds or fails in entering the Common Market.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) --Three strong advocates and three leading opponents of President Kennedy's medical-care plan for the aged stoutly defended their positions today in a television debate on the American Broadcasting Company program "All America Wants to Know."

Widows of executives have argued repeatedly with the Federal Government over the tax status of the payments they often receive from their husbands' employers. The widows seem to be winning the battle.

Things certainly have changed in the Soviet Union when Premier Khrushchev can get up and confess error without blaming it all on capitalist wreckers or anti-party elements in the Presidium. His acknowledgment that miscalculations in Soviet economic planning are responsible for higher food prices is the more remarkable because all the wrong moves were in policy areas in which he has made his own most distinctive contributions to the reorientation of orthodox Marxist principles.
ALGIERS, June 3 The unity of the Right-wing terrorist Secret Army Organization appeared tonight to have been destroyed.
Jack P. Schleifer and Lawrence and Richard Zirinsky, New York realty investors, have sold the Central Bergen Industrial Terminal, a fortythree-acre property with thirtytwo buildings in Garfield, N.J.

LONDON, June 3 Following a day behind Wall Street, the stock market last week had the biggest single day's index plunge on record, regained most of its loss the next day, and then took cover to wait and see what would happen across the Atlantic.
The Citizens Union asked Mayor Wagner yesterday to confer with the city magistrates on the advisability of dropping the bail requirement for persons charged with minor offenses.
NEW DELHI, India, June 3 Political and educational leaders outlined a program today to curb divisive influences in India.

IN THE twelfth round of the current Candidates' Tour nament at Curacao, Victor Korchnoi of the Soviet Union was the victim of an aberration while designing a delayed capture, a finesse, against Bobby Fischer of the United States.

LONDON, Monday June 4 (Reuters) Most national newspapers published today fullpage advertisements of a plea made by Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery in yesterday's Sunday Express that Britain should not join the European Common Market.
WOMEN'S shoe styles are slowly but surely shaping the look of men's footwear, according to Duke J. Rose, the 37-year-old president of the Johnson Murphy Shoe Company of Nashville, Tenn.
Roman Catholic parochial schools were praised yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral as imparting a comprehensive education' and attaining a high standard of achievement for large numbers of students.
The congregations of two churches in midtown Manhattan participated in a Spanish-English communion service yesterday morning and took a long step toward permanent unification.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 3 Gower Champion, the directorchoreographer, revealed today why he was eager to forsake movie work for the Broadway stage.
PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (AP) Johnny Callison made four straight hits and drove in three runs today as the Philadelphia Phillies rallied to defeat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7-5.
The city's traffic courts are a "disgrace," the Automobile Club of New York charged yesterday. It called on Mayor Wagner to request a survey by the American Bar Association.

MONTREAL, June 3 (Canadian Press)--A system of bankers' acceptances will be introduced by Canadian chartered banks on June 11, R. D. Mulholland, president of the Canadian Bankers Association, announced today.
LIMA, Peru, June 3 Communism is the major issue in the campaign for next Sunday's Presidential election.
HONG KONG, June 3 The Peiping newspapers gave prominent display today to the Soviet Government's recent announcement of price increases for meat and butter.
The New York City schools are currently being scrutinized by managing experts, educational consultants and members of the Board of Education itself.

Two leases have been signed for space for expansion purposes in the twelve-story office and bank building at 149 Madison Avenue, southeast corner of Thirty-second Street, the M. Robert Steel Company, agent for the building, has announced.
The Golden Hill Chorus, conducted by Charles Ennis, gave its spring concert at Town Hall on Saturday night.

EVERYTHING from the French plane disaster to a glaring sun in the sculpture Court of the Museum of Modern Art conspired late yesterday afternoon to pose difficulties for a taped presentation of the controversy over the school of abstract expressionism. But even against such odds, the program turned out to be one of the more rewarding additions of "A Nation's Future."
PARIS, June 3 A Moslem political group rivaling the dominant National Liberation Front made a bid for a role in Algeria today.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 3-- The sudden resignation of Premier Ismet Inonu of Turkey last Wednesday is now considered by observers here to have been a skillful maneuver.

The lack of suitable recreational facilities for foreign seamen is being accentuated by the short time the average merchant vessel spends in a port, a conference on changing waterfronts was informed here last week.
Almost every day for the last several years Mr. and Mrs. Frank Mazzariello of the Bronx have faced a curious and exasperating experience.

OSLO, Norway, June 3 (AP) Socialists from twenty-one countries lashed out today at communism, upheld the right of democracies to arm against the Red threat and proclaimed their own ultimate aim to be "nothing less than world government."

PARIS, June 3 A recognition of the conflicting demands of curing unemployment and slow economic growth on the one hand and the loss of gold on the other dominates European and British comment on the economic troubles of the United States.
MOSCOW, June 3 The Soviet Union warned today that the United States, would seriously aggravate the international situation if it went through with plans for a series of high-altitude nuclear tests.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, June 3 Foreign Minister PaulHenri Spaak of Belgium sharply assailed today the idea that Europe should develop into "a third force between the United States and the Soviet Union." The "third force" concept has been attributed frequently to President de Gaulle of France.

PARIS, June 3--President de Gaulle and Prime Minister Macmillan ended today a week-end of conversations that French sources said had dissipated mutual suspicions arising from negotiations for British entry into the European Common Market.

PARIS, June 3 The Popular Republican Movement, France's big Roman Catholic party, expressed hostility today to most of President de Gaulle's foreign policy. But Popular Republican leaders made it clear that the party would not vote against him.
Four new films are due at local theatres this week. The programs follow:
Union employes of the A. Food Stores in Manhattan, the Bronx and three suburban counties voted yesterday to accept a new two-year contract.

TRENTON, N.J., June 3 Jiggs Peters, a 42-year-old driver from Neshanic, N.J., won the fourth annual 250-mile midget auto race and set a world record on Trenton's onemile paved speedway today. Peters averaged 94.475 miles an hour, eclipsing the mark of 94.338 he established in 1958 in winning the first running.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) Pesident Kennedy's top disarmament adviser said today the presence of neutral negotiators at the Geneva conference, "is bringing pressure on the Soviet Union" to make progress toward disarmament.

TRENTON, N.J., June 3 Jiggs Peters, a 42-year-old driver from Neshanic, N.J., won the fourth annual 250-mile midget auto race and set a world record on Trenton's onemile paved speedway today. Peters averaged 94.475 miles an hour, eclipsing the mark of 94.338 he established in 1958 in winning the first running.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) Pesident Kennedy's top disarmament adviser said today the presence of neutral negotiators at the Geneva conference, "is bringing pressure on the Soviet Union" to make progress toward disarmament.
Two former Presidents of the United States, Herbert Hoover and Harry S. Truman, will attend the city's luncheon today for M. Scott Carpenter, the astronaut.

WASHINGTON, June 4--The margin, about 2.5 per cent, by which Texas Democrats chose John Connally over Ralph Yarborough as their candidate for Governor isn't much. And at least once when Texas Democrats have shown so close a division, the Republican candidate has been elected in November.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, June 4 (UPI)-- More than 185 of an estimated number of 600 Indonesian paratroopers have been killed, captuned or wounded by Dutch military forces since the first invaders parachuted into Netherlands New Guinea in mid-May, Dutch military spokesmen said today.

The twelve-story Blackstone Hotel at 50 East Fifty-eighth Street between Madison and Park Avenues has been sold by William Wilson to an investing client of the Brener Lewis Company, the broker in the deal. It contains 187 rooms and occupies a plot 75 by 100 feet. Carb, Luria, Glassner Cook were the lawyers for the seller.

An international debate between two students from Oxford University and two from North Texas State University will be televised live by the National Broadcasting Company on Tuesday, July 3, from 7:30 to 8:30 P. M. The topic for debate has not been selected.
The Viking Press said yesterday that a Chinese book pirate on Taiwan had reproduced its trademark without consent. It said it was investigating what legal action could be taken.

With fourteen judgeships up for election here this fall under the new court reorganization, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz held a conference yesterday with political-party and election officials on ways of designating candidates.
A special program designed for mothers who are resident physicians in psychiatric medicine has been announced by New York Medical CollegeMetropolitan Hospital Center.
BOSTON, June 4 (AP)-- Ralph E. Wagers of Boston and Chicago was named president of the Mother Church, the First Church of Christ, Scientist, today. He succeeds Mrs. Mary Lee Gough Nay of Boston.

WASHINGTON, June 4--A convention of 2,000 literary hucksters and publishers moved into the capital today with tons of new book, including "How to Succeed at Touch Football," "How to Play Golf in the Low 120's" and an unexpurgated, now-it-can-be-told biography of Caroline Kennedy's pony, Macaroni.
WASHINGTON, June 4-- The Supreme Court today put off until next term decision of one of its weightiest pending cases--the dispute between Arizona and California over the water of the Colorado River.

MOSCOW, June 4--The Soviet Government accused the fishing industry today of being inefficiently run and of operating below its capabilities. Moscow called on the newly created State Committee for Fisheries and local authorities to implement a series of measures to increase the fish catch and processing.

RENO, Nev., June 4 (AP)-- Harolds Club, Reno's biggest casino, will be sold to a new Nevada corporation for more than $16,000,000, the casino's attorney confirmed today. The founding Smith family will continue operating the club under a lease-back arrangement.
Clem McCarthy, whose broadcasts thrilled racing fans for twenty years, died yesterday in the Dresden Madison Nursing Home. He was 79 years old.
THE Eastern States Championships tournament, which began May 25, will end today with a two-session final round in the knockout team contest for the Curt H. Reisinger Cup.
ROME, June 4--Prince Juan Carlos of Spain and his bride of three weeks, Princess Sophia of the Hellenes, called on Pope John XXIII in the Vatican today.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI)--The Supreme Court ruled today that the Secretary of Agriculture may not require compensation payments from dairy producers who take fluid milk into a regulated area from outside.

ATLANTA, June 4 (AP)-- Flags were flown at half-staff at the Georgia Capitol, the Courthouse and City Hall today to mark the sorrow of this city over the loss of more than a hundred of its million inhabitants in the plane crash at Paris ` on Sunday.

LISBON, Portugal, June 4 (UPI)--Medical students and their professors clashed with club-wielding policemen on the University of Lisbon campus today in one of the worst outbreaks of violence here in recent weeks.

SEOUL, Korea, June 4 (AP) --The United States Army charged two lieutenants todaywith "unlawful detention and assault and battery" in the beating of a South Korean caught stealing at a front-line base of the First Cavalry Division.

VIENNA, June 4--A second lieutenant of the Hungarian secret police who escaped to Austria under a hail of bullets early this month was found poisoned last night in the maximum-security room of the Austrian State Security headquarters in Vienna.
SCHOOLEYS MOUNTAIN, N.J., June 4--Laughing gas was used here experimentally yesterday as a substitute for smoke in quieting obstreperous bees in a hive.

PARIS, June 4--France's highest appeals court refused today to grant a retrial to Edmond Jouhaud, the former general who was condemned to death as second in command of the Algerian terrorist Secret Army Organization.

Television advertisers come in for some sharp criticism in two new books about broadcasting. Both volumes take the view that the sponsors must share the blame for the supposedly mediocre state of television programing.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 4 --Hollywood's moviemakers, who scrutinize possible trends as diligently as farmers study clouds, are mystified these days because they can't guess the trends for musicals, comedies, spectacles or low-budget movies.
ATLANTA, June 4--Governor Rockefeller replied today to a Democratic challenge on civil rights and issued one to President Kennedy in return.

Two weeks ago, President Kennedy told a White House Economic Conference that we must distinguish between myth and reality in considering today's complex economic problems. Since an important element of your job as financial writers is to increase public understanding of economic complexities, I am most happy to have this opportunity to discuss some of them with you.
ALGIERS, Tuesday, June 5 --A midnight deadline set by the Secret Army Organization for concessions by Algerian nationalists passed here without immediate violence.

PARIS, June 4--A broad inquiry was opened today by the French Government into yesterday's crash of an Air France jet at Orly Airport. But the cause of the crash, which took 130 lives, remained a mystery. The Boeing 707 had thundered down an Orly runway but had failed.
OSLO, Norway, June 4 (AP) --The Council of the Socialist International said today that the current United States nuclear tests were made necessary by the Soviet tests series last year.
Reports of widespread cheating on examinations are being investigated at Long Island University's Brooklyn Center.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) --The Supreme Court, by a 4 to-4 vote, held in effect today that Creek Indians had the burden of proving in a lawsuit a contention that the United States had not paid its treaty debts to them.

E.J. Korvette, Inc., operator of a chain of 17 discount department stores, achieved record sales and earnings in the 13 and 39 week periods ended April 29, William Willensky, president, reported yesterday.
It's great to be old and a Met--especially if you're Frank Thomas. You hit home runs and other clubs want to spring you from the cellar for good behavior.

Samuel I. Newhouse, owner of a chain of sixteen newspapers, announced yesterday he had gained control of The Times-Picayune Company. The company publishes the only two newspapers in New Orleans, the morning Times-Picayune and the afternoon States and Item.
A runway arresting gear to prevent airliner crashes like the one outside Paris Sunday is being developed in this country under the auspices of the Federal Aviation Agency.
GENEVA, June 4--The Soviet Union launched a concerted attack on two fronts here today against the United States program for a series of high-altitude nuclear tests.
HAVANA, June 4 (UPI)-- Conditions in Cuba will change for the better "in ten or twelve years," Premier Fidel Castro said yesterday in an impromptu speech published today by the official press.

The Department of Health announced yesterday that it had found all but four city beach areas free of water pollution and safe for bathing. It said its classification of the beaches remained unchanged from that of last year.
WASHINGTON, June 4-- Capital investment projections, disappointing to the hopes of the Kennedy Administration, were released by the government today.
Chile, which has a predominantly Roman Catholic population, has established an official governmental committee to devise measures for birth control.
ATHENS, June 4--Students of the Athens and Salonika technical schools of subengineers are continuing a "hunger strike till death" to press their demand for full university status.
J. Anthony Panuch has resigned from his $35,000-a-year post as vice president in charge of industrial exhibits of the World's Fair Corporation.
The election of C. Peter Strong, director of the American-Scandinavian Foundation since 1959, as its president and a trustee took place yesterday at a meeting of trustees.

QUITO, Ecuador, June 4 (AP) --Moderate liberal forces apparently have scored a clear victory in Ecuador's Congressional and municipal elections. The voting yesterday was marked by clashes that left at least three dead and seven injured.
The financial paths of Billie Sol Estes and Lowell Birrell crossed at a court hearing here yesterday.
PARIS, June 4--A study asked by President Kennedy of how the nations of Europe, particularly France, have done so well economically is under way.

MILAN, Italy, June 4--Sir Oswald Mosely, Right-wing British politician, affirmed in court today his "adherence to the principles of fascism." But he categorically denied that he had "ever inspired killing or assassination."
Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, asserted yesterday that despite the recent performance of the stock market, "there is a growing prospect of prosperity for our nation."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 4--A Bolivian delegate told the Trusteeship Council today the United States was administering its PaPcific trust islands "with a minimum of economic resources" in a "shoestring empire."

WASHINGTON, June 4--The State Department defended its speech-clearance policies today as Senator Strom Thurmond. Democrat of South Carolina, returned to his attack on the alleged "muzzling" of anti-Communist speeches by military officers.

The "Canyonlands" of southeastern Utah offer the prospect of adding fantastic scenery and geologic curiosities to the national park system. Here the Green and Colorado Rivers, eroding their gorges and abetted by other forces of nature through the ages, have transformed an ancient plateau into a maze of colorful canyons, arches, needles and standing rocks, all set amid stairstep benches and highlands that provide vistas of sweeping grandeur.
LONDON, June 4----The Cunard Steam-Ship Company, Ltd., lost more than 1,700,000 ($4,760,000) last year, but is making efforts to improve its financial position.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 4-- The Southern Baptist Convention, spreading rapidly from the South, is likely this year to become the largest Protestant denomination in the United, States.
Commodity trading continued to be overshadowed by the activity on the stock market yesterday as prices on the New York commodity exchanges moved in narrow ranges in light volume.
TRENTON, June 4--Gov. Richard J. Hughes signed the "slumlord" bill today.
President Kennedy will propose a "top to bottom" reduction in income tax rates for enactment by Congress next year, Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon said last night.
MOSCOW, June 4--The Bolshoi will take three new ballets to the United States on its twelve-week tour, which will open in the Metropolitan Opera House on Sept. 6.
New York business men of the Jewish Catholic and Protestant faiths were urged last night to join in program to improve the moral climate of the community.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) --The Supreme Court set aside today the murder conviction of a Denver boy who was sentenced to life imprisonment at the age of 14 as the slayer of an old man in a robbery. The court split 4 to 3.
CARACAS, Venezuela, June 4 A revolt of marines at the Puerto Cabello naval base was reported officially "over" today.
City taxicab drivers who are veterans of World War II may now transfer or sell their cab medallions, or licenses.

WHITE PLAINS, June 4-- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors defeated a motion by Democratic minority members today for an invesgation of all the business at Playland, the county's amusement park in Rye.
WASHINGTON, June 4--The Supreme Court set aside today the convictions of six Freedom Riders who had tried to de segregate a bus terminal in Shreveport, La.
WARSAW, June 4--Rain fell again today from Poland's leaden skies, and farmers read in their water-soaked fields omens of a crop disaster.

NOW and again, it must be sadly admitted, c im- inals have a dashing, bloodthirsty allure about them. They do their dreadful deeds sometimes with such a diabolical artistry that ordinary citizens are led to harbor just a little admiration and awe at their awful talent and glamour.
The promotion efforts of the United States Travel Service are apparently meeting with success, a Department of Commerce statistical report indicated yesterday.

Reports from The New York Times' correspondent in Saigon make clear that President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam continues to operate a Government suffering from dictatorial rigidities and extreme preoccupation with sup pressing its critics, however anti-Communist. Such policies constitute a dangerous impediment to the successful prosecution of the joint South Vietnam-American struggle against the Communist guerrillas known as the Viet Cong.

The specter of automation hung over a six-and-a-halfhour meeting of the International Longshoremen's Association yesterday. It precipitated repeated demands for a shorter work week and for increases in pension, welfare and vacation benefits.
LUANG PRABANG, June 4 (Reuters)--Two British doctors arrested by pro-Communist guerrillas on May 26 were reported today to be under open arrest at a rebel-held village in southern Laos.
LONDON, June 4--Britain will compensate three Bahreinis who were deported to the island of St. Helena for five years.
DORTMUND, Germany, June 4--Economics Minister Ludwig Erhard demanded today that the Common Market be opened to all free European nations willing to underwrite its goals.

TIRANA, Albania, June 4 (UPI)--The Albanian Communist regime is hoping for early economic assistance from West Germany, sources said here today. They added that the isolated Communist regime also had hopes for assistance from Greece and Italy.

KATMANDU, Nepal, June 4 --Two former Premiers of Nepal, Tanka Prasad Acharya and Dr. Kunwar Indar Singh, were among fifteen members of Nepal's National Council nominated today by King Mahendra to take part in an allNepal intellectuals' conference beginning here Wednesday.

Bethlehem Steel Company has claimed a new American record, possibly a world mark, for one month's production from a blast furnace, on the 92,124 tons of iron poured in May by the "B" furnace at Bethlehem, Pa.
MOSCOW, June 4 (Reuters) --Vladimir Trusenev of the Soviet Union set a world record today in Leningrad of 61.64 meters (202 feet 2 inches) for the discus throw.
WHITE PLAINS, June 4-- Candidates for Congress and two county offices were designated tonight by the Westchester Democratic County Committee in its convention at the County Center.
Broadway stage directors and choreographers appear to be getting closer to their goal of achieving union status.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 4-- Roger M. Blough, chairman of United States Steel Corporation, told a press conference here today that he bore no bitterness towards the Kennedy Administration for its actions in the battle over steel prices in April.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) --The Supreme Court refused today to review a decision that the Kohler Company of Kohler Wis., was guilty of unfair labor practices in its prolonged dispute with the United Automobile Workers.
PEIPING, June 4 (Reuters)-- China has accused India of following a policy of "out-andout great power chauvinism" in connection with her northern borders.
WELLESLEY, Mass., June 4 (AP)--Santha Rama Rau, Indian author, urged Wellesley College graduates today to help develop values "that transcend national boundaries."
LONDON, June 4--Australia will protect "her own interests" should Britain erect trade barriers against her products, Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies declared tonight.

HARTFORD, June 4--Senator John Sherman, Cooper of Kentucky, keynote speaker for the Connecticut Republican State Convention, accused the Kennedy Administration tonight of making "unprecedented demands for power."

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 4 (AP)--The United States Information Agency is sponsoring a contest here for a new name for the Vietcong guerrillas, who are fighting to overthrow President Ngo Dinh Diem's Government.
EASTCHESTER, N.Y., June 4--Miss Suzanne Prentice and Thomas Edward Ambler 2d plan to be married in November.

Inspector Edward M. Joseph, the highest ranking officer of the 1,200-man Port Authority police force, died Sunday in his home at 23 Elmira Street, Oakwood, S.I., after a long illness. He was 52 years old.
Traffic courts should be removed from the criminal court system and maintained as a separate unit with specially trained judges, Chief Magistrate Abraham M. Bloch said yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 4--The nation's railroads agreed today to pay 500,000 off-train employes wage increases averaging 10.28 cents an hour.

Trading in over-the-counter issues was much less hectic yesterday than during last week's sell-off and subsequent partial recovery. As a result, traders were able to take short lunch breaks for the first time in a week.
SPARROWS POINT, Md., June 4--To the casual eye, the mill seemed almost frighteningly efficient. A seven-ton block of luminous, coral-red steel had been hoisted minutes
Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich yesterday ordered lawyers for the state and a dock workers' union to stop bickering and work together on details of a nondiscrimination policy for the union.
TOTOWA, N.J., June 4--Twenty-one defendants pleaded guilty today to fixing traffic tickets and were fined a total of $1,100.

Joseph Linyear's Loco, an eight-year-old dark brown stallion, won the Brooklyn Derby yesterday in a field of thirteen, covering three miles in 25:07 4/5 on a fast winding track through downtown Brooklyn.
The Sperry Hutchinson Company, a large tradingstamp concern, is acting to defend the right of gasoline station operators to put up signs advertising competitive stamps.

Edgar Kobak, a business consultant and former radio and publishing executive, died Sunday of a cerebral hemorrhage at the Marlborough-Blenheim Hotel in Atlantic City. Mr. Kobak, who was 67 years old and a resident of the Sheraton-East Hotel, had gone to Atlantic City to attend a meeting of the Edison Electric Institute.
"Anything being sold out here today is worth more than a piece of paper you can buy in Wall Street," said Humphrey Finney at the Belmont Park stable area yesterday.
CARACAS, June 4 (AP)-- Government troops wiped out the last Leftist snipers in Puerto Cabello today and ended the bloodiest revolt against President Romulo Betancourt's regime.

Refused unanimously to interfere with the conviction of Harry Lanza for refusing to answer questions of a New York inquiry into parole practices--questions that Lanza said stemmed from electronic eavesdropping on his conversation in a jail cell but that the court held were at least in part independent of any such eavesdropping (No. 236, Lanza V.N.Y.).
MOSCOW, June 4--Avery Brundage, the president of the International Olympic Committee, said today. "One of the greatest difficulties we have is to prevent politica, interference with sport."
WASHINGTON, June 4--A brother of Billie Sol Estes helped sign up farmers whose Federal cotton allotments wound up in Billie Sol's hands.
PARIS THE French high fashion in- dustry finds itself at an important crossroads.

PARIS, June 4--Premier Georges Pompidou of France foresaw today a "rearrangement" of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to take account of the changing balance of power between the United States and Europe.
WASHINGTON, June 4,-- should shorts be permitted in the halls of Congress?
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 4--Dr. Martin Buber said today he was inclined to view the execution of Adolf Eichmann as a "mistake of historical dimension."
PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 4 (AP)--Brown University ended its 194th Commencement Week today by awarding degrees to 716 seniors and graduate students.
LUANG PRABANG, Laos, June 4--Prince Souvanna Phouma said today that he was calling a "tripartite" meeting for Thursday to discuss the formation of a coalition government for Laos.
Except for a brisk and strong demand for short-term United States Government securities, they bond market yesterday was a perfunctory sideshow to the drastic new price decline in common stock values.

While volume on the New York Stock Exchange has been running at the highest level since 1929, business on the American Stock Exchange-- aside from an explosion last Tuesday--has been running pretty close to normal.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI)--Robert S. McNamara, Secretary of Defense, said today that he had no plans to set up an all-inclusive United States armed service to combine the Army, Navy and Air Force.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) --Edward A. McDermott, director of the Office of Emergency Planning, ruled today that imports of surplus military rifles do not threaten national security.

BIRMINGHAM, England, June 4 (Reuters)--England took a 1-0 lead over Pakistan in their five-match cricket series today, by winning the first test by an innings and 24 runs. England won the five-day match with more than a day and a half to spare.

THE seats of honor at the annual dinner of the Metropolitan Bowling Writers Association Sunday in the Hotel Lexington will be occupied by Dick Weber of St. Louis, Mrs. Shirley Garms of Chicago, Fred Lening of Yardley, Pa., Mrs. Richard Furst of New York and

WASHINGTON, June 4--A task force of United States business men has started a lowcost housing operation in the Dominican Republic. The operation is the first joint LatinAmerican project of the Alliance for Progress to be conducted by private enterprise.
MOSCOW, June 4--The Soviet Union raised again today before its people the specter of a surprise nuclear rocket attack by the United States.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 4 (AP)--A Negro woman on crutches from Louisville, Ark., became today the thirty-fourth "reverse Freedom Rider" to leave Little Rock on a one-way bus ticket.

The Department of Markets yesterday accused Dilberts Grocers Inc., of 22 West Thirtyfourth Street, of selling spoonbill fish as lake sturgeon. Summonses were issued to the corporation and to two of its employes.
ACCRA, Ghana, June 4-- President Kwame Nkrumah declared tonight that the United Nations should make a "firm declaration calling upon the colonial powers to quit Africa by Dec. 31, 1962."

MINEOLA, L.I., June 4--The Nassau County Board of Supervisors will authorize further studies of the county's water resources as the first step toward a comprehensive plan for water distribution and conservation.
Fred (Butch) Baird a 150pound pro from Galveston, Tex., led a large field of big-name golfers at Memphis, Tenn., yesterday in the sectional qualifying competition for the United States Open.

NEW DELHI, India, June 4 (AP)--Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru denied today Pakistani press accounts of massacres of Moslems in India's State of West Bengal near the Pakistani border in March and April.

MONTE CARLO, June 4-- There are 145,000 bowl- ing lanes in the world, and 3,000 of them are outside the United States. There are four here, fifty yards from the casino and surrounded by one of world's most elegant cocktail lounges. In Monte Carlo, Prince Rainier has Locker
KATMANDU, Nepal, June 4 --An expedition of British women has climbed the 22,000-feet Kanjiroba Himal in Western Nepal, the Nepali Foreign Office announced today.
MONTREAL, June 4--S. Morgan-Powell, a classic figure of Canadian journalism, died today on his ninety-fifth birthday.

LONDON, June, 4--Almost every section of the stock market fell today. The decline was caused by apprehension about the upheaval on Wall Street, by an absence of buyers and by a steady dribble of small selling.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) --American Communists preach racial equality but do not practice it, a former member of the party told House investigators today.
WASHINGTON, June 4--An attempt to set off a thermonuclear explosion high over Johnston Island in the mid-Pacific failed today when electronic difficulties developed in the launching rocket.

CHERRY BLOSSOM time is one of the prettiest of all seasons; it also is one of the shortest. There is one consolation, however. When the showy blossoms die, fruit begins to form and soon it is time for ripe cherries. Unfortunately, the fresh cherry season is also short. In this area, June and July are peak months for the fruit.
The States Education Commissioner has set up a committee of three citizens to advise him and the state school system on problems in human rerelations and community tensions.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 4 (AP)--The Tennessee Su preme Court upheld today the dismissal of charges against two men who could not be tried for murder because only two jurors could be found.

SIR OSBERT SITWELL'S "Tales My Father Taught Me"* shows the advantage a man who writes about the dreamy past enjoys over a man who writes about the nightmare future. For no one can revise what happened far away and long ago.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes staged his first big Broadway production yesterday with a cast of thousands.
WASHINGTON, June 4-- Night club dancing girls who complain that their union has not been protecting their interests will have an opportunity to tell their story to a Senate committee.
OTTAWA, June 4--Electricity from atomic energy was produced by Canada for the first time today.
LONDON, June 4--The reserves of gold and convertible currencies held by Britain as central banker for the sterling area rose last month by 19,000,000 ($53,200,000).

The Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Joan Aleen Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Albert Johnston Jr. of 65 Central Park West, to Charles Clarke Ambrose, son of Mrs. Oliver Stephens Ambrose of Westfieid, N. J., and the late Mr. Ambrose.
WASHINGTON, June 4--The Public Health Service has recommended to President Kennedy that a board be established to study possible links between smoking and certain diseases.
BUENOS AIRES, June 4-- Argentina's Peronist leadership will try to form a broad National Republican Front, seeking adherents from parties all across the political spectrum.

A school spokesman said yesterday that the Board of Education was insisting upon a nostrike pledge from teachers as a condition of a new contract that would provide more than $30,000,000 in salary increases starting July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP)--A key member of the House Ways and Means Committee indicated today that he would vote to keep President Kennedy's plan on medical care for the aged from reaching the House floor.
WASHINGTON, June 4-- The Treasury Department's announcement today on the results of its weekly auctioning of bills showed slight increases in borrowing costs over the previous issues.

Rose Net of the Foxcatcher Farm did what was expected of him--and then some--at Belmont Park yesterday. The 6-year-old son of Nasrullah was the 11-to-10 favorite of the 28,086 customers, and he came through, with a seven-length triumph over Flying Mercury of the Alamode Farm in the $10,000 feature.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 4 (AP)--The Supreme Court de cision invalidating compensatory payments, into a milk-producer settlement fund "may open the floodgates for outside milk" to enter the New YorkNew Jersey milkshed, a dairy spokesman said today.
TRENTON, June 4--The State Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the state may permit a blood transfusion for a sick child despite objections by his parents on religious grounds.
WASHINGTON, June 4--An attack on the use of electronic eavesdropping devices in a New York jail failed in the Supreme Court today without any resolu tion of the constitutional claims.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 4--A political attache of the United States Embassy said today he fired two shots at a prowler early this morning. Later a Congolese was found dead on his lawn.

Stocks once again were caught in a downdraught yesterday. Compared with that of the preceding Monday it was gentle but it swept away $11,000,000,000 in aggregate market value. Turnover was 5,380,000 shares against 5,760,000 on Friday and 9,350,000 a week ago yesterday.
A young actor who summarily took off last Saturday for Greece, where his wife is making a film, caused the producers of a Broadway musical hit some anxious moments yesterday.
Steel production declined again last week. It was the ninth consecutive week-to-week drop and took production to the lowest level in more than fourteen months.

Dan McDermott, a 17-yearold right-hander, pitched a nohitter yesterday as Curtis High of Staten Island defeated Tilden of Brooklyn, 14--0, in a Public School Athletic League semifinal baseball game at Pratt Field, Brooklyn.
AUSTIN, Tex., June 4 (AP) --Don Yarborough conceded defeat today in his bid for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
DETROIT, June 4 (AP)--The Chevrolet division of General Motors will push its 1962 calendar-year production past the 1,000,000-mark this week.
TOPEKA, Kan. June 4 (UPI) --A New York woman, daughter of an industrialist, was found strangled in her apartment today.
LONDON, June 4--Cecil Harmsworth King, one of Britain's most influential publishers, warned today that indirect censorship was curtailing the liberty of the British press.
A Federal court narcotics conspiracy trial was thrown into momentary, shocked silence yesterday when an enraged defendant suddenly hurled a heavy wooden witness chair at the prosecutor.

Each time a revolt from the Left is tried and fails in Venezuela, the hope arises that the Leftists will see there is no possibility of succeeding in present circumstances. On May 5 there was a marine uprising in Carupano and there had been other uprisings before. Last week-end there was still another and far more sanguinary revolt in Puerto Cabello.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 4 (AP)--Small groups of the United States troops who landed in Thailand last month are being brought to combat zones in South Vietnam for training, an in formed American military source said today.
