The Dean of Columbia College predicted yesterday that Students entering college in the future would face a more severe "intellectual hurdle" than is faced by current high school graduates.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4 (AP)--Admiral George W. Anderson Jr., Chief of Naval Operations, told the Annapolis graduating class today "the generation and maintenance of moral strength and courage are essential to the military power of our nation."

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., June 4--Mr. and Mrs. P. Corbin Kohn have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Childs Kohn, to Albert Nelson Hobart 3d of St. Louis. He is the son of Mrs. E. Frank Martin of St. Louis and Albert N. Hobart of Miami, Fla.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 4--The South African Government is starting a major drive to bring in settlers from Europe. fully planned and selective immigration projects in modern times.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 4--A committee charged with setting up a new agency to channel funds to under-developed nations decided today to open its doors to any country its executive board approves of, whether or not it is a member of the United Nations or the specialized agencies.
Copying machines produced multiple attractions yesterday for office executives at the opening of the 1962 National Business Show at the New York Coliseum.

SAIGON, Vietnam; June 4 (AP)--A United States professor under investigation by the South Vietnamese Government on charges of political plotting received an exit visa today. He had waited for the permit to leave for a month.

WASHINGTON, June 4--The Administration's foreign trade bill emerged from the House Ways and Means Committee today with heavy bipartisan backing. send it to the floor of the House of Representatives was 20 to 5.
Eight cars of a New York Central freight train went off their tracks in the Bronx last night, disrupting service on the Central's Harlem Division and on the New Haven Railroad.
MONTREAL, June 4 (AP)-- Doug Harvey tonight resigned as playing coach of the New York Rangers.
OLD TOWN; Me.,June 4 Max Conrad took off from municipal airport today on his ninety-first trans-Atlantic flight in a single-engine plane.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) --The Supreme Court ruled today that a husband had realized a taxable gain when he transferred to his divorced wife, in return for release of other claims, assets that had increased in value during his ownership.
The Rev. Dr. Stuart Hamilton Merriam, ousted minister of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, will be tried by a court of his peers on charges of "untruthfulness" and "tale bearing."
PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (UPI)--Sandy Koufax pitched a three-hitter and struck out thirteen tonight as he put the Los Angeles Dodgers back on their feet with a 6-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.
ROME, June 4--The floating laboratory of Guglielono Marconi, sunk in the harbor of Zara, Yugoslavia, during World War II, will be salvaged and turned over to Italy as a national monument.

The Administration, the country and the free world have all won a victory with the overwhelming approval by the House Ways and Means Committee of the bill to give the President increased flexibility in cutting tariffs. The strong support for the measure is an indication of the firmness with which the people of this country are committed to the idea of tearing down trade barriers rather than building them still higher.
MONMOUTH, Ill., June 4 (UPI)--It's now Dr. Stan Musial.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 4-- Nearly 150 lepers who hobbled from the Banmethuot leprosarium last week after Commu nists had kidnapped their American physician are believed to be missing in the rain forests of the central highlands.
Proceeds from a Bordeaux wine tasting at the Cafe Chauveron next Tuesday will go to the Multiple Sclerosis Clinic at the Hospital for Special Surgery.

The failure of our first attempt to explode a high-altitude nuclear device in the current series calls attention again to the fact that the United States is preparing to carry out these tests unilaterally despite protests of many leading astronomers and astrophysicists in this and other countries, including Britain.
Last week's heavy volume of trading in the stock market helped the nation's brokerage houses and their personnel. It beefed up the firms' profits, which had been dwindling for
WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI)--The Immigration and Naturalization Service said today it had temporarily halted deportations to Hong Kong, now jammed with refugees from Communist China.
IF William Faulkner had intended his new novel, "The Reivers," to illustrate the academic theory of comedy, he could hardly have done better.
BRUSSELS, June 4--The Council of Ministers, of the European Economic Community approved tariff increases tonight in reprisal against increases on imports of carpets and glass by the United States.

HANOVER N.H. Visitors to the Dartmouth College commencement on Sunday will see in brick, cement, stone and glass what many have only read about or seen in unadorned steel framework-- the Hopkins Center for the performing and creative arts.
State Supreme Court Justice, J. Vincent Keogh received a new Dodge automobile, storm windows for his city home and free medical care from Dr. Robert M. Erdman, it was disclosed yesterday.

Gary Gubner, New York University's shot-put prodigy, has smashed another record--this one of dubious merit. His put of 63 feet 9 inches in Compton, Calif., last Saturday night probably shattered the world record for a shot-putter with one foot in the bucket.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 4-- Californians vote tomorrow in a primary election highlighted by the national interest in its effect on the future of Richard M. Nixon.

Queens Democrats picked Borough President John T. Clancy last night as their candidate for Surrogate and named Assemblyman William G. Giaecio of Corona as his running mate for City Court. Assemblyman Louis Wallach of Little Neck and 3 for Assistant District Attorney Frank Cacciatore of Astoria. Two or three scattered nays were heard on the voice vote making the selection unanimous.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 4, --The Suffolk Board of Supervisors agreed today to start immediate proceedings to acquite 3,800 acres of wetlands along the Peconic and Carmans Rivers.
RALEIGH, N.C., June 4 (AP)--Judge Raymond Mallard denied today motions to dismiss charges against six men and two companies accused of influence-peddling in highway sign procurement.

MADISON, Wis., June 5 (UPI)--The Wisconsin Supreme Court ruled today that the state's controversial parochial school bus law was unconstitutional. The 4-2 decision knocked out a law, passed by the Legislature in 1961, that was to have gone into effect July 1.
A detailed explanation of why Lieut Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter overshot his intended landing point by 250 miles was put forth yesterday by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

LONDON, June 5 (AP)-- Max. Lionel Holliday, an 81year-old English farmer who has tried for thirty years to win the Epsom Derby, found his colt Hethersett, firmly favored tonight to make his dream come true. The mile-and-a-half Derby is set for tomorrow at Epsom Downs.

OVERLAND PARK, Kan., June 5--Dr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Miller have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Alling Miller, to Keith Andrew Libbey. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Wesley Libbey of Grand Rep. ids, Minn. The couple will be married on July 28. The future bride is a granddaughter of Norman Thomas, the Socialist leader.

CHICAGO, June 5 (UPI)-- Negotiators for the nation's railroads and 450,000 off-train employer announced tonight that they had reached agreement on wage increases as recommended by the President's fact-finding board.
PARIS, June 5--Ambassador James M. Gavin is scheduled to go to Washington next weekend with a new argument for negotiating a nuclear weapons agreement with France.
A former civilian administrative employe in the Army Reserve was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of taking bribes from reservists in return for preferential treatment.
The Arizona Public Service Company has sold $25,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds to institutional investors, it was announced yesterday.
BISMARCK, N.D., June 5 (UPI)--Dr. Larson denied President Kennedy's charge today that the A.M.A. opposed Social Security. He called the charge a "smoke screen."
Sixty per cent of the tickets for the opening week of benefit concerts at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts have been sold.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., June 5 (UPI)--United States District Judge Arthur Stanley Jr. ruled today that George John Gessner, an Army deserter, was mentally incapable of standing trial on charges of passing restricted military information to the Russians.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5-- The Mets managed to avoid losing their sixteenth straight ball game tonight and a harsh critic would say that the only reason they did was because their date with the Phillies at Connie Mack Stadium was rained out. A twilight-night double-header is listed here for tomorrow.

A twilight-night double-header at Cleveland and a game under the sponsorship of professional football's Hall of Fame are included in a thirty-six-game exhibition schedule announced yesterday by the National Football League. The schedule covers a period of six weeks.

More than 1,000 uniformed firemen, city officials and guests stood quietly in the rain yesterday to pay tribute to twenty-nine fire-fighters-- eight who lost their lives in fires during the last year and twenty-one who were cited for heroism.

Forceful evidence of the hurt we do our own trade program every time we lapse into protectionism is provided by the decision of the Council of Ministers of the European Economic Community to increase tariffs on certain American chemicals, paints and textiles. This step was taken in reprisal against the higher imposts President Kennedy recently ordered on American imports of sheet glass and woven carpets.

HARTFORD, Wednesday, June 6--John Alsop of Avon won the Republican nomination for Governor of Connecticut early this morning on the eighth ballot at the party convention. The convention had been deadlocked more than ten hours.
In a step in their program to make tennis a major sport in New York City high schools, the Eastern Tennis Patrons said yesterday they would award two college scholarships.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday plans for making a market study of three hectic trading days last week--Monday, Tuesday and Thursday--when almost 35,000,000 shares changed hands.
CHICAGO, June 5 (AP)--A bobble on what could have been a triple play blossomed into a five-run San Francisco eighth inning today as the Giants romped to an 11-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
Redemptions of outstanding Series E and H savings bonds exceeded new bond sales by $49,000,000 in May, a slightly smaller margin than the $52,000,000 in April.

A major Democratic primary contest took shape in Queens yesterday less than twenty-four hours after the party's executive committee designated its slate for judicial, Congressional and state legislative office.
The stock marked got off the roller coaster yesterday and moved onto a see-saw.
World sugar futures continued their decline yesterday and, with moderate activity in cocoa futures, led commodity trading in an otherwise dull day on the New York exchanges.
White business men were accused yesterday of conspiring to prevent Negro merchants from doing business in a prime shopping area in Harlem.
New York University will graduate 5,843 students at its 130th annual commencement exercises today before an expected audience of 12,000 persons.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 5-- West Coast shipowners in a "last offer" have proposed to arbitrate all issues involved in the West Coast maritime strike halted by a Taft-Hartley injunction on April 11.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) --Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen accused the Air Force today of requiring some of its civilian employes to enlist in the Air Force Reserve as a price for getting or keeping their jobs and winning promotion.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 5--A militant group of Vineland, N.J., business leaders embarked here today on a twoday drive to lure industry from northern New Jersey. Their battle cry is "The south Will Rise Again." Vineland is fourteen miles south of the MasonDixon Line.

The editorial board of Christianity and Crisis, a weekly journal of Protestant opinion, assailed the American Medical Association yesterday for its attack on the President's program for medical care for the aged under Social Security.

MOSCOW, June 5--The Soviet Communist party warned today that the cultural exchange program was in danger of getting out of hand if it permitted alien ideological views to be spread in the Soviet Union without effective rebuttal.
Edward N. Costikyan, Democratic county leader who conducts symphony orchestras for relaxation, employed a musical metaphor last night to chart a course for his party in the city and state.
Baltimore County, Md., announced yesterday plans for the sale of serial bonds totaling $18,800,000. Bids will be received on June 27.

Admiral Edwin J. Roland, the new Commandant of the Coast Guard, presented the American Merchant Marine Institute's Jones F. Devlin safety awards yesterday to thirty-nine United States-flag merchant vessels.

The Sperry Rand Corporation achieved record sales of $1,182,554,230 in the fiscal year ended March 31, compared with the peak volume of $1,176,999,343 reached in the preceding year, Earnings, however declined, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
The television industry's merchandising specialists, who until now have concentrated mainly on the juvenile market, have now begun to go after the adult trade.
DES MOINES, June 5 (AP)--Harold Hughes, a Democrat who advocates the sale of liquor by the drink, will challenge Norman Erbe, Republican Governor in Iowa's general election this fall.

The Austrian police knew him as Bela Lapusnyik, a deserter from the Hungarian secret police. A few weeks ago he had apparently forced his way over the frontier in a hail of bullets, bringing with him a package of documents which were said to have incriminated Communist spies and informers in Austria and other Western countries.

LONDON, June 5--Most sections of the stock market were weak today following yesterday's sharp fall on Wall Street. Most buyers awaited further developments in New York. The decline in volume was shown by the number of officially recorded deals, 11,800, a drop of 1,200 from yesterday's total.

Sixteen names of potential judges are being submitted to Mayor Wagner in the first application of a plan he says is aimed at taking judgeships out of politics and making selections free of possible corruption.
A trainload of sleepy-eyed commuters demonstrated yesterday that it took more than a men's fashion show to shake them from their early morning lethargy.

LOS ANGELES, June 5-- The Philadelphia Orches tra, which is bringing sweetness and light to the West Coast on the last leg of its transcontinental tour, opened the Los Angeles International Music Festival last night.
WASHINGTON, June 5-- Makarios III, Archbishop, former rebel and first President of the republic of Cyprus, received tributes and salutes here today at the
GENEVA, June 5--The United States strongly affirmed today a desire to see nuclear weapons eliminated from the arsenals of all states.

Fourteen wholesale concerns, seventeen individuals and three trade associations that do a yearly business of $40,000,000 in food products in the metropolitan area were indicted yesterday on charges of violating the antitrust laws.
Automation will play a substantial part in the development of all forms of transporttation, including the American merchant marine, a high Federal official said here yesterday,
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 5-- Communist guerrillas raided a district headquarters of the South Vietnamese Government in the Mekong delta early yesterday, killing eighteen persons.
Dr. William Beebe, naturalist and explorer whose dives to the ocean floor in a bathysphere won him fame a generation ago, died Monday night in Trinidad at the age of 84.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. announced last night that he had ordered an investigation by the House Committee on Education and Labor, of which he is chairman into alleged charges of discrimination in the New York City Fire Department.

Irving Maidman, West Side Raltor investor and builder, has purchased the plant occuled by the John Reber Bakery Corporation at 519 to 523 West forty-seventh Street, between Tenth and Eleventh Avenues. the bakery will move July 1 to

PARIS, June 5--Today's trouble started fifteen years ago when Gen. George Marshall made a speech at Harvard suggesting Europe should get together. Europe could then ask for American aid on an integrated basis and end the patchwork approach. From this grew the Marshall Plan.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 5--The Mashona basket weavers are being forced to leave South Africa.
Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, warned 6,100 graduating students yesterday that they and their contemporaries must reject futilitarian philosophies.
WASHINGTON, June 5-- The Democratic leaders of Congress told President Kennedy today that they would welcome the tax-cut proposal that he is planning for 1963.
WASHINGTON, June 5-- President Kennedy challenged the American Medical Association today to say that it always approved and still endorsed the Social Security System.

A strong possibility that paper ballots will be used in the Sept. 6 primary has developed as a result of the fact that the Board of Estimate has thus far not voted the $4,000,000 needed to buy modern voting machines.
CARACAS, Venezuela, June 5--The death toll in the abortive revolt by marines at Puerto Cabello was unofficially placed today at 400. The number of wounded was estimated at more than 1,000.
WASHINGTON, June 5--The United States is offering the European Economic Community a conciliatory package of lower tariffs to make up for increased duties on carpets and glass.

BONN, Germany, June 5-- Foreign Minister Geyhard Schroeder confirmed today that Karl Heinrich Knappstein, chief of the West German mission that acts as an observer for Bonn at the United Nations, will replace Prof. Wilhelm Grewe as Ambassador to the United States.
Ground-breaking ceremonies for construction of the Harlem Hospital Center will be held next October, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.

RYE, N.Y., June 5--George Haggarty of Detroit and James H. McAlvin of Lake Forest, Ill., shared the first-round lead in the United States Seniors' Golf Association's fifty-eighth annual championship today.

Julius Kaufman, a founder and formerly executive vice president, treasurer and a director of Dejay Stores, Inc., a chain of retail apparel and household appliance stores, died of a heart attack Monday in the IRT subway station at Lexington Avenue and Seventyseventh Street. He was 66 years old and lived at 35 Sutton Place.

David Ross, producer-director-operator of the internationally known Fourth Street Theatre, at 83 East Fourth Street, is branching out. He and his wife, Carmel, will follow the uptown trend toward the Lincoln Center by establishing a playhouse of the newest style in that area in the fall.

WASHINGTON, June 5--A scientific advisory committee has criticzied the United States program for monitoring fallout as inadequate. It has recommended that the Public Health Service substantially increase its surveillance and control of radioactive contamination.
Education in the United States is dominated by fear rather than by the power of constructive imagination, T.M. Stinnett of the National Education Association said here yesterday.

PARIS, Wednesday, June 6-- Edmond Jouhaud, in a dramatic appeal last night from his prison death cell, urged that the Secret Army Organization halt immediately its campaign of terrorism against the Algerian peace accords.

Interest rates on the biggest consumer credit item--homes --continued to decline in May, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. For anyone buying or building houses the decrease means lower carrying charges.

The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival will mark its thirtieth anniversary year with a tenweek season of dance performances that will begin on June 28 and run through Sept. 1. A total of sixty-five performances will be given in the Ted Shawn Theatre, which is nine miles southeast of Lee, Mass.
Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter flew into and out of New York yesterday through overcast weather that would have canceled the orbital flight that brought him glory.

WASHINGTON, June 5--The main issues of the 1962 Congressional election campaign are now coming clear. They are, for the most part, the traditional Republican issues against a Democratic Administration--namely, that President Kenedy is power-hungry, anti-business, and fiscally irresponsible.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 5-- Senator John G. Tower charged here tonight that one of the greatest scandals in American history was "breaking around" the Kennedy Administration.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 5 (UPI)--Gov. John Patterson ordered the Legislature today to convene in special session next Tuesday to consider reapportionment.
WASHINGTON, June 5-- Further Federal financial support for the New York World's Fair of 1964-65 has been threatened by the addition of a single word to the 1962 foreign aid bill.
Mrs. George Hyam and Mrs. Howeth T. Ford, co-chairmen of the eighth annual Pink and White Ball, met recently with their committee at Carlton House to complete arrangements for the event.
MONTREAL, June 5 (UPI)-- The National Hockey League picked five players from the Western League today during the annual interleague draft session.
LONDON, June 5--President de Gaulle recognizes the "enormous importance" of the British Commonwealth and of maintaining its strength, Prime Minister Macmillan said in the House of Commons today.
PARIS, June 5--As aviation experts pursued their investigation into Sunday's air tragedy at Orly Airport, President de Gaulle added his voice to those who have expressed sympathy for the victims.

WASHINGTON, June 5--The United States Government was reported today to be deeply disturbed over the threat of a military coup d'etat in Peru if Victor Raul Haya de la Torre is elected president in next Sunday's elections.
Scattered bullishness was visible in the bond market yesterday in an irregular session still largely eclipsed by the heavy churning of common stock shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

School may be a bitter pill to a large percentage of the city's pupils. But one high school in Brooklyn attracts them in droves, and with high zeal, by bus, subway and even ferryboat. It even turns some away.
LIMA, Peru, June 5--A retired army general and a Roman Catholic priest are the leaders in an active political campaign being waged in Peru by advocates of a Cuban-style revolution.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) --Defense-minded Senators added more than a quarter of a billion dollars to a record peacetime annual military money bill today but they attempted go keep their decisions secret.

ORDINARILY when one thinks of art in sports it is in connection with something like Sugar Ray Robinson's footwork, Joe Louis' combinations, Dick Durrance hurtling down a slalom course or someone like the late John Dieckman casting. But art is not motion or technique alone. It can be found in the tools of sport, and, indeed, it is derived from the sport.
Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh performed her last official function at Barnard College yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 5-- The Senate took up the $4,662,000,000 foreign-aid authorization bill today but with such evident indifference that leaders considered bringing it to a vote tommorrow to avoid laying it aside indefinitely.
A FORMIDABLE array of American drivers and equipment has been marshaled for the twenty-four hour world championship race at Le Mans, France, on June 23, 24.

DORTMUND, Germany, June 5--Chancellor Adenauer said today that he would not consider any East German request for large-scale credits unless the Communist regime restored freedom of movement for the people of Berlin.

Elliott Kahaner, former Federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, denied yesterday that he had conspired with Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh and others to fix the sentence of three men convicted of bankruptcy fraud.

THE sophisticated impishness of Hermione Badde ley and Cyrll Ritchard, in a fragile "Festival Revue" encompassing moments of extremely attractive hilarity and moments of rather specialized appeal, served last night to bring to a close the first cycle of "Festival of Performing Arts" over Channel 5. Surely, there can be no doubt of the festival's return next fall.

PITTSBURGH, June 5 (AP) --Sparked by the slugging of Willie Davis and the pitching of Stan Williams and Larry Sherry, the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Pittsburgh Pirates 3--2, tonight in the first game of a double-header at Forbes Field.
In an address to graduates at Queens College, Paul G. Hoffman, managing director of the United Nations Special Fund, called yesterday for a continuance of their fight against injustice.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) --The possibility that the proposed consolidation of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway and the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad might be jeopardized by employe job security requirements was raised today by the two railroads.
Earnings of the Paramount Pictures Corporation in the first half of this year will be below those of the 1961 period, Barney Balaban, president, disclosed following the annual meeting here yesterday.

The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it would ask the city today for permission to restore bus service on the Seventy-second Street crosstown and Upper Seventh Avenue routes of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc.
Thousands of commuters on the New York Central System and the New Haven Railroad were delayed during the morning and evening rush hours yesterday as a result of a freighttrain derailment.
NORTH BELLMORE, L.I., June 5--About forty youngsters carried 2,000 books yesterday from the children's section of the old library to the new $200,000 building a half-block away.
WARSAW, June 5--Rain continued to pour onto drenched Poland today, and the battle to control flooding rivers spread to new areas.
TWO of the busiest places on Sunday morning in West New York, N.J., are food stores that specialize in Italian delicacies. Shoppers go to the Italian Food Center, 6415 Bergenline
CHICAGO, June 5--The first Chinese refugee family to be admitted to the United States under President Kennedy's emergency program arrived here to a warm welcome early today.

ARDSLEY, N.Y., June 5-- Henry Ford 2d often rents cars made by competitors to see what the opposition is doing Saturday night he took the wrong Chevrolet from a restaurant parking lot here and caused a short-lived alarm for a stolen car.

Mah Moola, an 8-to-1 shot of the Merrick Stable, got up just in time to win the Imperatrice Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. For the greater part of the six-furlong sprint, Pixie Erin of the Claiborne Farm threatened to "steal it all," under a front-running ride by Larry Adams.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 5-- The New York investment banking concern of Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co. and a group of partners and staff members have been made defendants in a multi-million dollar damage suit filed in Superior Court here. The plaintiff is the First California Company, investment banking con
Preparations are nearing completions for two major annual screen festivals, in Boston and Vancouver, B.C.
Two Nobel Prize laureates, Dr. Niels Bohr of Denmark and Dr. A.V. Hill of England, received honorary Doctor of Science degrees yesterday from the Rockefeller Institute.

BERLIN, June 5--Two British armored cars and an East German armored troop carrier faced each other for more than two hours today at the Berlin border from opposite banks of the Spree River, where East German guards earlier had shot and killed a man swimming to the West.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) --An Agriculture Department official said today that a Supreme Court decision had raised a question about the regulation of milk-marketing in eightythree metropolitan areas.
CHICAGO, June 5 (AP)-- Bloomfield, N.J., was cited today by the National Safety Council for outstanding accomplishment in traffic safety during 1961.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) --Two officials of the Office of Emergency Planning told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today that they knew of no wrongdoing in connection with the nation's $8,700,000,000 stockpile.

The ninety-fourth running of the Belmont Stakes on Saturday shapes up as an eight-horse race, Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Daddy R., the winner of the Governor's Gold Cup at Bowie, will be a starter in the $125,000 added classic, but Mrs. Moody Jolley's Rldan, a popular and formidable campaigner, will not come in from Chicago to compete.

A GROUP of sixty-seven British writers, members of the London Women's Press Club here for a two-week sight-seeing tour, indicated yesterday that women on both sides of the Atlantic were interested in the same things, but the emphasis was somewhat different.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 5-- Senator George A. Smathers told top executives of the electric power industry here today that President Kennedy was "definitely not anti-business."
Twenty-four college students were arrested last night for a sitdown at Beth-El Hospital in Brooklyn in support of a strike by nonmedical employes.

CHICAGO, June 5 (AP)-- Speculative demand today strengthened rye and firmed some wheat futures but most contracts finished under their highs for the day on the Board of Trade. Other commodities were steady to weak.

In his speech before the New York Financial Writers Association, Secretary Dillon took the view that the economy may still attain the Administration's goal of a gross national product of $570 billion for the year. He therefore sees no need for an immediate tax cut, but prefers to rely on a thoroughgoing tax reform, which he promised to present to Congress for action next year.
A verse drama by Archibald MacLeish, written for radio twenty-five years ago, will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System Thursday, June 28, at 7:30 P.M.

NOT even the lush beauty of Belmont Park could give sparkle to the ancient cavalry post yesterday morning. The gray skies seemed to press down at tree-top level, smothering the gaiety and excitement that the post-dawn workouts usually provide. The dismal, drizzly setting appeared to affect man and beast, especially those involved in the ninety-fourth running of the classic Belmont Stakes on Saturday.
OTTAWA, June 5--The devaluation of the Canadian dollar to the equivalent of 92.5 cents in United States money is emerging as a major issue of the national election campaign.
MOSCOW, June 5--The International Olympic Committee rejected today a renewed Soviet effort to expand its membership on a national basis.

JERICHO, L.I., June 5--Mrs. Thorne Dempsey of Southward He scored a 39, 37-76 at the Meadow Brook Club today to lead the field in the opening round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association 54-hold medal-play championship.

Mrs. Hoyte Joyce of New York and Morton Dean Joyce of New York and Kennebunk, Me., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucy Curley Joyce, to William Jay Brennan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brennan of Buffalo.

Yesterday was a bad day for traffic, There were jams all over town, the police said. As one was unsnarled another formed. By nightfall the nerves of many a motorist and policeman were frazzled.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 5 --Claude Harmon's 137 led the metropolitan area's qualifiers for the United States Open golf championship today. After the 104 competitors battled through a heavy rain at the Montclair, Golf Club for thirty-two alloted places, the 45-year-old Winged Foot Golf Club instructor enjoyed a lead of one stroke.
ROME, June 5--The Jewish community of Rome protested today against neo-Fascist "provocations" after violent clashes in the midtown district of the former ghetto last night and again tonight.
The Fund for the Republic will embark on its first campaign for contributions, Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president, announced yesterday. He said the goal would be about $1,000,000 a year.

Yankee pitching received a welcome shot in its relief arm yesterday with the return of Hal Reniff from military service. The 23-year-old right-hander will join the active list of bullpen specialists as soon as he works himself back into condition.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 5-- The Vietnamese police raided the apartment of a United States Embassy secretary Saturday night and served a warrant on her for letting her American guests dance.
THE Eastern States Championships tournament that began May 25 finally reached its final round yesterday with a two-team match for the Curt H. Reisinger knockout team trophy.

"IF I were not a German, then I'd like to be an Amer ican." Karl Heinrich Knappstein, who was named today as Bonn's next Ambassador to the United States, told a visitor recently. He has been, as he says, "American minded" ever since he spent 1930 and 1931 as an exchange
MOSCOW, June 5--Leaders of the Soviet-bloc nations assembled here today to cope with some of the pressing economic difficulties confronting the Communist world.

A little-noticed but significant piece of legislation has become caught in an unfortunate conflict between Senate committees. It is a bill, H.R. 10079, to establish a permanent basis for United States aid to refugees.

WASHINGTON, June 5--A broad investigation into charges of discriminaion against Negroes within eighteen Chicago locals has been started by the International Hod Carriers', Building and Common Laborers' Union.

JACKSON, Miss., June 5 (UPI)--Representative Jamie Whitten, who bolted the national party ticket in 1960 and was re-elected on an anti-Kennedy platform, won renomination tonight over Representative Frank Smith in a Democratic primary race to eliminate one Congressman from Mississippi.
An error that resulted in the burial of a Roman Catholic man in a Jewish cemetery came to light yesterday when the Health Department issued an exhumation order.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 5--U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, said today that the projected American nuclear tests at high altitudes "are a manifestation of a very dangerous psychosis which is in evidence today."
Paul R. Milton, a founder and director of Aware, Inc., testified yesterday that he had once accepted a radio script-writing job from which a man he had labeled pro-Communist had been dismissed.
TRENTON, June 5--Gov. Richard J. Hughes accused the Republican leadership in the State Senate today of "fiscal irresponsibility" and of trying to foist a broad-base tax on the state.
One of the most esoteric, expensive and complex itineraries in the history of show business has resulted from a Broadway star's unshakeable bias against air travel.
STRATFORD-ON-AVON, June 5--The Royal Shakespeare Theatre presented "Macbeth" here tonight for the first time since Sir Lawrence Olivier played the title role in 1955.

There was much Pickwickian chuckling aboard the liner Queen Elizabeth on her latest crossing. Thirty members of the Dickens Fellowship arrived yesterday on the world's largest liner to attend a conference on Dickensiana in Boston from tomorrow through Monday.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (UPI) --A Florida official said today that rental car concerns overcharged their customers because auto makers installed mileage indicators that registered too high.
ATLANTA, June 5--A. Edward Smith, the first Republican candidate for Governor of Georgia since Reconstruction ended in 1876, was killed in a highway collision early today.

The United States Lines Company expects earnings for the first half of this year to rise to about $3,525,000, or $2 a share, John M. Franklin, chairman, told shareholders yesterday at the steamship concern's annual meeting in Hoboken, N.J.
Judges who feel that "if a traffic ticket is issued by an arresting officer, the defendant is therefore guilty" were chided yesterday by a fellow judge.

As the art season grinds to a halt in New York, the galleries are holding their yearly reviews--an appealing opportunity for teen-agers to glean leries are holding their yearly from one review chapter what has been going on all year in the book of art.
Former President Harry S. Truman yesterday deprecated the commotion over the recent cancellation by the White House of its subscriptions to The New York Herald Tribune.

In the chapel of All Souls Unitarian Church yesterday afternoon Miss Jeannie Sinclair McLane, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. McLane of 544 East Eighty-sixth Street and Willsboro, N.Y., was married to Byrd Luther Jones. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Elihu Roe Jones pf Ogden, Utah. The Rev. Walter Donald Kring performed the ceremony in the presence of the immediate families.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has been awarded a contract to design and supply the second and third cores, or nuclear fuel charges, for the Indian Point, N.Y., atomic generating station of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York.
A national survey has shown that Americans lose more than $700,000,000 in cash a year, and that the more education a person has the more likely he is to lose money.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) --A physician of Pecos, Tex., was identified today as the amateur investigator who put Federal authorities on the trail of Billie Sol Estes, indicted Texas financier.

The City Council allocated $1,000,000 in 1962 capital budget funds yesterday to renovate Sea View Hospital as a nursing home for 800 patients. The hospital, closed as a tuberculosis center last summer, is on Staten Island.
SAN FRANCISCO Wednesday, June 6--Richard M. Nixon became the Republican nominee for Governor of his home state today.

Stockholders of Federated Department Stores, Inc., were informed at their annual meeting in Cincinnati, Ohio, yesterday that the board of directors had raised the quar terly dividend to 30 cents a common share, lifting annual disbursements to $1.20 from $1.10 a share.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 5--President Sukarno notified the United Nations today that Indonesia was stepping up military activity against Netherlands New Guinea.

No stranger to New York is Mel McGaha, the handsome young manager of the Cleveland Indians. He was a big league ballplayer in our town. But it wasn't baseball. It was in basketball as a member of the New York Knickerbockers. Such is his versatility that on graduating from the University of Arkansas he found himself confronted by what Branch Rickey was wont to describe as "an election of professions."
LONDON, June 6 Firmness prevailed in most sections of the stock market today. Although trading remained quiet there was a reappearance of gains.
BERLIN, June 6 Secretary of State Dean Rusk's trip to West Germany later this month will not include a visit to West Berlin.
ALGIERS, Thursday, June 7 The Secret Army Organization ended a six-day truce last night and ordered its terrorists to resume action immediately.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 6 A United Nations commission recommended today that the General Assembly give independence separately on July 1 to the two parts of the Belgian East African trust territory of Ruanda-Urundi.

LONDON, June 6 The European Economic Community must fully understand the British Commonwealth and its ties if it is to make satisfactory arrangements with Britain, Edward Heath, the Lord Privy Seal, declared today.

WASHINGTON, June 6 The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended May 30:

WOODMERE, L.I., June 6 A choral composition about slavery, freedom and integration, the work of a sixth-grade class at the Woodmere Elementary School, has been recorded and will be sold commercially by a New York record company.
WASHINGTON, June 6 Legislation to clear the way for television debates in next fall's Senate and House election campaigns was introduced today by Senator Jacob K. Javits.
The president of New York University said yesterday that provate colleges and universities were endangered by mounting costs and the effects of taxation.

WASHINGTON, June 6 The Senate voted today, 57 to 24, to bar foreign aid to Communist-dominated countries. It dealt the Kennedy Administration its first major defeat in Congress in the field of foreign policy.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 6 (AP) Minnesota, behind the five-hit pitching, of Jim Kaat, scored a 7-0 victory tonight over the Kansas City Athletics.

JONES BEACH, L.I., June 6 Robert Moses' long-standing plan to stabilize the storm-battered shorefront from Staten Island to Montauk Point with a "mighty bulwark" was approved unanimously today by the Temporary State Commission on the Atlantic Shore Line.

George W. Wolf, retired president of United States Steel Export Company, died yesterday in Harkness Pavilion, Presbyterian Medical Center, after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 36 Beachside Avenue, Greens Farms, Conn., and at 35 Park Avenue.

The New York Stock Exchange has announced that it is making a detailed study of the trading that took place Monday, Tuesday and Thursday of last week, when the market suffered a drastic drop in prices.
MOSCOW, June 6 A toplevel conference of the Sovietbloc countries opened here today to consider means of meeting the challenge of the European Economic Community.
I wish to express the Administration's views on the [Senator William] Proxmire [Democrat of Wisconsin] amendments to the foreign aid bill.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 6 Today was D-day for sixteen former cadets of the United States Military Academy.

GLENCOE, Ill., June 6 Mr. and Mrs. George W. Gale have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Gale, to Steven W. Matthysse. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Irving Matthysse of Danbury, Conn.

NORTH PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 6 Msgr. James J. Weber, pastor of St. Columbanus Roman Catholic Church here, died of a heart attack today at Peekskill Hospital on the thirty-seventh anniversary of his ordination. His age was 63.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI) President Kennedy and Archbishop Makarios, President of Cyprus, ended two days of talks today "on topics of mutual interest."
The Board of Education announced yesterday the selection of Eugene E. Hult as Deputy Superintendent of Schools in charge of construction and maintenance.
Plans for greater use of pictorial symbols on the city's traffic signs were announced yesterday by Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes.

DETROIT, June 6 (AP) Consumers with new-car fever apparently paid no attention to the stock market plunge in late May. In the final ten days of the month, they bought more than a quarter of a million automobiles and pushed the total for May to the highest level since September, 1955.
EFFORTS for progress are being made in behalf of the Rottweiler breed of working dogs on both United States coasts.
BUENOS AIRES, June 6 The Federal Government entered an appeal today against a court ruling last night that the Government's cancellation of the March 18 election results was unconstitutional.
PARIS, June 6 Raoul Salan, former chief of the Secret Army Organization, remained silent today on Edmond Jouhaud's dramatic appeal for an immediate end of terrorism by the organization.

PITTSBURGH, June 6 (AP) The Los Angeles Dodgers choked off a ninth-inning Pittsburgh rally and beat the Pirates, 5 3, tonight. The victory moved the Dodgers within a half game of the league-leading San Francisco Giants.
The battle between broadcasters and advertisers over the issue of "product protection" appears to be widening.
Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., is "safely out of the phase of serious losses," Frederick H. Cook, chairman and president, told stockholders attending the annual meeting at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday.
