A WEDDING reception in the home of the bride conjures up the image of a small, intimate group of family members and special friends meeting in familiar surroundings to toast the happy couple.
ATLANTA, June 6 (UPI) Harry Belafonte, the Negro singer, and a racially mixed group were accepted for registration at an Atlanta motor hotel today, but were not allowed to eat in its restaurant.

The Board of Estimate took the first step yesterday in a program calling for substantial raises for 125 or more top city officials and their subordinates in executive posts outside the classified Civil Service.
VIENTIANE, Laos, June 6 A new effort by the leaders of three rival factions to form a coalition government for Laos was assured today.

LIMA, Peru, June 6 A crowd of 200,000 persons jammed a park here last night to hear Victor Raul Haya de la Torre deliver his final campaign speech before the Presidential and Congressional elections Sunday. The rally was described as the biggest political meeting ever held in Peru.

CLIFTON, N.J., June 6 Golfers of major league caliber returned to the metropolitan district today. Arnold Palmer and a nucleus of forty-nine other leading money-winners participated in a pro-celebrity tournament at the Upper Montclair Country Club.
Leading artists are being encouraged by a museum curator and the editor of an art magazine to design American postage stamps.

Miss Mary-Virginia More, daughter of Mrs. Morgan Berkeley More of New York and the late Mr. More, was married yesterday noon to Peter Ralph Anstruther, son of Mrs. Arthur Wellesley Anstruther of Watlington, England, and the late Mr. Anstruther.

The Handee Helpers Company of Staten Island, a Junior Achievement concern operated by nineteen high school students, was judged yesterday by the New York Financial Writers Association as having prepared the best annual report to stockholders of eighty-three companies in business in the city during the school year.
ROME, June 6 A series of visits by Italian officials to Tunisia, Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union underline what is termed here the new dynamism of Italian foreign policy.
A State Supreme Court justice directed St. John's University yesterday to reinstate three students who had been dismissed for participating in a civil marriage ceremony.

The participation of Prince Philip of Britain and Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands in sponsoring the American campaign for the World Wildlife Fund emphasizes the common interest held by civilized men everywhere in... preserving the special treasures with which nature has endowed the globe.

The National Maritime Union yesterday turned down $35,000 offered by an inland waterways operator in settlement of an unfair labor practice charge and held out for immediate reinstatement of eleven towboat crewmen by Federal Barge Lines of St. Louis, Mo.

The Transport Workers Union said yesterday that the wage settlement reached Tuesday night in Chicago for 450,000 off-train railroad employes put these workers "miles behind the vast majority of other organized workers."
HARTFORD, June 6 Connecticut Republicans rose in rebellion today and nominated Representative Horace SeelyBrown Jr. of Pomfret for United States Senator.
WASHINGTON, June 6 Mayor Wagner is establishing a government liaison office here for New York City. The office also will be a political outpost for his Democratic state organization.

The Regional Plan Association said yesterday that rural and non-rush-hour motorists and nonmotoring taxpayers were subsidizing rush-hour drivers in the New York metropolitan area by as much as 10 cents a mile.
KEARNY, N.J., June 6 Plans for a coordinated program leading to the reclamation of 15,000 acres of meadowland in Hudson and Bergen Counties are to be announced on Monday by Gov. Richard J. Hughes.
WASHINGTON, June 6 Hundreds of physicians from all over America are appearing on Capitol Hill to campaign against the Administration's bill on medical care for the aged.

DARIEN, Conn., June 6 Miss Patricia Ann Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Barney Walker of Old Greenwich, was married here at noon today to Stephen John Schulte. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Stephen Schulte of New York and Bedford, N.Y. Justice of the Peace Charles B. Boles of Greenwich performed the ceremony at the Woodway Country Club.

The Breitbart Corporation, Sheldon Lewis Breitbart, president, has contracted to buy the leasehold on the property at 2 Park Avenue, a twenty-ninestory office building occupying the blockfront between Thirtysecond and Thirty-third Streets.
Mayor Wagner was reported last night to have agreed upon a triumvirate to direct a Bronx campaign to unseat Representative Charles A. Buckley as Democratic county leader and to reorganize the party.
WASHINGTON, June 6 Radiological experts drastically reduced today their estimates of the amount of radiation the American public is receiving from medical and dental X-rays.

The immediate temptation in assessing the checkerboard of primary election results is to clutch for broad national conclusions. The variety of trends in the voting this week and last indicates how hazardous such attempts at generalization can be.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 6 The discount merchandising business reached another milestone here today when the F.W. Woolworth Company, one of the giants of American retailing, opened its first discount department store.
PARIS, June 6 The longsought goal of thirty Allied combat-ready divisions in Europe under the Atlantic Pact is expected to be reached within six months.
LONDON, June 6 The British Overseas Airways Corporation and the Cunard Steamship Company announced today that they were forming a new jointly owned airline company to be called B.O.A.C.-Cunard, Ltd.

SAINTE MERE EGLISE, France, June 6 (UPI) United States Ambassador James M. Gavin, who landed in France eighteen years ago as a paratroop general, led ceremonies today commemorating the D-Day invasion and the 10,000 American soldiers buried near here.

Stockholders of the Boston Edison Company authorized a new issue of thirty-year first mortgage bonds at a meeting in Boston yesterday. If cleared by regulatory agencies, the maximum amount of the issue would be $15,000,000. It would be used to refund a similar amount of first mortgage Series G 5 per cent bonds due in 1989.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, June 6 The cabinet of Pakistan's military Government met for the last time today after forty-four months in office. It will resign tomorrow to make way for a new Cabinet to be formed by President Mohammad Ayub Khan under the new Constitution, which will become effective Friday.
WASHINGTON, June 6 The Kennedy Administration expects to announce this week the granting of $50,000,000 in standby credits to Argentina's military-backed government.
PARIS, June 6 Financial nervousness was evident in Europe again today, but this time it was in the form of an unusually large demand for gold on the London market.
DAMASCUS, Syria, June 6 Premier Bashir al-Azmah announced today that his Government would take steps toward a partial restoration of Syria's union with the United Arab Republic.
The stock market rose sharply yesterday as volume fell to the lowest level in two weeks.

CHICAGO, June 6 (AP) Grain futures retreated today on the Board of Trade. All commodities were down except rye. Many contracts finished at their lows of the day as selling pressure increased during the final few minutes. Several contracts of oats and soybeans also fell to their season lows as declines of major fractions to well over a cent a bushel became general.
WASHINGTON, June 6 The tax bill that President Kennedy wants Congress to enact next year caused new trouble today for the one he wants enacted this year.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI) The House Ways and Means Committee today approved a slightly revised version of President Kennedy's proposal to increase the temporary national debt limit to $308,000,000,000.

Institute on "Pulmonary Function," Medical Society of Queens in association with the American Academy of General Practice, the Queens Hospital Center and the Queensboro Tuberculosis and Health Association, at the Queens Hospital Center, 82-68 164th Street, Jamaica, Queens, 9:30 A.M.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 6 When he was 11 years old, Herschel Harold Hobbs was baptized in a creek that ran by a little country church in Shelby County, Ala. He still remembers the hymn that the people sang on the riverbank. It was "Let Jesus Come Into Your Heart."
WASHINGTON, June 6 The Flight Engineers International Association teetered on the edge of a strike against TransWorld Airlines today, but was understood to have postponed it temporarily.
Shakespeare-in-the-park will find its way to television-inthe-home.

The Hammermill Paper Company of Erie, Pa., producer of writing and printing papers, has leased space in the Pan Am Building, 200 Park Avenue, adjoining Grand Central Station. Jerry L. Cohen and Ian G.M. Brownlie of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., was the broker. Cushman Wakefield, Inc.; is the renting agent for the building. James D. Landauer Associates, Inc., acted as consultant to the owner of the building.
The city moved yesterday to establish a central registry file of narcotics addicts.
PHILADELPHIA, June 6 Another first was "achieved" tonight as the Mets bowed to the Phillies, 2-0 and 2-1, at Connie Mack Stadium.

The Horn and Hardart Baking Company slashed its quarterly common dividend yesterday to $1.37 from $1.75 in previous quarters. The reduced disbursement will be paid July 2 to stockholders of record of June 15.

MONTAUK, L.I., June 6 Psychiatrists are reputed to be league leaders when it comes to honesty and sterlingness of character, among other things. But they usually view dreams as being something other than what they appear to be symbols and all that.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 6 A White House cultural connoisseur, addressing a convention of the American Association of Museums here today, asked why the association's membership included an ostrich farm in California and an alligator farm in Arkansas, and then he raised the question: What, precisely, is a museum?
WASHINGTON, June 6 David Probstein, a graying ghost from the past of James R. Hoffa, the president of the Teamsters Union, spent five minutes before a Federal grand jury here today.
The end of thirteen years of waiting came yesteray for 23year-old Deanna Chu, the seventh and last member of a Chinese refugee family to arrive in the United States.

JIM BROSNAN said his neck had been stretched so much it would take a drink of Scotch ten minutes to reach his stomach. Things were pretty tough everywhere in that spectacular season. The club trainer was only trying to help him along.

A leader of the American Council for Judaism asserted last night that differences between Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel and Dr. Nahum Goldmann, Zionist, resulted from "an internal struggle to control the single Zionist-Israel power structure."

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 6 The Government moved today to seal South Africa's borders to prevent flight by political refugees. It also moved to sever the republic's few remaining ties with the British Commonwealth.

One area that the Exchange should investigate is the amount of credit used for stock purchases, which is apparently greater than anyone realized. Without imposition of high margins, which is the Government's only direct means of exercising control over the stock market, the recent disorder would have been much worse.

WITH the advent of weekends at the beach, women have a chance to don shorts or bathing suits and bare their legs, arms and feet to the sun. There is more to it, however, than a mere change of clothes. The skin is not used to sudden exposure and, from the face to the toes, it should be given a thorough course in preparedness.
The New York Botanical Garden's twentieth annual Rose Day was observed in Bronx Park yesterday.
The nation's bill for going places and sending things last year came to more than $100,000,000,000, the Transportation Association of America reported yesterday.
Vincent W. Hartnett took the witness stand in State Supreme Court yesterday to answer a charge that he had "blacklisted" John Henry Faulk from broadcasting.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 6 President Kennedy told the graduates at the United States Military Academy today that the problems confronting the nation required them to be much more than professional soldiers. They must, he said, be diplomats as well.

Until the sixth inning of yesterday's game at the Stadium, the Yanks and Indians practiced a sort of grudging co-existence, sharing a room at the top of the American League standing. Then the Yanks served the interlopers with an eviction notice in the form of successive homers by Roger Maris and John Blanchard.

The National Freedom Education Center, established ten months ago on the campus of a Protestant institution, King's College of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., opened its first "Freedom Forum" in the city yesterday.

A syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation, Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Goldman, Sachs Co. will offer for public subscription today a new issue of $40,000,000 of first mortgage and collateral trust bonds of the United Gas Corporation.
SANTIAGO, Chile, June 6 (UPI) Brazil, Hungary and the Soviet Union assured themselves today of World Soccer Cup quarter-final berths.
Cardinal Spellman presented a pectoral cross and ring to Bishop-elect Reh at a brief ceremony before luncheon yesterday in the archdiocesan office on Madison Avenue.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 6 Communist guerrillas captured two freight trains filled with food and supplies yesterday in a bold daylight raid ninety miles east of Saigon.

A controlling interest in Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, Inc., has been acquired by a group of investors headed by John M. Foley, a Wall Street lawyer, and Dennison L. Slater, a New York business man and former fight promoter. The names of the other members of the group could not be learned.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8 The younger generation of moviemakers seems to be split about trying to elevate movies as an art. This was indicated today in interviews with a group training for movie careers on the set of "The Hook," a film starring Kirk Douglas and Nick Adams.

All present evidence indicates that the French terrorist Secret Army Organization in Algeria the O.A.S. has been defeated. No doubt elements in it can, and will, slaughter innocent Moslems (women and children included), assassinate Europeans who oppose them, and explode more bombs; but these acts will just be the mad
LOS ANGELES, June 6 An oddly mixed pattern of results met the efforts of conspicuously conservative candidates in California's primary election.
MOSCOW, June 6 The International Olympic Committee issued "a strong warning" today that South Africa would be barred from the Olympic Games if its government did not end racial segregation in sports.

"Citizen Hearst" is to reach the stage. Rights to W.A. Swanberg's biographical study of William Randolph Hearst have been acquired by Robert Fryer, Lawrence Carr and John Herman, the team that sponsored "Advise and Consent" and "A Passage to India."
LONDON, June 6 The Conservative Government suffered a stunning electoral defeat tonight when the Labor party won a "safe" Tory seat in a by-election in Yorkshire.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 6 (AP) The Naval Academy sent 766 new officers into the armed forces today. They went with a warning from Secretary of the Navy Fred Korth that they were "taking on the problems of the world."
WASHINGTON, June 6 Senator John L. McClellan announced today that on June 27 his Permanent Investigations Subcommittee would start several weeks of public hearings in the Billie Sol Estes case.
THE suburbs were portrayed recently as "ghettos of ho mogeneity" in which couples were often too preoccupied with the trappings of respectability to build a fruitful family life.
The telephone company has instituted a dialing system that it says should cut five seconds from the average time (thirtyeight seconds) spent on an Information call in this city.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 6 A Ford Motor Company executive urged here today that business men take an active role in their dealings with government.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 6 (AP) Daily Bible readings in Dade County (Miami) schools were upheld today by the Florida Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, June 6 A man whose company bought a release from its Government stockpile contract said today that, far from reaping windfall profits, the company had overpaid the Government.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 6 (AP) The rural-dominated Tennessee House has passed a bill that virtually assures the state its first legislative reapportionment in sixty-one years.

The biggest United States wrestling show ever moved into the New York Athletic Club yesterday for a five-day stand. Nearly 500 scriptless matches are involved and it can be guaranteed that no falls by the flying dropkick or airplane whirl will be registered, that no hair will be pulled and that no referee will be chased out of the ring.

The Phillips Petroleum Company announced yesterday that it had joined with Italian interests in forming a new company to market hydrocarbons and sulfur chemicals to the Italian petrochemical industry.

WASHINGTON, June 6 The margin of Richard M. Nixon's victory in the Republican primary of California does not encourage the conclusion that he as yet has overcome the sharp reversal of his meteoric rise in politics inflicted by his defeat for the Presidency in 1960.
WARSAW, June 6 Poland's first supermarket opened in midtown Warsaw today in the midst of an outbreak of scare buying.

Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., reported yesterday that for the nine months ended April 30, consolidated net income of $22,317,000, equal to $2.54 a share, compared with $21,261,000, or $2.42 a share earned in the corresponding period of the preceding year. This reflected the rise in sales to $629,818,000 from $603,980,000.

The return of strength to cocoa and world sugar futures was the highlight of commodity trading yesterday on an otherwise quiet day on the New York markets. Other commodities were generally mixed to higher.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 6 Richard M. Nixon, as Republican nominee for Governor, moved swiftly today to set up campaign strategy for a major battle againt his Democratic opponent, Gov. Edward G. Brown.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 6 Justin Bijur won the retailers' low gross prize with a 78 in the thirty-fourth annual New York City Newspaper-Retail Dry Goods Association tournament today at the Century Country Club.

The consumer was still showing his muscle in April, giving energy to economic activity through his purchases. That was indicated in the latest monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which spoke of "widespread gains in April and further advances in May."

MONTREAL, June 6 (AP) The New York Rangers acquired Bert Olmstead from Toronto in the National Hockey League's draft today and the left wing, who has been in the league for thirteen seasons, inmediately became the leading candidate for the coaching job vacated by Doug Harvey.

WASHINGTON, June 6 Barely two months after he took office, President Kennedy asked Congress to enact a tax bill that his Administration had designed to stimulate business. Today, fourteen months later, the bill is still a bill.
EPSOM, England, June 6 Larkspur, a 22-to-1 shot owned by an American, won the English Derby today in a race marred by a seven-horse pileup. It was the worst accident in the Derby's 183-year history.

The high-grade bond market showed more assurance yesterday in all areas. The trading session was only moderately active, however, and was still in large part a sideshow to the fluctuations in common stock values.

WESTFIELD, N.J., June 6 Charle E. Crandall, former manager of the New York City sales office of the Morse Chain Company, manufacturers of mechanical power transmission equipment, died yesterday in his home at 335 Benson Place after a long illness. He was 76 years old.
The list of starters in Saturday's $125,000 added Belmont Stakes was expanded to eleven yesterday, with the addition of a trio of late starters.

COLORADO SPRINGS, June 6 Weddings at the Air Force Academy following the fourth graduation exercise today were up 100 per cent over last year, when there were two. There would have been more this year if the Academy Chapel had been completed as expected, but it still lacks furnishings.
Miss Carolyn Goldmark, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Carl Goldmark Jr. of New York, became the bride yesterday afternoon of Oscar Baylin Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Allan Goodman of Narberth, Pa.
GENEVA, June 6 Britain appealed to the Soviet Union today to join in a study of measures for checking that all countries honored their pledges to scrap nuclear weapons under any disarmament treaty.

WASHINGTON, June 6 The stock market decline has been a prime cause for the withholding of an estimated $500,000,000 new securities from public offering, mostly at the expense of new companies and others wanting to go public.
Postmaster Robert K. Christenberry reported yesterday that a 30 per cent increase in parcel-post volume had resulted from the United Parcel Service strike.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 6 The Southern Baptist Convention mounted a three-sided attack today on theological liberalism in its seminaries.
PEIPING, June 6 The Chinese Communists issued an order today for a review of capital construction plans and told builders and factories to return unused land to the farmers.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 6 Soon after the impressive commencement exercises in the Field House at the United States Naval Academy here today, the forty weddings planned for five successive days began in the two chapels on the grounds of this naval command on the banks of the Severn.
PARIS, June 6 (UPI) A solemn all-faith memorial service was held in the American Cathedral here today for the 121 United States tourists who died with nine Frenchmen in Sunday's jetliner crash.

The Pennsylvania Public School Building Authority plans to borrow $14,150,000 in the bond market on June 26, on lease revenue bonds maturing from 1962 to 2001. The authority will use the money to finance construction of local schools.
FLANDERS, N.J., June 6 A 500-acre tract in Mount Olive Township has been acquired by an ultra-Orthodox Jewish sect from Brooklyn for the development of a self-contained community.
The Queens Chamber of Commerce called yesterday on the Federal Aviation Agency to approve the Port of New York Authority's plan to lengthen La Guardia Airport's two runways.

SLIGHTLY inferior in playing strength (supposedly) to that select group of players known as masters (including so-called international masters and grand masters) is a populous and active corps of players throughout the world who are considered experts.

DURHAM, N.C., June 6 (AP) Using a new plan suggested by a Federal judge, the Durham Board of Education has assigned several white children to Negro schools for the first time and placed about forty additional Negroes in predominately white schools.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that his office was investigating the City Licensing Department's procedures in the issuance of permits for distress sales. He disclosed that an official in the department had forfeited his job last week by refusing to sign a waiver of immunity before a grand jury.

JOHN ALSOP, the youngest brother of Joseph and Stewart Alsop, the writers, first sought the Republican nomination for Governor of Connecticut four years ago when he was favored by the party's so-called Eisenhower wing ... but former Controller Fred R. Zeller represented the Republicans and lost by 246,000 votes to Abraham A. Ribicoff ... a lifelong resident of Avon where he was born Aug. 4, 1915

The city's final valuation of real estate for assessment purposes indicates that the basic tax rate in the coming fiscal year will rise 8 cents to a record high of $4.18 on each $100 of assessed worth.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., June 6 (UPI) Vice President Johnson told the Air Force Academy's Class of '62 today uncompromising courage and idealism would help them win a long campaign against communism.

The Eastern States Championships tournament ended early yesterday morning after twelve days of play when the Curt H. Reisinger Cup was won by a team composed of Philip Feldesman, Samuel M. Stayman, Mr. and Mrs. Victor Mitchell and the brothers Sol and Morton Rubinow, all of New York.
Reflecting a sharp gain in refinery operations, domestic stocks of the major oil products showed gains in the week-end last Friday, according to the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute.

LONDON, June 6 The Government announced today that it had decided to accept an offer from the Hong Kong textile industry to continue the present ceilings on exports to Brittain of cotton cloth and madeup cotton goods to the end of 1965.

NEW DELHI, India, June 6 Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru brought back into the Government today a Cabinet member who resigned in 1958 during a scandal. He is Triuvallur Thattai Krishnamachari, who will serve as a Minister Without Portfolio.

Following is the text of President Kennedy's commencement address yesterday at the United States Millitary Academy, West Point, as furnished by the American Broadcasting Company and transcribed by The New York Times:
VAN NUYS, Calif., June 6 (UPI) Guinn Williams, a screen actor who played cowboy roles, died today of uremic poisoning at a hospital here, his manager, Al Kingston, reported. He was 63 years old.

Millard L. Midonick, long active in the reform Democratic movement and in civic affairs, has become the first person to pass Mayor Wagner's new judicial screening process. He appears headed for appointment as a Domestic Relations Justice.

BETHESDA, Md., June 6 Dr. Erich Mosettig, an organic chemist and chief of the steroid chemistry section of the National Institute of Arthritis and Metabolic Diseases, Public Health Service, died of a heart attack last Thursday in Vienna. He was 63 years old and lived at 6615 First Street, N.W., Washington.
A wife who specializes in helping her detective husband came to his aid again last night by collecting evidence as she and her husband chased a suspect on the East Side.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 6 Rutgers University conferred honorary degrees tonight on Adlai E. Stevenson, United States representative to the United Nations, and Gov. Richard J. Hughes.
Frank Costello petitioned the United States Court of Appeals yesterday to throw out an order for his deportation.
WASHINGTON, June 6 The Administration showed no interest today in reopening debate on its decision not to help France develop an independent nuclear force.
Representative Eugene. J. Keogh, a Democratic Congressman from Brooklyn for twentysix years, testified yesterday at the trial of his brother, State Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh.

Adult illiteracy is so insidious that we rarely take note of its extent or cost. Census Bureau figures disclose that 8,300,000 Americans over 25 one-twelfth of the adult population have completed less than five years of schooling.
WASHINGTON, June 7 President Kennedy announced today that he would ask Congress to enact "across-theboard" personal and corporate income tax cuts next year, to take effect on Jan. 1.

In an across-the-board decision, the New York State Harness Racing Commission yesterday penalized two drivers, an owner and Yorkers Raceway for the race that resulted in a riot at the Westchester standard-bred plant on the night of May 9.
WASHINGTON, June 7 President Kennedy said today that he was supporting Representative Charles A. Buckley for re-election despite Mayor Wagner's opposition to the Bronx Democratic leader.

KHANG KHAY, Laos, June 7 Prince Souvanna Phouma, the neutralist leader, said today that he and the two other Laotian Princes had reached agreement in prin ciple on the formation of a coalition government.
Philharmonic Hall, the Lincoln Center home of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, has made the cover of the 1962-63 Manhattan telephone directory.

Continued strength in world sugar futures, coupled with moderate volume in cocoa and cottonseed oil futures, led commodity trading yesterday on the New York markets. Other commodities were mixed in quiet trading.

Republican philosophy is rooted in the traditions of this land of ours in the Declaration of Independence that made this country free, in the Constitution that has kept it free, and in the free men and women who have made it the greatest nation on earth.

PARIS, June 7 The Bank for International Settlements suggested today that the United States should tackle its key economic problems by increasing the budget deficit to restore full employment and, at the same time, raising interest rates to curb the flow of funds overseas.
Bond prices in general tended to move upward yesterday in a trading session otherwise made significant by a broadening of activity in the market for United States Government securities.

In the Park Avenue Methodist Church yesterday afternoon Miss Victoria Nelson Stebbins became the bride of Edward John Wallop. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Philip A.C. Clarke. There was a reception at 1A East Seventyseventh Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 7 The Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, U Thant, has asked President Sukarno of Indonesia to resume negotiations with the Netherlands over western New Guinea "as early as possible."

The British electorate is making its desire for a political change clearer with every by-election. The Tories have been in power since 1950. While by American standards many of their policies are relatively Leftist (witness the National Health Service, government ownership of transportation, recognition of Communist China) they are conservative in most economic areas.

DOVER, Del., June 7 (AP) The Ogden Corporation holding company for several large concerns, reported today that net earnings of $614,000 for the first quarter of this year compared with $437,000 for the like period last year. The share earnings were equivalent to 12 cents a share against nine cents.
MOSCOW, June 7 Premier Khrushchev urged Italy tonight to withdraw from the European Economic Community and enter into expanded trade relations with the Soviet Union.

The strike that began against the United Parcel Service on May 15, halting deliveries of merchandise from department stores, has cut sales volume considerably for some metropolitan area stores, but gains by others appear to have offset the loss.

LOS ANGELES, June 7 For the most part, the Los Angeles International Music Festival is attuned to the contemporary scene, and it will become increasingly so if some of the planers here have their way.
WASHINGTON, June 7 The Administration's medical care bill will be called up in the House Ways and Means Committee next week amid growing doubt of favorable Congressional action this year.
An indirect warning to foreign ship lines that they would have to comply with United States regulatory statutes was issued yesterday by Thomas E, Stakem, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 7 The uncertainty at Twentieth Century-Fox about whether to replace Marilyn Monroe in a film being made at its studio here is the latest example of a serious flaw that has tended to cripple Hollywood production.

WASHINGTON, June 7 Secretary of State Dean Rusk, on his visit to Paris, Bonn and London later this month, will inject Washington's views into the current debate over the future of the Western alliance.
WASHINGTON, June 7 When the Senate of the United States tries to direct the nation's foreign policy, it almost always gets into trouble.
EPSOM, England, June 7 (Reuters) Four jockeys hurt in a seven-horse pile-up in yesterday's Epsom Derby were reported in "satisfactory" condition in a hospital here today.
Irving Berlin's next show, "Mr. President," with a plot by Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse, will open at the St. James Theatre on Oct. 18.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 7 (UPI) Yugoslavia and England earned the final two places today in the World Cup soccer quarter-finals. Yugoslavia beat Colombia, 5 0, and England played a scoreless tie with Bulgaria.

The American premiere of the motion picture "Boccaccio '70" at the new twin theatres Cinema I-Cinema II, Third Avenue at Sixtieth Street, on the evening of June 25 will benefit the Riverdale Mental Health Association and the William Alanson White Institute. The occasion will also mark the opening of the theatres.
The stock market failed to show a definite trend yesterday as prices sagged irregularly in dull and slow trading.
Moore-McCormack Lines was reported yesterday to be making preparations to assure the departure on Monday of the luxury liner Argentina with ship engineers employed by the line in shoreside positions.

ROME, June 7 A dispute over the European Economic Community dominated a meeting of the Communist-controlled World Federation of Trade Unions in Budapest earlier this month, an Italian participant disclosed today.

NEWARK, June 7 Gov. Richard J. Hughes warned members of the graduating class of Newark College of Engineering tonight that they had a "special responsibility" in preserving human values in a technological society.
THE Eastern States tournament, which ended here Wednesday morning after somewhat more than twelve days of play, left a residue of records and conclusions.

YONKERS, June 7 Royal Rick, the 6-year-old pacing son of Royal Blackstone and Ann Forbes, tied the world mark of 3:03 2/5 for a mile and a half tonight as he captured the $15,000 U.S.A. Pace Test No. 2 event at Yonkers Raceway.

ALBANY, June 7 Two new youth work-training programs will be started in New York City next month, the State Division of Youth announced today. They are designed to aid unskilled school drop-outs obtain jobs.
WASHINGTON, June 7 The conviction of Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, for contempt of Congress was set aside today by the United States Court of Appeals.
Max Blauner, vice president of Suzy Perette, Inc., dress manufacturers, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 79 years old.
The president of the United States Chamber of Commerce recommended yesterday that the Kennedy Administration eliminate controversial sections of its present tax bill and seek passage of the rest.
A group of West German educators voiced strong approval yesterday of the close relationship they had observed between students and teachers throughout the educational system in the United States.
WASHINGTON, June 7 A House subcommittee investigating Billie Sol Estes interrupted its work today to dismiss its Republican counsel for giving a confidential report to a newsman.
MOUND BAYOU, Miss. THE Mississippi Delta stretch es flat and green as a billiard table for 200 miles along U.S. 61 between Memphis and Vicksburg.
NEW HAVEN, June 7 Robert Grasson, retired fencing master at Yale University, died on Tuesday at the age of 78.

St. John's University announced yesterday it would appeal a State Supreme Court decision ordering the reinstatement of three students who had been dismissed for taking part in a civil wedding ceremony last March 13.
PARIS, June 7 The fate of Edmond Jouhaud was still in suspense after two other Secret Army Organization terrorists were executed today.

Cole Porter will be 70 years old tomorrow, but plans no special celebration. The composer of such Broadway shows as "Du Barry Was a Lady," "Anything Goes," "Something for the Boys," "Red, Hot and Blue" and "Kiss Me, Kate" will spend a quiet week-end at his country home in Williamstown, Mass.

LONDON, June 7 The Wall Street break on May 28 and the uneasy behavior of the market subsequently have provoked considerable discussion in economic circles here on the condition of the United Sates economy.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) Representative H. Carl Andersen of Minnesota, whose name has been linked to the Billy Sol Estes case, announced today he would not seek re-election as a Republican but would run as an independent.
Harlem and its periphery are being overloaded with low-rent public housing despite the growing need for higher-income housing in the area, it was charged yesterday.
STONE HARBOR, N.J., June 7 A first cousin of Emperor Hirohito of Japan was delighted today to see dikes that had been built for birds instead of just for rice paddies.

CHARLES G. KNUDSEN, the meteorologist in charge of the United States Weather Bureau at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, has contrived a new service for yachtsmen that will receive wide approbation. Knudsen is no landlubber, it must be known.
A chunky little 138-pounder from Japan's talented team, Osamu Watanabe, is well on his way to capturing individual honors in the Amateur Athletic Union national senior wrestling championships.
American Metal Climax, Inc., plans to acquire the Kawneer Company and the Apex Smelting Company in a three-way merger, it was announced yesterday by the presidents of the three concerns.

The United States Treasury gold stock remained unchanged for the third consecutive week as of Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. And some Wall Street money men thought they knew why.

MANCHESTER, England, June 7 (UPI) Carole Caldwell of Santa Monica, Calif., often criticized for a lack of concentration, scored the biggest upset of the 1962 tennis season today when she defeated Margaret Smith of Australia, the Italian and French champion, 6 2, 5 7, 6 2, to reach the semi-finals of the Northern lawn tennis championships.
Perfect weather greeted the traditional parades of Sunday school children in Brooklyn and Queens yesterday. As a result, a record turnout of 190,000 youngsters marched in forty-one communities.

HARLINGEN, Tex. June 7 (UPI) United States cotton, hard pressed in its competitive fight with foreign-grown cotton and substitute fibers, "must return to a one-price system as quickly as possible," an industry spokesman declared today.
I have a brief preliminary statement.

A six-hour day for the 60,000 longshoremen employed from Maine to Texas will be high on the list of demands to be presented next week by the International Longshoremen's Association to steamship operators.
The South American coffee bean, long the source of disputes over international production quotas, may soon loom as a major transport issue in President Kennedy's Alliance for Progress plans.
A total of $45,000,000 in securities of the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation of Houston, Tex., were marketed yesterday.

The International Minerals and Chemicals Corporation expects today to tap the world's largest deposit of high-grade potash, after a five-year-long engineering and mining struggle with the sub-surface geology of Western Canada.
WASHINGTON, June 7 The Senate approved a $4,662,000,000 foreign aid authorization bill today. It also modified yesterday's ban on aid to Communist-dominated countries.

LIME ROCK, Conn., June 7 Juan Manuel Fangio, the Argentine who retired four years ago after winning the automobile road-racing championship of the world five times returned to action today on a small scale.
GENEVA, June 7 The Soviet Union refused today to join in a search by experts for ways to determine that a pledge to scrap nuclear weapons under a disarmament treaty would be faithfully observed.

A new method of making bread, known as the "DoMaker Process," an automatic system for continuousmix production, is now being used in three plants of the American Bakeries Company in metropolitan New York.
WASHINGTON, June 7 The Memorial Day holiday last week cut railroad and truck freight loadings substantially below the preceding week's level.

CLIFTON, N.J., June 7 If Arnold Palmer is troubled by double vision nowadays, it is quite understandable. He has his eyes fixed on the $25,000 first prize offered by the $100,000 Thunderbird tournament, ...

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 7 Archbishop Makarios, President of Cyprus, appealed to the nuclear powers today to avert an impending catastrophe by taking action in accordance with their responsibility for "enlightened world leadership."

IT may be very much "U" in this country for men to con verse knowledgeably about the finer points of haute cuisine and to cook with sophisticated skill. But one Englishman would prefer to see men, at least the amateurs, stay out of the kitchen.
CLIFTON, N.J., June 7 There were several surprises as Gay Brewer's 66 led in the opening round of the $100,000 Thunderbird Classic golf tourney today.
WNDT, New York's new educational television station, is seeking an FM radio partner to help broadcast music and to give English translations of foreign TV films.
HONG KONG, June 5 The deployment of United States forces in Thailand as a result of the drive in Laos by proCommunist forces has improved the Western position throughout Southeast Asia.

WASHINGTON, June 7 The "Declaration of Republican Principle and Policy," which was drafted by a committee of twelve members of Congress and approved today by minority party caucuses of the House and Senate, was presented as a "consensus" of over-all Republican views.

SLOATSBURG, N.Y., June 7 Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Graham Field have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Morris Field, to John Whittaker Lonsdale Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lonsdale of New York and Mount Kisco.

President Kennedy was both calm and candid yesterday in appraising the economic situation, and in discussing what should be done about it. He is not satisfied with the rate of economic expansion, and recognizes that the main area of concern is the slow rise in corporate spending on new plant and equipment, which may be further impeded by the drop in stock prices on Wall Street.
TRENTON, June 7 Six wounded veterans of the illfated Cuban invasion of 1961 came here today to press a nation-wide drive for $62,000,000.
OTTAWA, June 6 Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's campaign for the re-election of his Conservative Government on June 18 has been plagued from the beginning by bad luck and hostile demonstrations.
Church World Service, the overseas relief arm of the National Council of Churches, will continue for another year its distribution of United States Government surplus food to families on Taiwan.
There is one group that has fared well in the weak stock market recently with good reason. The gold stocks have been strong.

Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, said here last night that the world, figuratively speaking, needed a modern Noah's Ark to preserve for future generations the species of wildlife that are threatened with extinction.

The Beacon Advertising Agency has leased a floor at 15 West Forty-fourth Street from Harry G. Silverstein Sons, owners and managers of the building, who are remodeling it. The lease is for ten years. The agency plans to move from 7 West Forty-fourth Street on July 1.

For a man who has just spent $42,000,000, Samuel I. Newhouse is in a remarkably chipper mood these days. In fact, the bantam-size, 67-year-old publisher, who now owns eighteen newspapers, is brimming with plans for new ventures and acquisitions.

Operations of Armour Co., in the six months ended April 28, resulted in net income of $7,023,154, equal to $1.30 a share on 5,384,066 shares, the company reported yesterday. This compared with $6,015,618, or $1.15 a share on 5,243,775 shares, for the six months to April 30, 1961. Sales totaled $880,900,182, compared with $848,617,055.
A VISIT with Thomas Hart Benton at his home in Neosho, Mo., introduced on Channel 2 last night a summer evening version of John Ciardi's program called "Accent."

MEN like weapons more than they like women, according to Robert Ardrey. Since Mr. Ardrey is a professional playwright ("Thunden Rock"), he can hardly avoid making dramatic statements in his "African Genesis" (Atheneum).

MOSCOW, June 7 The International Olympic Committee decided today to limit the number of sports in the summer Olympics to eighteen starting in 1968. Four sports thus will have to be eliminated from the twenty-two that will be on the program of the 1964 Games in Tokyo.

There has been much talk about the arts in this Administration, and some commendable action. The most decisive and substantial step, however, was taken the other day with the Government's announcement of an official policy aimed at the "adoption of improved architectural standards" for Federal buildings.
WASHINGTON, June 7 The United States Court of Appeals here reversed today the contempt conviction of an alleged Communist party official who had refused to tell a grand jury about party activities.
Indonesia may well have a valid legal basis for her claim to West New Guinea, but she is clearly the guilty party in resorting to military force to settle the dispute.
Government aid to private institutions is essential to meet the growing need for higher education, Gov. David L. Lawrence of Pennsylvania declared here yesterday.
LONDON, June 7 The Government outlined today in stark terms the gap between Britain and the European Economic Community over the Commonwealth.
LOS ANGELES, June 7 Richard M. Nixon opened his post-primary campaign for the Governorship of California today. He immediately ran into difficulty with party conservatives.

THE telephone, telegraph, television and other mod ern means of communication can be doubtful blessings. Catastrophes whose impact was once safely padded by distance are now abruptly brought into the living room to demand the emotional responses induced by direct contact with the event.

The thirtieth annual oneday flower mart of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association, Inc., was held yesterday on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The proceeds of the sale will be used by the association in its year-round drive against dirt in the city streets.
More than 300 civic, political and business leaders attended a luncheon yesterday to honor the West Side building accomplishments of two brothers.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 7 (AP) Bright Package scored a two-and-a-half-length victory in the mile-and-a-sixteenth Mount Holly Purse for 3-yearolds at Monmouth Park today.

Benjamin Lazrus and his son Jonathan have added to their realty holdings by purchasing the Rogers Peet Building at 485 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Forty-first Street, for investment. Benjamin Lazrus founded the Benrus Watch Company, of which he is the retired president and chairman of the board.

MONTAUK, L.I., June 7 The wind and the rain slanted in from over the blinking lighthouse at Montauk Point the other night as a peripatetic pursuer of things with fins pulled into Gerry Ruschmeyer's Lakeview Hotel here. The proprietor of this refuge for fishermen concocted a reviving potion and made ready to talk about what everybody here talks about, fish.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., June 7 The marriage of Mrs. Margaret Atwater Stetson, widow of George A. Stetson, to Stephen Bennis of Riverside took place here at noon today. The Rev. Dr. Vincent H. Daniels performed the ceremony in the chapel of the First Congregational Church.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) The Senate wrote into the foreign-aid bill today an amendment to insure Federal participation in the 1964-65 New York World's Fair.

WASHINGTON, June 7 A prominent radiologist warned today that resumption of nuclear tests in the atmosphere by the Soviet Union might require steps by the United States to remove contaminated milk from children's diets.
LONDON, June 7 The Conservative party has retained the Parliamentary seat for West Derbyshire in the face of a strong Liberal challenge.

WASHINGTON, June 7 Congressional Republicans made a strong attack on the Kennedy Administration today in a new statement of party principles designed as a major campaign weapon for 1962 and 1964. They accused the Administration of "incompetence" in managing the nation's economy and of "bluster" and "whimpering" in the conduct of foreign affairs.

LIMA, Peru, June 7 The massive public support commanded by Victor Raul Haya de la Torre in the final week of Peru's national election campaign is thawing military hostility to his Presidential candidacy.

WEDNESDAY night approximately 500 movie fans crammed the downtown Charles Theatre for a threehour look at one of its periodic programs of experimental shorts that are submitted on invitation of the management.
Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh took the stand yesterday at his trial on Federal charges of conspiring to obstruct justice.

Of ninety-three pitches delivered by Bill Stafford of the Yankees in last night's game at the Stadium, only two went for hits. As a result, it was relatively simple for the Yanks to blank the Indians, 4 0.
AMSTERDAM, N.Y., June 7 Governor Rockefeller disclosed tonight plans for a State University arts and sciences center at Albany with a capacity for 10,000 undergraduate and graduate students.
WASHINGTON, June 7 Surgeon General Luther L. Terry announced today that he would appoint an advisory committee to study the effect of cigarette smoking on health.
It was "back to normalcy" in Wall Street yesterday, and many brokers left their offices early some headed for the golf course.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 7 Edward M. Kennedy, the 30year-old brother of the President, and Edward J. McCormack, 38, a nephew of the Speaker of the House, will meet head-on here tomorrow in a bitter struggle for the Democratic Senatorial endorsement.
The field for the mile-and-ahalf Belmont Stakes tomorrow narrowed to seven likely starters with the withdrawals yesterday of Roman Line and Daddy R.

Samuel Wallace Reyburn, former chairman and president of Associated Dry Goods Corporation and former president of Lord Taylor, the department store, died Wednesday at the Hill Haven Nursing Home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 89 years old.
A wide search was begun yesterday for a Queens physician wanted for questioning in the death of a 19-year-old girl.

WASHINGTON, June 7 President Kennedy said today that as far as he knew his invitation to visit Mexico June 29 was still valid despite a bitter attack on the United States yesterday by the Mexican delegate to the Organization of American States.
WASHINGTON, June 7 One autumn evening in 1920, a teen-aged girl stood in a Toledo crowd and heard Warren G. Harding, the pride of Ohio Republicanism, proclaim his qualifications for the Presidency.
ALGIERS, June 7 European extremists resumed a campaign of arson and bombing in the major cities of Algeria today in accordance with an order issued by the Secret Army Organization last night.
Morris Zone, rubber jobber, died yesterday at Beekman Downtown Hospital of complications resulting from surgery. He was 102 years old.

THERE are at least as many imaginary American states as real ones. Novelists delight in inventing states with no dis cernible differences from Michigan or New York or North Carolina and giving them appropriate names.
PARIS, June 7 Ambassador James M. Gavin will go to the United States Saturday to receive an honorary doctor of laws degree at Dartmouth College, the United States Embassy announced today.
After three months of controversy and three series of tests, the city decided yesterday which of four parking meters it likes best.

PARIS, June 7 The Assembly of the Western European Union voted today to ask its Ministerial Council to require France to report on her military atomic program and to accept the Council's determination of permissible nuclear armaments.
BAY SHORE, L.I., June 7 Joseph Profaci, Brooklyn mobster and reputed leader of a powerful underworld syndicate, died of cancer last night at the Southside Hospital here.
WASHINGTON, June 7 President Kennedy vetoed Merriman Smith today.

Moore's, 216 West Forty-sixth Street, JUdson 2-9820. This restaurant, in the heart of the threatre district, has an excellent menu that is American to the core. Neat, turn-of-thecentury atmosphere. Specialties are corned beef and Irish stew and the seafood is first rate. All meals a la carte.
WASHINGTON, June 7 President Kennedy took the first step today toward obtaining a Federal court injunction to halt for eighty days the Republic Aviation Corporation strike at Farmingdale, L.I.

WASHINGTON, June 7 Jed Smith Foster, father of William C. Foster, director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, died today at Orangeburg (S.C.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 95 years old.
A committee of seven prominent citizens was appointed yesterday by the Board of Education to help it find a new Superintendent of Schools.
Vincent W. Hartnett denied yesterday that he had blacklisted radio and television performers or accepted fees for "clearing" their names.
LONDON, June 8 The Labor party sees a multiracial Commonwealth as an instrument for leading the new nations of Africa and Asia "forward to the light," Harold Wilson declared today.
Knighthood, an approaching fiftieth birthday and the rise of Peter Sellers have brought about a change in Alex Guinness.

WASHINGTON, June 6 Dr. Vladimir K. Zworykin was granted a patent this week for a rocket to be used in detecting the electric charges on clouds and in influencing weather. He has assigned the patent to the Radio Corporation of America, of which he is honorary vice president.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) Lionel Hampton, the jazz musician, tonight signed a contract to become musical director of the first television statioy planned for a Negro audience.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 8 (AP)--A Superior Court judge today upheld the contention of an unfrocked Roman Catholic priest that he was not the father of a fourth daughter born to his wife in Glen Head, L. I.
Dr. James F. Redmond, former Superintendent of Schools in New Orleans, has been ofered a job as deputy superintendent by the New York City Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, June 8 A former high official of the Agriculture Department told House investigators today that he and an assistant had received $400 from Billie Sol Estes but had sent the money to the Democratic party.

Charles J. Fitzpatrick, who was suspended by the State Harness Racing Commission for failure to report an alleged conflict of interest involving a horse he was catch-driving, won a stay of the sixty-night suspension from the Appellate Division yesterday.

Stocks continued to drift in the doldrums yesterday in slow trading. For the second consecutive day, most price changes on the New York Stock Exchange were limited to less than a point. The end result was a minor gain on average.

Five of Japan's free-style wrestlers captured individual titles and the San Francisco Olympic Club retained team honors yesterday in the Amateur Athletic Union's national senior championships at the New York Athletic Club.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) A flurry of buying, which started the grain futures market off in a firm range today, was quickly smothered by renewed liquidation. Prices finished generally lower on the Board of Trade.

The policy statement adopted by Congressional Republicans dedicates the party to the preservation and enlargement of human freedom; but the means it suggests are contradictory and, in some cases, perilous.

Sears, Roebuck Co. is going into the art business. The giant mail-order and retail chain has commissioned Vincent Price, the art collector and Hollywood actor, to seek art throughout the United States and abroad.

The American Enka Corporation does not expect an early end to a strike at its plant in Enka, N.C., Philip B. Stull, president, said at a special stockholders meeting here yesterday.
William S.B. Braithwaite, poet, anthologist and literary critic, died yesterday in his home at 409 Edgecombe Avenue after a brief illness. He was 83 years old.

The field for today's running of the mile-and-a-half Belmont Stakes was definitely, although surprisingly, set at eight horses when the entries closed a little after 10 o'clock yesterday morning.

CLIFTON N. J., June 8--Sam Snead, now 50 years old, played the kind of golf today any youngster would envy. With a 66, six under par for the Upper Montclair Country Club course, he assumed the lead in the $100,000 Thunderbird Classic.
PARIS, June 8 France's Finance Minister, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, indicated today that new help for the United States balance of payments problem would be forthcoming.

PARIS, June 8 The idea of a large drawing by the United States from the International Monetary Fund has begun to be viewed favorably in the highest official circles in Europe. The aim of such a drawing would be to halt almost completely United States gold losses over the next year, while the deficit in the balance of international payments is gradually eliminated.

WOMAN who was giving advice to parents when Theodore Roosevelt occupied the White House in 1906 reminisced recently about some changes in child-rearing, courtship and marriage since the turn of the century.

WHITE PLAINS, June 8 Edwin G. Michaelian, County Executive of Westchester, was exonerated of a "political payoff" charge today by two special deputies he had designated to investigate the case.

Both seamen's unions that have tied up millions of dollars worth of shipping in a jurisdictional dispute over manning rights were told by the National Labor Relations Board yesterday that they were on tenuous grounds.

Mary M. Blair, retired superintendent of elementary schools on Staten Island, died yesterday morning in her home at 395 Henderson Avenue, Randall Manor, S.I.

Forty-four years in aviation including a historic transAtlantic flight, have left undiminished Clarence D. Chamberlin's zest for flying or the verve of his views on the air industry today.
A school principal who not infrequently excuses thirdgraders so that they can pick up their unemployment checks, said farewell to her students yesterday.

C. Norman Shaffer, lawyer here who was long active, in the paper industry, died Thursday of a heart attack in Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 67 years old and lived at 138-22 Seventy eighth Drive, Kew Gardens, Queens.

Distressing news from Brazil sent world sugar futures sharply upward as volume climbed to the third highest of the year at the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Other commodities were mixed in quiet pre-week-end trading.

HYANNIS, Mass., June 8 (AP)-- Seven more Negroes were on the way to Cape Cod today from Shreveport, La. The raised the total of "reverse Freedom Riders" on the way or arrived at Hyannis to sixty-five.

WASHINGTON, June 8 A labor union that fined members for having exceeded a limit it had placed on their output did not violate Federal labor law, a trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board ruled today.
GENEVA, June 8 Gottlieb Duttweiler, wealthy merchant and one of Switzerland's most controversial figures, died in Zurich today of a heart ailment. He was 73 years old.
A grand jury is investigating a report that a high city official took a $25,000 bribe from a representative of a parking meter company.

The bond market had a quiet and firm trading session yesterday, with major interest centering on efforts of the Federal Reserve system to check the current bent of the money market toward lower short-term rates.

A new era in New York's courts begins Sept. 1. At that time, ten existing courts in the city will be merged into new city-wide courts of civil and criminal jurisdiction, the new state-wide Family Court and the present Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, June 8 President Kennedy himself took the initiative last Wednesday to get the Senate to modify its action on his foreign aid bill, officials disclosed today.
A recent trend in suburban apartment development has been the emergence of so-called "Siamese-twin" buildings.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 8 Africans and the Soviet bloc overrode Western opposition today to recommend the addition of the Southern Rhodesian question to the agenda of the present session of the General Assembly.
A movement to pool the talents of some of the country's foremost scholars and scientists in a search for a middle road to peace was put on a national basis yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 8 An ambitious, im patient young man whose career in agricultural economics led him to the executive suite of the Department of Agriculture had the center stage today in a Congressional investigation of the affairs of Billie Sol Estes.
An architect who specializes in designing religious buildings advises congregations to save the original drawings after the church or parish hall has been constructed.
Maritime labor costs to the Government went up $9,500,000 in the fiscal year 1962 as a result of wage contracts signed by fifteen subsidized shipping operators.
A two-month-old trial of fourteen men on narcotics conspiracy charges was adjourned yesterday until Monday after a defendant attempted suicide in his cell.

The leader of a group of dissident brokers who helped oust the former administration of the American Stock Exchange last year sees a threat to the existence of stock specialists because of a recent action by the exchange.
CHAMBER music, which was spirited away from the salon and placed in the concert hall a century ago, has come home again.

MADRID, Saturday, June 9--Apparently spurred by three recent bombings, Generalissimo Francisco Franco and his Cabinet issued a decree early today suspending for two years the constitutional right of Spaniards freely to choose where they will live within the country.
Three students at Long Island University's Brooklyn Center have been expelled over the theft of final examination questions, the university announced yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8--Marilyn Monroe was dismissed today by the head of the Twentieth Century-Fox studio from a movie she is making for Fox.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 8 Negotiators for West Coast shipowners and longshoremen have been engaged for three weeks in little-publicized talks over contract changes.
AUSTIN, Tex., June 8 (AP) Attorney General Will Wilson of Texas said today "tmat there is no doubt in my mind that Henry H. Marshall aided Billie Sol Estes in his operations."
LONDON, June 8 The Epsom Downs stewards today attributed the seven-horse pile-up in last Wednesday's Epsom Derby to the presence of inferior horses in the field of twenty-six.
CHICAGO, June 8 Harold H. Swift, honorary board chairman of Swift Co., meat packing concern, died of a heart attack today in Billings Memorial Hospital. He was 77 years old.

ALGIERS, June 8 European terrorists pursued their renewed scorched-earth campaign for the second day today by touching off explosions and setting fires in more than a dozen public buildings in Algiers alone.
TOTOWA, N. J., June 8 (UPI) A near riot occurred tonight when a fight between Tom McNeeley and Don McAteer was stopped by Referee Paul Cavalier at 2 minutes 40 seconds of the sixth round.

BLUE POINT, L.I., June 8 The Suffolk County Republican Committee endorsed Dr. Walter M. Ormsby of Bayport tonight as its candidate for Representative from the county's newly drawn First Congressional District.

YONKERS, June 8 New Jersey's ten-woman team won the Golf Illustrated Trophy for the first time since 1956 today over the hilly Hudson River Country Club course.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 8 In the Christ and Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Lily de Pourtales Lodge was married to James Lewis Marcus. She is the daughter of former Gov. John Davis Lod0ge of Connecticut and Mrs. Lodge.

Earnings of the Columbia Pictures Corporation for the nine months ended on March 31 rose sharply from the level of the year-earlier period, the company reported yesterday. Earnings before taxes and property sales amounted to $2,127,000, in contrast to $56,000 for the nine months to April 1, 1961.

DETROIT, June 8 (AP) The Kohler Company of Kohler, Wis., has offered to resume negotiations June 19 with the United Automobile Workers.
The National Broadcasting Company yesterday spelled out its willingness to let the National Association of Broadcasters have advance screenings for some television shows.
"Theatre for Large Audiences," an international seminar on the performing arts, will be held in Athens from June 16 through June 24.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 8--During an intermission at the theatre here the other evening a tight knot of people gathered at one end of the foyer. It kept growing larger and tighter. The faces in the group were tense.

The National Labor Relations Board yesterday dismissed charges of unfair labor practices brought by three Teamster Union locals against ice cream manufacturers who shut down eleven plants after the Meadow Gold plant had been struck on May 2.

PARIS, June 8 The Senate errs even in fixing automatic limits on United States aid to countries having a "Communist or Marxist form of Government." This raises unnecessary issues of political semantics and restricts the freedom of maneuver needed in foreign policy by the Executive.
BOULDER, Colo., June 8 Work is being rushed on what is believed to be the first balloon launching pad. From it, gigantic spheres will lift entire laboratories to the upper reaches of the atmosphere.

A handwriting expert testified yesterday that doodles in the office diary of Elliott Kahaner had obliterated notations concerning Dr. Robert M. Erdman and Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh.
SEOUL, Korea, June 8 South Korean military authorities called in troops today to block demonstrations by about 800 students at Seoul University. About thirty students were arrested.

WASHINGTON, June 8 Congress began trying to decide today whether Franklin D. Roosevelt should be memorialized with the simple stone marker he is reported to have wanted or with eight towering concrete slabs.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) An inquiry of nearly nine months into allegations by Senator Strom Thurmond that the Pentagon had curbed military men ended today with short tempers and sharp exchanges.

Following, as transmitted yesterday in English by Tass, the Soviet press agency, is the text of a Soviet note to Britain on the Berlin situation. Similar notes were sent to the United States and France.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 8 The Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Nancy Scott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Corwin Spencer Scott, to David Horton Carnahan Jr. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Carnahan of Cedarhurst, L.I.
LIMA, Peru, June 8 The military Secretaries clamped a ban today on all contact between members of the armed forces and the political parties that are competing in Sunday's national elections.

LOS ANGELES, June 8 California's primary election has projected a November runoff clash between rival philosophies of education. At stake will be the direction of one of the nation's largest public school systems.

Temple Israel's last worship service at 210 West Ninety-first Street will be conducted on Saturday. SERANIUMS are one of the most popular plants for city window boxes, back yards and terraces. There are many types zonal, ivyleaved, scented-leaved, dwarf and species to add variety to urban plantings.

The nation's railroads were loud in their complaints last week about a $105,000,000 new wage burden they must now shoulder. The figure is the estimated annual increase in labor costs brought on by the wage settlement reached Tuesday with non-operating employes.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 9 The University of Minnesota faculty senate has approved an internal reorganization calculated to spur the university's liberal arts role. The project has, been under study for two years.

MADISON, N.J., June 9 A plea that "all the arts the lively and creative arts, the fine arts and the popular arts receive among us the credit that is their due" was made today by August Heckscher, special consultant on the arts to President Kennedy.

RICK BESOYAN, who wrote "Little Mary Sunshine," has completed a new musical, which will be presented on Broadway early next year. The title is "The Student Gypsy or the Prince of Liederkranz." Like "Little Mary," its book, music and lyrics are by Mr. Besoyan.

VIENTIANE, Laos, June 9 Laos' three political princes came closer this week than ever to agreement on a coalition government to unify this fragmented country, but at weekend they still had not been able to reach final settlement.

Mrs. Jean DiFede, 36-yearold mother of two, and her teen-age boy friend, Armando Cossentino, were convicted in Queens County Court last night of slaying her husband. An allmale jury had deliberated two days.

PARIS, JUNE 10 Another brick has been laid in the defense wall being built by the leading European and North American countries to protect the world monetary system.
LONDON, June 10 Business slowed down in the stock market Friday as brokers and jobbers joined or prepared to join millions of other Britons on a long week-end holiday.

HAVANA, June 10 (AP) Cubans partial to the revolution begun by Premier Fidel Castro take pride in modern housing developments that have sprung up, mainly on palm-dotted fields but also around several cities.
