WASHINGTON, June 10 Justice Hugo L. Black of the Supreme Court believes that the Constitution prohibits all damage suits for libel and slander.

The transformation of the highly esteemed jazz vocal trio of Lambert, Hendricks and Ross to Lambert, Hendricks and Yolande has resulted in the addition of Ceylon to the growing list of countries that have become sources of jazz talent.
LIMA, Peru, Monday, June 11 A three-way race for the Presidency of Peru developed today in early returns from yesterday's national election.

Consolidated net earnings of the Universal Pictures Company, Inc., for the twenty-six weeks ended on April 28 rose sharply, amounting to $3,371,647, after provision of $3,080,000 for Federal income taxes, according to a report issued for publication today.

Willard Swire, executive director of the American National Theatre and Academy since 1953, has resigned, effective today. No successor has been designated as yet to the organization's key administrative post.
Frederick H. Boland, Ireland's permanent representative in the United Nations, declared yesterday that Roman Catholic students should not be permitted to graduate unless they understood communism.
Democrats have begun a detailed study of voter registration in the Bronx to help them plan a nation-wide campaign to increase the urban vote in this fall's elections.
Charles Cogen was re-elected yesterday as president of the United Federation of Teachers for another two-year term. His entire slate was elected with him.
CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) A few scattered flurries of buying failed to pull the grain futures market out of its bearish trend last week.

Miss Ellen Margaret Kheel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore W. Kheel of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married here yesterday afternoon to Arnold Stephen Jacobs. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Jacobs of New York.

"Journey to the Day" may bring Sidney Poitier back to Broadway, where three years ago he scored a success in "A Raisin in the Sun." The actor is waiting for Roger O. Hirson, the author, to complete certain adjustments in the role intended for him. These are expected to be finished by the end of next month.

THE Interscholastic Chess League Tournaments, 1962, in which 119 boys and one girl competed, represented eighteen junior high schools and sixteen senior high schools. The games were played on seven Saturday mornings at the Chess and Checker Club of New York.

HONG KONG, June 10--Marshal Ho Lung, a Chinese Communist Deputy Premier, attacked tonight what he termed the "new aggresive activities" by United States in Southeast Asia. He said the moves were intented to established a "military encirclement directed mainly against China."

When President Kennedy promised "across the board" tax reductions last week, he appealed to the taxpayer's sweet-tooth. But he said the tax cuts would be part of a "comprehensive tax reform bill" and this suggested he would ask Congress to give the taxpayer a bitter pill at the same time. Reform will mean that some avenues of escape from the impact of the basic tax rates will be closed.
MADRID, June 10 Jose Maria Gil Robles, a prominent Right-wing Opposition leader, left here by air this morning for exile in France rather than accept forced residence in Spain.
PEWAUKEE, Wis., June 10 (AP) John C. Schafer, a former Republican Representative of Wisconsin, died of a heart attack yesterday at his brother's home. He was 69 years old.
Religious schools and public schools are partners as well as competitors, Msgr. Charles J. McManus said yesterday.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 10 Robert Young sailed Running Bear to victory in the 210 class in today's Yacht Racing Association Regatta, the season's ninth on Long Island Sound. As a result of his triumph, Young led his class in the special three-race series that constituted the Beach Point Yacht Club's annual June regatta.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes aligned himself yesterday with those who believe the state ought to raise from 18 to 21 the age at which a person may legally buy an intoxicating drink.

WASHINGTON, June 10--The frock coats have not yet been put in mothballs nor the attache cases stored away, but the State Department is hesitantly exploring the possibility of solving the nation's foreign-policy problems with computers.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) Washington scored 2-1 and 5-4 victories over the Detroit Tigers today, with Don Rudolph pitching a five-hitter in winning the first game.
MEDFORD, Mass., June 10 (AP) Adlai E. Stevenson declared today public spending for education, urban development, and similar projects was vital if the United States economy was to expand.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 10--Not since shortly after Premier Abdul Karim Kassim's coup in July 1958 has Iraq's policy so clearly favored the Soviet Union over the West.

PRODUCING a hot meal on a cold day can be a pleasure. But the preparation of a cold meal on a hot day is not usually quite so enjoyable. Unless a sortia to the delicatessen is envisaged, even cold meals, normally require some form of cooking. Fortunately, however, there are a few exceptions to this rule main courses that may be made from ingredients that never have been, and never will be, cooked.
Twenty players in white shirts and bow ties demonstrated the Italian game of boccie yesterday morning on a new clay court in the midst of an East Harlem housing development.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 10 (UPI) U Thant, acting Secretary General of the United Nations, criticized today the proposals for weighted voting to prevent new African and Asian countries from "running away with" the world organization.
Crucial decisions affecting this year's round of bargaining between ship operators and dock workers will be faced in the next few days in New York and other Atlantic ports.

PARIS, June 10 NATO is almost certainly about to withdraw its protective umbrella from a vast section of Africa although this seemingly important topic has yet to be discussed by the alliance or any of its members. The area involved is Algeria.

EAST LANSING, Mich., June 10 (UPI)--The Senate Democratic Leader, Mike Mansfield, criticized United States policy in Southeast Asia today and called for a hard, critical study to determine whether another course could be found.
TOKYO, June 10 (AP) Japan appears to be heading for a large-scale expansion of exports to Communist nations and the trend is definite, a responsible trade association spokesman, said.
QUALMS about motherhood are about as typical a symp tom of a first pregnancy as an expanding waistline, according to the authors of a new book on childbirth.
Governor Rockefeller defended New York State's legislative apportionment yesterday with full knowledge that it will be a major issue in his campaign for re-election this year.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 10 (Reuters) A powerful Soviet Union team was eliminated from the World Soccer Cup play-offs today and the defending champion, Brazil, went into the semi-finals with a victory over England.

LIDICE, Czechoslovakia, June 10 Antonin Novotny, Czechoslovak Communist chief, delivered a slashing attack on the Western powers here today at ceremonies marking the twentieth anniversary of the Nazi destruction of Lidice.

POUND RIDGE, N.Y., June 10 The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Anne Sussman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph M. Sussman of New York, to Robert Harry Socolow took place here today. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Walter Socolow, also of New York.
HANOVER, N. H., June 10 The nation's chief disarmament negotiator declared today that an immediate solution of the East-West rivalry favorable to American ideals was not an absolute necessity.

A FURNITURE factory in the Bronx is developing a split personality. One shift produces finished chests, benches, tables, hutches, chairs, beds and mirror frames. The next makes the identical designs for do-it-yourself kits.

CLIFTON, N.J., June 10 Officials of the Professional Golfers Association consider the return of top-drawer tournament golf to the metropolitan district a success, Jim Gaquin, the P.G.A. tournament director, said tonight.

CINCINNATI, June 10 (UPI) Jim Maloney celebrated his return to the Cincinnati Reds by defeating the Philadelphia Phillies today, 9 2, in the second game of a double-header. The Phils won the opener, 7 5, on Wes Covington's slugging and Jack Baldschun's relief pitching.
ATHENS, June 10--The Government appealed to farmers today to limit wheat-growing on the ground that it deprived Greece of substantial United States aid in agricultural surpluses.

A FLOWER-LOVING English textile designer, as blond and fragile-looking as the primroses she loves to draw, has been in New York recently looking for inspiration. But the only flowers that captured her imagination were the artificial ones on women's hats.
The "Monday morning quarterback" always has an easy job.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, June 10 Paul Keres of the Soviet Union took the lead once again in the Candidates' Chess Tournament by winning his twentieth-round game from Pal Benko of the United States in a Sicilian Defense going thirtyeight moves.
Peter Mennin, one of America's leading composers, has been named to one of the most important musical posts the country has to offer the presidency of the Juilliard School of Music.
WASHINGTON, June 10 Three major aluminum companies have offered to buy the surplus aluminum in the Government's stockpile, provided they can have twenty years to do so.
ROME, June 10 Municipal elections that are considered a crucial test for Premier Amintore Fanfani's new Center-Left coalition started quietly today in 157 cities and towns.
A staff of about 100 professional city planners is trying a new approach, keyed to the basic needs and desires of the public, to solve the city's complex problems.
LONDON, June 10--A communion service in St. Paul's Cathedral tomorrow will mark the final healing of the great church's wartime wounds.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 10 Mrs. Crawford Blagden has been named permanent chairman of the Tuxedo Autumn Ball Committee. The event will be held this year on Oct. 20 in the Tuxedo Club with twelve debutantes as guests of honor.
Too little attention has been paid to the Administration's request for stand-by authority to reduce individual income taxes to combat recession.
Mayors from some fifty of Puerto Rico's seventy-six municipalities were among 50,000 persons who marched, danced or rode up Fifth Avenue yesterday in the sixth annual Puerto Rican parade.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 10 Cameo, a chestnut mare, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Donald Shapiro of Glen Head, L.I., took the open jumper championship today with 14 points at the Sands Point Horse Show. The Port Washington Lions Club was the sponsor.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 10 Premier Ismet Inonu's efforts to form a national coalition Government received a serious setback today when Justice party organizational leaders meeting in Ankara bitterly attacked his Peoples Republican party.

VALHALLA, N.Y., June 10 Plans for a multi-purpose four-year state college in Westchester were discussed by Governor Rockefeller today at the fourteenth annual commencement exercises of the Westchester Community College.

BERTRAND RUSSELL checked in with David Susskind last night. THEY will be playing the United States Open this week without Ben Hogan. The advancing years are beginning to catch up with Blazin' Ben, now approaching ...

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) The nation's civil defense chief said today the Government had no hopes or illusions about preventing "tens of millions" of deaths in the event of an all-out nuclear attack on the United States.

LOS ANGELES, June 10 (UPI) A Leon Wagner single drove home Albie Pearson in the sixth inning with the tiebreaking run today for a 6 5 Los Angeles victory over the Kansas City Athletics after the Angels, with Billy Moran driving in six runs, took the opener by 14 6.
"Mutiny on the Bounty" is reaching the end of an extended and expensive production journey.

ALBANY, June 10 On the basis of planning research by numerous agencies, public and private, the Rockefeller Administration will attempt to draw a picture of the needs of the state in the Nineteen Eighties.
A thorough study of the economics of air safety was urged yesterday by the CornellGuggenheim Aviation Safety Center in its twelfth annual survey of research projects.

GENEVA, June 10 The Swiss stock markets retreated on a broad front last week with sellers dominating the fairly heavy trading. No group of domestic issues escaped the trend and losses were often sharp.
MOSCOW, June 10 (UPI) Igor Ter-Ovanesyan of the Soviet Union smashed the world broad jump record today by leaping 8.31 meters (27 feet 3 inches), Tass, the official Soviet press agency, reported.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, June 10 The United States Army is resuming a policy that assigns troop indoctrination responsibilities to company officers rather than, as in recent years, to divisional and even higher headquarters.

For the first time since the Spanish Civil War ended twenty-three years ago, it is possible to say without fear of exaggeration that the Franco regime is in crisis. The working classes have won the right to strike; the Government has shown a surprising weakness; the monolithic structure of the Franco dictatorship has cracked.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 10 (AP) Polly Adler, who told of a twenty-five-year career as the madam of a house of prostitution in her book "A House Is Not a Home," died of cancer yesterday in Cedars of Lebanon Hospital. She was 62 years old.

Patrons of a Queens bar including two off-duty patrolmen turned on three gunmen who tried to hold them up early today. One policeman and a civilian were wounded, one of the gunmen was slain and a second was beaten unconscious. The third gunman escaped.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 10 A Twentieth Century-Fox executive declared today that movie studios could no longer afford to risk millions of dollars in films by permitting the whims of movie stars to control production schedules.
Plans are now under way to bring a troupe of Ivory Coast dancers and musicians to America late next year for a tour.
PITTSBURGH, June 10 Steel officials reported that demand was generally level last week.
The Federal Maritime Commission has been ordered to permit steamship lines to impose storage charges on certain strike-bound cargoes they cannot deliver to importers.

The Rev. Dr. Stuart Hamilton Merriam, ousted minister of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, worshiped yesterday with the congregation at Rutgers Presbyterian Church, 236 West Seventy-third Street. He took no part in conducting the service.

WASHINGTON, June 10 Following are the votes of Senators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on major roll-calls in the week ended yesterday. There were no major roll-calls in the House of Representatives.

MILWAUKEE, June 10 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Pirates survived a last-inning drive by the Milwaukee Braves today for a 3-2 victory in the second game of a double-header. The Pirates also took the first game, 12 8, with a fifteen-hit attack powered by Bill Mazeroski's two homers.

MANASQUAN, N.J., June 10 Holy Trinity Lutheran Church was the setting today for the marriage of Miss Rae Ellen Hanewald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Hanewald of Metedeconk, to Joseph William Wood Harsch. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Harsch of Washington, Jamestown, R. I., and London.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 10 Resurgence of world trade in oilseeds, oils and fats appear probable in 1962 after a setback last year, the Food and Agriculture Organization reports in its annual commodity review. Global production is expected to increase.
ALGIERS, June 10 European terrorists sabotaged a gas well yesterday in the Sahara, in southern Algeria, it was announced today.
The world of the beat and the offbeat was welcomed into the Presbyterian Spencer Memorial Church yesterday at Clinton and Remsen Streets in Brooklyn.

Trading continued quiet in the domestic cotton market last week. Spot values improved somewhat; futures prices closed with small net losses.

HOUSTON, June 10 (AP) The Los Angeles Dodgers scored six runs in the sixth inning today and won the second game of a double-header, 9 7, from the Houston Colts. The Dodgers also took the opener, 9 3, on Don Drysdale's six-hitter before 30,027.
CHICAGO, June 10 The Cubs and the Mets, performing like the ninth and tenth-place outfits they are, divided a double-header at Wrigley Field today in an exchange of giveaways.

Eastern Air Lines asserted yesterday that its much-debated air-shuttle service between New York, Boston and Washington was "solidly profitable" and, for the first time, backed up its claims with figures.

British pound sterling was erratic on moderate turnover during the past week. Canadian dollar continued steady in a dull market.

This reply to your letter of May 10 on behalf of the executive committee of the Citizens Union of the City of New York has been delayed until I had the opportunity to set out for you in full my present thinking regarding the apportionment of seats in the New York Legislature.
CLIFTON, N.J., June 10 In a prelude to the defense of his United States Open golf championship, Gene Littler won the $100,000 Thunderbird Classic tourney today.

ATLANTA, June 10 Students will be admitted on a nonracial basis next September to Roman Catholic schools in the Archdiocese of Atlanta.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 10 Ch. Willets Red Jacket, a big-boned Pembroke Welsh Corgi owned by Mrs. William B. Long of Carlisle, Mass., rounded out an even dozen best-in-show victories in the thirtieth event of the Longshore-Southport Kennel Club today.

Fire Commissioner Edward Thompson sent to Mayor Wagner yesterday an annual report showing that the city's firemen had answered a record total of 97,683 alarms in 1961, about one-fifth of which were false.

Factional conflicts within the Democratic party, based on ideological and philosophical differences, are disturbing Mayor Wagner and other party leaders. Some top Democratic strategists fear that these conflicts could seriously reduce Democratic chances of winning this year's election, if they have not ...
SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 The wave of office building construction in many of the nation's largest cities appears not to have resulted in the vacanies that were widely predicted for older structures.

Japan's crack wrestling team and the United States Navy's Pearl Harbor Admirals shared the honors last night as the Greco-Roman championships of the Amateur Athletic Union's 1962 national senior tourney ended.
WASHINGTON, June 10 Stock market margin requirements will remain as is for the time being, according to authorities here, unless the market really goes "dead."

OTTAWA, June 8 The New Democratic party, a Socialist blending of the old Cooperative Commonwealth Federation and organized labor, is not expected now to have much effect in the Canadian election June 18.

The New York Yankees, leading the American League by two games when they went into a double-header with the Baltimore Orioles at the Stadium yesterday, finished the afternoon a bare 10 percentage points ahead of the secondplace Minnesota Twins.

POZNAN, Poland, June 10 (AP) The thirty-first Poznan International Fair opened today with the United States and Soviet exhibitions side by side. West Germany showed a vast assortment of industrial machinery.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. yesterday repeated his charge that the state had discriminated against Negro communities in the distribution of Federal funds for construction and renovation of hospitals.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System presented at 10 A.M. yesterday the world premiere of George Antheil's Cantata, "Cabeza de Vaca." This was the last work written by the American composer, who died in 1959.

Charles H. Brower, president of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., advertising agency, recommended yesterday that college graduates return to America's "old beliefs in ideals, pride, patriotism, loyalty, devotion and even hard work." He spoke at the Pace College commencement in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, June 10 The nation's space program, until now largely a civilian undertaking, is set to acquire a military tinge.

America of Rio de Janeiro, the only unbeaten team in the first section of the International Soccer League, had to settle for a 1-1 tie with Reutlingen of West Germany yesterday at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

MOSCOW, June 10 Two 25year-old Armenians who tried to hijack a light plane last September for a flight abroad have been sentenced to death for treason and an attempt on the pilot's life.

Mercaz Equities, Inc., has sold the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 639 West End Avenue, northwest corner of Ninety-first Street, to Leon Scharf for investment. Phillips, Wood, Dolson, Inc., was the broker. The building is on a plot 65 by 100 feet and contains sixty-two apartments. It was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $580,000.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 10 (AP) The hitting of Rich Rollins and clutch performances by three pitchers enabled the Minnesota Twins to take a double-header today from the Chicago White Sox.

SEATTLE, Wash., June 10 A sweeping series of victories in this year's elections by the Republican party, composed of "kinda lousy politicians," was forecast today by Representative William E. Miller of New York.

Plans for a long-range program to improve employment, education and social opportunities for the youth of Central Harlem were announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
After drifting in the doldrums during the three preceding trading sessions, the stock market abruptly went into a steep decline yesterday. The volume of trading increased sharply on the downturn.
WASHINGTON, June 12 Senators got some fundamental instruction today in the role of the stripper, the exotic dancer and the B-girl in the context of labor-management relations.
WASHINGTON, June 12 The most interesting commencement speech of this year was one that was discussed in Washington but never delivered.
ROME, June 12 Complete returns from the administrative elections Sunday and yesterday indicated today that the new Italian Center-Left regime was here to stay, at least for some time.
City College will graduate its largest class in ten years at commencement exercises in Lewisohn Stadium tonight.

The Yankees discovered an antidote last night to Detroit's Frank Lary, who has been pitching poison to them for years. Manager Ralph Houk turned Bill Stafford loose against the Tigers and the rangy young right-hander proved even more venomous than Lary.

Good news has come from Laos. As a result of successful completion of negotiations between the three political forces of Laos, it has been possible to form a coalition Government of national unity headed by Prince Souvanna Phouma.

The petroleum industry continues to be a source of turbulence along Madison Avenue. Within the last eighteen months, such well-known oil concerns as Union Oil Company, Texaco, Inc., and Socony Mobil Oil Company have announced agency shifts.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12--Miss Sally Day Storm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Storm of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to Henry Francis Sears 2d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sears of New York.
Budget Director David E. Bell expressed Confidence yesterday about the present state of the American economy but was uncertain about possible developments this summer and fall.
SEATTLE, Wash., June 12 A Republican gain of four to six seats in the United States Senate in the November election is "a reasonable expectation," the Republican National Committee was told today.

Senator Clifford P. Case last night urged a reappraisal of the plan for a Department of Urban Affairs and Housing. He laid its defeat in Congress in part on the Kennedy Administration's "insufficient emphasis" on suburban problems.

THERE seems to be an increasing restiveness evi dent in outdoor circles over the Government's carrying out of the Wetlands Acquisition Program, which was de signed to save a part of the nation's duck-nesting grounds from destruction.
PARENTS who are concerned with the way their child talks or the fact that he does not talk at all should scrutinize their own speech habits, according to Miss Flora Rheta Schreiber.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 12 Disarmament will result in economic problems and opportunities for industry, a Governent official said here today.
TUNIS, June 12 The Algerian Nationalist Provisional Government will issue a declaration tomorrow giving "assurances" to Europeans on their future in an independent Algeria.

LONDON, June 12--Australia will refuse to agree to the abandonment of Commonwealth preferences by 1970 as a price of Britain's entry into the European Economic Community, her Prime Minister, Robert Gordon Menzies, declared tonight.

FRUITS for dessert seem particularly appropriate for summer. This is not only because so many delectable varieties come into season at this time, but also because most fruits have a refreshing tartness that provides just the right taste to conclude hot weather meals.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 12--Reliable sources said today that the United Nations would have to borrow $2,000,000 or $3,000,000 in the next few days to help meet... bills for its Congo force, its emergency force in Egypt and routine activities.

The first factory entry for the Grand Prix de Puerto Rico, to be run in November, was announced yesterday by David Ash, race chairman. Now under construction in the John Cooper plant in England, the car is a new ...

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 12 The New York Knickerbockers, who have been pushed around considerably by the other National Basketball Association clubs in recent years, could exert some pressure of their own next season with the finest crop of rookies in the seventeen-year history of the club.

A special detail of Customs inspection personnel will leave today by car for Albany to handle the debarkation of 235 passengers the first passenger ship arrival at the state capital to require such services within memory of observers.
The nation's railroads reduced their passenger operating deficit by $77,000,000 last year to $408,200,000 the lowest level since 1946, a study by the Interstate Commerce Commission showed yesterday.
Pedestrians will find a new traffic-light arrangement at Seventh Avenue and Thirtysecond Street late next week to end the confusion in signals there.
LIMA, Peru, June 12 Tension over conflicting claims of victory increased here as the official count began today in Peru's national elections.
The Rent and Rehabilitation Administration yesterday announced three changes in the city's tenant relocation regulations, which go into effect today.

EDITORIALIZING by radio and television broadcast ers is growing throughout the country, but few station owners carry their civic zeal as far as R. Peter Straus, president of WMCA. On Monday Mr. Straus had the satisfaction ...

ONCE upon a time, women did not talk about money. In fact, it was even considered ladylike not to know about money. Those days are gone forever. With 24,000,000 women now working in the United States, it is not surprising that a good part of the female population is curious about money to some degree.
JERSEY CITY, June 12 (AP) Three school officials, a contracting company and the company's president were convicted tonight of having conspired to avoid state bidding laws.

Governor Rockefeller refused yesterday to reconsider his refusal to call the Legislature into special session to deal with legislative reapportionment despite a fresh barrage of demands for such action.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 12 A van driver swore here today that he helped whisk an 8-year-old boy into hiding two years ago to prevent the boy's parents from taking him back to the Soviet Union. The boy is still missing.
HONG KONG, June 12 Observers here believe that conditions are ripening in the neighboring Kwangtung Province of Communist China for a new mass refugee assault on Hong Kong's border.

THE riotous disturbance at the Yankee Stadium the night before last was made singularly disgraceful by the actions of the two rival managers, Ralph Houk of the Yanks and Billy Hitchcock of the Orioles. They provoked it because they blew their tops. Instead of being restraining influences on the youthful hot-heads under their commands, they went beserk in trying to exact personal vengeance by physical violence on each other.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) The Senate Judiciary Committee went ahead today with its overhaul of a drug industry regulatory measure over the bitter protests of its sponsor Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee.
WASHINGTON, June 12 Getting the big powers out of Laos loomed today as a problem as difficult as their involvement in the fighting there in recent years.
Mr. Ireland's work at the college influenced many English composers. His distinguished pupils included Benjamin Britten, Alan Bush, Humphrey Searle and Richard Arnell.
LONDON, June 12 Heavy Continental and United States buying again raised prices of gold mine shares today when the stock market resumed after yesterday's Whit Monday holiday.

WASHINGTON, June 12 President Roberto F. Chiari of Panama arrived here this morning for two days of discussions with President Kennedy over the Panama Canal. Panama wants more benefits from the canal.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 12 President Moise Tshombe of Katanga province said today that the Congolese Government was unwilling to make concessions in the present negotiations for an end of Katanga's secession because the Government believed the United Nations would help it take Katanga by force if the talks fail.
The Standardbred Owners Association yesterday denounced the State Harness Racing Commission for the penalties it imposed following the disturbances at Yonkers Raceway on May 29.

IT was only a simple family wedding celebrated in the flower-filled living room of the McNeils' suburban house. Sally McNeil, whose mother was one of the Boston Gardiners, was marrying Mark Gallatin, whose family had French connections. It was June and the weather was perfect. Only relatives and close friends were present.
The plan of the segregationist White Citizens Councils to ship at least 1,000 impoverished Negroes to the North in "reverse Freedom Rides" has fallen far short of its goal.
Montefiore and Mount Sinai Hospitals, two of the city's largest voluntary institutions, will be largely responsible for the medical staffing of two city hospitals beginning July 1.
Sales and earnings of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation for the fiscal year ended on April 30 were the highest in the history of the producer of cellulose and paper products, it was announced yesterday.
The North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference has asked the Federal Maritime Commission to give it some ammunition with which to fight independent carriers in the North Atlantic trades.
CINCINNATI, June 12 (AP) The United States Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals, refused today to order immediate desegregation of all municipal recreational facilities and parks in Memphis, Tenn.
The high-grade bond market put on a mildly bullish show yesterday.

The eighteen-story and penthouse office building at 55 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Twelfth Street, has been purchased by the Glickman Corporation, a diversified realty investing company. The purchase included a four-story residential and store building adjoining on Fifth Avenue.

Elliott Kahaner, former Federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, was depicted yesterday as a fine, upstanding young man who could not possibly have committed the "rotten filthy crime" of which he has been accused.
BERLIN, June 12 The motto of the East German authorities seems to be: Speed the parting guest, particularly if he is an American.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 12 --Three Alcatraz convicts, serving long terms for robbery, used spoons to dig and cut their way out of the island penitentiary in San Francisco Bay early today.
WASHINGTON, June 12 Senator Harry F. Byrd, an influential force in Congress on fiscal policy, rejected today President Kennedy's plea for revised thinking on the budget and public debt.
TRENTON, June 12 Gov. Richard J. Hughes today assured completion of a sevenmile-long protective sand dune at Sea Isle City before the hurricane season begins about Aug. 15.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 12--Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium warned the United Nations today that it faced heavy responsibility for avoiding disorder and violence in the trust territories of Ruanda and Urundi when Belgium gives them independence July 1.

"A request for a twenty-foot gondola filled with crepes suzette wouldn't floor us," said Budd Cox, a designer for Dennison's Party Bazaar. Mr. Cox is referring to the store's Personal Party Service Department, which is prepared to decorate anything from an intimate dinner for two to a fiesta for 2,000.

Stravinsky's music turns up on virtually every program these days in recognition of the old master's eightieth birthday, and last night's concert in Carnegie Recital Hall by the New York Chamber Society was no exception.
BERLIN, June 12 A large group of East Germans staged a successful escape to West Berlin today, city officials announced, but they gave no details of the flight for security reasons.
HOUSTON, June 12 The Houston Colts, more pestiferous than last night's mosquitoes, stung the Mets with a ninthinning rally tonight and defeated the New Yorkers, 3 2.
BAD TOLZ, Germany, June 12 More than 1,000 men with a wide range of combat and civilian talents are in training here for what the United States Army considers one of its most vital missions.
Prof. Paul J. Tillich, the Protestant theologian, was named yesterday to a new chair, established by an investment banking concern, at the University of Chicago Divinity School.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 12 South Vietnam's First Lady, Mme. Ngo Dinh Nhu, today bade the mushrooming American colony here to abide by the regime's new puritanical regulations and desist from dancing.
Vincent W. Hartnett, anti-Communist consultant and writer, testified yesterday that he thought it "unrealistic" to rely on legal procedures in assessing a person's patriotism.
POZNAN, Poland, June 12 The United States is making a smooth and persuasive bid to increase its sales of consumer goods to Poland at a moment when the trade prospects are threatened.
Governor Rockefeller called last night for an "all-out offensive against disease" in which all the forces of government and other sectors of American life would be marshalled.

The Federal Aviation Agency said yesterday that a hard left rudder movement resulting from the loss of a small bolt might have caused the March 1 crash of a Boeing 707 jetliner at New York International Airport.
Blackmail, Mrs. Ogden Phipps' excellent jumper, had only his jockey for company yesterday in the final stages of the Meadow Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park.

World sugar futures ended their week-long advance yesterday and closed unchanged to off 5 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on a volume of 13,150 tons on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Other commodities were mixed to off in narrow trading.
COLUMBIA, S.C., June 12 Senator Olin D. Johnston, who supports the Kennedy Administration on key issues other than civil rights, won Democratic renomination today by a 2-to-1 margin.
MANILA, June 12 The Philippines celebrated Independence Day today, switching from July 4, the date the United States granted her independence in 1946.
SUFFERN, N.Y., June 12 Appeals by New Jersey and Connecticut to New York to raise its legal drinking age from 18 to 21, conforming to theirs, ran into heavy opposition at a public hearing here today.
Taylor S. Gay, the oil company executive who was shot in Hudson Terminal on Monday night, died yesterday in the Beekman-Downtown Hospital.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 12 Princeton University conferred 1,086 degrees at its 215th annual commencement today, held during a slight rainfall.
Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy called on the American people yesterday to face the "unusual and heavy burdens" of the present with sound judgment rather than emotion.
WASHINGTON, June 12 The Sente approved tonight funds to acquire property across the Potomac from Mount Vernon and prevent the construction of a sewage disposal plant.

ARDMORE, Pa., June 12 Tish Preuss of the Pompano Beach (Fla.) Country Club and Mrs. Ann Netsky of the Green Valley C.C. in near-by Lafayette Hills, Pa., tied for the lead in the first round of the women's Eastern 54-hole golf championship today with twoover-par 77's on the rainswept East Course of the Merion Country Club.
PIERRE, S.D. Complaints of gross mis treatment of Indians by white policemen dominated a recent hearing on constitutional rights here.

WASHINGTON, June 12 The Government reported mildly encouraging news on employment today. But it had somewhat discouraging news on retail sales, personal income and profits of corporations. The new economic statistics showed that:
WASHINGTON, June 13 Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy had a dozen business leaders in to lunch last week to tell them the Administration had no antagonism to business.
KANSAS CITY, June 13 (UPI) The Kansas City Athletics beat the Chicago White Sox for the second consecutive time, 4 3, tonight. Ed Rakow got credit for the victory.
A narcotics expert suggested last night that all "hard-core" heroin users be confined to prisons or work camps because no effective control had been found for such addiction.
San Diego, Calif., Unified School District plans on July 31 to offer $14,827,000 of school bonds due 1964 to 1983.
The abandoned Air Force training station at Manhattan Beach in Brooklyn is involved these days in a clash of goals.
Prices of prime-risk corporate bonds rose to the best levels of the year in heavy over-thecounter trading yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 13 (UPI) A Federal judge ordered a New York lawyer today to stop practicing in his court. The judge said the lawyer had abused his rights and was too closely linked with the Teamsters Union.
Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg yesterday described as "a lot of nonsense" charges that is Kennedy Administration is anti-labor.
The City Planning Commission yesterday approved the conversion of a drab tract of land in Flatbush, Brooklyn, into a three-acre playground over a 250-car underground garage.

The British Iron and Steel Corporation, Ltd,, the overseas purchasing subsidiary of the British Iron and Steel Federation, has leased space for headquarters in this country in the Pan Am Building, 200 Park Avenue, adjoining Grand Central Terminal.

OAKMONT, Pa., June 13 There is one especially intriguing and provocative aspect of the United States Open golf championship, which will begin on the morrow over the roller-coaster hills of the Oakmont Country Club. It should be the usual terrifying ride. Three times in the past the supreme test of the divot-digging sport has
PARIS, June 13 The Soviet Union gave its hostility to the Common Market concrete form today for the first time by breaking of fthe trade negotiations with France.

While awaiting the results of the extraordinarily close Peruvian election, it is only fair to pay tribute to the way that election was handled. It was secret, honest, democratic. Electoral officials, party officials, army officers and the public all performed their civic functions in exemplary fashion. This week, despite the tension due to not knowing the results, there has been complete calm. The final result will, we hope, be respected by all concerned.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 13 Lloyd Webster Hyde, president of the National Association of Commercial Collection Agencies, died yesterday at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge after a short illness. He was 48 years old and lived at 9 Graham Terrace.

ARDMORE, Pa., June 13 Phyllis (Tish) Preuss of the Pompano Beach (Fla.) Country Club and Mrs. Charles Wilson of the Philadelphia Country Club finished in a tie for the lead today after the second round of the Women's Eastern Golf Association's 54-hole medal play championship.

NEW YORK AIRWAYS, the helicopter line that serves the metropolitan area's three major airports, will have stewardesses for the first time in its ten-year history starting July 1. Eleven brunettes and one auburn-haired woman were hired to staff five new and larger helicopters the concern has added to its fleet.
Governor Rockefeller told a radio audience last night that he would try to obtain an agreement this summer on legislation to license chiropractors in New York.
ABERDEEN, Scotland, June 13 (UPI) Mary Garden, once hailed as the "Queen of American Opera," has given her first performance, since the Nineteen Thirties in a hospital ward.
NEW DELHI, India, June 13 Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today that Soviet MIG's seemed to be the "most suitable" planes to meet India's need for new fighter aircraft.
Rose O'Neill, who once ran as a $6,500 claimer, increased her stakes status yesterday by taking the twelfth running of the $23,300 Vagrancy Handicap at Belmont Park.

SOUTH KINGSTON, R.I., June 13 Charles Crane Colt, 6-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Zenas C. Colt of Matunuck, R.I., and 45 East End Avenue, New York City, was killed on Monday in a four-vehicle crash here.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 13 George W. Ball, Under Secretary of State, today criticized "those still among us" who feel that the forces confronting the non-Communist world "can best be dealt with through incantations."

A NEW kind of dog training course will begin in Great Neck, L.I., in the fall. Its purpose will be to give paraplegics and other disabled persons a new interest. It will be a joint project of the Great Neck Public Schools Adult Education Program, the Long Island Chap
One of the nation's fastest growing indoor sports consists of thinking up ways of befuddling direct mail advertisers.
CHICAGO, June 13 (AP) A variety of considerations exerted a generally bullish influence in grain futures today and prices closed mostly higher ,on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) Johnny Romano's eleventh home run of the season drove in three runs tonight and enabled the Cleveland Indians to snap the Washington Senators' five-game winning streak, 4-1. Washington took the first game of the double-header, 4-2. BOSTON, June 13 (AP) Don Schwall blanked Baltimore with two hits tonight and the Boston Red Sox defeated the Orioles, 4-0.
CLEVELAND, June 13 (AP) John (Hondo) Havlicek, the captain of the Ohio State basketball team last season, signed today with the Cleveland Browns of the National Football League.
The Dictaphone Corporation displayed yesterday its newest dictating machine, the Time-Master Model/7.
WASHINGTON, June 13 James E. Webb, administrator of the Space Agency, told Congress today the next Mercury astronaut probably would be sent on a three-orbit flight.
HAVANA, June 13 (AP) No one starves in Cuba these days, three months after Premier Fidel Castro announced food rationing, but the lack of choice makes shopping lists obsolete.

MOSCOW, June 13 Diplomatic officials here reported today that the agreement in Laos to form a coalition government had strengthened the position of Premier Khrushchev within the Communist bloc. In reply to the criticism of the Chinese Communists and the conservatives in the Soviet leadership,

Nothing but a soft patter of rain fell at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, washing out the series finale between the Yanks and the Detroit Tigers. But for Manager Ralph Houk things were definitely picking up despite the enveloping gloom
PINE RIDGE, S.D. Much of the Pine Ridge Indi an Reservation, the largest in South Dakota, has had almost no law enforcement on its highways for the last year.
WASHINGTON, June 13 Mayor Wagner said today he planned to inject new money and new ideas and techniques into the Democratic party's campaign to attract voters among the country's newest citizens.
TUNIS, June 13 The Algerian nationalists made it plain today that they viewed any increase in the guarantees already accorded to the Europeans of Algeria as impossible.

WASHINGTON, June 13 President Kennedy echoed Premier Khrushchev today in welcoming the formation of a neutral coalition Government in Laos. He warned the Soviet leader, however, that "no untoward actions anywhere" must disrupt the gains that have been made.
CHICAGO, June 13 The Right Rev. Edwin J. Randall, retired Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Chicago, died today at his home in Evanston. He was 92 years old.

ALGIERS, June 13 A spokesman for the Secret Army Organization declared tonight in a pirate broadcast that talks between representatives of his organization and the Algerian nationalists "continued at the highest level."
FRANKLIN, Tex., June 13 Billie Sol Estes spent nearly two hours today with a Robertson County grand jury investigating the death of an Agriculture Department official.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) House Republicans accused the Administration today of having threatened to curtail defense contracts in areas whose Congressmen had refused to support a requested $8,000,000,000 increase in the ceiling of the national debt.
GENEVA, June 13 The United States said today that the establishment of an international peace force was essential for the achievement of general and complete disarmament.

Six building violations cases against a receiver were dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Edward J. Chapman in Housing Court. He directed the Department of Buildings to find the former owner and bring him into court.

Up in Greenfield, Mass., there has been going forward a contest in honor of Father's Day, which is Sunday. Store window cards have urged essayists to write on "My Pop Is Tops, Etc., Etc.," with the prize an excursion by the winner's entire family, including Pop, to a Red SoxYankee ball game.

BRISTOL, England, June 13 (AP) Chuck McKinley of St. Louis, who lost to Rod Laver in the Wimbledon final last year, moved into the quarterfinal round of the West of England tennis tournament today with a pair of victories.
WASHINGTON, June 13 Senators tried today to get some advice on stock prices from a former stockbroker, Douglas Dillon, now Secretary of the Treasury. They were not very successful.
LOS ANGELES, June 13 (AP) The Minnesota Twins rallied on Bob Allison's tworun homer in the eighth inning tonight and took second place in the American League by defeating the Los Angeles Angels, 4-2.
The seventeen-year locust, phenomenon of the insect world, has posed a new mystery in the New York suburban area this year.

The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association struck Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., again yesterday in an effort to establish the principle in deep-sea shipping that labor contracts follow ships in a transfer of ownership.

WASHINGTON, June 13 In the White House there used to be, perhaps still is, a large lighted globe so adjusted that the President could turn it vertically and horizontally whenever he wanted to get an impression of the planet as a whole. If Mr. Kennedy engages in this geographical pastime, more areas of troubles for the United States will come into his purview than any predecessor beheld.
CINCINNATI, June 13 (AP) Bob Purkey, ace of the Cincinnati pitching staff, avenged the Reds' defeat in a doubleheader last night by shutting out the San Francisco Giants, 5-0, tonight on three hits.

ROME, June 13 The "fundamental duty" of the Roman Catholic Church to teach and its intention to defend its freedom to teach were stressed today in a report presented to a meeting of the Central Preparatory Commission for the Ecumenical Council.
WASHINGTON, June 13 The president of a New York chemical company said today that the company's relations with Billie Sol Estes had been those of "customer and supplier, no more."

ESTELLE HAMBURGER, an energetic woman who calls herself "the flowing glue that sticks a store together," is one of several behind-the-scenes fashion authorities who try to bring the news and excitement of New York's garment district to out-of-town stores.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges made known yesterday the following changes in stockholdings reported by officers, directors and large stockholders of listed companies, pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934:

The West Side Symphony Orchestra will present a series of free Saturday concerts at the Central Park Mall this summer. The orchestra is affiliated with the Eger Youth Concerts and will be conducted by Joseph Eger.
BOSTON, June 13 A frecklefaced Little Leaguer went home from the Massachusetts General Hospital today, three weeks after surgeons rejoined his completely severed pitching arm to his body.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 13 (UPI) Brazil, the defending champion, whipped Chile, 4 2, and Czechoslovakia beat Yugoslavia, 3 1, today to qualify for Sunday's title game in the World Cup soccer tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 13 The Federal Aviation Agency's theory that the loss of a small bolt might have caused the crash of a jetliner at New York International Airport on March 1, killing all ninety-five persons aboard, was sharply disputed in some quarters today.

BOYS from the choir of St. Paul's Church in Flatbush raised their soprano voices in "Oh, Perfect Love" and Macy's public bridal showing for fall opened to a capacity audience of 3,000 last night in the Grand Ballroom at the Astor Hotel.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 The skycraper entrepreneur's version of the no-down-payment G.I. mortgage a 100 per cent loan for construction of new office buildings was heralded today as the latest refinement in the heady field of real estate economics.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) The House passed today and sent to the Senate a bill authorizing the $170,000,000 Fryingpan-Arkansas Water Project in Colorado.

OAKMONT, Pa., June 13 Rain today canceled the final practice round for the United States open golf championship. Officials of the 72-hole competition, which starts tomorrow, said there never had been such a cancellation in the sixty-one previous tournaments.

WABAN, Mass., June 13 Miss Ann Frances O'Connor, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Martin O'Connor of Newton Highlands, was married this afternoon to Ensign Richard Monroe Fairbanks 3d of the Navy. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Monroe Fairbanks of Indianapolis.
Waterfront labor in the Port of New York asked the steamship industry yesterday for new contract conditions representing an increase of $200,000,000 a year in the cost of cargo handling.
WATERMELONS and cantaloupes, two of summer's most coolly satisfying fruits, have been American favorites for so long that all association with their exotic origins has been forgotten.

WASHINGTON, June 13 A revised version of President Kennedy's urban transit bill cleared its first Congressional hurdle today.
MADRID, June 13 A bomb that a man here was carrying in a briefcase exploded this morning, killing him instantly.

OFTEN in the pursuits of summer, the shooter is overlooked while the fisherman gets all the attention. There is no doubt that the warm months are made to order for the angler. But the firearms enthusiasts, who breath fire when they think they are being overlooked, actually have a good amount of sport available to them.
WASHINGTON, June 13 The Senate's chief stockpile investigator has come under fire for supporting, a measure his critics say will subsidize the production of materials already in surplus.
LONDON, June 13 Sir Eugene Goossens, the conductor and composer, died early today in Hillingdon Hospital, Middlesex. He was 69 years old.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 13 Four debutantes made their bows to society tonight at dinner dances and a supper dance in the Oyster Bay-Huntington sector of the North Shore. All of the young women are June graduates of finishing schools and will enter college in the fall.
A microscope that can show the arrangement of individual atoms on the tip of a hair-thin needle has been acquired by Columbia University.

Tax experts who will testify next week against the foreign proposals of the Revenue Act of 1962 got together yesterday to map strategy. The Senate Finance Committee will hear their testimony on the bill that passed the House of Representtives in another form.
During the decline on the stock market, a slow ticker has been one of the problems harassing the New York Stock Exchange.

MILWAUKEE, June 13 (AP) Los Angeles' fire-ball pitcher, Sandy Koufax, outpitched Warren Spahn of Milwaukee with a three-hitter and cracked his first major league homer tonight in the Dodgers' 2-1 victory over the Braves.
Algerians, on July 1 you will be called on to sanction the independence of Algeria before the world.

Organized architects here have called upon President Kennedy and other officials to hold up plans for an $80,000,000, forty-one-story Federal office building in Foley Square pending completion of a new city study for the area.
How will commercial bank earnings for the first six months of this year compare with those of last year?
OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 13 Bird experts from around the world bucked a northeast rainstorm today to see American birds and learn what conservationists were doing for them in this country.
BERLIN, June 13 East Germans were told today to raise chickens and pigs in their backyards to help overcome a shortage of food.
HOYLAKE, England, June 14 (UPI) Bob Sweeny, a 50-yearold New Yorker, and two other Americans gained the fourth round of the British Amateur Golf championship today as the field was cut to thirty-two.
WASHINGTON, June 13 The Senate decisively overrode Administration objections today by approving extra funds to speed the development of the RS-70 reconnaissance-strike bomber.
Counsel for Lawrence A. Johnson argued unsuccessfully in State Supreme Court yesterday that Mr. Johnson was too ill to testify as a defendant in the libel suit brought by John Henry Faulk.
LONDON, June 13 Representative London critics expressed reservations about Tennessee 'Williams'. "Period of Adjustment," which opened tonight at the Royal Court Theatre.

WASHINGTON, June 13 India's desire to buy Soviet MIG fighters has stirred concern here not only about the exten sion of Soviet influence in New Delhi but also about the likelihood of a hostile reaction in the United States Congress.

The Government summed up its case yesterday against Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh, former Assistant United States Attorney Elliott Kahaner and Antonio Corallo.
BERLIN, June 13 Although Eliza Doolittle at long last is about to cease turning into a lady on Broadway, her nightly transformation on the Kantstrasse will go on for months.
Cotton futures were 20 cents a bale up to 50 cents down on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.
The key job of administering the $10,000,000 Lincoln Center Fund will be filled by Mark Schubart, dean of the Juilliard School of Music.
The performance next Monday of "The Merchant of Venice," which will open the new amphitheatre at Belvedere Lake in Central Park, will be followed by a supper dance at the Plaza.

Prof. and Mrs. William A. Hance of 106 Morningside Drive and Nantucket, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Adams Hance, to Ensign Andrew Roy Zagayko, U.S.N. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vladimir L. Zagayko of New York.
Investors, both large and small, are concerned but not panic-stricken over the stock market's decline in the last two days.
Supreme Court Justice Saul S. Streit has been appointed to the key post of Administrative Judge of the new consolidated Supreme Court, which begins its sessions here on Sept. 1.

ROME, June 13 The English language is in danger of splitting into several idioms, "Oxford English, Australian English, New York English" and so forth, Britain's Minister of Education, Sir David Eccles, warned today.

HARTFORD, June 13 Edwin H. May Jr. of Wethersfield announced today that he would not conduct a statewide primary against John D. Alsop of Avon, who defeated him last week for the Republican nomination for Governor.

Junius Irving Scales of North Carolina has since last fall been serving a six-year term in a Federal prison because he was convicted in 1955 under the Smith Act of having been a member of the Communist party. His unique position is that he is the only member or former member of the Communist party of America in jail on that precise count.
WASHINGTON, June 13 A Presidential commission said today that there should be no strikes in future disputes over the size of railroad tug and ferry crews in New York Harbor.

MOSCOW, June 13 The Soviet Union suspended its trade talks with France today. It did so after having been rebuffed in its demand for tariff concessions equal to those accorded to the countries of the European Economic Community, or Common Market.

PARIS, June 13 Faced with a situation of profound legal doubt and even confusion, the European Economic Community has decided, in effect, to postpone from Aug. 1 to Nov. 1 the deadline for filing notifications of inter-corporate agreements as required by the Community's new antitrust regulation.

LONDON, June 13 (AP) Seven records were set today as a combined Oxford-Cambridge team defeated the best of Cornell and Pennsylvania in a track and field meet. The English team won eleven of the fifteen events. Only victories counted.
Friends of Council President Paul R. Screvane reported yesterday that he had told both Mayor Wagner and William H. McKeon, the Democratic state chairman, that he did not wish to run for Governor.
WASHINGTON, June 13 A witness told a Senate subcommittee today that he had been dismissed from an executive job in a union of entertainers because he had cooperated with the panel's investigators.

The Commercial Solvents Corporation, whose officers have begun testifying before a House subcommittee about how they helped Billie Sol Estes finance his West Texas operations, is the outgrowth of a joint British-American effort to win the first World War.

Ernest A. Carlson, controller of Johnson Johnson, manufacturers of surgical dressings and other medical products, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived at 708 Shadowlawn Drive, Westfield, N.J.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt urged parents yesterday to speak up immediately in protest when they hear prejudiced statements against minorities especially when the statements are made in front of children.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 13 Premier David Ben-Gurion said tonight that he questioned whether American Jewry would survive when the United States evolved from what he regarded as a nation of groups into a unitary state, in perhaps ten or fifteen years.

WASHINGTON, June 13 United States Army "mobile training teams" of anti-guerrilla specialists are assisting Washington's regular military missions in Latin America. The mobile teams are helping to train Latin-American security forces to combat subversive elements.

ELIZABETH BOWEN explores two timeless fields of mystery in her fine new book, "Seven Winters and After thoughts."* First, the shadowed wonderland of childhood. Second, the eternal riddle of writing--how (and, in many cases, why!) authors create their dust-jacketed, words-on-paper children.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 13 The Soviet Union's long "cold war" against this North Shore city became hotter last night when the City Council voted unanimously to sell two tax liens on Killenworth, the Russian estate here.
Flag Day ceremonies will be held today by patriotic groups in the city.

Sydney Chaplin, Howard Da Silva and Kay Medford have been lined up for mayor roles in "In the Counting House." The new play by Leslie Weiner will be introduced by Fred Coe and David J. Cogan, in association with Hiller Productions.
New issues of corporate debt securities totaling $58,405,000 will be offered for public subscription by investment banking syndicates today, The list is as follows:

Russia has played a front-of-the-stage role for the Communist powers in Laos during the last year and a half. She has handled the air supply of rebel forces and taken the lead for the Communist side in negotiations over settlement of the Laotian war.
LONDON, June 14 The British Overseas Airways Corporation is considering cutting its order for a new British airliner and buying Boeing 707's instead.

The J.C. Penney Company, which operates 1,689 department stores, had a 33.6 per cent increase in earnings for the three months ended April 30 on a sales gain of 14.3 per cent. Yesterday's report was the first issued by the company for a quarterly period.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan began an investigation yesterday into the withdrawal of $1,953,000 from the treasury of the E.L. Bruce Company by Edward M. Gilbert.

MOSCOW, June 13 The Soviet Minister of Health said today that with some additional research poliomyelitis in the Soviet Uniom could be reduced "to isolated cases." Sergei V. Kurashov reported that the incidence of disease last year was a tenth that of the peak in 1958.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 13 (AP) In the muddy going at Monmouth Park, a $35.80-for-$2 chance named Towson, was an easy winner of the Salvator Mile today. The 4-year-old colt carried the colors of Mrs. Mary G. Christmas of Towson, Md., to a five-length victory.
The city's "scofflaw king" was fined $12,725 yesterday, the largest fine ever imposed in a traffic case here.

AT the age of 65, when most men have begun to lighten their work load, Supreme Court Justice Saul Seymour Streit is taking on new administrative tasks without easing up on his duties as a trial judge. He will be Administrative Judge of the First District, comprising New York
OMAHA, June 13 (AP) Pat Rigby's sacrifice fly in the seventh inning scored across the winning run tonight as Texas eliminated Ithaca from the college world series, 3-2.
St. John's University went into court yesterday to fight the reinstatement of three students whom it had dismissed for having taken part in a civil marriage.
WASHINGTON, June 13 President Kennedy and President Roberto F. Chiari of Panama agreed today to arrange high-level discussions on Panamanian objections to some aspects of the Panama Canal treaty.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) A Teamsters Union official said today that the wiretapping bill backed by Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy could be used as a "club" to keep an administration in power.

SAIGON, Vietnam June 13 Communist guerrilla leaders are seeking to win a propaganda advantage from the impend ing release of an American service man, S. 4/C George F. Fryett Jr., who was captured last Christmas time.

HOUSTON, June 13 Rain washed out tonight's National League game between the New York Mets and the Houston Colt .45's, postponing what had been billed as a keen pitching duel involving Jay Hook of New York and Bob Bruce of Houston.
MOSCOW, June 12 Premier Khrushchev, the chief public relations man of communism, is busy again making friends and influencing visitors.

ALLENDALE, N.J., June 13 Mr. and Mrs. William Short have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Nicholas Short, to John Howard Beebe Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Beebe of Fair Haven.

The meetings of the President of the Republic of Panama and the President of the United States of America during the past two days have been marked by a spirit of frankness, understanding and sincere friendship.
Dr. Fred C. Schwarz, the antiCommunist lecturer, said yesterday that he was beginning to dispel "a climate that was created by misrepresentation and misinformation" about him here.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 Three convicts who dug escape hatches with spoons through cell walls on Alcatraz Island were aided by the erosion and debilitation of the Federal penitentiary.
Sir Charles Snow criticized American elementary and secondary education last night and urged that it be strengthened and made rigorous.
WASHINGTON, June 13 Influential members of the Senate Judiciary Committee wish that President Kennedy would withdraw the nomination of Irving Ben Cooper to a Federal District judgeship in New York.
Stocks seesawed yesterday in heavy trading and closed on the downstroke with a moderate loss.
New art treasures acquired for The Cloisters, the medieval branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Fort Tryon Park, are on display.
The Securities and Exchange Commission will hear preliminary arguments in Washington this afternoon on a mutualfund matter that has brought near-unity to the disjointed $24,000,000,000 industry.
A gold mining executive predicted a bright future for his company yesterday and stockholders promptly petitioned him for higher dividends.
PARIS, June l3 More than half the Deputies in the National Assembly walked out to day to protest the Government's refusal to submit its foreign policy to a vote.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 13 T.B. Payseur of Evanston, Ill., carded a 39, 36 75 today and won the Eastern Seniors' Golf Association's second annual championship with a 36hole total of 153 at the Siwanoy Country Club.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., June 13 May, a young woman who has specialized in stealing wallets from men's pockets in New York, hoed beds of flowers in a rockery at the state's Prison for Women here today and said: "I never knew before I could make beautiful things grow from the earth."
Bob Hope will receive the coveted Gold Medal authorized by Congress, made by the mint and presented by the President:

A VOTE for "Fiorello!" is a vote for good musical theatre. There was no electioneering when the show was revived at the City Center last night. None was needed. The Honest Ballot Association was nowhere in sight. It was a clean campaign. It's "Fiorello!" in a landslide.

QUEBEC, June 12 Quebec is a key province in next Monday's Canadian election. It has seventy-five of the 265 seats in the House of Commons. The Conservatives hold fifty of Quebec's seats and the Liberals twenty-five.
LONDON, June 13 The Bank of England cautioned in its quarterly bulletin today against any undue relaxation of economic restraints in this country.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, June 14 (AP) Airline and flight engineer negotiators met with Government mediators early today in a session aimed at averting a strike that would ground three major lines.

EASLEY BLACKWOOD of Indianapolis, in the televi sion bridge show he conducted in the last season, often pitted the professions against one another doctors against lawyers, and so on. Once he even had a team of clergymen on his show.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 13 Premier Andre Muhirwa of Urundi declared today that his country could maintain law and order without outside help after it wins independence from Belgian trusteeship July 1.
Only mild activity in cocoa and world sugar futures held commodity trader interest. Other commodities generally were lower in narrow trading.

LONDON, June 13 (AP) Darlene Hard, too ill to play a year ago, will carry the heavy burden Friday and Saturday as the United States tries for a second straight Wightman Cup decision over the British girl tennis players at Wimbledon.
Producton of electric power in the country totaled 15,876,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended June 9, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.
LONDON, June 13 With dealers and investors reacting nervously to yesterday's poor showing on Wall Street, practically all sections of the stock market here declined today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 13 One of the most fantastic by-products of the dispute between Twentieth Century-Fox and Marilyn Monroe over "Something's Got to Give" is the story of Lee Remick's position in the movie.
WASHINGTON, June 13 The Kennedy Administration gave its warm personal blessings today to the re-election campaign of Representative Alfred E. Santangelo of New York City.
HONG KONG, June 13 Hong Kong issued an invitation today to governments interested in the colony's refugee problem to contribute funds to the Hong Kong program of capital construction.
CHICAGO, June 13 (AP) The report of today's livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

YONKERS, June 13 The $50,000 International Pace at a mile and a half tomorrow night will introduce two new pacing stars to the American scene James Scott, the champion of Australia, and Patchwork, New Zealand's outstanding performer.
COLUMBIA, S.C., June 13 Senator Olin D. Johnston's renomination by the Democrats has set the stage for a clear test of strength between party loyalists and conservative Demoocrats and Republicans.

At the St. Vincent Debutante Ball at the Apawamis Club in Rye, N.Y., last night, twentyfour young women of Westchester County made their formal bows to society. They were received by Cardinal Spellman in the ballroom.
The nation's supply of gasoline declined by 37,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
City Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan has opened an inquiry into the sale of an $18,000 mortgage by two former building inspectors and Frank J. Crisona, a Queens Democratic leader.
Patrick B. McGinnis unexpectedly retired yesterday as president and chief executive officer of the financially troubled Boston and Maine Railroad.

The administrator for the Alliance for Progress, which seeks to help develop economic, social and political programs in Latin America, said yesterday that the project needed more United States involvement than the Marshall Plan needed in Europe.

The economic indicators for May give cause neither for rejoicing nor for gloom nor for complacency. While some sectors employment, hours worked, personal income continued climbing, the increases were smaller than expected. There was discouraging news in other areas: first-quarter profits declined from the peak set in the last quarter of 1961; retail sales for May were down 1% from the previous month.

The rejection by the flight engineers of a Presidential plea for arbitration of their row with the airline pilots indicates afresh how hard it is to achieve a sound balance between freedom and responsibility on the industrial front. Unless the engineers reconsider, there looms the possibility of Government compulsion to keep the air lanes open.
PARIS, June 14 A European Space Research Organization designed to put Europe into the space race with the United States and the Soviet Union came into being here today.
The bond market's bullishness subsided yesterday before a new outbreak of misgivings about stock market values and the gravity of the outflow of gold abroad.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System were at $47,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, down $8,000,000 from the previous week, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 14 Republicans were urged by President Kennedy today to break party ranks and support his farm bill.

WASHINGTON, June 14 Representative Samuel S. Stratton said today that the Columbia Broadcasting System owed him, as a Democratic candidate for Governor, as much television time as it had given to Governor Rockefeller recently.
CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) Grain futures ran into their first general resistance of the week today and nearly all commodities weakened on the Board of Trade.

The marriage of Miss Rivkah Teitz, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Pinchas M. Teitz of Elizabeth, N. J., to Rabbi Yosef Blau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Blau of New York, took place last evening at the Statler Hilton Hotel.

COOKING directly in the coals is a form of barbecuing that is not for the timid, but the results are truly rewarding. A large bed of white-hot charcoal with the ash knocked off is the prime requisite. Corn in the husks and baking potatoes wrapped in heavy-duty aluminum foil will cook to perfection if rotated frequently.

WASHINGTON, June 14 Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy is believed likely to ask a Federal Court in New York tomorrow for an injunction ordering employes of the Republic Aviation Corporation in Farmingdale, L.I., to suspend their eleven-week strike.
MADRID, June 14 The Spanish police have ordered a United States diplomatic courier to open his personal baggage twice in the last two days in a general search for explosives.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 14 Edward M. Gilbert is considering taking up permanent residence in Brazil, it was indicated today.

MOSCOW, June 14 Premier Mamadou Dia of Senegal said here today that his country could profit from Soviet technological and cultural development and the Soviet system of training specialized personnel.
The stock market spotlight has been focusing with pitiless intensity on the shares of the International Business Machines Corporation these days. It has shown a disturbing picture for many investors.

LONDON, June 14--Two dissident Conservative Members of Parliament published today a pamphlet calling for a more constructive attitude toward the British Commonwealth rather than entry into the European Economic Community.
Two stock traders were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of having defrauded stock brokers in connection with the purchase of $950,000 in listed securities.
WASHINGTON, June 14 A high level Government study unit has completed a broad program to cope with continuing labor strife in the maritime industry.
PARIS, June 14 Thousands of Algeria's weary, confused and bitter Europeans are pouring into France daily with a "wait-and-see" attitude about what to do next.
The National Biscuit Company is expanding its operations in New Zealand through the purchase of Griffin Sons, Ltd., producer of biscuits and hard candy.

WASHINGTON, June 14 In calling on the flight engineers to subordinate their dispute with three major airlines to their public responsibility, Mr. Kennedy today invoked his personal prestige and that of the Presidency as firmly as when he denounced the notice of a price increase by the United States Steel Corporation.

LOS ANGELES, June 14 (AP) The Minnesota Twins broke a ninth-inning tie on a single by Len Green today and defeated the Los Angeles Angels, 5 4.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 A syndicate headed by the Bankers Trust Company of New York was the successful bidder today for a $100,000,000 offering of California state bonds. The bid called for a net interest cost of 3.2075 per cent.
Federal officials seized the personal files of Edward M. Gilbert yesterday as investigations continued into his withdrawal of $1,953,000 from the E. L. Bruce Company.

WASHINGTON, June 14 President Kennedy issued a stern warning to the flight engineers' union today to refrain from striking against three major airlines.

OAKMONT, Pa,, June 14 It was a day of lights and shadows for the opening round of the United States Open golf championship over the dread hills of the Oakmont Country Club today. The weather played a game of tag. The black clouds were chased by gray clouds which, in turn, were chased by stabbing rays of sunshine. Then the game started all over again.

AS temperatures climb, so do the prices of some foods. Lamb seems to be the commodity most adversely affected to date. An increase for the second straight week now brings prices for this meat to their highest level in four years.

The 293 Deputies more than half of the French National Assembly who walked out of the chamber in disgust over the Government's refusal to submit its foreign policy to a vote will not have impressed Charles de Gaulle. The President has something approximating contempt for the legislative assemblies he has known in the Third, Fourth and Fifth Republics.

Ian Woodner, 58-year-old multimillionaire builder, architect and art collector, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri to two-and-a-half years in prison and was fined $20,000 for income tax evasion.

Massey-Ferguson, Ltd., set record sales of $263,000,000 in the six months ended April 30. The semi-annual report disclosed yesterday that net income for the half-year amounted to $5,338,000, equal to 38 cents a share, on 12,257,902 shares of common stock outstanding.
President Roberto-F. Chiari of Panama received full honors from this city yesterday a ticker-tape parade, a red carpet to walk on, a gold medal and an official scroll.

VESOUL, France, June 14 A group of heavily armed members of the Secret Army Organization was arrested in east-central France last night and today by security police officials who charged that the terrorists were plotting to assassinate President de Gaulle.
IN her somewhat jittery landscape oils at the ACA Gal lery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street, Jehudith Sobel is well aware of the pleasing aspects implicit in sunny, summery outdoor scenes.

WASHINGTON, June 14 The nation should be concerning itself with its real economic problems, President Kennedy said today, and not with the political question of whether he should be in the White House.

Joseph M. Roebling's 4-yearold roan filly Hill Song, the 22-1 betting outsider among the five starters, won the $10,000 St. Albans Purse yesterday at Belmont Park. She closed powerfully to finish the sevenfurlong feature a head in front of the 23-20 favorite, Elmendorf's Oil Royalty.

SYRACUSE, June 14 Washington and Cornell, two of the top varisity contenders in the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta, are each prepared, in the event they should win here Saturday, to race against the eight of the Soviet Union at Philadelphia on Independence Day.
WASHINGTON, June 14 labor organizations in the United States have net assets of more than $1,300,000,000, Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg reported today.

The Murchison Brothers of Dallas, Tex., yesterday sought to have the Alleghany Corporation named as plaintiff in their two-year-old fraud suit against Allan P. Kirby, the holding company's former chairman.
VIENTIANE, Laos, June 14--The United States resumed its financial aid to the Laotian Government today.

To mark the 150th anniversary of the birth of Charles Dickens, the Morgan Library is displaying a few of its Dickens treasures. The police last night raided what they called the biggest policy operation in New York--a "bank" handling half a million numbers bets a day.
MILWAUKEE, June 14 (AP)--The Milwaukee Braves scored five runs in the first inning and breezed to a 7--1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers today behind the six-hit pitching of Bob Shaw.

EUGENE, Ore., June 14 Oregon's host squad was an overwhelming favorite tonight to capture the team title in the forty-first annual National Collegiate track and field championships, being held in the Pacific Northwest for the first time.

The drug reform bill over which Senator Kefauver and his Senate antitrust subcommittee toiled for two and a half years has undergone drastic dilution as the result of a coup engineered by Senator Eastland of Mississippi in collaboration with the bill's Republican foes.

The Weyerhaeuser Steamship Company of San Francisco, one of the few remaining intercoastal steamship operators, said here yesterday that it was laying up its entire fleet indefinitely because of the current labor crisis in West Coast shipping.

Longshoremen, tired of losing a day's pay whenever the members of seagoing unions decide to set up picket lines on the New York waterfront, called yesterday for a new approach to settling the problem.
