GREENWICH, Conn., June 14 Julius George Forstmann, former president and board chairman of the Fortsmann Woolen Company, Passaic, N. J., died this evening in his home at Broad Field, Belle Haven. His age was 52.

PERU ARMY CALLS BELAUNDE VICTOR LIMA, June 14--The nation's military commanders have decided that the winner of Sunday's Presidential election is Fernando Belaunde Terry, candidate of the Popular Action party, according to informed sources.
The kind of persuasive economic planning that has achieved recent marked success in France may be good for increasing consumption but not for satisfying the consumer.

HOYLAKE, England, June 14 (AP) Richard Davies, a real estate man from Pasadena, Calif., overwhelmed two opponents in a gale today to become the only American survivor in the British amateur golf championship.

Federal narcotics agents arrested five men yesterday who they said had operated an elaborate system for smuggling large quantities of narcotics into the United States.
Yeshiva University held its commencement exercises yesterday, bringing to an end a year-long celebration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of its founding.

A plan to bypass long stays in over-crowded Bellevue Hospital for patients en route to state mental institutions will go into effect today. The plan will be extended to Kings County Hospital soon.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 14 American Jewish leaders told Israeli officials bluntly today not to equate Judaism with nationality.

SHUSHAN, N. Y., June 14 "There must be thirty five trout in that one little area," Johnny Falk said yesterday morning. He was right, for one could stand on an old wooden bridge, just over the state line in Vermont, and watch the pesky rascals in the water below.
The New York Board of Rabbis yesterday requested the cancellation of the scheduled telecast of "The Merchant of Venice" in Central Park.

A flight engineer is an aircraft's mechanical superintendent. In flight he monitors a panel containing all instruments on mechanical functions of the plane--fuel supply and oil gauges, various pressure gauges, the fire warning system. He operates the fuel controls and transfer valves which switch the engines from one fuel tank to another. In case of a malfunction, he makes whatever repairs are possible. On the ground he supervises refueling.

SEVEN Arts Productions and director-writer-pro ducer Robert Rossen, who have as many irons in the movie fires as any film operative, now have added another screen subject to their already bulging dossiers. The news is that Seven Arts has acquired rights to Brendan Behan's boisterous play "The Hostage" and will film it in association with Mr. Rossen's independent Centaur Enterprises, Inc.
IT soon will be time again to pack the family and picnic gear into our aging sedan and set off on the first of many Saturday safaris to the antiques flea markets in Connecticut.
OTTAWA, June 16--On Monday 7,350,000 of Canada's eligible 9,800,000 voters are expected to go to the polls to choose their country's next government.

SHELLEY BERMAN, who found fame and fortune with Jack Paar in 1957 and has been a constant television visitor ever since, will finally get a show of his own. He will star in a one-hour, one-man telecast on the American Broadcasting Company network Tuesday, Aug. 14 at 10 P.M.
A word picture characterizing New York City as so economically healthy that it is relatively recession-proof was painted yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

PARIS. FEWER films have gone into production in Paris this spring than at any time since the German occupation, but to the French screen colony one of those in progress is more than enough. Orson Welles is behind the cameras, once again, and French movie buffs, the most vehement breed in the world, are overjoyed.
WASHINGTON, June 16--The toughest thing to do in politics is to be third man in a fight. Yet President Kennedy is taking over this role both at home and abroad.
WASHINGTON, June 16-- The Federal Government today announced a grant of $109,209 to help finance a Hunter College project to train teachers for slum schools.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16-- In a society that commits an increasing proportion of its population to life in a business office, the much-maligned skyscraper appears destined to proliferate in the large and small cities of the nation.
NEW DELHI, India, June 14 --India's third Five-Year Plan, the basis of much of her hopes and dreams of economic progress, is in serious trouble.

FAR more tragic than what Fidel Castro has wrought in Cuba is what the phenomenon of his tyranny has done to us, his neighbors. Because of its quick and quixotic turns, deceitful means and novel setting, the Castro revolution has traded on our guilts and sympathies, appealed to our highest ideals and around our most shameful instincts. It has caused us to
EASTBOURNE, England, June 16 (AP)--England moved into the semi-final round of European zone Davis Cup play today by taking both final singles matches from Brazil. The final score was 4-1

BORDENTOWN, N.J.--For many years, this historic little community on the banks of the Delaware River has been progressively assuming the aspects of a ghost town. Now, like the legendary Rip Van Winkle, 280-year-old Bordentown appears to have been amused from its slumbers, to have become suddenly aware of its potentialities for future growth and prosperity and to be most anxious to take full advantage of them.
One of the tallest cooperative apartment houses in West Chester County--and one of the first to be centrally air-conditioned--has been completed in the Lawrence Park West section of Bronxville.
CHICAGO, June 16--Gov. Otto Kerner prompted a storm of reaction with a proposal this week that relief checks be cut to help balance the Illinois budget.
A careful study of the shopping potential of the site for a new Supermarket is essential to the success of the project, according to a leading realty broker specializing in retail store properties.

WASHINGTON, June 16-- The space program, which at times seems to have grown in the same undesigned manner as the house that Jack built, is undergoing a significant metamorphosis in objective and organization.
SEOUL, Korea, June 16-- Song Yo Chan, a hero of the Korean war, resigned as Premier today in what appeared to be a dispute over the charting of South Korea's economic future.

THE title of William Melvin Kelley's first novel, a highly improbable fantasy on racial tensions in the Deep South, comes from the well-known passage in "Walden" that suggests men may sometimes engage in "desperate enterprises" because they "step to the music" others do not hear. The preface in

The integrity of century-old laws reserving coastwise trading privileges to merchant ships built and continuously registered in this country is at stake at hearings before the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee.

Faculty housing has become a major attraction or deterrent in the inter-university contest for good teachers. The University of Pittsburgh announced plans last week to erect on campus this fall one or two highly experimental homes which could revolutionize professorial living.
FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, June 16--Graham Hill of England, driving a BRM, this afternoon won the pole position for tomorrow's Grand Prix of Belgium, which counts toward the drivers' world chamnionship.

WINCHESTER, Va., June 16--White snapdragons, gladioluses, pom pon chrysanthemums and palms on each side of the sanctuary in Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church provided the background this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Patricia Hazard Donovan to Raymond Richard Guest Jr.

OAKMONT, Pa., June 16--Arnold Palmer wasn't the only tiger in the Oakmont jungle on this scorching day. He met a fighter of equal tenacity and competitive fire in young Jack Nicklaus, who hung in there so doggedly that they tied for the United States Open golf championship with scores of 283.

THE making of potpourri has been going on for generations. It is a pleasant way to capture the fragrances of the garden. By drying or "pickling" flower petals, gardeners can savor favorite flower scents at any time of year. Petal colors can be retained, too, if the dry method of preserving is used.
In the last ten years air conditioning in Manhattan apartment houses has lost its luxury status and has become a takenfor-granted utility.

Volunteers of the Shelters, Inc., "an experiment in personal charity," are sponsoring a tea dance Wednesday at the Stork Club. The proceeds will go toward the plarchase of an encephalograph machine for the Kennedy, Child Study Center at 151 East. Sixty-seventh, Street.

SIX picture books recently published combine photographic reproductions and text in a variety of ways. At one extreme, text is used only as introductory material, so as to give major emphasis to the photographs; in contrast, another book uses pictures mostly as illustration material for the text.
New York Met fans, undeterred by a miserable won-lost record, spent another unrewarding afternoon under Coogan's Bluff yesterday while their team lost a 6-3 game to the Chicago Cubs.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 16--The marriage of Miss Celinda Jane Hardy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gelston Hardy of Stamford, to John Forest Harkness, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis W. Harkness of Haworth, N.J., took place here this afternoon. The Rev. Jesse E. Thomas performed the ceremony in the Round Hill Community Church (nondenominational).

In Algiers last Friday a crowd of Europeans gathered in a covered market place--a center of communal life for generations-- and set it afire as though in ritual sacrifice. Children danced around the flames; women wept.
DARIEN, Conn., June 16-- The open jumper championship of the four-day Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show was narrowed to three possible winners today --Jacks or Better, Windsor Castle and McLain Street.

Stair-climbing is held to a minimum in a new Long Island split-level house with a layout that places the rooms used during the day mostly on a level apart from the formal living room and the bedrooms.
NEW LONDON, N.H., June 16 (AP)--Dr. Eugene M. Austin, president of Colby Junior College, a school for Women, died last night in Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital in Hanover. He was 52 years old.

LONDON, June 16--Hugh Gaitskell challenged Prime Minister Macmillan today to hold immediate general elections now that the Conservative Government had, as the Labor party leader put it, "utterly lost the confidence of the country."

WILLIAM INGE, whose last work for Broadway was "A Loss of Roses" in 1959, is pre paring two new plays. After completing a script for Columbia Pictures--an adaptation of a novel by Charles Williams titled "Hill Girl," Mr. Inge will concentrate on "Natural Affection" and "Bus Riley's Back in Town."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 16--Patience was rewarded by good races for skippers of four classes today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's eighty-second annual spring regatta. For the rest of the 104 starters in the other six classes, however, this was a long day of frustration: the wind died and they couldn't complete their races.
A sculpture exhibition will be included for the first time this summer at the fifth annual Festival of Two Worlds at Spoleto, Italy.

WASHINGTON. A HISTORIC term of the Supreme Court is drawing to a close. It rates that adjective because of a single momentous decision--the decision in Baker v. Carr, opening the doors of the Federal courts to legal attacks on the apportionment of seats in state legislatures.

A NEW type of appliance which has become increasingly popular in recent years is the port able air purifier. Designed so they can be easily carried from room try room, these portable units come in a bewildering variety of different styles and sizes. They range in price from a low of under $10 to a high of about $100.

An odd assortment of stones with a variety of colors was used to construct the exterior and lobby facade of a new apartment building in Freeport, L.I. The stones were chosen to give the building an appearance of "weathered maturity" in contrast to the newness of freshly quarried stone.

THE Metropolitan Opera's great central chandelier was lowered last week so its 280 bulbs could be changed. The same day, the New York City Opera, fifteen blocks farther north, announced that it would open its new season on Oct. 4 with its first production of Charpentier's "Louise." The two acts were symptomatic of what is happen ing across the country.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 16-- Twelve villages in Nassau County will hold elections on Tuesday, but there is a contest in only one.

Laos, a Southeast Asian tinderbox for three years, is important for its strategic situation, surrounded as it is by six nations of varied political coloring--pro-Western Thailand and South Vietnam; Communist China and North Vietnam; and neutralist Burma and Cambodia. It also has been important as a touchstone of East-West relations.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., June 16--In Christ Protestant Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Cheryl Croston Cushing, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lee Cushing, became the bride of John Robert Campbell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Campbell. The Rev. Herbert H. Cooper performed the ceremony.

Grace Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights was the scene yesterday afternoon of the marriage of Miss Cicily de St. Croix Warren, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ro bert Fiske Warren of Brooklyn Heights and Northville, N.Y., to Joseph Valentine Hajek. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Hajek of New York.

The marriage of Miss Mary Renwick Delafield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Sloane Delafield of Brewster, N.Y., to Lieut. David Arthur Newcomb, U.S.N., son of Mrs. Charlotte Newcomb and Kenneth Newcombe both of Brewster, took place yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Riverdale, the Bronx, by the Rev. Gerald Barry.
YONKERS, June 16--Muncy Hanover, a 5-year-old son of Adios-Madam Butterfly, turned in the fastest pace of the Yonkers Raceway season tonight in winning the $7,500 Monitor, a junior free-for-all race.

THE high tide of an exceptionally long and busy season has been slowly receding and for the past month we have been listening to its melancholy, long withdrawing squeak. So today the critic finds himself in the position of someone puttering around on an

Stocky market analysts tend to be long on market comments these days but noticeably short an suggestions of what stocks to buy. That is understandable in the face of May 28's sharp drop and the downward trend of the market since and especially Thursday's sharp break.

SEATLE, Wash.--There is a region about ninety mile wide and eighty miles long in northern Washington that the United States Forest Service calls the North Cascade Primitive Area. Access is limited, because of the terrain, to pack trains and airplanes; not one road crosses the backbone of peaks which range from 8,000 to 10,000 feet high. The few towns near by are thirty to forty miles from the area's edge.

The recent gyrations in the stock market have focused public attention on Wall Street, one of the world's great financial centers. An estimated 15,000,000 Americans now own stock directly. Many others have an indirect interest in the market through investments in savings banks, insurance companies, pension funds and other institutions that invest in stocks. What follows are questions and answers about the market and its fluctuations.
OAKMONT, Pa., June 16-- Arnold Palmer tried to win the United States Open golf championship outright today with a putt for a birdie.

PARIS, June 16--With characteristic sublime indifference to what he calls mere "peripeties"--roughly "ups and downs"--president de Gaulle has assured Frenchmen that, so far as France is concerned, the Algerian problean will end July 1 when the Algerians vote themselves independent.

Fur-trimmed coats continued to be bought heavily last week, resident buying offices here reported. Mink, squirrel, raccoon and imitation furs all were popular. There apparently was a revival of interest in longhaired furs.

MOST people cross the George Washington Bridge. Not Albert Lamorisse, the gifted Frenchman who made those two superb movie miniatures, "White Mane" and "The Red Balloon." Approaching the bridge by helicopter recently, from Philadelphia, M. Lamorisse slipped into the pilot's seat and sailed right under it. '

IN one of these essays, Elizabeth Bowen recalls to us Flaubert's definition of literary style as "a manner of seeing." Isn't style in this sense, the integration of perception and language, achieved only by our best writers? And isn't Miss Bowen one of them? Certainly, it is style that harmonizes this collection of miscellaneous papers, reviews, prefaces and broadcasts. The particular sub

Fifteen hundred American Jewish youngsters will spend seven weeks to a year in travel, work and study programs in Israel. They will be sponsored by the Jewish Agency in coop eration with the American Zionist Council.

Miss Patricia Ann Sullivan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Sullivan of 2 Fifth Avenue, was married here yesterday morning to John A. Reisert. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ambrose B. Reisert of East Greenwick, R.I.

THE article by Allen Hughes on "dance-watch ing" in New York reminds me of Sol Hurok's recently issued booklet announcing the appearance of the Bolshoi Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House in September.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., June 16 The marriage of Martha Anne Klippert, daughter of Walter E. Klippert of Peninsula, Ohio and the late Mrs. Klippert, to John Gurdon Brewster, son of Mrs. Carroll H. Brewster of New York and Ridgefield and the late Mr. Brewster, took place here this afternoon.
MADRID, June 15--Talleyrand, when told that his master Napoleon had ordered the young Duc d'Enghien kidnapped and shot, made the immortal observation: "It is worse than a crime. It is a blunder."
WASHINGTON. MEMBERS of the American Booksellers Association met here the other day, the annual convention marking its sixty-second year.

NEW YORK'S bridge clubs were once a unique phenomenon, and even today there is no other city in the world in which there are literally hundreds of clubs devoted to contract bridge, where serious players assemble both to play and to talk about their favorite game.
Business thefts are adding 5 per cent to the cost of merchandise bought by the consumer, a business-investigative company has reported following a tenyear study of employe dishonesty.
NEWARK, June 16--A group of residents of the Clinton Hill section of Newark are seeking to disprove the saying: "You can't fight City Hall."
HARTFORD, June 16--The Democrats have taken the center of the political stage in Connecticut.
A second-half comeback gave America of Rio de Janeiro the First Seccion championship of the International Soccer League yesterday at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

REDSTONE, Colo., June 16-- Miss Barbara Joan Clagett, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. O. Theron Clagett of Rochester, Minn., was married here this afternoon to Harold Hawthorne Green, son of Mr. and Mrs. Athol Green of Seattle.

WHEN Robert Goulet appears before the television cameras on tonight's "Ed Sullivan Show" over the Columbia Broadcasting System network, it will be his eighth visit to the program in the last year and a half.
Chile Wins, 1-0, Takes Third in World Soccer
RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 16 --Contests are scheduled in only two of the fifteen Suffolk County villages that will hold annual summer elections on Tuesday.
LA NEUVEVILLE, Switzerland--Tourists who want to abandon the present and live in the relaxed and candlelit atmosphere of the eighteenth century can do so in Switzerland thin summer. Hav
A nine-room Colonial type of house has been added to the Beacon Hill community in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

UNTIL the recent appearance a of a new paperback edition, Selma Lagerlof's. "The Story of G sta Berling" (translated by Robert Bly; SignetNew American Library) has long been out of print in America. Surely this should not have happened to the masterly first novel of the first woman Nobel laureate in literature.

St. James Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Laura Castleman Gary, daughter of Theodore Sauvinet Gary of 176 East Ninety-third Street, Indian Creek Island, Miami Beach, Fla., and Madeline Island, Wis., and the late Mrs. Laura Brown Gary, to Edwin Thorne Jr. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thorne of Greenwich, Conn.
WASHINGTON, June 16-- The Flight Engineers International Association said tonight that it would call a strike tomorrow in its contract dispute with three major airlines.

LEVITTOWN, L.I., June 16-- President Kennedy was accused today of seeking an injunction against striking employes of the Republic Aviation Corporation in Farmingdale "to reassure the business community that he can still flex his muscles against labor."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 16--The possibility of the European Common Market countries replacing Canada, Australia and New Zealand as suppliers of food to Britain is slim, in the view of qualified officials here. A major exception is butteran export of importance to New Zealand.
VACATIONS and rainy days provide time for reading to improve plant growing techniques. The new books currently available are as varied as summer blossoms, and some are as eyecatching.

EUGENE, Ore., June 16-- Jerry Tarr, Harry Jerome, Dyrol Burleson and Mel Renfro paced Oregon to a smashing team victory today in the forty-first annual National Collegiate track and field championships.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 16--The American tennis champion, Darlene Hard, ruthlessly cut down 6-foot Christine Truman, 6--2, 6--2, to clinch a United States triumph over Britain in the annual Wightman Cup competition today.
Renovating an old building can be as difficult as putting together a jigsaw puzzle in the dark, according to one renovating specialist.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 16--The Children's Summer Theatre will open its second season at Douglass College of Rutgers University next month.

Columbia University has acquired a field ion emission microscope, believed to be one of ten in the world. It can show the arrangement of atoms on the tip of a hair-thin needle. This is the first commercial

VENTICE, Italy, June 16-- President Antonio Segni led a cavalcade of motorboats, gondolas and skiffs dowm the Grand Canal today to the Public Gardens, which were designed by Napoleon, to inaugurate the thirty-first International Biennale Exposition of Contemporacy Art.
Three hundred and twenty seven persons devoted to rolling stock took an eight-hour, 100mile grand tour of the New York subway system yesterday. They paid $5 each.

THE SLAVE by Isaac Bashevis Singer, is a tem pestuous love-story set against a background that has eagaged the imagination of this Yiddish author deeply--the aftermath of the Chielnicki Massacres in Poland in 1649. As in his previous

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., June 16--Miss Hester Laning Pepper, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Dickinson Sergeant--Pepper of Hartford, was married here this afternoon to Anthony Edward Williams. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Clarence James Williams of Sabot, Va., and the late Mr. Williams.

ON Sweden, Midsummer Eve is not meant for sleeping. It is a time for dancing into the not-so-small small hours, with time out only for climbing the nearest mountain to watch the sun rise. The sun does not get much respite either. In the south of Sweden, it sets around midnight and rises again about 2 A.M. Even during this brief night it is light enough to read a book.
WASHINGTON, June 16-- In a setting of heightened acrimony between the business community and the Federal Government, President Kennedy has called for"a serious dialogue" on national economic policy.
WILTON, Conn., June 16-- Miss Cornelia Sherrill Cudlipp and Henry Blodget are planning an August wedding.
DURING the hot days of summer broadleaved evergreens will respond to a little extra atten tion each week. Chores include watering, mulching and pruning.
Westfield (N.J.) High gained its first major team victory in more than a decade yesterday in the sixth annual Eastern States Schoolboy track and field championships at Columbia's Baker Field.
BERLIN, June 16--United States officials disclosed today that two American students have been imprisoned by East Germany for some time. The charges against them have not been made public.

SAN FRANCISCO--Happy days are here again, if sometimes frantic one's, for West Coast ground and air carriers that are adding equipment to accommodate travelers bound for the Seattle World's Fair. Some airline

HOYLAKE, England, June 16 --A hard-driving Californian, Richard Davies, today won the British Amateur golf championship, 1 up, by mastering his own nervousness and outlasting John Povall of Wales in the 36-hole final.
The outlook is bleak, but by no means hopeless, for many New York youngsters looking for summer jobs this year.
LONDON. TO mark the consecration of the new cathedral, Coventry is holding a festival that has already produced major new works by Benjamin Britten, Michael Tippett and Sir Arthur Bliss.

The most widely discussed trend in the publishing industry is the slow-motion merge$ taking place between the world of books and the world of magazines. The trend is having a fundamental impact on the economics of the publishing business as well as on its editorial product.

ALGIERS, June 16--Fiftyfive members of the Secret Army Organization were captured and up to eleven others killed in two related operations yesterday and today near Oran, official sources announced here tonight.

BRYN MAWR, Pa. June 16-- Ch. Yankee Pride Col. Stump, a 5-year-old miniature Schnauzer owned by Mrs. Joseph Sailor of Philadelphia, won best-in-show honors today in a field of 620 at the forty-second annual Bryn Mawr Kennel Club's event.

ONE of the great confusions of modern aviation was cleared up here last week when Alan S. Boyd, speaking for the Civil Aeronautics Board of which he is chairman, cheerfully told a public gathering that "We don't know what a spontaneous group is."

THE Sixth District of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State has scheduled a house and garden tour, with flower show, for Wednesday, Three historic and three contemporary homes in the vicinity of Syracuse will be opened that day from noon to 8 P.M.

WHAT with his impressive volume of short stories, "Goodbye, Columbus" (1959), for which he won a National Book Award, his Guggenheim and his Writer-in-Residence appointment at Princeton, Philip Roth has become the golden boy of his generation of writers. It is not altogether an enviable lot for a raan writing his first novel, which cannot possibly fulfill all the expectations generated by such a reputation.

Larlos Hernandez, the 22-yearold power puncher from Caracus, Venezuela, accomplished last night wht forty-eight other ring rivals of Paolo Rosi had not been able to do in the Bronx fighter's eleven-year career as a professional fighter.
All-electric kitchens, usually associated with private homes, are being used increasingly in high-rent apartment houses in Manhattan.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 16-- In an interview in Baghdad recently Foreign Minister Hashim Jawad was asked whether he was not worried by the increasing isolation of Iraq in the Arab world.
SYRACUSE, June 16--Cornell gained the championship of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association today and will go to Philadelphia to race the eight-oared crew of the Soviet Union on Independence Day.
NEW DELHI, June 16--Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told a Communist member of the up per House of Parliament today that India was unlikely to adopt communism "whatever else happened."
President Kennedy tried last week to convince business he was not anti-business and pro-laborand apparently failed.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 16--St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church was the scene this afternoon of the marriage of Miss Tove Erichsen Nordness, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nedville Erving Nordness of Belle Haven, Alexandria, to Francis Troost Parker 3d. He is the son of Mrs. Samuel Taliaferro Pendleton of Forest Lodge and Mr. Parker Jr. of Riverdale Farms.
LONDON, June 16 (Reuters) --The Earl of Sandwich died at his Hertfordshire home during the night. He was 87 years old.
A Westchester retirement community, turning away from traditional planning concepts, has placed as much emphasis on its natural surroundings as it has on living accommodations.
CAIRO, June 16--Leaders of the six members of the Casablanca bloc agreed today to establish a military high command.
Many families are said to be denying themselves the opportunity of buying or renting a moderately priced apartment because they do not understand the state and city middleincome dwelling programs.

FOR a number of years, we Americans have spoken eas ily, even confidently, of the Atlantic Alliance. In the past two years--more particularly in recent months--there have entered our national dialogue other more far-reaching terms, such as "Atlantic Partnership" and "Grand Design.' This timely and important book by Joseph Kraft, a political writer and author previously of "The Struggle for Algeria," explores the substance behind the terms.

BETHPAGE, N.Y--To earlier generations, limited by a lack of good roads and travel facili ties, a park was primarily a place for pleasant strolling. Today the word "park" means many things to many people. It covers vast preserves of forest and mountainland in the West. It also is applied to recreation sites of varying size within or near urban communities.
BRISTOL, England, June 16 (UPI)--Margaret Smith of Australia defeated Maria Bueno of Brazil, 6--1, 3--6, 6--2, today to win the women's final in the West of England lawn tennis championships.
More than 400 off-duty flight engineers from the New York area were told by their union's leadership yesterday to remain on the job until further orders.
DAYTON, Ohio, June 16-- The marriage of Miss Constance Cappel to Raymond Almiran Montgomery Jr. took place here this afternoon in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church.
STANTON; Del., June 16 (AP)--Be Somebody, owned by David P. Reynolds, held on in the stretch today and won the $24,700 Christians Stakes at Delaware Park.
A corrugated paperboard ceiling in a building at the Seattle World's Fair is one of the fair's architectural sidelights.
HAVANA, June 18--The Government paraded tanks, troops and artillery through the streets of Cardenas today following "provocations" in the city a few days ago.

AFTER five journalistically efficient nonfiction books and a commercially successful Kinseyesque novel, "The Chapman Report," Irving Wallace felt prepared for his magnum opus. This has to be it--"The Prize," a novel of the human drama behind the Nobel Prize awards, which is magnum to the extent of 768 pages and unmistakably an opus. One guesses that there has never been anything quite like it on the literary landscape.
PHILADELPHIA--Historic Congress Hall closed for eighteen months by a structural and interior restoration project, will be reopened to tourists and others in time for the Fourth of July.

A former editor of the College Entrance Examination Board and an expert on college admission, yesterday offered a new guide for high school students who want to look for the right college. In his revised edition of "The New American Guide th Colleges" (Columbia University Press; $5.95) Gene R. Hawes added a "College Discovery Index" which groups colleges according to their admissions policy or the relative difficulty of getting in and the tution cost.

"IS there really, a Herman Kahn?" one reviewer de manded when the author's huge tome, "On Thermonuclear War," came out in December, 1960. More than a question, it was an exclamation of dismay. Could there be such a person who looked the Gorgons of nuclear war in the face without becoming petrified?

The problems in one corner of Southeast Asia were tentatively eased last week by the agreement among warring neutralist, pro-Communist and pro-Western factions in Laos to form a coalition government for that country. But the difficulties and in particular the Communist pressures in the region as a whole continued to present the United States with a major challenge. I

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 16--In a switch on the thriller staged here in 1950 when Harvard hung on grimly to win, Yale's varsity heavyweight rowers survived trouble in the last half-mile today and defeated an onrushing Crimson eight.
Wall Street, with one eye on falling stock prices at home and the other on rising gold prices in London, reacted last week as though it were looking into a double-barreled shotgun.

WASHINGTON, June 16-- Legislative measures to implement President Kennedy's message in April on transportation policies are falling "far short of the mark," according to A.C. Ingersoll Jr., president of Federal Barge Lines.
Heidelberg, where German student princes pledged their loves and international scholars knew the golden days of youth, is "growing too much and has many big problems."

LOS ANGELES, June 16 (AP)--The league-leading Los Angeles Dodgers were beaten by a former team-mate for the second straight time tonight as Dick Farrell of the Houston Colts pitched a three-hit 4-1 victory before 51,530.

IN the light of the few but stirring movies that have been made about American politics and the impact of forceful individuals upon the workings of government, it is startling and really quite disturbing to see one as crass and cynical as the film Otto Preminger has fashioned out of Allen Drury's novel "Advise and Consent."
In an era of affluent gloveowning Little Leaguers, Harry Bodeck; a former gloveless boy from Brooklyn, instructs youngsters in the anachronistic art of bare-handed catching.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 16--The African-Asian bloc circulated today a draft resolution calling on Britain to scrap the 1961 constitution of Southern Rhodesia.
WASHINGTON, June 16-- Senator Clifford P. Case appealed today to the Department of the Interior, to help speed a hurricane protection system for the New Jersey shoreline.

CONCORD, N.H., June 16--Secretary of State Dean Rusk warned tonight that the danger of war by accident was being increased by the unchecked nuclear arms race. He appealed a new for an enforceable disarmament agreement.

ATLANTA, June 16--The elimination of enforced segregation in interstate transportation throughout much of the South has brought a shift in emphasis in the civil rights struggle. The Freedom Rides hate disappeared from the scene and the national and regional organizations who sponsored them have turned to other tactics.
New York State will embark next fall on its first campaign to attract tourists from abroad, a state official said yesterday.
The Federal Aviation Agency has notified the nation's airlines that it is considering new detailed safety regulations for airplane passenger cabins.

ALGIERS, Sunday, June 17 --Speculation ran high in Algiers today that the Secret Army Organization of European extremists might have reached an agreement with the Algerian transitional executive to end the terrorism in the territory.

HARTFORD, June 16--Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Alice Cole Anthony, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hand Anthony of Bloomfield, to John Poinier Jr. He is the son of Mrs. Robert Sargent of Summit, N.J., and Mr. Poinier of Short Hills. N.J.
A Reform rabbi yesterday hailed "the courageous action" of two Roman Catholic archbishops in the Deep South for decreeing that their parochial schools would be desegregated this September.

Any remaining doubts abcut the dominant role of the African-Asian group in the United Nations were removed Tuesday, when the General Assembly added the question of Southern Rhodesia to the agenda of the sixteenth session.

THE popular novel of Chinese tradition is a sprawling, almost endless affair that moves from group to group of characters, many of whom disappear only to show up later in somewhat improbable disguises that other characters may or may not penetrate. It depends for its appeal on a lively portrayal of many levels of society, a feeling for roguery and sheer narrative drive.

Department store sales in the nation for the week ended June 9 were 1 per cent above the level of a year earlier, the Federal Reserve Board reported. Sales in the preceding week were 4 per cent move the yearago level.

James and Groucho Marx. Then he stopped abruptly a dozen years ago. Since that time, we have had only his short stories to console us.

Ditzen. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Harold L. Goff of Waterbury, V., and the late Mr. Goft. Secretary Rusk embarks this week on a mission to Europe which could be of momentous import to the whole West. It will be his purpose to explain American foreign policy and to enlist support for it, to carry President Kennedy's "New Frontier" across the Atlantic and to build up under American leadership an Atlantic community structure that will outlast the generation that now rules Europe.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 16--Uruguay is doing brisk business with the Soviet Union this year in her campaign for new markets. She may expand her trade with other Communist-bloc countries, including mainland China.

THE world is in one of those icy times that come, appar ently, only about once every 250,000,000 years, occasion enough, one would, think, for the publication of such a book as this. Such is "The World of Ice," by James L. Dyson, head of the Department of Geology and Geography at Lafayette College. It is a splendid book, written smoothly and simply enough for any high-school student--but sufficiently challenging for adult appreciation--and illustrated magnificently.

WASHINGTON, June 16--A long-run opera bouffe starring two Congressional octogenarians took a serious turn at the Capitol this week. While billions of dollars awaited prompt release for Government projects and payrolls, the elderly legislators refused to turn them loose.

WASHINGTON, June 16--On White House orders, a port and highway development project for southern Iran has been marked for highest priority in foreign aid planning. The project could alter the economic and political pattern of Central Asia.

EACH summer New York City's problems reach a peak. Juvenile delinquency rises as youngsters spend more time on the city's streets. Gang warfare erupts in vacant lots and playgrounds. The heat itself produces tensions which may result in misery or violence. In a city with millions of men and women and hundreds of thousands of children, tragedies occur so frequently that they become commonplace.

But while the long summer vacation as an institution resists change, it is being eroded by summer school. VIENTIANE, Laos, June 14 --Lights burn brightly in front of the Vieng Rattay, the more popular of Vientiane's two night clubs. But it is not necessary to peer into the normal darkness inside and see dozens of empty tables to know that business is not as usual.

LOS ANGELES. IGOR STRAVINSKY is 80 years old today (according to most encyclopedias) or tomorrow (according to his open reckoning) He is incommunicado somewhere in Italy where he is quietly celebrating his birthday.

THE Internal Revenue Service is a century old. In honor of 100 years of service by this taxcollecting agency, the Treasury Department on July 1 will produce the first commemorative documentary revenue stamp ever issued by the United States. The 10-cents blue and green stamps will be on sale at all first class second class and county-seat post offices and will also be available at Internal Revenue offices where documentary stamps are sold.

Screeches, walls, crashes, twangs, roars, twiddlings and buzzings announced in the Cafe Figaro at 186 Bleecker Street yesterday afternoon that electronic music was here to stay. The unreasonable refusal of the United Federation of Teachers to give a no-strike pledge has forced the Board of Education to break off contract negotiations. MADISON, Wis., June 18 (UP) Gov. Gaylord Nelson charged the Wisconsin Legislature today with the "solemn, constitutional duty" of reapportioning the state's Congressional and legislative districts on the basis of the 1960 census.
Mrs. Grace Baer Bachrach of 1111 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, prominent in health, welfare and cultural activities for more than fifty years, died Sunday of a heart attack. Her age was 78.
The six-member group of Democratic insurgents in the Bronx claimed control of all patronage there yesterday in its war to defeat Charles A. Buckley as Democratic county leader and Representative.
MILAN, Italy, June 18 (AP) Manuel de Falla's "Atlantida," the late Spanish composer's unfinished cantata, made its world premiere tonight at La Scala Opera House.
BERLIN, June 18 Until 6 o'clock this evening this was a normal day in Berlin, if any day since the Communists built their wall through the city can be called normal.

Advertising men in general are a practical lot who take little interest in the world of scholarship. But there is at least one academician who, in forty years of teaching, has exerted a very considerable influence over advertising and advertising men.
A new step in truck-railroad cooperation will be taken Friday when rates for a small-shipment service become effective.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) The Air Force starts tests this week on a new backpack designed to enable an astronaut to leave his vehicle, move around and work in space.
A new guidance aid for the blind was described here yesterday at the opening of the International Congress on Technology and Blindness.

DETROIT, June 18 (AP)--Imported cars may hold the key to just how good an auto sales year 1962 proves to be. So far, the imports as a class have not shared in the domestic sales boom. Official registrations through the first four months showed then with a total of 115,126, down 4,500 from the comparable 1961 period.
Mickey Spillane's detective hero, Mike Hammer, a fictional character possibly more famous than Franny, Zooey or Raskolnikov, will be back on the bookshelves this summer after ten years' absence.
WASHINGTON, June 18 The pace of home building rose in May for the third consecutive month, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Collars were wilting from the heat all over town yesterday and stores were pushing bathing suits, picnic tables and air conditioners. But at the New York Trade Show Building. Christmas was in the air.

The first big sale of General Motors Corporation stock under a court order requiring E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., to divest itself of its 23 per cent interest in G.M. will probably come some time next month.
VALENCIA, Spain, June 18 Generalissimo Francisco Franco warned the workers of Spain today that the nation could not and would not tolerate strikes.
Bryant Park last night was brighter than ever as the Salute to Seasons ceremonies took place under $9,000 worth of new lighting.

The one and two-story building with manufacturing and office space at 763 Saw Mill River Road, Yonkers, has been sold by the Laundry Workers International Union, Local 284. The properly, with a plot 116 by 121 feet was bought by the 763 Saw Mill River Road Corporation. William J. Sherry was the broker.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 18 The Long Island Rail Road said today that it probably would have to ask for an across-theboard fare increase if Congress did not eliminate the 10 per cent transportation tax by July 1.

THERE is something about the current crop of summer sleepwear that seems to invite cool and comfortable nights. Crisp cotton and easy-care Dacron and cotton mixtures have replaced nylon, which many women find too hot.
VIENTIANE, Laos, June 18 A new dispute prevented today the scheduled installation of the coalition Cabinet agreed upon by Laos' three rival factions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 18--The United States said today that the United Nations would bear a grave responsibility if violence broke out in Ruanda-Urundi after that Belgian trust territory becomes independent July 1 as two separate nations.

WASHINGTON, June 18 New York Republicans, led by Governor Rockefeller, will have a major part, statistically if not otherwise, at next week's Republican conference with former President Dwight D. Eisenhower at Gettysburg.

LONDON, June 18 The Conservative Government's defense policy, already bitterly criticized by political opponents, was exposed to new attacks today as a result of a speech by Robert S. McNamara, United States Secretary of Defense.

NOWADAYS it is easier than it was in times past to become a member of an expatriate establishment. In the Nineteen Twenties, for example, a week or more of ocean travel was required to change an insular young American into a terribly sophisticated Continental avant-garde.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 18--West Coast shipowners requested today that two Federal mediators who have been trying to head off another maritime strike June 30 return as soon as possible.
HYANNIS, Mass., June 18 (AP) Six more impoverished Southern Negroes, including a 17-month-old child, arrived in Hyannis today on "reverse freedom rides."
BONN, Germany June 18 A leading West German educator strongly rejected as unjustified today foreign criticism of the quality of history textbooks used in German schools.
As the first gray touches of evening cast a shadowy mantle across Central Park on Sunday, a full, golden moon appeared on the skyline to the east.

The new home of the New York Shakespeare Festival in Central Park was dedicated as the Delacorte Theatre last night at a benefit performance of "The Merchant of Venice."
Mayor Wagner charged Governor Rockefeller yesterday with attempting to spread confusion as to the fairness of New York's system of legislative representation.
Opponents of the proposed $100,000,000 Lower Manhattan Crosstown Expressway enlisted a new ally yesterday in their fight to defeat the road Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

The Waste King Corporation returned to profitable operations in the fiscal year ended on March 31, with a net income of $749,287, Bertram Given, president of the appliance manufacturer, reported yesterday.

Steel production increased slightly last week, ending a ten-week downward trend. In light of present order patterns, however, many mill officials doubt that the trend has been reversed more than temporarily.
CHICAGO, June 18 (UPI) Most grain futures rallied to start the week on a steady to strong note today on the Chicago Board of Trade.
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, June 18 Mikhail Tal, former world's champion, withdrew today from the Candidates' Chess Tournament because of illness.
A New Jersey commercial bank has become the nation's first institution to retreat from the higher level of interest rates that many thrift institutions have been paying on savings since Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Tuesday, June 19 Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg continued yesterday his efforts to head off a strike against Trans World Airlines set for 2 P.M. today.
The holder of a credit card has been ruled responsible for charges incurred between the time it was stolen and the time he notified the issuing company of its loss.

James M. Power, president of the Board of Elections, told the Board of Estimate yesterday that paper ballots would have to be used in the Sept. 6 primary if the city did not vote the $4,000,000 needed for new voting machines by June 30.
AUBURN, N.Y., June 18 Senator Jacob K. Javits defended his claim to good standing in the Republican party in a speech tonight to the Cayuga County Republican committee.
PITTSBURGH, June 19 (AP)--Jerry Lynch's third hit of the game scored Don Blasingame in the eighth inning to-night and gave the Cincinnati Reds a 2-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
LOS ANGELES, June 19 (UPI)--Frank Borzage, Academy Award-winning motion-picture director, died today after a long illness. He was 69 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) Peace marchers ran afoul of picketing regulations at the White House today and at least four of them were arrested.
Contracts have been signed for the construction of the American Museum of Immigration at the base of the Statue of Liberty National Monument and the work is expected to start in a matter of weeks.
The days when a woman buys a lipstick on impulse are numbered if Yardley of London has its way. The color she picks will be a matter of scientific analysis.
LOS ANGELES, June 19 This sprawling metropolis of diversified creeds, cults and convictions is the seat of an unusual athletic organization, too.

ABOARD U.S.S. SHANGRILA, with Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean, June 19 The new nuclear-powered aircraft carrier Enterprise has been assigned to operations duty with the Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean.

Charles Fitzpatrick and William Myer failed yesterday to win a stay of suspension from the New York State Harness Racing Commission, which is investigating the spectators' riot that took place at Yonkers Raceway on May 29.

Railroads across the country are beginning to lay off thousands of their nonoperating employes. The lines are seeking to compensate for pay increases granted workers in an agreement with eleven unions two weeks ago.
The First National City Bank, New York's second largest commercial bank and the nation's third largest, is making another attempt to expand through a merger.

A FASCINATING aspect of fishing is that there is always something new to be learned odd and interesting variations, methods and materials to be developed or rediscovered. Which brings matters straightaway to grass shrimp and striped bass.
The National Labor Relations Board yesterday upheld The New York Times procedure for assigning work to its mail-room employes.

CAIRO, June 19--The Premier of the Algerian nationalist Provisional Government rebuked his Government's delegate on the Algerian Transitional Executive today. He criticized the announcement of an amnesty for European terrorists in Algeria, if violence ceased.

The women's magazine field, once prim and sedate, is going through a time of ferment. Further evidence of this trend was unfurled in the Crystal Suite of the Savoy Hilton yesterday where the Ladies' Home Journal staged an elaborate "press preview" to present changes in the magazine.

Arnold K. Isreeli, who retired in 1953 as director of information for the American Zionist Council, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Caledonian Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 79 years old and lived at 3825 Atlantic Avenue, Seagate Brooklyn.
LONDON, June 19 (AP) Whitney Reed and Chuck McKinley, America's top singles players, eliminated Soviet Davis Cup team members in the third round of the London tennis championship today.

WASHINGTON, June 19 Secretary of Defense McNamara, in a speech approved by President Kennedy, made an extraordinary proposal last week-end to the Soviet Union which was ignored by almost everybody but a few perceptive observers in the Washington diplomatic corps.
The nation's major retail store chains increased their sales in May by 7.5 per cent from the 1961 level, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.

Vocational Foundation, Inc., will benefit from a preview of "Mr. President" on Oct. 17. The musical with music and lyrics by Irving Berlin and a book by Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse is scheduled to open at the St. James Theatre on Oct. 18.
The gentle rain from heaven showed no mercy last night as it washed out the opening of "The Merchant of Venice" in Central Park.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) President Kennedy signed a bill today that outlaws the formation of Communist cells, as well as Communist party recruiting in the United States.
A high school English teacher has been named host of the new Columbia Broadcasting System TV "Reading Room" series for children.

LOS ANGELES, June 19 State Assemblyman Joseph C. Shell, defeated conservative Republican candidate for gubernatorial nomination, endorsed the candidacy of Richard M. Nixon today after two weeks of factional acrimony.
The Consolidated Edison Company borrowed $100,000,000 yesterday on thirty-year first and refunding mortgage bonds at an interest cost of 4.308 per cent.
The Transit Authority assured its 6,000,000 daily subway and bus riders yesterday that the 15-cent fare would remain at least until June 30, 1963.
The National Maritime Union said yesterday that it had appealed to the National Labor Relations Board in Washington a decision handed down by Ivan C. McLeod, the agency's regional director.

A swampy subsurface and a subterranean storm sewer line were the major factors in the buckling of pavement Monday on the Long Island Expressway. The 93-degree heat of that day was the added straw that broke the pavement's back.
Leaders of organized labor yesterday reaffirmed their intention of withdrawing from the Permament Administrative Committee, which oversees labor conditions in voluntary hospitals.

PAGO PAGO, American Samoa, June 18 Under strict security precautions, scientists prepared to observe the fivehundred-mile high nuclear bomb experiment scheduled for between 11 P.M. and 2:30 A.M. (5 A.M. and 8:30 A.M. Wednesday, Eastern daylight time).

The successful launching yesterday of Tiros V, the 286-pound television weather eye, marks one more step in a program aimed at making weather forecasting an exact science, developing accurate long-range prediction and bringing about some measure of weather control.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 19 (UPI) Australian tennis stars headed by Rod Laver and Margaret smith, dominated the seedings announced today for the Wimbledon championships starting next Monday.

LAWRENCE, L. I. June 19 The engagement of Miss Jac queline Susan Buchman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Buchman, to Wayne Morris Lampert, the son of Mrs. Marty Lipschutx of East Rockaway, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., June 19 (AP) Professional boxing was banned today on all city property as a result of a Fort Lauderdale Boxing Commissioner's campaign, begun with the death last March of Benny (Kid) Paret in his welterweight tittle bout with Emile Griffith in New York.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) The Supreme Court overturned today a contempt of Congress conviction of Frank Grumman, of Fort Lee, N.J.
THE Westchester Interclub League, composed of six country clubs that play bridge matches during the summer, began its 1962 season last week. William Root of New York is the tournament director.

ASCOT, England, June 19 (AP) Queen Elizabeth II and a fashionable crowd watched a thrilling finish today in the St. James Palace Stakes one of the big races of the first day of the Royal Ascot meeting.

ATHENS, June 19 King Paul of Greece formally opened today an international seminar on the theatre and its mass audiences. The week-long seminar is sponsored by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
A little known part of the securities business has been receiving increasing attention lately. It is the off-board trading of shares listed on stock exchanges.
A ship's engine room where buttons replace men was unveiled here yesterday.

AUSTIN, Tex., June 19 (UPI) Texas' Attorney General, Will Wilson, charged today that a district judge had prematurely dismissed a state grand jury that spent five weeks investigating the death of Henry H. Marshall.
WASHINGTON, June 19--Democrats sought today to exploit a disclosure in the Billie Sol Estes case to help them put across the Administration's farm bill in the House.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) After listening to a daylong recital of alleged white slave traffic, Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, said that the American Guild of Variety Artists had no place "in the house of decent unionism."

Loew's Capitol Theatre, one of the best-known movie houses in the country, will close tonight to complete extensive alterations for the world premiere on Aug. 7 of the first "dramatic film" in the Cinerama wide-screen process. MetroGoldwyn-Mayer's "The Wonderful World of the Brothers Grimm."
The bond market was influenced by crosscurrents of sentiment yesterday, with defensiveness dominant.

TUNIS, June 19 The Algerian nationalist Provisional Government appeared today to be hardening its position toward the European terrorist Secret Army Organization and backing away from the promise of amnesty made in Algeria Sunday by Dr. Chawki Mostefai.
A very quiet day on the New York commodity exchanges was punctuated early yesterday afternoon by a flurry of trading in world sugar futures.

BERLIN, June 17 Stung by the international renown of the Berliner Ensemble, a showpiece of Communist East Berlin, West Berlin has taken action to develop a progressive theatre able to compete with the powerful group on the other side of the wall.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) Herbert D. Vogel resigned today as chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority. His resignation will be effective June 30.
WAYNE, N.J., June 19. The marriage of Miss Jenne Katz to Peter Stuart Britell took place tonight at the Preakness Hills Country Club, Rabbi David F. Panitz performed the ceremony.
CARLSTADT, N. J., June 19 A seal swam twenty miles into suburbia today and wound up in a doghouse.
BONN, Germany, June 19 Four West German jet fighters of a precision flying team crashed near Cologne this afternoon, killing their pilots, one of them a United States training officer.
A thirty-family apartment house at 2629 Sedgwick Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by the King Properties Company to investing clients of Benjamin Housman, lawyer.
ZURICH, Switzerland, June 19 (AP) -- Volkmar Andreae, Swiss conductor and composer, died here today at the age of 82.
The strike threat that hung over Trans World Airlines yesterday drove passengers away as quickly as a cloud build-up promising zero weather.
LONDON, June 19 Industrial shares turned dull again on the stock market today. Small declines dominated most groups, but the volume of trading was small again.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, June 20 The Flight Engineers' International Association delayed a strike against Trans World Airlines yesterday while it decided whether to accept a last-minute Government proposal for settlement of the dispute.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 19 Mayor Wagner of New York proposed today that the Metropolitan Regional Council pool its resources to help meet the problem of the great migration to the region by new Social groups.
WASHINGTON, June 19 The Kennedy Administration has decided to waive the "buy American" restriction on foreign aid funds to South Vietnam to let the regime spend $22,000,000 anywhere it wants.
The city suffered through the fourth day of its first heat wave of the year yesterday. The high temperature for the day was 93 degrees, at 2:30 P. M.
A sign of rising construction activity came yesterday with an announcement by the Veterans Administration that its G. I. home loan business was on the increase in May.

James A. Farley has been almost--but not finally--excluded from serving as a delegate to this year's Democratic state convention by reason of action taken by three reform faction clubs in the First Assembly District, Manhattan.
CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) Improvements in 1962 carpet sales and a healthy growth period for the industry through 1967" were predicted today by a carpet industry executive.

WASHINGTON, June 19--A sub-Cabinet officer of the Eisenhower Administration acknowledged today that the stockpiling law had been used to raise lead and zinc prices. But he insisted that the objective had been to elevate the domestic industry to a mobilization footing.
Two youths in a stolen truck were arrested yesterday after a five-mile chase through Manhattan. The police fired six shots during the twenty-minute pursuit. No one was injured.
BANKGKOK, Thailand, June 19 Thailand retaliated sharply today against what Government sources termed unwarranted United States favoritism toward Cambodia in a dispute over a 1,000-year-old temple.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 19 One seeded player was elimmated from the New York State women's tennis championship in the third round today at the Beach Point Club.
SEATTLE, June 19 (AP) Adlai E. Stevenson defended today the provision in the United Nations Charter that gives equal voting rights to all members of the world organization.
WASHINGTON, June 19 Senator Jacob K. Javits called on President Kennedy today to "clarify" the controversial role of Robert B. Troutman Jr. in the Administration's drive to open up jobs for Negroes.

DETROIT, June 19 -- The Ford Motor Company laid off more than 20,000 additional workers in manufacturing facilities today as a result of a strike at the company's stamping plant in Walton Hills, Ohio.

Alfred L. Levy, president of Talent Asssociates-Paramount, Ltd., died yesterday in the Littleton (N. H.) Hospital after a long illness. He was 52 years old. His company has produced and packaged numerous television shows and has been active in the production of motion pictures and Broadway plays.
James MacDonald, a reporter for The New York Times who covered many of the decisive developments of World War II, died in his sleep yesterday morning. He was 65 years old.
Andrew Geller, Inc., Brooklyn shoe manufacturer, is expanding into the handbag field in its first diversification move, it was announced yesterday.

An executive of one of the largest mutual fund selling groups said yesterday that the industry could eliminate automatically many of its practices that have been criticized if it were allowed to advertise freely.
Twenty-six drawings and oils by Ginseppe Napoli will go on exhibition Monday in a new ritualistic barber shop on Madison Avenue.

The "Perils of Pauline" never had a more cliffhanging climax than has attended Secretary of Labor Goldberg's effort to stave off the threatened strike of flight engineers against Trans World Airlines. The nature of the dispute, with its intertwining of issues of technological progress, union jurisdiction and emotion, always made it illogical to expect a rational solution through the grounding of planes.

Los Angeles, June 19 (AP) Frank Howard drove in two runs with a first-inning homer and scored the deciding run on a misplayed grounder in the seventh inning tonight as the league - leading Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 3 2, before 33,986.

The election of August Belmont as president and Frederic H. Brandi as chairman was announced yesterday by Dillon, Read Co., Inc. Mr. Brandi, who had been president, will continue as chief executive officer of the investment banking concern. The chairmanship is a new post.

New technology for increasing the high-temperature strength of such metals as nickel, copper, aluminum, and iron, to provide a new range of materials for aerospace, jet engine, and electronic applications was announced by E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Co., Inc., at... its Baltimore Metals Center yesterday.

Studies believed to demonstrate for the first time a change in the chemistry and structure of the brain as a result of learning were reported here yesterday at the international Congress on Technology and Blindness.

Mayor Wagner promised yesterday an early "advisory review" of the city's tax structure by "qualified experts." He made it clear, however, that he would not go along with any recommendation for a city income tax or payroll tax.
VIENTIANE, Laos, June 19 Gen. Phoumi Nosavan, military chief of the Right-Wing faction, has thrown a new obstacle into the path of a Laotian coalition Government.
BERLIN, June 19 West Berlin officials believe that an "explosive" situation is building up on the border between West and East Berlin.
MOSCOW, June 19 A Lith uanian accused of having "terrorized" the populace with an anti-Communist armed band has been condemned to death by a Soviet Court.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 19--Northern Light, the seventy-three-foot yawl owned by A. Lee Loomis Jr. of New York and the first to finish in the Newport-to-Bermuda yacht race two years ago, ended the ocean classic at the head of the fleet again tonight.

J. Ray McDermott Co., Houston, Tex., offshore oil drilling, engineering and construction company, achieved the highest gross and net income in its history during the fiscal year ended March 31, according to the annual figures disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, June 19--The British Government disclosed today that its program for entry into the European Economic Community had been slowed down.

Work will start soon on a new, fourteen-story Lighthouse building for the New York Association for the Blind. The building, at 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, between Lexington and Park Avenues, will replace the original Lighthouse, a sixstory structure completed by the association in 1913.
Four men were arrested yesterday on charges of counterfeiting travelers checks issued by the Canadian Pacific Railway, Three other men were arrested in Detroit on the same charges.

A French national was in jail here yesterday after trying to leave the country Monday with $247,400 cash in a valise. He was arrested after the plane had made an unscheduled stop at New York International Airport and his luggage had been searched.

TRENTON, June 19 Gov. Richard J. Hughes notified all school officials in New Jersey today that the traditional neighborhood concept in the assignment of children to schools must be made sufficiently flexible to prevent racial segregation.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 19 (AP) A special three-judge Federal court declared all Oklahoma's legislative apportionment laws null and void today because of discrimination against urban residents, It gave the state until July 31 to start correcting the situation.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 19. A suit seeking desegregation of patient care, the medical staff and medical training at Grady Memorial Hospital and of state and local medical and dental societies was filed here today.
Stock prices eased yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in slow trading. The loss on average was minor and was considered encouraging by many in Wall Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19--Belgium presented today to the United Nations a detailed plan for the withdrawal of Belgian troops from Ruanda and Urundi within three months after the two African territories became independent July 1.
CHICAGO, June 19 (AP)--Prices of grain futures ranged in small fractions both ways from previous closes in dull dealings on the Board of Trade.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 1,155 persons were hurt in car accidents in the city last week. This was an increase of 114 compared with the similar 1961 week.
The Florida Development Commissioner announced plans yesterday to offer on July 12 an issue of $25,000,000 of revenue bonds due 1965 to 2050.

PARIS, June 19 For twelve hours today the economic life of France and the normal living of her 45,000,000 inhabitants were thrown into turmoil by strikes that cut drastically the supplies of electricity and gas.

TRENTON, June 19--New Jersey Republicans called on their New York counterparts today to press for an increase in that state's minimum age drinking law, to end "needless highway deaths" and to reduce juvenile delinquency.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 19 A leading rabbi proposed here tonight that all religious groups join Judaism in a "universal Yom Kippur" in an effort to ward off nuclear destruction.
WASHINGTON, June 19 The Federal Government sought today to crack down on nutritional quackery, a $500,000,000a-year business.
WASHINGTON, June 19 A major Congressional controversy over the financing of President Kennedy's $500,000,000 urban mass transportation program appeared almost inevitable today.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 19 (AP) A Justice Department suit, filed today, to desegregate the Birmingham airport restaurant, is the latest development on the integration front in Alabama.

OTTAWA, June 19 Prime Minister John Diefenbaker, whose Conservative party lost its majority in yesterday's election, was planning today to form a minority Government with the Social Credit party holding the balance of power.
WHEN the gods of rain visit an outdoor concert in New York, that is not news. When the gods are defied, however, and the concert continues, that is definitely news.
WASHINGTON, June 19 Land reclaimed from the swampy New Jersey Meadows is now worth as much as $35,000 an acre and has a "terrific" future potential.
NEW DELHI, India, June 19 India has accused Communist China of having established "no less than five new military bases" in the Ladakh area of eastern Kashmir since April, 1960.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 19 Ewan Clague, United States Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said today that a recession was likely in 1963. But he added that it was too early to tell whether the stock market decline in recent weeks would hasten its advent.

A plaintiff in the Federal court suit challenging New York's legislative representation system said yesterday that there was a strong possibility the existing system would be outlawed before this year's legislative elections in November.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) The State Department disclosed today that its Policy Planning Council, headed by Walt W. Rostow, had completed and submitted to the White House a comprehensive survey of United States foreign policies.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 19 Roger Girsberg of Riverdale, the Bronx defeated Bob Gardner, the metropolitan amateur champion, in a one-hole playoff today to win the Hochster Memorial golf tournament.

Donaldson, Lufkin Jenerette, Inc., investment bankers and members of the New York Stock Exchange, have leased enlarged quarters on the entire eighteenth floor and half of the seventeenth floor in the new office building being erected by Samuel Rudin at 1 Whitehall Street.

The Polo Grounds, a Manhattan enclave surrounded on the east by Yankee Stadium, on the west by Coogan's Bluff and on the north and south by enemy home runs, became a batting range yesterday for (of all people) the New York Mets.
WASHINGTON, June 19 A Senate committee staff report said today that many elderly Americans had to put up their homes as security to qualify for medical assistance under the Kerr-Mills Program.
WASHINGTON, June 19 Senate leaders, with a White House aide present, scanned the dockets of the committees today, checking for ways to speed up action on lagging Administration programs.
WASHINGTON, June 19--West Germany and France have formally committed themselves to take part in the proposed $6,000,000,000 enlargement of the International Monetary Fund.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, advised the United Federation of Teachers yesterday to sign a no-strike contract with the Board of Education if other provisions of the contract were acceptable.

ALGIERS, June 19 Jean Jacques Susini, political head of the Secret Army Organization, demanded tonight that Europeans be included in the new Moslem police force in Algeria. He insisted that his request be fulfilled within forty eight hours.

The massive March storm that swept manmade structures off Atlantic beaches from Virginia to Long Island, drowning several people in the process, was a costly reminder that it is only at enormous risk that man undertakes to build or live in an area that belongs naturally to the sea.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 19 Premier Khrushchev reiterated today that unless an agreement was reached with the West on a German peace treaty the Soviet Union would sign a separate pact with East Germany that would "end the occupation of West Berlin."

YONKERS, June 19 Andrew J. Valuchek has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Lynn Susan Valuchek, to Edwin John de Beer Jr. He is the son of Mrs. Edwin de Beer of Tuckahoe and the late Dr. de Beer.
WARSAW, June 19 The East German Minister of Defense, Col. Gen. Karl Heinz Hoffmann, has arrived in Poland for a six-day goodwill visit.
The International Finance Corporation, private financing affiliate of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank), went into the securities underwriting business yesterday.
The city's fire houses will hold an open house for visitors on Sunday from 1 to 5 P. M.
Property owners in Brooklyn, Queens and Richmond will pay $4.28 for each $100 of assessed valuation of property in 196263 under final combined tax rates set yesterday by the City Council.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 19 Miss Juliet Greathouse Cain and John Alexander Roberts Jr. are planning to be married Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Cain of Indianapolis and Northport, Mich. have made known thei daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. Roberts of New York and Mrs. Roy Alan Rowe of Long Beach, Calif.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 19 (AP) Federal Judge Robert P. Anderson gave the bankrupt New Haven Railroad permission today to seek inclusion in a proposed merger of the New York Central Railroad and the Pennsylvania Railroad.

The Canadian election turned into a stunning surprise and a deep, even dismaying, disappointment. The surprise was the remarkable showing of the Social Credit party, which now holds the balance of power in the House of Commons. The dismay comes from the fact that Canada must now stagger along with a minority Conservative Government at a time of financial crisis.
BALTIMORE, June 19 The Yankees lost no arguments with the umpires tonight. They didn't have any. But they did lose another ball game.
YOU'RE a fat slob," said Frank Torre, the nimble first-base man of the Milwaukee Braves, at the family dinner table in Brooklyn.
MOSCOW, June 19 General of the Army Aleksei I. Antonov, the Soviet Chief of Staff of the joint armed forces of the Warsaw Treaty nations, died yesterday. His age was 65.

ROME, June 19 Announcement of the Government's plan to nationalize the electricity industry appeared to have sparked a notable price rise in stocks on the Rome and Milan stock exchanges. Electrical issues shared in the increase.
WASHINGTON, June 19 Howard Hughes received Government authorization today to buy control of Northeast Airlines through his Hughes Tool Company.

Cotton futures rose 10 cents to $1 a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The market Opened 20 cents to 75 cents up, with buying by New Orleans brokers noted in new October. The offerings were light, and the market had a steady tone.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 19. The Piping Rock Club here was the setting tonight for a supper dance attended by four young women who are making their debuts on the North Shore this little season.
The Southern Pacific, the nation's second largest railroad, is holding exploratory merger talks with the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad.
The drive to ransom 1,179 survivors of the ill-fated invasion of Cuba last year entered its third month yesterday with a promise of support from numerous world figures.
COWES, Isle of Wight, June 19--A commercial version of the SR-N2 Hovercraft, capable of carrying at least sixty-six passengers at speeds up to seventy miles an hour, was demonstrated here today.
PARIS, June 19 Secretary of State Dean Rusk explored today with President de Gaulle the boundaries of the large area of misunderstanding and disagreement between France and the United States.

JACKSON, Miss., June 19 (AP) Lawrence Hudson Jr., editor of The Mississippi Free Press, said today he had been beaten with a blackjack and leather strap by a highway patrolman and Rankin County officers.

There is talk of sending two of Broadway's popular musicals. "Wonderful Town" and "Brigadoon," on a six-month tour of Europe and South Amer ica, starting next March. The itinerary is to include the Soviet Union.
Fines against an East Harlem landlord were substantially reduced yesterday in a rare action in the Court of General Sessions.

Councilman Joseph C. Di Carlo, coordinator of the Bronx insurgent drive against Representative Charles A. Buckley, announced yesterday the first seven appointment to a country-wide advisory committee.

BUYING a house may be one of the greatest sources of pleasure mixed with anguish in a woman's lifetime. Finding a nest is an ordeal for so many families because of high prices and a dearth of well-built houses.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the once staid and ultra-conservative food retailing concern, disclosed yesterday at its annual stockholder's meeting that it had entered the non-food' discount field.
OTTAWA, June 19 Real Caouette, deputy leader of the Social Credit party, was the real hero responsible for the tremendous and unexpected surge of his party in yesterday's election.

John R. Kimberly's Tronidor made it two in a row on the turf by taking the seven furlong Summer Festival at Belmont Park yesterday. The last time out, on Belmont Stakes day, Tronidor won by a neck over the same distance. He scored by a length and a half yesterday over Leland F. Mattison's Will Ye, with the Rokeby Stable's Goose Creek next

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) The Air Force brought down a high-altitude research balloon today after a record nineteen-day flight that carried the sphere 9,300 miles from Bermuda to near Iwo Jima in the Pacific.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) President Kennedy is sending a veteran career diplomat, John Kenneth Emmerson to Tokyo to serve as deputy chief of mission in the United States Embassy under Ambassador Edwin O. Reischauer.

A truck-load of white whale arrived at the Coney Island Aquarium yesterday. Except for a slight loss of appetite, it seemed to have enjoyed its jiggly ride down from the St. Lawrence River, where it was caught.

The following listing includes derbusses, muskets, pistols and events that have been selected rifles, some of the type used by by New York Times critics. Daniel Boone and Davy Crocket. For children of all ages, unless others ornamented by carvings otherwise specified, ivory inlays and silver easings.

CLEVELAND, June 19 (UPI)--Bill Monbouquette limited the league-leading Cleveland Indians to four hits tonight and pitched the Boston Red Sox to a 4-2 victory. Frank Malzone's homer in the third inning and Carroll Hardy's two-run double in the sixth were the decisive Boston hits.
THE twenty-fifth annual 100-mile national cham pionship race for Indianapolis cars and drivers will be run on the Langhorne (Pa.) circular mile dirt track on Sunday afternoon, A. J. Foyt
A well-dressed man carrying a colorless liquid in a medicine bottle attempted a hold-up yesterday at a Park Avenue bank. The liquid was a martini. He drank it while waiting for the police to arrive.

By way of dramatizing "the new spirit" of the city administration, Mayor Wagner went on television and radio yesterday with his annual message to the City Council. The value of this experiment in giving New Yorkers a better understanding of why it costs $2,750,000,000 a year to run their municipal government would have been greater if the tone had not been so much that of a Madison Avenue commercial.

SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, June 19 The Dominican Republic, fearing that curtailment of its current rate of sugar exports to the United States may shatter its economy, plans to notify Washington tomorrow that it must refuse Alliance for Progress aid unless Congress raises the allocation.

THE first salad of summer may seem wonderfully re freshing. However, as one hot day succeeds another, and one salad succeeds another, a hot, cooked entree becomes increasingly attractive despite the temperature.
Msgr. Joseph Kelly, pastor of St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church, Fourth Avenue and Ninety-fifth Street, Brooklyn, died yesterday in the rectory of the church. He was 77 years old.
