PARIS, June 19 The French were content to receive Secretary Rusk today and hope his visit can remove some clouds. But they are neither optimistic about solution of essential problems nor do they think the timing was particularly apt.
WASHINGTON, June 19 The House of Representatives passed today a sugar bill that the Administration does not want.
Vincent W. Hartnett acknowledged yesterday that he had once agreed to try to undo any harm caused by published charges that John Henry Faulk had been associated with Communist-group fronts.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 19 Edward M. Gilbert, New York financier who withdrew nearly $2,000,000 of his company's funds without authorization and flew to Brazil, said tonight he intended to "pay back every penny for which I am accountable."
The Communications Workers of America said last night that 23,000 workers employed by the New York Telephone Company throughout the state would remain off their jobs today.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday that it was making grants totaling $4,459,378, chiefly for educational programs overseas.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 19 Ireland appealed to India and Pakistan today to start direct discussions on the Kashmir dispute and to refrain from actions or statements that might prejudice the situation.

LONDON, June 20 The attempt by Duncan Sandys to induce Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India to think twice about buying MIG's from the Soviet Union is the latest of many tasks he has undertaken for British governments. In his years as a soldier and Member of Par liament and in his ...

EL PASO, Tex., June 20 (UPI) Complaining bitterly that the President and the Attorney General had pronounced him guilty before he was tried, Billie Sol Estes asked a Federal District Judge today to stop a grand jury from investigating him further.
The Planning Commission's 1962-63 urban renewal study program, released yesterday, appeared to be designed as a trial balloon.
CLINTON, N.Y., June 20 (UPI) The New York Synod of the United Presbyterian Church has elected a Negro for the first time in its 105-year history.
A LAST-MINUTE telephone call announcing two or more unexpected dinner guests does not faze Phyllis Krasilovsky.
Earnings of the Avco Corporation climbed 35 per cent for the six months ended on May 31 on a sales gain of 18 per cent, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

THE runless stocking has hit a snag. Two weeks after introductory supplies of the stocking went on sale, warning flags have gone up to caution the consumer not to accept some of the earlier claims about the new hosiery.
OMAHA, Neb., June 20 (AP) The Interstate Oil Compact Commission asked today that oil imports be held to a definite percentage of domestic crude production.

The Magnavox Company and the W.A. Sheaffer Pen Company have selected new agencies to handle their accounts. Both companies, which bill about $2,000,000 a year each, have been interviewing leading Madison Avenue agencies for several weeks.
ONESTI, Rumania, June 20 (Reuters) Premier Khrushchev said today that "no magicians or witches will ever revive the dying capitalist system."
At least five men were injured and two "Molotov cocktails" were hurled during a riot between Cuban exiles and sympathizers of the Castro regime outside a West Side meeting hall last night.

Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons was the star of the show at Belmont Park yesterday. The 88-yearold trainer put across a consecutive double, including a success in the $28,850 feature, the Bowling Green Handicap at a mile and half on the turf.
Besides playing the title role in "King Lear" at England's Stratford-on-Avon, Paul Scofield may also act in Friedrich Duerrenmatt's new comedy, "The Physicists."
The Board of Estimate yesterday discussed the $4,000,000 appropriation that the Board of Elections wants to purchase new voting machines. But it did not fix a time for a vote on the issue.

IT would have been fitting had there been dogs and benches at Luchow's restaurant yesterday. For the guest of honor at a meeting of the Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club was none other than George Francis Foley Mr. Dog Show himself celebrating his eightieth birthday.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) The United States balance of payments deficit declined to an annual rate of $1,900,000,000 in the first three months of 1962, the Department of Commerce reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) Jackie Bright, head of the American Guild of Variety Artists, was pictured in a Senate investigation today as violating Federal law by accepting free lodging at a resort hotel with which his union has contracts.
SANTO DOMINGO, June 20 A fifteen-man Dominican delegation headed by two Cabinet ministers flew to Washington today to plead this country's sugar case before the Senate.
WASHINGTON, June 20 The Flight Engineers' International Association and Trans World Airlines were said to be nearing agreement tonight on the main points of a new contract.
The Tarrant County, Tex., Water Control and Improvement District 1 plans to offer on July 12 an issue of $13,500,000 of bonds, due 1964 to 2001.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 20 Americans are digging in for a long war in South Vietnam.

Todd Shipyards Corporation is experiencing an "encouraging" first fiscal quarter, which ends June 30, but uncertainties as to the future course of business bar specific predictions on earnings and dividends for the full year, John T. Gilbride, president, reported here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 20 The Administration sought to turn off unwanted talk of recession today.

MADRID, June 20 A Roman Catholic Spanish Army chaplain was reported today to have been sentenced to eight years' imprisonment for alleged "Communist activity" during the recent industrial strikes in Spain.

THIS is a department con cerned with such information as the state of salt-water fishing from Cape May to Montauk Point and beyond. However, when there is little more to say than that it is better than good and improving, a fellow feels as if his audience left hours ago. The only thing left to say is to get out there and enjoy it while it lasts.

BALTIMORE, June 20 Rain deprived the Yankees of a chance to end their slump tonight, but Manager Ralph Houk had hopes the club would be virtually slump-proof by Friday. The Yankee manager announced that on that night Mickey Mantle would return to the starting line-up.
A bit of old Detroit moved out of New York yesterday on its way to San Francisco.
State Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh, who was found guilty in Federal Court last Saturday on a conspiracy charge, has filed to retire on pension.
NEW DELHI, India, June 20 Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru asserted today that there had been "no formal offer" by the Soviet Government to supply India with MIG jet fighters.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 20 Althea Gibson, a former queen of Wimbledon tennis, made her debut as a Metropolitan District tournament golfer today.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 20 The Belgians have come back to the Congo, their former African colony. Even now, as the Congolese prepare for the second anniversary of independence, this city's aspect is changing.
WASHINGTON, June 20 Communist China is massing troops and jet planes in an extraordinarily large build-up opposite the offshore islands of Quemoy and Matsu. The islands are held by Nationalist China.
WASHINGTON, June 20 President Kennedy challenged some 4,000 college students today to discard the cliches and political arguments of the past in trying to solve present-day problems.

World production of sugar is something like 25 per-cent above consumption. As a result, the price on the world market has dropped to 2.5 or 2.7 cents a pound. In order to protect domestic sugar producers, the price in the United States is fixed around 6.4 cents a pound.

WALNUT, Calif., June 20 John Thomas' return to highjumping form was the chief item of news today as the spiked-shoe set began to assemble for the Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships this week-end at Mount San Antonio College.
The Conservative party yesterday interpreted last week's Republican attack on its activities as a sign of panic on the part of Governor Rockefeller and Senator Jacob K. Javits.

BERLIN, June 20 The West Berlin police built sandbag barricades and earth breastworks at various points along the twenty-eight-mile Berlin wall today to provide Western border guards with cover against fire from East Berlin.
HONG KONG, June 20 Forty to fifty orphans will leave Hong Kong next week in a chartered plane for the United States, where they will become adopted children of American families.

WASHINGTON, June 20 A plan to develop a potentially significant new source of mortgage money was introduced in Congress today by Senator John J. Sparkman and Representative Albert Rains, chairman of the housing subcommittees of the Senate and House.
The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association said yesterday it expected to strike against American Export Lines tomorrow.
The New York Central Railroad asked the Public Service Commission yesterday for an across-the-board fare increase of $3.04 a month on all commutation tickets in the New York suburban area.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 20 The two Latin-American members of the Security Council urged today that India and Pakistan make a new effort to settle their dispute over Kashmir by direct negotiation.
TO New Yorkers long accustomed to an Oct. 1 moving day, the idea of changing households in the summer may seem out of order. However, the New Yorker, not the nation, is out of step.
ALGIERS, June 20 Members of the Secret Army Organization in the west and east of Algeria continued their terrorist attacks and sabotage today in spite of the truce concluded in Algiers last Sunday.

Norman Bailey Woolworth, a member of the family that founded the Woolworth chain of five-and-ten-cent stores, died of uremic poisoning and diabetes Tuesday night at the Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 60 years old.
MANHASSET, L.I., June 20 Mr. and Mrs. John F. Pryor have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Ellen Pryor, to Peter Woodhouse Werden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lincoln A. Werden.

A trade group representing most of the nation's leading apparel manufacturers yesterday praised the Federal Trade Commission's campaign against discriminatory cooperative advertising allowances to retailers.

WASHINGTON, June 20 The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended June 13:

STRATFORD, Ont., June 20 For the second produc tion of its tenth season the Stratford Festival moved last night from the unrelieved gloom of the opening "Macbeth" to the farcical humors of "The Taming of the Shrew." A happy and welcome move it was, one likely to be generally appreciated through the summer, and deservedly so.

The nation's inventories of gasoline declined by 1,762,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. At the week-end, total supplies were 189,965,000 barrels, compared with 191,727,000 a week earlier and 193,896,000 a year ago.
LONDON, June 20 Miss Denise Lawson-Johnston and Rene Bouch , the American portrait painter, were married here today in the Chelsea Registry Office.
OTTAWA, June 20 Prime Minister John Diefenbaker called a meeting of his Conservative Cabinet today to plan the formation of a minority government and to ponder the pressure on the Canadian dollar.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 President Kennedy's personal representative met separately today with employer and labor groups involved in a Pacific maritime dispute.
Compromise negotiations aimed at obtaining a place for James A. Farley, the former Postmaster General, as a delegate to this year's Democratic state convention were in a state of collapse yesterday.
Two physicians found guilty of selling the questions and answers to a licensing examination for doctors were sentenced yesterday to a year in jail each.
WASHINGTON, June 20 Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall today challenged Robert Moses' program for protecting Fire Island.
WASHINGTON, June 20 New York City law enforcement officials pleaded with Congress today to help them fight organized crime with a limited legalization of wiretapping.
PARIS, June 20 France politely turned aside today as premature a proposal by Secretary of State Dean Rusk that an eventual French nuclear force be coordinated with United States and British forces.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 20 (AP) The Cambodian Government declared today that it "will use every means at its disposal" to dislodge Thai forces from a border temple that the International Court of Justice had ruled was on Cambodian territory.
HONOLULU, June 20 The United States failed last night for the second time to detonate a high-altitude nuclear device over the Pacific Ocean, 800 miles south of here.
KATMANDU, Nepal, June 20 An American mountaineering team was reported today to be lost in bad weather in the Himalayan heights in Nepal.
PARIS, June 20 The Soviet Union is represented at this year's season of international theatre at the Theatre des Nations by astonishingly undistinguished performances.

The Supreme Court's decision that the NorrisLa Guardia Act forbids Federal injunctions to halt strikes called in violation of union contracts raises a serious threat to industrial stability. Fifteen million workers are now employed under labor-management agreements prohibiting strikes and requiring that all disputes be settled through arbitration. Such provisions are now standard in nine-tenths of all contracts.

The Securities and Exchange Commission approved yesterday an application by the Atlas Corporation, an investment company, to sell its 56 per cent controlling stock interest in Northeast Airlines to the Hughes Tool Company for $5,000,000.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) ?The United States and Australia agreed today to work together on problems affecting both countries that arise from Britain's proposed entry into the European Economic Community.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) lent yesterday the equivalent of $160,500,000 to Mexico. The funds will be used to finance expansion of electric power facilities and to extend the country's toll transport system, including a 250-mile ferry linking ... Baja, California to the mainland.
DETROIT, June 20 Negotiations were resumed in Cleveland today to resolve the work standards dispute that has halted the production of Ford Motor Company passenger cars.

WASHINGTON, June 20 Some influential citizens of California who urged Richard M. Nixon to become a candidate for Governor this year have forwarded here an analysis of the recent primaries, with conclusions which differ substantially from those prevailing that the odds are heavily against the election of the former Vice President.
VIENTIANE, Laos, June 20 The Laotian Rightists dropped today one of their demands that have blocked the installation of a coalition regime, but they appeared to be standing firm on at least one.
United Parcel Service drivers and sorters yesterday turned down a tentative agreement that would have ended their thirty-eight-day-old strike.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 20 The Foreign Minister of Nigeria, Jaja A. Wachuku, suggested today to the General Assembly that an interim solution for Southern Rhodesia's "very explosive" problems could be a Parliament equally divided between Africans and whites, with Britain holding a single deciding vote.
Tomorrow, the National Educational Television network will tape the first of a new series of "visual essays" to be seen on sixty educational stations across the country in the fall.
Retired Justice Louis A. Valente, who served on the Supreme Court bench here from 1926 to 1953, died yesterday in his home, 37 Washington Square West, after a brief illness. He was 79 years old.

The bitterness already existing between the two kingdoms makes acceptance by Thailand of the World Court ruling in favor of Cambodia over Preah Vihar especially galling to the Thais at this time. Diplomatic links between Bangkok and Pnompenh were broken off last fall for the second time in recent years in a flare-up of recriminations stemming from Cambodia's neutralist and Thailand's pro-West policies. Since then feelings have not improved.
Owners of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., which was taken over by the city as a result of a strike dispute, have filed a claim against the Transit Authority for $251,000,000.
WASHINGTON, June 20 House Democrats defeated today two Republican attempts to write a civil rights amendment into the Administration's farm bill.
PARIS, June 20 There has been a subtle but important improvement in the atmosphere of the negotiations for British entry into the European Economic Community, though serious problems remain.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 20 The Central Conference of American Rabbis viewed with careful caution here today the so-called "shared Time" plan that would permit public and parochial schools to use jointly certain tax-supported educational facilities.
A major effort to ease Manhattan will get under imposition of no-standing crosstown traffic snarls in midway next Wednesday with the rules on Fifty-fifth and Fifty-sixth Streets, between Sutton ...
CHICAGO, June 20 Five hundred members of the American Symphony Orchestra League gathered here today for the organization's largest convention since its founding twenty years ago.
The Ruberoid Company announced yesterday that it planned to invite tenders for a minimum of 350,000 shares of common stock of the Celotex Corporation at $25 a share.

Still another reason has been given for the stock market's decline. John R. Bunting, a vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia and an economist, reasons that the market "is reflecting the fact that we are assuming a larger position in world affairs than we as a people want to assume."

BOSTON, June 20 Five shirt-sleeved trumpeters blowing loud and prolonged blasts signaled the opening of the eleventh Boston Arts Festival at the Public Gardens at 7 here this evening. Multi-colored balloons were released over the artificial lake, and Dr. George Richardson, president of this year's festival, said, "I now declare the eleventh Boston Arts Festival officially open."
The City Planning Commission announced yesterday its 1962-63 urban renewal study program, recommending an intensive survey of eleven areas for possible redevelopment.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) Gordon Weller, executive director of the Uranium Institute, accused Kerr-McGee Oil Industries and its board chairman, Senator Robert S. Kerr, Democrat of Oklahoma, today of "predatory politics" in uranium operations.

At the start of his swing around five European capitals, Secretary Rusk declared that, while the West was united on common goals and commitments, it was nevertheless entering upon a "new chapter," and that the question he would discuss with European statesmen was, "Where do we go from here?"

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the increase in the short interest position on the Big Board in the month ended on June 15 was the biggest for any month since it started keeping records in 1931.

A thirty-minute documentary describing Mrs. John F. Kennedy's recent visit to India has been selected as one of the official American entries in the short-subject competition of the Berlin Film Festival, which opens tomorrow.

TACOMA, Wash., June 20 (AP) A Government launch today carried Dave Beck, onetime labor chief, to the life of a Federal prison inmate for tax fraud. He was taken to McNeil Island Penitentiary in Puget Sound.
A radioactive hot spot on the floor of the Pacific Ocean may mark for centuries the United States' second failure to explode a hydrogen bomb at an altitude of about 200 miles.

More than 100 teachers in the city's public schools have requested applications for service in the Peace Corps since it was announced on Monday that the school system would grant leaves of absence to those who joined the corps.

WASHINGTON, June 20 A House committee charged today that several Army officers had deliberately violated seventeen Federal and military laws in building an airfield that the Pentagon had twice rejected.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) Gen. John L. De Witt, U.S.A., retired, who commanded the Western Defense Command early in World War II, died today of a heart attack. He was 82 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 20 A Government official told Senate investigators today that members of the Eisenhower Administration had spent $200,000,000 for unneeded lead and zinc.
THE question in the deal shown today is: Who should have bid hearts?
ATLANTA, Ga., June 20 A Federal court panel here dismissed a suit today seeking Congressional redistricting in Georgia.

ALL critics know that by giving someone a book they have reviewed they can count on receiving in return a livelier critique. Few other forms of bread cast upon the waters come back so crustily. Nothing like it, really, for widening horizons and general enrichment. Except, of course, what happens to authors.

LENINGRAD, June 20 (AP) Benny Goodman and his band were applauded wildly tonight by more than 5,000 Russians, most of them teen-agers, at the Winter Stadium Bandstand. The band was forced to do forty minutes of encores.
Price gains in a quiet bond market yesterday were confined to United States Government securities.
Stock prices sank yesterday in quiet trading. Although the volume was not large, the weakness in the market was pronounced.
CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) Except for some pressure in rye, grain futures drifted today and closed with small fractional changes on the Board of Trade.

Most of the tryouts for the 1964 United States Oympic team will be held in New York in the spring and summer of that year, it was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner and Robert Moses, the president of the 1964-65 New York World's Fair.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 20 (Reuters) The six European Common Market countries proposed today that the enlarged community sign comprehensive bilateral agreements with India, Pakistan and Ceylon before the end of 1966 to safeguard the trade of these countries.
Lewis B. Maytag Jr., the new president and controlling stockholder of National Airlines, Inc., declared himself out of the airlines merger movement yesterday.
TUNIS, June 20 Premier Benyoussef Ben Khedda returned to Tunis tonight to face the problem of maintaining the unity of his Algerian nationalist Provisional Government.
Three Federal agencies pursued separate inquiries yesterday into the mysterious affairs of a French citizen jailed here Tuesday after trying to leave the country with $247,400 in cash.
A 42-year-old Texan is ready to challenge a bid by the Georgia-Pacific Corporation to gain control of the Crossett Company, an Arkansas lumber and paper concern with valuable timber holdings.
Sam J. Slate, a vice president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, denied yesterday that "controversiality" was a factor in the C.B.S. decision to take the John Henry Faulk Show off the air in 1957.

CHEVY CHASE, Md., June 20 All Saints Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Christine Alexander Willcox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Augur Willcox, to George Henry Spencer Jr. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Spencer of Traskwood, Ark.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 20 Nina, old-fashioned as a bustle with her schooner rig, long bowsprit and heart-shaped transom, but kept forever young by deCoursey Fales, the 74-year-old New York banker who owns her, won Class A honors in the Newport-to-Bermuda yacht race today.

GENEVA, June 20 The International Commission of Jurists described the South African Government's sabotage bill today as the "culmination of a determined and ruthless attempt to enforce the doctrine of apartheid."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 20 Dean Francis Keppel of the Graduate School of Education at Harvard and Mrs. Keppel have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Tracy Keppel, to Samuel S. Drury Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Drury of Chestnut Hill.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 21--Joseph A. McBride of Arcola, last year's winner, lost in the first round of the sixty-first annual New Jersey state amateur golf championship today.

Phelps Dodge Corporation may cut its production 5 to 10 per cent in the second half of 1962 in an attempt to hold copper supply in close balance with demand, Robert G. Page, president, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 21 --The Government bought lead and zinc for four years without competitive bidding, the Senate subcommittee on stockpiling found today.

A plan to keep museums open until 10 o'clock every night "for the enjoyment of all New Yorkers and visitors" is being urged by the city. Most of the thirty-three private and city-supported museums in the five boroughs now close at 5 P. M.
Broadway showmen unofficially have agreed to union status for stage directors and choreographers, it was learned yesterday.
The $5,000,000 Lestoil Products, Inc., account is leaving Sackel-Jackson Company, the Boston agency that helped build Lestoil into a national brand.
WASHINGTON, June 21-- Rail freight loadings last week were smaller than a year ago for the third consecutive week. Truck volumes continued to show gains.
WASHINGTON, June 21-- The Public Health Service announced today that preliminary reports showed substantial declines in radioactive iodine levels in milk in the first half of June.
WASHINGTON, June 21-- Republicans and forty-eight dissident Democrats killed the Administration's farm bill tonight. The defeat was a major blow to President Kennedy's legislative program.
LONDON, June 21--Industrial shares continued to decline on the stock market today. The drop was sharper than yesterday's, but volume was again small.

WALNUT, Calif., June 21-- With perhaps the gretest field of athletes in the seventy-fouryear history of the event, the Amateur Athletic Union's na tional outdoor track and field championships will be staged tomorrow and Saturday in Mount San Antonio College's Memorial Stadium.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, June 21--Two games were finished and one adjourned in the Candidates' Chess Tournament tonight. Ewfim Geller and Paul Keres, both of the Soviet Union, drew an uneventful Catalan Opening in fifteen moves.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (AP)--Art Mahaffey hurled a five-hit shutout tonight in pitching the Philadelphia Phillies to a 3-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs. The loss snapped a five-game Chicago winning streak.
The Board of Estimate created three new high-level positions in the city administration yesterday and increased the salaries of several departmental aides.
What was happening in midJuly, 1958? Yesterday's decline in stock prices took The New York Times combined average down to 299.44 during the day, the lowest since July 18, 1958, when it was 297.78.

MUNICH, Germany, June 21 --Eidelstedter of Germany and Nochize of France, two of Europe's fastest trotters, were the co-favorites in today's sixtieth jubilee of the Grand Prix of Bavaria. Eidelstedter had won nine races in a row Nochize four.
Mrs. Alta Rockefeller Prentice, widow of E. Parmalee Prentice and last surviving child of John D. Rockefeller Sr., died early yesterday morning at the Midtown Hospital. She was 91 years old.
A Federal grand jury indicted David Charnay, chairman of Highway Trailer Industries, Inc., and two vice presidents on charges of perjury yesterday.

LONDON, June 21--A Government committee that was created to study the laws protecting investors in British stocks and securities recommended today that a number of changes be made in investment regulations.

Business loans at major New York City commercial banks, spurred by the June 15 tax payment deadline, rose during the week ended on Wednesday by $249,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
ATHENS, June 21--Prof. Stratis Andreadis, chairman of the Union of Greek Shipowners, called today for international cooperation to solve the world shipping crisis.
PRINK HILL. IT is one thing to read that the sun moved into the belt of Cancer yesterday afternoon and that summer has begun.

Plans for three new feature films were disclosed yesterday by Leopoldo Torre Nilsson, the Argentine director-producer, daring a local stop-over en route from the recent Cannes Film Festival to his home country.
A garden apartment development for 1,338 famlies in Astoria, Queens, has been purchased by the Realty Equities Corporation and leased back to the sellers.

Once upon a time (it really was yesterday, but who ever heard of a fairy tale beginning that way), a girl named Cinderella (her real name is Bernice Massi, but the press agents called her Cinderella) tried on a golden slipper.
The Curtis Publishing Company said yesterday that it had decided to move the editorial offices of the Saturday Evening Post from Philadelphia to New York.
THE chief interpreter of United States policy in Laos, Ambassador Winthrop Gilman Brown, is an austere, gentlemanly Maine Yankee who spent most of his adult life trying to avoid a diplomatic career.

Three major faith groups in this country will officially sponsor a National Conference on Religion and Race "to bring the joint moral force of the churches and synagogues to bear on the problem of racial segregation."

While the U.N. General Assembly is discussing the forthcoming Belgian evacuation of its old trusteeship, Ruanda-Urundi, word comes from Leopoldville that many Belgian civilians who fled after the Congo became independent are now returning. There were some 22,000 Belgians in Leopoldville before independence; the number fell to possibly 2,000, and now it may be back to 15,000.

CINCINNATI, June 21--A Protestant editor charged today that the American Medical Association. "has organized to silence or to confuse" expressions of church opinion on the issue of medical care for the aged through Social Security.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 21--Miss Sherrell Bingham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan Brewster Bingham of Riverdale, the Bronx, and James Edward Bland were married here this afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Franklin Bland of Chestnut Hill, Mass.
United States Government securities extended Wednesday's price gains in a moderately active trading session yesterday.
Bitter primary battles were in the making in every borough yesterday as insurgents and party regulars began circulating designating petitions for public and party offices.
PARIS, June 21--The United States asked Western Europe today for comments on how to tackle its problem of lagging economic growth combined with a deficit in the balance of international payments.

LAST night's presentation of "The Merchant of Venice" was an extraordinary television experience on every count--a full and uninterrupted evening of exciting theatre presented under circumstances that may mark the opening of a new and fruitful liaison between stage and TV.

Between diplomatic talks in Paris and Bonn, Secretary Rusk took time out to visit the front line of the East-West battle where not only words but bullets fly--the Berlin Wall. He brought new assurances of American solidarity with beleaguered West Berlin. The visit was also an eye-opener for the Secretary himself, for the wall must be seen to be believed.
KANSAS CITY, June 21 (AP) --Bo Belinsky, the Los Angeles rookie, hurled the Angels into second place in the American League tonight, beating they Kansas City Athletics, 3--1, with a seven-hitter.
EVERY means save carrier pigeon seem to have been employed by city shoppers and merchants to get merchandise to its destination during the thirty-nine-day-old United Parcel Service strike.
THE metropolitan district of New York will be well represented in the New Jersey Bridge League's sectional tournament at Asbury Park, N.J., which will begin today and continue through Sunday.
Organized labor withdrew last night from an advisory board serving a committee that oversees wages and working conditions in the city's voluntary hospitals.

Edward M. Gilbert, former president of the E.L. Bruce Company, will decide soon whether to return to the United States to face claims arising from his unauthorized withdrawals of $1,953,000 from the hardwood flooring concern.
A group of angry Brooklyn parents ignored the refusal of a Board of Education official to see them yesterday and marched into his office to demand adequate facilities for their children.
MOSCOW, June 21--A team of Italian musicologists have found the "lost" scores of sixtytwo Italian operas after a twoweek search in the libraries of Leningrad.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 21 --William H. Sneath, a retired executive of the Union Carbide Corporation, died yesterday after a brief illness in his home here at 3 Oak Lane. He was 83 years old.
YONKERS, June 21--Stephan Smith, prominently placed at all times, won the thirteenth edition of the $65,300 Good Time Pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

WASHINGTON, June 21-- Two Republican Senators accused Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman today of sanctioning an attempt to dig up information about them in a move to thwart the Senate investigation of the Billie Sol Estes case.
Al Jackson, the only Met who has pitched a shutout, will oppose the Houston Colts in the first game of a double-header at the Polo Grounds tonight.
Stocks fell sharply yesterday in active trading. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange, as measured by the averages, sank to new lows for the year and the lowest level since July, 1958.

WASHINGTON, June 21--This week the Supreme Court suspended not only its extreme concept of the "equal rights" guarantee of the Constitution, but also its role of keeper of the moral conscience of the nation--a function neither implied nor specified in the judicialpowers grant of Article III.

WASHINGTON, June 21-- President Kennedy paid tribute in person today to a group of Michigan students who almost missed their senior trip to Washington because they chose to help a classmate stricken by cancer.
Discussions are being held with the Soviet Union to have Russian television participate in the first live trans-Atlantic telecast to this country.
WASHINGTON, June 21-- Two busloads of southern New Jersey labor leaders arrived today to discuss unemployment problems in their area with officials of the Labor and Defense Departments.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 21 (AP)-- Maj. Robert M. White piloted the X-15 rocket plane to a record of 250,000 feet--47.3 miles --today to achieve the research craft's designed maximum height.

SECAUCUS, N.J., June 21-- An explosion this morning aboard a ninety-foot sailing yacht injured four of the nine persons aboard. Seventeen trains were delayed when the burning hulk drifted against a Pennsylvania Railroad bridge.
WASHINGTON, June 21--A document that few persons here have read is fast becoming the subject of a resounding political argument.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 21--State Tax Commissioner Joseph H. Murphy disclosed today that he had ordered a study of the state pari-mutuel taxes to determine what inequities, if any, existed.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 21--The bodies of two teen-aged girls who had been badly beaten were found this afternoon in a densely wooded area about a mile from this northern New Jersey town.
Two declared candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor took opposite stands yesterday on the issue of Federal aid to private and parochial schools.

The Ampex Corporation in the fiscal year ended April 30 had net earnings of $3,203,000 after taxes and special items applicable to prior years, William E. Roberts, president of the California electronics producer, reported yesterday. In the preceding fiscal year the company showed a net loss of $3,930,000.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)--A spokesman for the United States sugar growers strongly endorsed the domestic provisions of the House-passed sugar bill today but avoided the controversial foreign sections.

Universal Controls, Inc., and the Glen Alden Corporation are planning to merge. Directors of the companies approved in principle yesterday the terms of the proposed consolidation, subject to shareholders approval.

VIENTIANE, Laos, June 21 --Gen. Phoumi Nosavan, the Laotian Rightist, announced tonight that the National Congress would be convened tomorrow to empower King Savang Vatthana to put the new coalition government in office by royal decree.

AN abundance of beef cuts for charcoal-broiling continues... to be available at reasonable prices. With beef roasts, these currently constitute the best buys in meat. Lamb remains unusually high in cost, but pork is a good buy.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP)-- Speculative dealings comprised most of the activity today on the Board of Trade but they apparently lacked any urgency and prices held generally within a small fraction range.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy and Kings County District Attorney Edward S. Silver ordered separate investigations yesterday into the death Tuesday night of 11-year-old Dennis McKenna, who had been injured when hit by an automobile earlier in the day.

The problem of what kind of a job a retired military or naval officer can hold without forfeiting his retired pay is one which directly affects the welfare of many officers and, more important, of the country. As things stand now, the conflict-of-interest statutes and directives are discriminatory and muddled--a hodge-podge of outdated and special legislation, of inadequate Congressional attention and of unwise Executive action.
TOLEDO, June 21 (AP)-- Turkey, which had made a poor showing in the 1961 world championships after dominating amateur wrestling for years, moved into the lead today as the 1962 championships opened.

Colleges and universities have only one more year of grace before the influx of "war babies" turns the stream of applicants into a flood tide. The danger is that, because the number of candidates has remained relatively steady this year and can be expected to stay at that level in 1963, the academic planners may lack a sense of urgency.
WASHINGTON, June 21--A threatened strike on Trans World Airlines was averted today by an agreement between the airline and the Flight Engineers International Association.

Ground was broken yesterday for the $3,500,000 exhibition building that the Bell Telephone System will have at the 1964-65 New York World's Fair. The building will be in the form of a 400foot-long wing, and will be supported at four points. Visitors will be seated in moving chairs and will ride through a series of theatres in which the story of communications will be dramatized.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 21--United Nations officials here said today that they feared the talks between Premier Cyrille Adoula of the Congo and President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province might have broken down completely.

LENINGRAD, June 21--Several hundred aroused young Leningraders called Benny Goodman and his band back to the stage for a twenty-minute jam session tonight in what promised to be one of the most successful stands of his Soviet tour.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI)--A former branch manager of the American Guild of Variety Artists testified today that the union's executive secretary took him up on his offer when he said "I would pay $2,000" to bet a job in Florida.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York made two announcements yesterday that raised eyebrows all along Wall Street --and perhaps in financial citadels overseas as well.

AUSTIN, Texas, June 21 (UPI)--Attorney General Will Wilson of Texas filed suits today totaling $2,800,000 against a county judge and five other east Texans in the state's spreading scandal over slanthole oil drilling.

NEW JERSEY has a spanking new lake for its an glers. It's called Lake Linvale and extends for eleven acres on the headwaters of Stony Brook in Southern Hunterdom County, a few miles north of Hopewell.
The "Look-Ma-no-hands!" method of processing census data has put the Government in the position of reporting that there are more British people in Westchester County than there are people.

WASHINGTON, June 21--The Federal Trade Commission today ordered a manufacturer and a retailer to stop quoting "suggested list prices" that are, in fact, higher than the prices usually charged for the goods in question.
ALGIERS, June 21--A spokesman for the Secret Army Organization announced tonight that terrorist commandos had been ordered to fire on any French security forces that continued to arrest its members.
The long-discussed "moon illusion" was reported today to be an effect of landscape distance perception.
Small daily doses of a female hormone mixture seem to protect heart attack patients from strokes, according to a study that has been in progress for five years.
WARSAW, June 21--Hundreds of thousand of Roman Catholic faithful followed the Blessed Sacrament through the streets of Polish cities today in traditional Corpus Christi processions.
WASHINGTON, June 21-- Government officials expressed increasing concern today over shortages of operating funds as the SenateHouse deadlock over appropriations bills persisted.
PARIS, June 21--The French Government gave its blessing today to the agreements reached between Moslems and Europeans to halt disorder in Algeria.

Met with students from Glen Lake High School, Glen Arbor, Mich.; Saw Murray Gross, American Veterans Committee national chairman, and others; selected William M. Rountree as United States Ambassador to the Republic of Sudan; signed proclamation anal notification of July 1, 1962, as effective date of various interim trade agreements negotiated at the tariff conference of 1960-61.

AFTER having been rained out two nights in a row in... Central Park, the New York Shakespeare Festival finally opened its season last evening with a stylish, opulent and beautifully acted production of "The Merchant of Venice."
NEW DELHI, June 21--Four agreements were signed here today providing United States loans to India totaling $285,200,000.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 21-- The Nassau County Board of Supervisors was directed today to appear in State Supreme Court here next Friday in a special legal proceeding designed to provide a salary for the Commissioner of Accounts.
An unauthorized walkout of 800 Brooklyn longshoremen in a jurisdictional dispute interrupted cargo operations on six piers and six freighters yesterday.
A request for an early trial of the suit to invalidate New York's legislative representation system was filed yesterday in the Federal District Court for the Southern District.
Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $77,000,000 to $124,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

CHANGES come slowly but surely to bridal fashions. In the last eight years, without anyone paying much attention, the bridal gown has gone from fuss and furbelows to the simple, elegant silhouette of a Balenciaga ball gown.

FORT LEE, N.J., June 21-- This borough has lived up to its agreements with the Sealantic Fund, Inc., to limit the height of buildings on eightyone lots Fort Lee acquired from the find in 1956, the Mayor and Council declared in a special meeting last night.

PARIS, June 21--The police disclosed today that Antoine Rinieri, arrested last Tuesday in New York with $247,000 in his luggage, was known to them as an "extremely able adventurer," twice questioned but never convicted.

ATHENS, June 21--The inadequate tools the actor brings to a craft that requires increasing skills was the subject o lively discussion today at an international conference here on the theatre and its mass audience.

CHICAGO, June 21--A Representative of the American Symphony Orchestra League said to day that there were indications of a "tremendous" shift in community sentiment toward approval of Federal subsidy for the arts.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 21--Nifia and her owner, de Coursey Fates of New York, were the toast of Hamilton when all 131 yachts that had participated in the ocean race from Newport were snugged down safely today.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 21--Furniture and Grand Rapids have long been synonymous in the American mind. At is one time this pleasant, rather sleepy city was the capital of the furniture industry. Times change and today the industry is spread all over the United States.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 21--The United States gave ground under Indian pressure today and obtained a twenty-four-hour recess in the Security Council's debate on Kashmir.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 21 --They came, "some in rags, some in tags" but not "in velvet gown" as did the beggars in the old English nursery rhyme, "Hark, hark, the dogs do bark; the beggars are coming to town."
Distress conveyances of Manhattan properties increased in number, but decreased in the average value of the liens in the first quarter of 1962 compared with the corresponding period last year.
STRATFORD, Ont., June 21 --"The Tempest," one of Shakespeare's most beautitally poetic plays, has been given a most regal and enticing production on the Stratford Festival stage.
WASHINGTON, June 21--President Kennedy has called for a "sober, dispassionate and careful discussion" of national economic poilcy, but it is not taking place.
Contractors who give presents to school employes were denounced last night as seducers and corruptors by a member of the Board of Education.

LONDON, June 21--Chuck McKinley, the only American seeded at Wimbledon, was the only American to reach the semi finals of the London grass court tennis championships today. The rubbery little Missouri slugger defeated Neale Fraser of Australia a former Wimbledon champion, 6--2, 7--5.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)--Matthew H. McCloskey, the Democratic fund-raiser nominated to be Ambassador to Ireland, said today he had been told some Republicans would be glad to get him out of the country.

The United States Court of Appeals yesterday ordered the issuance of a permanent injunction restraining the sale of stock of Taylorcraft, Inc., maker of light planes, by Herbert Rapp, a broker doing business under the name of the Webster Securities Company of New York.
New York City will purchase prepaid voluntary insurance for medical care for 15,000 welfare recipients.
WASHINGTON, June 21-- The Government announced today that it would begin a nation-wide campaign to seize what it termed a worthless diagnostic machine used by many health practitioners.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 21-- Agreement as a basis of a set tlement to avert resumption of the Pacific maritime strike was announced here tonight.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 21--The trial of an Orthodox rabbi and three of his adherents on charges of kidnapping a child ended abruptly today after the star prosecution witness confessed that he had lied in court.

The engagement of Miss Carlys Reeve Bowden to John Saltonstall Belmont has been announced by the future bride's parents, Laurens Reeve Bowden of New York and Mrs. Logan Morrill of Annapolis, Md. Mr. Belmont is the son of August Belmont of Syosset, L.I., and Mrs. R. Lockwood Tower of Santa Barbara, Calif.

WASHINGTON, June 21-- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed charges today of discriminatory labor practices against a major oil company, that had signed a White House pledge against unfairness in employment.
The city moved yesterday to prepare tree-shaded vistas along its parkways and main thoroughfares for visitors to the World's Fair in 1964-65.
BOSTON, June 21 (AP)-- The Dead Sea Scrolls were the subject of a tax decision by the United States Court of Appeals today.
BERLIN, June 21--Secretary of State Dean Rusk got his first look today at the wall built through Berlin by the Communists and predicted it would be broken down eventually.
PARIS, June 21--The Government, stirred by a threeweek hunger strike of a 74year-old French anarchist and pacifist, has made a historic decision in favor of conscientious objectors.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) --A suit for an injunction to halt all atmospheric tests of nuclear weapons was filed today in United States District Court here. Sponsors said a similar action was entered simultaneously in Moscow.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 21-- Efforts of the Kennedy Administration to provide medical care for the aged within the framework of the Social Security system were endorsed here today in a pronouncement adopted by the central Conference of American Rabbis.
RABAT, Morocco, June 21-- Morocco closed today the United Hias Service in Casablanca. The Jewish organization was charged with having encouraged massive departures of Moroccan Jews to Israel.
Two physicians gave conflicting testimony yesterday on Laurence A. Johnson's physical ability to testify in the suit brought by John Henry Faulk.
Mayor Wagner ordered a change in the West Side urban renewal plan yesterday to add more middle-income and lowrent public housing units.
OTTAWA, June 21--The Canadian Government acted today to attempt to halt the run on the Canadian dollar with a record raise of almost 1 per cent in the short-term interest rate.
WASHINGTON, June 21-- The refurbished White House library, a cozy nineteenth century room, was officially opened today by Mrs. John F. Kennedy.

The Bird and Bottle Inn. Albany Post Road, U.S. 9, Garrison, N.Y. Garrison 4-3342. About one and one-half hours' drive from the city, this restored eighteenth-century tavern offers leisurely dining and friendly service in an old colonial atmossphere. Cocktails are served on the terrace overlooking a stream or in a diminutive bar. Hearty. American food predominates.

A pro-Castro meeting here that caused a riot Wednesday night had been the target of Spanish newspaper and radio criticism for a month previous, the police reported yesterday. In the violent battle outside the West Side hall where the meeting was held, at least six persons were injured.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) --The State Department announced today that the United States and India had signed and agreement for reciprocal tariff concessions.
BALTIMORE, June 21-- Whitey Ford, long the bellwether of the Yankee pitchingstaff, returned today to his familiar role.

The Central Presbyterian Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Elizabeth Colgate Cowles, daughter of Mrs. Duncan Van Norden of New York and the late Francis Russell Cowles, to Morgan Hovey Harris Jr. He is the son of Captain Harris, U.S.N., and Mrs. Harris of Key West, Fla., and Boston.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 21--The Belgian Foreign Minister, Paul-Henri Spaak, accused the Soviet bloc today of trying to create disorder in the Belgium's African trust territory of RuandaUrundi, which is to become independent as two countries July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)--The Federal Aviation Agency reported today that two airliners were mistakenly permitted to fly at the same altitude in the New York area the night of June 12 with "less than minimum radar separation."
CLEVELAND, June 21 (AP) --Earl Wilson and Dick Radatz held the Cleveland Indians to three hits today in pitching the Boston Red Sox to a 3-1 victory.
Ken Strong was signed yesterday as a special kicking coach by the New York Giants, the Eastern Conference champions of the National Football League.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 21-- Prof. Harold Zink, a political scientist and faculty member of Ohio State University, died Tuesday of a heart ailment in University Hospital. He was 61 years old.

EL PASO, Tex., June 21 (UPI)--A Federal grand jury, helped by a Justice Department official from Washington, handed up a new indictment of twenty-nine counts today against, Billie Sol Estes, former Texas fertilizer and grain storage leader.

The speed with which the Federal courts are acting to correct unfairness in legislative apportionment ought to be a warning to Governor Rockefeller that he may not have much more chance to delay in changing the archaic representation system within this state.

The eleventh annual Capezio Dance Award of $1,000 was presented yesterday to Barbara Karinska, designer and maker of theatre costumes. The presentation was made at a reception attended by members of the dance world.
Three American missionaries kidnapped by Communist guerrillas in South Vietnam have been seen alive and well but are still captives, the Christian and Missionary Alliance said here yesterday.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 21-- Clashes along the frontier are again threatening relations between South Vietnam and Cambodia.
The city's Buildings Department announced a plan yesterday to inspect systematically the cellars, fire escapes, public halls and roofs of the 35,000 multiple dwellings in Manhattan.

THE sixth annual Festival Casals in San Juan, P.R., ended on Wednesday night. Yesterday morning the participants packed bag and baggage--and instruments--and flew to New York, turning up in Carnegie Hall last night for the first of two programs. It was the organization's first appearance outside of Puerto Rico. To New Yorkers it was a welcome and exciting musical event in month when they are rare.

The MacSweetie Stable's Lady Pampa came on in the last sixteenth to beat the Meadow Stable's Baroda by a nose in the Idlewild Lions Club Purse, worth $10,000, at Belmont Park yesterday. Willie Boland rode the victor and Bom Ussery was in the stirrups on Baroda.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI)--The American Civil Liberties Union told Congressmen today that passage of the Administration's bill to legalize wiretapping might some day result in their own phones being "bugged."
Dr. Samuel L. Sar, Dean of Men at Yeshiva University, died of a heart attack yesterday in the Harry Fischel Synagogue of the University, Amsterdam Avenue and 186th Street. He was 69 years old.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 21--Pablo Picasso, Georges Braque, Jean Dubuffet., Marc Chagall, Jacques Villon and Bernard Buffet will be invited to come here and exhibit their masterpieces next year when New Rochelle celebrates the 275th anniversary of its founding by French Huguenots.
Cottonseed futures gained in active trading and losses in copper, cocoa and potatoes declined yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges.
CHICAGO, June 21 (UPI)-- A four-run surge in the first inning and two-hit relief pitching by Ed Fisher carried the Chicago White Sox tonight to a 6-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

Earnings of the Transcontinental Investing Corporation for the fiscal year ending next February are expected to "exceed last year's impressive record," Robert K. Lifton, president, told shareholders yesterday at the annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel here.
BERLIN, June 21--Like everyone else these days, the State Department has been trying to figure out who's on first in West German politics.
The Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America will move next week to "bring the ecumenical movement into every parish."
Cotton futures were 75 cents a bale down to 65 cents up on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) A group of Colorado editors and publishers had lunch with Presiident Kennedy at the White House today. They reported that he described himself as a friend, not an enemy, of business.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 22 Premier Cyrille Adoula publicly offered at least one ministerial post in his Government today to the Conakat party of President Moise Tshombe of Katanga.
BONN, Germany, June 22 Chancellor Adenauer and Secretary of State Dean Rusk conferred for seventy minutes today and reached "agreement on all major issues."
CHICAGO, June 22 (UPI) The American Cancer Society decided today to urge college presidents and the Federal Trade Commission to help curb the promotion of smoking among college students.
CHICAGO, June 22 The nation's railroads broke off negotiations with the five operating rail brotherhoods today, charging the unions with delaying tactics.
WORCESTER, Mass., June 22 (AP) William F. Hebert, West ern editor and manager of Boxoffice, national weekly of the film trade, died early today at City Hospital. He was 56 years old.
A massive, 420-foot-long barge with a carrying capacity one and one half times that of a Liberty ship is scheduled to be launched today at Avondale Shipyards in New Orleans.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 22 (AP) Ministers of the seven European Free Trade Area countries, known as the Outer Seven, today wound up a two-day session in Copenhagen with an agreement to reduce tariffs by 10 per cent within the coming ten" months years ahead of schedule.

When the Mets are good they are a delightful surprise, but when they are bad they are horrid. Both of the team's schizophrenic faces were on display as it split a twilight night double-header with the Houston Colt 45's at the Polo Grounds last night before 11,484 spectators.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 22 Premier Khrushchev declared tonight that the Soviet Union was adamantly opposed to war as a solution to international problems. But he said the Kremlin still believed in the "class war" to promote communism.
The State Department has appointed a resident protocol officer to New York to help the city in its obligations to the increasing number of foreign dignitaries coming here on official visits.
DETROIT, June 22 Mickey Mantle made his first appearance in the Yankee starting line-up in more than a month tonight before a crowd of 43,723.
WASHINGTON, June 22 Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address tonight at a $100-a-plate dinner sponsored by the Republican Campaign Committees of the Senate and House of Repretatives:
LONDON, June 22--Industrial share prices fell sharply on the stock market today, sending The Financial Times index to its lowest level in nearly three years.
Hundreds of organized workers in the city are expected to defy a State Supreme Court injunction today and picket BethEl Hospital, Brooklyn, in support of striking nonprofessional workers.
NEWTON, Conn., June 22 J. Townsend Russell, archaeologist and research writer, died at his summer home here yesterday. He was 69 years old and lived at 2 East Seventieth Street in New York City.

HOW did the American national character become what it is today? That question provides a generously recep tive public with dozens of new books every year. One element rather heavily discussed, as you know, is the enduring spirit of Puritanism. Another is the frontier tradition. Still another is the melting-pot syndrome which can be applied to all nations, though students of Americana sometimes seem to have taken out a patent on it.
VIENTIANE, Laos, June 22 Prince Souvanna Phouma announced tonight that a settlement had been reached with the Rightists and that a coalition government would take office in Laos tomorrow.
CHICAGO, June 22 A Pulitzer Prize-winning composer offered a formula today for lifting opera's estate in the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 22 in June, 1957, Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts was a guest of honor at a reception in Atlanta. One of the pleasant things he heard came from his host, Robert Battey Troutman Jr., a rising local lawyer.
PARIS, June 22 In a move of major importance to many nations of Latin America, the European Common Market has reached a tentative decision to reduce its tariff on coffee by two-fifths.
Paul Speckenbach, a fast-ball pitcher from St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn, signed a bonus contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday for a sum estimated at $100,000.
MEDFORD, Mass., June 22 (AP) John Holmes, poet, author and Professor of English at Tufts University, died today. He was 58 years old.

STANTON, Del., June 22 (AP) Crimson Satan, Greek Money, Cyane and Noble Jay, the leading 3-year-old colts still competing in the East, were entered today for the $42,500 Leonard Richards Stakes at Delaware Park tomorrow.

Owners of summer homes and vacation cottages are urged to equip their dwellings to protect them from the hazards of fire. Fire safety officials point out that many vacations end in tragedy that might have been avoided with proper safeguards.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, contended today that many LatinAmerican countries would be given a vested interest in keeping Fidel Castro in power in Cuba if the sugar bill passed by the House of Representatives becomes law.
The Dana Corporation and its subsidiaries, in the nine months ended May 31, 1962, earned more than in its full fiscal year ended Aug. 31, 1961, according to the results announced yesterday.
MOSCOW, June 22 The Soviet press published today three typical news items that portrayed the nature of one of the most serious social problems
WASHINGTON, June 22 Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower came back to the White House today and saw for herself that her successor, like women down through the ages, had been moving thigs around.
The Puerto Rican community continued yesterday to oppose the city's West Side urban renewal plan even though Mayor Wagner on Thursday ordered more low-rent public housing for the project area.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois said today that Agriculture Department research into the correspondence of two Republicans on the Senate committee investigating the Billie Sol Estes case "smacks a little of a Gestapo technique."
WICHITA, Kan., June 22 The last B-52 strategic bomber on order for the Air Force rolled from the final assembly area of the Boeing Company's production line here today.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 22 Suzy Wong, a forty-foot yawl belonging to William F. Buckley Jr. of New York, was withdrawn as a finisher in the Newport-to-Bermuda yacht race by the owner today because one of her crew broke radio silence during the 635-mile event completed yesterday.

BEFORE summer's lazy mood catches hold, there is still time to complete shopping for leisure-time activities. Macy's has comfortable and colorful plaid hammocks that are practical (mildew resistant and water repellent) in red, green and white. They are $6.59 each in the basement garden depart
WASHINGTON, June 22 President Kennedy urged industry today to speed up equality of job opportunities for Negroes. The best way, he said, is "to make it happen."
Five Kings County judges who have been handling criminal cases exclusively will be transferred to the new Supreme Court in the Brooklyn Civic Center on Sept. 1.

LE MANS, France, June 23 (UPI) The annual twentyfour-hour Le Mans endurance race, Europe's biggest and most dangerous auto event, will begin at 11 A.M. New York time tomorrow. Eighteen American drivers are taking part.
MOSCOW, June 22 The Soviet Union told its people today that the United States was preparing for nuclear war under leaders who surpassed Hitler in savageness, shamelessness and hypocrisy.
