WASHINGTON, June 22 The Administration rushed a compromise extension of emergency farm legislation to the House of Representatives today to fill the gap left by the defeat of its farm bill.

BOSTON, June 22 Speaker John W. McCormack has been asked to keep hands off the Massachusetts Democratic Senatorial fight. The request came from his nephew, State Attorney General Edward J. McCormack Jr., in a letter made public today.
The Federal Aviation Agency said in Washington yesterday that it had no plans to ground all Boeing 707 jets as a result of the crash in Guadeloupe.

A suit seeking to block the distribution next month of 23,000,000 shares of General Motors Corporation common stock by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., was filed here yesterday in Federal Court by two du Pont stockholders.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 22 A Soviet veto defeated a move in the Security Council today to bring India and Pakistan together for negotiations on their fourteen-year-old territorial dispute over Kashmir.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 22 The Federal Government was asked today by the Central Conference of American Rabbis to explore the possibilities of sending surplus food to the mainland of Communist China.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 22 The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Advent was the setting this afternoon for the wedding of Miss Dorothy Bradley Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alastair Bradley Martin of Glen Head, to William Henry Moore 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Moore of New York and Old Lyme, Conn.

Cocoa and cottonseed oil declined yesterday as traders anticipated the arrival of first notices for the July contracts in the coming week. Trading was almost at a standstill on other commodity markets here.
ALGIERS, June 22 The Secret Army Organization in Oran announced tonight the breakdown of negotiations for a truce there and resumed its "freedom of action" terrorism.

THE New Jersey Bridge League tournament at Asbury Park this week-end continues today with a twoseason open pair contest at 2 P.M. and 8 P.M., and it was erroneously stated here yesterday that play would be at the Convention Hall there. The tournament is being played at the Empress Motel.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 22 (UPI) A Federal court found today that Tennessee's new legislative reapportionment laws, enacted to prevent Federal intervention, were still unfair to city voters. But the court said it would give the legislature a chance to correct the laws in 1963.
CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., June 22 (UPI) The new Finger Lakes race track erased three more dates from its 100-day racing calendar last night after trainers failed to meet daily entry deadlines.
LONDON, June 22 A tactical-command problem has developed to complicate further the recent United States offer to assign six Polaris-missile submarines to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
A demonstration home containing many new materials and appointments intended for use in homes has been opened by a New Jersey building concern.
CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) The House defeat of the Administration's farm bill prompted a burst of selling today in the grain futures and nearly all contracts slumped sharply on the Board of Trade.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 22 Three former champions and a 24-year-old newcomer reached the semi-finals today in the sixty-first annual New Jersey amateur golf champion ship.

THE occasion last night in Carnegie Hall was one of rare sentiment and nostalgia. Pablo Casals, engaged in his "personal crusade for peace," conducted the first New York performance of his oratorio "El Pesebre" ("The Manger") before a crowded audience that had obviously come just as much to pay tribute to the musician as to hear his music.

The graduation exercises of Public School 401 yesterday marked the last official school ceremony for Mrs. Mary F. King, its principal for the last twenty years. Her "school" consists of twenty-eight classes in hospitals in Manhattan and Welfare Island.
LOS ANGELES, June 22 Reese H. Taylor, president of the Union Oil Company of California, died today in Good Samaritan Hospital at the age of 61.
American Export Lines' new round-the-world division was blacklisted by the International Longshoremen's Association yesterday.

Bonds of many railroad systems sold at new low prices for the year yesterday in a wave of selling on the New York Stock Exchange. Transactions in such securities accounted for more than $1,000,000 of the $9,790,000 bond business on the Big Board yesterday.
Consumers in the metropolitan area are tightening their purse strings as a result of the precipitous stock market decline, a spot check by The New York Times showed yesterday.
MANILA, June 22 President Diosdado Macapagal claimed Philippine sovereignty over British North Borneo today and announced that his Government wanted to negotiate to acquire the territory.
ACCRA, Ghana, June 22 Stephen D. James, an advertising copywriter from the Bronx, introduced today his peace hostage exchange program before the Accra Assembly on Disarmament.
PARIS, June 22 The European Common Market is moving gradually toward a common energy policy whose chief emphasis is on non-Soviet oil.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 22 A two-foot tire iron appeared today to be the principal clue in the investigation of the slaying of two Morris Plains teen-aged girls.
WASHINGTON, June 22 Former President Eisenhower said tonight that the Kennedy Administration was "floundering" while "confidence at home and abroad weakens."

WASHINGTON, June 22 A week-end boating enthusiast, who is a father of four boys, has invented a safety device for youngsters who fall overboard. It is an automatic radio transmitter designed to inflate the child's life jacket.
After nine weeks of testimony, both sides rested yesterday in the trial of the libel suit brought by John Henry Faulk.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 22 Divorcing of the state's twenty-three community colleges from political controls was asked today by petitions of some educators and civic leaders in Dutchess County.
CARACAS, Venezuela, June 20 Guerrilla activity in Venezuela by Communists and "extremists" is now "completely under control," according to the Defense Ministry.

WALNUT, Calif., June 22 Bob Hayes of Florida A. and M. sped to the Amateur Athletic Union's 100-yard dash title tonight in 9.3 seconds as Frank Budd, Villanova's ace, broke down after leading at the halfway mark.
The word atom comes from a Greek root meaning indivisible. The Greeks were mistaken, as we now know. Thus, the future of the world is infinitely more uncertain than it used to be.
Revlon, Inc., a leading cosmetics manufacturer, was accused yesterday of having fixed artificially high wholesale and retail prices for its products.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 22 Mayor Wagner's appointment of a nonpartisan committee to evaluate potential candidates for appointment to the bench won the praise today of a former Republican judge.

SUSAN GREENBURG WOOD's view of life through ground glass has won her a respected niche in a man's world. Her photographs, in which she tries "through a gesture or an appearance to gain insight into a personality or a mood," are published regularly in national magazines. She is one of the few women who have succeeded as photo journalists.

ZUCCHINI, the slender green squash with lengthwise streaks of gray or lighter green, is one of the most versatile summer arrivals at vegetable stands. The squash, actually a European marrow first cultivated in Italy, can be baked, sauteed, boiled or steamed. If it is cooked in water, the liquid should be used sparingly because zucchini is full of juice.
A wrought iron producer, industrial cousin to the nation's ingot iron and steel makers, is planning a price increase because of rising costs.
CLEVELAND, June 22 (AP) The Ford Motor Company and the United Auto Workers Union reached agreement tonight to settle a strike at the Walton Hills stamping plant.
The National Mediation Board acted last night to avert a strike by the flight engineers' union against Pan American World Airways and Eastern Airlines.
KATMANDU, Nepal, June 22 The three Americans and a Swiss in an expedition feared lost in the Himalayas have been found safe, the Nepalese Foreign Ministry announced today.
The Internal Revenue Service disclosed yesterday that it had filed tax liens against Edward M. Gilbert, former president of E.L. Bruce Company, for $3,341,742.

WHITEFIELD, N.H., June 22 (UPI) An Interstate Commerce Commissioner, Clyde E. Herring, said today the I.C.C. would consider carefully the transportation interests of New England when it ruled on the proposed Eastern railroad mergers.
LONDON, June 22 Chuck McKinley was soundly spanked today by Rod Laver of Australia in a carbon copy of the Wimbledon final of a year ago.

Maximum public support for traffic safety is sorely needed in this city to counter the alarming rise in accidents, up nearly 15 per cent from last year. With schools about to close, hundreds of thousands of youngsters will be on the streets longer and in greater numbers. If the toll is to be cut below the 1,000 killed or maimed last summer in the under-15-year age group, motorists must use extra and extreme caution.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) A sculptured likeness of President Kennedy as a winged angel, for which he posed twenty-three years ago is part of an altar panel in the Vatican, The Washington Post and Times-Herald related today.
PARIS, June 22 Following is the text of Raoul Salan's letter calling for the end of the violence in Algeria:
WASHINGTON, June 22 The Senate Appropriations Committee moved today to break the long deadlock over money bills in Congress.
Life in an apartment house with fewer-than-average suites, according to a local builder, offers advantages of which many apartment-seekers are not aware.

A recent and sudden order of the Secretary of the Navy supports a proposal made by Vice Admiral H.G. Rickover for the establishment of "a civilian educator of national rank" as "Dean of Academics" at Annapolis. It requires the ultimate substitution of civilian for officer instructors in all academic departments except the naval science division.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP) Stan Musial set a major league record for career total bases tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 7 3, in the first game of a twilight-night double-header. The Phils won the second game, 11 3.
Using tree-ring intervals as a code, scientists have established an 804-year chronology of climate change for the pre Christian era in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) Senator Francis Case, Republican of South Dakota, a member of Congress since 1936, died today in Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., of a heart attack after he was stricken yesterday in his Capitol Hill office. He wad 65 years old.
The Duncan Parking Meter Maintenance Company notified the city yesterday that it would "cease performance" when its contract expired next Saturday.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Winslow Rosenberry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Landfair Rosenberry of 155 East Seventy-second Street, to Roger Overton Hoit took place here yesterday afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic William Hoit of 181 East Seventy-third Street and Chatham, Mass.

A Maritime Administration examiner ended hearings yesterday in a case in which the American President Lines was accused of seeking a "hunting license" for lucrative cargoes in Far Eastern ports on the routes of other lines.
WASHINGON, June 22 (AP) President Kennedy told 292 students who are going to Africa to work this summer that they could demonstrate their country's concern for newly independent nations.

Cicada, with more than half a million dollars in earnings to her credit, will be the odds-on favorite to fatten her bankroll in great degree today when she runs in the Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park.
A convoy of twenty-seven armored cars shuttled through the Wall Street district early today carrying a cargo of more than $24,000,000,000 in securities.
Salary increases totalling about $7,700,000 art scheduled for supervisors and non-teaching professional personnel in the city school system for 1962-63.

LONGVIEW, Tex., June 22 (UPI) Four East Texas independent oil operators and a company they own appealed today to Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy to see if eight major oil companies had violated Federal antitrust laws. The operators sued the big companies in a $10,000,000 crossaction.
Mayor Wagner and his family will leave New York by air next Wednesday for a monthlong vacation tour of several European countries.
One of the major functions of real estate managing agents is protection protecting tenants from injuries and protecting themselves and the building owners from subsequent lawsuits.

WARSAW. "We are the Mafia in the Communist movement." With these words a flashingeyed Pole summed up the role being played by intellectuals and all manner of artists in the drive to win and hold a measure of freedom in Poland.
Lortogs, Inc., manufacturer of children's sportswear, has acquired the assets and business of two companies Regal Novelty Company, Inc., and La Regale, Ltd.
WASHINGTON, June 22 The Senate's decision on whether Irving Ben Cooper should be a Federal judge moved one small, hesitant step nearer today.

PARIS, June 22 Raoul Salan, serving a life sentence for leading the Secret Army Organization in Algeria, called today for an end to the terrorism there and urged his former followers to join in building a new "brotherly Algeria."

A subcommittee of the United Nations Committee of Seventeen on colonialism reported a few weeks ago that conditions in Southern Rhodesia were "grave and potentially explosive." The British position then and since has amounted to saying that in the first place this is not so and that in the second place, even if it were, the interference of the United Nations is largely to blame.

YONKERS, June 22 Ten of the twelve pacers in last night's $65,300 Good Time at Yonkers Raceway are scheduled to start in next Thursday night's $75,000 National Championship Pace. Acceptances for all were received today by Ted Gibbons, the racing secretary at the Westchester course.
An Air France jetliner trying to land in a storm at Guadeloupe, in the West Indies, crashed into a hillside near the airport early yesterday. All 112 persons aboard the Boeing 707 were killed.
Prices of stocks fell again yesterday in heavy trading. On average, prices on the New York Stock Exchange dropped to the lowest level since July, 1958.
HERSHEY, Pa., June 22 (AP) Senator Barry Goldwater, said tonight that President Kennedy should replace some of his advisers with "hardheaded businessmen" to spur a revival in the economy.

The muses won by a narrow margin over the elements in Central Park last night, as the Goldman Band made a second, and successful, try at beginning its forty-fifth season of concerts on the Mall. The program was the same as that scheduled for last, wet, Wednesday.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 22 The trustees of the Bergen Community Museum are prepared to fight what they regard as an attempt by the State Museum in Trenton to take ownership of the 8,000year-old skeleton of a mastodon that is being excavated here.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 22 (AP) The police picked up and carried a number of anti-hydrogen-bomb pickets away from the front of the Pentagon today when they tried to hand out pamphlets and to enter the building with protest signs.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 22 The General Assembly agreed today to reach a decision on the future of Ruanda-Urundi by next Tuesday, five days before the territory is scheduled for independence.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 22 Communist Yugoslavia hopes to start exporting mink pelts soon to keep the wives of capitalists warm.
The annual Music Industry Trade Show will open at the New Yorker Hotel tomorrow and the leitmotif of the meeting, undoubtedly will be the sweet jingling of the cash register.

WASHINGTON, June 22 The Veterans Administration has directed its hospitals to negotiate new contracts with non-discrimination clauses for funeral and burial services. Standard procedures, however, could dilute the impact of the order.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 22 (AP) The Soviet Union, Turkey, Iran and Japan continued to pour on the coal in the world amateur wrestling championships tonight, heading for a series of showdown matches tomorrow.
KUHAVA, Finland, June 22 (UPI) Pentti Nikula of Finland bettered the world pole vault record today by scaling 16 feet 2 inches during the national championship meet.

PARIS, June 22 President Kennedy warns that myths are the enemy of truth and that mythology can even distract the realm of foreign affairs. One might say Secretary Rusk's current voyage of discovery is designed to explore a myth we invented ourselves the myth that France's current nuclear policy, which we find so embarrassing, is a Gaullist invention and that it will fade when de Gaulle retires.

CINCINNATI, June 22 Leaders of several Jewish organizations and human relations agencies throughout the country adopted a set of guidelines today for Jewish communities coping with problems relating to censorship.
A team of physicians at Bellevue Hospital was operating early today in an effort to sew back the severed left hand of a City Workhouse prisoner.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 16 The Latin American Free Trade Association, after a full year in operation toward the goal of a common market, has registered few startling successes.

THE barriers of prejudice between us create new bar riers within us suspicion, selfcontempt, the need for revenge and these separate us still further. There is a modern triad of objects of prejudice who internalize the prejudice: Jews, homosexuals and Negroes.
TO initiate its eighth season, the American Shakespeare Festival at Stratford, Conn., has attempted an experiment that must have looked very attractive on paper to the board of trustees.

BALTIMORE, June 23 (UPI) Ron Hansen broke a tie with a two-run homer and Billy Hoeft pitched seven and onethird shutout relief innings in giving the Baltimore Orioles a 5-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox today.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo It was Saturday, shortly before midnight, and the United States jeep was just passing the Netherlands Embassy. Tolo Hart, a Nigerian inspector, spotted two Congolese in the shadow of near-by trees.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 23 The Asian-African bloc agreed on a resolution today on Ruanda-Urundi calling for the confinement to barracks of all Belgian troops not evacuated by July 1. The African trust territory is scheduled to become independent as two nations on that date.
STUTTGART, Ark., June 21 A seeming shift from ultraconservatism and a slashing attack on an old political friend mark Representative Dale Alford's Democratic gubernatorial campaign.

The Soviet Union has been urged in a petition isgned by 223 Americans to abandon the death penalty for alleged eco nomic crimes. Some of the petitioners have had to fight accusations in the past that they have aided Soviet or Communist causes.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 23 Carole Wright of Brooklyn gained her third straight New York State women's tennis championship and her fourth in five years today.
After hearing fifteen hours of arguments, the Board of Estimate early yesterday held over until Tuesday a decision on the $180,000,000 West Side urban renewal project.

Howard Hughes, an erratic and reclusive multi-millionaire, has been flying high for almost forty years in the motion picture business, the oil field equipment industry, aviation design and air transportation.

CLEVELAND, June 23 Dave Stenhouse pitched last-place Washington to a 5-3 victory over league-leading Cleveland today. He limited the Indians to six hits, including a two-run homer by John Romano in the ninth inning.

BLUEBERRIES, one of summer's most delightful fruits, have a long tradition in American cuisine. Long before the Pilgrims landed, the Indians were eating the wild berries, either fresh or dried. From them, the early settlers learned how to preserve blueberries by drying them for use in the winter months.

Two air-conditioned models of split-level and two-story Colonial homes are on display at Southgate-at-Livingston, a fiftyunit community being built on Blackstone Drive, off West Mount Pleasant Avenue, in Livingston, N.J.

PEOPLE frequently want to know which is the best dog to buy. Fanciers will advise them to visit a dog show, where they will see a large variety of breeds and perhaps find one that will catch their eye.

The Kashmir dispute, which was the official issue before the United Nations Security Council last week, was secondary in importance to a broader question: the relations between the United States and Pakistan, our ally in the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization, and between the United States and India, the most important non-Communist power of Asia and the leader of the neutralist forces in the United Nations.
PALO ALTO, Calif., June 23 The president of the Association of American University Presses forecast this week an increasingly important role for the organization in international communication.

MADRID, June 23 Jose Maria Gil Robles, liberal monarchist leader of the shadow Christian Democratic movement, has resigned from the advisory Privy Council to Don Juan de Bourbon. Count of Barcelona and pretender to the throne.

A center hall entrance leads to a seventeen-foot reception room, which is overlooked by a galleried living room, in a two-story model at House Beautiful, a new development at Beach Drive and Cynthia Lane, south of Merrick Road, in Merrick, L.I. The model is priced at $24,990.

Abel Kiviat, a middle-distance star of the pre-World War I era, reached another milestone yesterday. He celebrated his seventieth birthday. He still has more bounce to the ounce than men fifteen and twenty years his junior.

PARIS, June 23 Algeria only a few days away from the referendum that is to bring independence to the territory, was in a state of confusion seldom equaled in the seven years and seven months since rebellion broke out against French rule.
For a man who has lived in the glare of publicity, Howard Hughes has been remarkably successful in keeping to himself.
More than 250 children paraded for two hours in Harlem yesterday as part of a campaign against narcotics and crime.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 23 Three American missionaries who were kidnapped by Communist guerrillas May 30 are being used to treat the wounded and to train the guerrillas in medical aid.

RAPID CITY, S.D., June 23 What was to be a routine Republican state convention here has been thrown into confusion by the death of Senator Francis E. Case, who was scheduled to run against George McGovern in the election next November.

HOLLYWOOD. THE perfect antidote for Hollywood's "depression blues" was found the other day on a sound stage at Revue Studio. Even the carpenters and electricians, who have been hit hard by the stampede of American producers to make movies abroad, forgot their troubles for a while and burst into uproarious laughter.
The start of the strike by the Flight Engineers International Association yesterday forced more than 300 passengers here and at other United States airports to disembark from waiting airplanes.
WASHINGTON, June 23 President Kennedy is in deep trouble in the Congress, where his past experience and his one-third majority were supposed to assure a greater degree of success.
WASHINGTON, June 23 Communist China opened political and diplomatic campaigns today to support its military build-up near the Nationalistheld offshore islands of Quemoy and Matsu.
VIETNAM, June 23 Communist North Vietnam broadcast orders today for an intensified struggle against the strategic hamlets that dot South Vietnam.

Department store sales in the nation for the week ended June 16 were 2 per cent below the level of a year earlier, the Federal Reserve Board has reported. Volume in the preceding week was 1 per cent higher than a year ago. Of the eleven Reserve districts reporting, five showed gains.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Junes 23 (AP) The Minnesota Twins whipped the Los Angeles Angels, 5 0, today with Jim Kaat coasting to his seventh straight victory behind the home-run hitting of Vic Power and Zoilo Versalles.

EDGEWATER, N.J., June 23 The handling of highway containers has been speeded at Seatrain Lines facilities here by the installation of a new traveling crane, described by its builders as the largest of its type in the world.

Australia has been much the most vociferous of the Commonwealth nations in expressing alarm over Britain's efforts to join the European Common Market. Prime Minister Menzies of Australia came to Washington from London several days ago breathing fire. After talking to President Kennedy and other Government officials he seems to have left in a calmer mood.

The Rev. Dr. Stuart Hamilton Merriam, who was ousted May 7 as pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, went on trial yesterday before a judicial commission of the New York Presbytery on charges of "untruthfulness" and "talebearing."

INNOCENTS ABROAD THERE are now about 250,000 American family groups living and working abroad, and tales of their adventures frequently stoke up the fires of wanderlust in even the most contented wife and mother. Wouldn't it be nice, she fantasies, to have a couple of years abroad with the family.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, June 23 Leaders of North Borneo's three political parties have rejected with some anger the Philippines' claim to the British colony of North Borneo on behalf of the descendants of the former Sultan of Sulu.
LONDON, June 23 Prime Minister Macmillan said today that the British Commonwealth would have a "healthier and stronger future" if Britain entered the European Economic Community.

WESTBURY, L.I. June 23 Miss Elizabeth Dorrance Warriner, daughter of Mrs. E. Edgar Iglehart of Greenview, here, and East Hampton, and John Dorrance Warriner of Villanova, Pa., was married here this afternoon to Samuel Morse Putnam. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Putnam of Concord, Mass.

IN the latest novel by Frank Swinnerton, an aging esthete named Graham Stanhope is being badgered by a demonic young journalist in the interest of "posterity." I was wondering," muses the eightyish Stanhope, "why I should care for posterity. I have never done so."

FLYING into Paris today, you are struck by the fact that something is happening to the green countryside around the city. On all sides, new apartment houses are springing up, almost as if some geological upheaval were disturbing the earth's crust.

PECOS, Tex., June 23 (UPI) An assistant state attorney general, reading from telephone company records, testified today on calls made from Billie Sol Estes' telephones. These in cluded calls to a member of Vice President Johnson's staff and to Senator Ralph W. Yar borough, he said.

BOSTON This year will mark the 200th anniversary of the construction here of Faneuil Hall, Boston's famous Cradle of Liberty. Erected first in 1742, the building was later destroyed by fire, and the present hall was built in 1762.

Lawn Pointers The rainless growing season thus far has not been conducive to proper grass growth. Too many lawns are straw-like and dormant. But some lawns are yellow and brown for other reasons: chinch bugs. These are the hot weather pests that feed primarily on bentgrasses and fescues.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 23 Joseph G. Burbeck of the Larchmont Yacht Club was the winner today in the opening race of the Arms-White series held for Star boats by the Rocky Point Club.

Two outstanding research scientists the discoverer of vitamin C and a noted geneticist will retire from the Columbia University faculty on June 30. They are Dr. Charles Glen King and Dr. Leslie C. Dunn.

MEXICO CITY. WHEN President Kennedy makes his first official visit this week to our nearest Latin neighbor, Mexico, the eyes of all Latin America will be upon him. For Mexico, with more than 37 million inhabitants, is the biggest Spanish-speaking nation to the south and is regarded by many latinos as their natural leader.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 23 Three major championships were clinched and seven minor titles were awarded today in the Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show that ends its fourday run tomorrow.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 23 Chief Judge Charles S. Desmond of the Court of Appeals denounced today the failure of the Legislature to create new judgeships for New York City as "inexcusable and indefensible."

TOKYO One of the most popular excursions in this nation of avid excursionists is the climb up Mount Fujiyama. Every summers, thousands of Japanese make the trip, and in recent years more and more foreign visitors have been joining them.

There are knotted problems, economic, political and, most of all, psychological, within Europe.

A thirteen-story office building, being built in Pittsburgh, will wear its structural steel framework on the outside a departure from the typical office building where a thin curtain wall is applied to a steel or concrete frame.

THE wild Klondike Gold Rush of the Eighteen Nineties will be the theme of the Gold Rush Festival, which opens July 1 in Dawson City in the Yukon Territory. Sponsored by the Canadian Government and many of Dawson City's 900 residents, the fifty-five-day celebration is expected to attract 1,000 visitors daily with reminders of gold-boom days.
BERLIN, June 18 Company F of the Fortieth Armored Battalion is a crack tank unit of the United States Army in Berlin. It is the only armored combat unit in the Allied garrison here.

GARDENERS start to plant flowers and vegetables as early as possible in spring, working with enthusiasm the minute the ground can be turned. Such early work is essential for edible peas, sweet peas and certain border annuals. But there are other flowers and vegetables for which the month of June is a sensible planting time.

Summer began on Thursday afternoon, according to the almanac, and sunrise has already begun to lag by a slight margin in that perennial shift toward autumn, still three months away. It is the eternal change that comes to any land of varied seasons, since the summer solstice is the year's own meridian, not a resting place.

TORONTO. COMPETITIVE Canadian television has become an actuality in eight of Canada's major markets since last Oct. 1. HARTFORD, June 22 The chances that a Negro will be elected to state office this year for the first time increased strongly this week.

Prospective visitors to the Saratoga Battlefield here, where the Continental Army scored its most decisive victory, will report to a new field headquarters this year, will get a new set of expert briefings on the battle and the Revolutionary War and will be sent off on their field inspection mission more fully trained than any previous contingent.

AN extra door installed near the back end of an attached garage is a wonderful convenience which many homes lack. It enables the home owner to get in or out of the garage (while the car is inside) without having to squeeze past the car each time. It also simplifies the task of removing bulky equipment which is often stored at the rear of the garage (in front of the car).

WASHINGTON, June 25 Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman reprimanded today a Department of Agriculture official who said he had, under pressure, written a report favoring Billie Sol Estes.
Stocks rode a roller-coaster yesterday in heavy trading. At the end of the ride, prices on the New York Stock Exchange showed a fairly large loss.
OTTAWA, June 25 Financial circles approved today the Government's drastic action to restore the Canadian economy to health by bolstering the dollar and curbing imports.

A proposed amendment to the Federal Constitution would meet the problem of what to do when a President becomes incapacitated. This amendment has recently been endorsed by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and has wide support among constitutional lawyers and others.
WASHINGTON, June 25 In two of its most important antitrust decisions in years, the Supreme Court today gave Government trust busters powerful weapons to enforce competitive conditions in business.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) Suport piled up in the House today for an $11,000,000,000 World War I pension bill that Representative Olin E. Teague, Democrat of Texas, denounced as a "give-away," unfair to most veterans and to the taxpayers.
Sea-Land Services, Inc., will increase the capacity of its trailership service from New York to Puerto Rico by 36 per cent next month, Michael R. McEvoy, president of the company, said yesterday.
LONDON, June 25 The Foreign Office announced today that arrangements had been concluded with the Soviet Union to reconvene the Geneva conference on Laos next Monday.

The New York Cocoa Exchange recorded its second most active session of the year yesterday, as first notice day of intention to deliver on the July contract produced heavy selling. The delivery notices involved 140 contracts, or 4,200,000 pounds of cocoa beans.

THE Basques of Spain and the average American family living in the suburbs have one thing in common. Both like to cook outdoors over charcoal. The Basques, however, have been doing it longer. In fact, it is one of the ancient customs that the Basques, one of the oldest surviving racial groups in Europe, have preserved.

FARGO, N.D., June 27 (AP) North Dakota Republicans outpolled the Democrats, 3 2, in yesterday's primaries. With nearly 90 per cent of the state's 2,308 precincts reporting, the total vote cast had reached only 110,000, the lowest turnout in more than thirty years.

James M. Symes will continue indefinitely as chairman and chief executive officer of the Pennsylvania Railroad despite the fact that he will reach the normal retirement age of 65 on July 8, the railroad announced yesterday.

James C. Reid, president of the Southern Union Gas Company predicted yesterday a more favorable dividend rate on his company's common stock, after allowing for adjustments from a recent stock split. WASHINGTON, June 27 A Senate investigator charged today that delay by the Agriculture Department in taking action on Billie Sol Estes made it "difficult not to suspect bad faith." The charge was made by Paul E. Kamerick, assistant counsel of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

AS this is written five games have been decided and two are adjourned in the grandmaster match between United States Champion Larry Evans and William Lombardy for the George P. Edgar trophy. The match is being played at the Marshall and Manhattan Chess Clubs.

True to tradition, Emile Griffith, the world welterweight boxing champion, received a gift bag yesterday on the eve of his departure for Las Vegas, where he defends his title on July 13 against Ralph Dupas.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 27 The General Assembly confirmed today, 93 to 0, the independence of the Belgianruled African trust territory of Ruanda-Urundi, effective Sunday.

The U.N. has now ratified without a dissenting vote the creation of two new nations, beginning at midnight Saturday, formed out of the Belgian protectorate of Ruanda-Urundi. Many had hoped that these two areas in central Africa might become one nation, but their spokesmen preferred separation. Therefore we now have the Republic of Rwanda in the north, running from ...

Jerome Lewine, senior partner in H. Hentz Co., and one of the financial district's elder statesmen, observes today the sixty-second anniversary of his first job in Wall Street and the beginning of his long association with the Hentz firm. Mr. Lewine is 77 years old.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., June 27 The Rev. and Mrs. David W. Jenks have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Lee Jenks, to the Rev. Edwin S. Redkey. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Redkey of Rockville, Md.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) The United States announced the explosion of two more nuclear test shots today, one in the atmosphere over the Pacific and the other underground in Nevada.

BOSTON, June 27 (AP) Taking charge at the start and repulsing repeated bids from his rivals over the mile and a quarter route, Horace Wise's Air Pilot was a surprise winner today in the twenty-eighth running of the $50,000 added Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 27 Paul-Henri Spaak, Foreign Minister of Belgium, predicted today that negotiations next month would bring decisive developments regarding Britain's application for admission to the European Economic Community.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 27 Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Affectionately, a victor at Santa Anita, Aqueduct, Delaware and Belmont Park during an unbeaten six-race campaign, met her first setback today before 16,551 fans at Monmouth Park.

Henry James published 112 tales, besides his many novels. He personally selected fiftytwo of the stories for inclusion in the New York Edition. Lippincott is publishing today the first two volumes of a projected twelve-volume edition to be called "The Complete Tales of Henry James."

A $50,000,000 fuel storage facility on the East River waterfront under the windows of Peter Cooper Village and Stuyvesant Town was announced yesterday a joint project of the Consolidated Edison Company and the city's Marine and Aviation Department.
MOSTAGANEM, Algeria, June 27 Oran is a city living in anarchy and fear bordering on hysteria.

THE stocky, bubbly movie tycoon who resigned yes terday as president of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation (but who in keeping with his never-say-die philosophy continues as a $50,000a-year consultant), relishes challenges so much that he is sometimes called The Colossal Optimist.
LONDON, June 28 Industrial shares rose today for the third consecutive day. There were many gains of a shilling (14 cents) or more.

Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes was accused in Supreme Court yesterday of using half-truths and "scanty, vague or misstated data" to justify his proposal to revise the traffic pattern of the West Village section of Manhattan.
FAIR LAWN, N. J., June 28 Floyd Lyle, former head of the fellowship and travel service of the Rockefeller Foundation in New York, died today at St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson.

CHICAGO, Jun 28 (AP) Fred Hawkins of El Paso, Tex., fired a three-under-par 68 today to steal the first-round thunder from Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer in the $50,000 Western open golf tournament. Hawkins, 38 years old, whose last victory was the Oklahoma City open in 1956, had 34's for both nines of the Medinah No. 3 course, which measures 7,110 yards.

Net free reserves a basic index of monetary conditions have become less voluminous in the banking system in recent weeks, giving rise to speculation about a possible change in Federal Reserve monetary policy.
MOSCOW, June 28 Residents of Sestroretsk are eagerly awaiting mail from Huntington, L. I., according to a five-page illustrated article in the July issue of the magazine Soviet Woman.

LOS ANGELES, June 28 The Los Angeles Dodgers, in a stunning reversal of form, had to rally in the eighth inning to tie the New York Mets in an extra-inning contest tonight at the Chavez Ravine Stadium before 19,080 fans.
ROME, June 28 Conductors, singers, musicians and stagehands of Italian opera houses are in a melodramatic agitation against Parliament.

Stouffer's. 666 Fifth Avenue, PLaza 7-6662; 100 East Fortysecond Street, Oxford 7-2380. All things considered food, service and price there are few finer restaurants in all of Manhattan. Whether it is a sandwich or spinach souffle, the quality is almost always first class.

LAST night at Lewisohn Stadium, the orchestra settled for, and settled down to, an all-Russian program. It was made up of sure-fire or what one would have thought to be sure-fire material, the Prelude to Mussorgsky's "Khovanstchina," Tchaikovsky's "Pathetique" Symphony and Rachmaninoff's Second Piano Concerto.

WASHINGTON, June 28 Francis B. Coker Jr., Professor of Corporation Law at the Yale Law School and a consultant to the Securities and Exchange Commission, died here today of a heart attack. He was 44 years old and lived on Twin Lakes Road in North Branford, Conn.
Edward M. Gilbert was indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday on charges of misappropriating $1,953,000.

HARTFORD, June 28 The first comprehensive test of payas-you-see television in the United States starts tomorrow night when upwards of 300 families in West Hartford will have an opportunity to pay $1 to tune in one of last season's films, "Sunrise at Campobello," starring Ralph Bellamy. Ther a will be no commercials.
WASHINGTON, June 28 Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman told a Senate subcommittee today that his Under Secretary, Charles S. Murphy, had made a "mis take" in naming Billie Sol ...
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP)-The Air Force is planning a big fifteenth birthday celebration-and it would like a "lift" from the Lord.

WASHINGTON, June 28 Contractors, lenders and brokers in the home remodeling and improvement industry criticized the Kennedy Administration today for its handling of a new Federal housing program designed to encourage rehabilitation and upgrading of existing homes.
More television specials that will tell stories from the Bible through great works of art are being planned by the National Broadcasting Company.

Preparatory to sailing today for England on the HollandAmerica Line flagship Rotterdam the combined Yale-Harvard tennis team defeated representatives of the West Side Tennis Club yesterday at Forest Hills, Queens, 6 matches to 1.
TOKYO, June 28 (AP) Communist China today announced the death of Lung Yun, Governor of Yunnan Province under Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek. He was 77 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 28. (AP) Following are the roll-call votes by which the House rejected recommittal of the foreign trade bill the action would have substituted a one-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act and passed the bill:
SOME inexperienced players can perform brilliant feats at bridge, but the value of experience cannot be held lightly. At the very least, it saves time.
THE FALL OF THE CITY," written by Arch ibald MacLeish twenty-five years ago for radio, was televised on Channel 2 last night.
Leon J. Davis, the leader of New York's striking hospital workers, was released from Civil Jail yesterday after completing a thirty-day sentence for contempt of court.
WASHINGTON, June 28 Foy D. Kohler, a 54-year-old career diplomat, will be nominated soon as the next Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

Mining crews of the Federal Resources Corporation have reached a silver ore zone of commercial grade on the 2,000foot level of the Conjecture silver mine near Lakeview, Idaho, according to a letter to Federal shareholders.
ATLANTA, June 28 A spokesman for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said today that a hotel here had refused to provide a room for Dr. Ralph Bunche.

WASHINGTON, June 28 The Pentagon has awarded more than, a half billion dollars worth of defense contracts in the last two days. Additional big contracts are expected to be announced tomorrow and perhaps Saturday as the fiscal year comes to a close.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 28--Dr. Robert A. Soblen, who was due to surrender in New York today to begin serving a life sentence for spying for the Soviet Union, was arrested by the Israeli police this morning in a hotel in Tel Aviv.

Miss Judith Alene DeFoe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. DeFoe of Detroit, was married here yesterday afternoon to Anthony David Berns. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Berns of New York. Supreme Court Justice Samuel M. Gold performed the ceremony in the Chateau Suite of the Savoy Hilton.

LIMA, Peru, June 28 (UPI)--The armed forces charged today that there were "grave irregularities" in the vote count in the recent Presidential election, which appeared to have been won by Victor Raul Haya de la Torre. It appeared that the military were ready to nullify the election, which took place June 10.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 28 Towering Frank Froehling is the only American in the last sixteen men at Wimbledon tonight. The 20-year-old gangling giant from Coral Gables, Fla., won from Owen Davidson, one of the more promising juniors along the Australian assembly line 8 6, 7 5, 6 8, 6 4, as a near-sellout crowd of 30,000 jammed these ivied grounds under sunny skies.
DETROIT, June 28 A new Protestant church was born today in the ultra-modern setting of the huge Convention Arena in this industrial city.
BERLIN, June 28 (UPI) East German policemen discovered an escape tunnel under their Berlin wall today and captured two West Berliners helping build it.

WASHINGTON, June 28 The necessity to good government of the constant exercise by Congress of its powers to investigate is again being demonstrated by the Senate subcommittee headed by Senator McClellan of Arkansas.
WASHINGTON, June 28 President Kennedy signed into law tonight the first permanent legislation to admit refugees to this country without regard to immigration quotas.
ALGIERS, June 28 The proclamation of the independence of Algeria is expected Monday, the day after the selfdetermination referendum, Dr. Chawki Mostefai, nationalist delegate, told newsmen tonight.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 28--What had been intended as a crucial stage in the negotiations for Britain's entry into the European Economic Community got off to a slow start here today. Little headway was made on the key problem of British imports of food from Canada, Australia and New Zealand.

LONDON, June 28 The cornerstone of a building that some day will serve as a "powerhouse for the use of English" if its sponsors wishes are fulfilled, was laid into place today at the Warwickshire town of Stratford-on-Avon.

Some of the highest fouls and flies in the annals of baseball missilery rode the wind in Yankee Stadium yesterday. Two of these launched by Roger Maris and Mickey Mantle landed in home run territory, starting the Yanks toward a 4-2 trimriph over the Minnesota Twins.

PARIS, June 28--Roger Degueldre, former lieutenant and a French Foreign Legion deserter, was condemned to death tonight for having directed a terrorist campaign in Algiers on behalf of the Secret Army Organization.

Willard Hurst's 3-year-old bay colt Sawgrass took, the lead soon after the start of the $10,000 Pompoon Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday and held it throughout in winning the seven-furlong turf sprint by three lengths.
Most commodities rose yesterday on New York exchanges. Activity ranged from light to moderate.
Two Texas colleges borrowed a total of $10,000,000 on the bond market yesterday to finance expansion.

PLEASURE boating is a sport that requires books, volumes of rules and regulations and various guides adding to the delights of cruising. On every well-found craft will be such publications as "Tide Tables," "Tidal Current Charts," "Light Lists" and "Coast Pilots."
BONN, Germany, June 28 Chancellor Adenauer's coalition Government teetered dangerously today when its junior partners, the Free Democrats, rebelled in Parliament.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) The Governors of New Jersey and Delaware urged Congress today to approve establishing a port authority for development of the lower Delaware River and Delaware Bay.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 28 Alfred E. Abbot former New York importer of Limoges china, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital after a brief illness.
WASHINGTON, June 28 The Senate blocked an economy drive by Republicans today and passed legislation temporarily raising the national debt ceiling to a record of $308,000,000,000.

TRENTON, N. J., June 28 (AP) The appellate division of the Superior Court today ordered a Plainfield couple to pay $1,000 to a Hillside housing concern to cover lost profits on a house they failed to buy.
Mayor Wagner has ordered "top priority" for the drafting of a local law establishing a minimum hourly wage of $1.25 for all employed in the city.

ALGONQUIN PARK, Ont., June 28 There are two ways of seeing how large and wild this park is, with its nearly 3,000 square miles of woods and water. One is to paddle along the hundreds of miles of canoe routes; the other is to fly over it.
A 6-year-old boy was thrown into the Hudson River last Monday and peppered with rocks by three 8-year-old boys until he drowned, the police said yesterday.

The management of the Radio City Music Hall has announced that the two opening weeks of "That Touch of Mink," ending on Wednesday night, drew $408,505, a record for that period of time in the thirty-year history of the Music Hall.
Eight thousand supporters of the Christian Anti-Communism Crusade rallied in Madison Square Garden last night as 200 pickets marched outside in protest.
WASHINGTON, June 28 The House of Representatives passed the Administration's foreign trade bill today by a heavily bipartisan majority of 298 to 125.

PARIS, June 28 France has laid down all the details of the transfer of authority to a new Algerian government except the question of whether French and Algerian soldiers will salute each other when they meet.
The high grade bond market was checkered by light and dark spots yesterday.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 28 The Tennessee Valley Authority said today that it would transfer $28,270,820 to the United States Treasury tomorrow.

FRED CHARLES SCHWARZ is a hellfire-and-brimstone evangelist whose particular devil is communism. A physician, psychiatrist, school teacher and Baptist lay preacher from Australia, Dr. Schwarz has since 1953 spent most of his time in the United States running the ...
LAKE FOREST, Ill., June 28 (AP) Mickey Cochrane, one of baseball's great figures, died today in Lake Forest Hospital. He was 59 years old.

OSSINING, N. Y., June 28 Presiding Justice George J. Beldock of the Appellate Division, Second Department, said today he was prohibited by stature from starting disbarment proceedings at this time against Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh.

RYE, N. Y., June 28 Two Long Island contestants, Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Harbor Hills and Mrs. Allan A. Ryan of The Creek Club today reached the final of the fifty-ninth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship.

WASHINGTON, June 28 The railroad industry reported today that last week's freight movements were above the level of the prior week but down from last year, while the trucking industry registered a rise from 1961 and a slight decline from the preceding week of this year.
PURCHASE, N. Y., June 28 Flying Curlew from Mrs. Henry Paxson's Holicong, (Pa.) Stables, won two blue ribbons in the Goldens Bridge horse show on the Blind Brook Polo Grounds today.
The Vermont Public Service Commission indicated yesterday it would take a dispute with the New York State Power Authority to the courts.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) A rally, which brokers termed overdue, gave grain futures a broad and general lift today in active transactions on the Board of Trade. All except wheat registered gains running to more than a cent a bushel.

Two workers on the Cross-Bronx Expressway were crushed to death this week when four arm sections of a huge crane buckled and crashed down on them. This tragic accident lends urgency to the efforts of Commissioner of Buildings Harold Birns to curb the height of the towering rigs used to hoist material to the upper stories ...
The advertising director of the United States Steel Corporation urged media salesmen yesterday to face up to some of the harsh realities of the advertising industry.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) A bill to help train teachers for handicapped children and to broaden rehabilitation services for handicapped adults was approved today by the House Education and Labor Committee.

Work on one of the world's largest air conditioning installations is proceeding on schedule in the forty-threestory Sperry Rand Building at 1290 Avenue of the Americas, according to Bernard Reissman, secretary-treasurer of H. Sand Co., Inc., the mechanical contractor.

A September wedding is planned by Miss Susan Marlowe Paige and James R. Morrison. Announcement of their engagement has been made here by Miss Paige's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Paige of Taipei, Taiwan, and Washington. The prospective bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joe Wood Morrison of Olga, Orcas Island, Wash.

FLORAL PARK, L. I., June 28 A Long Island Rail Road diesel engine sounded its horn loudly and slowly edged through an arch of green boughs at a new station here today to mark the completion of a $12,000,000 grade-crossing elimination project.
PORT NEWARK, N.J., June 28 Port Newark was hit by a wildcat longshoremen's strike today.

LONDON, June 28 (Reuters) Premier Khrushchev has said once again that the Soviet Union is ready to sign a treaty prohibiting nuclear tests even before an agreement is reached on complete and general disarmament, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.
OSSINING, N. Y., June 28 State Supreme Court Justices contended today that lawyers, and not they were responsible for congested court calendars.
Ned J. Parsekian, director of the New Jersey division of motor vehicles, yesterday urged New York State to raise its minimum drinking age as a matter of "simple logic."

The $100,000 forfeited yesterday to the Federal court after Dr. Robert A. Soblen jumped bail represented $44,000 raised by his wife through pledging her savings, insurance and pension rights and $60,000 lent to her by two well-to-do New Yorkers with a concern for civil liberties.
The Jewish Child Care Association of New York will purchase four apartments in a Brooklyn middle-income cooperative to house sixteen foster children.
The Board of Education adopted a salary schedule yesterday granting increases totaling $7,700,000 for supervisors, administrators and other nonteaching personnel for 1962-63.

A bill that would require all employers in New York State to provide hospital insurance for their workers was sharply criticized yesterday by labor spokesmen and representatives of business and industry.
LONDON, June 28 The Cabinet was said today to have endorsed a second television channel for the British Broadcasting Corporation as recommended yesterday in a controversial report on broadcasting.
A "big-name" in the liquor industry has entered the business of importing and selling Scotch in bulk, it was disclosed yesterday.
DETROIT, June 28 Some leading Michigan business executives are being asked to pay $1,000 each to attend an informal discussion of the economy with President Kennedy in Detroit next October.

ROSLYN, L. I., June 28 The marriage of Miss Hilary Paley daughter of Mrs. Dorothy Hirshon of Glen Cove and William S. Paley of Manhasset, to J. Frederic Byers 3d took place here this afternoon. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Byers Jr. of Westbury.

WASHINGTON, , June 28 President Kennedy said tonight that the United States sought peace and prosperity for all Middle Eastern countries, "firm in our belief that a new spirit of comity in that important part of the world would serve the highest aspirations and interests of all nations."

LISBON, Portugal, June 28 The United States and Portugal have agreed to resume negotiations for an extension of American military rights to bases in the Azores Islands for five more years. The current agreement expires Dec. 31.
WASHINGTON, June 28 President and Mrs. Kennedy will leave here early tomorrow for a forty-eight-hour state visit to Mexico.
A laboratory model of a device that its inventor believes can remove fall-out from milk for less than a cent a quart was demonstrated here yesterPolytechnic Institute yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 28 The Federal Maritime Commission has approved rate increases of 22 per cent on ocean cargo moving between Pacific Coast ports and Hawaii.
Alexander Stuart (Jock) Sturrock, the co-helmsman of Gretel, the Australian 12-Meter challenger for the America's Cup, arrived yesterday.
A ship engineer union and two ship owner groups announced here yesterday that they had reached agreements to improve pension benefits and to provide specialized training.
The Rodgers and Hammerstein Foundation has made a gift of $150,000 toward the construction of a theatre at the proposed Columbia University Arts Center.

FOR those who like water shows, but are averse to open air, the place to go these days is the New York Coliseum. On the second floor of the large exposition center John McKnight has installed a quarter-of-a-million dollar aqua theatre.
CHICAGO, June 28 A computer system to scan electrocardiograms and pick out normal and abnormal patterns was described here today at the American Medical Association's 11th annual meeting.
MOSCOW, June 28 Chancellor Alfons Gorbach of Austria declared today upon his arrival in Moscow that his country intended to stand by its policy of neutrality.

WASHINGTON, June 28- Secretary of State Dean Rusk flew home tonight from a ten-day journey to examine the Atlantic alliance. He will tell President Kennedy tomorrow morning to expect a feverish summer in the diplomatic area.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 28 The twenty-first annual fair of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, a continuation of the old strawberry festival held ...

VIENTIANE, Laos, Friday, June 29 (AP) Two British doctors and two British Embassy officials have been released by the pro-Communist Pathet Lao movement, the British Embassy announced today. The four had been held just over a month.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 28 S/4c George F. Fryett Jr., the United States soldier who was released four days ago after he had been a prisoner of the Communist guerrillas for six months, said today that his captors had "exhibited" him in numerous villages.
MORE than 500,000,000 pounds of wood charcoal briquets were used last year for cooking by more than 20,000,000 American families, according to the Wood Charcoal Briquet Producers Association.

A State Supreme Court jury awarded $3,500,000 last night to John Henry Faulk, former radio and television entertainer, in his libel suit against Aware, Inc.; Vincent W. Hartnett, and the late Laurence A. Johnson.

ORAN, Algeria, June 28 Representatives of the Moslem and European communities of Oran made last-minute efforts today to restore peace to this tortured city before Algeria's independence referendum Sunday. Their efforts appeared to be gaining ground.
ACCRA, Ghana, June 28--The "World Without a Bomb" Assembly called on the United Nations today to organize trained teams of experts to serve as disarmament inspectors. Immediate action was urged.
The 1962 show business gold rush is on. A small army of stars heading for New York for the biggest bonanza in years.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) The Senate Judiciary Committee today scheduled hearings next week on proposed constitutional amendments designed to overturn the Supreme Court decision banning official prayers in public schools.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 (UPI) The criminal conviction of the 1,500-member Northern California Pharmaceutical Associations for conspiring to fix prices of prescription drugs was upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
LONDON, June 28 Sir Winston Churchill will probably be confined to his bed for at least four months as a result of today's fall, medical authorities said tonight.

Lawrence B. Karter, realty investor, has contracted to sell the leasehold on the four-story business building at 782 Eighth Avenue, between Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Streets. Buyer is an investing client of Louis Jay, lawyer. The parcel is 18 by 97 feet and is assessed at $60,000. Joseph O'Gara was the broker in the deal. The property is south of the new Loew's Midtown Motor Inn.

TERRY MOORE of the Cardinals hesitated before broaching the subject, then barged boldly ahead. He approached Bill Dickey of the Yankees before an exhibition game on a glorious spring day in St. Petersburg, Fla., about a dozen years ago.

OTTAWA, June 28 (AP) The average interest rate on ninety-one-day Canadian Government Treasury bills jumped today to 5.45 per cent from the 4.92 per cent level reached last week just before the Government's austerity program went into effect.
Federal Judge William B. Herlands ordered Dr. Robert A. Soblen's $100,000 bail forfeited yesterday after being advised that the convicted spy had fled to Israel to avoid serving a life sentence.
The United Steelworkers of America and the five major aluminum companies signed two-year contracts yesterday covering 27,000 union members in plants throughout the nation.

The stock market advanced yesterday in a major rally. Prices rose on the New York Stock Exchange in a sweeping surge that was the second best of the year, exceeded only by the massive rally of May 29, the day after the sharp break.
KIGALI, Ruanda-Urundi, June 28 In this tiny capital city high in the mountains, the impoverished people of Ruanda await Sunday and independence with an austerity program already in progress.
LONDON, June 28 An almost audible sigh of relief arose in London tonight when it was learned that Sir Winston Churchill would be flown home tomorrow.
New orders received by manufacturers in May were slightly more than $33,000,000,000 after seasonal adjustment, the Department of Commerce reported yesterday.

OXFORD, England, June 28 Charlie Chaplin, now an honorary Doctor of Letters from Oxford University, said today that he planned two more films. One will be a comedy, with his son Sydney, and the other a parody on historical spectacles. The comedian explained the films will be Mr. Chaplin's first since 1957.
ALBANY, June 28 A number of New York State residents who earned their entire incomes last year in New Jersey and had taxes withheld there have mistakenly applied to New York for refunds.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, June 28 Sir Winston Churchill broke his left thigh this morning when he slipped and fell while getting out of bed.

Administration officials admit that the United States dollar problem has been complicated by Canada's difficulties; but they point out, quite correctly, that our position is much stronger than Canada's and, in any event, the effects of the Canadian crisis are likely to be temporary.
Ebbing stock prices during the last seven months have washed away the merger plans of the Meadow Brook National Bank of Long Island and the Bensonhurst National Bank of Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, June 28 with a smiling salute to whatever White House ghosts there may be, Mrs. John F. Kennedy opened the redecorated Treaty Room today.
WASHINGTON, June 28--Congress moved decisively today to keep Government agencies from running out of funds next Sunday.
MOSCOW, June 28 Marshal Ivan S, Konev, one of the leading military strategists of the Soviet Union, was reported today to be seriously ill.
YONKERS, June 28 Last through most of the grueling race, Irvin Paul rallied to win the two-mile National Championship Pace in world-record time tonight at Yonkers Raceway.
CHICAGO, June 28 (AP)--A doctor said today that physicians should "step back and let God take over," instead of trying to prolong the lives of hopeless, suffering, dying cancer patients.

Mrs. Reyna Stodel Friedman, who in 1927-28 was the first president of B'nai B'rith Women's District No. 1, died Wednesday in the Dresden Madison Nursing Home, 36 East Sixty-seventh Street. She was 92 years old and lived at 327 Central Park West. She was the widow of Abram Friedman, an insurance broker.

IN discussing the wilderness bill on June 1, this column was too bland about one factor. It surmised that the timber on Government lands is now more scrupulously protected than it was a half century ago:

CHICAGO, June 28 Dr. Edward R. Annie, one of medicine's most articulate spokesmen against the King-Anderson bill for medical care of the aged, was named president-elect of the American Medical Association today.
ST. LOUIS, June 28 The religious American, both Roman Catholic and non-Catholic, is engaged in a general war between secularism and religion, a Catholic Family Life Conference was told here today.
PECOS, Tex., June 28 What is life like these days for Billie Sol Estes, celebrity of Pecos, subject of two Congressional investigations in Washington?

The securities and Exchange Commission has issued another questionnaire. Ever since it began investigating the securities trading practices last year, it has been sending questionnaires to brokers, brokerage houses and exchanges.

President de Gaulle's insistence that France must acquire nuclear capability of her own has been met by an understandable reluctance on the part of the Kennedy Administration to assist in the dispersion of nuclear weapons.

BUFFALO, June 28 (AP ) The football season opens early this year with the All-America Bowl game tomorrow night at War Memorial Stadium. The teams, the East All-Stars and West All-Stars, include most of the leading college seniors of 1961.

New York has many eyesores, but it does not yet have a, glittering eighteen-story glass and stainless steel tower flanked by two massive, funereal five-story black granite wings with inscriptions, statues, steps and a full complement of flags. It will have this within two years, however, if the plans materialize for a $7,000,000 memorial for the north end of Union Square sponsored by a joint committee of veterans' organizations.

A pacifist demonstrator who protested that she was a victim of police mistreatment at a rally in Times Square last March was found guilty of disorderly conduct and resisting arrest yesterday and given the choice of paying a $25 fine or spending five days in jail.
William Archibald, the play wright, has been appointed chairman of a committee that will reorganize the playwrights' unit of the Actors Studio.

WASHINGTON, June 28 The United States has quietly resigned as chief broker of the international consortium formed to aid India. Washington hopes that the Indians will become more vigorous advocates of their own cause.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, June 28 (Reuters) The Marquess of Winchester, Britain's oldest peer, died in the Princess Grace Clinic here today at the age of 99.
The flight from justice and forfeiture of bail by Dr. Robert A. Soblen followed a bail jumping pattern that had been set by several top Communists.
LEE, Mass., June 28 The 1962 Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival opened tonight in the 600seat Ted Shawn Theatre, located in the Berkshire Mountains nine miles from here.

MILWAUKEE, June 28 (AP) The Justice Department filed civil complaints today against six major paper and pulp mills and five individuals. It charged price-fixing in purchases from small farmers and loggers. Joseph J. O'Malley, department antitrust ofifcer, filed the complaints and then left for Madison where, he said, other civil and criminal complaints would be filed in Federal District Court.

WASHINGTON, June 28 The first half of 1962 is now ending with Washington worried about Billie Sol Estes and profits. Last year at this time it was worried about Nikita Khrushchev and war. The comparison is instructive and even a little reassuring.
THE two men were alone in the New York apartment. "Well," said John, "I don't know why you should be so discouraged. You've read plenty of other novels no worse than this one."

Mr. and Mrs. ROSS Reid of 142 East Seventy-first Street have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Heather Reid, to Edmund Arthur Schaffzin. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Schaffzin, also of New York. The wedding is planned for Aug. 12.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 28--A top-level Yugoslav delegation will leave for Moscow next week to seek an expansion of economic relations with the Soviet Union. Belgrade hopes for more trade and Soviet aid to bolster the ailing Yugoslav economy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 28--The General Assembly, overriding British legal objections, voted today to call on London to hold a constitutional conference to give adequate political representation to the African inhabitants of Southern Rhodesia.
WASHINGTON, June 28 The Government began legal and diplomatic efforts today to bring Dr. Robert A. Soblen back from Israel.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP)--The United States Court of Appeals vacated today the contempt of court citation against James E. Jackson, editor of the Daily Worker. He had refused to testify before a grand jury investigating Communist party activities.
Following are excerpts from newspaper editorials on the Supreme Court decision banning official prayers in New York State public schools, as gathered by The New York Times:
Record sales and earnings for the quarter ended on May 31 were reported yesterday by the Beatrice Foods Company.
The United States Court of Appeals yesterday granted Henry Winston, the Communist party leader, the right to sue the Government for alleged negligence in medical attention while he was in prison.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 28 Mayor Joseph M. Reilly rejected today a request for a meeting with a representative of the State Department to discuss the sale tomorrow morning of tax liens on Killenworth, the Soviet estate here.

MYRTLE BEACH, S.C., June 28 (AP) Ruth Jessen matched par on each nine today to shoot a 72 and take a three-stroke lead over the defending champion, Mickey Wright, after the first round of the United States women's golf open.

The New York Mets, who have no past and are dismally bogged down in the present, invested a substantial sum in the future yesterday by signing Ed Kranepool, a 17-year-old first baseman from James Monroe High School in the Bronx. Kranepool received a bonus, estimated to be in excess of $75,000.

President Kennedy, who twice has reluctantly invoked the provisions of the TaftHartley Act in maritime disputes, was asked by a labor leader yesterday to promote an election between two unions seeking to represent the nation's unlicensed seamen.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 28 The Brazilian Chamber of Deputies rejected today President Joao Goulart's nomination of Dr. Francisco San Tiago Dantas as Premier. The vote was 174 to 110.

WHEN twenty fashion-conseious American college girls swoop down on Rome enmasse, just about anything can happen. One such group, which has just returned from a fiveday stay in the Eternal City, has issued what may be a unique fashion report.
Within the next two or three days, the Curtis Publishing Company is expected to select Matthew J. Culligan, a 44-yearold advertising man, as its new president.
July cotton futures fell $2 a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Other months were 25 cents up to 15 cents down.

VIENNA, June 29 The Communist regimes of Hungary, Rumania and Czechoslovakia are reported to be alarmed at what will happen to their trade with Western Europe when the European Economic Community's unified tariff reduction goes into effect Sunday.
Activity in most of the New York commodities markets was featureless yesterday as traders evened-up, for the week-end.
WASHINGTON, June 29 Government officials were watching developments in Israel today in their efforts to devise a way of getting Dr. Robert A. Soblen back into the United States custody.

The Government of Panama has threatened shipping reprisals against vessels flying the United States flag if the sovereignty of ships flying the Panamanian flag is jeopardized by United States labor laws.
The aircraft carrier Forrestal docked here yesterday morning at Hudson River Pier 90. She is the lead ship of thirteen members of the United States Second Fleet arriving for a Fourth of July visit.
DETROIT, June 29 The major Lutheran churches in the United States were invited here today to participate in a joint study of the theology of confirmation.
A city-wide search is being conducted for about 150 "missing heirs" to middle-income cooperative apartments being built on the lower East Side.

WASHINGTON, June 29 The controversial issue of whether to merge all Zionist groups in this country evoked sharp differences of opinion today.
WASHINGTON, June 29 A bipartisan compromise on medical care for the aged was offered in the Senate today. Debate is scheduled to begin next week.

MALVERNE, L.I., June 29 W. Donald Jordan, secretary of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company since 1947, died yesterday at his home at 31 Beacon Street here after a long illness. He was 63 years old. His office was at 20 Pine Street, New York City.
Defense attorneys took steps yesterday to appeal a Supreme Court jury's $3,500,000 libel award to John Henry Faulk.

The practice of permitting prayers in schools in Great Britain, France, Italy and West Germany varies considerably, according to a survey by correspondents of The New York Times.
WASHINGTON, June 29 A compromise on a new sugar law was unexpectedly reached late tonight by Senate-House conferees.

Sacramento, Calif., plans to offer on July 12 an issue of $7,905,000 in water revenue bonds falling due 1963 to 2000.

"The Great Parade," a painting 10 feet high and 13 feet long by Fernand Leger, has been acquired by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The House Agriculture Committee approved today a new farm bill that would extend for one year the present emergency wheat and feed grains programs with slight modification.

BRIAN FRIEL'S "The Saucer of Larks" is an interesting collection of stories about frontier people in an old world. You may have read some of them in The Commonweal, Ave Maria, The Sign, and The New Yorker. They are swiftly and discerningly told.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation sought evidence yesterday on possible accomplices in the flight to Israel of Dr. Robert A. Soblen three days before he was to begin serving a life sentence as a Soviet spy.

Gene (Ace) Armstrong returns to Madison Square Garden tonight for a television fight after a sixteen-month layoff, just as Joey Archer did last Saturday.

Stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange were sharply lower in the first six months of this year. The market lost ground starting at the beginning of the year and the decline continued almost until the end of June, when a good rally developed.

TRENTON, June 29 (AP) The state Supreme Court today refused to recognize different tax assessment standards for commercial and residential property in the City of Newark.

LIME ROCK, Conn., June 29 Two hundred and six cars were tuned up today for the Sports Car Club of America national championship point races tomorrow. Most of the leading drivers in the various classes are on hand to participate.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 29 Tax liens against Killenworth, the Soviet estate here, were offered for sale at public auction today. There were no bidders, so the City had to buy them.

Sales of the General Instrument Corporation for its first fiscal quarter ended May 31 increased 4 to 5 per cent from the 1961 level, M.H. Benedek, chairman, told shareholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Newark, N.J. Volume in the 1961 period was $20,400,000.

President Kennedy gained his most important legislative victory with the House's approval of the Trade Expansion Act. He had appealed to Republicans to vote for the measure, and their response helped to provide a truly impressive majority. Thus it was not a partisan triumph but, as Mr. Kennedy himself acknowledged, one that reflected the "national character of the legislation as well as its importance."

The United Nations General Assembly has just adjourned a session that began last September and was twice interrupted. It sat for 155 days, which for a U.N. Assembly may be compared with a twenty-two-inning baseball game. It dealt with ninety-seven items, the final one of which was a doubtlessly well-meant but wasted effort to get the Europeans in Britain's Southern Rhodesia to behave in a more democratic fashion.

LONDON, June 29 Six Winston Churchill underwent a successful operation tonight to mend his broken left thigh.

WASHINGTON, June 29--The nation's railroads told the National Mediation Board today that they were willing to submit to binding arbitration their controversy over work rules with the five train-operating unions.

WASHINGTON, June 29 The House sent to the White House today legislation to require manufacturers to equip future television sets to receive all eighty-tow channels. The President is expected to sign the measure.

MEXICO CITY, June 29 President Adolfo Lopez Mateos, who was inaugurated for a six-year term Dec. 1, 1958, is a grimmer and grayer man as he welcomes President Kennedy to a state visit to Mexico.
WASHINGTON, June 29 Senator Kenneth B. Keating proposed today the creation of a political youth corps to help revitalize Republican leadership in areas where the party was lagging.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 30 --A troika is a Russian sleigh pulled by three horses. When all three horses run in the same direction the troika is a marvelously efficient vehicle. HERMANN HESSE, who was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1946, will be 85 years old tomorrow. Unlike his contemporary, Thomas Mann, Hesse achieved an international reputation only in his later years.

ALGIERS, June 30--The Algerian nationalist Provisional Government dismissed the General Staff of the nationalist army tonight and denounced the "criminal activity" of the three men who composed it.
ORAN, Algeria, June 30-- Moslem crowds took possession today of the center of the city of Oran, the last bastion of diehard European resistants to Algerian independence.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., June 30--John Van Nostrand Dorr, chemical engineer, metallurgist and inventor, died last night at Gaylord Hospital here. He was 90 years old and maintained residences at 30 East Thirtyseventh Street, New York, and Washington, Conn.

WARRENTON, Va., June 30 --Miss Natalie Farrar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Farrar of Warrenton and Palm Beach, Fla., was married here this afternoon to Jacques S. Theriot, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Theriot of Woodstock,

HURLEY, N.Y.-- Once each year, the doors to history are unlocked as this picturesque old town welcomes visitors to one of the most unusual open-house tours in America, Endorsed as a National Historic Site, this pre-Revolutionary War village provides the setting for an annual celebration called Old Stone House Day, and the date this year is July 14.

THE first shock of excitement at the arrival on the international scene of more than a score of newly independent African states is being succeeded by an increasing awareness of the importance of understanding their background and their characteristics.

LIME ROCK, Conn., June 30 --Roger Penske of Gladwyne, Pa., set a one-lap course record and lapped all twenty of his competitors in winning the featured twenty-five-lap race over the one-and-one-half-mile Lime Rock sports-car course today.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 30--Thank heaven for American girls. America's top tennis trio breezed into the quarter-finals today, but for the first time in modern memory there wasn't a man from the States in the last eight at Wimbledon.
School has just let out for the summer, but the pupils of one class at Public School 2 in Queens will continue the regular study of one of their favorite texts until classes begin again in September.
