SARATOGA SPRINGS, June 30--Governor Rockefeller dedicated a $3,500,000 Saratoga Springs State Park today, calling it an "emerald" in the development of the capital district.
PARIS, June 30--Despite a certain amount of concern about the future, the European boom stubbornly refuses to come to an end.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 30 --Patrick O'Neal, sailing Linda Christiansen's La Belle and Henry T. (Hank) Hornidge Jr. at the tiller of Westron Wynde were among the winners today in the third regatta of the Yacht Racing Association's new Westchester Offshore championship series.

BONN--In the Nineteen Twenties, when Bonn was only a sleepy Rhineland town, Max Reinhardt, the famous Berlin stage director, was invited to attend a student performance at one of the city's public schools.

MANTEO, N. C.--A summer-long festival will get under way here today in observance of the 375th anniversary of the final unsuccessful attempt in 1587 by Sir Walter Raleigh and a group of colonists to establish a settlement on Roanoke Island.
CESAR, DARIO is a Latin American revolutionary with incorruptible social ideals, but no moral principles at all when it comes to the means of achieving them.

Lung Yun, the former warlord who died in Peiping last week after serving for twelve years as a minor "democratic front" showpiece for the Chinese Communists, underwent protracted brainwashing in 1957 for lashing out against what he felt were onerous Soviet financial dealings with Communist China. IS it too whimsical to wonder if Dwight L. Moody and Rob ert G. Ingersoll have met in heaven? They should have arrived there almost simultaneously, as both died in 1899. If they have met, doubtless each of them was astonished:
BERKELEY PLANTATION, Va., June 30 (AP)--One hundred years ago next week an American general made history here--not in war but by composing a melody.

STOCKHOLM--There was a time when a ferryboat, regardless of the distance traveled, provided only the necessities of life for its passengers, leaving abundant time for contemplation. But today there has evolved a ferry that can keep passengers on the go from the start of the run to the finish.

SASKATOON, Sask., Sunday, July 1--A compulsory medicalcare plan went into effect in Saskatchewan Province at one minute after midnight today. Last night a majority of the province's doctors said they would not work under it.
MOSCOW, June 30 (AP)--Sin Kim Den of North Korea bettered the world record in the women's 400-meter dash today with a time of 53 seconds.

The postwar growth of Nassau County long ago emptied the hangars and runways of the once famous Roosevelt Field, but an association has been formed to insure that nostalgic memories will always hover over the "cradle of American aviation."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 30 --The marriage of Miss Leslie Courtenay Heye to Sidney Sayre Quarrier Jr. took place here this afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Howard Stone Anderson performed the ceremony in the Scarsdale Congregational Church. He was assisted by the Rev. H. Brevart Cannon of Morristown, N.J.
Mr. and Mrs. Leo Rosten of New York have announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Madeline Sherwood Rosten, to Todd Granville Lee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bailey Lee of Greenwich, Conn.

LOU HAZAM, who goes about as far in historical in-depth as anybody, is now working on televi sion specials about Classical Greece and Shakesperean England.
MEXICO CITY, June 30--President Kennedy and President Adolfo Lopez Mateos declared today that a "new era of understanding and friendship" had been reached between their two countries.
Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said here yesterday that he felt a consitutional amendment should be considered in order to clarify the status of prayer in public schools.

THE sportsman, like the nature photographer, usu ally takes the camera along for the record. If, occasionally, he gets something a notch or two better, as in some of the pictures in "Sportsmen in Action," the exhibit which opened last week at the Kodak Exhibit Center in Grand Central Terminal, even the lay man observer can appreciate some of the results.

THIS is "fun trial" time and the summer's first event for spaniels will be held Saturday at Deer Park on the Stuyvesant estate in Allamuchy, N.J. It will be conducted by the New Jersey Spaniel Field Trial Club.

MONTREAL, June 30--The Social Credit party, Canada's newest political phenomenon, has attempted to reassure the country that it intends to live up to its name.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld.--June 30 -A multi-million-dollar Iron ore development is scheduled to start operations on July 11 at Labrador City, formerly known as Carol Lake, under the auspices of the Iron Ore Company of Canada.

Every seven days or so, a smallish man who didn't drive in a harness race until he was 33 years old boards a sulky to do battle with the formidable stakes horses of Stanley Dancer, Billy Haughton and Del Miller.

MYRTLE BEACH, S. C., June 30 (AP)--A mistake at a proamateur tournament at Clearwater, Fla., five years ago started Mrs. Murle McKenzie Lindstrom, the new United States women's open golf champion, on her way to a career as a professional golfer.
New York City and Nassau County are pressing for an early hearing in the suit by radio station WMCA to force New York State to revise its formula for representation in the Legislature.

KEESVILLE, N.Y.-It was not long ago that all roads in the Adirondack Mountains were of dirt, and the thought of driving on a paved highway was exciting. Today, the situation is reversed. It is the dirt roads that create excitement and beckon a new breed of motorist down the mountain country's dusty paths.
ENDICOTT, N.Y., June 30-- The lone greyhound in a field of 389 took best-in-show honors today in the Susque-Nango Kennel Club's seventh dog show and obedience trial.
CLEVELAND. CLEVELAND is a gardenminded city. Beautiful parks abound, garden clubs thrive, and home owners plant and dig with know-how.
YONKERS, June 30--Silver Song overtook favored Air Record at the halfway pole and went on to win by a neck tonight in the $15,000 free-for-all mile trot at Yonkers Raceway.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP)--Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg announced today the appointment of a thirteen-member group to be known as the Advisory Council on Employee Welfare and Pension Benefit Plans. The appointees will serve two-year terms.

Pan American World Airways will operate its 100,000th trans-Atlantic flight tomorrow when a jet Clipper takes off from New York International Airport for London, Frankfurt and around the world to San Francisco.

EASLEY BLACKWOOD of Indianapolis, whose meth od of slam-bidding is used by more millions of play ers throughout the world than use any single bidding system, is in the anomalous position of being celebrated but not a celebrity.
CAIRO, June 30--President Gamal Abdel Nasser presented a record budget to the United Arab Republic today. It reflected the higher cost of administering his Socialist Government.

BETTING on a sure thing, the Brooklyn Museum has pulled a new show out of its vault, a por trait of London in the middle of the eighteenth century as one man saw it. The man being William Hogarth, who investigated everything from high life in brothels to low life

Pleasure boating teaches its skippers some strange new experiences and delights. They learn that week-ends can be stretched into playtime interludes of four days--from Friday through Monday. These weekends become bonuses, not deductible from annual vacations.

At a time when stock values are in doubt, gold and silver have a glitter all their own. Brokers report that more and more investors are asking about shares in gold and silver producing companies, propmted probably by many brokerage-firm letters sug-, gesting them.
Authorities here said yesterday there was little chance that the persons who put up $100,000 bail for Dr. Robert A. Soblen could get their money back after the spy was returned to the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Ewan Clague, Commissioner of Labor Statistics in the Department of Labor, has always been concerned about loose use of the data his bureau gathers and distributes. He is known for the care that he gives to his own interpretations, and for his avoidance of politically tinged controversy.

Old-line New York families, unwilling to part with property they and their forebears acquired, but not averse to having their property bring in additional revenue, are leasing their sites to builders of cooperative apartment houses.

WASHINGTON. THE morality of men who hold public office--a matter being brought forcibly to public atten tion in the case involving Billie Sol Estes--has been a subject of concern throughout the history of the United States.
BUENOS AIRES, June 27-- A sharply critical analysis of the Argentine way of life has caused a stir here. It is said to have been written by economists working for military leaders.

THAT strange looking bird that has been flapping its noisy wings over Manhattan for the past two weeks, circling below the upper floors of skyscrapers and peering into offices, will go to work today carrying paying passengers for New York Airways at nearly twice the speed of the old helicopters.
NEWTOWN, Conn., June 30 --The six-member Newtown Board or Education resigned unexpectedly last night after a long controversy with the Superintendent of Schools.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., June 30--Miss Mary Ann Warner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Warner Jr. of Laurel Hollow, was married this afternoon to Tarrant Putnam. He is a son of Mrs. Arthur M. Crocker of Laurel Hollow and Harrington Putnam of New York.

OAXACA, State of Oaxaca, Mexico--A magnificent and authentically ancient twin festival takes place on a 350-foot hill just outside this city the last two Mondays in July. Each year, these ceremonial rites bring to life the proud history of the Zapotec Indians who have inhabited this part of southern Mexico since before the Conquest, four centuries ago.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., June 30-- The saddest thing in American political life is a circus tent rally by the party out of power.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 30--Here in the heart of the Catskills, where sunshine and sour cream mix well, vacationers loll leisurely under the sun seven afternoons each week. Then, on six out of seven nights, they switch to the frenzy that accompanies harness racing under the lights at Monticello Raceway.

AMERICANS paid more than $53 billion to go places in 1961, or about $1 in every $10 that was spent for all goods and services, according to a recent study by the Transportation Association of America. The nation's bill, for freight handling and transportation, the report said, cost another $1 out of every $10 spent, or about $47 billion.

EFFORTS of stamp collectors to curb an overflow of new issues, mostly directed toward the Amer ican market, received added impetus through a resolution adopted by the American Topical Association at its mid-June convention in Colorado Springs, Colo.

AMONG the most enjoyable and illuminating of true crime books have been those which studied in some detail the crimes of a particular region--the Duell, Sloan Pearce "Regional Murders" series ("New York Murders," etc.), Manly Wade Wellman's "Dead and Gone" (about North Carolina) or Roberf Tallant's "Ready to Hang" (about New Orleans).

The publication of the 1961 edition of The New York Times Index, which summarizes the day-by-day history of the world as reported in The Times, was announced yesterday by Joseph Curtin Gephart, editor.

A business man is always on the defensive, either against his customers or his suppliers. A manufacturer dealing with a retailer, for instance, must defend his pricing policy.

LIMA, Peru, June 30--The final official tabulations of the June 10 election ballots showed last night that no candidate had received the necessary one-third of the valid votes for election as President. As a result, the new Congress which convenes July 28, will have to elect the President.
USUMBURA, Burundi, Sunday, July 1--At the stroke of midnight last night independence came to Rwanda and Burundi, two of the smallest, poorest and least-known territories on the African Continent.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 30 --Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Carolyn Bunting Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Davis Levis Lewis Jr., to Stewart Samuel Richmond. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Smith Richmond of Concord, N.H.
One of the best ways to increase the supply of a favorite plant is to root cuttings. This is a relatively simple process; the plants do all the work. The gardener just lends a guiding hand.

Spending on new building projects set a monthly record in June. The rate was almost $63,000,000,000 on a seasonally adjusted annual basis, according to the Census Bureau. The previous record rate was $61,000; 000,000, set last November.

The salesman, memorably characterized by Willy Loman in Arthur Miller's play "Death of a Salesman" as a man "riding on a smile and a shoeshine," generally gets a cold shoulder from the builders of Manhattan's towering office structures.
LONDON, June 30--Hundreds of Pakistanis, West Indians and Cypriotes jammed British airports and seaports today, the last immigrants from the Commonwealth to arrive on an unrestricted basis.
Thirty years ago, physicians advised their patients to move to Washington. Heights for its "mountain" air and its pure drinking water.
GREAT SAND DUNES NATIONAL MONU MENT, Colo. -- All kinds of attractions were added this past winter at this strange, cosmic freak of the Rocky Mountains.

DURING this year, some 800,000 Americans will visit Europe and return, tired and happy, but just a slight bit sorry to be home again. Why the disappointment? Because, with recollections of Europe fresh in mind, most American cities don't stand up well to comparison.

The first all-plastic piping expressly designed for hot water lines throughout the house has been perfected and soon will be installed in key cities as a test of its acceptability under plumbing codes. The plumbing fittings weigh one-third to one-tenth as much as their conventional metal counterparts.

Although most schools in the United States posted the financial distress signal last year, at least one segment of the academic spectrum reported a profit.
Two national champions, Elfsborg of Sweden and Panathinaicos of Greece, will meet today in the opening doubleheader of the International Soccer League's second section at Randalls Island Stadium.

MYRTLE BEACH, S.C., June 30--Mrs. Murle McKenzie Lindstrom, who had planned to make it her last tournament after five years without a victory, made up five strokes in the last eighteen holes today and won the national women's open golf championship by two shots.
DIRECT personal knowledge of the Communists is not the only thing, it seems clear, that distinguishes the novels of Arthur Koestler from those, say, of Ian Fleming.
One bedroom units will predominate in a group of seven apartment buildings being erected as part of Carlyle Towers, a Queens residential development. The first tow structures were cooperatives.
Fighting off a strong challenge in the stretch, David K. of the Harbor View Farm won the $28,350 Saranac Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

The Permanent Administrative Committee, which oversees wages in voluntary hospitals, disclaimed yesterday an announcement that subscribing hospitals would meet on Tuesday to plan joint action in a strike situation.
BALBOA, C.Z., June 30-- For the tenth year, the Panama Canal has set a record for putting through commercial ships that are big enough to ply the high seas. Other records were also topped.

STANTON, Del., June 30 (AP) -Polarity, flying the Hill-nDale Farm silks of Mrs. Ray Wines, Jessup, Md., took the $30,900 Sussex Turf Handicap today before 20,283 Delaware Park fans.
CHICAGO, June 30--Early Wynn, struggling to reach the 300-victory mark, pitched the Chicago White Sox to a fivehit, 7-0 triumph over the Cleveland Indians today.
ST. LOUIS, June 30 (AP)-- Smoky Burgess drove in seven runs tonight; four with two homers, and Roberto Clemente batted in five as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 17--7.
WASHINGTON, July 1 The State Department is reorganizing its scientific activities in an attempt to make science a more important factor in the formulation and execution of foreign policy.
ALMOST thirty chairs line the entrance hall of a Park Avenue duplex. Although of different styles and periods, they have two traits in common. Each is a collector's item and none was made to sit on.
LONDON, July 1--Like New York, London has its Shakespeare in the park.

Several Protestant clergymen in the New York area expressed varied, but generally favorable, opinions in their sermons yesterday on the Supreme Court's decision barring an official prayer in the public schools.
The Yankees moved into first place in the torrid American League pennant race yesterday, but they didn't quite make it with the impressive splurge usually associated with the world champions.
A retired Methodist Bishop characterized the present age yesterday as one in which childhood weaknesses of pretension and limited knowledge were carried over into adulthood.
A boy believed to be Yosef Schuhmacher, a 10-year-old Israeli whose kidnapping touched off three years of bitter religious and legal controversy, has been found in Brooklyn,
TOKYO, Monday, July 2 Japan's ruling Liberal-Democratic party today again won control of the upper house of the Diet, or Parliament, in national elections yesterday.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that in the hectic market days of late May only 2 per cent of the dollar value of all Big Board transactions involved the liquidation of securities to meet margin calls by member firms.

Goldsmith Bros., one of the country's largest stationers with a headquarters store and offices at 77 Nassau Street, has leased a store for a branch at 304, 306 and 308 Madison Avenue in the former Union Carbide and Carbon Building, between Forty-first and Fortysecond Streets.

CLEAR skies and light music filled the air at Lewisohn Stadium Saturday night as 8,500 persons gathered to sip some sparkling concoctions skimmed from four Broadway shows by Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe "Brigadoon," "Paint Your Wagon," "Camelot" and "My Fair Lady" and from their movie "Gigi."
The brokerage concern of Burnham Co. said yesterday that it had refused to honor a put on E.L. Bruce Company stock for fear of violating Securities and Exchange Commission rules on control stock.

LOS ANGELES, July 1 Don Drysdale, the 6-foot-6-inch right-handed star of the Dodgers, struck out thirteen Mets today en route to becoming baseball's first fourteen-game winner this season. The score was 5 1.
Drivers for the United Parcel Service accepted yesterday the terms they had twice rejected for settling their seven-week-old strike.
WASHINGTON, July 1 An obscure organization of World War I veterans appears to be forcing a reluctant Congress to consider a liberal and controversial pension bill.
Automobiles will determine their own traffic light patterns along Riverside Drive before the end of the year.

A RIPE fresh mango, with its skin of yellow over laid with red, looks as fiery as the curry it traditionally accompanies in chutney form. Yet the fruit is cool in flavor, jucy in texture and has a musky aroma. Mangoes are delicious eaten raw aid, because much of the aroma is lost by prior slicing, they generally are served whole.

HERSHEY, Pa., July 1 Governor Rockefeller said today he hoped to recommend to the next session of the New York Legislature the principles he believes should govern the development of a new legislative representation system.
THE bizarre career of a man under a life and death sentence took another bizarre turn yesterday when he was taken to a London hospital after a suicide attempt.

Two different groups work to increase the popularity of contract bridge. To one group the game is a profession, to the other a hobby, but the two have always agreed that the place to start is in the teen ages, with high school and college students.

New Yorkers took advantage of a sunny and seasonably warm day yesterday by flocking to the beaches and amusement parks. Many strolled through the city parks. Others crowded aboard the naval flotilla docked at the Hudson River piers to see sights and chat with sailors.

WASHINGTON, July 1 White House and State Department officials worked throughout the week-end here trying to avert a major crisis in United States relations with the Dominican Republic over this country's new sugar legislation.

A garment cutters' union has been ordered by the State Commissions for Human Rights to arrange for employment of a Negro at union rates commensurate with his skill and to admit the Negro into union memberships if his work is satisfactory.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 1 Significant developments noted by the United Nations in the world economic survey of 1961, published today, include the diminishing capacity of many potential borrowers among less-developed nations to carry new external debt.
PARIS, July 1 It was a quiet, ordinary Sunday here today as 132 years of French power in Algeria closed with a vote across the Mediterranean.
MEXICO CITY, July 1--President Kennedy left Mexico today after having received the applause of crowds as enthusiastic as those that greeted him Friday.

THE record of television in the United States was a major consideration in persuading the Committee on Broadcasting in Great Britain, headed by Sir Harry Pilkington, to frown on the thought of more commercial TV without drastic reforms.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., July 1 This was a week-end of reverence, fun, nostalgia and near tragedy as the Italian fishermen of Gloucester honored St. Peter, their patron saint, with their thirty-first annual fiesta.
CALCUTTA, India, July 1 Dr. Bidhan Chandra Roy, Chief Minister of the state of West Bengal and one of India's foremost national leaders, died of a stroke today on his eightieth birthday.

MOST supposedly educated citizens of our enlightened society have no interest in words, use them clumsily and when they can't find the words to express their primitive thoughts say: "Know what I mean?" John Moore's new book, "You English Words,"* is not intended for the likes of them. It is a book for those who
ALGIERS, July 1 Moslems danced in the streets and embraced Europeans tonight in a wild celebration of Algerian independence.

WASHINGTON, July 1 President Kennedy has told a leading banker that he believes increased business profits to be desirable, but that the sound, sure road to that goal is growth and a greater use of capacity.

LANGHORNE, Pa., July 1 Hugh Randall, a 29-year-old driver from Louisville, was killed today in an end-over-end flip during the 100-mile Indianapolis car race on the one-mile Langhorne Speedway dirt track.
ORAN, Algeria, July 1--Europeans of Oran voted today in large numbers, in a sharp and sudden reversal of attitudes.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 1 The International one-design sloop, No. 19, which once dominated the class in Yacht Racing Association competition on Western Long Island Sound, won today for the first time in nearly two years.
ROME, July 1 The powerful Italian Hydrocarbons Authority accused international oil interests today of using the United States Senate to discredit it.

Three new African nations were born yesterday. Algerians, exhausted by years of bitter struggle, fired their guns in rejoicing as they trooped to the polls to vote independence of France. Closer to the heart of the restless continent, the Belgian flag was hauled down in formal token of self-rule for two of Africa's most impoverished territories, henceforth to be known as Rwanda and Burundi.
Bathers will not be able to use the city beaches to be built in the next few years unless marginal sewage pollution is ended, Park Commissioner Newbold Morris warned yesterday.
HERSHEY, Pa., July 1 The Governors of New York, California and Ohio endorsed today an immediate Federal tax cut.
WASHINGTON, July 1 President Kennedy has ordered 1,000 of the 1,800 United States Marines in Thailand to return to their ships, the Defense Department announced today.
The city's Labor Department announced yesterday a new program to speed the handling of complaints by members against their labor unions.
LOS ANGELES, July 1 (AP) When the Los Angeles Dodgers signed Sandy Koufax eight years ago, they knew the raw material had enormous potential. The trick was to harness it.

ATLANTA, July 1--Delegates to the convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People were encouraged today to demonstrate their disapproval of hotels and restaurants here who turn them away.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 1 "The ship must desert the rats." This has become the mocking rallying cry at the studio of Twentieth CenturyFox.

WASHINGTON, July 1 Despite asusrances by Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara, members of the House Armed Services Committee are concerned about what they believe to be a calculated downgrading of the military departments in favor of extreme service unification.

ALGIERS, Monday, July 2 More than 70 per cent of Algeria's 5,000,000 eligible voters balloted yesterday to pile up a massive majority for independence in cooperation with France. Europeans as well as Moslems generally voted in favor of ending 132 years of French rule.

The United States Tax Court in three recent instances had news for taxpayers with medical expenses. Two rulings brought good news and the third mixed news. In one, a man who developed a lung infection in cold weather wintered in Florida on doctor's advice. While there, he found it necessary to taxi to a restaurant that would prepare salt-free food.

WASHINGTON, July 1--The Zionist Organization of America urged the United States to continue its aid to Middle East states and insisted that such aid not be utilized for an arms build-up that would "threaten the stability of the entire Middle East."
Fourth of July travelers will face most of the same traffic bottlenecks that existed over the Memorial Day holiday.
TRIPOLI, Libya, July 1 An open power struggle split the Algerian nationalist leadership today as the huge territory held its independence referendum.

A distinguished Soviet mathematician has called for Soviet schools to train creative scholars who can think rather than merely turn out human robots "whose chief virtue is blind fulfillment of orders."

EARLY last season Leon Wagner, an outfielder with a wry sense of humor, discovered that he was moving on almost even terms with Roger Maris and Mickey Mantle in the home-run derby. So he raised a reflective eyebrow and offered a whimsical observation to his boss, Bill Rigney, the manager of the Los Angeles Angels.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 The Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia and Robert C. Lea 3d, a Harvard sophomore also from this city, qualified today to row against the Soviet Union in the eight-oared and single sculls finals of the Independence Day regatta here.
RABAT, Morocco, July 1 Morocco reassured the future Algerian regime today that she believed that border disputes in the Sahara should be settled by negotiations and not by force.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 For the first time in memory, American men have come to the end of the road in the singles competition of the world lawn tennis championships with half the tournament still to be played.

The Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, where 10-year-old Yosef Schuhmacher apparently had been living, is populated by Hasidic Jews so Orthodox that women, when married, cut off their hair and wear wigs not deemed a temptation.

PARIS, July 1 It would be illusory to assume that creation of an independent Algerian state, which will result from today's referendum, can suddenly produce stability in that scarred and bloody land. The problem only now begins.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 1 President Joao Goulart nominated today the President of the Senate, Dr. Auro Soares de Moura Andrade, as Premier of Brazil.

Former Presidents Dwight D. Eisenhower and Herbert Hoover will evaluate earlier White House occupants--Lincoln and Wilson, respectively--on half-hour programs to be televised next season by the National Broadcasting Company.

PARIS, July 1 Gen. Rene Marie Edgard de Larminat, the head of a special military court set up to try Raoul Salan and other Right-wing terrorists, committed suicide in his home here last night. He was 66 years old.
More than 35,000 patients visited the Brooklyn Longshoremen's Medical Center in the six months to March 31, the center reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) Pressure continued to mount in Congress today for a tax cut this year. The aim would be to stimulate the economy, even though such a cut would enlarge a projected budget deficit.

BONN, Germany, July 1 Franz Josef Strauss, West Germany's embattled Defense Minister, asserted today that he had been chosen as the target of a Communist defamation campaign. At the same time he denied that he had offered his resignation.
PARIS, July 1 Algeria's vote for independence today will remove a diplomatic millstone from the neck of France and the West.

Saturday was the day of reckoning for most mutual funds. June 30 marked the end of the first half, which meant that figures closed on the worst period in the postwar mutual fund world. There was nothing that could be done beyond that day to alter the true figures on performance in the down market.
The voice of the television announcer is loud and imploring. "Parents," it says, "help your children get better school grades now! And help them earn up to $150,000 more in the future!"
USUMBURA, Burundi, July 1 The former Belgian territory of Ruanda-Urundi became the separate and free nations of Rwanda and Burundi today.
WASHINGTON, July 1--In the long history of the Supreme Court few of the court's terms have equaled in significance the one that ended last Monday.

STRATEGY and tactics, the making and enforcing of plans, are the alternating currents of the chess game. The function of strategy is to project ever changing designs and that of tactics to perform them.
The Liberal party has added its support to the drive to block Board of Estimate approval of the $100,000,000 Lower Manhattan Crosstown Expressway.

The big surprise so far of the national fencing championships, which moved into its second day of competition at the Park Sheraton yesterday, has been little Steve Werre. The surprise is that Steve, a 105-pound sandy-haired youngster, showed up.
WASHINGTON, July 1 The real signs and sounds of the times came in incidental intelligence here this week.

The Supreme Court's decision on prayer in the public schools has imparted a new highly emotional twist to the Federal aid-to-education controversy, making it a bigger issue than ever in the 1962 Congressional campaign. It has quickly become evident that the widespread protests against the de

REGINA, Sask., July 1 (AP) Many of the 700 physicians in Saskatchewan Province began closing their offices today. They were going on vacations or leaving the province to practice elsewhere in a strike against North America's first compulsory medical care plan.
WASHINGTON, July 1 The Kennedy Administration is beginning to debate in private what it means by a "partnership" between the United States and Western Europe.
The Most Rev. Francis Reh, the new Bishop of Charleston, S.C., yesterday celebrated his first pontifical mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, where he was consecrated Friday by Cardinal Spellman.

Rachel Carson, who has charmed readers with her rhapsodic accounts of the natural life of the sea and the seashore, has written a three-part series for The New Yorker that few will read without a chill, no matter how hot the weather.
NEW DELHI, India, July 1 Purshottamdas Tandon, former president of the ruling Congress party, died today in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh. He was 80 years old.
THE modern permanent, which stems from the invention of the Marcel wave in 1872 has reached what is considered to be the peak of its curling career.
Dr. Robert A. Soblen slashed his left wrist and stabbed himself in the abdomen in a suicide attempt yesterday aboard an airliner carrying him back to New York from Israel.

CHICAGO, July 1 Al Oerter of the New York Athletic Club reclaimed the world discus throw record tonight as a powerful American men's track and field team completed a rout of Poland's formidable team in their two-day dual meet. His distance was 204 feet 10 inches.
Major labor and management interests in the merchant marine have set up an arbitration apparatus designed to halt the dissension that threatens the very life of the industry.

NEWPORT, R.I, July 1 It will be Columbia against Nefertiti and Easterner against Weatherly tomorrow in the first competition of the yachting trials that will lead to the selection of an America's Cup defender.

WASHINGTON, July 2--The Administration is making an intensive re-examination of its position on a nuclear test ban treaty to determine whether any modifications should be made to meet objections of the Soviet and neutralist blocs.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 3-- Japan's conservatives claimed today a solid vote of public confidence in the economic policies that have helped this country rise from the ashes of war to its greatest heights of industrial power.

Racing returned to utilitarian Aqueduct yesterday after a twenty-six-day session at arboreal Belmont Park. A biggerthan-usual Monday crowd of 34,081 turned out for the activity, which was headed by the fifth running of the Liberty Belle Handicap for fillies and mares at six furlongs.

World sugar futures rose nearly 14 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) at the opening of trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. They dropped off, however, during the day, when early buyers resold pending the final outcome of the new sugar legislation.
The high-grade bond market yesterday was a session marked by a drift to inactivity and to slightly lower prices.
The Board of Education indicated yesterday that it would place greater emphasis in its future plans on improving instructional programs and involving the community in school planning.
BUENOS AIRES, July 2--A high Argentine internal security official has resigned in protest over what he charged were inadequate measures to combat an outburst of anti-Semitism.
Darryl F. Zanuck, the film producer, called yesterday for a special meeting of stockholders of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation.
The City Council will receive a bipartisan bill today to amend the new City Charter along lines recommended by the Citizens Union and an affiliated group of business and civic organizations.
An Israeli woman was reunited here last night with her 10-year-old son, who had been abducted three years ago in Jerusalem in a family dispute over his religious education.
BALTIMORE, July 2 (AP)-- Fraser Gange, Scottish baritone, died last night of a stroke. He was 76 years old.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2 --At the Twentieth Century-Fox studio the set of "A Woman in July" is a tiny island of creativity in a restless sea of idleness.

The analysis by the Council for Financial Aid to Education of gifts to American colleges and universities is a reassertion of the nation's willingness and ability to support a vast and diverse system of higher education. During the 1960-61 year well over a billion dollars was contributed by alumni, friends, foundations and corporations. This represented a 28.1 per cent increase over the 1958-59 period, the last aca-...
DENVER, July 2--The National Education Association gave the signal at its annual convention today for a new battle with its traditional union rival, the American Federation of Teachers.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 2--DeWitt Van Buren, a retired real estate lawyer, an authority on real estate appraisals and an educator, died yesterday in Greenwich Hospital after a short illness. He was 81 years old and lived at 76 Maple Avenue.

MADRID, July 2--William Bass, 37-year-old American businessman from Chicago, was sentenced by a Spanish superior court here today to a year in prison on accusations of disrespectful acts toward Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

Supreme Court Justice Abraham N. Geller yesterday was asked to set aside as excessive a jury's award of $3,500,000 to John Henry Faulk in his libel suit against Aware, Inc., Vincent W. Hartnett and the late Lawrence A. Johnson.
GENEVA, July 2--The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has called for the opening of negotiations with the oil companies concerning a crude price rise.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 2-- Time seems to be running out for Alcatraz Prison, the place where time stands still.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 2--Congolese and United Nations officials arrived today for talks on the new crisis in the Congo created by the collapse of negotiations to end the secession of Katanga Province.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 2--A special committee in effect recommended today that the 129-year-old fraternity system be eliminated from the campus of Williams College here.

Confetti and friendly words cannot, of course, settle all issues between the United States and Mexico. But friendliness of the intensity reflected in Mexico's welcome to President Kennedy gives a basis on which to proceed.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2-- Gene Woodling, a stocky 40year-old who has seen twentytwo professional baseball summers, belted a three-run double tonight that lifted the Mets to an 8-5 victory and pushed the Giants out of the National League lead.

Cowen Co., stock brokerage concern, said yesterday that it had refused to honor options to sell stock of the E.L. Bruce Company and the Celotex Corporation because it believed acceptance of the options might violate Federal securities regulations.
Net operating earnings of the Irving Trust Company during the first six months of 1962 were $7,907,653, or $1.43 a share, compared with $8,019,390, for $1.45 a share, in the like l961 period.
"RAISIN' HELL IN THE SON," which opened last night at the Provincetown Playhouse, examines the relations between Negroes and whites, and it is, unfortunately, an embarrassing failure.

Louis Abrams, realty operator, has purchased the fivestory apartment house for thirty-eight families at 15 East 196th Street, the Bronx, from Fay Rosenthal. The property, with a plot 75 by 100 feet, was sold for cash over mortgages of $152,000. Leonard, Levites, Schiller, Inc., and Philip Gold were the brokers.

Nuclear physicists may be pardoned if they sometimes wonder whether nature is not playing a series of perverse jokes on them. A few years ago, for example, they were startled by the discovery that in certain nuclear phenomena--the so-called weak interactions--the law of parity, which had previously been regarded as a basic principle of physics, does not hold. Now comes similarly surprising news about that most elusive of nuclear particles--the neutrino, an entity with...

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2--Rafael Osuna of Mexico and the University of Southern California was eliminated today as four Australians, including the first brother act since the turn of the century, reached the Wimbledon tennis semi-finals.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 2-- Nefertiti, the new Boston 12meter yacht, showed today that she was a fast, well-sailed boat in her first start. She beat Columbia in the opening race of the America's Cup defense elmination trials.

IN many families, the picnic will be as important a part of tomorrow's holiday festivities as the fireworks. Although the cold picnic has not changed radically over the years, it continues to rival outdoor barbecue cooking. Here are a few menus reported from here and abroad that may inspire the home chef to more imaginative summer preparations.

WASHINGTON, July 2--Secret documents of the Trujillo dictatorship, now available for the first time, tell a story of intensive Dominican lobbying in the United States Congress in an effort to increase Dominican sugar profits.
Where are the rail stocks? Holding up better than quite a few industrials, according to a study by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis.
TRENTON, July 2--The State Supreme Court upheld unanimously today the validity of a recently enacted law extending the horse racing season at three New Jersey tracks.
MADISON, Wis., July 2--Gov. Gaylord Nelson vetoed today two bills passed last week by the Republican-controlled Legislature to reapportion Wisconsin's Congressional and state legislative districts.
WASHINGTON, July 2-- President Kennedy has told United States career diplomats that he wants more decisions and more ideas from the State Department, and he wants them "with more speed."
PARIS, July 2 (UPI)--Peter Ryan, 24 years old, of Mont Tremblant, Que., died today of injuries received when his racing car somersaulted off the track in a qualification run yesterday at Rhiems.
The stock market continues its recovery into the summer quarter in a session yesterday that saw $6,500,000,000 added to over-all valuations.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 2--Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Mrs. Nixon, who are here for the Fourth of July celebrations in Rebild, had lunch today at the East Asiatic Company's headquarters with prominent Danish business people.

A marine engineers union announced yesterday that it would extend its picketing, to include all forty-three ships of American Export Lines. It has been picketing--as they arrived in ports--fourteen ships that were recently transferred from the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., to American Export.
ATLANTA, July 2--This city of 1,000,000 persons played the uneasy host today to three organizations--one seeking racial equality, one opposing it and one with no expressed interest in the issue.

ALGIERS, July 2--Moslem policemen closed off European quarters of Algiers tonight to give the Europeans a chance to sleep after twenty-four hours of ecstatic Moslem celebration over the vote for independence yesterday.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) July 2--Israel's Minister of the Interior, Moshe Haim Shapiro, will propose to the Cabinet on Sunday that the state drop all further prosecution of persons involved in the abduction of Yosef Schuhmacher, a source close to the Minister said tonight.

WE live in what you might call the age of "the age of" books. If our time is not labeled, say, "The Age of Anxiety" much the same effect can be achieved-- terribly ironically, of course--by calling it "The Age of Happy Problems."
The big national magazines may be having their problems nowadays, but there is at least one segment of the magazine industry that seems to be burgeoning.

The dialogue President Kennedy sought with business men has begun in the form of an exchange of letters with David Rockefeller, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank. Their differences, in the main, are in degree, not kind. Mr. Rockefeller urges increased efforts to cut the deficit in our balance of payments and suggests that a higher level of domestic interest rates is needed, along with lower taxes and more effective control over expenditures.

The only book published today is Margaret Millar's new novel of suspense, called "How Like An Angel." The story deals with a private investigator and a quasi-religious organization that hired him. Random House is the publisher and the book sells for $3.50.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) --The Senate cleared the way today for full-dress debate on a compromise proposal for old age health care under Social Security, but then a appeared little prospect of a vote before the end of the week.
GENEVA, July 2--The fourteen-nation conference on Laos resumed today and the signs from the first session after a five-month recess were considered cheering.

THE sustained exposure of children to television pro grams portraying violence has been so exhaustively and fruitlessly discussed in the United States that the topic has very nearly worn itself out. But if American parents are somewhat resigned to the inevitability of a high diet of mayhem on the screen, it is not true for many adults in other parts of the world.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 2-- Kerby H. Fisk, board chairman and chief executive officer of the Allied Chemical Corporation in New York, died this morning in Palm Beach, Fla., where he was on a business trip. His home was at 185 Gates Avenue here.

Seventeen salesmen were questioned by a special Kings County grand jury yesterday in an effort to break up what District Attorney Edward S. Silver called a "fraud against generous householders and legitimate organizations trying to help the blind."
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) --J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, advocates fingerprinting of teachers and other school employes to screen out potential child molesters.

PARIS, July 2--Frenchmen today found their satisfaction at Algeria's overwhelming and peaceful approval of independence yesterday tempered by great disquiet at the factionalism that has broken out among the men who are to assume responsibility for running the country.

The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday it would make available free television documentary and public affairs programing to overseas countries where television is just emerging. Among the countries to be supplied initially are four in Africa and one in the Middle East.
ALBANY, July 2--The Rev. Dr. Stuart Hamilton Merriam, ousted minister of the Broadway Presbyterian Church in Manhattan, lost his appeal for reinstatement here tonight.
MOSCOW, July 2--Premier Khrushchev warned tonight that the Soviet Union would join in repelling any attack on Communist China.

State Supreme Court Justice A. David Benjamin offered yesterday to serve as peacemaker in the labor dispute at Beth-El Hospital, Linden and Rockaway Hospital, Linden Boulevard and Rockaway Parkway, Brooklyn. The offer was accepted by lawyers for the institution and the striking union.

Quemoy and Matsu, small Nationalist-held islands a few miles off the Chinese mainland, are again the center of crisi. Premier Khrushchev focused attention on them anew yesterday by warning that the Soviet Union would support Communist China in the face of "provocations" in the area.
LONDON, July 2--Dr. Robert A. Soblen will be placed aboard a plane for New York as soon as he is well enough to travel, an official at the British Home Office said today.

BONN, Germany, July 2-- The Justice ministries of five West German states reported today that several dozen judges and prosecutors who had been involved in pronouncing sentences in Nazi courts had asked to retire.
WASHINGTON, July 2--Interest costs of new Treasury short-term securities soared today on the regular weekly sale.
Representative Samuel S. Stratton of Schenectady asserted yesterday that every poll showed him to be "the grassroots choice" of Democrats for Governor.
The Lone Star Cement Company of New York announced yesterday that it planned to acquire the Southern Materials, Company of Norfolk, Va.

BRASILIA, July 2--President Joao Goulart's nominee for Premier, Dr., Auro Soares de Moura Andrade, said today that an attack on inflation would be "the first order of business" of the Government he is expected to head.
An attempt by the Board of Regents to censor the motion picture "The Connection" on the ground of obscenity was overruled yesterday by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) --Senator Barry Goldwater, the Republican conservative spokesman from Arizona, condemned today the proposed All-Republican Conference backed by formet President Dwight D. Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) --The House approved a resolution today that its sponsors said would assure better radio service for millions of Americans.
The American consumer is still "soberly optimistic"' and by no means afraid to buy, the University of Michigan Survey Research Center reported yesterday in Ann Arbor, Mich.

City Council President Paul R. Screvane presided at a ceremonial as Acting Mayor yesterday and found that sometimes the path of the city's chief executive is a rough one. For a few moments $250,000 was missing.
The police and safety officials yesterday hung an "extra danger" sign on this year's Independence Day celebration.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 2, --Work on defense projects at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology was not immediately affected today by a strike of 1,350 employes of the institute.

ROME, July 2--The Government's recent decision to nationalize the electric power industry has led to country-wide discussion whether the Italian state can cope adequately with the heavy additional tasks involved.
PARIS, July 2--Chancellor Adenauer of West Germany arrived in Paris today for a weeklong visit designed to set the seal on French-German reconciliation, the keystone of European unity.
LONDON, July 2--A new edition of Roget's Thesaurus of English Words and Phrases, with a slight American accent, appeared here today.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) --Arch Roberts, who was an side to former Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker, sued the Army today for having dismissed him from active duty over a controversial speech.
WASHINGTON--July 2 (AP) --The Senate Finance Committee heard another barrage of testimony today against the foreign income sections of President Kennedy's tax revision bill.
Peter Carver, designer and builder of ice-skating rinks in this country and abroad, was arraigned yesterday in General Sessions Court on a charge of having obtained $111,034 by fraud.
A State Supreme Court justice was accused yesterday of obstructing an inquiry into "ambulance-chasing" in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, July 2--The Senate approved a compromise sugar bill tonight and sent it to the White House. It gives the United States producers a bigger share of the domestic market and continues premium payments for foreign sugar.
MOSCOW, July 2--A Soviet conservationist warned today that mismanagement of the water resources in Central Asia threatened the fish and wildlife in the region's desert lakes with extinction.

REGINA, Sask. July 2--Fear and anxiety prevailed today among the 928,000 citizens of Saskatchewan as this prairie province passed its second day of a physicians' strike against a compulsory medical care plan.
Business continues strong for the world's largest corporate enterprise.
The New York Travelers Aid Society will benefit from the Blue Grass Ball, to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza Sept. 27. Mrs. Conrad W. Thibault is chairman for the fifteenth annual event.
PHILADELPHIA, July 2-- The premiere of "The American Bell," a $250,000 sound-andlight dramatization of events leading to the Declaration of Independence, enthralled a thousand guests tonight.
Paul Shyre, who established last season the repertory company designed along the lines once drawn by Eugene O'Neill, has abandoned it because "it is not financially feasible."
BUFFALO, July 2 (UPI)-- Gerard G. Dennis, master jewel thief of the nineteen-forties, was freed today from Auburn Prison and promptly deported to Canada.
WASHINGTON, July 2--Cotton brokers who acted as agents for the Government were said today to have made illegal profits by selling Government cotton to themselves.
Half-year sales and earnings of the Corning Glass Works in the period from Jan. 1 to June 17, were the highest in its history, according to the report issued for release today.
ALGONQUIN PARK, Ont., July 2--The philosophy behind Algonquin Provincial Park is much like that of New York State's forest preserve: It is to keep the park "for ever wild."

ROCKPORT, Mass., July 2-- As the herring gulls wheel over the fishing piers in Gloucester, or over the random dumps and piggeries of Cape Ann, a bright green bird will stand out from the others with their sober gray backs.
GOSHEN, N.Y., July 2-- Grand Circuit harness racing, with the usual emphasis on competition among the 2 and 3 year olds, moved into this idyllic village today for the first of five matinee cards.

Instruction about communism, as part of the public school curriculum, is gaining in popularity and professional respectability. But the effectiveness of the teaching is hampered by confusion over objectives and ignorance of facts.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI)--President Kennedy unveiled today a white marble mantel in the White House State Dining Room. He described it as one of "the most notable improvements" in the mansion.
Steel production staged a decline again last week, the prelude to an even sharper drop expected this week.

EMPATHY is a fashionable term these days and prob ably should have its place in bridge. The declarer failed in today's deal because he did not have empathic appreciation of his left-hand opponent's problems.
Schick, Inc., which has been manufacturing only electric shavers and accessories since it was founded in 1930, announced plans yesterday to market its first non-shaving products.
MILWAUKEE, July 2--Robert Byrne of Indianapolis posted his fifth straight victory today in the fifth round of the Western Open Chess Championship Tournament here.
The United Parcel Service announced yesterday that its operations--halted by a sevenweek strike--would be back to normal by Thursday.

HERSHEY, Pa., July 2-- Republicans in Congress believe that President Kennedy's popularity is slipping, but Democratic Governors attending the national Governors Conference here are scrambling for his campaign services next fall.

STANTON, Del., July 2 (AP) --Cordon R. Potter, the trainer of Crimson Satan, was suspended indefinitely today by the Delaware Park Stewards. They have been investigating administration of a medication to Potter's 3-year-old colt.
Cotton futures were 15 cents a bale down to 25 cents up on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.
RABAT, Morocco, July 2-- Algerian Nationalist Army officers on the "western front" went into open rebellion today against the Algerian Provisional Government.

HERSHEY, Pa., July 2--The Governors Conference agreed today, after a lengthy parliamentary wrangle, to consider a request to Congress to propose a constitutional amendment to permit the saying of prayers in public schools.

SAN DIEGO, CALIF. LOOKING don on gleaming San Diego Bay and its budding metropolis from El Cortez Hill, it is hard to visualize trouble in this Southern California bid for paradise. The seimitar-shaped harbor is dotted with destroyers, cruisers and small craft.
The city gave a present to its youngsters yesterday-- thirty-nine whole blocks.

Even the clubs just beyond the outer fringe of the tightly packed American League pennant race seem determined to make it tough for the Yankees. The Bombers beat the Athletics, 8--4, last night but it wasn't easy.
LAST week's protest in this space against the New York Board of Rabbis' protest against "The Merchant of Venice" has in turn brought a flood of protests to this desk. The circle has been completed.

PLANS to establish in Paris a museum of wigs, hair styles and ornaments through the ages are being made by a leading French hair stylist, according to Reuters. Alexandre, the 40year-old "hairdresser to queens," is said to be unhappy over the fact that Paris has virtually every kind of museum, including the "Carnavalet," for clothes and costumes, but none for coiffures.
The Wellington Fund reported over the week-end that its net assets rose by $10,403,000 in the twelve months ended on May 31.

CHICAGO, July 2 (UPI)-- The heavyweight champion, Floyd Patterson, and the challenger, Sonny Liston, will wear eight-ounce gloves and take the mandatory 8-count in case of knockdowns in their title bout Sept. 25, it was disclosed today by Joe Triner, the chairman of the Illinois Athletic Commission.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 2--Representative Seymour Halpern, Republican of Queens, today was acquitted of a disorderly conduct charge made by a New Jersey state trooper who gave him a speeding ticket.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 2--A United Nations representative has arrived in Usumbura, Burundi, to help the new nations of Rwanda and Burundi organize their administrations, a United Nations spokesman said today.

CAIRO, July 2--President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic appealed tonight to Algerian nationalist leaders to close ranks to assure the "victory of the revolution."

The National Maritime Union said yesterday that it would appeal a decision by David L. Cole, as an umpire, to the executive council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP)--The National Aeronautics and Space Administration ordered 114 space engines from Rocketdyne division of North American Aviation, Inc., at a cost of $289,000,000 today.

HERSHEY, Pa., July 2--Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today he would resist with all the power he can muster any attempt to invalidate New Jersey laws dealing with religious observances in public schools.

Cutters' Local 10 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union said yesterday that it would appeal a decision of the State Commission for Human Rights supporting a Negro who charged that the union had discriminated against him.

DETROIT, July 2 (AP)-- Production figures for the first half of 1962 show that sixteen automotive makers built more cars this year than last. Total industry production for the period was 3,625,832 against 2,736,423 in 1961.
As a corollary to the long-standing debate over how best to spur economic growth, President Kennedy has launched another debate on the basic issue of budget policy.

WHEN Bucky Harris was managing the Yankees, he was continually casting anxious eyes in the direction of one of his outfielders, a fellow named Joe DIMaggio. There was reason for the concern because Jolting Joe was bedeviled by a bone spur on his heel. It was so crippling that he was out of the line-up part of the time and far from his effective best when he was in it.
Directors of the G.C. Murphy Company authorized yesterday a two-for-one split of the common stock.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 2--Pan American World Airways, prime contractor for the maintenance and operation of the Atlantic Missile Range with headquarters at Cape Canaveral, has awarded a contract to Marine Transport, Inc., of New York to run its ten-ship ocean fleet.
Federal Judge Eward Weinfeld granted a motion yesterday to postpone former Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh's sentencing for conspiracy from July 17 to Aug. 2.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Tenney of 770 Park Avenue and Islip, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Lusk Tenney, to John Randolph Hearst Jr. He is the son of Mrs. Gretchen Wilson Donahue of New York and the late Mr. Hearst.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 2-- Six murderers sawed their way Out of cells on San Quentin's death row today. They surrendered three hours later within the prison.

DUBLIN, July 2--In a sense, the race horse dominates Irish business, Irish entertainment and even the green and rolling Irish countryside. Irish-bred horses won 114 races in Europe last May alone. Before this year is out, judging by past years, Irish get will have won 3,500...

PARIS, July 2--The surge of private demand for gold that swept the London gold market at the end of last week abated today. Although the "fixing" price of $35.10 7/8 was higher than the Friday "fixing" and the highest since mid-February, this price marked a fairly large drop from Friday's unofficial closing price of about $35.11 an ounce.

SPRUCE PINE, N.C., July 2--The Federal Government's stoppage of its sheet-mica buying last June 7 has wiped out the jobs of more than 1,000 miners in New Hampshire, North Carolina and Georgia, industry sources report here.
ALBANY, July 2--Sewage systems and sewage treatment plants for the Great South Bay area were recommended today by the State Health Department to control the growths of algae.

It was Ladies Day at the Sheraton Plaza yesterday as the national fencing championships moved into the third session. At stake was the only individual crown that a woman fencer can take home--the foils title.
EASTCHESTER, N.Y., July 2--In 1958 the Japanese mission to the United Nations taught the Town of Eastchester that the legal distance between two points was on a straight line.
ON summer week-ends, city life becomes more relaxed and tailored dark cotton clothes are frequently put aside for more informal wear. Smart women feel that pants are not...
LONDON, July.2--Dr. Robert A. Soblen's condition continued to improve today but doctors attending him believed it would be at least two more days before he could he moved.
PARIS, July 3--The United States received a rebuff today in the first test of a new effort to induce European nations to eliminate import controls on non-farm goods.

Briggs Swift Cunningham, who has been driving cars since he was 8 years old and racing for more than fifteen years, nudged American car manufacturers yesterday to go after a waiting market: the small sports car whose European counterparts are steadily climbing in sales.

PARIS, July 3--It is extraordinary enough to see Paris' moat famous squares and avenues adorned with the red, black and gold of Germany without contemplating the curious inner implications of Chancellor Adenauer's visit to his friend de Gaulle.

WASHINGTON, July 3--Pal Benko led the field in the Eastern Open Chess Tournament here last night with a score of six points. Carl Burger was next with five and one-half points, with the tournament about twothirds over.

After a rather active day on Monday, trading in world sugar leveled off yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. There was some realizing after the recent rise, but new buying was postponed pending final sugar legislation.
NEWARK, July 3--Four persons were killed this evening when a tractor-trailer truck crashed into a parked car on a westbound lane of the Holland Tunnel extension of the New Jersey Turnpike.
HARTFORD, Conn., July 3 (AP)--A New York real estate concern has purchased three Scot's Department Store buildings in Connecticut for $2,075,000.
ROME, July 3--A lionied author was given tonight a suspended sentence of fifteen days in prison at the end of a sensational trial that cast a lurid light on la dolce vita of Rome,
Five new leases in the Empire State Building have been announced by Helmsley-Spear, Inc., the renting agent.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 3--A common drainpipe will soon replace the ancient process of digging a channel to permit the ebb and flow of tides between Georgica Pond and the Atlantic Ocean one mile west of here.
DENVER, July 3--American schools must give "in depth" treatment to the Communist threat to democracy, a national conference of educators was told here today.
The Honest Ballot Association was engaged yesterday by a hospital workers' union to conduct representation elections among nonmedical employes of eleven voluntary hospitals.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) --The Government filed today monopoly charges against the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., the country's largest producer of phonograph records, and its subsidiary, the Columbia Record Club, Inc., New York City.

UNITED NATIONS, J.Y., July 3--Justin Bomboko, the Foreign Minister of the Congo, spent all day today in conferences with United Nations officials and Asian and African delegates on the new crisis caused by the collapse of talks to end the secession of Katanga Province.

Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri removed a possible legal block yesterday from the path of a distribution of 23,000,000 shares of the General Motors Corporation's common stock by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.

France formally proclaimed the independence of Algeria yesterday. Using sweeping powers given him by the French, President de Gaulle acted quickly to shift sovereignty to the Algerians, who voted overwhelmingly for independence last Sunday.
John Martin, dance critic of The New York Times for thirty-five years, retired this week. He has been succeeded by Alien Hughes.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 3--This is a town dedicated to the trotter and the tablet. It is especially so during Grand Circuit time at the 108-year-old Historic Track, where today the Castleton Farm's Speedy Scot won the featured $17,100 E.H. Harriman Challenge Trophy.
WASHINGTON, July 3--The Pentagon sought again today to reassure state Governors that proposed cutbacks and changes in the National Guard were subject to modification.

LIMA, Peru, July 3--The American Popular Revolutionary Alliance called today an emergency national convention for tomorrow to consider a demand by the armed forces that Dr. Victor Raul Haya de la Torre withdraw as a presidential candidate.
Antonio B. Caragol, an American-Spanish import-export executive, died on Monday at Long Island College Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 57 Montague Street in Brooklyn.
By the referendum of Jan. 8, 1961, the French people acknowledged the right of the Algerian populations to choose their political destiny with respect to the French Republic.
PARIS, July 3--President de Gaulle and Chancellor Adenauer conferred for two hours today on their stalled plans for a European political confederation.
Stock prices rose yesterday for the fourth successive session. Trading was heavy. It was the first time since March that there had been such a sustained advance on the New York Stock Exchange.

OCEAN BEACH, Fire Island, L.I., July 3--Governor Rockefeller was asked again today to review charges of irregularities surrounding the actions of the Temporary State Commission on Protection and Preservation of the Atlantic Shore Front.

ATLANTA, July 3--An official of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called in effect today for the ouster of a member of the President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2-Mrs. Karen Hamtze Susman is the only American woman in the Wimbledon tennis semifinals tonight. The American champion, second-seeded Darlene Hard, was upset by Mrs. Vera Sukova, a 30-year-old accounts clerk in a Prague airplane factory, 6--4, 6--3, and Billie Jean Moffitt was trounced by Ann Haydon of Britain, 6--3; 6--1.

HAVE you ever heard of St. Brendan? Probably not--unless you are Irish and revere him as the patrol saint of County Kerry; unless you belong to that curious company of readers who delight in books about Atlantis, the Lost Continent of Mu, the Lost Tribes of Israel and the discovery of America by ancient Sumerians, ...

More than 100 etchings and engravings by old masters can be seen at Associated American Artists, 605 Fifth Avenue (near Forty-ninth Street). The prints date from the fifteenth, sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, and the artists include Rembrandt, Durer, Tiepolo, Callot and many others. Monday through Friday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Free.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 3-- Brazil is carrying surplus stocks of coffee that are larger than the world's yearly consumption into the decisive negotiations for an international coffee price stabilization agreement.
RABAT, Morocco, July 3-- Moroccans celebrated the independence of Algeria today as a national holiday.
Americans started for their favorite beaches, mountains and cities yesterday to celebrate the nation's 186th Independence Day.

The Citizens Union will consider court action to try to block a pension for Supreme Court Justice J, Vincent Keogh, whose application for retirement is to become effective July 18.

Now that the mayor leagues are committed to 162-game campaigns, the Fourth of July has been reduced to a date of mere historic and patriotic significance. It falls a bit too early to be the barometric halfway mark in the pennant races--the point at which possession of first place is tantamount to world series berths.
CHICAGO, July 3--The Air Line Pilots Association said today it had won the right to have a dispute over dues paid by flight attendants decided by trial.

THE concert at Lewisohn Stadium last night did not generate much vitality or warmth until the second half. This was strange because the pieces heard before the intermission--the Overture to Schubert's "Rosamunde," Prokofieff's Symphony in D (the "Classical") and Ravel's "La Valse"--are not what one would call flat or lifeless.

CHICAGO, July 3--Dr. Nicholas Dimitrius Cheronis, internationally prominent research chemist, educator and author, who recently retired from the faculty of Brooklyn College, was killed yesterday in an auto accident. He was 66 years old.
A powerful but serene face looks out of a canvas that has come to New York for the summer. It is easily the star of an exhibition of illustrious Americans.

TOKYO, July 3--Japan's "church militant," a Buddhist sect that believes in ancient incantations and modern machine politics, emerged today as a strange, strong force in the political life of the country.
TORONTO, July 3 (AP)-- Heart attacks killed five Shriners today, casting a pall over thousands of their lodge brothers in the brassy opening of the Eibhty-eighth North American Shriners convention.
Carpenters renovating a row of dilapidated single-car garages in Jersey City found a cache of about $2,400,000 in the trunk of an old car yesterday.

CINCINNATI, July 3 (UPI)-- Manager Fred Hutchinson selected the National League allstar pitchers and reserves today, naming Stan Musial to the team for a record nineteenth time while passing over one of his own Cincinnati players, Frank Robinson.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 3 --The Art Barn, this town's newest cultural venture, got under way here today in a big red barn that once housed prize cattle.

The Yankees put on a gorgeous pyrotechnic display at the Stadium yesterday. Paced by their famed M-M duo, they thrilled a crowd of 13,378 by exploding five home runs. Mickey Mantle and Roger Maris hit two apiece. Bobby Richardson hit the other.
DENVER, July 3--A top labor leader surprised the National Education Association's annual convention tonight with an attack on the association's opposition to teachers' unions.

PARIS, July 3--Until he was almost 50 years old, Jean Marcel Jeanneney led the quiet life of a scholar and a professor. When he was not in the lecture hall, he spent his time with his family--a wife and seven children of whom he was extraordinarily proud.

Edmund W. Fitzgerald, general partner in H. Hentz Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange and leading commodity markets, died yesterday in his home at 255 Greenway North, Forest Hills, Queens. His age was 74.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 3-- The San Francisco Giants today discovered the Mets' only three weaknesses--pitching, fielding and batting--and proceeded to exploit them for a 10--1 victory before 7,083 customers. The crowd was the smallest of the season at Candlestick Park.
JAKARTA, July 3--President Sukarno announced today that Indonesia would send a representative to Washington for talks with the Netherlands on the Netherlands New Guinea dispute.
The anti-capitalist and antiAmerican indoctrination given Soviet pupils in all Soviet schools is being matched by anti-Communist and anti-Soviet indoctrination in many American schools.

RECIPE collections, haphazardly filed and occasionally spattered with food, can look tattered enough to have existed through the American Revolution. Generally, however, even the most avid recipe collector does not look back to colonial times for culinary inspiration.

George Abbott, one of Broadway's leading producer-directors, got a useful gift yesterday--a permanent caddy named Sam. Mr. Abbott, ever the pushy director, immediately suggested that the caddy change his name.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 3 --Alabama's Legislature may be the only one in the nation to count a professional magician among its members. But no amount of magic on the part of Representative Bernard Cabiness of Scottsboro is going to make the reapportionment problem go away or solve it to the satisfaction of both the state's lawmakers and the Federal judiciary.

Information from Saigon provides striking evidence of how Vietnamese Communists are using Laotian territory as a sanctuary for the supply, training and regrouping of guerrillas for South Vietnam. Thousands of fresh reinforcements for Vietcong forces have turned up in the plateau region north of Saigon after having crossed the Vietnam frontier from camps in Laos.

Instead of retiring, James M. Symes recently agreed to continue as chairman of the Pennsylvania Railroad--and concentrate on mergers. Yesterday Mr. Symes was in Washington doing just that. He told a Senate antitrust subcommittee that Eastern railroads need mergers desperately to rescue them from a "steadily deteriorating situation."

Two New Jersey business men yesterday reported the theft of $15,000 in cash and jewels from a safe deposit box at a midtown bank. However, the police said later the men might have been swindled of $100,000.

CHICAGO, July 3--John F. Duffy, president of the Cook County (Chicago) Board and former Chicago alderman, died today in Little Company of Mary Hospital. He was 63 years old. His health had been failing since he underwent abdominal surgery a year ago and he had been in the hospital for two weeks.
Picketing by a ship engineer union against American Export Lines failed yesterday to interfere with the sailing of the 23,764-ton luxury liner Independence.
A bill limiting the amounts of liquid in pumped or cured meats sold in the city was passed, 22 to 1, yesterday by the City Council.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 3 --Chester B. Price, architect, architectural illustrator and etcher, died here Last night in Lawrence Hospital after a brief illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 66 Palmer Avenue.
MOSCOW, July 3--The Soviet Union denied today that Communist North Vietnam was supporting the rebel movement in South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, July 3--The White House accepted today the prospect of a delay on the pending tax bill until later in this session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 3--President Kennedy announced today that he would nominate Inzer B. Wyatt, a New York City lawyer born in Alabama, to fill a vacancy on the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York. The salary is $22,500 a year.
TEEN-AGERS are moving into off Broadway theatres to produce children's shows that rival the offerings of more seasoned companies.

THE ingenuity of the major league club owners is surpassed only by their avarice. They have foisted a particu larly hideous monstrosity on their customers --and their hired hands--this season, a compressing device that is known as the 162game schedule. Its purpose is to squeeze out as many extra dollar bills as this infernal machine is able to produce.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) --Consumers increased their installment credit debt by $413,000,000 in May, or about $100,000,000 less than in April, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The national amateur champion and two former champions are on the United States golf team named yesterday to defend the Curtis Cup against the British women's squad. The matches are to be played at the Broadmoor Golf Club, Colorado Springs, Aug. 17-18.
The high-grade bond market clung to its defensive mood yesterday.
Forty top-ranking New York labor leaders, most of them from the building trades, have organized to seek renomination and re-election for Representative Charles A. Buckley of the Bronx.

New York Democrats intimated yesterday that Governor Rockefeller's refusal to call a special session of the Legislature on legislative reapportionment was directly linked to his Presidential ambitions.
LONDON, July 3--Britain's long-awaited National Theatre cleared its last major hurdle today.
The Board of Estimate will try on Friday to decide whether to appropriate $4,000,000 to buy 2,750 new voting machines for the primary election on Sept. 6.

Gil Eisner, a commercial artist from Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, became a new champion in an ancient sport last night. The 22-year-old athlete captured the epee title in the national fencing championship staged at the Park Sheraton Hotel.
St. John's University had the right to dismiss three students for participating in a civil marriage ceremony, the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division in Brooklyn ruled yesterday.
ALGIERS, July 3--The Provisional Government of the Algerian Republic came home today from Tunis to a tumultuous welcome six hours after a proclamation of independence by France.
WASHINGTON, July 3--Pan American World Airways has asked the Federal Aviation Agency to make it easier for its pilots to take over the jobs of its flight engineers if the engineers go on strike.

New York City hotel men are starting to complain about the 1962 stock market slump, which, they say, has aggravated what had already been a serious decline in their business.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP)-- Short covering for the July 4 holiday generated a moderate late rally in grain futures today. Most contracts on the Board of Trade were unchanged to up.

LEONARD DEPAUR, who is best known in musical circles as a conductor of choruses, led the Lower East side Neighborhoods Association Orchestra in its third concert of the season at the East River Park Ampitheatre, Mr. dePaur had made his orchestral debut in last summer's LENA series.

REGINA, Sask., July 3--A group of citizens is considering an injunction against the Saskachewan Government on the ground that the act creating its medical care plan is unconstitutional. A final decision on whether to proceed with the suit has yet to be taken.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 3-- The High Court of Justice was asked today to free Nahman Shtarkes, who has been in Ramle prison more than two years for refusing to help trace his missing grandson, Yosef Schuhmacher.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3-- On the eve of the first meeting in this country between oarsmen of the United States and the Soviet Union in tomorrow's Independence Day regatta here, the calm of the Schuylkill changed in troubled waters today.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 3-- The same yachts that won yesterday when the observation races in the America's Cup defense trials began won again today, but they beat different opponents.
CHICHESTER, England, July 3--With a handsome new home and a glamorous company of players, a theatre festival was born tonight in West Sussex.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 4 --Foreign Minister Halvard Lange stressed the need to protect the livelihood of Norway's coastal fishermen and isolated farmers in presenting today an application to join the European Economic Community.

BRASILIA, July 4--Auro Soares de Moura Andrade, who was elected Premier of Brazil yesterday by an overwhelming Congressional majority, resigned today because of President Joao Goulart's opposition to his Cabinet choices.

VALLEJO, Calif., July 4 (AP) --Thomas Jefferson Jackson See, a retired naval captain and internationally famous mathematician, astronomer, author and lecturer died today at the Oak Knoll Naval Hospital, Oakland, after a long illness. He was 96 years old.

WILMINGTON, N.Y., July 4--Perhaps on this Day of Independence, a blow should be struck for the emancipation of outdoor writers from the scurrilous canard visited on them by the unthinking, the envious and the ignorant.

BABYLON, L.I., July 4-- The Ormen Hing Lange II, a sixty-nine-foot reproduction of a Viking warship that rests in a museum in Oslo, Norway, was pulled out of the harbor here today by nine rowers to the delight of those on board and those in near-by conventional craft.
