MOSCOW, July--Premier Khrushchev said today at a Kremlin reception that an EastWest agreement on a German peace settlement "can and must be reached in the nearest future."

PARIS, July 4--France and West Germany reached substantial agreement today on seeking an early meeting of the heads of government of the European Economic Com munity to revive negotiations for a European political confederation.
STUTTGART, Ark. THE green rice fields lie quiet and all but deserted now, their blanket of water shimmering in the summer sun for mile upon mile across the Grand Prairie.
PARIS, July 4--A heavy demand for gold swept the London bullion market today, pushing the price up to $35.12 an ounce at closing time.

LOS ANGELES, July 4 (AP) --The league-leading Los Angeles Dodgers scored their seventh straight double-header sweep today and ran their winning streak to six by beating the Philadelphia Phillies, 16--1 and 7--3.

PARIS. A new supermarket in Montparnasse that puts its American cousins in the shade is causing excitement in Paris these days. Called Inno-France, it is a one-stop shopping center that offers everything from striped bass to striped sheets.

A COUPLE who have logged more than 350,000 miles to study animal and plant life on four continents have found that their sense of wonder increases with each discovery.

WASHINGTON, July 4-- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower firmly rejected today Senator Barry Goldwater's censure of two new Republican policy organizations.

PARIS, July 7--President de Gaulle and Chancellor Adenauer sought this week to prepare the way for a Europe capable of accepting, if it chooses, President Kennedy's offer of "equal partnership."
Long waiting lists for new apartments in France may soon be shortened as a result of that country's efforts to stabilize its currency and the easing of once-strict zoning laws.

DURING the first half of July the native flowers of Colorado's highest mountains reach their peak. Mountain climbers sometimes have difficulty finding a footing among the thick cushions of tightly packed dwarf blooms.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 7-- A string of labor-management settlements leads some employers to believe that inflation will continue through at least the next two or three years.

The Washington premiere on Sept. 25 of Irving Berlin's new musical comedy, "Mr. President," will be a joint benefit for the Lieut. Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Institute and the Kennedy Child Study Center.

A year ago yesterday George Alpert, president of the deficitridden New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, called reporters to his office and announced: "Our battle to save the New Haven Railroad from bankruptcy has been lost."

WESTFIELD, N.Y.--The Barcelona Lighthouse at Barcelona Harbor, near here, has been re lighted after standing in darkness for more than 100 years. Believed to be the only gaslit type of lighthouse in existence, the structure has been restored by its owner, G. Patterson Crandall, and the Iroquois Gas Company.
LONDON, July 6-Sir Winston Churchill has developed signs of phlebitis, an inflammation of the veins, in his injured leg, hospital authorities reported today.

One of the historical curiosities of the advertising business is that agencies originally worked not for advertisers but for advertising media. Their basic job was to drum up advertising linage for the dozens of small, isolated newspapers that had sprung up around the country.

MOST children, like most adults, probably don't know how many kinds of Indian life there were in this country. They read about the Plains, Pueblos and Navahos repeatedly, while the corn-raising Pimas of the Southwest or the forest hunters of the Great Lakes are almost unknown.
Traffic deaths in New York City in the first six months of this year were 23 per cent higher than in the same period last year.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 7-- This queen of summer resorts is looking forward to its busiest social season in many summers. Among the highlights will be the America's Cup races in the fall and a visit by President and Mrs. Kennedy.
On Wall Street, where fashions change at least as often as they do on Seventh Avenue, there has been a rather abrupt return to classic yardsticks to measure values.
JONES BEACH, L.I., July 7 --A stormy session is expected when Robert Moses' plan for a proposed ocean boulevard along the Fire Island barrier beach is detailed at a public hearing on Tuesday.

ROUEN, France, July 7 -- Graham Hill stands 6 feet tall and weighs 180 pounds. The cockpit of the BRM race car he will drive in tomorrow's Grand Prix of France had to be widened to allow room for his shoulders.
A New Englander transplanted to the South is convinced that sheep-raising can bring new prosperity to South Carolina's cotton and tobacco farmers.
USUMBURA, Burundi, July 7--Breakfast is not an easy meal here. The juice is warm, the eggs are small and the service is slow--but the coffee is excellent.

Alaska has become the first state in the union to adopt legislation barring racial and religious discrimination in all housing offered for sale or rent in the state, whether built with public or private funds.
WASHINGTON, July 7--The medicare debate in the Senate is creating the impression that Congress may, after a11, approve a program of Federal health insurance for the aged this year.

MOSCOW, July 7--The Soviet Union has provided a glimpse into one of its secrecy shrouded industries by describing a plant for the production of zirconium, one of the metals of the atomic age.
WASHINGTON, July 7--The Administration called on foreign honeybees this week for help in taking the sting out of the prickliest sugar legislation ever produced by Congress.

ON June 28, 1939, Pan American World Airways sent off its first transAtlantic flight, the 150 mile-an-hour Dixie Clipper Boeing flying boat that took off from Port Washington Bay with twenty-two passengers.

IN recounting the outsize story of Charles Taylor, known in the early nineteenth century by the self-styled title, Master of Melodrama, his son Dwight, author and screenplay writer, recaptures much of the color of good old gaslight, blood-andthunder theatre when stalwart heroes, black-hearted villains and trembling virgins were the order of the day.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 7--Miss Patricia Stockdale Day, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Fisher Day, and John Luther Putnam Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Putnam of Forest Hills, Queens, and East Hampton, were married this afternoon.

FROM garden to freezer while the dew is still on the plants is the ideal arrange ment for freezing fruits but one that is seldom possible. The alternative is to choose fresh fruits and to work swiftly in preparing them for the freezer. Fruits that freeze especially well include blueberries, cherries, cranberries, peaches, pineapples, strawberries, raspberries, cantaloupes and honeydew melons.

THE Federal transportation tax, which has been with us man and boy, in peacetime and war and again in peacetime for nearly twenty-one years, is about to disappear--but, like all easily collected taxes, not completely. In a Hairbreadth-Harry race with the expiration of the 1962 Federal fiscal year at midnight on June 30, Congress passed, and President Kennedy signed, the Tax Rate Extension Act of 1962.

THE moral armor girding American industry lost some of its luster last year when a Federal judge ordered jail sentences and fines in punishment of a price-rigging conspiracy involving the giants of electrical manufacturing.

GREENSBORO, N.C., July 7 --Miss Barbara Wolff Brandon, a member of the History Department at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill, was married here this afternoon to John Martin Schnorrenberg, assistant professor of the history of art there.
PARIS, July 6--What may become a major new foreignaid program for Greece and Turkey is taking shape in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
The police are investigating a second man in connection with mysterious disappearance of $100,000 from a Manhattan safety deposit box.
A New York real estate investment firm has been specializing recently in converting socalled "misfit" sites into prime income-producing properties.

THE New York Shakespeare Festival in Central Park may become an annual event for television. Station WCBS-TV, which recently presented "The Merchant of Venice," is trying to make long-term arrangements whereby it would televise the festival's opening play each summer.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 -- "Gang-workers," men with faith in the Father Flanagan theory that "there is no such thing as a bad boy," are setting a pattern here for rechanneling the energies and potentialities of juvenile gangs into constructive endeavors.

EASTHAM, Mass.--The only sign of a Cape Cod Na tional Seashore this season is the one that proclaims the old Nauset Coast Guard station here as the local headquarters. That, and perhaps an occasional team of surveyors working on boundaries of the project.
COLONIAL HEIGHTS, Va., July 7 (AP)--Eight persons were killed today in a two-car crash on U.S. Highway 1.

YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo.Vacationists have been arriving in the last few weeks in this oldest of all our nation's parks, lying mostly in Wyoming but lapping over into Montana and Idaho, at a rate 35 per cent above last year's levels for a similar period.

NEW DELHI, India, July 7-- Three top-ranking air force officers left today for Britain on what was described as a mission to evaluate a supersonic jet fighter Britain is reported to have offered to sell to India. It would be an alternative to Soviet MIG-21 jets, which the New Delhi Government has had under consideration.

DANBURY, Conn., July 7-- Miss Lavinia Rundle McLean was married here this afternoon to Dr. Charles Tilden Fischer. The Rev. John Duane Verdery, headmaster of the Wooster School, performed the Protestant Episcopal ceremony in the school's chapel.

SEOUL, Korea, July 1--Leading Seoul newspapers have expressed fear that the South Korean press might eventually be placed under tight control of the government when the recently announced press reform policy becomes effective.

JERSEY CITY, July 7--Detectives searched more garages in the West Bergen section here today hoping to add to the $2,590,525.52 found in two garages in the last five days.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., July 7--In the Memorial Chapel of Wesleyan University, Miss Jane Paula Spaeth was married this afternoon to A. Conrad Neumann 3d. The Rev. Joseph C. Harvey, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, performed the ceremony.
BOSTON, July 4--The Boston wool market--the largest in the United States--is a worried giant tiptoeing through the quicksand of changing world business conditions.

MONTREAL--Two new developments here are of importance to motorists visiting Montreal or heading for the nearby Laurentian resort region. One is the opening last weekend of the new $35,000,000 Champlain Bridge across the St. Lawrence. The other is the announcement that the Laurentian Autoroute, the high-speed toll route into the Laurentian vacation country, is to be extended another seventeen miles.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 7--All of but three of the 105 starters today in the first half of the Orienta Yacht Club's fifty-seventh annual regatta on Long Island Sound finished despite trying conditions. It was the seventeenth regatta of the Yacht Racing Association season.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. --Here in the shadow of the Blue Ridge Mountains the pioneer spirit was nurtured early. Two of the nation's great explorers came from this Piedmont region. George Rogers Clark, conqueror of the wilderness north and west of the Ohio, was born a couple of miles east of here in 1752.

Watson Barratt, a theatrical designer, died on Friday in Columbus Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in the Royalton Hotel at 44 West Fortyfourth Street. He also maintained an estate at Highlands in Macon County, N. C.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., July 7--Former Secretary of the Army Elvis J. Stahr Jr. said in an interview today that decision-making at the Pentagon had become overly centralized under Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara.

VIENNA, July 7--An international conference urged today that under-developed countries assume the primary responsibility for their own development, but that rich industrial countries increase their aid.

Denny Moyer and Ted Wright put on one of the best fighting shows of the year last night at Madison Square Garden. Moyer scored a unanimous decision in the ten-round nationally televised middleweight bout.
A typewriter you can talk into and make your words come out printed in English or even translated into another language is now a reality, according to United Press International.
OXFORD, Miss., July 7-- William Faulkner was buried here today in the North Mississippi hills from which he drew the tragic themes of some of the century's greatest novels.

OLD BENNINGTON, Vt., July 7--Miss Katharine Anne Salter, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Manning Salter of Newbury, formerly of Glen Ridge, N. J., and the late Mr. Salter, was married here this afternoon to Everard Kempshall Pinneo. He is the son of Mrs. Edgar Harriott Pinneo of Elizabeth, N. J., and the late Mr. Pinneo.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 7 --Drill Site defeated the favored Admiral's Voyage by a head today in capturing the $113.900 Hollywood Derby, the summer racing classic in the West for 3-year-olds at Hollywood Park.

WASHINGTON, July 7-- More than 500 Foreign Service officers began moving their trunks overseas this week as they prepared for new assignments. About the same number began returning to this country for further study.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 7 --On this muggy afternoon on which local beaches did a thriving business, women in Bermuda shorts shopped on Main Street and resort hotels served meals out-of-doors, the fifteenth annual Junior Chamber of Commerce ski jumping tournament was held.

Although U Thant has deprecated any suggestion that he is seeking re-election, his behavior last week did nothing to dispel the belief that he would be highly receptive to a full term as Secretary General of the United Nations.

PORTSMOUTH, Va.--In the great storm of last March, which did such widespread damage to shore resorts, the angry Atlantic hurdied sea walls and protective dunes, smashing boardwalks, cottages and motels at Virginia Beach. But those who counted among the casualties the resort's traditional Boardwalk Art show and celebrated summer season were unduly pessimistic.

District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor of Queens, an Irish Catholic seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor, rejected yesterday the suggestion that a Jewish candidate might have the best chance to defeat Governor Rockefeller.
LENOX, Mass., July 8 The Bach week-end drew 16,855 persons to Tanglewood, and the second and third concerts devoted to the chosen master were of the same high quality as the first.

IN an ordinary adventure story readers can count on numerous traditional consistencies. Villains will be villainous, heroes heroic and heroines in love with the hero and not with the villain. No such comfortable order of things can be found in the topsy-turvy and grimly sardonic world described by John Christopher in his "The Long Winter."*
RABAT, Morocco, July 8 Two ministers of the Algerian Provisional Government arrived here tonight on a mission designed to end the rift in the Algerian leadership.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 8 Establishment of a new Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Center for Aerospace Health and Safety at Harvard University was announced today.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 8 Francis F. Gibson's thirty-threefoot sloop Mag, from the American Yacht Club in Rye. N. Y., today won the top prize in the Riverside Yacht Club's annual overnight race around Stratford Shoal.

The report of the Temporary State Commission on the Atlantic Shore Front comes up for what may be stormy public discussion tomorrow. The report is convincing on the need for the erosion control projects recommended by the Corps of Engineers. It fails to make a case for the twenty miles of costly "ocean boulevard" Commissioner Moses wants to build on Fire Island.
Mass., July 8 Peter Gunn, a 10-year-old bay gelding, won the regular working hunter championship of the Great Barrington horse show today.
A wide divergence of opinion was expressed over the weekend on the Supreme Court's decision banning an official prayer in the public schools.

William H. McKeon, Democratic state chairman, said yesterday that he was supporting Representative Charles A. Buckley for re-election in the Bronx because he "votes for Democratic philosophies and the principles that I believe in."
The Board of Estimate was asked yesterday to "stop stalling" and to approve the start of full-scale construction of the Lower Manhattan Expressway when the project comes up for discussion on Aug. 23.

A "fur" coat protects the cool interior of one of the most unusual fruits ever to appear on the New York scene. Hailing all the way from New Zealand and bearing the name Chinese gooseberry, this fruit resembles not one whit the small green bullet that is known by the name gooseberry in this country.

PASCAGOULA, Miss., July 8 The great insurance companies of this country believe in the American merchant marine and are demonstrating their faith in the future of the shipping industry by heavy investments, an insurance leader said here yesterday.
HONG KONG, July 8 The Chinese Communist Government lodged a strong protest with the Indian Government today against "a serious intrusion by Indian troops into the Sinkiang region of China."

LIMA, Peru, July 8 The Apra party and former President Manuel A. Odria, who persecuted it for eight years, are being thrown together increasingly in a "constitutionalist" front against the Presidential aspirations of Fernando Belaunde Terry and the threat of a military coup.

Jose Greco and his Spanish Ballet must be feeling rather good today, for on Saturday night they had great box-office success at Lewisohn Stadium. An attendance of 18,000 was reported by the Stadium Concerts management, and there was no reason to doubt it.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) Gen. George H. Decker, United States Army Chief of Staff, said today that an article describing military operations in South Vietnam as confused and ineffective did not "reflect accurately the opinions of responsible army authorities in Washington or in the field."
CAIRO, July 8 Delegates of nearly thirty nonaligned countries gathered here today to discuss mutual fears for their economies in the face of such blocs as the European Common Market.

PITTSBURGH, July 8 Reports from steel mills were pessimistic last week. The best that was expected was a modest upturn in shipments next month. Most marketing men said that it would probably be September before there was any significant change in steel movements.

LOS ANGELES, July 8 (AP) Vivien Brown and Leah Bennett set 220-yard dash and the 880-yard run records tonight and Mrs. Wilma Rudolph Ward easily retained her title in the 100-yard dash in the Women's Amateur Athletic Union national championships.

The city's Department of Real Estate announced yesterday that it had put into effect a number of recommendations of the Community Service Society to improve methods of relocating tenants of buildings scheduled for demolition.
WASHINGTON, July 8 Few men can lay a better claim to having come up the hard way in their profession than Henry Luke Giordano, the new Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics.

The Sanitation Department's forty-man anti-litter "flying squad" has been more than doubled and split into four twentyfive-man units assigned to clean up 187 areas, Commissioner Frank J. Lucia announced yesterday. The four units will begin work this morning.

Sidney Schwartz, a rugged black-haired player from Kew Gardens, Queens, won his fourth Exccessive tennis tournament yesterday. He defeated Herbert FitzGibbon of Garden City, L. I., for the New York State championship at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.

The New York City Board of Health, responding to a request by Mayor Wagner, delivered to City Hall in 1955 a comprehensive report recommending fluoridation of water supply. It reviewed the benefits of fluoridation, demonstrated throughout the world, in prevention of tooth decay. It answered authoritatively the unsubstantiated objections that there are hazards to general health in drinking properly fluoridated water.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, July 8 Public demonstrations arranged by the Government supported today the candidacy of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner for a third term as President.
LONDON, July 7 The doctors attending Sir Winston Churchill said today that the phlebitis in his left leg had not advanced.

WASHINGTON, July 8 A new man took over last week as chief of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics. As he did, a small but intense controversy enveloped his predecessor and the whole attitude of the Government toward narcotics addiction.

A 999-year leasehold on the fourteen-story apartment building at 135-39 East Thirty-third Street, northwest corner of Lexington Avenue, has been sold by David Green, a lawyer. The sale of the unusually long lease was negotiated by Samuel Kutay, a Brooklyn broker.
ROME, July 8 A proposal to grant regional autonomy to the linguistically mixed area around Trieste has run into violent Right-wing opposition.
EVER since the opening two-bid was first used as a forcing bid and that covers almost the entire life of contract bridge two no-trump has been the standard negative response to show great weakness.

No national commitment is more sacred than the fulfillment of Government responsibility to the veteran with service-connected injury that seriously impairs his health and ability to earn a living. But the hundreds of millions of dollars in superfluous handouts going to well and working veterans are a serious drain on the Treasury, an intolerable burden on the taxpayer, a parody on the democratic concept of service in the name of patriotism.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) A Presidential order barring racial discrimination in Federally aided housing would cause a serious drop in new residential building, a home builders' survey indicated today.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
ALBANY, July 8 The Governors of the nation's two most populous states are debating this question by mail: which state has the more favorable economic climate?
TROON, Scotland, July 8 Almost all the names that count in the world of golf will be among the 350 who will try to qualify tomorrow for what is being called the British Open of this century.

PARIS, July 8 Something approaching a consensus appears to be emerging among key European central bank and treasury officials about the proper "mix" of budget and financial policies to be pursued by the United States.
MOSCOW, July 8 Benny Goodman wound up his sixweek tour of the Soviet Union today with words of praise for Premier Khrushchev.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 8 -- The calmness and orderliness surrounding the three-day jazz festival that came to an and this evening at Freebody Park has given an encouraging boost to the sponsors' hope that a "purist" jazz festival--one devoted to jazz and without the added allure of "popular" acts -- can attract large, well-mannered audiences.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 8 Nine Federal civil servants have been chosen to spend the next school year at Princeton University in a new educational program for governmental employes, Dr. Robert F. Goheen, Princeton president, announced today.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 8 A joint effort is being quietly pushed by California and Nevada state agencies, in cooperation with conservation groups, to save for public use rapidly diminishing available scenic areas on Lake Tahoe.

SOME of the happiest young women in New York appear to be those who are combining a career with a recent marriage. The transition from being a single working woman to being a working wife is not without its trials, but few women going through this would have it otherwise.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 8 The Music Corporation of America has notified the Screen Actors Guild that it will surrender its talent agency franchise.
A Staten Island restoration project, begun and carried on by volunteers "for the fun we get out of it," will take a big step forward today with the moving of a 1742 house to Richmondtown.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn. July 8 Despite a stiff breeze that blew directly out to center field, for the second straight day no home runs sailed off the mighty bats of Roger Maris and Mickey Mantle today but that still didn't help Minnesota's fading Twins.
The Health Department has given out 238,142 doses of Sabin anti-polio oral vaccine since May, Dr. Leona Baumgartner, Commissioner of Health, said yesterday.

Foes of the Revenue Act of 1962 are more hopeful than ever that Congress will reach adjournment without acting on the controversial tax bill. The Senate Finance Committee, which has the House-approved measure in hand, has turned its attention to the President's trade program.

WASHINGTON, July 8 Senator Harry F. Byrd charged the United States Chamber of Commerce today with "fiscal irresponsibility in the highest degree" in recommending an immediate tax cut without a reduction in Federal spending.

A leading director of Finland's National Theatre disclosed yesterday that recent plays by such young American playwrights as Edward Albee, Arthur Kopit, and Jack Richardson might be produced in Finland.

Millions of persons went to beaches and parks in the metropolitan area yesterday to escape heat that reached 96 degrees at 2:35 P.M. The day was the second hottest of the year, with the high 3 degrees under the 99 recorded on May 19.

Cotton future prices last week held to a narrow range, for the most part. At the close on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were off 5 to up 30 points for the week. A week earlier, the market had been off 85 points to up 1 point.
The Rev. Dr. Stuart Hamilton Merriam, ousted minister of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, has a new pulpit if only on a temporary basis.
ATLANTA, July 8 Robert C. Weaver said here today he had told the White House he had no desire to succeed Secretary Abraham A. Ribicoff as head of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The Government announced plans today for a thorough study of the impact of television on the nation's children. The industry offered its approval and support.

An appeal for help in advancing the Federal program to provide fall-out shelters was made yesterday by William P. Durkee of the Office of Civil Defense to county officials gathered here from all over the country.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) Warren Spahn scored his first triumph on the road this season by pitching the Milwaukee Braves to a 5 3 victory today over the Chicago Cubs. The Cubs won the first game of the doubleheader, 7 5, before 31,112.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 8 Israel has recognized Algerian independence, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said here today. The announcement was the second gesture of goodwill to the new Arab country in two weeks.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 8 Efforts are being made by moderates in both the Government and the Opposition here to rescue the Venezuelan constitutional system from one of the most serious threats it has faced.
ROUEN, France, July 8 Dan Gurney of Riverside, Calif., won the Grand Prix of France today. It was a bizarre race in which one car after another broke down.
HYANNIS, Mass., July 8 Political satire has never seemed more impertinently hilarious than it did this week-end in this Cape Cod resort village.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee said today he would recommend that his group bow out of planned investigations into the activities of sugar lobbyists here. This would leave the field to the Foreign Relations Committee.
Double-knit woolen threepiece suits continued to be among the most heavily ordered items last week, resident buying offices here reported. Furtrimmed coats for fall and winter also sold well.
WASHINGTON, July 8 Who's for chess with the Ambassador?
Douglas Gibbons, a real-estate broker and a leader in civic activities here, died Saturday night, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 550 Park Avenue. His age was 78.

JUNNAR, India, July 8 (UPI) An Alitalia DC-8 jet airliner that crashed into a hilltop sixty miles east of Bombay, killing all ninety-four persons aboard, apparently caught fire in flight, an examination of the wreckage showed today.
The Airways Club, a private company formed to represent airline passengers, has reported that its membership has increased sevenfold in the two years since its inception.
GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., July 8 McLain Street, a gray gelding from the Duffy Stables of Rye, N.Y., won the open jumper championship as the four-day Great Barrington horse show ended tonight.
James Junius Allen of 225 East Fifty-fourth Street, a painter specializing in landscapes and seascapes, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a long illness. His age was 64.
The Winston-Muss Corporation of New York, realty developer, has announced its purchase of ninety acres at the junction of Routes 73 and 41 in Moorestown, N.J., for a regional shopping center.
SOME recent votes in the Board of Estimate on highly controversial questions focus attention afresh on the close relationship between local disputes and politics in general.

MOSCOW, July 8 A leader of the South Vietnamese rebels said here today that the aim of his movement was to form a coalition government with a neutral policy after President Ngo Dinh Diem had been overthrown and United States forces had withdrawn.

WASHINGTON, July 8 Secretary of State Dean Rusk indicated today that he might confer again soon with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, on a whole range of problems, including Berlin and disarmament.
BONN, Germany, July 8 Chancellor Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union suffered a sharp defeat in today's election for a new state legislature in North-Rhine Westphalia.
RANGOON, Burma, July 8 Burmese troops fired on rioting students at the Rangoon University campus last night, killing fifteen persons and wounding twenty-seven.
LOS ANGELES, July 8 Negroes have opened a campaign in this urban center against the barriers of tacit racial segregation in housing.
LONDON, July 8 The nuclear defense theory, based on counterforce rather than countercity strategy, and first enunciated by Secretary McNamara, produced confused reactions in Europe. It is now dead.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 8 The America's Cup defense trials, which the New York Yacht Club refers to as observation races, were called off today when a wall of cottony fog precluded all chance of observation.
GRAND BLANC, Mich., July 8 (UPI) Bill Collins of Miami scored a par 34, 38 72 today for a four-under-par 284 total that won him the $9,000 top money in the Buick open golf tournament.

It will finally be fashionable this winter to be protected from the icy blasts. American millinery designers are muffling and bundling heads into turbans, toques, snoods and helmets of fur, fabric and leather. French films have inspired a wave of skullcaps and mannish hats to be worn with sleek hairdos, although high, hard-crowned hats continue, too. The perennial deep-brimmed slouch hat is labeled "Garbo." Furs, precious or unusual, are used lavishly. CARRIE DONOVAN.

PITTSBURGH, July 8 (AP) Roberto Clemente drove in three runs with a home run, a double and an infield out and carried Pittsburgh to a 6 5 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies in the second game of a double-header today.
KANSAS CITY, July 8 (AP) The Kansas City Athletics defeated the Washington Senators 6 5, in a 15-inning game today and completed a sweep of a three-game series.
DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., July 8--An "Indian village," with tepees, totem poles and an archery range, has been built here at Children's Village, a home for emotionally disturbed and delinquent boys.
The Citizens Budget Commission suggested yesterday a revision of state and local taxes so that the state could finance all costs of education and welfare.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 8 A day that had offered little promise of good sailing weather proved to be one of hard work today for the foredeck sailors who handle spinnakers in the Yacht Racing Association of Western Long Island Sound.

AMARILLO, Tex., July 8 (UPI)--A Continental Airlines Viscount II turbo-prop airliner carrying sixteen persons crash-landed and burned in a muddy wheat field today after an engine caught fire on take-off.
GENEVA, July 8 Sitting in a bare hotel bedroom, his voice suddenly taking on a strong new timbre, Georges Bidault said:

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 8 President Kennedy urged the nation's school administrators today to adopt effective programs of physical fitness before the start of the next school year.

RHEIMS, France, July 8 President de Gaulle and Chancellor Adenauer sealed French-German reconciliation today with a review of soldiers of the two countries and by jointly attending services in Rheims Cathedral, a focal point of more than a thousand years of French history.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 8 Late in 1880 a bearded young French explorer, Savorgnan de Brazza, set out on foot and under the most primitive conditions to penetrate the Niari Valley in what is now the southern section ...

LONDON, July 8 In one of its quietest periods of trading this year the London stock market last week maintained the price levels reached in the strong rally the week before. The firmer tone of Wall day acted as a stabilizing factor in solidifying the rises of Street on Monday and Tuesthe preceding Wednesday and Thursday.
JERSEY CITY, July 8 It was like any other Sunday in this waterfront industrial community, except that everybody seemed to be talking about where the next batch of money might turn up.

DETROIT, July 8 (AP) A disputed run in the ninth inning of the second game and superb pitching by Paul Foytack and Hank Aguirre gave the Detroit Tigers a 5-1, 3-2 double-header victory today over the Baltimore Orioles.
BUFFALO, July 8 Ch. Treceder's Painted Lady, a boxer, won best in show honors at the Kennel Club of Buffalo's thirtyseventh annual dog show today.
RICHMOND, Va. July 8 The marriage of Miss Barbara Thalhimer to Stanton L. Oppenheimer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Oppenheimer of New York, took place here this afternoon.

MIAMI BEACH, July 8 Orthodox rabbinical leaders took sharp issue today with participants in the recent dialogue in Jerusalem on the relationship between the American Jewish community and Israeli Jews.
CONCORD, N.H., July 8 Five Negroes from Louisiana arrived today in Concord on a gamble that the economic climate of New Hampshire would improve their lot.
ALGIERS, July 8 Hopes for a compromise to end the breach between leaders of the Algerian Provisional Government rose today.
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has announced the election of Eger V. Murphree as a vice president and research policy coordinator.
LOS ANGELES, July 8 (AP) Pete Runnels' eighth-inning homer provided the margin of victory today as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Los Angeles Angels, 5 4.

MOSCOW, July 8 Several United States companies have been sending representatives to the Soviet Union in recent weeks to study industrial processes with the possible view to acquiring licenses for manufacturing rights in the United States.
CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) Influences in the grain futures market were minor this week. Prices showed only moderate net changes.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 8 The chief of the Israel security services said at a Cabinet meeting in Jerusalem today that Jewish religious fanatics abroad were seeking to subvert the state of Israel.
A one-word explanation for the existence of the numerous and diverse religious communities within the Roman Catholic Church was offered yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. It was "need."

PENNINGTON, N.J., July 8 Stephen H. Barlow, former State Quartermaster General, died tonight at Princeton Hospital, where he had undergone surgery Friday. He was 67 years old and lived on Elm Ridge Road here.

GENEVA, July 8 The impasse in the international conference on Laos was broken suddenly tonight, renewing hope that the long-sought accord on Laotian neutrality would be signed within a week or ten days.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 9 (AP) Don Heinrich, a former All-America quarterback who helped lead the New York Giants to the National Football League championship in his first pro season, was purchased by the Oakland Raiders today from the Dallas Cowboys. The price was not disclosed.

KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., July 9 (AP) Robert C. Currier, owner of the Kennebunkport Playhouse, said today that seven hotels in this area had refused to lodge Claudia McNeil, the Negro actress, star of last week's play, "A Raisin in the Sun." An eighth consented to give Miss McNeil accommodations, he added.

Events today: George Gershwin concert, Stadium Symphony, Franz Allers, conductor, Camilla Williams, soprano, Lawrence Winters, baritone, Earl Wild, pianist, Lewisohn Stadium, 8:30 P. M.; Lower Eastside Neighborhoods Association Symphony Orchestra, Edgar Fischer, conductor, Leon Hyman and Judith Alstadter, pianists, East River Park Amphitheatre, 8:30.

CAIRO, July 9 President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic declared tonight that the nuclear arms race and the "pressures of overpopulation" were the principal dangers confronting the world.
CHICAGO, July 9 Cornelius Crane, an explorer and archaeologist, died today at his summer home in Belfast, Me. He was 57 years old.

Record sales and earnings were registered by Von's Grocery Company in the first twenty-four weeks of this year, T. A. Von der Ahe, president of the Southern California supermarket chain, reported yesterday.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 9 The Claude Harmons, father and son, became a par-wrecking pair as the Westchester open golf championship opened today.
WASHINGTON, July 9 Reduced 1963 schedules for the major leagues were requested today by the players, meeting here in conjunction with tomorrow's all-star game.
GENEVA, July 9 The Government of Laos submitted a statement of neutrality today at the fourteen-nation conference on the country's future.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 9 Plans for the control of erosion on the Long Island Sound shoreline of the village of Asharoken were approved today by the Suffolk Board of Supervisors.

Two Democrats who want to be Governor of New York took a hand yesterday in the debate Governor Rockefeller is having with Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California. Mr. Rockefeller, the only Republican in the group, got the worst of it.

THE new president of the Curtis Publishing Com pany, Matthew Joseph Culligan, has held high executive positions in the radio, television, magazine and advertising agency businesses. "He's fought on every side and has usually won," says one friend. Whenever people talk about ...
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) A proposal to divert a 2-centa-gallon tax on motorboat fuel to a fund for building up national parks was approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

PERHAPS no beauty salons offer a more needed respite for harried women than the few situated in New York City's garment district. For the semiannual fashion collection showings, Seventh Avenue becomes a crush of models, buyers and fashion press, and no matter what their mental state, their appearance must be immaculate.

LIMA, Peru, July 9 Fernando Belaunde Terry, Presidential candidate of the Popular Action party, made a violent attack tonight on the National Electoral Board, which is weighing the results of Peru's national election last month.
HAMMACHER SCHLEMMER, a store that is world famous for zany and eminently useful household devices, recently embarked on a project that will bring its specialties to stores across the country.

WASHINGTON, July 9 At the first all-star game last year a gale came howling through the Cave of the Winds San Francisco's Candlestick Park. It whistled out of the hills with such velocity that it actually blew Stu Miller, the frail pitcher, off the mound and caused him to be charged with a balk.
Darryl F. Zanuck is prepared to engage in a proxy fight for control of Twentieth Century-Fox, sources close to the film producer said yesterday.
Germany and American policy in Europe are discussed by Fred Warner Neal in his forthcoming book, "War and Peace and Germany."

A SUMMER wardrobe means not only cool clothes but also jewelry that matches their cool, fresh look. This season's costume jewelry turns to coral, turquoise, lapis lazuli and other semi-precious stones for inspiration. White is popular as always, but this year it is shaded to a subtle ivory or is brighter ...

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) Opposing forces totaling more than 60,000 paratroopers and other soldiers backer by Air Force fighters and bombers will maneuver next month for control of 5,500 square miles of land between Fort Bragg, N.C., and Fort Jackson, S.C.
An official of the Securities and Exchange Commission has been named vice president in charge of operations for the American Stock Exchange, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 9 President Kennedy is expected to make his four-day visit to Brazile on schedule if the Brazilian, political crisis is solved in the next few days. The visit on which Mrs. Kennedy will accompany him, is to begin July 30.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he opposed any state-wide sales tax and asserted once again that he saw no reason for new state taxes or increases in present taxes.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 9 LeRoy King, Rhode Island director of the National Emergency Council under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died at his home, Indian Spring, today. He was 77 years old.

LOUIS AUCHINCLOSS' "Portrait in Brownstone"* is a novel of social mountaineering in Manhattan. It traces with a kind of fiduciary fidelity the ups and downs of a prosperous. Fifty-third Street clan's tribal ways.

Theodore J. Flicker, whose improvisational theatre-cafe, The Premise, has become a popular fixture in Greenwich Village since it opened there almost two years ago, will brave London this month with a similar enterprise.

Clarence N. Sayen, former president of the Air Line Pilots Association, has been appointed mediator by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations in a maritime labor dispute.
The high-altitude nuclear explosion over the South Pacific was the first part of the biggest, most widely publicized and observed "secret" military experiment conducted anywhere in the world.
A Federal research grant for construction of a prototype automobile "completely designed for safety" was urged yesterday by a state legislative committee.
In the money league, the Mets are faring considerably better than they are in the National League.
REGINA, Sask., July 9 Reports were current here today that outside mediators might be called in to settle the Government and doctors' deadlock over medical care.
The Board of Education added a chapter yesterday to an unusual success story--the school system's Demonstration Guidance Project.
Acting Mayor Paul R. Screvane signed a bill yesterday making it illegal to employ or recruit strike-breakers in a legal strike or lockout.
The president of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association offered some words of praise yesterday for a competitive medium television. But the "praise" contained more than a few barbs.

Small of stature (5 feet 6 inches), slight of build (140 pounds) and comparatively short on experience (seven seasons of competition), Bob Farrington last year drove more winners (201) than any other reinsman in harness racing history.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) Claims of property damage as a result of noise from lowflying planes were discussed today at a meeting of congressmen, government officials and a special committee of the Conference of Mayors.

THE city's new educational television station, WNDT, expects to open its appeal for grass-roots support from the general public within the next two months. Contrary to widespread impressions occasioned ...
BLOOMFIELD, N. J., July 9 Mrs. Henry Doubilet of Hollywood, Deal, N. J., won the qualifying round medal in the ninth annual Garden State Women's Golf Association championship today.

Dr. John A. Glassbury, a physician who specialized in diseases of the ear, nose and throat, died Saturday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a brief illness. He was 64 years old. His home and office were at 150 West Fifty-fifth Street.
ALGIERS, July 9 Premier Ben Khedda stressed tonight the need for unity in building a new democratic state in Algeria.
NEWARK, July 9 Three school segregation suits involving Englewood, Montclair and Orange were dismissed today by United States District Court Judge Anthony T. Augelli.
By the time Congress adjourns, the Federal Reserve Board may get the idea that the heat in Washington this summer has been unusually oppressive even though the temperature remains normal.
RABAT, Morocco, July 9 Rival factions of the Algerian Provisional Government opened secret talks here today in an attempt to heal the breach in the nationalist leadership.
BAYONNE, France, July 9 Today, the sixteenth day, the Tour de Francepedaled briskly across Provence from Montpellier to Aix, a mere 115 miles or so.
WITH one bold stroke of imagination, a news paper publisher has come up with an exciting new form of wing shooting: the bagging of locusts.
DeKalb County, Ga., announced plans yesterday to offer an issue of $4,350,000 of water and sewer revenue bonds on July 24.

Morris Shapiro, a pension expert in the administration of the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, will lead a legal battle to deny a pension to Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh, who was convicted of conspiracy in an attempt to fix a Federal judge.
An opposition Nicaraguan leader asserted here yesterday that his country faced a revolt led by Communists as a result of the "dictatorial" regime of President Luis Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

MADRID, July 9 Ten leading Spanish and Portuguese banks have agreed here to form a consortium to promote economic and industrial expansion in their two countries, which have a total population of 40,000,000 people.
LONDON, July 9 The City of London, a densely built square mile of daytime financial activity, threw off its ghostly nighttime wrap tonight to begin a two-week festival.

MIAMI BEACH, July 9 Orthodox rabbinic leaders today deplored what they described as a tendency of Jewish lay and synagogue leaders to usurp the role of the rabbi in strengthening Jewish religious life.
DALLAS, July 9 (AP) The National Bowling League will suspend operations for 1962-63, Edwin Tobolowsky, acting league commissioner, said today.
PARIS, July 9 Industrial production in the European Common Market continued its gentle rise in the first third of this year, the Executive Commission of the six-nation group reported today.
Federal Aviation Agency test pilots will be given flight training this summer to enhance their practical knowledge of the variations that exist in airplane handling qualities.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 9 Merilyn Shapiro of Syracuse and Cheryl Ornes of Puerto Rico led the way into the quarter-final round of the 16year-and-under division as the New York State girls tennis championships began today at the County Tennis Club of Westchester.

The bond market continued to decline yesterday. United States Government securities of intermediate and long term sold off by from 4/32 to 14/32 in an inactive trading session dominated by the price markdowns of the professional dealers.
LONDON, July 9 The swelling in Sir Winston Churchill's injured left leg has increased but there is no cause for alarm, the doctors attending the 87year-old statesman reported today.
HONOLULU, July 9 Hawaiians, who had waited for more than a month for a front-row view of the Johnston Island nuclear test shot, were rewarded last night with a spectacular view.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 9 The mining concern whose large tax payments to Katanga Province are claimed by the Congo Central Government hopes for a reconciliation between the two regimes but continues to pay its taxes to the secessionist province.

When Chancellor Adenauer got aboard the plane to go back to Bonn, he seemed a little tired. But until that moment, in spite of his eighty-six years, he had made his visit to France with the energy, if not the sprightliness, of a man half his age.
Joseph V. (Newsboy) Moriarty, serving a two-to-threeyear term in New Jersy State Prison for gambling, may face new gambling charges.

GENEVA, July 9 Adlai E. Stevenson, the United States' chief delegate to the United Nations, called today on the European Economic Community to adopt "positive policies" in favor of the newly developing nations.
The ticker tape will be watched closely today for investor reaction to the margin cut. The chances are that the reaction will be enthusiastic.
Eastern Air Lines, Inc., the nation's fourth largest domestic air carrier, asked the Government yesterday for a subsidy of $23,869,051 to cover its needs for the rest of this year.
The task of moving a 220year-old, 250-ton house through Staten Island streets to a restoration project at Richmondtown was about half completed last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 9 In an atmosphere of general optimism, representatives of fifty-four producing and consuming countries today opened a conference designed to produce solutions for the increasing problem of the world's surplus of coffee.
A man who has spent twentytwo years in prison for murder was ordered freed yesterday by Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri.
The explosion of a hydrogen bomb above the Central Pacific yesterday sent magnetic waves and other effects coursing around the world.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 9? Talat Aydemir, a retired colonel and the leader of an unsuccessful attempt by a group of army officers to overthrow the Government of Premier Ismet Inonu last Feb. 22, was arrested by the Turkish police today.

The Royal Government of Laos, resolved to follow the path of peace and neutrality in conformity with the interests and aspirations of the Laotian people, as well as the principles of the joint communique of Zurich dated June 22, 1961, and the Geneva agreements of 1954, in order to build a peaceful, neutral, independent, democratic, unified and prosperous Laos, solemnly declares that:
A diode has been developed that can convert informationcarrying electric current directly into infromation-carrying light and is thus applicable to a number of communications problems.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 9 President Rafael F. Bonnelly asserted tonight that the Dominican Republic would utilize a special economic readjustment fund offered by President Kennedy for a diversified economic development.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 9 The South Vietnamese Government reported today that thirty-seven of its men had been killed, thirty-one wounded and thirty-seven men were missing as a result of a number of engagements with the Vietcong, the Communist guerrillas.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 9 (UPI) Kennecott Copper Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America announced jointly today the terms of a new two-year labor contract. This averted a strike at Kennecott's properties in Utah and Arizona.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) The Senate formally ratified the new three-year international wheat agreement today by a vote of 79 to 0.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee overrode Republican opposition today and approved President Kennedy's nomination of Matthew H. McCloskey as Ambassador to Ireland.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, July 8 On a chilly night last week relays of young men turned a huge wheel operating an old printing press. They were striving to keep alive the weekly El Enano, or The Dwarf, one of the remnants of the Opposition press in Paraguay.
CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) Few grain futures gained today and those slightly as speculators controlled most of the activity in the absence of any significant commercial demand on the Board of Trade.
American Airlines and the Transport Workers Union announced the settlement yesterday of contract disputes involving 10,000 airline ground personnel.

A syndicate of investors, including Harry A. Kotcher, a lawyer, has bought the eightstory apartment building at 1608 Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn. The building, which was constructed in 1958, was bought for $500,000 in cash and mortgages. It contains forty apartments.
A committee has been formed to plan for the fourth annual Gourmet Dinner and Dance, to be held this autumn as a benefit for the Visiting Nurse Service of New York.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) A somewhat smaller cotton crop than last year's was indicated by a Department of Agriculture report today that plantings are down 1 per cent from last year's level.
ON Thursday afternoon I finished a cheerful column about three novels by William Faulkner. On Friday noon the melancholy news of his death arrived.
ROME, July 9 Violence in a two day strike of metalworkers became a serious issue in national politics today.

The major television networks said yesterday they hoped to present tonight the first television pictures to be relayed by Telstar, the experimental communications satellite developed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
M. Francis Snowber was the broker in the recent sale of the synagogue property at 202 to 210 West Ninety-first Street.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) Nearly 30,000 new jobs will be provided in areas of chronic unemployment by projects approved in the last year by the Area Redevelopment Administration, Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges reported today.
A new Belgian steel plant costing nearly $260,000,000 in its first stage of development is expected to begin operations in about three and one-half years, it was disclosed yesterday.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 9 Mrs. David Sinclair and her crew of two from the Noroton (Conn.) Yacht Club took a commanding lead today after three of seven races for the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound.

LEWISBURG, Pa., July 9 Moose McCormick, an outfielder on the New York Giants of yesteryear who figured in one of baseball's most famous episodes, died today in Evangelical Community Hospital. His age was 81.
LONDON, July 9 Alterations will begin this month on the Royal Festival Hall, one of London's principal concert halls, at a cost of 1,500,000 ($4,200,000).

The students of Rangoon University have long been notorious for indifference to study and a propensity for turbulent, often Communist-manipulated, political activity. Popularly elected governments made up mostly of men who began their political careers thirty years ago as anticolonialist student radicals have been reluctant to impose discipline and academic standards on a younger generation at the state-run school.

A leasehold running for twenty-five years on the four-story business building at 150 West Thirty-fourth Street, opposite Macy's, has been sold by the Schwartz Food Corporation through the Charles Berger Company, broker. It was bought by the 148 West Thirty-fourth Street Corporation for investment.

The election of a man from Madison Avenue, Matthew J. Culligan, as president of the Curtis Publishing Company, foreshadows the twilight of a dynasty that has ruled a great magazine enterprise for three generations.
A familiar sound echoed through the city yesterday, mingling with the shouts and laughter of children at play.

The planned launching this morning of the Telstar communications satellite marks another dramatic thrust in man's penetration of the mysteries of space. The satellite, sent into orbit through a partnership of industry and Government, inaugurates a new era in communications.

Two trans-Atlantic liners, the 51,988-ton United States, of the United States Lines, and the 81,237-ton Queen Mary, of the Cunard Line, will arrive behind schedule today, each with an additional and unscheduled passenger aboard.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) A Government-sponsored tour of Southeast Asia by Joey Adams, comedian, included a feud with his band leader and a newspaper column by his wife recalling the time she called a prime minister "Honey," according to Congressional testimony released today.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 9 Cambodia rejected today a South Vietnamese claim to two tiny islands in the gulf of Siam and as much as challenged her neighbor to bring the case before the International Court of Justice at The Hague.

LOS ANGELES, July 9 (AP) Unheralded Phil Moyer of Portland, Ore., beat Sugar Ray Robinson tonight. He gained a ten-round split decision after the world featherweight champion, Davey Moore, had knocked out Mario Diaz in the co-feature of an all-star boxing card.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 9 Columbia's mast went over the side as though felled by an ax during her match with Nefertiti in today's America's Cup observation trials.
FRESH green beans, crisp and snappy looking, are current ly available in profusion. Both in quality and cost, they act as a direct reproach to anyone tempted to use the frozen version at this season.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) Four Republican Congressmen today scored the Kennedy Administration's "human rights" record. They mentioned discrimination against Negroes, captive nations behind the Iron Curtain, and immigration law reforms.
The appointment of Edmund Antrobus as director of public relations for the British Travel Association here has been announced by James T. Turbayne, the group's general manager in this country.
WHITE PLAINS, July 9 The State Attorney General's office has begun an investigation of expenditures in the construction of the New England Thruway.

Lawyers for Allan P. Kirby, former chairman of the Alleghany Corporation, charged yesterday that the proposed plan for recapitalizing the shares of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., would "divest Alleghany of control of I.D.S. without compensation."
LONDON, July 9 British Government securities and South African gold mining shares led the stock market again today.

Having completed their sixweek jazz tour of the Soviet Union, sixteen members of Benny Goodman's band flew into New York International Airport yesterday and announced that everything about their trip had been great, except that the King of Swing was insufficiently far out.
Some trans-Pacific radio circuits fell silent as though a plug had been pulled when the United States fired a hydrogen bomb high over Johnston Island yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 9 The Department of Agriculture proposed today an increase in Federal bonds required of warehousemen holding agreements to store government-owned grain.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) The Senate prepared tonight for a showdown next week on the Administration-backed bipartisan medical care plan by agreeing to limit debate on the controversial issue.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 9 Motions of no confidence in the Government of Premier David Ben-Gurion for its quick expulsion of Dr. Robert A. Soblen were presented to the Knesset (Parliament) today. They are to be debated on Wednesday.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., July 9 William Edward Lane Jr., formerly Supervisor of the Town of Cortlandt and president of the Peekskill Village Council, died today at his home, 735 Requa Street, after a long illness. His age was 81.
RANGOON, Burma, July 9 (AP) Gen. Ne Win's ruling Revolutionary Council stepped up measures to end student outbursts by closing all of Burma's colleges and universities tonight.
ATLANTA, July 9 Gov. S. Ernest Vandiver defended today the failure of state highway patrolmen to carry out his order prohibiting a Ku Klux Klan demonstration on near-by Stone Mountain.

Within a week of the seventeenth anniversary of the test of the first atomic bomb on the desert of New Mexico, the United States exploded a rocket-borne thermonuclear device high above Johnston Island. Contrary to general belief, this was not the first hydrogen bomb exploded high in the upper atmosphere.
WASHINGTON, July 9 The Federal Reserve Board cut the minimum cash requirement for stock market purchases today to 50 cents on the dollar.
The day of the meter reader may be going the way of the lamplighter and the ice man if a test in Owosso, Mich., is successful.
A Red Cross drive for blood to prevent the usual critical summer shortage was begun yesterday by Acting Mayor Paul R. Screvene at City Hall.

The Gustin-Bacon Manufacturing Company's Kansas City, Mo., maker of glass fiber insulating products, has expanded into the safety brake field through acquisition of Maxibrake, Inc., of Pasadena, Calif.

WASHINGTON, July 9 The United States set off a thermonuclear explosion high over Johnston Island in the Pacific Ocean early today. It released a powerful flash of energy that lit up the night skies from Hawaii to New Zealand.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) The Senate Judiciary Committee finished rewriting Senator Estes Kefauver's drug bill today by knocking out a provision designed to inform physicians more fully about harmful side effects of prescription drugs.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) The Government today decided not to prosecute James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, on assault charges pressed against him here.
Trading in Maine potatoes futures spurted yesterday in anticipation of the Government's late-summer and fall acreage report expected today.

ALBANY, July 9 Two Democratic legislative leaders today predicted that if Governor Rockefeller should be re-elected, he would attempt to rescind the present income tax credits of $25 for married couples and $10 for individuals.

HYDE PARK, N. Y., July 9 Mrs. Helen Rebecca Roosevelt Robinson, widow of Theodore Douglas Robinson, Assistant Secretary of the Navy during Calvin Coolidge's Administration, died Saturday at Northern Dutchess Hospital in Rhinebeck. Her age was 80.

WASHINGTON, July 9 Washington first in war, first in peace and, as the old line goes, still last in the American League girded itself tonight for another brief whirl in the major league baseball spotlight.
Service between 168th Street and 207th Street on the A (Eighth Avenue) line of the IND division of the subway was slowed for an hour yesterday afternon because of telephone cable trouble.
BUFFALO, July 9 (AP) The president of the American Newspaper Guild called today for Federal legislation to halt what he termed the spread of monopoly in the newspaper industry.

KANSAS CITY, July 9 (UPI) The executive committee of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics declined today to join the federations being formed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The move was expected.
WASHINGTON, July 9 The Government's short-term borrowing costs rose slightly on the regular weekly sale of Treasury bills today.

The word for yesterday's weather in New York was "miserable" until late at night. A high temperature of 95 degrees made it the third hottest day this year. This, combined with oppressive humidity, reduced millions of New Yorkers to sticky, unhappy creatures longing for relief.
WASHINGTON, July 9 The House-Senate stalemate on appropriations, led on each side by an octogenarian, erupted in a flurry of harsh words on the Senate floor today.
CHICHESTER, England, July 9 This was more like it. With its second production tonight, John Ford's "The Broken Heart," the new Chichester Festival began to look alive.

WASHINGTON, July 9 President Kennedy set the stage today for an early reversal by the House of the Senate's prohibition of all aid but surplus food to Communist Poland and Yugoslavia. The President summoned leaders of both parties in the House of Representatives to an unusual White House conference ...

PITTSBURGH, July 9 (AP) An operating engineer who tried to save a man from fatal acid burns and a building contractor who rescued a man trapped in a well were cited for bravery today by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission.
The wholesade commodity price index was unchanged Friday from 80.5 Thursday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 84.2 on June 30, 1961.
TROON, Scotland, July 9 Samuel Jackson Snead shot a 69 on the old links at Troon today.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These notes do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.
BUFFALO, July 9 (AP) Four players with two-over-par 73's shared the lead today in the opening qualifying round of the thirty-seventh United States Public Links golf championship at Sheridan Park.

The Federal Reserve Board's first cut in margin requirements in two years was hailed in the financial district yesterday as a "welcome" move that should give the sagging stock market at least a temporary shot in the arm.
Negotiators for 10,000 organized painters and 173 contractors were reported far apart yesterday in efforts to agree on a new contract.

Steel production last week dropped to the lowest level since the closing days of 1960. Output in the July 4 holiday week fell to 1,239,000 tons, down 17.5 per cent from the 1,501,000 tons of the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., July 9 A pall of smoke rolled across the Hudson River toward Manhattan tonight from a general alarm grass fire that began about 3 P. M. in the Jersey Meadows. By 10 P. M. firemen reported the blaze's progress had been checked.

MADISON, Wis., July 9 (UPI) Attempts to reapportion Wisconsin's legislative and Congressional districts in time for the fall elections ran into an unexpected obstacle today when the State Treasurer, Mrs. Dena Smith, refused to countersign a $3,500 check for Federal court fees.

AS part of its expansion program, the Museum of Mod ern Art announced this week that its Architecture and Design Collection will have a permanent gallery of its own, named in honor of Philip L. Goodwin.

MASAUSI PASS, American Samoa, July 9 For fifteen minutes last night the earth's magnetic field was made visible in the skies here during a spectacular celestial display set off by the United States thermonuclear explosion 2,000 miles away.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 9 Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has abandoned its plans to make a movie of William L. Shirer's best-selling book, "The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich."
TWENTY-ONE paintings and twelve sculptures from the collection of Governor Rockefeller go on exhibition today at the Brooklyn Museum, where they will remain through Aug. 26.
The New York Herald Tribune publishes today an editorial concerning an article in Sunday's New York Times.

Stocks resumed their rally yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange after a one-day pause on Friday. Wall Street was further encouraged by the fact that volume increased on the advance, even though over-all volume was less than on Friday.
MOSCOW, July 9--A professor from Chicago took the rostrum at a Kremlin conference today and criticized Soviet policy.
A small blaze on a parapet of the Women's House of Detention in Greenwich Village threw inmates into an uproar last night and drew a crowd of about 100 persons.
Cotton futures were 25 cents a bale down to 25 cents up yesterday, except for new December. That month rose $1.75 bid on the New York Cotton Exchange.
VIENNA, July 9 Physicians closed their offices today in a one-day warning strike against the Health Insurance Institute, which administers Vienna's public health plan.
HAVANA, July 9 (UPI) The Castro regime called on its followers today to "crush energetically "any further public criticism of the Government."
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) President Kennedy welcomed home today some of the first Air National Guardsmen to return as a unit from Germany after having been sent there in the Berlin crisis last year.
DETROIT, July 9 (AP) Ford Motor Company reached the 1,000,000 mark in auto production for the calendar year last week, as it attempted to erase losses caused by a twoweek strike in June.
The American-Korean Foundation, Inc., announced yesterday that it had contributed more than $12,000,000 in money and goods toward the rehabilitation of South Korea.

CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) The American Hospital Association expressed opposition today to a newly proposed bipartisan amendment to the health care for the aged bill. The association voted its objection in January to the King-Anderson bill during its annual meeting.
PHILADELPHIA, July 9--Matthew Joseph Culligan, 44-year-old New York advertising and public relations executive, was elected president of the Curtis Publishing Company of Philadelphia today.

Polylady of the Darby Dan Farm proved to be the true favorite in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The 30,026 customers sent her off the oddson favorite in the six-furlong Forever Yours Purse, and she won by four lengths. She paid $3.10 for $2 straight.

THE declarer in this deal was Gerard Oestreicher, who plays regularly in one of New York's strongest games and who also produced the musical show "Milk and Honey," which has been running on Broadway since last October.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., July 9 More than 200 children started participating today in special pilot projects in physical fitness throughout Huntington Township.
CORNING, N.Y., July 9 (AP) Robert J. Manning, Assistant Secretary of State for public affairs, insisted tonight that Government leaders recognized that the public needed more, not less information.

Joseph E. Seagram Sons, considered the largest manufacturer of distilled spirits in the United States, was sued yesterday by Austin, Nichols Co., Inc., a wholesale liquor distributor, for $15,000,000.
Vincent J. Donehue has taken on the assignment of staging "Lord Pengo," the S.N. Behrman dramatization of his New Yorker profile on Lord Duveen, the fabulous art collector.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 10 Three men who were graduated in June from Fairleigh Dickinson College in New Jersey and a girl were arrested here today and charged with burglary.

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., July 10 Once a Week, the controller of the First Strategic Aerospace Division stops worrying about millions of dollars of Air Force assets and takes his place in front of a class in painting.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., July 10 Nadine Netter of Scarsdale, the top-seeded player, and Alice Christer of Jersey City, No. 2 in the draw, won their opening matches in the New York State girls' tennis championship at the County Tennis Club today.
SYDNEY, Australia, July 10 Roman Catholic schools in Goulburn, New South Wales, will be closed for six weeks starting Friday in a protest against the lack of state aid. The schools have 2,200 pupils.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 10 Roger Ginsberg, a 23-year-old amateur from the Harrison Country Club, holed a birdie on the fifty-fourth hole today to win the Westchester open golf championship with a score of 212.

The proposal of the Norfolk and Western Railway to form a new system through merger drew mixed reactions yesterday from two smaller Eastern roads, which so far have been left out of the rail-merger picture.

The showings of American fall fashions, which began in May, drew to a close Monday night with the collection of Norman Norell. LONDON, July 10 The brief flurry during which we tried to impose our nuclear strategy and total nuclear control on the rest of NATO now seems over. The illogical policy, so logically argued by Secretary McNamara, appears to have been abandoned after a three-month unsuccessful effort to push it through.

BOSTON, July 10 (AP) A Federal grand jury returned a two-count indictment today against the president of a New York company in connection with a proposal to construct the Carlton Towers Apartments in Springfield.

The initial screen treatment of "Meeting at a Far Meridian," the first co-production by the United States and the Soviet Union, has been approved by officials of both governments, Lester Cowan, the producer, aid yesterday.
Two former citizens of the Soviet Union have written accounts of their disillusionment with communism.

In generally quiet trading, the leading commodity futures on New York exchanges hovered between plus and minus signs. Some of the disinterest in commodities was attributed to a switch of some speculative interest to the active stock market.
BRASILIA, July 10 Dr. Francisco Brochado da Rocha was confirmed today as the new Premier of Brazil.

WASHINGTON, July 10 Maybe it's just the drowsy indolence of the summertime, but American opinion seems remarkably receptive, or at least acquiescent, to President Kennedy's proposal for a "partnership" of the Atlantic nations.

While summer jobs for young men in New York are usually air-conditioned but unremunerative, there nevertheless are some college boys now earning) more than $120 a week while enjoying the fresh breezes of the Hudson River amid parties, rich men and sleek yachts.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 10 Supervisor John J. Burns anpounced a plan today to rezone an undeveloped 325-acre site to permit residential, industrial and recreational development.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) Republican Congressional leaders disputed today Senator Barry Goldwater's contention that the new Republican National Citizens Committee intended to influence policy and the selection of candidates.

WASHINGTON, July 10 Players from ten different clubs who had been battling one another tooth and nail from the start of the baseball season pitched in together today and scored "a real team victory" for the National League in the allstar game.
The delicate fiber of FrancoAmerican relations was snarled here this week in a tangle of not so bon mots.

A retrospective exhibition of the work of Edward Lear, English humorist, painter and naturalist known for his "Nonsense" books, is on view in the Central Children's Room of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The exhibition ...

MADISON, Wis., July 10--The nation's first hearings on reapportionment before a court-appointed special master opened today. State Attorney General John W. Reynolds testified that "invidious discrimination" existed against voters in Wisconsin's populous districts.
The prospects for diverting substantial numbers of travelers from the airlines' chief rival, the automobile, to the transport plane do not appear bright, a nation-wide survey indicated yesterday.

Directors of Reichhold Chemicats, Inc., yesterday omitted the second-quarter dividend on the common stock. The company has paid 2 per cent in stock dividends in the last three quarters, the most recent on May 15.

BONN, Germany, July 10 Chancellor Adenauer said today that he and President de Gaulle had agreed on the necessity of French-German relations so close that neither country could ever again make a pact with the Soviet Union against the other.

One key point emerged from the flow of rhetoric in Premier Khrushchev's wide-ranging speech in Moscow yesterday: The Soviet Union intends to continue the arms race, despite the privations it inflicts on the Russian people and the menace it holds for all nations. This will not surprise those who remember that the Soviet Union started the current round of nuclear testing by ending the moratorium on such explosions last fall.

The decision of Senators Eastland and Dodd to bow out of an investigation of the sugar lobby leaves the field to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, the group best qualified to look into the whole troublesome issue of the tactics some foreign representatives use to influence United States legislation. Two men carrying a paper bag containing $50,000 worth of stolen jewelry were arrested yesterday at the Avenue of the Americas, and Forty-seventh Street after a struggle.
