Dr. Royal Wilbur France, who turned from corporation law and teaching to crusading for civil liberties, died yesterday in University Hospital, where he had undergone a heart operation a week ago. He would have been 79 years old July 27.
ORAN, Algeria, July 10 The Algerian Liberation Army in Oran appeared tonight to be planning public executions for Moslems convicted of lootding and kidnapping.

THERE are platoons of happily surprised sportsmen in Westchester County these days now that a court decision favorable to them has been handed down in the argument over the establishment of a sportsmen's center on park land near Cortland.
A sapphire-studded object about the size and shape of a beach ball, weighing as much as a man, went into orbit yesterday to forge a new communications link between America and Europe.

MOSCOW, July 10 Premier Khrushchev proposed today that the United States, British and French forces in West Berlin be replaced by troops from the small nations in the North Atlantic and Warsaw alliances.

AMERICAN family life has put out to sea. Last summer, 35,875,000 Americans more than the population of Mexico went before mast and motor, many to complain about, the increasing congestion of the waterways.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey warned today that "Democrats are digging their own political grave" in the dispute between the two Appripriations Committees.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 10 "The world's coffee situation is unsatisfactory and it can only get worse unless we are successful in concluding an effective (international) agreement," W. Michael Blumenthal, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, declared today.

The Columbia Broadcasting System omitted most of the remarks of Frederick R. Kappel, chairman of the board of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, from its coverage last night of the satellite telecast.

WASHINGTON, July 10 An experimental communications satellite was rocketed into orbit today in a joint Government-industry venture into space. It marked a historic, highly successful first step toward achieving a revolutionary new global communications system in space.
CAIRO, July 10 Delegates to an international conference of developing nations heard strong pleas today for means of supporting prices of the raw materials on which their progress depends.

THE debt that most cooks owe to the lemon is great at any season, but it is greatest of all in summer. In addition to this fruit's ability to provide its own flavor or to enhance most others, it also has the summertime advantage of being extremely refreshing.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) A group of major stockholders of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. asked Federal authorization today to offer the public about $80,500,000 of General Motors, Corporation stock distributed to them yesterday.
Clergy and laity of the Protestant Episcopal Society for Cultural and Racial Unity will mount a vigil outside St.John's Episcopal Hospital in Brooklyn this afternoon.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 10 The first Venezuelan steel was poured yesterday in a huge iron and steel plant on the Orinoco River.
Laughter echoed in the Columbia Grammar School's indoor pool yesterday where laughter was not expected this summer.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, July 10 Two United Nations'jets roared over head today on the eve of the second anniversary of Katanga's announcement of secession from the Congo.
NAIROBI, Kenya, July 10 Britain announced today she was prepared to pay the cost of purchasing 1,000,000 acres or more of farmland owned by whites in Kenya, to resettle landless blacks.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) A nuclear test device dropped from an airplane was set off today in the vicinity of Christmas Island in the Pacific.

BERLIN, July 10 Three Brazilian labor leaders walked out of the congress of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions here today in a conflict over nominations for the group's executive board.

Matthew J. Culligan, who was named on Monday to be the new president of the Curtis Publishing Company, is a man with considerable self-confidence. As such, he is convinced he has the formula for restoring the vast magazine empire to its former health.

TROON, Scotland, July 10Arnold Palmer and Phil Rodgers fired 67's the best round of the day and a native son, Eric Brown, won the medal with 139 as almost all the world's best golfers qualified today for what is expected to be the most exciting British Open in years.
BUFFALO, July 10 (AP) A State Department official said tonight that the Communists were making "some goofs" in their foreign aid programs "that make our bureaucracy look like a management dream."
A dispatch dictated in Andover, Me., by Richard Witkin and relayed via the orbiting Telstar satellite teas received last night by The New York Times.

WASHINGTON, July 10 Ralph Houk, the American League manager, could have used a few of President Kennedy's "quail highs" today. In fact, the way his all-stars were performing at the plate, he might have done worse than use the President himself.

PAGOPAGO, American Samoa, July 9--The dazzling and sustained brilliance from America's high-altitude thermonuclear explosion last night left some Samoan natives terrified that the heavens might fall on them.
TURIN, Italy, July 10 The police tore down barricades here today and later broke up renewed rioting to quell what they called an attempted revolt.
McLean Industries, Inc., and its two subsidiary shipping companies were accused yesterday of attempting "to secure a monopoly" in the trade between Atlantic Coast ports and Puerto Rico.

CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) Flour mill buying, the first of any consequence since harvest of the winter crop began, sent wheat futures up on the Board of Trade today. Other grants and soybeans slumped under selling pressure.

WASHINGTON, July 10 The power hitters of the National League were getting nowhere today against the American Leaguers in a tense, exciting allstar game on a glorious afternoon in the capital's splendiferous new stadium. So the brain cells began to whir in the cranium of crafty Freddie Hutchinson, the No. 1 thinker of the Nationals.

MORE than 150 entries have been placed for the Sports Car Club of America's Northeast divisional championship races to be held at Thompson, Conn., on Saturday and Sunday. Six races are scheduled over the two-mile course. The opener, ...
The Democratic State Committee outlined its plans yesterday for liberalizing party rules to make New York "as much a Democratic state as New York City is a Democratic city."
VIENTIANE, Laos, July 10 (AP) Deputy Premier Phoumi Nosavan proposed today the formation of a "unified national movement" to preserve the independence and neutrality of Laos.
A high Treasury official told the House Banking and Currency Committee yesterday that the United States balance of payments deficit would be less this year than originally anticipated.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 10 Jules Eckert Goodman, a playwright and author, died of pneumonia today in Peekskill Hospital. He was 85 years old.

EXACTLY twenty-six years ago last night George Gershwin made the last of his many appearances in the summer concerts at Lewisohn Stadium. Twenty-five years ago today he died, but already Gershwin Night at the stadium had become established as an annual event.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) The Government predicted today that farmers would harvest the smallest total acreage of crops this year since 1909. Nevertheless, production appears likely to be plentiful.

WASHINGTON, July 10 A Government expert asserted today that there were immense difficulties in the way of carrying out successfully a peacetime national wage policy designed to produce noninflationary labor contract settlements.
LONDON, July 10--President William V. S. Tubman of Liberia was greeted by the Queen and Government leaders today as he arrived to begin a four-day state visit.
Buildings Commissioner Harold Birns yesterday announced a relaxation of the general ban on the use of power-operated scaffolds on buildings in the city.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 10 The New York Yacht Club's seventeenth annual junior regatta was held on Long Island Sound here today.

MIAMI BEACH, July 10 Two prominent American Orthodox rabbis asserted today that Orthodox Judaism could not be considered "an anachronism or outmoded faith which can only survive or live in a ghetto surrounding."

REGINA, Sask., July 10 Hearings on an injunction sought by three Saskatchewan citizens to halt the Government's medical care plan were postponed for a week today in court here. Judge D.C. Disbery granted the plaintiffs more time to prepare their case.

The numbers of onlookers crowding the balcony overlooking the floor of the New York Stock Exchange was far above average yesterday. Besides the usual groups of out-of-towners, quite a few interested observers came to watch the reaction to yesterday's margin cut.

ANDOVER, Me., July 10 Live television pictures leaped the ocean for the first time tonight when broadcasts beamed from here were relayed to France and England by way of the Telstar satellite. The pictures were also seen on television screens in the United States.
The right of the President to make interim judicial appointments when the Senate is in recess was upheld unanimously yesterday by the United States Court of Appeal.
A court decision was reserved yesterday on a move to obtain a temporary injunction to block the proposed $270,000,000 World Trade Center planned by the Port of New York Authority.

Following are excerpts from Premier Khrushchev's address yesterday in Moscow to the World Congress on General Disarmament and Peace, as trans- mitted in English by Tass, the official Soviet press agency:
NEW DELHI, India, July 10 An Indian note charged today that Chinese Communist troops had encircled an Indian checkpost in the Galwan Valley in the disputed Ladakh area of eastern Kashmir.
WASHINGTON, July 10 Efforts to clear the way for Kennedy-Nixon-style television debates by local political candidates next fall received a warm reception in Congress today.

RICHMOND, Va., July 10 (AP) John O. Marsh Jr., a lawyer, topped a field of five in the strongly conservative Seventh District Democratic primary election today. A proKennedy Democrat easily won the other House primary in the northern Virginia Tenth District.

Miss Martha Artemis Taylor, daughter of Mrs. Charles G. Taylor of 40 Central Park South and the late Mr. Taylor, was married here yesterday afternoon to Albert Robert Koehl. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Koehl of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y.
Los Angeles borrowed $21,000,000 yesterday to finance school construction. The money was raised through an issue of unified school district bonds and an issue of junior college district bonds.

ALGIERS, July 10 The breakdown of the leadership negotiations in Rabat tonight appears to leave the Algerian National Liberation Army as the only really organized force in Algeria outside the capital itself.

CLEVELAND, July 10 The requiem sounded over American tennis, after what happened in the men's singles at Wimbledon, belongs in the same category as the report of Mark Twain's demise. So says the captain of the Davis Cup team.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee urged Congress today to act before vital United States policy interests "become tangled in webs of domestic lobbying prompted and paid for by foreign interests."
An extension of the urban renewal program was proposed yesterday to let the Federal Government buy homes in the nuisance area around airports and resell them for non-residential use.
HOLMDEL, N.J., July 10 The first live television broadcast beamed from a satellite in orbit was received at the Bell Telephone Company's laboratories on a closed circuit tonight.
ATHENS, Tenn.,, July 10 Paul Cantrell, whose McMinn County political machine was smashed in 1946 after a wild armed uprising by war veterans, died Sunday night. He was 66 years old.
Thirteen men convicted of narcotics conspiracy were sentenced to a total of 276 years in prison yesterday in Federal Court. In addition, two were fined $20,000 each.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 10 Nefertiti shot across the finish line on the only tack made during what had been planned as a closing windward leg today and scored a close and spectacular victory over Easterner in the America's Cup defense trials.

LIMA, Peru, July 10 The National Electoral Board rejected today a petition calling for invalidation of the election results in La Libertad Department, where Victor Raul Haya de la Torre had rolled up 100,000 votes for President.
WASHINGTON, July 10 A decline in retail sales for the second successive month gave a further sign today that the recovery from the recession may be slowing down.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 10 Worth Seein' fashioned a stunning upset tonight, winning the $10,742.50 Senator John J. Dunnigan Trot at Monticello Raceway, as Impish, the 1-4 favorite, wound up a soundly beaten third in the one-mile test for 3-year-old fillies.

SEATTLE, July 10 (UPI) A Federal grand jury here today indicted five insulation contracting companies doing business in the Pacific Northwest and four of their executives on charges of conspiring to fix prices and rig bids.
The City Club of New York formally asked the city and state Controllers yesterday to deny a pension to former Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh.
JERSEY CITY, July 10 A Hudson County grand jury heard testimony today from nine witnesses concerning the gambling empire of Joseph V. (Newsboy) Moriarty.

WASHINGTON, July 10 Abba P. Schwartz, a Washington lawyer who has long been active in refugee and other humanitarian causes, will soon be named head of the State Department's politically sensitive Bureau of Security and Consular Affairs.

The National Basketball Association expanded to ten teams yesterday by taking in the Cleveland Pipers. Cleveland has been the prize team of the American Basketball League and the move may mean at least a temporary suspension of that league.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 10 Five public colleges and universities in the South admitted Negroes for the first time last month, the Southern Education Reporting Service said today.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 10 Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells started defense of her Garden State Women's Golf Association championship today with a hard-won victory.
LONDON, Wednesday, July 11 The first Transatlantic television signal appeared briefiy on British screens last night, relayed by the Telstar from high over France.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 10 The Yugoslav Government announced today something everyone in Belgrade has known for months: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Union's titular Chief of State, will pay an official visit to Yugoslavia this fall.
A second union announced yesterday that it would seek to organize non-medical workers in New York's voluntary hospitals.
Supreme Court Justice Abraham N. Geller yesterday refused to set aside a jury's award of $3,500,000 to John Henry Faulk in his libel suit against Aware, Inc., and two individuals.
WASHINGTON, July 10 Televised debates are beginning to look like the biggest develop ment in American politics since the whistle-stop gave way to the airport rally.
WASHINGTON, July 10 The State Department issued two statements today dismissing Premier Khrushchev's proposals to replace Western troops in Berlin as unacceptable ...

A father threw his 2-year-old daughter and 1-year-old son out of their third-floor apartment in the Bronx last night and then jumped himself, the police reported. The girl died instantly and the father two hours later. The son was critically injured.

Mitsui Co., Ltd., Japanese import-export concern, has leased a floor in the Pan Am Building, which is nearing completion at 200 Park Avenue, behind Grand Central Terminal. The lease was announced by James D. Landauer and Jacks Cotton, who head investment interests building the skyscraper.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 10 South Vietnamese infantrymen ferried by United Mates Marine helicopters struck back hard today at a Communist guerrilla band believed to be from the force that overwhelmed a Government civil guard post last Thursday in the Camau peninsula.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, July 8 President Alfredo Stroessnee has opened the campaign for re-election, of his dictatorial regime in February by claiming credit for impressive economic and social gains in this landlocked nation of l,760,000.

The first day of 50 per cent margins caused volume to soar to a three-week high on the New York Stock Exchange, brokerage houses to worry some about having sufficient personnel, and the small investor to wonder whether this was a good time to buy.

CLEVELAND, July 10 (AP) The head of the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots called today for a program to protect deck officers from what he called the adverse effects of automation.
The Garden Properties Company has bought two six-story elevator apartment buildings at 770 to 780 Garden Street, facing Bronx Park, for investment. The Sidney Newman Company was the broker.

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 10 Native Fire Islanders and summer residents came here in ferries, buses, private boats and cars today to voice their opposition to a plan to build a road atop a barrier dike.

Eastern Air Lines, Inc., grounded for eighteen days by a walkout of flight engineers, suggested yesterday that the only way to settle the strike might be to amend the labor laws to require compulsory arbitration in such disputes.

THE first television pictures received last night from the communications satellite Telstar had excellent quality and stability. If the inaugural program hardly seemed worthy of so historic an occasion, the realization that the pictures were reaching one's home via space imparted its own sense of excitement.

WASHINGTON, July 10 The National League spiked the big guns of the American League today, turned on a bit of blinding speed in its own behalf and won the first of 1962's two all-star games. The score was 3 1.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 10 Lee Andrews of Saw Mill Lane, prominent Greenwich real estate official and former member of the Greenwich Town Plan Commission, died last night in, Greenwich Hospital after an illness of several weeks. His age was 62.

MT. CLEMENS, Mich., July 10 (AP) Tommy Milton, pioneer auto race driver, who was the first to win the Indianapolis 500-mile classic twice, was found shot to death today at his home near Mount Clemens. He was 68 years old.

Prices of United States Government securities and other prime debt securities moved upward yesterday in a trading session visibly broader than that of Monday. The recovery in the Government market wiped out most of Monday's losses.
The Neighborhood Conservation Bureau of the Housing and Redevelopment Board will be headed by Harry C. Harris, the Board announced yesterday.

Prices of stocks advanced yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in heavy trading following the reduction in margin requirements from 70 to 50 per cent. However, sharp early gains were pared in later transactions.
MADRID, July 10 Generalissimo Francisco Franco will carry out a major Cabinet overhaul tomorrow and create the post of Vice President of the Cabinet.
LEE, Mass., July 10 The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, in the third week of the season, has come up with the most ambitious and possibly the most satisfying program seen here this summer.

BURBANK, Calif., July 10 Mr. and Mrs. Francis Henry Ryan have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Patricia Ryan, to Peter Stuyvesant French. His parents are Mrs. Harriet Holder Peabody of Haverford, Pa., and Stuyvesant LeRoy French of New York and Dexter House. Chester, N.H.
HOLMDEL, N.J., July 10 Following is the text of a telephone conversation between Frederick R. Kappel of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Vice President Johnson by way of Telstar:

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., July 10 Two public members of the state's joint legislative committee studying the alcoholic beverage control law said in response to inquiries today that in their private professions they represented distillers.
LONDON, July 10 Sir Winston Churchill has developed a thrombosis a blood clot has formed in his injured left leg.
ALBANY, Ga., July 10 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Negro integration leader, and a fellow minister went to jail today to emphasize their nonviolent defiance of racial barriers.
WASHINGTON, July 10 Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said after a White House meeting today that the Administration was "more sympathetic than ever" to an immediate tax cut.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 10 Rabbi Judah Leib Maimon, Israel's first Minister for Religious Affairs died in a hospital today. He was 87 years old and had suffered a heart attack ten days ago.

American Export Lines warned the International Longshoremen's Association yesterday that it would sue for damages resulting from the refusal of dock workers to handle the line's cargo ships at Philadelphia and Boston.

WASHINGTON, July 20 Congress is giving the Soviet Union an advantage in international propaganda by not providing funds for a United States exhibit at the New York World's Fair, Senator Jacob K. Javits declared today.

A CORRESPONDENT who held a ten-card suit last week asked what she should bid and had to be given the usual answer: There is no "correct" bid on a freakish hand. They are a law unto themselves, If the bid works out well, it is a good bid.
RABAT, Morocco, July 10 Negotiations here to restore Algerian unity have failed and were broken off tonight.
LONDON, July 10 Against the weathered walls of the Tower of London, which in ages past knew many tales of sorrow, they are singing these nights "Rapture, Rapture, Joy and Jollity."
TRENTON, July 10 (AP) Gov. Richard J. Hughes signed a bill today permitting teachers to retire and collect both a full state pension and a full Social Security benefit.
JONES BEACH, L.I., July 10 Robert Moses walked out of a public hearing today when a speaker quoted a twenty-fouryear-old letter comparing him to Adolf Hitler.

WASHINGTON, July 11 Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, left for Hartford this afternoon to seek the Democratic nomination for Senator from Connecticut. His resignation will go to President Kennedy tomorrow.
BRASILIA, July 11 And end to the Brazilian political crisis appeared at hand tonight.

CAIRO, July 11 The Yugoslav delegate to the unaligned nations' economic development conference here called on the great industrial powers today to join in a world-wide movement of "economic coexistence" to prevent the impoverishment and ruin of vast overpopulated areas.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), July 11 Premier David Ben-Gurion's four-party coalition won a confidence test in the Knesset (Parliament) this evening over the expulsion of Dr. Robert A. Soblen, the convicted spy, without a trial. The vote was 53 to 28, with 15 abstentions.

READING, Pa., July 11 , Mrs. Elizabeth Bland Gaynor, wife of Leonard Gaynor and former motion picture critic of The New York Mirror as Bland Johaneson, died early today in Reading Hospital after a long illness. She was 62 years old and lived in Mount Penn, a suburb.
The united opposition to Representative Charles A. Buckley's Democratic leadership in the Bronx announced yesterday it would fight him in all twelve Bronx Assembly districts in the Sept. 6 primary.

THE midway glamour point in the season was reached with the All-Star show. It will continue on a slightly reduced scale in our village for the better part of the week when the Dodgers and Giants come to the Polo Grounds. Unfortunately, they won't be facing each other. They will be squaring off against those notorious baseball squares, the New York Mets.
Two Chicago railroads expressed interest yesterday in the Gulf, Mobile and Ohio Railroad, one through a study of a possible merger and the other by substantial stock
PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (AP) The Philadelphia Phillies beat the Houston Colts tonight for the eighth time in eight games as Art Mahaffey, posted his eleventh victory. 6 1.

How have over-the-counter stocks fared this year in comparison with shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange? The National Quotation Bureau's index of unlisted bluechip industrials compares well with the trends in Big Board stocks.
BERLIN, July 11 A 19-yearold American student went on trial today in East Berlin on charges of having tried to help an East German escape to the West.

The Administration's decision to appoint Abba P. Schwartz as chief of the State Department's Bureau of Security and Consular Affairs reflects a recognition that immigrants make a positive contribution to this country and that the officials in charge should not be primarily policemen.

LONDON, July 11 Sir Winston Churchill continued to make satisfactory progress today. His son, Randolph, reported that he had found his father sitting up in bed, smoking a cigar, sipping a glass of brandy and wiggling his toes.

Frank Wallace, a certified public accountant and a former professor at Cornell University, died Monday in Great Barrington, Mass., where he had gone on a business trip. He was 51 years old and lived on Tudor Road, in West Redding, Conn., where he worked as an independent management consultant.
Three floors in the new thirty-two-story office building at 555 Madison Avenue, between Fifty-fifth and Fifty-sixth Streets, have been leased by the International Business Machines Corporation.
Onondaga County, N.Y., has authorized a $45,000,000 borrowing on serial bonds to finance expansion of water works. No sales data has been set.
CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) The Department of Agriculture's July crop report weakened grain futures on the Board of Trade today.

High fashion invaded the world of bowling last night when the American Machine and Foundry Company unveiled a collection of women's sportswear created for it by eleven leading European and Latin-American designers.
JERSEY CITY, July 11 Hudson County police chiefs and directors of public safety received as ultimatum on gambling today.
PARIS, July 11--Buying on the London gold market continued brisk today, raising the "fixing" price by 3/8 cent to $35.11 . This was a full cent lower, however, than the peak reached early last week.
Governor Rockefeller has asked for approval of applications made to two Federal agencies by the Tri-State Transportation Committee for financial aid.
Six young American alpinists have scaled the hitherto unconquered southeast spur of Mount McKinley without frostbite, injury or melodrama.

BONN, Germany, July 11 The Government announced today the "compulsory retirement" of the Chief Prosecutor of the Federal Supreme Court, Wolfgang Fraenkel, and hopefully declared the case of the former Nazi judge closed.
WASHINGTON, July 11 Casualties in South Vietnam's struggle against the Communist Viet Cong insurgents were said today to be running at a rate of five Communists to every three for the Government.
Copper production curtailments are spreading.

CLEVELAND, July 11 The Davis Cup tennis teams of Canada and the United States went through their last stiff workouts today in preparation for their meeting here in the opening round of the American Zone.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 11 Weatherly made the first leg decisive today in achieving a solid victory over Nefertiti in the America's Cup observation trial competition.

Announcement has been made here by Mrs. Dmitri Dubassoff of 43 East Sixty-seventh Street and Basil Wadkovsky of Sea Cliff, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Natalie Wadkovsky, to Thomas Donaldson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. J.G.S. Donaldson of Bletchley, Buckinghamshire, England.

Edward Francis Hutton, founder of the New York Stock Exchange firm of E.F. Hutton Co. and former chairman of the General Foods Corporation, died yesterday at his home, Hutfield, on Wheatly Road, Westbury, L. I. He was 86 years old.
The Soviet Union plans to use four sputniks to transmit television programs, former United States Senator William Benton of Connecticut reported last night.
PARIS, July 11 The French Government streamlined its national defense organization today as a direct result of the end of the Algerian war.

The Maremont Corporation has purchased more than 100,000 common shares of the Gabriel Company, Cleveland-based producer of automotive parts and electronic and aero-space products, with a view to eventual consolidation.

BUFFALO, N. Y., July 11 (AP) The American Newspaper Guild's national convention toady adopted resolutions denouncing the doctors' strike in Saskatchewan and urging Congress to pass the King-Anderson Bill for medical care to the aged under Social Security.

TROON, Scotland, July 11 Arnold Palmer, the defending champion, shot a 71 in the first round of the British Open golf championship today but the United States Open champions of the last two years are no longer even a threat.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) The president of the National Association of Broadcasters, LeRoy Collins, urged Congress today to rescind the rule that radio and television stations must give equal broadcasting time to all political opponents.
Tuesday's upturn in the bond market developed further impetus Yesterday.
TLEMCEN, Algeria, July 11 Mohammed Ben Bella, dissident Vice Premier, returned today to Marnia, his native town, for the first time in almost six years and received a tumultuous welcome.

The Treasury has made public its long-awaited replacement of Bulletin F, the business man's bible governing depreciation procedures for tax purposes. The new guidelines constitute a basic reform of the depreciation rules, providing a simpler, more realistic and more equitable approach for measuring the useful lives of taxable equipment. The Treasury estimates that its ...
The head of the city's elementary schools declared yesterday that the division's reading program had proved "highly effective" this year.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 11 (AP) Green Ticket, from the stable of Adele L. Rand, registered his third stakes victory of the Monmouth Park meeting today as he stepped out of his 3-year-old division to whip older rivals in the six-furlong Rumson Handicap.
LONDON, July 11 Thirtyfive impressionist and modern French paintings valued at 350,000 ($980,000) were stolen from a London art gallery last night. It was the biggest art theft in British history.

IN 1957 Carol H. Baldi went to work for the United States Trust Company, an investment bank in New York. In April of this year she broke precedent at the 109-year-old bank by becoming its first woman officer.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 11 Battle lines have formed here, on a regional basis, as delegates to the International Coffee Conference go into closed session tomorrow to dispute export quotas.
Cotton futures were 15 cents a bale up to 25 cents down on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, except for old July, which fell 85 cents.
WASHINGTON, July 11 The Kennedy Administration gave business a $1,500,000,000 tax cut today in the form of more liberal allowances for depreciation of machinery and equipment.

PURCHASE, N.Y., July 11 Carrie Heldman of New York upset Sheila Maroschick of Brooklyn, and Nadine Netter of Scarsdale, N.Y., eliminated Carmen Lampe of Forest Hills, Queens, today in the quarterfinals of the Eastern women's clay court tennis championships.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 11 Sweeping reorganization at the studio of Twentieth Century-Fox has been decided upon by the company's board of directors.
ALBANY, July 11 Governor Rockefeller said today he was going to insist that his campaign for re-election be limited to state issues.
Alexander H. Cohen has made arrangements to bring the London company of "The School for Scandal" to Broadway early next year for a run of six to eight weeks.

The General Electric Company's first-half report, released yesterday, showed a 12 per cent increase in sales and a rise of 28 per cent in net earnings. Sales for the second quarter ran 13 per cent above the year-earlier level and net income rose 26 per cent.
Sir Charles Snow, who writes under the name C.P. Snow, has renewed his attack upon the principal scientific adviser to Prime Minister Winston Churchill during World War II.

The Hackensack Trust Company, Hackensack, N. J., and the Bank of Bogota (N. J.) announced merger plans yesterday. Under a resolution adopted by the directors of the two institutions, the Bank of Bogota will merge under the Hackensack charter and will become Hackensack's Bogota branch office.

FRANZ ALLERS, who has earned his spurs in the Broadway theatre and as conductor for such events at Lewisohn Stadium as the Gershwin and Vienna Nights, took on a program of more symphonic substance at the stadium last night and acquitted himself very well.

There will be a new author at literary cocktail parties this month a jaunty gentleman who will be 100 years old on July 27, and who has embellished his life with abundant alcohol, fine smoking, frolicsome nightlife, and an almost total rejection of the physical fitness principles now being advanced by President Kennedy.

VIENNA, July 10 The withdrawal of official United States cultural activities from Austria's provincial capitals has become a subject of widespread concern and speculation among Austria's educational and cultural leaders.

CHICAGO, July 11 Rabbi Maurice B. Pekarsky, dean of the B'nai B'rith Hillel Foundations staff and director of its program at the University of Chicago since 1940, died today at Michael Reese Hospital, a day after his fifty-seventh birthday. He had suffered a heart attack on Saturday.
LONDON, July 11 Although the Festival of the City of London is designed to celebrate the square mile that is the British capital's historic financial center its affection encompasses the entire city.
A spokesman for President Kennedy assured the National Association of County Officials here yesterday that the Administration had no desire to take over the tasks of local government.
THE deal shown is from a game played in Washing ton Monday night by four prominent bridge players.
BONN, Germany, July 11--The leaders of West Germany's uneasy coalition Government met for three and a half hours tonight but settled nothing except that they would maintain the coalition.
Trouble at two points on the subway system last night caused injuries to thirteen persons and delayed the Lexington Avenue IRT line in the Bronx for sixteen minutes.
MADRID, July 11 On a hot September day in 1925 a Moorish battalion of the Spanish Army stormed ashore under heavy fire at Alhucemas, on the north Moroccan coast.

Edward M. Gilbert, the 39year-old fugitive speculator, was indicted yesterday by a New York County grand jury on twelve counts of grand larceny involving $1,953,000, the amount that was named in a Federal indictment returned two weeks ago.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 80.1 Tuesday from 80.3 Monday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 84.4 on July 3, 1961.

IT may be that Mrs. Richard Siegel represents a trend among young housewives. A cook with an obvious flair, she has traveled at times for miles in search of a single ingredient fresh ginger root, tarragon ...
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 11 Semi-finalists were determined today in the Garden State Women's Golf Association's ninth annual match play championship.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) The domestic textile industry may yet have to be classified as essential to national defense, Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges said yesterday.
PARIS, July 11 (UPI) France has decided to speed up repayment of long-term loans given her by the United States and Canada, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) The Department of Commerce predicted today that new construction spending this year would rise to a record $60,000,000,000 with new private housing and highway expenditures leading the increase.

WASHINGTON, July 11 Former Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. and Samuel I. Rosenman, legal adviser to Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman, today opposed the nomination of Judge Irving Ben Cooper to the Federal court.
DETROIT, July 11 (AP) Gordie Howe, the highest pointmaker in National Hockey League history, today signed a contract for his seventeenth season with the Detroit Red Wings.
The Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue will receive the proceeds of a dinner dance Oct. 4 at the Plaza.

Total gasoline supplies in the United States last Friday were 186,478,000 barrels, against 187,271,000 barrels a week earlier, and 184,611,000 barrels a year ago, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 11 A Federal farm official from Texas said today that he had gone along with approvals of Billie Sol Estes' cotton dealings on the advice of a subordinate.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 Plans to build a new plant to turn out business and calculating machines will be built in Mechelen, Belgium, at an ultimate investment of about $5,000,000, executives of Friden, Inc., announced here today.
PARIS, July 11 (Reuters)--There will be no open lawn tennis tournaments for at least two years, the International Lawn Tennis Federation decided today.

WASHINGTON, July 11--A Presidential commission recommended today that seven railroads that operate lighters in New York harbor be given authority to switch regularly assigned captains from one boat to another in a single day.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) Representative Samuel S. Stratton accused the West Point basketball coach today of trafficking in Congressional appointments to the military academy.
MEDFORD, Mass., July 11 The International Business Machines Corporation unveiled today an experimental device capable of transmitting handwritten numerals into a ...
WASHINGTON, July 11 The Senate Finance Committee rejected today President Kennedy's revenue proposal to withhold income taxes on dividends and interest. The vote was 10 to 5.
WITH the shark season at hand reports of oceanic predators caught on rod and reel and sighted in the surf will be coming in more frequently. With that in mind, ...

NEW DELHI, India, July 11 Within twenty-four hours of lodging a "strong protest" against the "threat" posed by Chinese Communist forces to an Indian post in eastern Kashmir, the Government announced today that the situation was not serious.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) and an affiliate organization announced yesterday commitments aggregating $48,000,000 to Yugoslavia and India. The commitments are the bank's first for the new fiscal year.

The tendency of man's technological progress to outdistance his institutions for coping with that progress is strikingly indicated by current developments in space. The new era in global communications opened by the brilliant initial successes of the Telstar satellite is the latest in an incredibly rapid series of feats by both the United States and the Soviet Union.
Bert Martin's 4-year-old filly, Rose O'Neill strengthened her reputation as a "bargain beauty" yesterday.
YONKERS, July 11 Harold J., a 3-year-old colt trained by Billy Haughton and driven by Al (Apples) Thomas, easily won the feature Class B-1 mile pace before 20,478 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
A decline in sales and earnings this year was forecast yesterday for the United Whelan Corporation.
LONDON, July 11 Nearly all groups eased in quiet trading on the stock market today.

MADRID, July 11 (Reuters)--The official Government bulletin said today that the new Vice Premier of Spain "will carry out those functions that are expressly delegated to him" by Generalissimo Francisco Franco and will serve as deputy for General Franco "in the case of vacancy, absence or illness."

Lewis B. Maytag Jr., who acquired a controlling block of 250,000 shares of National Airlines stock on April 25 and became the line's president, sold 100,000 shares of National stock in June, it was disclosed yesterday in a New York Stock Exchange report.
WASHINGTON, July 11 President Kennedy has asked for a report on the arrest at Albany, Ga., yesterday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and other Negro integration leaders.
WASHINGTON, July 11 The House of Representatives voted tentatively today against a loan to help the United Nations out of debt until other member nations had...

The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is in jail in Albany, Ga. With him is another Negro clergyman. Their offense was that last December they had led a peaceful demonstration against segregation practices without first securing a permit from the police. They were in jail because they refused to pay their $178 fines or to ask for bail on appeal.

ALBANY, Ga., July 11 The police arrested thirty-two Negroes today as they marched on City Hall to protest the imprisonment of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Four others were seized while picketing on a downtown street.
WASHINGTON, July 11 Authorization of $3,820,515,250 for the United States' rapidly growing space programs was approved by the Senate today.
MIAMI BEACH, July 11--The Rabbinical Council of America voiced sharp opposition today to participation by Jewish secular groups in the Roman Catholic ecumenical council in Rome, which meets Oct. 11.
ANDOVER, Me., July 11--American television viewers received tonight, by way of the Telstar satellite, their first television broadcast from across the ocean.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 11 (UPI)--The president of the Cleveland Pipers predicted today that Jerry Lucas would stay with the team despite its shift yesterday to the National Basketball Association.

Results of the International Business Machines Corporation for the three months ended on June 30 set records for any quarter, and lifted the sixmonth figures to the highest levels for any half-year in the company's history, Thomas J. Watson Jr., chairman, reported yesterday.
SAIGON, Vietnam, July 11--Communist guerrillas have stepped up their attacks on the fortified rural settlements being set up in South Vietnam to isolate peasants from the insurgents.
LONDON, Thursday, July 12--British pride was badly hurt by the first French trans-Atlantic transmission through the Telstar communication satellite early this morning.
The Treasury has today completed its work on the first administrative modernization of Federal tax depreciation schedules and procedures in the twenty years since the present guidelines...

THE Founding Fathers stated in the Declaration of Independence an attitude toward the Indians that long endured. They did so in their arraignment of George III, who, they said, "has endeavored to bring on the inhabitants of our frontiers, the merciless Indian savages, whose known rule of warfare is an undistinguished destruction of all ages, sexes and conditions."

VIENNA, July 11 The Supreme Court in Budapest has rejected the appeals of five men sentenced last month to prison terms on charges of "conspiracy against the state," M.T.I., the official Hungarian press agency reported.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) President Kennedy signed into law today a measure that may bring a revolution in the habits of television viewers across the country.
Casey Stengel's battered Mets will return to the baseball wars tonight against the strongest opposition the National League has to offer. Their guests of the evening at the Polo Grounds ...

Stock of the Celotex Corporation, the company Edward M. Gilbert was trying to acquire at the time of his financial collapse last month, soared 2 7/8 points to 28 5/8, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
The H.R. Weissberg Corporation of New York announced yesterady that it had purchased the Palm Beach Biltmore Hotel in Palm Beach, Fla., and the Edgewater Beach Hotel in Chicago.

The magazine industry seems to be running into difficulties in its efforts to introduce the concept of the "continuing" subscription. At least two major periodicals report they have encountered resentment and reader resistance to the new plan.

Each July, as department and specialty stores throughout the city unveil model rooms, a band of New York women troops through in search of ideas in decor. This summer's parade of amateur decorators begins at 9:45 A.M. today on the seventh floor of Stern's, where five model rooms are on view.

ST. LOUIS, July 11 (AP) Ben Lane Jr., of Amarillo, Tex., upset Herb Durham of Dallas, the 1961 winner, in the first round of the fifty-ninth annual Trans-Mississippi golf tournament today. The score was 3 and 2.

WASHINGTON, July 11 The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended July 4.

THE French won and the British placed in last night's rivalry marking the inauguration of trans-Atlantic television westward from the Continent and environs. The satellite Telstar, in impartial orbit, performed superbly in relaying the samplings of both national images to American TV homes.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., July 11--Owen D. Young, industrialist and monetary expert, died at his winter home here today at the age of 87. He had been in failing health for several months.
There is an irresistible temptation these days to say of Spain what Galileo is supposed to have said of the earth: "And yet, it moves!"
DEARBORN, Mich., July 11 (AP) The Ford Motor Company declared today a quarterly dividend of 45 cents a share on its outstanding common stock, payable on Sept. 1 to stockholders of record of Aug. 2.
A BLACK and tan Afghan hound will be placed aboard a jet plane in London today. Eleven hours later, after having flown over the polar route, the plane will land in Los Angeles.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 11 Miss Emily Page Hewitt, daughter of Anderson Fowler Hewitt of 1172 Park Avenue, New York and this community, and Mrs. Anderson Fowler Hewitt of Stowe, Vt., was married here this afternoon to Thomas Wallace Bryant 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wallace Bryant ...

The International Longshoremen's Association has been told by the District Attorney's office to get rid of several former convicts who allegedly continue to participate in the affairs of the 60,000-member union.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 11 (AP) Premier Cyrille Adoula solidified his moderate rule in a Cabinet reshuffle today. He removed extremist politicians of Right and Left.

Bishop James P. DeWolfe sent a message to Episcopalians protesting outside St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Brooklyn yesterday, promising that he would use his office to correct "any purposeful segregation" at the institution.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) The Government accused seven pulp and paper manufacturers and three of their officers today of conspiring in an illegal price squeeze on small pulpwood suppliers in Michigan.

BUFFALO, July 11 (AP) George Archer of San Francisco, the medalist, was ousted today in the thirty-seventh annual United States Public Links golf championship by Steve Oppermann of Milbrae, Calif., 4 and 3. Oppermann made four birdie putts in the second-round match.
Stock prices rose again yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in active trading. It was the eighth advance in the last nine trading sessions.

MADISON, Wis., July 11 (UPI) The Wisconsin Legislature presented Gov. Gaylord A. Nelson today with a revised version of a once-vetoed reapportionment bill and adjourned for a week to seek what a Federal court does next.
Remedeco, a real estate investment company owned by nine institutions in Morningside Heights, including Columbia University, has bought the Devonshire Hotel.
It is getting late, and from now until September the speed of the hands of the clock will accelerate in reverse

PAGO PAGO, American Samoa, July 10 Technical experts were still trying today to solve what appeared to be the biggest puzzle connected with the thermonuclear burst Sunday night over the Pacific, why it had such unexpectedly little effect on radio communications.

RABAT, Morocco, July 11 Rival factions in the Algerian Provisional Government, who failed to settle their differences in the talks that ended here last night, have agreed to call on the army chiefs as the next step.

WASHINGTON, July 11 The marriage of Mrs. Ann Sears Busby, daughter of Samuel Powers Sears of Boston and Dennis, Mass., and the late Mrs. Helen Nickerson Sears of Boston, to William Worthy Whiteman Jr. took place here this afternoon. The bridegroom is the ...
REGINA, Sask., July 11 About 4,000 persons, many from as far as 400 miles away, attended a mass meeting today outside the Legislative Building to protest the Socialist Government's medical care law.
In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
Local 1199, Drug and Hospital Employes Union, announced yesterday that it had signed a contract with French Hospital, 330 West Thirtieth Street.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 11--Mrs. Martha Taylor Howard, board chairman of the Susan B. Anthony Memorial here, died today in General Hospital. She was in her late eighties. Mrs. Howard, the widow of George Howard, was a descendant of Presidents John Adams and John Quincy Adams.
LOS ANGELES, July 11 Los Angles County Republican leaders rejected early today Richard M. Nixon's choice for their chairman.

A revised plan to ease crosstown snarls in mid-Manhattan was drafted by Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes yesterday. It is less stringent than the original program, to which the Teamsters Union and business men had objected.
BALTIMORE, July 11 Representative Thor C. Tollefson, Republican of Washington, warned today that the Soviet Union could well become the greatest maritime nation in the world.

Britain has been the prime beneficiary of a drive by American maritime unions to organize the foreign-flag fleets operated by American owners, according to a study published yesterday by the American Committee for Flags of Necessity.

WASHINGTON, July 11 Ten farm officials in Louisiana were ordered suspended today by the Department of Agriculture pending an investigation on whether they had rigged production figures on their farms to gain larger Government payments.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 11 Nassau County's average level of education is as high as anywhere else in New York State and its median income is higher, a county planning commission report showed today.
BUENOS AIRES, July 11 The Argentine Government has warned the Metalworkers Union that it will act harshly against any attempt to occupy metalworking factories that have laid off about 50,000 workers.

FREEPORT, L.I., July 11 In a hull-to-hull dash down the East River today, August Nigl of Oceanside, L.I., brought his seventeen-foot Eltro outboard 100-horsepower runabout home first in the Around Long Island Marathon.

The temperature reached 90 degrees yesterday for the fifth day in a row. The Northeast continued in a dry spell that has seriously damaged crops, posed a threat of forest fires and caused farmers in near-by states to seek Federal disaster aid.
CAMP MERCURY, Nev., July 11 (AP) A small atomic device was exploded under the desert surface today, sending a geyser of earth and a ball of fire soaring into the sky.
PAL BENKO, the American dark horse in the Candidates Tournament in Curacao, though finishing with a percentage below 500, nevertheless played a vital role in the final standings.

WASHINGTON, July 11 An early meeting of Senate and House spokesmen for a further attempt to break the deadlock over blocked governmental operations funds appeared to be assured today. How the meeting would turn out, however, opened a wide field for speculation in Congress.
LIMA, Peru, July 11 Mediators in Peru's political crisis worked today under the threat of military intervention to bring about agreement on a "national coalition" President.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) The irregular heart action that prevented him from becoming the second American in orbit took Maj. Donald K. Slayton off the seven-man astronaut team today.

PARIS, July 11 (Reuters) Jacques Soustelle, a dissident former French official, announced today that he was renouncing his Legion of Honor decoration and Resistance Medal in protest against what he called France's "abandonment" of Algeria.
NORWALK, Conn., July 11 Mayor Frank J. Cooke called on the public today to help the police stamp out vandalism.

WASHINGTON, July 11 President Kennedy was pushed, shoved and nearly overwhelmed by an enthusiastic crowd of foreign students on the White House lawn today. Finally he was rescued by Secret Service agents and policemen.
Only sugar futures showed any signs of strength yesterday, as the commodities markets here were generally dull.
CORTLAND, N.Y., July 11 Carl D. Reed, former Broadway theatrical producer, died today in the Cortland Memorial Hospital. He was 79 years old.
ROME, July 11 With Italy's newspapers suspended by a strike, most Italians seemed unconcerned today about what is going on at home or abroad.
The White House plans to initiate a study of international communications that will examine the new opportunities and problems arising from the successful launching of the relay satellite, Telstar.

Yesterday's front page was full of news about man's penetration of space, what with a telecast Yves Montand bouncing off the Telstar satellite, the Senate voting nearly $4 billion for space programs and the Government announcing new plans for sending explorers to the moon.

One fireman was missing and sixteen others were injured when a four-alarm fire swept a downtown building last night. The five-story building at 390 Broadway, between White and Walker Streets, is occupied by several textile concerns.

ABOUT a quarter of a century ago the Boston Red Sox cast covetous eyes on a spright young shortstop who was performing with singular skill for the Louisville Colonels of the American Association. They wanted him so badly that they bought the entire ball club in order to get him.
ORAN, Algeria, July 12-- Mohammed Ben Bella, dissident Vice Premier, received a delirious welcome today from the Moslem population of Algeria's second largest city.

EAST HAMPTON L.I., July 12--A country auction, an innovation this year, will mark the opening on July 27 of the sixty-fifth annual Ladies Village Improvement Society Fair to be held on the grounds of the seventeenth-century Mulford Farm overlooking Main Street here.
Ralph Hirschberg, an insurance broker here and a nationally known contract bridge player, died Wednesday at his home after a long illness. He was 56 years old and lived at 115 Central Park West.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) --The Senate confirmed Matthrew H. McCloskey as Ambassador to Ireland today after a Republican attempt to return the nomination to the Foreign Relations Committee had been defeated, 60 to 30.
A white business man has moved to ease racial tensions in Harlem by offering to turn over to Negroes a steakhouse he had planned to open in a choice Harlem business district.
MANY bridge lessons are followed by a session of rubber bridge supervised by the teacher, and the deal shown is from such a session of supervised play.
YONKERS, July 12--Vicki's Jet was the victor in the $15,000 Dan Patch Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight but the real drama was wrapped up in the second race, in which the purse was a mere $2,000.
Moving out of a gray haze that veiled the Lower Bay, five Navy warships manned by reservists steamed in combat formation into New York Harbor yesterday.

GENEVA, July 12--The European Broadcasting Union said today that France had "contravened" an international agreement by transmitting the first television broadcast from Europe to the United States with the Telstar satellite as a relay.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- A Federal farm official from Texas testified today that the late Henry H. Marshall warned his staff late in 1960 about cotton dealings of the type made by Billie Sol Estes.

BONN, Germany, July 12-- The suspension of two highranking police officers, one in Hamburg and the other in Flensburg, became known today in the aftermath of the "Fraenkel affair."
Cotton futures were 45 cents a bale down to 5 cents up on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, July 12--Joseph V. (Newsboy) Moriarty, convicted numbers racket leader of this city, was named today by the Hudson County grand jury in a forty-four-count indictment charging him with possessing numbers lottery slips and engaging in a lottery.

In a major financial coup, the Jim Walter Corporation announced yesterday the acquisition of one-third of the outstanding stock of the Celotex Corporation. Celotex is the company Edward M. Gilbert was trying to acquire before his flight to Brazil a month ago.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI)--J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, reported today that major crimes committed in the United States rose 3 per cent last year to a record.
The right of Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes to change the traffic pattern in the West Greenwich Village area was upheld yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice. Francis X. Conlon.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 12 --The Suffolk County Planning Commission today recommended the acquisition of three additional county park sites.

BALTIMORE, July 12 (UPI) --A five-run rally in the ninth inning, paced by a three-run homer by Chuck Essegian, a pinch-hitter, lifted the Cleveland Indians to a 6-4 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.
TRENTON, N.J., July 12-- New Jersey may send a fulltime representative to Washington to represent the state in its transactions with the Federal Government, Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) --Two Medal of Honor winners placed wreaths today at the graves of three men who died for their country.
HARTFORD, July 12 (AP)-- Gov. John N. Dempsey of Connecticut today accused New York State authorities of interfering with Connecticut fishing rights in the waters off Long Island.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- Seven nations receiving United States aid have refused to let this country sell a small part of its holdings of their currencies to American tourists for dollars.

President Kennedy is expected to appear on a live tele vision program to be transmitted from this country to European countries on July 23. The fifteen-minute program, which will include pickups from various points throughout the United States, will be part of...
LONDON, July 13--The Labor party held its Parliamentary seat in northeast Leicester today against a surging Liberal party vote. The Conservative candidate dropped to a poor third.
Traffic violators and other persons fined in the City Magistrates' Courts will soon be permitted to pay their fines by check.

The two-story office and store building at 2 Newbridge Road, Hicksville, L.I., has been sold by Walter and Mathew Bergen o an investing client of the Mainland Realty Company, broker. It fronts 185 feet on Newbridge Road and 111 feet on Jerusalem Avenue.
The St. Regis Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, Plaza 3-4500. For years the St. Regis has maintained its reputation for having one of the best hotel kitchens in town. The food is French.
EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa., July 12--Half a cold war is being waged here in the Pocono Mountains where Sammy Baugh has dug in as a $20,000 a year consultant in the training camp of the New York Titans.
Following is the text of a statement on Germany issued by Tass, the official Soviet press agency, as made public in English by the agency:

It may have been an impending thunder shower, or a coyote howling like fifty coyotes on some neighboring bluff, or it may have been simply a hoot owl in one of the cottonwoods down by the dry arroyo. But the House of Representatives, that sometimes dignified body, jumped the corral on Wednesday night.
Royal Patrice, a 3-year-old bay filly carrying the Harbor View Farm's colors, made her eleventh start of the season her first victory yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- The Association of American Railroads reported today that carloadings for the holiday week ended July 7, totaled 419,584 cars. This was a decrease of 170,072 cars or 28.8 per cent, from the preceding week.

The Port of New York Authority voted unanimously yesterday to pay former Gov. Thomas E, Dewey's law firm an $85,000 fee for successfully handling the appeal of Austin J. Tobin, its executive director.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that recent progress in detecting underground nuclear tests might help to narrow the differences between the United States and the Soviet Union on a test ban agreement. Negotiations on testing will be resumed Monday in Geneva.
An unusual legal action has been brought against a psychiatrist in which he is charged with abuse of professional standards and loyalties in the long-term treatment of a husband and wife.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, July 12--This capital of Katanga Province was again the scene of uneasy military movement today. A company of United Nations soldiers and a company of Katangese soldiers, both heavily armed, were stationed opposite each other on a main route to the heart of the city.
The United Steelworkers of America urged President Kennedy yesterday to issue immediately an Executive Order forbidding racial discrimination in Federal or Federally assisted housing.
PARIS, July 12--Premier Georges Pompidou confronted the National Assembly today with the classic demand: Your money or your life!

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) --A Chicago publishing company was accused today of "a clear case of violation of the Foreign Agents Registration act" for publishing an attack on a West German official of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, now serving in the Pentagon.

Stanley M. Isaacs was for many years the conscience of our city government. His activities were marked by political independence, integrity and an abiding concern for the welfare of this city's large and complex population.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 12 --The Englewood Board of Education, which has been under pressure of parents and civic groups since June, 1961, to end racial imbalance in the elementary schools, announced tonight that in September all fifthgrade pupils would attend the same school.

PARIS, July 12--France used part of her mounting stock of dollars today to repay in advance $293,400,000 owed to the United States. Most of the debt, $210,000,000, stemmed from the loan portion of the Marshall Plan, which began in 1947. The payment cleared France's debt under the United States aid program.
The biggest weekly loss in eight months hit the nation's supply of monetary gold in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Earnings of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the largest food chain, rose slightly in the quarter ended on May 26, despite a bigger tax bill than a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- Legislation defining the role of supplemental airlines in civil aviation has been signed by President Kennedy.

Uday Shankar's Hindu Dance Company will appear at the City Center from Tuesday, Sept. 25, through Sunday, Sept. 30, at the outset of a transcontinental tour of twenty-five cities in the United States and Canada.

Select Syndications, Inc., has purchased for investment the five-story walk-up apartment building at 344 Fort Washington Avenue, northeast corner of West 175th Street, in the Washington Heights area. The build
Two productions of the same Bertolt Brecht play, "Mann ist Mann," are scheduled for Off Broadway this season. And, most unusually, both will be done within a fortnight of each other.

Saw Thai Ambassador; met with Amvets national commander and Senator Edmund Muskie of Maine; lunched with Defense Secretary McNamara, Treasury Secretary Dillon and business executives and magazine publishers; saw Gov. Terry Sanford of North Carolina; reviewed evening parade at Marine barracks; postponed trip to Brazil until Nov. 12.

Bishop James P. DeWolfe, responding to public protests against segregation in semiprivate rooms at St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Brooklyn, told the City Commission on Human Rights yesterday that he would be willing to meet with it to review the situation.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- Official optimism about reduc ing the deficit in the United States balance of payments may be fortified by a wide cut in the, deficit for the second quarter of this year, authoritative sources said today.
Governor Rockefeller, Mayor Wagner and many other public officials, civic leaders and citizens paid tribute yesterday to the memory of City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs.

A fragment of a wall from a Roman theatre built in the second century and a stone from Moscow's famous Art Theatre will become part of the permanent display of theatrical memorabilia at the new playhouse opening in September on the Bergen Mall Shopping Center in Paramus, N.J.

Ambassador Dean left yesterday to go back to Geneva for the resumption of the disarmament conference next Monday. We hope very much that that conference will be able to make some headway. It has made very little thus far.

Arthur H. Folwell, writer and editor associated with The New York Herald Tribune for forty years until his retirement in 1958, died yesterday of a heart condition in his home at 370 McDonough Street, Brooklyn. He was 84 years old.
Although gains predominated, the commodities markets here yesterday continued generally dull. Rubber, wool tops, the "M" coffee contract and lead were not traded at all.
ALGIERS, July 12--Premier Ben Khedda told 100,000 cheering Kabyles at Tizi-Ouzou today that national unity was essential if the "goals of our revolution are to be achieved."
MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 12--Darkness closed in on the field of 108 golfing teams trying to qualify today for the Anderson Memorial tourney at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- President Kennedy made a sortie from the White House to the southeast section of the city tonight to see if the Marine Barracks were exactly where President Thomas Jefferson said they should be.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) --Two Army Signal Corps civilian employes and a manufacturers' representative were ar rested tonight in New Jersey on bribery charges, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.

The Dreyfus Fund, Inc., reported yesterday net assets of $283,933,185, equal to $13.64 a share, on 20,812,567 shares outstanding June 30. One year ago the fund showed net assets of $237,704,401, or $17.15 a share, on 13,856,389 shares outstanding.
LAS VEGAS, July 12--Emile Griffith, the world welterweight champion, was rated a 12-5 favorite today for his fifteenround title match tomorrow night against Ralph Dupas of New Orleans.

De Veaux O. Smith, personal assistant to David Rockefeller, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, shot and killed himself yesterday in a room at the Harvard Club, 27 West Fortyfourth Street, the police reported.

The stock market was battered by two waves of selling yesterday but still managed to end with a small gain. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange have now posted a net gain in nine out of the last ten trading sessions.
PRINCETON, N.J., July 12 --The woman put down a work of pottery 5,000 years old and said, "How many want to stay and hear a story about a poor boy?"

The major elements of the East-West program for launching Laos on a career of peace and neutrality have all been worked out at Geneva. Barring a last-minute hitch, the international agreements will be signed and sealed next week.

WASHINGTON, July 12--There is now a kind of pause in the leadership of President Kennedy on the home front as if he were startled by the counter-attacks of the business community after the clash with Big Steel.
REGINA, Sask., July 12--The Socialist Government of Saskatchewan said today it would appoint a commission to investigate charges of harassment of doctors from outside the province.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 12-- Nefertiti, her race with Columbia seemingly lost when her spinnaker took off like a bird over the stern while she was ahead, recovered on the closing leg today to remain unbeaten against the 1958 America's Cup defender. The race between them was the fourth.
CHICAGO, July 12 (UPI)--Frank Robinson drove in his third run of the game with a ninth-inning double today to break a 4-4 tie and lead the Cincinnati Reds to an 8-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
PORT-JERVIS, N. Y., July 12--Fred D. Salmon, former publisher of The Port Jervis Union-Gazette, died yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital, West Palm Beach, Fla., at the age of 67.
WASHINGTON, July 12--Secretary of State Dean Rusk reiterated strongly today that troops of the major Western powers would have to remain in Berlin as part of any East-West accommodation there.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- The House of Representatives responded overwhelmingly today to President Kennedy's appeal for a free hand in providing aid to Poland and Yugoslavia when he believes it is in this country's interest.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 12--The United States Information Agency has established an "interneship" program, which will enable young American moviemakers to do documentaries for the Government while preparing themselves to work in the film industry.

THE two big questions in musical circles yesterday were: Would it rain? and How many people would be attracted to Lewisohn Stadium for the evening's concert? These are, always pertinent queries as far as the stadium series are concerned, but yesterday they took on special interest, for Igor Stravinsky was to make his first appearance there.

Business men are rubbing their hands in anticipation of a tax bonanza that many will reap under the Treasury's liberalization of the rules governing deductions to recover the costs of machinery and equipment.

CLEVELAND, July 12-- Chuck McKinley of St. Ann, Mo., and Jon Douglas of Santa Monica, Calif., were named today to play the singles for they United States in the Davis Cup match with Canada on the clay courts of the Cleveland Skating Club.

State Supreme Court Justice Francis X. Conlon named a referee yesterday to inquire into the ownership and whereabouts of $867,704 in furnishings and art works allegedly owned by fugitive financier Edward M. Gilbert.

TROON, Scotland, July 12--Arnold Palmer stormed down the back nine at Troon today with a magnificent 32 to take a two--stroke lead halfway through the British Open. The defending champion had a 69 for a two-day total of 140.

SOME years the people in predicting business take a terrible drubbing. If they are lucky, they don't strike out all the way; they just suffer out the slump, if baseball terms may be used in an outdoor column.

The atmic energy division of the Babcock Wilcox Company reported yesterday that it has achieved the first sustained chain reaction on the experimental version of the Atomic Energy Commission's advanced test reactor.
THE old-fashioned multidormered American home with an attic full of forgotten treasures received a spirited defense last night from Harry Reasoner on Channel 2.

WHITE PLAINS, July 12-- Eighteen sealed indictments charging grand larceny, forgery and collection of illegal fees in the construction of the $91,617,000 New England Thruway were filed in County Court here today by a Westchester grand jury.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- President Kennedy has postponed his trip to Brazil from July 30 until the middle of November, apparently because of the political crisis there.

MOSCOW, July 12--The Soviet Union appeared today to move a step closer to the signing of a separate German peace treaty that would give the East Germans control Over air and land routes to West Berlin.

ROME, July 12--Italian fall fashions are now being shown in Rome, but hardly any American buyers are here to see them. Patrick de Barentzen, always one of the most popular couturiers, drew only a handful of people to his showing today.

LAMB is currently breaking records--unfortunately of the wrong sort. A rise of 6 cents a pound on loin lamb chops brings them to a general cost of $1.45 a pound, which is the highest price ever recorded and 20 cents above their cost of a year ago. Rib chops also advanced 5 cents and now sell for $1.15 a pound.

William H. McKeon, the Democratic state chairman, said yesterday that Governor Rockefeller had backed away from his original plan to make the Kennedy Administration's record the key issue in the 1962 state campaign.
RABAT, Morocco, July 12-- The Moroccan press agency, which generally represents Government thinking, charged today that the Algerian Army had attacked Moroccan frontier posts in the Sahara.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 12--Sergio Armando Frazao, head of the Brazilian delegation to the International Coffee Conference here, quoted today recent projections estimating the loss to Latin-American coffee-exporting lands at $130,000,000 a year. He said this was "due solely to the barriers to the trade in, and the consumption of, the commodity."
Southern Airways, whose union pilots have been on strike since June, 1960, has reported record passenger and cargo business in the first half of the year.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- Senator Harry F. Byrd offered a $21,000 personal contribution toward balancing the Federal budget, today, and the Senate Finance Committee readily obliged him.

LONDON, July 12--Sir Winston Churchill has developed a bronchial infection that caused a slight rise in his temperature today. The physicians attending Sir Winston declined to evaluate the effect this development would have on the 87-year-old statesman's recovery from a broken left thigh.

PARIS, July 12--The upsurge of economic strength that France has shown in recent years has brought a number of bright young men to key positions in public service and private industry. One of them is Val ry Giscard d'Estaing, the 36-year-old Minister of Finance and of Economic Affairs, who announced today France's repay ment in advance of her debt to the United States and the purchase of $112,500,000 worth of gold from the United States.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- A compromise was worked out today in the Congressional feud that has blocked all of this year's appropriations bills.

The Government's new taxcutting depreciation reforms yesterday met applause in most sectors of the business community. The welcome generally was for the principle of the changes designed to stimulate investment in more modern and efficient facilities.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI)--Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, urged Congress today to proceed cautiously in any moves to suspend the requirement that equal free broadcast time be allowed opposing candidates for public office.
PRINK HILL. SINCE readers of this column have put up with a lot of bleating over the scarcity of bluebirds, they are entitled to all the news.

BERLIN, July 12--Mayor Willy Brandt announced today that the city government would register travelers who use the land routes through East Germany between Berlin and West Germany because of a growing number of arrests by the East German police.

WASHINGTON, July 12--The House Agriculture Committee unexpectedly proposed today a sharp cut in the Federal price support for corn. It added this provision to the new farm bill, which it approved by a vote of 29 to 5. The proposal means the price support could be cut up to 46 cents a bushel on the basis of current prices. The existing support for corn is $1.20 a bushel. The cut would be effective in 1964.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, July 12--Two Soviet diplomats have been expelled from New Zealand for espionage. They left here today with their families for the Soviet Union by way of Australia.

The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday the following changes in stockholdings by officers, directors and large stockholders of its listed companies, in accordance with rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission:

LIMA, Per, July 12--The joint command of the Peruvian armed forces charged tonight that the official results of the June 10 Presidential election were "untruthful and a deformation of the popular will."

WHEN Joyce Cary's "The African Witch" was first published in this country twenty-six years ago it was respectfully received by several American critics.
