Leon J. Davis charged yesterday that nonmedical workers in New York voluntary and private hospitals received lower wages than similar employes in eight other major cities.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 12 --Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood and Charlotte DeCozen of Montclair advanced today to the 36-hole final of the ninth annual Garden State women's golf championship.
ALBANY, Ga., July 12-- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was released against his will from jail today after serving two days of a fortyfive-day sentence.

THE movies, which used to be one of the strongest forces in fashion, are having their say again about how american women look. Although they do not have the power they exerted in the heyday of such stars as Clara Bow, Marene Dietrich and Greta Garbo, both European and American films are influencing Seventh Avenue designers and helping to establish "new looks."

Former Gov. James Thomas Blair Jr., was born on March 15, 1902 in Maysville, Mo. His father, the late James Thomas Blair Sr., had been a member of the Missouri House of Representatives and later a justice on the state's Supreme Court.
Plans for making Eightieth Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, a Police Athletic League Street, marked off and closed for children's play and safety, were abandoned yesterday.

The City Council will fill the vacancy caused by the death of Stanley M. Isaacs within the next two or three weeks. A call for a meeting will be issued by Council President Paul R. Screvane and Vice Chairman Eric J. Treulich, leader of the Democrate majority.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 12 (AP)--Jim King smashed a pair of two-run home runs, the second breaking a 4-4 tie tonight as Washington won a battle of home runs from Minnesota, 7--4, in ten innings.

Practically everyone is getting into the trading-stamp act. Big corporations are using them now for incentive programs. Workers get stamps as rewards for meeting sales quotas, for regular attendance and for safety programs.
Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $65,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday to $55,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
The Board of Education announced yesterday that it had rejected an offer by the United Federation of Teachers to sign a twenty-month contract with a "no-strike" pledge.

Consumers continue to pay their debts at an "impressive" rate, according to the American Bankers Association. Its latest report shows that only sixteen loans out of each 1,000 are past due. This is the lowest rate since August, 1959. The figures covering May show a slight improvement over the April total.
Price gains in prime debt securities were extended yesterday in all areas of the highgrade bond market.
Language laboratories will be installed this fall in four city elementary schools, the Board of Education announced yesterday.

City and state officials ordered yesterday that the demolition of a ten-story brick building at 535 Pearl Street be halted because of "significant radioactive contamination." The structure is in the Manhattan Civic Center area north of City Hall.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12-- Matthew Joseph Culligan, new president of the Curtis Publishing Company, announced today the "first in a series of promotions from within the company of dedicated and experienced young executives."

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (UPI)--Willie Mays made three hits, batted in a run, stole a base and scored despite a drawn-in infield on an infield out as the San Francisco Giants topped the Philadelphia Phillies, 5--3, tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, July 12 --Leading Democrats demand-, ed today that a special courtordered grand jury begin investigating alleged City Hall scandals at once. The inquiry is scheduled to start Sept. 4.
The American Society of Travel Agents is trying to stop illegal practices on trans-Atlantic group and charter airfares.

MADRID, July 12--Generalissimo Francisco Franco and Don Juan, the Count of Barcelona and pretender to the Spanish throne, are expected to meet soon outside Spain. They will review the Spanish political situation in the light of recent changes in the Cabinet, according to informed political circles.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- The House Agriculture Committee approved today the Senate's proposal to give the Dominican Republic, an extra share of the United States sugar market.

Negotiable securities worth at least $1,370,475 have been stolen from the vaults of Bache Co. at 36 Wall Street. A spokesman for the brokerage house said last night that "we simply must assume that someone on the inside just took those stocks." He said that

The New York Mets made a noble effort last night to make some sort of impression on the National League pennant race. However, being more than thirty games away, they never even came close to their target.
Although advertising expenditures were rising during the first half of 1962, Madison Avenue, nonetheless, remained apprehensive for second--half prospects.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- Southern efforts to block the confirmation of Thurgood Marshall as a judge of the United States Court of Appeals came out into the open today.
LONDON, July 12--Price movements were small and irregular on the stock market today.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP)-- Gains dominated grain futures today after late buying strengthened corn and oats on the Board of Trade.

LOS ANGELES, July 12-- With hellishly effecient competence, the Los Angeles Angels defeated the New York Yankees, 5-4, tonight and added, substance to the Smogsville phantasy of a freeway world series.

The Senate Finance Committee seems to have decided on a new technique for eviscerating the Administration's tax bill. Instead of letting it die the lingering death of indefinite postponement, the committee is now hacking away at its key provisions.
An 18-year-old youth who shot at a rival gang member three years ago was cleared of all trace of a criminal record yesterday in General Sessions Court because he had led an exemplary life since then.

The best that can be said of the internal struggle for power in Algeria is that there seems to be a desire to avoid an armed clash. The conflict has by no means been resolved, and since it is essentially a matter of personalities, the present situation is a truce, not a settlement.
The Upstairs at the Downstairs, which is closed for the summer, has moved a new version of its satirical revue "Seven Come Eleven," downstairs to the Downstairs at the Upstairs.

A Denver oil promoter and budding contractor pleaded guilty in Federal Court here yesterday to conspiracy charges in two separate eases in which the public was defrauded of a total of $9,000,000 in the sale of stock.
The legality of an intercoastal shipping operation proposed by Sea-Land Service, Inc., has been challenged by Seatrain Lines, Inc.

BUFFALO, July 12 (UPI)-- More than 200 delegates to the Ameriacn Newspaper Guild convention demanded in a resolution today that newspapers end employment discrimination against women and minority groups.
Stanley M. Isaacs, the Republican minority leader of the City Council and a lifelong champion of civic causes, died early yesterday at his home here. He was 79 years old.

Roger Wolfe Kahn, orchestra leader and aviation enthusiast, who was a son of the late Otto H. Kahn, the financier, died yesterday afternoon at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 54 years old.

The Cabinet shake-up in Great Britain went so far beyond any expectations that it can only be described as sensational. Since British Cabinet ministers have executive powers and are directly responsible to Parliament, the move has far greater meaning than if President Kennedy tomorrow were to change seven of the top posts in his Cabinet, as Prime Minister Macmillan did.
REGINA, Sask., July 13--Socialist Premier Woodrow Lloyd criticized the striking doctors of Saskatchewan today for "badgering" doctors from outside who had come here to help in the emergency.

The stock market was in a cautious mood yesterday. Prices moved back and forth in irresolute fashion and closed with a small loss on average on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading was much quieter than in the more ebullient sessions earlier this week.
To most people, New York International Airport is a diverting stopover point en route to somewhere else.
TROON, Scotland, July 13-- Arnold Palmer, the defender, shot fantastic rounds of 67 and 69 today amid unruly mob scenes to win the British Open by six strokes with a final total of 276.
The Conservative party of New York announced yesterday that it had selected David H. Jaquith, a 44-year-old Syracuse business man, as its candidate for Governor.

ALGIERS, July 13--Conversation in Algiers was carried on by automobile horns for the first few days after independence was proclaimed on July 3. They honked incessantly a rhythmic bedlam standing for "Yahia Aldjezair" (Hail Algeria.)
A Police Department reorganization designed to cut costs and achieve better results was announced yesterday.
Assemblyman Bentley Kassal threatened court action yesterday to prevent two men with liquor-industry connections from sitting on a state panel considering the legal drinking age.
THE problem of the vanishing servant that has plagued the American home since World War II has had one unexpected consequence:
CHICAGO, July 13--The existence of a black market in a drug that causes hallucinations was reported today.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 13--A Negro obtained housing for himself today in litigation under the ten-month-old private housing provisions of the New York State law against discrimination.
MOSCOW, July 13--The Soviet Government and the Communist party called on local authorities today to stop the expensive practice of recruiting townspeople for summer farm work.
The high-grade bond market closed the trading week yesterday with the most stable look in several weeks.

CLEVELAND, July 13-- Against surprisingly strong resistance, the United States won the first two singles matches from Canada today in the opening round of the Davis Cup American Zone tennis play at the Skating Club.
BALTIMORE, July 13 (AP)-- Charlie Lau, a reserve catcher, tied a major league record by pounding out four doubles tonight as the Baltimore Orioles whipped the Cleveland Indians 10--3.
CANOE PLACE, L.I., July 13 --The dish-shaped antenna of the world's largest shipboard radar started its maiden voyage from Shinnecock Canal today, ignominiously welded to the deck of a coal barge.
WASHINGTON, July 13-- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg said today that he hoped the airlines labor dispute could be settled next week.
LONDON, July 13 (UPI)-- The British Medical Journal today dismissed as "vulgar, cheap and nonsense" attacks by the American Medical Association on England's National Health Service.
WASHINGTON, July 13-- Senator John L. McClellan demanded today that the Agriculture Department provide "better administration" to prevent future versions of the Billie Sol Estes case.
The Mets, who are establishing a legend of their own, will help today to recreate the swingingest moment in baseball history.

Like every other head of the Defense Department, Secretary McNamara's battle cry is cutting costs. By eliminating red tape and injecting a new element of competition in military procurement, he predicts annual savings of $3 billion within five years.
An increase is predicted in rentals for office space as a result of the city's new zoning law.
WASHINGTON, July 13-- The House Rules Committee cleared a new farm bill today for House consideration next week.

BUFFALO, July 13 (AP)-- Representative Samuel Stratton of Schenectady, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, predicted today that the medical care for the aged bill backed by the Kennedy Administration would...
Eli Lilly Co., producer of pharmaceuticals, reported yesterday substantially larger sales and earnings in the first six months of this year compared with those of the 1961 period.
NEW DELHI, India, July 13 --India warned the Chinese Communists today that if their troops "creep up" closer to an Indian post in the Galwan Val ley, Indian troops "may have to fire in self-defense."
HOLLYWOOD, July 13-- Jerry Wald, the motion picture producer, died tonight at his home in Beverly Hills. He was 49 years old.
A Negro group, led by a Black Nationalist, shifted its protest tactics yesterday away from a white business man to Jackie Robinson, the former Brooklyn Dodger star.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP)--The Federal Aviation Agency said today it may attempt to standardize airplane lights to help prevent collisions by reducing confusion of lights in the night sky.

TLEMCEN, Algeria, July 13--Vice Premier Mohammed Ben Bella and his followers widened their breach today with Premier Benyoussef Ben Khedda and the majority of the ministers of the Algerian Provisional Government.

The Board of Education, in its search for a new Superintendent of Schools, is pledged to look for the best man it can find for this pivotal post. Accordingly, it should be superfluous to urge that the search be nation-wide and not confined to city limits.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) --The Government filed three damage suits today against eight of the electrical companies convicted in 1960 in Philadelphia of antitrust conspiracy.
The market for new issues will be moderately active next week, with roughly equal amounts of corporate and municipal bonds up for sale.
ROCKPORT, Mass., July 13 (UPI)--The Board of Selectmen here has banned two stage plays because they are "quite sexy."
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) President Kennedy named Draper Daniels, Chicago advertising executive, to the new post of national export coordinator in the Commerce Department today.
With trading quiet and prices narrowly mixed in most items, commodity futures ended the week with adjustments in the expiring July deliveries and week-end evening-up operations.

The "hard luck" horse of 1962, Peter Salmen's Crimson Satan, will make his second New York start of the season today when he competes in the Dwyer Handicap at Aqueduct. The race is for 3-year-olds at a mile and a quarter.

The world's longest commercial vessel and the largest merchant ship ever built in the United jstates were among the sixty-four new ships that came here on their maiden voyages during the first six months of this year.

The American Veterans Committee has been chosen to oversee employe representation elections at eleven voluntary hospitals in the city, Leon J. Davis, president of Local 1199, Drug and Hospital Employes Union, announced yesterday.

The Soviet Union's track and field squad arrived in New York late yesterday afternoon. Three hours later it took off for San Francisco to prepare for its dual meet against the United States at Palo Alto, Calif., next Saturday and Sunday.
LOS ANGELES, July 13-- The Federal Government filed a civil antitrust suit today against the Music Corporation of America.
WASHINGTON, July 13--A patent was granted this week on the R-85, or Clejan car, a long, low, stripped-down model with a reputation for economy and smooth riding.
MADRID, July 13--The Spanish Government has approved the formation here of an international consortium of investment banks, with American, British, French and Spanish participation in equal shares.
WASHINGTON, July 13-- There is no sense or expectation of crisis over Berlin in the Administration despite the somewhat harsher tone of the East-West dialogue this week.

The chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, may advocate a new tax measure for discouraging certain types of United States investments abroad.
St. Agnes, a 13-year-old Roman girl who was martyred in 304 A.D., has been designated by Pope John XXIII as patroness of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre.
From the remote distance of thirty-two and a half games away, the Mets last night finally got around to making their presence felt in the National League pennant race.
WASHINGTON, July 13-- The expected break in the Congressional feud blocking all this year's appropriations bills failed to develop today.
BRASILIA, July 13--Brazil's long Government crisis apparently ended tonight when the Chamber of Deputies approved a new Cabinet presented by Premier Francisco Brochado da Rocha.
PARIS, July 13--France will not boycott informal East-West exchanges, on the Berlin problem at Geneva next week.

BRUSSELS, July 13 (AP)-- Forminiere, one of the largest raw diamond producing companies in the world, has halted activities in the Congo province of Kasai because of what the company called tribal disputes and clandestine exploitations.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP)--Senator Frank J. Lausche, Democrat of Ohio, said in the Senate today that there had been "inordinate delay" in Senate judiciary subcommittee consideration of Thurgood Marshall's nomination to the United States Court of Appeals.
LIMA, Peru, July 13--The threat of a military coup to upset the June 10 national elections has been eased by a rising prospect that Gen. Manuel A. Odria will be the next President of Peru.

The career of Abraham A. Ribicoff as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare developed into a perpetual tug-of-war between amiability and ability, between courage and compromise. The legislative programs for which he stood as the Administration's principal public and Congressional advocate were generally excellent.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 13--William Hyndman 3d of Philadelphia and his 22-year-old son, Bill, made a successful entry into the Anderson memorial golf tourney today.
A Montclair, N.J., producer said yesterday that exorbitant labor costs and obstructionist labor disputes made the use of the New York Coliseum uneconomical for theatrical productions.

BUENOS AIRES, July 13-- Organized labor moved toward a showdown with the Government and industry today as leaders of the General Labor Confederation voted unanimously to stage a forty-eight hour nation-wide general strike Aug. 1 and 2.

ALBANY, July 13--Governor Rockefeller declared nine upstate agricultural counties disaster areas today because of the prolonged drought. They made a total of eighteen counties in the state that have requested such a designation or are preparing to request it.
The battle over whether New York should prohibit teen-age drinking of alcoholic beverages is fierce enough without enmeshing it in issues of conflict of interest.

One man was killed and four others were injured yesterday when a wooden form for a concrete wall collapsed and buried them beneath splintered wreckage. The accident occurred at a construction site on Sixtyeighth Street near Fifth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, July 13-- President Kennedy and his advisers in and out of the Government took a hard look today at the economics and politics of a quick tax cut. It was a no-decision meeting.
LONDON, July 13--The Earl of Home, Britain's Foreign Secretary, warned tonight that racialism and aggressive nationalism could kill the United Nations.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 13-- Weatherly surged down the last half-mile of the course spurred by a fresh northwest wind today and passed Columbia at the end of a fantastic yacht race. The margin was 9 seconds.

TOKYO, July 13 (AP)--The United States and Japan wound up a three-day shipping conference today with agreement to make special efforts to stabilize freight service between the two countries.

The transfer of radio station WINS to the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company was approved yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission. The sale price was $10,000,000, the second highest amount ever paid for a radio station.

Irate operators of small businesses on the west side in downtown Manhattan began a "survival" campaign yesterday with picketing, a mock funeral procession and the collection of signatures on a protest petition.
WASHINGTON, July 13-- Labor Department figures issued today showed continued sluggishness in employment last month.

THE increasing difficulty of matriculation into colleges --more than 1,000,000 students are expected to apply next year --has prompted a number of educators to advise parents to begin preparing their children for college even before they enter high school.

DUBLIN, July 13--Ireland's most splendid sentimental monument is a gaunt and towering old patriot who lives in the fine residence of Phoenix Park where until forty years ago, dwelled the viceregal lord lieutenants of the British Empire.
WOODSTOCK, England, July 13 (AP)--The tenth Duke of Marlborough gave the year's biggest ball tonight in Blenheim Palace.

WHITE PLAINS, July 13-- Edward J. Petrillo, a prominent road builder, surrendered in Westchester County Court here today on charges of bribery and grand larceny in the construction of the New England Thruway. Three of his chief aides also gave themselves up and two others arranged to do so next Monday.
Steel production in June totaled 6,685,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This compared with 7,535,506 tons in May and 8,551,856 tons in June, 1961.

THERE is a saying in France that General de Gaulle is a man of decision-- not action. Of course no decorous per son believes that. WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) --The Senate rejected today by a vote of 75--5 a Republican sponsored substitute proposal for President Kennedy's compromise health-care plan for the elderly.

LOVELADIES, N.J. With the arrival of thousands of families with the sole idea of enjoying their vacation weeks, Long Beach Island has managed to shift its preoccupation with repairing storm damage to putting more emphasis on the cultural and entertainment aspects of summer at the seashore.

YONKERS, July 14 Samuel Huttenbauer's Lang Hanover scored a half-length victory over Brown Jet in the Monitor Pace before 30,097 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

BABYLON, L.I., July 14 The marriage of Miss Glen Cumming Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Loughton Thayer Smith, to Robert Andres Nielsen Jr. took place here this morning. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nielsen. The Rev. Harold C. Jones performed the ceremony in the Methodist Church.

AMITYVILLE, L.I. July 14 Close sailing in heavy wind puffs resulted in several craft being disabled today as the Narrasketuck Yacht Club's annual invitation regatta got underway. One craft sailed over another, and many of the 120 starters did not finish.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 14 A warning that this city's downtown area faces a steady deterioration unless a projected $88,000,000 urban renewal program was pushed to completion was sounded this week by the Stamford Good Government Association.
CAIRO, June 30 The campaign to save the Nubian monuments from waters of the Aswan High Dam has reached the halfway point.

WASHINGTON, July 14 A two-toothed, slightly rusted, seven-inch piece of iron hangs in the hallway of George Washington's mansion at Mount Vernon, Va. It is the key to the Bastille, the key that opened the gate to the French Revolution 173 years ago today, on July 14, 1789.

United Nations delegates were shocked last week when the House of Representatives attached a rider to the Foreign Aid Bill that would force the Kennedy Administration to renege on its pledge to buy United Nations bonds.
MEXICO CITY, July 14 What has been termed the gravest split in Mexico's political Left appears to be widening despite strenuous efforts to restore unity.
LOS ANGELES, July 14 In a ten-inning carnival of good wood, the Yankees defeated the Los Angeles Angels, 9 8, today before a roaring crowd of 35,228 at Chavez Ravine Stadium.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP) Bob Wine's single scored Jacke Davis, a pinch-runner, with two out in the tenth inning today and gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 6-5 victory over the San Francisco Giants. Thus, the Phillies took the series, 2 games to 1.

NEW DELHI, India, July 14 Chinese Communist forces advanced to within fifteen yards of an Indian army post in eastern Kashmir yesterday but withdrew during the night after the Indians threatened to fire, an official spokesman said today.

SCITUATE, Mass. What is probably America's most famous well, now in its 288th year of continuous use, is primed and ready for summer visitors to this small, seashore town in southeastern Massachusetts. This is the 36foot-deep well in which hung the Old Oaken Bucket immortalized by Scituate poet Samuel Woodworth.

LONDON, July 14 Stunned members of the Conservative party were trying today to determine the meaning, and the effect, of Prime Minister Macmillan's drastic shake-up of his Cabinet.

MACAO, July 11 (Reuters) This tiny Portuguese colony in sight of Communist China has embarked on a program to increase revenues from tourism and gambling. Gambling casinos have already earned Macao the nickname Monte Carlo of the East.

TANGIER, Morocco The face this city shows to the sea is deceptive. Those who enter the harbor by trans-Atlantic ship, or by ferry from Algeciras or Gibraltar across the Strait, are struck by the beauty of Tangier, the three-mile curve of beach cupped in a rim of green hills and its pale hotels and apartments as sleek and modern as any to be found along the Riviera.

Tax experts who have studied the Treasury's new maroon booklet that sets forth the number of years over which business men can offset the cost of machinery against earnings believe that the small business man will be a principal beneficiary.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 14 The father-and-son team of William Hyndman 3d and Billy of Philadelphia today gained the final of the Anderson Memorial Golf Tournament for the second year in a row.

ROME, July 12 The temperature was steadily in the 90's this week. The city was choked with tourists, the Romans were thinking about their own vacations and the Municipal Council was in the painful process of electing the city's fifty-seventh Mayor since the end of Papal rule in 1870.

CENTERPORT, L.I., July 14 Gray Lady, skippered by J.B. and L.L. Shafer, captured the Indian Harbor Division I cruise honors today as it completed a twenty-six-mile triangular course with a corrected time of 4 hours 43 minutes 44 seconds.

LONDON, July 14 (Reuters) The Cairo radio reported today demonstrations, labor unrest and violent clashes in three Syrian cities.
ALGIERS, July 14 A secret meeting of chiefs of the Algerian nationalist military command zones may already have begun in the region of M d a. Reports indicated the meeting had started today.

Among economic barometers, retail sales trends rank high as an indication of the nation's business health. In both March and April, sales rose, a sign of strength, but then they dropped by 1 per cent in May. Last week the Government reported that June sales were 2 per cent below those for May.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) Ridan, making his first start since a second-place showing in the Preakness last May, sped through the mud today to score a seven-length victory in the $102,250 Arlington Classic.

VIENNA, July 14 Communist China's failure to deliver pork promised in this year's trade agreement with Czechoslovakia has contributed to a serious meat shortage there, informed East European sources said today. The latest in a series of developments designed to provide visitors with every possible view of one of nature's best-known spectacles is scheduled to be opened to the public today. The new facility, a walkway to the base of the Horseshoe Falls, has been built by the Niagara Frontier State Park Commission.

REGINA, Saskatchewan, July 14 As the struggle between the Socialist Government of Saskatchewan and its 900 doctors entered the third week, a solution to the dispute seemed as far off as ever. Neither side was talking to the other.

HONG KONG. RELUCTANTLY, furtively and guiltily, china's communist masters are backsliding again into the Marxist heresy of birth control. It is a bitter retreat to the hard mood of 1957, when Emperor Mao and his Marxist mandarins issued an edict insisting that "all areas in our country must promote appropriate birth control." This program, which lasted a scant eight months, was the first official, full-scale birth-control campaign ever initiated in a Communist state.

The Mercer Museum here, which has one of the largest collections of tools and machines of the presteam era, has taken two important steps in a move designed to place new emphasis on visitor enjoyment. LAS VEGAS, July 14 Emile Griffith retained his world welterweight boxing title and regained his confidence last night with a convincing fifteen-round victory over game Ralph Dupas of New Orleans.

The island of Tristan da Cunha still lies where it used to, far out in the Atlantic at about 37 south and 12 west. Its 262 inhabitants were taken off in an act of benevolence by the British Government, which owns and administers the island.

Some use their legs faster than others and that makes a lot of people happy or unhappy, depending on what numbers they happen to pick at the $2 window. Otherwise, few give a horse much thought. As for the horse doing any thinking, that's ridiculous.

Cotton futures fell 50 to 95 cents a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The market opened moderately active. Commission houses sold, especially old October. Most of the trading was in old crop months.

WASHINGTON, July 17 House negotiators predicted today a settlement of the long Congressional feud over appropriations bills within thirtysix hours. Senate negotiators said they hoped this forecast would come true, but they offered no guarantees.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower sailed for Europe yesterday on his first trip there "as a private citizen" since 1929. "I'm going to make a lot of calls on a lot of old friends," he said.

It is another thing entirely to have the student, who should be standing silently digesting the pearls of hard-won knowledge, pull out a bigger fish than most more experienced anglers have taken.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 18 --Henry Finch Holland, former Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, died at Greenwich Hospital today. He was 49 years old and lived on Khakum Wood Road.

WASHINGTON, July 18--The United States suspended diplomatic relations with Peru today within hours of the military coup d'etat there. The suspension automatically meant the interruption of negotiations for programs of assistance to Peru under the Alliance for Progress.
CAIRO, July 18--Thirty-one's countries called on wealthier industrial powers today to join a world-wide program of more aid and freer trade.

AS if enough books on baseball already haven't been written to fill all the bookcases in Macy's unpainted furniture department, another is about to make its appearance. RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 18 --Governor Rockefeller said today that the state would study the feasibility of a high-speed hydrofoil ferry system across Long Island Sound for vehicles and passengers.
DALLAS, July 18 (AP)-- Doctors hope to immunize 3,250,000 Texans during the next four Sundays to fight off an unexpected polio increase. They will use the relatively new Sabin vaccine.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 18--The eighteen LatinAmerican countries participating in the international coffee conference served notice today that they would give high priority in the discussions to pressing for removal of barriers to coffee consumption and coffee trade.
BALTIMORE, July 18 (AP) --Dr. George Eli Bennett, one of baseball's leading physicians, died last night at his home of a heart attack. He was 77 years old.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 18 (AP)--Four United States airmen, missing since their transport plane crashed into a jungle mountainside Sunday, were found alive today after they had been virtually given up for lost.
BABYLON, L. I., July 18-- The state Department of Public Works confirmed today that it had approved a road-widening project for the Village of The Branch.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., July 18--Bertha E. Blakeley, head of the Mount Holyoke College library for thirty-five years, died today at Tranquillity Nursing Home in Peterborough, N.H., after a long illness. She was 92 years old.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, July 19--Negotiations to settle the twenty-six-day strike by the Flight Engineers' International Association against Eastern Airlines collapsed tonight. There was no time set for renewal of talks.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)--Senate-House negotiations agreed tonight on a compromise $300,000,000 welfare reform bill embodying most of the Administration proposals for stepping up aid to the needy and helping get some of them off relief.

MOLES, skunks, squirrels, rabbits and muskrats have had their pelts sheared, dyed and cleverly disguised to make the fur coat seem almost a budget fashion. Stern's demonstrated the new character of these members of the fur family yesterday in a collection of coats and jackets that were frequently elegant.

WASHINGTON, July 18--A Republican Senator testified today that Dwight D. Eisenhower, while President, suggested helping the distressed mining industry by buying lead and zinc for the national defense stockpile.
WASHINGTON, July 18--Is it impertinent to suggest that the New Frontier is floundering in its obligation to keep the country moving ahead on the gloom front in the Nineteen Sixties?
TEHERAN, Iran, July 18-- Premier Ali Amini of Iran resigned today and blamed the United States for the fall of his Government.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 18--Venezuela, which is seeking support for an emergency meeting of the foreign ministers of the Americas to discuss the Peruvian situation, will ask other countries in the hemisphere also to withhold recognition of the military regime there.

WOMEN who pride themselves on pinching pennies --and inches--when they buy furniture, would do well to examine Kroehler's new collection of storage units, chairs and tables that have just been uncrated at Gimbels.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 18 (AP)--State Controller Arthur Levitt said today that "of course, I'll defer payment" of any pension to State Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh until the State Attorney General had reviewed the pension law.

WASHINGTON, July 18--The United States and some of its allies were reported today to be evolving a program of economic pressures to compel President Moise Tshombe of secessionist Katanga Province to accept federation with the central Congo Government.

PARIS, July 18 (AP)--Alan Murray, a 22-year-old Australian professional, won the French open golf championship today by one stroke with a 68 on the final round for a 72-hole total of 274, fourteen under par.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Senate and House conferees on the foreign aid authorization bill endorsed today President Kennedy's demand for a free hand in waging the "cold war" against communism.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18-- Eugene J. Houdry, inventor of a catalytic cracking process for producing gasoline and holder of more than 100 patents, died today in Delaware County Hospital after a short illness. He was 70 years old and lived in near-by Ardmore.

LANSING, Mich., July 18 (UPI)--The Michigan Supreme Court ruled today that the present apportionment of the State Senate violated the United States Constitution. It ordered an at-large election of all members unless the Legislature takes corrective action by Aug. 20.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, the nation's largest tobacco producer, had the highest first-half sales and earnings in its history. Alexander H. Galloway, president, reported yesterday. Second-quarter sales also set a new record for the period, but earnings dipped from those of a year ago mainly because of increased cost of leaf tobacco, he said.

Gian Carlo Menotti, the composer and librettist, will prepare two original musical dramas or operas for the Columbia Broadcasting System, the television network announced yesterday. Mr. Menotti also will produce and direct the programs.
TOKYO, July 18--Japanese politics went through a strange double ritual today--the formal installation of a new Cabinet and the backroom preparation for its demise.
LIMA, Peru, July 18--The Peruvian armed forces overthrew and imprisoned President Manuel Prado y Ugarteche today in a coup d'etat.
PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP)--The president's council of the Transport Workers Union's Railroad Division voted today to accept a compromise agreement with the Pennsylvania Railroad.
PASADENA, Calif., July 18-- The United States' first shot at the planet Venus, scheduled for Saturday, has a six-fold mission.
Advertising men are a resourceful lot. Whenever existing media become too expensive or competitive they seem to develop new ways of reaching the consumer.

WASHINGTON, July 18-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk will fly tomorrow to Geneva, where he will have another round of talks with Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister. Their purpose this time will be not so much to break the East-West deadlocks on Berlin and nuclear testing as to find ways of living with them.
The Continental Can Company, Inc., announced yesterday that its second-quarter earnings were 28 per cent higher than in the corresponding period last year.

BOSTON, July 18--Red Sox pitching seldom has looked better than it did today--to the Yankees. With extra-base hits sailing hither and yon in Fenway Park, the American League leaders added a 12-4 triumph to a winning string that now spans six road games and stretches from coast to coast.
SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., July 18--A proposal to permit a sewage treatment plant to empty into Pascack Brook southeast of here was protested today by the Spring Valley and Hackensack Water Companies.

C-E-I-R, Inc., an independent computer service company, has leased 24,000 square feet of space for a new Manhattan center in the twenty-two-story office building being constructed at 1180 Avenue of the America's (Sixth Avenue), corner of Forty-sixth Street. The lease, which is for fifteen years, involves the eighth and part of the ninth floors. It was negotiated by Jerry L. Cohen and Ian G.M. Brownlie, vice presidents of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.
Daniel P. O'Connell, the powerful Albany County Democratic leader, yesterday threw his support behind the movement to draft Justice Bernard Botein as the Democratic candidate for Governor.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)--The House approved a $1,990,000,000 Federal allotment for 1964-65 state highway construction today and for the first time included authority to help pay moving costs of persons displaced by rights of way.

The consolidation proposal of the Marine Midland Corporation and the Security National Bank of Long Island cleared an important hurdle yesterday, but the banking institutions have a long way to go before they reach their goal.

TO brew a good cup of coffee, it is necessary to start with a thoroughly clean coffee maker, which should always be rinsed with hot water just before using.
WASHINGTON, July 18--The Labor Department disclosed today that it was making broad changes in its administration of a law fixing minimum wages on Federal construction projects.
ALGIERS, July 18--A secret council of military leaders was reported today to have agreed on nominations for a political bureau to direct the National Liberation Front as a "party of the masses."
Striking non-medical workers at Beth-El Hospital and Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital voted unanimously yesterday to return to work today.
State Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Chimera denied a motion yesterday for a temporary injunction that would delay action on the projected $270,000,000 World Trade Center on the lower West Side.

WALTHAM, Mass., July 18 --Specialists in communications from sixteen foreign countries will fan out across the United States on Sunday evening to make a first-hand study of American television and radio.

LONDON, July 18--If you set aside matters of the spirit, the best buy of the festival of the City of London is a masque for wine tasters called "In Praise of Wine."
