TO MANY minds there is no perfume of Araby or France to equal the full-bodied aroma that comes from a freshly brewed cup of coffee. It has been known as the elixir of life, the philosopher's cup and the drink of wisdom. For the full essence, coffee must be newly made and newly poured.
WOODBURY, L.I., July 18 --The construction of a cancer research building and a cancer detection center here will start at 8 A.M. Saturday with donated labor, equipment and material.
STRATFORD, Conn., July 18--In "Shakespeare Revisited" which joined the repertory of the American Shakespeare Festival last night, Helen Hayes and Maurice Evans have chosen to run the gamut.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, July 18--Robert K.A. Gardiner, the United Nations chief in the Congo, arrived today for talks with President Moise Tshombe.

BONN, Germany, July 18--A Mexican company, Impulsora Mexicana Automatriz, was reported today to have purchased most of the production machinery of the Borg ward Auto Company, West Germany's fifth largest car maker until it went bankrupt last year. Immediately after the declaration of bankruptcy the production of Borgward cars was stopped.
ALBANY, July 18--Spokesmen for upstate savings banks and savings and loan associations asked the Joint Legislative Committee on Banking today for legislation permitting them to make personal loans.

Two men accused of being key figures in a Harlem narcotics ring that served at least 300 addicts daily and grossed $2,000,000 a year were arraigned in Federal Court yesterday. They were arrested Tuesday night.

The New Jersey Highway Authority yesterday financed the construction of an Essex County interchange linking the Garden State Parkway and the EastWest Freeway by the sale of $40,000,000 of long-term bonds to forty-eight investing institutions.
MOSCOW, July 18--The Soviet bloc has set up a new international body to coordinate the economic development of its member nations short of complete integration.
ALBANY, July 18--The Public Service Commission has refused to permit the New York Central Railroad to increase fares on Aug. 1 in the metropolitan New York commuting area.

Bishop James P. De Wolfe requested the board of managers of St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Brooklyn yesterday to direct the staff to carry out a policy of assigning patients to all rooms without regard to race.
A taxpayer's suit was started in State Supreme Court yesterday to block the purchase by the city of 2,750 voting machines from the Shoup Voting Machines Corporation.
Mayor Wagner's chief political deputy in the Bronx said yesterday that seven district Democratic clubs had been mobilized to fight Representative Charles A. Buckley's regular Democratic organization.

Peru is not the only place where achieving reform without revolution is proving a formidable task. In Iran it has defeated the best efforts of Dr. Ali Amini, the ablest and most determined Premier that kingdom has had in a long time.

The undefeated Ahoy of Dr. Leon Levy's Jaclyn Stable "carried the weight" to a clear triumph in the $28,050 Great American Stakes at Aqueduct's yesterday. The son of Sailor and Westminster Bridge scored by a half-length over the favored Near Man, of the October House Farm, with C.V. Whitney's Tom Cat, next, three lengths behind Near Man.
BERLIN, July 18--Communist East Germany admitted today that it had arrested an undisclosed number of Western travelers on the land routes through East Germany between Berlin and the West.
A gentle rain fell over parts of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania yesterday, alleviating a drought that has been characterized as one of the worst in many years.

HIGHLAND MILLS, N.Y., July 18--Some literary cocktail types, including many who never before had been to a prizefighter's training camp, visited Floyd Patterson here today and discovered him to be a shy, solitary craftsman, like J.D. Salinger, and about as comfortable with literary cocktail types.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)--Walter S. Hallanan resigned today as chairman of the National Petroleum Council and brought to light an apparent conflict-of-interest dispute between the council and the Interior Department.

THE guest of honor at a dinner in the Palmer House, Chicago, on Aug. 10 will be a dog. This will be no ordinary pup. It will be the winner of the Ken-L-Ration gold medal, awarded annually in a competition to choose the most heroic dog of the year.

LONDON, July 18--A panel of three High Court judges ruled against Dr. Robert A. Soblen today in his fight against detention by British immigration authorities. His lawyers immediately announced they intended to appeal this ruling.
A brown-and-white puppy with a broken leg was rescued from the tracks of a major subway line here yesterday after tying up morning rush-hour service.
Benny Goodman, the band leader, returned here by plane late yesterday from a six-week concert tour of the Soviet Union with nothing but praise for the Russian audiences.

Leaders of a Negro medical organization in Queens charged yesterday that for fifteen years Mary Immaculate Hospital, a Roman Catholic institution in Jamaica, had discriminated against the appointment of Negroes to its ppofessional staff.

Dr. Jack Applebaum, a podiatrist and physiotherapist, died Monday of a heart ailment at St. Joseph's Hospital, Far Rockaway, Queens. He was 70 years old and lived at 63-60 Ninetyeighth Street, Forest Hills, Queens. His office was at 221 East Fiftieth Street.

Long John Distilleries, Ltd., a major British affiliate of Schenley Industries, Inc., has acquired "a substantial majoirity interest" in D. Johnston Co. (Laphroaig), Ltd., of the island of Islay, off the west coast of Scotland.
MOSCOW, July 18--The Soviet Union sought to assure Western European countries today that it had no intention of using oil exports as an instrument of economic pressure.
Picketing of a Chock Full O' Nuts restaurant at Seventh Avenue and 125th Street was ordered halted shortly before 6 P.M., yesterday by Lewis Miichaux, African Nationalist leader.

Pullman, Inc., has been paying quarterly dividends in an unbroken string back to 1867, earned or not earned. Among Big Board issues it ranks as second behind American News whose payments stretch back to 1864. In the last five quarters, however, Pullman has not earned the 50 cents it has been paying. Yesterday the dividend watchers knew that Pullman directors were meeting to ponder the matter.

YONKERS, July 18--If the favored A.C.'s Viking is to be upset tomorrow night in the $105,422 Yonkers Futurity Trot at Yonkers Raceway, the upsetting most likely will be done by either Safe Mission or Sprite Rodney.

OTTAWA, July 18 (Canadian Press)--Justice T.G. Norris of Vancouver has been appointed a one-man commission to investigate shipping disruptions and labor unrest on the Great Lakes, Labor Minister Michael Starr announced today.
Dockworkers and steamship companies failed for the fourth time yesterday to negotiate a new three-year contract.

TLEMCEN, Algeria, July 18 --Former Premier Ferhat Abbas endorsed today the charges leveled by Mohammed Ben Bella against the Algerian Provisional Government. But he made it clear that he disagreed with some of the dissident Vice Premier's Leftist political views.

The metropolitan area will before long have two new movie houses. One, a neighborhood playhouse in Brooklyn turned art theatre, is already in the last days of preparation and will open its doors Friday. The other is being built at a shopping center in Fort Lee, N.J., and plans to show its first film on Christmas Day.
Record sales and earnings were registered for the first six months of this year by the Corn Products Company, the semiannual report of John R. Rhamstine, president, disclosed yesterday.
SASKATOON, Sask., July 18 --A basis for settlement began to appear today in the strike of Saskatchewan's physicians against the Provincial Government's compulsory medical care program.

WASHINGTON, July 18-- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman turned his news conference into a forum today and made a speech accusing the Republicans of playing "the narrowest, most partisan, most bitter kind of politics" with farm legislation.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)--Four men who have piloted the rocket-powered X-15 research plane to the fringes of space received the Robert J. Collier Trophy today from President Kennedy.
The Board of Education accepted a $90,000 grant from the Ford Foundation yesterday to cut red tape.

A SUPERIOR tactician doesn't necessarily ex amine every variation developing from an imbalance of a position. Often, he will initiate an imbalance when he feels that general principles are on his side. This is the spot where tactical and strategical appraisal (or feeling) must jibe.
ALBANY, Ga., July 18--Negroes opened the second week of a drive against segregation today with demonstrations at five drug and variety stores, a bus terminal and a swimming pool.

The National Maritime Union said yesterday that it has asked the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service for formal recognition as bargaining representative for civilian seamen employed aboard Governmentowned cargo ships in the service's Atlantic and Gulf fleets.

The seizure of power in Peru by military leaders, the arrest of President Prado, who re fused to bow to their demands, and the annulling of an election which the official National Electoral Board pronounced honest after the most careful investigation, are in the worst tradition of Latin America's unstable and violent political history. It had been hoped that Peru had outgrown the garrison revolt.
The Boston and Maine Railroad and the New York Central Railroad announced plans yesterday to study a merger of the Central's Boston and Albany division with the B. M.
F. SCOTT FITZGERALD tried to give Pat Hobby the air of insolence tinged with servility that marks a low budget charlatan.
WASHINGTON, July 18-- The months-long Congressional deadlock that has blocked all of this year's money bills was broken temporarily today.
WASHINGTON, July 18-- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara ordered the cancellation today of the Navy's work on what would have been the world's largest movable radio telescope.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 18 --Nearly 900 sailors, none more than 17 years old, sailed in the thirty-seventh annual Larchmont Junior Regatta this afternoon. They came from thirtynine clubs on both shores of Long Island Sound.

WHITE PLAINS, July 18-- Westchester County will get 534 acres of land for parks and institutions and New York City will prevent the pollution of its water supply at Mount Kisco, under an agreement drafted today.
Inventories of refined petroleum products continued to reflect seasonal trends last week.
The City Planning Commission asserted yesterday that small businesses forced to move from the sites of public improvements were not receiving fair treatment in relocation benefits.
The recent notices from Wall Street are being felt on Broadway. The business of raising money for show business has become more difficult because of the stock-market slump.
Stock prices fell yesterday for the fourth successive session. Trading was active on the decline, a rather disturbing sign to many Wall Street observers.
World sugar moved against the tide in the local commodity futures markets yesteday, by continuing to show gains on fairly good trading volume.
WASHINGTON, July 18-- Democrats took a cue from President Kennedy today and began a drive to capitalize on the defeat yesterday of medical care for the aged under Social Security.

RABAT, Morocco, July 18-- Col. Houari Boumedienne, the head of the ousted Algerian General Staff, said in an interview published here today that the aim of the Algerian Liberation Army was a "peasants' revolution" with agrarian reform as its first objective.

A five-alarm fire swept through two abandoned buildings on 137th Street, between Lincoln and Alexander Avenues the Bronx, yesterday afternoon. For a time it threatened other vacant buildings slated for demolition for a housing project.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose by 546,888 shares to 5,158,849 shares in the month ended last Friday, July 13, to the highest level in nearly four years, the exchange announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 18-- President Kennedy announced today the appointment of a twelve-member Consumers Advisory Council "to give broad consideration to the consumers' needs and point of view."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 18 --The marriage of Dr. Mary Ellen Beck to Dr. Martin Jay Wohl took place here this afternoon at the Appleton Chapel of Harvard University. Rabbi Kenneth Rifkin of Malden performed the ceremony.

NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa., July 18--Arnold Palmer scored a one-under-par 69 in the rain today on his last preparatory round for the Professional Golfers Association championship, which starts tomorrow at the Aronimink Country Club.
BONN, Germany, July 18-- A meeting of the Belgian and West German foreign ministers July 26 may disclose the chances of swift progress toward the political integration of Western Europe.

AMONG the tournaments played over the last week-end, outside the metropolitan area but near enough to attract automobile-loads of New Yorkers, was the historic Southern New England Championships at Norwich, Conn.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Senate investigators were told today that Billie Sol Estes was blocked when he tried to transfer cotton-acreage allotments from Alabama to Texas.

LONDON, July 18 (AP)-- The Marquis of Exeter, president of the International Amateur Athletic Federation, backed the Amateur Athletic Union today in its differences with the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had taken disciplinary action against Townsend E. Allen, a regular member of the exchange and a floor partner in Ira Haupt Co. The exchange said Mr. Allen was penalized for negligence in dealings with expelled stock specialists Gerard A. and Gerard F. Re.

RIVER FOREST, Ill., July 18 --Darlene Hard of Long Beach, Calif., the national grass court champion, and Frank Froehling 3d of Coral Gables, Fla., a member of the Davis Cup team, made their exits from the United States clay court tournament today during another day of major casualties at the River Forest Tennis Club.

Bond prices were little changed yesterday in only moderate active trading. Most interest centered on the pricing of new issues of public utility corporate and local government bonds put up for sale at public sealed bidding.

CHICAGO, July 18--Jim Walter Corporation, Tampa, Fla., builder of shell homes, has increased its holdings of Celotx Corporation stock to 400,000 shares, or about 40 per cent of the 1,018,651 outstanding shares of the Chicago manufacturer of building and insulating products.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Senate Finance Committee actions on the tax-revision bill would mean a loss of $860,000,000 in the anticipated yield to the Treasury in the measure's first year, Government fiscal experts estimated tonight.

Burton Riglander Blumenthal, a specialist in corporation reorganization law, died Sunday of multiple sclerosis in his home at 111 Downs Avenue, Shippan Point, Stamford, Conn. He was 46 years old and also had a home here at 3 East Sixtyninth Street.
GENEVA, July 18--The United States rejected today two Soviet proposals that the Russians had characterized as attempts to meet Western views on disarmament.

SASKATOON, Sask., July 18--Probably no man's life has been more drastically changed by the bitter feud between Saskatchewan's physicians and the provincial Government than that of Dr. Harold David Dalgeish.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 18 (AP)--The Minnesota Twins scored eleven runs in the first inning today and went on to overwhelm the Cleveland Indians, 14--3.
MIAMI BEACH, July 18-- About 900 persons attended today a Cold War Education Conference sponsored by Gov. Farris Bryant at Bal Harbour's Americana Hotel.
Five men charged with having conspired to commit robberies in New Jersey were arraigned yesterday in Felony Court and held in bail of as much as $51,000 each pending a hearing on July 27.

Miss Barbara Silver, daughter of Mrs. Barnett L. Silver of 115 Central Park West and the late Mr. Silver, was married here yesterday to James S. Marcus. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Bernard K. Marcus of 944 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Marcus.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) --Spokesmen for the American Merchant Marine said today that mandatory use of United States flagships in domestic trade was not the basic cause of the decline in Northwest lumber shipments to East Coast markets.

NEWARK, July 18--The Newark Housing Authority received final authorization today from the Federal Urban Renewal Administration for the the expenditure of more than $7,700,000 in Federal funds to acquire and clear land for two urban renewal projects.

HOLLYWOOD, July 18--Attorneys for the Government and the Music Corporation of America conferred today in Los Angeles in an attempt to clarify the situation resulting from the Government's civil antitrust suit against the company.

A man who had attacked a woman in Central Park was chased a third of a mile through the park last night by a church sexton. He was finally arrested by policemen, who found him next to the third rail in a BMT subway tunnel. Power was shut off for six minutes while the police made the arrest.

WASHINGTON, July 18--The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended July 11:

Edward J. Maloy, senior partner of Bertschmann Maloy, an insurance brokerage firm, and a figure in Democratic party activities on Staten Island, died Tuesday in his home. He lived at 85 Forest Ave., Silver Lake, S.I., and was 71 years old.
The head of New York City's mental health services urged the state yesterday to go beyond its matching-funds formula in providing local financial aid to improve the services.
Theodore R. Kupferman, former legislative assistant to the late Stanley M. Isaacs, was named by Manhattan Republican leaders yesterday as their candidate to succeed Mr. Isaacs in the City Council.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 19 Dr. Helen Gertrude Canoyer, chairman of the newly created Consumers Advisory Council, is regarded by her colleagues as an academic rarity, because her skills in administration and teaching are equally high.

MILWAUKEE, July 19 (AP) The Milwaukee Journal announced today that it had purchased the strike-bound Milwaukee Sentinel from the Hearst Corporation and would resume publication of the mornning newspaper next Monday in The Journal's recently expanded plant.
WASHINGTON, July 19 The Kennedy Administration will support proposals for increased home rule for Guam in the Western Pacific.
BERLIN, July 19 American officials disclosed today that a Soviet fighter approached a Pan American World Airways airliner on Tuesday over Berlin.
Grants totaling $2,500,000 have been made to the American Council on Education by two foundations so the council may "keep pace with the growing demands on the nation's system of higher education."
CAIRO, Ill., July 19 Seventeen students, all but one of them Negroes, were found guilty today of "mob action" in seeking admission to a skating rink here. Each was fined $100.
An experimental city program aimed at "problem" tenants in a West Side tenement was hailed as a success yesterday by the city, the landlord and the tenants themselves.
SALISBURY, Conn., July 18 Clyde Brion Davis, author of "The Anointed" and "The Great American Novel," died here today in his home. He was 68 years old.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 19 Mrs. Sheldon E. Prentice has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Clare Ellsworth Prentice, to Ensign Cary Nicholas Potter, U.S. N.R. The future bridegroom is the son of Cary Potter of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Mrs. William Thompson of Victoria, B.C.

THE annual Brooklyn Championship tournament will be played at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn this week-end, beginning today with men's and women's pair contests at 2:30 P.M., and a mixed pair contest at 8:30 P.M.
Not long ago, one of Madison Avenue's better known agencies, Geyer, Morey, Madden Ballard, Inc., decided to change its name to Geyer, Morey Ballard, Inc.
Business loans at major New York City commercial banks declined $173,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

YONKERS, July 19 Never farther back than second and on top for most of the mile and a sixteenth, A.C.'s Viking easily won the richest Yonkers Futurity last night at Yonkers Raceway. The time of 2:10-4/5 was only a fifth of a second slower than the track record.

ELISABETHVILLE, July 19 Robert K.A. Gardiner, chief of the United Nations operations in the Congo, accused the Katangese Government today of contradictions in its statements about the unity of the Congo.
Two leaders in the discount field reported yesterday that more and more apparel manufacturers were abandoning their reluctance to sell to discount stores.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Friday, July 20 (AP) A United States Air Force helicopter reported that it had sighted wreckage of a plane believed to be a United Arab Airlines jet missing with twenty-six persons aboard.
Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg and Paul G. Hoffman were married yesterday in the Chapel of All Souls Untarian Church.
Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday the development of new silicone metal protectants, ehich prevent corrosion and tarnish on a variety of metals.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 19 Finance ministers of Nigeria and Dahomey conferring at Lagos signed a common customs pact yesterday between their two countries. The agreement appears to be the first of a series of similar pacts among the African countries known as the Monrovia group. It provides for free passage of goods exchanged between the two countries at the border crossing point in Idiroko.

WASHINGTON. ANITA J. MOLLER, the State Department's chief interior designer for its overseas buildings, sat in her coral-carpeted office one day this week, sorting out fabric swatches, consulting color charts and making notes.

Two autumn theatre parties are being planned by the Women's Division of the Legal Aid Society. They are the evening performance on Nov. 7 of "The Affair," a play scheduled to open Sept. 20 at Henry Miller's Theatre, and the Dec. 6 performance of "Mr. President," a musical that will open Oct. 20 at the St. James Theatre.
The little plot of land in Brooklyn that Cobble Hill residents banded together to protect was back in the news yesterday stirring new controversy and historic memories.
Consumption of newsprint in the United States set a record high in the first half of 1962, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.
TENAFLY, N.J., July 19 An unusual concept in housing, in which 300 single-family homes would be built in five clusters on a 275-acre tract, has been presented to the planning board here.
WASHINGTON, July 19 Italy will repay the United States $178,100,000 plus interest tomorrow to settle accounts on six loans decades before the final deadlines.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) A Miami savings and loan association for which the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. interceded with a government official was enjoined today from opening for business.
BERLIN, July 19 East German authorities have established a forbidden zone more than three miles wide along their entire seacoast in an attempt to prevent escapes.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 19 The United States and Britain have told Israel that the Government of Jordan wants tranquillity along the armistice lines between Jordan and Israel, reliable sources here said today.
Edward S. Silver, Kings County District Attorney, announced yesterday that he had ordered a grand jury inquiry into the sale of products assertedly made by blind persons.
The return of major television dramas with exciting themes was predicted yesterday by Hubbell Robinson, senior vice president of television programs for the Columbia Broadcasting System.

IN EVERY mail, publications dealing with conservation and fish and game matter flood in. They contain accounts of violations of fish and game laws, and how much the fall from grace cost when the judge applied the walletthinning majesty of justice.

LONDON, July 19 Queen Elizabeth II, owner of what is considered the world's largest and finest private art collection, will allow the public to view her treasures in a new gallery adjoining Buckingham Palace.

WHITE PLAINS, July 19 The State Attorney General's office was accused in Westchester County Court here today of using criminal indictments to fight a $1,592,269 civil claim in the construction of the New England Thruway.

WASHINGTON, July 19 The Treasury reported today that it paid out $6,300,000,000 more than it received in the year ended June 30. This was $700,000,000 less than the estimate made in January, midway in the fiscal year.

A bill limiting the added moisture content or curing solution in most processed meat sold in the city to 10 per cent of the meat's weight was signed yesterday by Acting Mayor Paul R. Screvane. It will become effective in thirty days.
LONDON, July 19 An appeal by Dr. Robert A. Soblen against a High Court ruling upholding his detention by British immigration authorities was filed with the Court of Appeals today.
WASHINGTON, July 19 Foreign Minister Subandrio of Indonesia arrived today to resume his country's negotiations with the Netherlands over the future of Netherlands New Guinea.

FLORENCE, July 19 The last collections of the season were presented today at the Pitti Palace. Another moment of fashion truth for Florence is over, but the days of financial reckoning have only begun.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 19 World records will fall in the United States-Soviet Union dual track and field meet at Stanford Stadium on Saturday and Sunday, John Oelkers, the American head coach, predicted today. Gabriel Khorobkov, the Soviet coach, concurred.

Sales of the Allied Chemical Corporation sets record for the quarter and six months ended on June 30. Earnings, however, declined sharply from those of the 1961 periods, the company reported yesterday.
Stauffer Chemical Company will dedicate a new $10,000,000 trona mine and soda ash refinery today near Green River, Wyo.

Operations of Standard Oil Company of California in the first half of this year resulted in sharply higher sales and earnings over the similar period of 1961, the report of R.G. Follis, chairman, revealed yesterday.
TO a vivacious Civil War diary from the Confed erate side, we can now add its equivalent from the Union side.
CARLSTADT, N.J., July 19 A white couple here, the parents of four children, have asked to adopt a 6-year-old Negro boy.
A hitch in the rehiring of Beth-El Hospital strikers threatened Governor Rockefeller's hospital peace plan for a time yesterday, but was resolved last night.

GROTON, Conn., July 19 (AP) Mediators sat down with management and union representatives today in an effort to end a strike that affects construction of nuclear submarines at Electric Boat Division of General Dynamics Corporation.

RIVER FOREST, Ill., July 19 Mrs. Karen Hantze Susman of San Antonio, the winner at Wimbledon, defaulted in the national clay court tennis championship today. Not a seeded woman player remains in the semi-final brackets.

Two floors in the Sperry Rand Building, which is nearing completion at 1290 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) at Fifty-first Street, have been leased by James Talcott, Inc., 108-year-old finance company. The space was leased for twenty

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) A former Agriculture Department official who was dismissed for accepting favors from Billie Sol Estes accused Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman today of trying to side-step his responsibility in the case.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 19 Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran appointed as Premier today his aide and personal friend, Assodollah Alam.

ALGIERS, July 19 It appeared probable tonight that the schism in the Algerian nationalists' ranks would be resolved by vesting the movement's essential power in six men who unleashed the revolt against French rule in 1954.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) Following is the vote by which the House today passed and sent to the Senate a farm bill:
Potatoes and cocoa led the local commodity futures markets in activity yesterday, followed closely by sugar. The first two declined, but sugar rose.
Several leading paper companies announced increased sales and earnings yesterday. First-half profits of the St. Regis Paper Company were 19 pet cent above the 1961
WASHINGTON, July 19 The House of Representatives passed tonight a farm bill stripped of the strict production controls the Administration wanted for major crops.

The fourth annual Roosevelt International, a $50,000 item on the Aug. 18 agenda at Roosevelt Raceway, is beginning to shape up. With the announcement yesterday that Nicias Grandchamp of France will be among the starters in the mileand-a-quarter race, the field, which eventually will total eight, already includes three fair-to-middlin' trotters.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it was mailing questionnaires to all New York Stock Exchange member firms calling for information on their trading for their own accounts during the May 28 market plunge and on other dates.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 19 Max E. Blatt founder or the M. E. Blatt department store here, died today in the Atlantic City Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in the President Hotel.

A special board named by Secretary Goldberg is studying the tortured question of American owned vessels operating under foreign flags-- the "flags of convenience"--to gain benefits of lower taxes and lower operating costs. These ships under Panamanian or Liberian registry are valued by our military authorities as stand-by emergency ships, pledged to this country when needed...

Samuel Knepper, New York realty investor, has sold the two-story business building at 10-12 North Broadway running through the block to 7-9 Pali sade Avenue, Yorkers. He bought the property two years ago.

Yankee Stadium, home of the New York Yankees, is now in the hands of Texans from Houston. Rice University received all the capital stock of the Yankee Stadium Corporation, which holds title to the park, two months ago.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 19 An official of the Republic Aviation Corporation in Farmingdale said today that predicted lay-offs of 13,000 of the company's 15,500 employes by the end of 1964 would not take place.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) The Senate completed Congressional action tonight on compromise legislation giving President Kennedy most of his requested reforms in the nation's multimillion-dollar program of aid to the needy:
BUENOS AIRES, July 19 The Peronists began a campaign today to get major political parties to boycott next year's elections.

WASHINGTON, July 19 The agonizing reappraisal at the White House has started. The defeat of the Administration's medical care bill in the Senate, even though it was a sham battle, has forced a re-examination not only of the President's past attitude' toward the Congress but of the Administration's whole procedure of preparing and presenting legislation to the country.

LONDON, July 19 The scuttlebut was that John Osborne, the first of the "angry young men" among British playwrights, had written a savage attack on the Royal family and that the premiere of this play tonight would be a scene of angry demonstrations.
MOSCOW, July 19 The Soviet people were told for the first time today about the dramatic recovery of Lev D. Landau, the nuclear physicist, after a serious automobile accident last January.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 19 Howard McMichael, who is the season leader of the International Class with his sloop, Kangaroo, was the winner of today's race on Long Island Sound. As a result he moved into the Larchmont Race Week
Officials in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania looked at the sunny skies over their drought-stricken states yesterday and turned to Washington for more help.
Plans to continue telecasts on Channel 31 after the Federal Communications System completes its experiment were outlined yesterday by Seymour N. Siegel.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. became today the first American Negro to address the National Press Club.
WASHINGTON, July 19 The White House charged in President Kennedy's name today that the military coup d'etat in Peru was a "serious setback" for the Alliance for Progress in Latin America.

NINE years ago next Thursday 120 peace officers raided the town of Short Creek, Arizona, which is just south of the Utah border in the sparsely settled region north of the Grand Canyon. They arrested virtually the entire adult population thirty-six men and eighty-six women

LONDON, July 19 The possibility that a child might be born deformed because its mother had taken the drug thalidomide is not a lawful ground for abortion, the Lord Chancellor said in debate today is the House of Lords.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, July 19 (AP) The United Nations has charged Katangese troops with having killed an African woman and child near a besieged United Nations roadblock in Elisabethville Tuesday.

Benny Goodman spent his first morning back in the United States yesterday after his six-week tour of the Soviet Union playing a round of golf. Then he relaxed in his East Side apartment and considered the results of the trip with his eighteen-piece jazz band.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday accused the Yee Gai Association, whose members starch and iron shirts for the city's 4,000 Chinese hand laundries, of fixing prices illegally.

Charles Harrison Meyer, a lawyer and an authority on stock brokerage law, died yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a short illness. He was 70 years old and lived 135 East Fifty-fourth Street.
Common stocks worth $122,828 have been reported missing and presumably stolen from Carl M. Loeb, Rhoades Co., at 40 Wall Street. One lot, worth $52,612, has been recovered.
The Georgia-Pacific Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to refinance about $220,000,000 of its long-term debt.

WASHINGTON, July 19 Officials of the Eastern Air Lines chapter of the Flight Engineers International Associalion said today that the carrier's steps to break the solid front of the union's strike had made the members angry.

The controversy involving $95 billion in temporarily blocked Federal appropriations and the delicate question whether Congressional conference committees shall meet on the House side or the Senate side or somewhere in the middle has ended at last. The issues were superficially trivial. The American liking for personal drama led many to look on this as a struggle

Yields on basic short-term investments in the United States market moved lower yesterday as an abundance of money sought investment in Treasury bills. The demand came both from commercial banks and non-financial corporations.

MOSCOW, July 19 The Soviet Government announced today the appointment of Vladimir N. Novikov, a Deputy Premier, as its permanent representative on the Communist bloc's Council of Mutual Economic Assistance.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) A refugee Cuban political writer accused three American reporters today of writing distorted stories on Cuba in favor of the Castro regime.
The sweet smell of newness is being used by some Queens auto dealers to peddle used cars as new, the Queens District Attorney's office reported yesterday.

Two industrialists and the head of a mutual fund, acting as officers of an Ohio corporation, have nearly completed negotiations to acquire working control of the B.S.F. Company, a holding company based in Wilmington, Del.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., July 19 "This city is like a guy who tries to forget his troubles by going on a binge," said the young doctor as he gazed out the window overlooking Newburgh's drab main street.
Seatrain Lines, Inc. announced plans yesterday for a service to San Juan, Puerto Rico, with its specialized tonnage capable of carrying railroad cars and highway trailers.

The following is a listing of New York restaurants that are recomvended on the basis of varying merits. Such a listing is published every Friday in The New York Times. Unless otherwise indicated, the restaurants are open seven days a week.
Prices of stocks rose yesterday, reversing a four-day decline. Trading was moderate and some profit taking developed in late transactions.

WASHINGTON, July 19-- The Senate beat off today a bipartisan effort to defeat a compromise $4,672,000,000 foreignaid authorization bill worked out last night with negotiators for the House of Representatives. The negative voice vote culminated seven hours of debate in which advocates of a total ban on aid to all Communist-governed countries nearly had their way.

NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa., July 19 Arnold Palmer trailed by five strokes in the opening round of the Professional Golfers Association championship today as 50-year-old John Barnum took the lead with a fourunder-par 66.
The Celanese Corporation of America announced yesterday that it had entered the domestic tire-cord market with production of Fortrel polyester yarn at Shelby, N.C.

SASKATOON, Sask., July 19 Negotiations were continuing today in an effort to settle the dispute between the Government and the prnvince's physicians, who are striking against the compulsory medieal care program.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) A high-altitude nuclear test over Johnston Island in the Pacific has been scheduled for the early morning of next Tuesday, July 24, the Atomic Energy Commission announced today.
YAPHANK, L.I., July 19 Governor Rockefeller asked Suffolk officials today to reconsider their stand against assuming the cost of maintaining Long Island Rail Road com muter stations in the county.

The Pittsburgh Pirates, desperate upward-strivers in the National League pecking order, defeated the New York Mets, secure in the status-less cellar, in a twilight-night double-header last night at the Polo Grounds before 16,450 fans.
WASHINGTON, July 19 The Department of Agriculture announced today the suspension of a Texas employe on charges of receiving money for concealing irregularities in Federal rice planting allotments.

WASHINGTON, July 19 Senator Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York, charged today that the Department of State had done "next to nothing" to protest the rising wave of anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union.
The Staten Island tower of the $325,000,000 Verrazano Narrows Bridge is 80 per cent complete.

Two Wall Street investment banking houses expect to begin selling to Western European private institutional investors about $100,000,000 in ExportImport Bank participation certificates within the next thirty days. The banking houses are Dillon, Read Co. and Kuhn, Loeb Co.
Lily May Hyland, pianist, composer, piano teacher and musicologist, died Monday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 77 years old and lived at 7 Jane Street.

BOSTON, July 19 Myrtle Alice Worthy said today that she had lost eight pounds in the first week of a hunger strike in protest against her brother's indictment in connection with his passport difficulties.
The French Line yesterday detailed the preparations being made for what may be the fastest turnaround of any superliner in the Port of New York.
Bronx Borough President Joseph F. Periconi yesterday promised full support in the Board of Estimate for the Transit Authority's proposed $l97,000,000 subway from mid-Manhattan to the Bronx.
BONN, Germany, July 18 A controversy over the role of the military in politics has flared up here with denunciations of military leaders for publicly offering their views on political
LIMA, Peru, July 19 The (military junta that seized power in Peru yesterday formally requested diplomatic recognition today from the United States and other non-Communist countries.
The nation's public utilities raised $2,099,000,000 in the first six months of this year through securities offerings. This was 32 per cent below the $3,071,000,000 raised in the 1961 period.
A WIDE variety of furs for fall and winter was shown yesterday by Arnold Constable, a store that believes in classics as well as fashion innovations.
WASHINGTON, July 19 The railroad industry reported today that freight movements last week were substantially higher than during the preceding holiday week but below the 1961 level.

BOSTON, July 19 Yankee base-runners staged another merry hoedown in Fenway Park today, but the resident Red Sox were not amused. Some seemed downright depressed, in fact, as they stood about rather helplessly while the Bombers completed a sweep of the three-game series. The score was 10 6.
WASHINGTON, July 19 The Administration expects to decide early next month whether to seek an emergency anti-recession cut in Federal income taxes.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 19 Foreign Minister Marcos Falcon Briceno said today that the military take-over in Peru was "scandalous" and that the other American states should not recognize the new regime.
WASHINGTON, July 19 President Kennedy told his new Consumers Advisory Council today that he expected it to become a definite and permanent part of the "governmental structure."
WASHINGTON, July 19 The Army's Nike Zeus defense missile intercepted the nose cone of an Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile today high over Kwajalein Island in the Pacific.

The fractiousness Congress has been exhibiting toward most Administration programs is still asserting itself on the issues of foreign aid and financial support for the United Nations areas in which the rebel spirit on Capitol Hill is calculated to do greatest harm to this country's position in international affairs. The agreement of Senate and House conferees to revise the aid
LONDON, July 19 The British are honking their horns and slamming their car doors with too much energy for the comfort of the general public, an officially appointed committee reported today.
THE rain on Wednesday did not fall, unfortunatley, so generously where it was really needed. The effect of the rainfall on the drought conditions in farming areas is not yet completely clear.

WASHINGTON, July 19 The United States denounced the "intransigence" of President Moise Tshombe of Katanga today and threatened him with "all possible measures" short of military action if he persisted in secession from the Central Congolese Government.

VAST, indeed are the changes that have come over a sport variously described as the noble art of self-defense, pugilism or just plain fight racket. Recently it has been spending most of its time in selfdefense, with nothing very noble about it.

IT was Richard Strauss Night at Lewisohn Stadium yes terday an interesting and distinguished variant on the more standard Beethoven, Brahms, Tchaikovsky and Gershwin programs. Julius Rudel, general director of the New York City Opera Company, returned to the stadium for the first time this season to conduct.

WASHINGTON, July 19 The United States Court of Appeals here said today that union funds should not be used to defend union officers charged with wrongdoing seriously detrimental to the union and its members.

The Sanford Stud Farms' Dartmoor allowed a rival entry to take turns at setting the pace in the fifteenth running of the Hitchcock Steeplechase Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. At the strategic time, just approaching the last obstacle, Willard Thompson moved Dartmoor into the lead and kept him there to the finish.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 19 At least 1,000 Government troops were landed yesterday and Tuesday north of Saigon by United States and Vietnamese helicopters in a new and largely secret phase of the war against Communist rebels.
LONDON, July 19 The decline in industrial prices continued in the stock market today. Losses were as heavy as yesterday's and in some cases were larger.
AUSTIN, Tex., July 19 (UPI) The Texas Rangers said today the death of the first Agriculture Department official to question Billie Sol Estes' dealings undoubtedly had been murder.
ROME, July 18 Political parties dug in today for a summer battle in Parliament and Deputies and Senators reluctantly canceled reservations at vacation spots.

Robert Thompson Pell resigned late yesterday as the, Conservative party's candidate for the United States Senate. He said the step had been prompted by "differences of opinion as to the conduct of the campaign."
GENEVA, July 19 The United States urged today that immediate action be taken to reduce the threat of war "by accident, miscalculation or failure of communications."

Representative Hugh L Carey has asked Federal aviation authorities to ban New York Air ways flights over densely populated areas of Brooklyn until the investigation of the emergency helicopter landing Monday is completed.
Robert Rossen, who was named best director of the year by the New York Film Critics, is negotiating with James Baldwin for the stage rights to his new novel, "Another Country."

Temple Emanu-El, among the largest houses of worship in the world, had its millionth visitor yesterday. He was a 9-year-old boy in a vacation school group from Rendell Memorial Presbyterian Church in Harlem.

The management of Benguet Consolidated, Inc., expects to win all seven directors' posts at the annual meeting election in Manila today and defeat dissident stockholders bidding for four of the board seats.
NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa., July 20--Arnold Palmer remained five strokes off the pace today while Doug Ford became the new leader in the Professional Golfers Association championship.
LONDON, July 20 (UPI)-- The British Court of Appeal said today it would hear the case of Dr. Robert A. Soblen next Thursday.
WASHINGTON, July 20--The Senate Finance Committee tentatively approved a greatly modified version of the Administration's tax revision bill today.
LONDON, July 20--The Lord Chamberlain, Britain's theatrical censor, declined today to reverse his ban on a lampoon of President Kennedy despite White House consent.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 20--The International Court of Justice expressed the opinion today that all members of the United Nations are legally obligated to pay expenses of the peace-keeping forces in the Congo and Middle East.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 20--Efforts to set a legal standard for "proper dress" on the beaches and streets of the Town of East Hampton broke down in a dispute today.
LONDON, July 20--The stock market ended the week quietly down today.

A man drove up to the main gate of the Concord Hotel here on a recent Saturday night. He carried a large carton and told the guard at the gate, "I'm delivering trophies for the winners of the swimming contest this afternoon."

The "son et lumiere"--sound and light--dramatization of historic buildings recently introduced to this country in Philadelphia could have a wide application to commercial buildings as well as historic ones, an electrical engineer believes.
PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (UPI)--Right-handed Art Mahaffey pitched a six-hitter and struck out eleven batters to beat Milwaukee, 3--2, tonight.
PALO ALTO, Calif., July 20 --The common carrier received some words of comfort today at Stanford University.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)--William E. Simkin, Chief Federal mediator, reported today that labor contract negotiations with three major aerospace companies were deadlocked.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) --Republican leaders in the Senate began today a fight to block President Kennedy's farm bill pegged to strict controls.

CHICAGO, July 20--Population experts, speaking at the Conference of International Economic and Social Development here, questioned today whether living standards in Latin America could be raised without controlling population growth.

Carry Back will make the first venture of his new career as a "prestige" horse today when he competes in the Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct.
WASHINGTON, July 20-- The opinion today by the International Court of Justice at The Hague on United Nations assessments was considered by many to be its most important decision to date.

RENO, Nev., July 17--The Smith family, after taking twenty-six years to stretch $600 into northern Nevada's most famous gambling casino, Harolds Club, has cashed out for $16,675,000.
HARTFORD, July 20 (AP)-- The Rev. George Lawrence of Brooklyn, a Negro minister, spoke to 1,000 swaying, shouting persons packed into the Metropolitan A.M.E. Zion Church.
PENNSVILLE, N.J., July 20--A prisoner being driven from one jail to another tonight overpowered his two guards, shot one of them three times and fled with the other as a hostage.
J. Gould Remick, a former governor of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 131 East Sixty-ninth Street.
PARIS, July 20--Radical reforms in the pattern of farm ownership and use in France were voted by the National Assembly early this morning.
A two-year survey of the habits of buyers at a colony of homes in River Vale, N.J., indicates that home purchasers' tastes vary with their age.

HARVEY CEDARS, N.J., July 20--This little Long Beach Island community and seven other New Jersey seashore resorts, devastated by the storms of March 6-8, are well on the road to recovery. But none as yet is attracting the tourist trade they all enjoyed in recent summer seasons.
Eastern Air Lines said yesterday that striking members of the Flight Engineers International Association were notifying the company "in impressive numbers" that they were ready to go back to work.
The success of the Telstar satellite in trans-Atlantic television has stirred memories of the first live images sent across the ocean thirty-four years ago.
TLEMCEN, Algeria, July 20 --Abderrahmane Fares, President of the Transitional Executive ruling Algeria until elections, spent nearly ten hours today closeted here with dissident Algerian leaders.
Lethargy settled over the stock market yesterday as a modest gain was chalked up in aimless trading.
WASHINGTON, July 20-- Senate investigators heard testimony today that the late Henry H. Marshall had failed to insist on measures to put an end to Billie Sol Estes' disputed cotton dealings.

Los Angeles plans to offer a revenue bond issue of $33,300,000 at competitive bidding on Aug. 29.
ROME, July 20--Italy's economy seems to be heading for another boom year, despite the last six weeks of labor unrest and a threat of more strikes in the offing.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)--Senator Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York, reported today that Senate-House conferees on a supplement appropriation bill have agreed to provide $17,000,000 for a Federal Pavilion at the New York's World Fair in 1964-65.
Rush-hour express service on the IRT Seventh Avenue subway from Brooklyn to Chambers Street was interrupted for an hour yesterday by third-rail trouble.
WASHINGTON, July 20--Dr. H. Bentley Glass, the Johns Hopkins geneticist, has put his mind to the problem of surviving nuclear war and is betting on the cockroach.
Elementary school children in the Bronx and Queens have been found to be far below the national level in physical fitness.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)--A spokesman for the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations endorsed legislation today to give an average pay increase of at least 14 per cent, retroactive to last Jan. 1, "to all postal and classified workers."

On July 20, 1962 the International Court of Justice delivered an advisory opinion on the question of certain expenses of the United Nations (Article 17, Paragraph 2 of the Charter), which had been put to it in accordance with a resolution adopted by the General Assembly on Dec. 20, 1961.
Stockholders of Noma Lites, Inc., dimmed the lights from their company name but beamed a variety of questions concerning recent corporate activities at their annual meeting here yesterday.
Two volumes of works by Henry David Thoreau are scheduled for September publication by Twayn in conjunction with the celebration of Thoreau's centenary.

LIMA, Peru, July 20--The Foreign Minister of the Peruvian military junta said today that the United States had adopted a "headlong and unjustified" attitude toward the military overthrow of President Manuel Prado y Ugarteche Wednesday.
JERSEY CITY, July 20-- Roosevelt Stadium, the municipal baseball park here, will become a community of 20,000 persons for this weekend.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 20 (UPI)--President Kennedy thanked a group of Naval Reservists today for their service in a year of active duty. He told them that they had been called up only "after a most serious consultation by the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the Congress and by the President of the United States."
BUTTON BAY, Vt., July 20 (AP)--Ten thousand Girl Scouts and staff members at the Senior Roundup heard a message from President Kennedy tonight.

NATO is losing a commander of exceptional ability and qualities on Nov. 1 with the resignation of Gen. Lauris Norstad. He had grown with his job in the six years he headed the NATO forces, and this means that he departs at a time when he is more valuable than ever.

The possibility of an increase in milk prices arose yesterday as a result of the drought in New York, New Jersey and parts of Pennsylvania.

Governor Rockefeller last night lauded Jackie Robinson as "a hero of the struggle to make American democracy a genuine reality for every American." He called the former Brooklyn Dodger star the "symbol, the inspiration, the personal leader" of his race.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 20-- South Vietnamese Government forces swooped down on the Communist-controlled Plain of Reeds sixty miles west of here today. They were reported to have killed eighty-five guerrillas and seized arms and ammunition.

NORWALK, Conn., july 20-- Legal voters of Grace Protesant Episcopal Church, which is being forced to vacate its present home because of an urban renewal project in the uptown business center, have approved buying a tract near by for about $145,000.
WASHINGTON, July 20-- The Senate adopted today a compromise bill authorizing $4,672,000,000 in foreign aid during the year that began July 1. The vote was 56-27.
President Kennedy signed an Executive Order yesterday to prohibit Americans from importing gold coins or holding them abroad after next Jan. 1, except in unusual cases.
CINCINNATI, July 20--The latest chapter in the losing ways of the Mets was recorded in neat and precise fashion tonight by the Cincinnati Reds, primarily through one swing by Gordie Coleman.
A union representing most employes of Macy's was ordered yesterday to cease picketing in support of a Teamsters strike against the store.
AINTREE, England, July 20 --Jim Clark of Britain, driving a Monocoque Lotus, today won the pole position for tomorrow's British Grand Prix here.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 20 --The United States and Soviet Union athletes who have lived together convivially for the past week were set tonight to have at each other in two days of fierce competition.

HARTFORD, July 20 (UPI) --Rabbi David I. Shackney pleaded not guilty in Federal court today to nine counts of holding a Mexican family in involuntary servitude on his chicken farm in Middlefield, Conn.

Initial arrangements are being made for the second annual benefit of the Girls Club of New York, to be held Nov. 14 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. The event, named the Daiquiri Ball, will be a salute to Puerto Rico.

WASHINGTON, July 20--The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that licenses granted by the Federal Communications Commission to two radio stations should not be effective until the Court had disposed of objections to commission rulings in the cases.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 20--The British Medical Association in conference here today acted to stop the marketing of new drugs without adequate clinical trials.
WASHINGTON, July 20-- Wholesale prices in primary markets were unchanged at 100.3 per cent of their 1957-59 base during the week ended July 17, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Lawyers for Leon J. Davis, the hospital union head who was sentenced to a six-month prison term for contempt of court, will seek dismissal of his sentence in Supreme Court in Brooklyn next Wednesday.

PARIS, July 20--France and Tunisia announced today the resumption of diplomatic relations. The announcement came a year to the day after relations were broken off following bloody fighting around the French-held Bizerte naval base.

LOS ANGELES, July 20 (UPI)--Lee Thomas' three-run homer bapped an eight-run fifth inning tonight that brought the Los Angeles Angels from behind for an 8-5 victory over Cleveland. The loss was the Indians' eighth straight.
ALBANY, Ga., July 20--The city government was told today that 300 to 500 Negroes would stage a mass demonstration tomorrow in front of the City Hall.

Although virtually a nonentity as far as the pennant race is concerned the Washington Senators posed a rather formidable challenge to the Yanks last night at the Stadiem before the American League front-runners could put the finishing touches on a 3-2 triumph.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 20--Rutgers University has filed a petition to stop the Piscataway Township Board of Education from barring children of married Rutgers students from township schools.

THE college student who waits on table at a resort hotel, types in an office or sells clothing has long been a familiar figure on the summer scene. The encouraging news in recent years is the increasing number of meaningful jobs that offer a collegian the opportunity of earning while learning.

LAKE PROVIDENCE, La., July 20 (AP)--A state judge tonight restrained United States District Judge Edwin F. Hunter's action in declaring twentyeight East Carroll Parish (county) Negroes to be qualified voters.

As on most summer Fridays there was not much excitement yesterday on the local commodity markets.
LONDON, July 20--The drastic shake-up of Prime Minister Macmillan's Government is to be followed by equally drastic changes in the Conservative party's local organizations.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 20 (Reuters)--A swimmer from Detroit, Miss Mary Margaret Revell, became today the first woman to swim from the Black Sea through the Bosporus to the Sea of Marmara.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20--Four nations already risk loss of their votes in the General Assembly for arrears of payments if the Assembly follows today's advisory opinion by the International Court of Justice that all assessments are obligatory.

The Military Sea Transportation Service said yesterday it was waiting for the National Maritime Union to show evidence that 10 per cent of its unlicensed civilian seamen wanted the union as their bargaining agent.
Mrs. Frances White McMillan, a Commissioner of the Salvation Army, died Thursday in a nursing home in Joliet, Ill. She was 86 years old and lived at 856 North Dearborn Street, Chicago.
A number of New York churches will offer their pulpits tomorrow to visiting clergymen from overseas as well as from other parts of this country.

The United States has now announced a new and firmer policy toward President Moise Tshombe of the secessionist Congo province of Katanga, and the United Nations has reaffirmed its own position. Two important facts ought to be noted; first, that the United States is now threatening to use "all possible measures" short of war to end Tshombe's secession; second, that neither the United States nor the United Nations intends to go to war.

LAGOS, Nigeria, July 20-- While New Yorkers endure a generally humid but rain-shy summer, the temperature here is in the low eighties and the tin roofs of this island city are cooled under almost incessant rain.

LONDON, July 20--The plain fact is that the Macmillan Government has no fall-back position on the issue of the Common Market. It is determined Britain shall gain admission and refuses to contemplate an alternative.

THE thirtieth annual Brooklyn Championships, one of the most popular tournaments conducted each year by the Greater New York Bridge Association, will continue today at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn with a two-session open pair contest at 2 and 8 P.M.

The Federal budget deficit for fiscal 1962 turned out to be less than the $7 billion estimated by the Administration last January. But at $6.3 billion, the traditional administrative deficit is still the second largest to be recorded in peacetime, and is far above the Administration's original projections.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- The United States welcomed today the opinion of the International Court of Justice on United Nations financing and served notice that it would support moves to deprive debtor nations of their voting in the General Assembly.
WASHINGTON, July 20-- The President's Council of Economic Advisers has lowered its estimate of the nation's total output of goods and services in the second quarter.

The Aluminum Company of America reported yesterday second quarter net earnings of $16,243,114, equal to 73 cents a share, compared with all $11,687,620, or 52 cents a share, for the 1981 period. A special gain on the sale of investments of $7,875,000 lifted the net income for the June quarter this year to $24,118,114.
WASHINGTON, July 20 --After months of bitter Congressional feuding over chairmanships of appropriations conferences, a presiding officer for one was selected today by the flip of a coin.

LOS ANGELES, July 19-- California authorities took action this week against out-ofstate real estate promoters who have been peddling raw Western land at high prices to gullible people all over the country.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 20--U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, today called the leaders of Katanga Province in the Congo "a bunch of clowns."

WASNINGTON, July 20 (AP) --The Federal Power Commission announced today settlements under which three natural gas pipeline companies must refund about $43,000,000 plus interest, and reduce present rates by about $6,548,600 s year. The refunds will go to wholesale customers.

The American short-subject candidates for the annual Venice Film Festival, to be held from Aug. 25 through Sept 8., have been announced. The screen conclave is the last of the major European festivals this year.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)--The Civil Aeronautics Board closed the books today on an airline crash that killed eighteen persons and led to major reforms.

A group of conservative Republicans is planning to enter a candidate against Theodore R. Kupferman in the primary election for the nomination to the City Council seat left vacant by the death of Stanley M. Isaacs.

Secretary of Agriculture Freeman has announced that more sawtimber is being logged in the National Forests than in any previous period in history, and that the Forest Service has reduced appraised stumpage prices substantially in a "great effort ... to help timber purchasers and counteract the depressed conditions of the industry."
The Kordite Company, a producer of plastic film and packaging products, has been sold for the third time in seven years.

SASKATOON, Sask., July 20 --A conciliatory resolution calling for a resumption of negotiations between the doctors and the Government over the application of the Medical Care Insurance Act was voted today at the annual convention of the Cooperative. Commonwealth Federation-New Democratic party.
Sales and earnings of the General Motors Corporation, the world's largest automobile maker, broke all records in the quarter and six months ended on June 30.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 20 (AP)--Project officials pronounced everything ready today for an attempt before dawn tomorrow to launch a Mariner I spacecraft on a 140day journey to the planet Venus.

A $120-a-week clerk at Bache Co. was arrested yesterday and charged with stealing more than $1,300,000 in stocks from his employer. He was said to have walked out of the brokerage house at 36 Wall Street on June 12 with the stocks tucked under his shirt.
WASHINGTON, July 20-- The United States suspended its military assistance to Peru today. The Administration increased its pressure on the new military junta there to restore democratic processes.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- The Department of Agriculture chemists have made it possible for the American housewife to cook green vegetables without turning them pale. She can do it by soaking them in a mixture of citric acid and sodium phosphate.

Several equity-issues are to be offered in the new capital market next week according to present plans of the underwriters. This would be the first week of important activity since the stock market break on May 28.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP)-- Most grain future activity was limited today to selling out or buying back contracts in the July delivery, on which dealings ended at noon on the Board of Trade.
The cooperative apartmenthotel--a relatively new and unusual residential accommodation--is gaining in popularity.

Two drug companies sued Simon Schuster for $6,500,000 yesterday, charging that the publishing concern had broken an agreement to sell the companies' weight-control capsules jointly with the best-selling book "Calories Don't Count."
BOSTON, July 20 (AP)-- The Massachusetts Legislature has imposed a curfew from 1 A.M. to 5 A.M. on automobile drivers under 18 years old.

LONDON, July 20--Churning the water beneath its jets and raising a thin curtain of sea spray all around, a Hovercraft was put into scheduled commercial service today for the first time. It operated over the Dee Estuary in North Wales.

LIMA, Peru, July 20--The United States military assisttance program to Peru provided the Sherman tank that rammed through the iron gates of the Pizarro Palace when President Manuel Prado y Ugarteche was deposed and taken prisoner Wednesday.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP)-- Tommy Davis today drove in four runs, becoming the first major leaguer to knock in 100 this season, and led the Los Angeles Dodgers to an 8-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

YONKERS, July 20--Nadine Netter of Scarsdale, N.Y., retained her girls' Eastern clay court tennis championship today. She defeated Alice Christer of Jersey City, 4--6, 7--5, 6--3, in the final round at the Racquet Club of Yonkers.
PITTSBURGH, July 20 (AP) --Homers by Willie Mays and Willie McCovey sparked the San Francisco Giants to a 6--3 victory tonight over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
An agreement settling a suit filed against city officials and the Tavern on the Green by persons interested in Morton Sobell, who was convicted of spying, was filed yesterday in Federal Court.
ROME, July 20--The Communist party warned its rank and file today against what it described as "anarchic" tendencies in the Italian labor movement.

Nelson S.T. Thayer, a divinity student, will marry Miss Leung Yuk Mei on July, 31 in Hong Kong. She is a graduate of the New Asia College in that city, and Mr. Thayer, a Yale graduate, taught there for two years under the Yale-in-China program.
STANTON, Del., July 20 (UPI)--The daily double at Delaware Park returned $3,211.40 for $2 today, the third highest of the year at an American track.
MOSCOW, July 20--The Soviet Union has launched a 300-passenger hydrofoil ship as part of an experimental shipbuilding program.
MOSCOW, July 20--A Soviet midyear economic report made public today disclosed a quickened rate of industrial growth and confirmed an expected lag in meat and butter production.
KEEPING up with the Joneses may be all right for most people, but at one California home it is imperative to stay several years ahead of them.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 20--A bequest of $500,000 has been left to Mercy Hospital of Rockville Centre, L.I., in the will of Julia M. Loft, widow of a candy manufacturer. The money will be used for a new wing.
WASHINGTON, July 20-- President Kennedy announced today a major reshuffling of the military high command, with a new chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and a new United States commander in Europe.

Owners of turtles suffering from softening shells, dogs that can't seem to make themselves comfortable on the family couch and tropical fish that dote only on fresh shrimp can take heart.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- Gen. Maxwell Davenport Taylor, who will become the new chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has had a brilliant military career and has long been regarded as one of the best minds in the Army.
YONKERS, July 20--Su Mac Lad, who needs merely to finish fifth to regain the honor of being the leading money-winning trotter in history, will have that opportunity tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway.

Activity in the bond market yesterday stemmed largely from a willingness of corporate bond houses to increase inventories. As a consequence, bids for representative issues of prime corporate debt investments rose in the over-the-counter market by to 3/8 of a point.

PELHAM MANOR, July 20 --Mrs. Carl T. Chadsey Jr. of Round Hill today won the Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship by defeating Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester Country Club on the thirty-seventh hole at the Pelham Country Club.

In the chapel of the Marble Collegiate Church last evening, Miss Alexandra Dracos, daughter of Mr. and Mrs., Harry M. Dracos of Darien, Conn., became the bride of Richard Horace Penney. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace F. Penney of Greenwich, Conn.
PARIS. July 20--The United States has nominated Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to succeed Gen. Lauris Norstad as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe.

The report on the progress and problems of the city's junior high schools is an honest document. Unfortunately, however, it fails to ask some basic questions. It is honest in noting that improvements in teachers' working conditions and in the academic program have been limited by insufficient funds and resulting shortages of qualified teachers.
Cotton futures were unchanged to 70 cents a bale up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Trading was the lightest in months.
The United States Court of Appeals yesterday upheld sentences for contempt of court imposed by a Federal judge on convicted narcotics conspirators for outbursts during their trial last spring.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)--The backyard swimming pool may be a sign of affluence, but it can also be a potential danger area, according to the American Medical Association.
LONDON, July 20--The drawings and paintings left in the studio of Augustus John, who died last October at the age of 83, were sold for 99,540 $278,712) at Christie's today.
The United Funds reported yesterday declines in total net assets for its four funds during the first half of 1962.
MONTPELIER, Vt., July 20 (AP)--The full bench of the Vermont Supreme Court has ruled that the present apportionment of the state Senate is unconstitutional.

Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said last night he was hopeful that an extradition treaty with Brazil would be worked out "within the next few months" and that Edward M. Gilbert could be brought back to this country to face trial no matter how long he stays in Brazil.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla.-- New York State contri buted 13 per cent of Florida's 1961 winter visitors and 8 per cent of its summer visitors, leading all other states in the country except Alabama and Georgia, according to a study made by the Florida Development Commission.

THE all-steel Nikor film developing tanks, for many years standard equipment in professional and many amateur darkrooms, have been redesigned. Normally, these daylight-filling tanks must be tilted slightly when pouring solutions through the light-tight cover.
STOCKHOLM, July 21--The "stagnant" United States economy needs a drastic remedy that goes far beyond tax cuts, according to Dr.Gunnar Myrdal, the Swedish economist and sociologist.

YONKERS, July 21--Air Record upset Su Mac Lad with a spectacular front-trotting mile at Yonkers Raceway tonight. In front from the outset, the 6year-old mare spoiled Su Mac Lad's return to the local harness-racing scene with a neck victory over the 1961 champion.

LOS ANGELES, July 21-- First in population since the War of 1812, New York State will be surpassed by California this year after a sesquicentennial of leadership. Governor Brown's demographers estimate that some time in mid-November California will pass New York at the 17,300,000 mark.

GRENOBLE, France--Sleek autoroutes have their use in the swift world of travel these days. Yet nothing coming off the highway engineer's drawingboard parallels the memory-jogging grandeur of a trip, along a certain narrow road winding through the French Alps. From the Riviera up to this university city and diversified resort center in southeastern France, history follows a scenic route, leaving road-markers for today's travelers.

WASHINGTON, July 21--The engagement of Miss Louise Melissa Cahill, daughter of Mrs. James A. Cahill and the late Dr. Cahill, to Warwick Montgomery Carter has been announced by Mrs. Cahill. Mr. Carter is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Newman Carter Jr. of Chadds Ford, Pa.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 21-- California talks casually in terms of billions as it figures ways of financing the spectacular growth of the state and its subdivisions.

VENICE, Italy--After their massed demonstration early this month against motorboat com petition, during which 200 gondolas blocked the Grand Canal, smoldering gondoliers here have started doing business at their old stands again.

VANCOUVER, B. C., July 18 --The last link in the transCanada highway will be open to the public July 30, and Canadians will at last be able to drive across their own country in comfort. The barriers will be taken down at the western end of the ninety-two mile Rogers Pass route through the Rockies, which cuts 100 miles off the route from the Pacific to prairie cities.

PITTSBURGH, July 21--The United Steelworkers Union has joined with Indiana University to estebliah the first labor college with full academic standing in America. The project is scheduled to begin in September, 1963.

BANGOR, Me.--Morse Bridge, the last covered bridge here and the longest one in the state of Maine, lies disassembled in an empty lot, awaiting disposal or rehabilitation. The 220-footlong bridge, which was built in 1884 to carry wagons and horses across the Kenduskeag River, was recently pronounced unsuitable to carry today's heavy trucks and ever increasing car traffic, and was replaced by a more sturdy concrete and steel structure.
VISALIA, Calif., July 21-- The Quakers are getting Ford Foundation help in an experimental program of self help for migratory farm workers.

RENO, Nev., July 17--Marriage seems to be a much bigger business in Reno than divoroe ever was. Last year 22,256 couples were wed here and 3,893 marriages were dissolved.

Three groups of steamship companies in the same cargo trades have announced a change of address effective today. They are the India, Pakistan, Ceylon and Burma Outward Freight Conference, the Persian Gulf Outward Freight Conference and the South and East Africa Rate Agreement No. 8054. The three groups have moved from 26 Beaver Street to Room 368, 11. Broadway, New York 4.
GENEVA, July 22 Delegates to the seventeen-nation disarmament conference voiced little reaction today to the Soviet Union's announcement of its intention to conduct another round of nuclear tests.

Swinging feet, swinging truncheons and swinging fists and umbrellas were in order yesterday at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, as a riot by fans and players marred the International Soccer League double-header.
OPENING play for Black is quite partisan these days to the King's Indian Defense. The general idea for Black is to explode the position along the king bishop file in his favor.
Invitations are being issued this week for two benefits for the Manhattanville Community Centers.
OYSTER, BAY, L.I., July 22 Peter J. Barrett of Madison, Wis., the United States entry in the Finn Class at the 1960 Olympics, won the first North American single-handed sailing championship today.

TEANECK, N.J., July 22 Dr. Isaac N. Gatto, a gynecologist and obstetrician here, died yesterday at Polyclinic Hospital in New York, where he had been an attending physician and a professor. He was 59 years old.
Msgr. Thomas A. Donnellan celebrated his last mass as a member of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday and was paid homage in the sermon by Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly.
RYE, N.Y., July 22 The American Yacht Club cruise, a six-day voyage being held for the thirty-first time, started at noon today with the traditional overnight race.
B'nai B'rih, the 118-year-old Jewish service organization, announced yesterday that it would open a regional district in Australia and New Zealand next month.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 22 Preparations were under way today for a Security Council meeting, probably within a few days, on the continued deadlock between the Congo Government and secessionist Katanga Province.

The Christian concept of the universe is more realistic than the Marxist or the scientific because it sets true value on human suffering, a German Bishop who once faced a Nazi death sentence said here yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, July 22 The steel recovery seemed to be gathering strength last week. The order rates of most mills indicated that steel shipments would rise in August at least as much as they will have dropped in July.
WASHINGTON, July 22 The staff union within the International Ladies Garment Workers Union has won its long fight for certification by the National Labor Relations Board.

ALGIERS, Monday, July 23 Ministers of the Provisional Government appeared early today to have been entirely unprepared for the formation of a regime last night in Tlemcen by a group headed by Vice Premier Mohammed Ben Bella.
HANOVER, N.J., July 22 Uncle Max and Cameo, from Donald Shapiro's Glen Head (L.I.) stables, finished first and second in the open jumper division of the three-day Hanover Farm horse show today.
