TLEMCEN, Algeria, July 22 Dissenting Algerian leaders headed by Vice Premier Mohammed Ben Bella and supported by the army proclaimed here tonight that they were supplanting the Provisional Government.

SASKATOON, Sask., July 22 The deadlock between the Socialist Government and the doctors of this province entered its fourth week today. Last night the dispute appeared to be on the verge of settlement, but new difficulties arose, at the last minute.
PALO ALTO, Calif., July 22 In addition to providing an opportunity for the muscular flowering of Soviet-American amity, the two-day track meet here will make a lot of money.

CAIRO, July 22 President Gamal Abdel Nasser assured 300,000 cheering Egyptians today that the United Arab Republic had gained vast economic and military strength in the ten years since the Egyptian revolution that ousted King Farouk.
HYANNIS PORT, July 22 (AP) With President Kennedy looking on, Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr., the astronaut, and Mrs. Jacqueline Kennedy water skied today.

IN 1603, when James VI of Scotland became James I of England, the plague was raging in London. More than 30,000 people died, one-fifth of the city's population. Twenty-two years later when James died at the age of 58 he was an old man, ravaged by disease and exhausted by self-indulgence.
The International Air Transport Association sent to Governments and manufacturers a guide on the development of a supersonic commercial transport airplane.
GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 22 (AP) The Wimbledon champion, Rod Laver of Australia, beat Neale Fraser of Australia in the men's singles final of the Swiss tennis championships today, 6-4, 6-4, 8-6.

LOS ANGELES, July 22 (AP) The Cleveland Indians, powered by homers by Willie Kirkland and Jerry Kindall, broke their longest losing streak in more than fifteen years by defeating Los Angeles, 7 3, today.

NEW DELHI, India, July 22 India protested today to Communist China against what the Indian Government charged was a provocative attack yesterday on an Indian border patrol in Ladakh, in eastern Kashmir.

LIMA, Peru, July 22 The police broke up demonstrations today by women dressed in mourning "for the death of Peruvian democracy" and in protest against the military junta that took over the Government five days ago.
Gordon Hake,an artist, illustrator and cartoonist, died Saturday at his home, 130 East Ninety-fourth Street. He was 63 years old.
GENEVA, July 22 A good rally on Friday cut earlier losses on the Swiss stock markets, but all domestic sectors were off for the week. The retreats, however, were mostly narrow.

A bold program for revitalizing the American economy has been advanced by one of the world's most eminent economists, Dr. Gunnar Myrdal of Sweden. What Dr. Myrdal urges is nothing less than a peacetime mobilization of all this country's vast energies to break out of the rut of economic stagnation that has held us captive for a decade. He envisions the attainment of a new
A funny thing happened to the New York Yankees on their way to the American League pennant yesterday. They lost a double-header to the Washington Senators.
WASHINGTON, July 22 The Senate Finance Committee is expected to report out on Friday a badly mauled version of the Administration's tax-revision bill.
LONDON, July 22 English cloths are more "occasion" than fashion, and London's leading couturiers try to dress women for the life they lead, not to set world fashion trends.

WASHINGTON, July 22 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress in the week ended yesterday.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 22 The first United States attempt to launch a spacecraft to explore the planet Venus ended in failure nearly 100 miles above the Atlantic Ocean today. The
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 22 A plan to include both Nationalist and Communist China in the United Nations was urged in a report published today by the Commission to Study the Organization of Peace.

VALHALLA, N.Y., July 22-- Visitors examined Westchester County's proposed park acquisitions today and approved of what they saw. Unlike some Westchester parks, the new ones would be open to all persons regardless of where they lived.

Gabriel Beaumont, a chef who had held notable positions on both sides of the Atlantic, died in Zurich, Switzerland, on July 15. He and his wife, Aurelie, had been visiting relatives and friends in Europe. He was 80 years old, and lived at 360 First Avenue.
LOS ANGELES, July 23 United Automobile Workers locals at two California aerospace plants voted today to comply with President Kennedy's request to postpone a threatened strike for sixty days.
DOVER, N.J., July 22 Today was Christmas in July at the First Memorial Presbyterian Church here.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 21 Although the justices of the International Court of Justice upheld the obligation of members of the United Nations to pay for the organization's peace-keeping operations by a 9-to-5 vote, there was dissent within the majority opinion.

The income of America's colleges and universities will be more than doubled in the next decade, an economist predicted in a study published yesterday.
A thousand persons stood in in brilliant sunshine and humid shade on Seventy-second Street yesterday for two and a half hours to hear twenty-one speakers call for justice for hospital workers.

OSSINING, N.Y., July 22 Thirty members of the 1962 United States Wheelchair Sports Team participated in a final stateside workout this afternoon at The 52 Association's outdoor recreation center for the wounded.

A 16-year-old youth was arrested yesterday in the fatal shooting of another teen-ager during a gang fight Saturday night in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.
TEL AVIV, July 22 The Cabinet today ordered a ministerial inquiry into the circumstances of Dr. Robert A. Soblen's expulsion from Israel on July 1.

The Rev. Dr. Stuart Hamilton Merriam yesterday delivered his first formal Sunday morning sermon since he was removed on May 7 from the pulpit of the Broadway Presbyterian Church. But he spoke as a guest minister in another sanctuary.
A new state program of medical care for the aged should a broad Federal program not be adopted was proposed yesterday by Howard J: Samuels, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

YONKERS, July 22-Oscar Moore, a 24-year-old office worker, won the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union's 15kilometer run today and paced the New York Pioneer Club to the team title, Raid fell throughout host of the race, which drew a field of sixty-two.
Eastern Air Lines will begin limited service today for the first time since June 22, when the Flight Engineers International Association began a strike against it.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 22 Some of the most exciting dancing our country has to offer was seen at the American Dance Festival last night, when the Alvin Ailey Dance Theatre, sharing the program with Paul Draper, appeared at Connecticut College's Palmer Auditorium.

WESTON, Vt., July 20 To enter the lovely common of the village of Weston is to encounter a scene reminiscent of wartime devastation. The Weston Playhouse, a Vermont landmark with its graceful facade and six white Doric columns, lies in charred ruins from a fire that wiped out the cultural center operated by the community of 590 persons.
LONDON, July 22 Depressed conditions hit the London stock market last week in the wake of Prime Minister Macmillan's Government reorganization.

For a few hours on Saturday night the sky over Lewisohn Stadium might have been sheltering early nineteenth-century Rome, as the melodramatic passions of Puccini's and Sardou's "Tosca" boiled on stage.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation called upon the public yesterday to help it recover securities still missing in the theft of more than $1,300,000 from the Wall Street vault of Bache Co.

Lieut. General David W. Traub, who is retiring this month as Controller of the Army, has been appointed general manager of the State University Construction Fund.

A Common Market commission once asked France to drop a new tax rule that gave preference to its own manufactured goods over those of other nationS in the European Economic Community. France agreed to do so. This may have been the first time the European group exercised a supra-national jurisdiction over tax matters.

The three major television networks did a "run-through" yesterday of their jointly produced program, to be transmitted live to Europe today at about 3 P.M., Eastern daylight time. The Europeans will send a program here about 6 P.M. in the first formal exchange of live programing across the Atlantic.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 22 (UPI) Jackie Brandt and Jim Gentile led the Baltimore Orioles to an 8 6 victory over the Minnesota Twins today. The defeat ended a six-game win ning streak for the Twins.

North American Aviation, Inc., reported over the week-end for the nine months ended on June 30, a net income of $24,451,000, or $2.94 each on the average of 8,327,510 shares outstanding. Sales and other income amounted to $1,145,249,331.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 22 The president of the State Patrolman's Benevolent Association said today that the problem of recruiting policemen was "rapidly becoming serious."
MOSCOW, July 22 A Moldavian has been sentenced to eight years in jail on charges of speculating in gold coins.

SASKATOON, Sask., July 12 One aspect that has not been emphasized in the dispute between the doctors and the Socialist Government of this province is what the medical care plan is going to cost the tax-payer.
GENEVA, July 22 Western experts believe that the hardening Soviet stand on Berlin indicates that the Sovietbloc nations will sign a peace treaty with Communist East
The liner France sailed from Pier 88 on the Hudson River at 11 o'clock last night after being in only nineteen hours and forty minutes.
Now that the smoke has cleared from the bear market begun May 28; available statistics prove that the mutual funds were buyers on balance. This is just as they had reported earlier.
The Waterfront Commission has proopsed to the port industry a program to improve the standards of private policing along the waterfront.
NEW HAVEN, July 22 The Rockefeller Foundation Virus Laboratories will move to New Haven and share a new ninestory laboratory with the Yale Department of Epidemiology and Public Health.

"Shoot the Piano Player," a French-made comedy-drama with English subtitles, starring Charles Aznavour and directed by Francois Truffaut from his script, will have its American premiere today at the Fifth Avenue Cinema at Twelfth Street. Based on the novel "Down There" by David Goodis and produced by Pierre Braunberger for Films de la Pleiade, it is being presented here by Astor Pictures, Inc.
LONDON, July 22 A Tate Gallery guard eyed a 4-year-old boy in a large exhibition room today and said, "Go ahead: touch it."
Roosevelt Hospital disclosed yesterday that it has a new emergency psychiatric service that provides help immediately to any patient who goes to the emergency room and asks for it.

WASHINGTON, July 22 Lloyd G. Whitebrook, an adviser to Democratic candidates on advertising, radio and television aspects of their campaigns, died here last night at George Washington Hospital. He was 43 years old and lived at 85 East End Avenue, New York.
New York City's Employes Suggestion Program, which invites, evaluates and often pays for the ideas of city workers, has saved New York $5,328,213 in its first decade.
TRENTON, July 22 Rodger Ward of Speedway, Ind., drove Bob Wilke's Leader Card roadster to an easy victory today in an Indianapolis-car race cuts (from 150 to 142 miles by rain) at Trenton Speedway.

CINCINNATI, July 22 If baseball games lasted only five innings, the Mets would have swept a double-header from the Cincinnati Reds today. The New Yorkers posted 4-1 and 1-0 leads that carried midway through the first and second games, respectively.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 22 A thunder squall during the interclub sailing on Manhasset Bay today helped Steve Moore, in Jerky Bird, cross the finish line fifty minutes in front of his nearest competitor in the Blue Jay Class.

Panama is the name of a small country that usually evokes among most Norte Americanos the image of a big hat or a Big Ditch. But in the last decade Panama has come to mean for many Latin Americans a small country with a big cattle business.

Three changes in the top echelon of Wellington Management Company were announced over the week end. Walter L. Morgan was named chairman; Joseph E. Welch was elected president and chief executive officer, and John C. Bogie, administrative vice president.
The emergency shipment from here of a scarce drug through the help of amateur radio operators was credited yesterday with saving the life of a man who was near death in Brazil.

A poll taken for the White House by a national advertising agency indicates that adult Americans overwhelmingly admire President Kennedy's handling of his news conference and regard them as "worth while."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 22 If the Yankees were to disband overnight, the disturbance in major league baseball would approximate what has happened in Hollywood since the Government filed a civil antitrust suit against the Music Corporation of America on July 13.

WASHINGTON, July 22 Like his predecessors, Charles E. Bohlen and Llewellyn E. Thompson, Foy Kohler has been chosen Ambassador to Moscow partly because of his skill in the arcane modern science of "Kremlinology."

NORRISTOWN, Pa., July 22 (AP) W. Curtis Martens, a 49year-old racer from Newport News, Va., was seriously injured today when his hydroplane was upset at 130 miles an hour and disintegrated during the Port Indian Civic and Boat. ing Club Association regatta.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 22 (AP) Mailers and typographers, two of the five unions on strike against the Minneapolis Star and Tribune, voted at membership meetings today to approve new contract offers.
ALBANY, July 22 Governor Rockefeller announced today the appointment of Joseph Kaitz of Cedarhurst, L.I., as the New York State member of the Waterfront Commission.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., July 22 Tropicstar Poodanne Ingenue, a white miniature poodle owned by Florence Michelson of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was judged best in show today in the thirteenth annual Holyoke Kennel Club dog show and obedience trial.

WHEN Mrs. Richard Williams paid a two-day visit to New York last week, she dashed around town looking for, among other things, copper casseroles and cassia buds. The copper casseroles were needed because Mrs. Williams "never seems to cook in anything but copper these days." The cassia buds were required for pickling peaches because "they add a wonderfully subtle cinnamon flavor."

Miss Susan Kohn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Blondheim Kohn of 535 East Eightysixth Street, became the bride of Raoul Ronson yesterday. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Mirko Ruzicka of 668 Riverside Drive.

LONDON, July 22 Lord Robins, president of the British South Africa Company, a large complex of rail and mining interests in South Africa, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home herb, He was 77 years old.
The Rev. Dr. Rudolph Boeker urged closer ties between continents in his sermon yesterday at the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street.
MOSCOW, July 22 The largest international congress in the history of cancer research was formally opened today at a ceremony in the Kremlin Palace of Congresses.

IT is a strange foursome that will be inducted into baseball's Hall of Fame at Cooperstown today. Temperamentally, characteristically and in the skills that gave them national distinction, they have nothing in common. Yet here, all on the one day, they meet to receive baseball's highest award.
The unanimous declaration by the thirty-one neutralist nations that met in Cairo to discuss problems of economic development is happily free of any anti-Western propaganda.

ASPEN, Colo., July 22 Henri Sauguet is a con temporary French composer who is not very well known in America. He was born in 1901 and has been, on the whole, a member of the conservative wing.

MANILA, July 22 (UPI) Floods caused by Typhoon Kate inundated wide areas of fourteen provinces on the main Philippine island of Luzon today, menacing thousands of homeless persons.
NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa., July 22 Gary Player of Johannesburg, South Africa, today became the first non-resident of this country to win the Professional Golfers Association championship.

Local markets are currently displaying bumper crops of several varieties of melons at moderate prices. Served alone or with other fruits or fruit ices, melons make excellent appetizers and desserts with no work.
Mrs. Janos Hajdok, a refugee who fled Hungary following the unsuccessful anti-Soviet revolt of 1956, became an American citizen yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 23 An underground atomic explosion set off in the Sahara by France May 1 was clearly detected by seismic instruments in the United States, more than 5,000 miles away, Defense officials disclosed today.
Peak-period traffic moved about 40 per cent faster yesterday on Fifty-fifth and Fiftysixth Streets as a new plan to ease crosstown snarls went into effect.

Stock prices dipped slightly yesterday in quiet trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The impression in Wall Street was that traders were waiting to see if the President would say anything indicating a quick tax cut at his afternoon press conference. He didn't.

Ten years ago, when King Farouk of Egypt was ousted, the power behind the coup was a 34-year old Lieutenant Colonel named Gamal Abdel Nasser. Yesterday this young officer (who is about the same age as our President Kennedy) reviewed a formidable display of armed forces, and he is, beyond question, the outstanding figure in the Arab world.
The Soviet Union appears to have been outproducing the United States in steel during recent weeks thus at least temporarily achieving one of Premier Khrushchev's fondest dreams.
BERLIN, July 23 The Russians harassed Allied flights in the Berlin air approaches again today.
LIVERPOOL, England, July 23 In England, the fox is only one jump ahead of the hounds. And the hunter, it seems, is only one jump ahead of the law.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehinan, who returned from Europe yesterday, said he would campaign "with all my heart" for Justice Bernard Botein if the Democratic party nominated him for Governor.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) President Kennedy asked Congress today for $225, 000 to tighten export controls to "reduce clandestine Cuban efforts to procure items from the United States through a third country."
The password among Shubert Alley denizens these days is musical comedy.
The Nash Engineering Company, manufacturer of pumps, has leased tower space in the Pan Am Building at 200 Park Avenue adjoining Grand Central Terminal.
DIJON, France, July 23 Thirty-six persons were killed today when the crack ParisMarseilles express train was derailed near here, the French Railways announced tonight.
MOSCOW, July 23 (Reuters) The Soviet Union favors a direct telephone link between the White House and the Kremlin, informed Soviet sources said here today.
NEWARK, July 23 Three hundred carpenters walked off therir jobs today after contract negotiations broke down last Thrusday.
The Puget Sound Pulp and Timber Company plans to expand its Eastern operations by purchasing the Gould Paper Company, Lyons Falls, N.Y., for about $5,300,000.

The seven-story building at 1350 Madison Avenue, southwest corner of Ninety fifth Street, has been purchased by Eugene Hollander and his associates, Louis Engel Co. Hanfield, Callen, Ruland Benjamin, Inc., were the brokers.

CAIRO, July 23 The United Arab Republic showed off its new military strength today in a three-hour parade celebrating the tenth anniversary of the Egyptian revolution Military observers deemed the display the most impressive since the revolution.
PARIS, July 23 Perhaps as many as 100,000,000 European viewers watched the television broadcast from the United States.

A booklet of "Revised and Clarified Rules" governing the conduct of taxicab drivers was issued yesterday by the Police Department to the 39,000 taxi drivers in the city.

JERSEY CITY, July 23 Mayor Thomas Gangemi today notified Thomas Finn, administrator of the Jersey City Medical Center, that his employment would end Sept. 15. The Mayor said he was "not happy with conditions" at the hospital.

Directors of National Airlines, Inc., yesterday elected Dudley Swim to the new office of chairman of the executive committee. It also added G. Robert Truex Jr. to this committee, thereby increasing its membership to five from three.
BUENOS AIRES, July 23 Latin-American steel production will reach 8,000,000 tons a year by 1966, according to a prediction at the recent LatinAmerican Steel Conference here.
Cocoa futures rose 25 to 30 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) at the opening of trading on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday but closed with only modest gains as early buyers became sellers.
A look at the new styles in luggage indicated yesterday that travel gear is becoming more and more colorful.
LONDON, July 23 The program beamed from America to Europe today by way of the Telstar satellite came through almost perfectly on British sets.
ALGIERS, July 23 The Government of Premier Benyouseff Ben Khedda made a concession tonight that seemed certain to settle the Algerian crisis.

BELLPORT, L.I., July 23 The Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual Race Week championships opened under sullen skies today but John Zimmerman's committee considered it fortunate that the event got under way.
A change in control of the Irving Air Chute Company, Inc., a leading manufacturer of parachutes based in Lexington, Ky., is in the offing after a long and at times bitter proxy fight.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) Half of the grain futures on the Board of Trade fell to their lowest levels of the season today under pressure of heavy selling.

Radio Station WMCA pressed in Federal Court here yesterday to have the state's legislative apportionment declared unconstitutional in advance of the Nov. 6 election.

William Koff has been named vice president in charge of food and beverages for the hotels of International Airport Hotel System, Inc. He had held a similar position at the Forum of the Twelve Caesars and at the Fontainebleau Hotel.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 23 President Tito said today that the new retreat from liberalism in Yugoslavia would affect cultural life as well as politics.
Supermarkets, beset by the highly competitive tradingstamp war now in progress, are being armed with a new weapon with which to arouse consumer interest.

Emile (The Cat) Francis, a little man with a voice and personality that carries weight, is regarded as the No. 1 candidate to coach the New York Rangers of the National Hockey League next winter.
BONN, Germany, July 23 From the North Sea to the Alps, West German television viewers watched the dawn of a new era in intercontinental communication today.
DETROIT, July, 23 (AP) Before the auto makers shut down for changeover to the 1963 models, eleven makes are expected to pass the 100,000 mark this calendar year.
Anthony Anastasia, the Brooklyn dock leader, challenged the leadership of the International Longshoremen's Association again yesterday.
CAIRO, Ill., July 21 Mack's Barbeque in this city at the southern tip of Illinois gets a good deal of transient trade because it is a modern restaurant on the main thoroughfare to town.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 23--The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors agreed today to a temporary plan to pay for the maintenance of the Long Island Rail Road's fifty-four stations in the county.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 23 (AP) Gov. John Patterson signed today a bill providing for a special primary election as a result of a federal court order reapportioning the Alabama legislature.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 23 (AP) A South Vietnamese force transported by United States Army helicopters landed at a suspected Communist guerrilla concentration point twelve miles south of Saigon today. No guerrillas were found and the troops returned to base.
WASHINGTON, July 23 Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg proposed a formula today to end the Eastern Air Lines strike, but the company turned him down.

MOSCOW, July 23 Soviet specialists in cancer have established links between geographic, climatic and other living conditions and the frequency of some cancers, according to a paper presented today at the International Cancer Congress.

Jan Mitchell, dispenser of Gemutlichkeit at Luchow's Restaurant and eclectic cuisine at Longchamps, will purvey Gallic charm with his latest acquisition Charles French Restaurant in Greenwich Village.
WASHINGTON, July 23 President Kennedy today described the continued secession of Katanga Province from the Congo as "very, very serious."
Cotton futures were unchanged to 25 cents a bale up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 23 After two thunderstorms had interrupted play, Jacky Cupit won the pro-celebrity charity golf tournament at the Huntington Crescent Club today with a five-under-par 65.
THE Brooklyn Championships in bridge ended Sun day night with a tie in the two-session team contest.
Rear Admiral R.K. James, chief of the bureau of ships, disclosed yesterday that the Navy had begun a work-study program aimed at improving the design of Navy Vessels.
State Senator Harry Kraf urged yesterday that the Board of Estimate withold approval of the proposed sale and lease of city lands to Westchester County for parks.

GENEVA, July 23 In a casual twenty-five-minute ceremony, the representatives of fourteen countries signed agreements today guaranteeing the neutrality and independence of Laos.

MANILA, July 23 President Diosdado Macapagal of the Philippines said today that President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan was "lukewarm" to the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization "due to despair over the inefficacy of the United States."

THE first live program from Europe will rank as one of the magnificent accomplishments in television history. A breathtaking scientific wonder was not merely demonstrated; it received an inspired use that opened a viewer's imagination to the excitement and enrichment that can lie ahead.

Following is the transcript of President Kennedy's news con ference yesterday afternoon in Washington as recorded by The New York Times:

Bond prices were firm in inactive trading yesterday. Among United States Government securities, most of the business was transacted in the short-term area. The Treasury's

Directors of the Scovill Manufacturing Company yesterday increased the company's quarterly common-stock dividend to 30 cents a share from the 25 cents paid previously. The Concern reported that first-half earnings were nearly double those of the 1961 period.

WHITESBOG, N.J., July 23 Susan Jo Shill bent over six Tittle children squatting on the splintery floor of a brownshingled salt-box structure this morning. She was trying to teach the somewhat bewildered youngsters, from 1 to 4 years old, to model with clay.
LONDON, July 23 The government is considering setting up an authority to su pervise the marketing and prescription of new drugs, Parliament was told today.

HONOLULU, July 23 A Canadian Pacific airliner, returning for an emergency landing with one engine dead, veered from the runway last night and crashed in flames, killing twenty-seven of the forty persons aboard.
Brocade and double knit wool dresses were heavily ordered last week, resident buying offices here reported. Fur-trimmed coats for fall and winter were also in demand.

The report of the Commercial Solvents Corporation disclosed yesterday that second-quarter consolidated net earnings were $2,082,051, equal to 71 cents a share. In the similar three months last year, $1,608,915, or 55 cents a share, was earned.
MONTAUK, L.I., July 23 It's not difficult to find a connection between certain recent convulsions in the stock market with its subsequent falling economic barometer and the charter-boat business.
LONDON, July 23 Most industrial shares declined on the stock market today. Selling was not heavy.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 23 Intent on improving their records after suffering recent upsets, Whitney Reed, the No. 1 ranking U.S. player from Alameda, Calif., and Margaret
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 23 The Federal Government and Music Corporation of America filed a stipulation today whereby M.C.A. agreed to divest itself of its talent agencies throughout the world.
The drought that has plagued the Northeast came to an end in much of the East yesterday, the New York Weather Bureau reported last night. However, It said it was still too early

GENEVA, July 23 Communist China's Foreign Minister, Marshal Chen Yi, who seldom visits the Western world, found himself a center of attention at a diplomatic reception here tonight to celebrate the signing of accords on Laotian neutrality.
WASHINGTON, July 23 President Kennedy said today that there were some "very good" as well as well as some disappointing signs in the American economy.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 23 Burton James Lee Jr., a vice president of the First National City Bank in New York, died yesterday of a heart attack while playing tennis at the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club. He was 54 years old and lived on Harbor Road here.

THE United States is getting briskly along toward a population of 200,000,000 persons. And astonishing numbers of them seem to serve sporadically as unpaid, voulunteer Secretaries of State or, should I say, unelected Presidents at large.
LIMA, Peru, July 23 A general strike called by the Apra party against Peru's military junta today was a failure.

NEW DELHI, India, July 23 Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today that the situation in the Ladakh region of Kashmir had become "serious" following Chinese Communist shooting at Indian patrols Saturday at two places.

VIENTIANE, Laos, July 23 (AP) A Right-wing official accused representatives of the pro-Communist Pathet Laos today of having blocked an onthe-spot investigation of an outbreak of fighting in southern Laos.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) An unsuccessful attempt to sell the United States Government $50,000,000 worth of rare platinum in 1951 was detailed for Senate investigators today.

ALBANY, Ga., July 23 Chief Judge Elbert P. Tuttle of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit agreed today to review the legality of a restraining order barring Negro demonstrations here.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 23 (UPI) Rex C. Ellsworth's Prove It defeated Windy Sands by a nose today in taking the $88,000 Sunset Handicap at Hollywood Park.

LAGOS, Nigeria, July 23 The Nigerian Federal Government launched today a longawaited investigation of corruption that could result in a major reshaping of this country's delicate balance of political powers.

YONKERS, July 23 Mighty Tide, a two-time winner from Henry T. Adios in out-of-town races this season, gained the rail in this morning's draw for post positions for Thursday night's $32,850 Empire Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

RIVER FOREST, Ill., July 23 Chuck McKinley won the United States clay court tennis championship today and left this evening for the Davis Cup zone matches in Mexico.
The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth largest steel producer, reported yesterday a sharp drop in earnings for the second quarter of this year.
Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon was asked yesterday to investigate the possibility that one of the departments under his control had approved "speculative contracts."

WASHINGTON, July 24 The Department of Agriculture has begun an investigation of leaking cans of salad oil and shortening stored in warehouses in the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area. Tne products were purchased by the Government for distribution abroad by private relief agencies.

When Stephen P. Kennedy moved out of his office at Police Headquarters on the morning of Feb. 23, 1961, after a controversial career of five and a half years as Police Commissioner, he left a "Good Luck" note and a bottle of aspirin for Michael J. Murphy, his successor.

Counsel for two leading civic organizations will confer with State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz this morning in an effort to convince him that Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh is not entitled to retire on either a state or city pension.

GENEVA, July 24 Two truisms help stall the drawn-out disarmament and nuclear negotiations here. The first is that nations always show themselves less devoted to peace than to what might be called peace-plus. The second is that while fear drives men to negotiate, it can also avert agreement.
The Wembley Farm's Outgiving, a 6-year-old horse of modest pretensions, took on Fred Hooper's Crozier, a substantial money-winner, in the main race at Aqueduct yesterday.
BUENOS AIRES, July 24 (AP) President Jos Maria Guido, closely supervised by the military, banned Communists "and other totalitarian parties" tonight from taking part in elections.

American Can Company reported yesterday second-quarter net income of $13,871,000, equal after preferred dividend requirements, to 83 cents a share. This compared with $13,756,000 and 83 cents in the 1961 period. There were 15,822,607 shares outstanding in the 1962 quarter and 15,760,843 last year.

VIENTIANE, Laos, July 24 Leonard Unger, United States Ambassador to Laos, called today on Prince Souphanouvong, Acting Premier and Left-Wing leader, to renew discussions on the release of United States and Filipino prisoners captured by neutralists and pro-Communists during the two years of the Laotian civil war.

ELISABETHVILLE, The Congo, July 21 The giant smokestack of the Lubumbashi Smelting Plant of the Union Mini re du Haut-Katanga towers above this city like an enormous political and economic weather vane.

The city's Department of Air Pollution Control declared yesterday that the public's former "careless attitude toward control of air pollution is being replaced by a more intelligent understanding of the problem and what can be done about it."

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 24 Frederick M. Hibberd, with his thirty-eight foot yawl, Caprice, won in Division I and Franklin J. Dickman's thirtyone-foot sloop, Puritan, took the second-division laurels today as the fleet on the thirty-first annual American Yacht Club cruise raced from Fishers Island across Block Island Sound to this island.

A STARTING field includevirtually all of America's leading sports car drivers and a half-dozen or more of Europe's finest seems assured for the first Grand Prix of Puerto Rico, to be run on a course just outside Caguas in November. David Ash, the race organizer,...
Merger of the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company and the American Chicle Company was proposed yesterday by directors of both companies. Their combined assets would exceed $153,000,000.
Dr. Ralph Houk's antidote for double defeat (Whitey Ford plus second-division opposition equals victory) made the Stadium a lush rehabilitation center for the Yankees last night.
The Housing and Redevelopment Board announced yesterday that it would provide tax and mortgage aid to a housing development in Queens that was originally planned for private financing.
WASHINGTON, July 24 Irving Ben Cooper fought today for Senate confirmation of his controversial appointment as a Federal judge.

BEFORE leaving on a holiday, it might be wise to take a few precautions to help, insure the safety of the home during the family's absence. Here is a checklist of prevacation tasks suggested by Dr. Robert F. Prindle, director of the Lysol Home Health Information Bureau:

GREENWICH, Conn., July 24 Mrs. Jane Bagley Long and Orin Lehman, both of New York, were married here yesterday in the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Gilbert Verney. Mr. Lehman is the son of Mrs. Evelyn Schiffer Lehman of New York and the late Allan S. Lehman.

ST. LOUIS, July 24 (UPI) Ernie Broglio held the Los Angeles Dodgers to four hits tonight but needed a perfect relay from Julian Javier on Frank Howard's double in the ninth inning to cut down the potential tying run and give the St. Louis Cardinals a 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
MOSCOW, July 24 Soviet nuclear tests are to be resumed in the Arctic proving grounds starting Aug. 5, foreign observers concluded on the basis of an announcement here today.
BONN, Germany, July 24 Willy H, Schlieker, one of West Germany's top industrialists, who built himself a business empire in the last fifteen years, moved today to avoid bankruptcy.
HOUSTON, July 24 (AP) Willie Mays hit two home runs and scored a third run after he was hit by a pitched ball as the San Francisco Giants scored a 3-1 victory over the Houston Colts tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) Democratic Congressional leaders scoffed today at Republican gibes about lack of progress on President Kennedy's legislative program. They promised to stay in session to enact as much of it as possible.

The so-called Mr. X, who had been sought as a key figure in a $1,300,000 stock theft from Bache Co., surrendered yesterday afternoon at the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan. His name was given as Alan Jack Pomeranz, a 33year-old part-time interior decorator.
Anthony Anastasia, head of 15,000 longshoremen in Brooklyn, appealed to Mayor Wagner yesterday to help find jobs for 300 dockworkers.
For the first time in years, there will be a major contest for membership on the board of governors of the American Stock Exchange. Five regular members of the...

WASHINGTON, July 24 The crisis in the relations between President Kennedy and the Congress is more serious than either side has been willing to admit in public. It is not a personal or even partisan crisis so much as it is an institutional crisis, and it is not likely to vanish merely by adding a few more Democrats to the already sizable Democratic majority.
LIMA, Peru July 24 Ambassador James Isaac Loeb is the prime exponent of the New Frontier among United States diplomats in Latin America.

IN a recent, much regretted lapse of sanity, this writer printed a column on the sport of shooting flying insects on the wing. The initial response was from, of all places, Sparse Grey Hackle, who proposed a magnificently devious scheme through Which I would become disgustingly wealthy by promoting the proposition.

Arnold H. Vollmer Associates, consulting engineers, have leased a floor at 2 West Fortyfifth Street and will move from 25 West Forty-fifth Street in September. The new quarters will be laid out from plans by Daniel Chait. The floor was leased through Melvin D. Wolf, vice presiednt of Julien J. Studley, Inc., broker. The George Comfort Company is the agent for the building.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) Early Wynn of the Chicago White Sox held the Washington Senators to five singles tonight and beat them, 6 0, for the 297th of his American League career. At 42, Wynn is the oldest active player in the major leagues.

Three new features, including a double bill, will open here today. "Hemingway's Adventures of a Young Man," a Twentieth Century-Fox compilation of short stories by the Nobel Prize winner, is at the Paramount Theatre, Broadway and Forty-third Street, and the Trans-Lux Fifty-second Street Theatre at Lexington Avenue.
LONDON, July 24 Henry Moose, the British sculptor, has agreed to create a centerpiece for the North Plaza Pool of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, it was announced here today.

THERE were only eight of them, an old man and an old woman, two young men and two young women, a small girl and a baby boy. They were naked and hairy and their hair was red. Thick ridges protruded over their eyes. They had no foreheads to speak of and hardly any chins. When they walked they often used the knuckles of their hands to aid locomotion.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 24 U Thant, Acting Secretary General, outlined today a program of economic pressure under which he hopes to compel Moise Tshombe, President of Katanga Province, to accept the authority of the Congolese Central Government.

WASHINGTON, July 24 The General Accounting Office charged today that Westinghouse Electric Corporation had overcharged the Navy by more than $1,000,000 on reactor components for the nuclear-powered carrier Enterprise.

A special three-judge Federal court will begin next Wednesday a review of the fairness of New York's nineteenth century formula for legislative reapportionment. The briefs filed with the court by radio station WMCA impressively document the way in which this city and other population...
CAMBRIDGE, Mass, July 24 Members of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Empolyes Union voted today to end a twenty-four-day strike against the school.
WASHINGTON, July 24 Henry Cabot Lodge, director general of the Atlantic Institute, announced today initiation of its first major international study project.

A generation ago Puerto Rico was one of the problem children of the Caribbean, although its problem was not violence or revolutionary tendencies but poverty. If the island had not been so poor, we would not have so many Puerto Ricans in the City of New York.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 24 (AP) The Rhode Island Supreme Court ruled today that the state's General Assembly had an obligation to reapportion the House of Representatives on the basis of the 1960 census.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) Organized labor and two spokesmen for business joined today in endorsing President Kennedy's liberalized trade program. But labor attached an important "if" to its support.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) Two Republican Representatives attacked testimony on the Billie Sol Estes case today given by Donald A. Russell, director of auditing for the Agriculture Department.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) President Kennedy ordered heads of Government agencies today to take immediate steps to guarantee that there would be no discrimination against women in appointments or promotions in the Government career service.

Alvin Gallen, chief attorney for the General Electric Credit Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Electric Company, died Monday in an ambulance after a short illness. He was being taken to White Plains Hospital from his home, 9 Warnke Lane, Scarsdale, N.Y. His age was 42.
WASHINGTON, July 24 The House approved the $4,672,000,000 foreign-aid authorization bill today and sent it to President Kennedy for his signature. The vote was 221 to 162.
LONDON, July 24 President Kennedy's pledge that the United States would not devalue the dollar brought a sharp decline in gold mining shares on the stock market today.
New York City borrowed $103,725,000 yesterday to finance a wide range of city improvements. The bonds were sold at an interest cost of 3.0278 per cent to a syndicate headed by Chase Manhattan Bank.

WASHINGTON, July 24 President Kennedy and President Carlos Julio Arosemena Monroy of Ecuador reaffirmed their faith in the Alliance for Progress today and pledged joint efforts to speed up that aid program for Latin America.

Where is the economy now? The Cleveland Trust Company has an answer: "June was the sixteenth month of the fifth post-World War II business upswing." It finds the "upswing" not so vigorous as preceding ones.
The newest "prestige" ship in the United States merchant fleet, the nuclear vessel Savannah, has run aground in a shoal of labor difficulties.

GENEVA, July 24 Secretary of State Dean Rusk failed today to find the "useful purpose" that President Kennedy said yesterday would keep Mr. Rusk in Geneva for further talks with the Russians on Berlin.
PASSAIC, N.J., July 24 A Federally assisted plan to revive Passaic's moribund downtown shopping district and perhaps halt the city's declining population was made public today.
Philip Schneider, a Yiddish theatrical manager here for more than fifty years, died yesterday at University Hospital at the age of 82. He lived at 170 Second Avenue.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 24 Paul C. Edwards, a retired editor and a former president of the Stanford University Board of Trustees, died of a heart attack last night at his home in near-by Los Altos Hills. He was 80 years old.
JOAN SUTHERLAND made her first popular-priced appearance in New York last night, and 20,000 persons crowded into Lewisohn Stadium to hear her.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., July 24 The expansion program of sight restoration and research of Eyes Right, Inc., will be furthered by the proceeds of the Midsummer Supper Dance at the Bridgehampton Community House on Saturday.

The property of the Old North Baptist Church at 215 West Eleventh Street, northeast corner of Waverly Place, in Greenwich Village, has been sold to an investor. The buyer, who acquired the parcel through William Alfred White, Inc., broker, plans to alter the building for residential use.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 24 William E. Eppler, one of the nation's foremost railroad financial consultants, died of cancer last evening at All Souls Hospital. He was 73 years old.

The Unisphere, the huge stainless steel orbital globe that is the symbol of the 1964-65 New York World's Fair, will be a familiar sight around the world by the time the fair closes its gates in November, 1965.
The struggle for power in Algeria seems to have ended with the triumph of the Ben Bella faction in Tlemcen. The group headed by Premier Ben Khedda and Belcacem Krim has had to accept defeat.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) A Senate committee heard opposing views today on a proposed commission to study the desirability of a department of science and technology.
LONDON, July 24-Britain's shipbuilders were told today that they had set a new low in peacetime construction and that the prospects remained discouraging.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) The Interstate Commerce Commission has refused to let Government auditors examine all its records concerning a $35,600,000-loan guarantee to the New Haven Railroad.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) Five Senators called today for a change in existing drug approval procedures. They said the American people were unwittingly being made to serve as guinea pigs for the prescription drug industry.

WASHINGTON, July 24 The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People asked Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg today to withhold Federal funds from state employment services that discriminate against Negroes.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, July 25 Pan American World Airways and the Flight Engineers International Association reached agreement early today on a formula for settling their contract dispute.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 24 (AP) Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, left for home today after having cut short a goodwill visit that left many Indonesians puzzled and some annoyed.

The Civil Aeronautics Board granted Trans World Airlines permission yesterday to carry special groups of twenty-five or more persons at fares 20 per cent lower than normal on its regular domestic flights.
Dr. Theodor Blum, a founder of the Institute of Clinical Oral Pathology, died yesterday in his home at 176 East Seventyseventh Street. He was 79 years old.

SASKATOON, Sask., July 24 The College of Physicians and Surgeons called its members back to resume normal practice today after a twentythree day boycott of the Saskatchewan socialist government's implementation of a compulsory tax-supported medical care plan.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 24 Rear Admiral Timothy J. Keleher, who had Naval commands in both World Wars, died here yesterday at the Naval Hospital. He was 77 years old.
ANY bridge player in whose breast hope has sprung eternal, even on a hopeless hand, can share vicariously in East's triumph on today's deal.
GREAT NECK, L.I., July 24 A regional planning board has been formed by nine villages and the Town of Hempstead to draw up a master urban renewal plan.
DAWSON CITY, Yukon, July 24 (AP) The cast of the musical "Foxy," the leading attraction of the first Dawson City Gold Rush Festival, was given a week's notice last night.

A fight for control of the B.S.F. Company loomed yesterday when three new directors, who last week acquired a 30 per cent stock interest in the company, submitted their resignations and stormed out of their first board meeting.

The dizzying succession of legal and extralegal modes the White House has made in its efforts to establish peace on the airlines between flight engineers and pilots over control of the third seat in jet cockpits indicates anew the desirability of stronger laws to curb emergency strikes.

MILWAUKEE, July 24 With the Mets, even the pattern of defeat can become routine. It did tonight when Del Crandall crashed R.G. Miller's first pitch in the last of the twelfth inning into the leftfield bleachers at County Stadium. The drive gave the Milwaukee Braves a 5-4 victory.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir July 24 Indian troops have reclaimed from the Chinese Communists about 3,500 square miles in Ladakh, according to senior Indian officers responsiable for the defence of the area.

WASHINGTON, July 24 Compromise legislation authorizing a $3,744,115,250 budget for the civilian space program in the current fiscal year was approved today by conferees of the Senate and House space committees.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 24 Gen. and Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower received a warm welcome on their arrival here tonight by train from Paris.
ALBANY, July 24 The State of New York has moved to take over the regulation of all uses of radioactive substances within its borders except fissionable materials of a critical mass.
LEE, Mass., July 24 An attractive assortment of Spanish dancers has been brought together at Jacob's Pillow for the season's fifth program.

A 5-cent increase in the quarterly dividend of the Magnavox Company was declared by directors yesterday. The dividend will be 17 cents a common share, against 12 cents, and is payable on Sept. 15 to holders of record of Aug. 24. The company said it was placing the dividend on a 70 centsa-year basis because of a substantial increase in earnings.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 24 Vic Seixas, who had won the title seven times since 1946; Juan Couder, a Spanish Davis Cup player from Madrid, and Larry Nagler, Hollywood, Calif., all of whom were seeded, were eliminated in the sixty-third Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship today at the Merion Cricket Club.

Most European currencies weakened in relation to the dollar on the New York foreign exchange market yesterday, as the European money market reacted sharply to President Kennedy's speech transmitted across the Atlantic via the Telstar satellite on Monday.
The first live news telecasts from Europe were presented here yesterday when the three networks presented individual reports from Paris and Geneva.
WASHINGTON, July 24 A new effort is being made to persuade Congress to exempt Fedleral compensation to wartime Japanese-American evacuees from Federal taxation.
PARIS, July 24 France has instructed her Ambassador and consuls in the newborn and troubled Algerian state to take "energetic action" to protect French lives and property there.

FEW fish are more likely to inspire a lively discussion among fishermen and others than the salmon. Not only are the habits Of this champion of the leap open to speculation, but also the differences between Eastern and Western salmon leave room for debate as do the methods of bringing them to market.
Activity in the bond market slowed to a near standstill yesterday as the financial community swapped conjectures as to the likely shape of the Treasury's next financing operations.
Potato and wool futures declined in heavy trading yesterday, although other commodities on the New York exchanges were having dull and listless sessions.
A committee of junior high school principals has come out in favor of enriched rather than accelerated programs for gifted pupils.
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) The new national track and basketball federations put themselves into business today with the blessing of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.
MOSCOW, July 24 The Soviet Union announced today new patent regulations designed to protect its technological improvements abroad.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 24 The annual pro-amateur charity golf tournament of the Piping Rock Club was held today.
PHOENIX, Ariz., July 24 Controversy raged today over a proposed abortion for a young Phoenix mother who fears her baby may be deformed because she has taken European-made tranquilizer pills.

PARIS, July 24 Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer, designated to succeed Gen. Lauris Norstad as commander of United States and Allied forces in Europe, left for Washington today after forty-eight hours of conferences here.

LOS ANGELES, July 24 Wally Byam, who led caravans of automobile trailers through North and Central America, Africa and Europe, died of cancer Sunday at his home here. He was 66 years old. His full name was Wallace Merle Byam.

The works of younger artists are on view at the Whitney Museum of Art, 22 West Fiftyfourth Street, in an exhibition called "Forty Artists Under Forty." Taken from the museum's collection, the show includes paintings, sculpture, water-colors, drawings and collage by Ben Kamihira, Joan Mitchell, Roubet Rauschenberg and others. To Sept. 16, every day, 1 to 5 P.M. Free.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 24 Two diplomats from the Philippines and Mexico disagreed today about the authorship of a controversial report on South-West Africa.

The Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., reported yesterday a net income of $117,400,000, or $2.41 a share for the six months ended June 30. This compared with $108,800,000, or $2.24 a share, in the 1961 period.

PARIS, July 24 Consistency is rarely a virtue at collec tion time in Paris. While other designers seem to be neglecting curves. Jules-Francois Crahay enshrined them in his autumn showing at Nina Ricci.

JOB-AID MEASURE REVIVED IN HOUSE WASHINGTON, July 24 A $900,000,000 public works bill suddenly came to life today, with prospects of its passage by the House next week. The Senate has passed a generally similar bill.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 24 The smashing success of the fourth United StatesSoviet Union track and field meet as a contest, a spectacle and an instrument of international goodwill points up the urgent necessity for a closing of ranks on the administrative level in amateur athletics in this country.

Major commercial finance companies announced yesterday a lowering of rates on shortterm commercial paper. The move followed yesterday's drop in the rates of ninety-one and 182-day United States Treasury bills.
The United States, by massive and unqualified support of the regime of President Ngo Dinh Diem, has helped arrest the spread of Communist insurgency in South Vietnam. But victory is remote.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 24 Breakdowns caused by heavy gusts of wind marred an otherwise perfect sailing day today as the great South Bay Yacht Racing Association completed the second program of its Cruise Week competition.
LIMA, Peru, July 24 Argentina took a step today that was viewed here as indicating a split with other Latin-American countries in their attitudes toward the military junta in Peru.
Stock prices, on average, declined moderately yesterday in show and desultory trading. However, there were more than twice as many individual declines as advances.

THE PRESIDENT Had breakfast with Democratic Congressional leaders; received report from Benny Goodman on Soviet tour; named Richard W. Reuter, Food for Peace director; saw G. Mennen Williams, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs; attended luncheon given in his honor by Ecuadorian President Arosemena; received message of goodwill from President of Turkey delivered by new Turkish Ambassador.
ALBANY, Ga., July 24 The police dispersed a crowd of 2,000 angry Negroes tonight after a Federal court ban against mass demonstrations had been suspended.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) President Kennedy's mother, who resents wisecracks about political dynasties, said today she would campaign to help her youngest son, Edward M., win a Senate seat in Massachusetts.
Jean-Louis Barrault will be a guest director next spring at the Institute for the Advanced Studies in the Theatre Arts. M. Barrault will stage Robert Lowell's version of "Phaedra."
TRENTON, July 24 State Treasurer John A. Kervick approved today the final plans for New Jersey's first cultural center.
ALBANY, Ga., July 24 The police dispersed a crowd of 2,000 angry Negroes tonight after a Federal court ban against mass demonstrations had been suspended.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) President Kennedy's mother, who resents wisecracks about political dynasties, said today she would campaign to help her youngest son, Edward M., win a Senate seat in Massachusetts.
Jean-Louis Barrault will be a guest director next spring at the Institute for the Advanced Studies in the Theatre Arts. M. Barrault will stage Robert Lowell's version of "Phaedra."
TRENTON, July 24 State Treasurer John A. Kervick approved today the final plans for New Jersey's first cultural center.
TRENTON, July 24 State Attorney General Arthur J. Sills ruled today that a rebate program adopted for customers by two North Jersey milk distributors was illegal.
Leonard Bernstein has been commissioned to write as original musical drama for television.
TOKYO, July 24 The most important economic news in Japan these days is that eighteen Japanese business men, after more than a year of hesitation, have decided to go on a journey.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara returned today from another Pacific conference. He said he was encouraged over progress of affairs in South Vietnam but he was still convinced that the war there against the Communists could last for years.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 24 Lightning Class skippers received a lesson on the importance of carefully reading race circulars today in the Sea Cliff Yacht Club's annual Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound open regatta.
ROSELLE, N.J., July 24 A group of babysitters here has drafted a code to assure fair treatment and fair pay.
GENEVA, July 24 India proposed to the disarmament Conference today that the Big Four powers undertake immediately to bar the spread of nuclear weapons.

The Permanent Administrative Committee on hospital wages and working conditions recommended yesterday that the city's voluntary nonprofit hospitals pay their non-medical workers a minimum of $1.35 an hour.
LOS ANGELES, July 24 James J. Oppen, who has been practicing law in suburban Van Nuys for several years in relative obscurity, found sudden acclaim today.

Morris Weiss, a real estate operator, was fined $285 in Housing Court yesterday after pleading guilty in five cases. This brought the number of Mr. Weiss' convictions in the court in the last three years to 121.

The Brunswick Corporation, maker of bowling equipment, boats, aircraft parts, furniture and other products, reported yesterday declines in sales and earnings for the first half and second quarter of this year.

LIMBE, Nyasaland, July 24 Nyasaland's Africans are breaking their country away from its federation with Northern and Southern Rhodesia with a determination that amounts to secession in all but the name.
Within a year, two experts predicted yesterday, the world high jump record will be 7 feet 6 inches and the broad jump record will be 28 feet.
Cotton futures were unchanged to 60 cents a bale up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The Southern Railway had a net income of $13,400,000, or $1.79 a common share, in the first half of this year, the company reported yesterday. This compared with $11,100,000, or $1.48 a common share, in the first six months of 1961.

The Armco Steel Corporation reported yesterday that secondquarter earnings declined to $12,747,425, or 86 cents a share, from $13,915,22, or 94 cents, in the 1961 period, despite a sales gain to $247,793,189 from $226,372,912.
A new specialty has sprung up in the field of electronic computers the brokerage of idle time on the big and expensive machines. In effect, companies that spend large amounts to rent computers on...
Genung's, Inc., department store chain with headquarters in Mount Vernon, N.Y., announced yesterday that it had agreed to purchase the Goerke Stores in New Jersey and Connecticut.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, accused some of his colleagues today of "sheer demagoguery" for sponsoring a World War I pension bill.

Seventeen tenants at 30 and 50 Church Street moved in State Supreme Court yesterday to prevent the seizure of the properties of the bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad by the Port of New York Authority.

PARIS, July 24 The door to a convention sponsored by a United Nations agency was slammed shut today against Communist China and other countries outside the world organization after they had a chance to get a foot inside.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 24 Foreign Ministers PaulHenri Spaak of Belgium and Joseph M.A.H. Luns of the Netherlands agreed today on a new approach toward creation of a European political union.
In Tokyo last evening a Japanese G.I-bride boarded a plane for Little Rock, Ark., to join her husband. The flight is being paid for with 289,500 Gold Bond trading stamps.
WASHINGTON, July 25 Following is the text of the exchange of letters between Luis Munoz Marin, Governor of Puerto Rico, and President Kennedy on the status of Puerto Rico.
PARIS, July 25 A two-hour stoppage by employes of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization paralyzed operations at headquarters here this mroning.
In the twilight at the Stadium last night the Boston Red Sox sneaked up on the big, bad Yankees and escaped into the shadows with a 4-2 victory.
LONDON, July 25 With the Government and the Arts Council cast as villains a conflict erupted today over the future of the Royal Stratford Theatre's London operations.
Stock prices edged off slightly yesterday. Trading was light and no real selling pressure was evident.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)--Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman today designated thirty-nine of New York State's Sixty-two counties as an area where the Farmers Home Administration would offer emergency loans to drought-distressed farmers.

A major talent shift from the Music Corporation of America to another agency has been made. The world's largest artistmanagement operation had been ordered by the Government to dissolve its activities as an agency.

Darryl F. Zanuck was elected president of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation last night after a stormy three-and-a-half-hour session of the board of directors in the company's headquarters at 444 West Fifty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, July 25 The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended July 18:

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 25 (AP) Mrs. Henry Obre's Hunter's Rock won the Midsummer Hurdle Handicap at Monmouth Park today. The favorite, Windward Farm's Guardian Angel, lost his jockey at the tenth of the twelve jumps.

Everybody who has anything to do with Long Island knows that the population of Nassau and Suffolk Counties has been increasing rapidly. You can tell this by several symptoms including the traffic.
