A public works bill designed to provide funds on a discretionary basis is now being considered by the House Rules Committee. The Senate has already passed similar legislation, which gives the President standby authority to accelerate public works spending if unemployment and other indicators reveal that increased outlays are required to counter recessionary tendencies.

BERLIN, N.Y., July 25 A tank truck loaded with liquid propane gas exploded near the center of this Renssalaer County village today. The police said one person was killed and sixteen others were injured.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) The Army announced plans today to rotate combat units to Europe for six-month tours, leaving families at home.
Paddy Chayefsky plans to offer his next play to the Lincoln Center Repertory Company.

THIS is the time of season, just before the second all-star game sends the pennant races winging into the home stretch, when the old-timer has his big inning. The old boys enjoyed some bantering the other day at Cooperstown when Jackie Robinson, Bob Feller, Eddie Roush and Bill McKechnie were inducted into the Hall of Fame.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 25 Sir Hugh Foot, special adviser to Britain's delegation, suggested today that the Communists seemed to be suffering from a kind of "colonial mentality."

SASKATOON, Sask, July 25 (Canadian Press) Private practice outside the Medical Care Insurance Act was chosen by more than 100 Regina distract doctors, members of the Regina and District Medical Society, last night.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 25 At the end of four rounds of play in the New York States Chess Championship Tournament, Paul Brandts of New York, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, is in first place with four wins and no losses. The tournament is being played at the International Business Machines Country Club here.

WASHINGTON, July 25 President Kennedy agreed with Gov. Luis Munoz Marin today that the time had come for Puerto Ricans to express a preference for statehood, independ ence or a revised and permanent commonwealth relationship with the United States.

MADISON, Wis., July 25 (UPI) An officer of the Federal Court recommended today that the court not force reapportionment of Wisconsin's legislative and Congressional districts before the 1962 elections.
ALAVISH poker game redistributes the wealth of the players. The comparative celerity of horses or hounds is a popular matter for hot and wager-backed disputation.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., July 25 (AP) United States District Judge Waldo H. Rogers says he will defy any possible future orders forbidding him to open court with a prayer.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 25 Henry T. Adios, called by Stanley Dancer the world's "easiest horse to handle," is listed as the even-money favorite to win tomorrow night's $32,850 Empire Pace at Yonkers Raceway.
ALBANY, Ga., July 25 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. canceled plans to lead a mass demonstration today and declared a day of penance for an outbreak of violence last night.
The shake-up in the Department of Buildings spread yesterday to a large segment of the agency's inspection and examining staff.
BUENOS AIRES, July 25 Argentina's extensive new political regulations are seen by many observers here as tailored to fit the Presidential prospects of retired Gen. Pedro E. Aramburu.

ATHENS, July 25 Troops were called in today to quell farmer riots at Herakleion, the main harbor town of Crete. The soldiers fired shots in the air to disperse a crowd of about 2,000 armed with cudgels and stones.
MOSCOW, July 25 A former Soviet Finance Ministry official has been sentenced to death on charges of having extorted bribes.

PHOENIX, Ariz., July 25 A youn Phoenix mother who fears that she is going to have a deformed baby because she took a drug filed suit today for a declaratory judgment against the legality of Arizona's law forbidding abortion.
The state Democratic party's, sixty-two county leaders have been summoned to a meeting here next Monday in a move to develop an early consensus on a candidate for Governor.
WASHINGTON, July 25 Labor troubles in the merchant marine may nullify all efforts of Congress and the Government to keep the industry alive, Representative Herbert C. Bonner said today.
In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
A MAN can hardly turn around these days with out hearing a story about bluefishing. The latest comes from Dick Gross of the New Jersey Conservation Department.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 25 Dr. Robert A. Soblen applied today for permission to enter Israel under the Israeli Law of Return.
MONTREAL, July 25 (Canadian Press) Thibeaudeau Rinfret, Chief Justice of Canada from 1944 to 1954, died today in the Hotel-Dieu Hospital at the age of 84.

Rockets, missiles and Telstars are launched by millions of dollars and brilliant scientists. But who launches the scientists? Two scientist brothers one of them the brain behind Telstar say their scientific careers should be credited to the inspiration of a teacher, now retired, formerly of Newton High School, Queens.

BONN, Germany, July 25 Willy H. Schlieker, the West German industrialist who is fighting to keep his steel and shipping combine from going bankrupt, was reported today to have found financial backing for the biggest of his more than twenty companies.
CAIRO, July 25 President Gamal Abdel Nasser formally opened today a jet aircraft factory ready to turn out trainers, fighters and troop transports, official sources reported.

The "Festival of Performing Arts," which had a ten-week television run here last spring, is expected to present a new series of programs next season starring outstanding artists from the stage, recital hall and opera.
TIARET, Algeria, July 25 Dissenting Algerian leaders grouped about Vice Premier Mohammed Ben Bella disclaimed tonight either responsibility or foreknowledge of the shooting incidents in Constantine.
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) Soybean and feed grain futures recovered today on the Board of Trade after having sold most of the week at the season's lows. Wheat and rye were steady to weak.

WASHINGTON, July 25 The Federal Communications Commission today refused to renew the license of a South Carolina radio station because it broadcast obscene remarks and was generally deficient in programing.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 25 A funny thing happened on the way to the racing forum this morning. A crowd of 987 men, women and children showed up at the training track at Roosevelt Raceway. They sat, stood ...
WASHINGTON, July 25 The House approved this evening a bill to assure equal pay for equal work, regardless of the sex of the worker.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 20 President Tito's regime is cutting down still further the tiny area in which private business is permitted to function in Communist Yugoslavia's economy.
DOVER, N.J., July 25 On Aug. 1 the eighty-two-year-old Picatinny Arsenal in this Morris, County community will become the headquarters for the Army's new Munitions Command.

WASHINGTON, July 25 Within six weeks, a soft-spoken doctor from Alabama will have to perform one of the most delicate operations of his career appoint a twelve-member panel of experts to study possible links between smoking and such diseases as lung cancer and heart trouble.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) Senator Estes Kefauver, Tennessee Democrat, rejected today a plea by Bethlehem Steel Corporation that it be permitted to withhold its production cost figures from his Senate subcommittee's investigation of steel prices.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) The Department of Commerce said today that United States imports dropped 3 per cent in June.
ROME, July 25 Italy's imports for the first five months of 1962 exceeded its exports by 346,900,000,000 lire ($555,000,000) the Institute for Foreign Trade said today.
"IT WAS a poodle that started it all," said Sen hora Ethel Marie Neele. "A friend who came to visit me in Rio de Janeiro in 1952 had such a cute poodle that I decided I wanted one. Later that
LIMBE, Nyasaland, July 25 The Nyasaland Government publicly apologized today for what it termed racial "illtreatment" of three of the territory's guests.

The invasion of the European Common Market by American advertising agencies picked up new steam yesterday. The D'Arcy Advertising Company announced that it was setting up a new company in conjunction with a West German agency.
WASHINGTON, July 25--Settlement of the thirty-three-day-old flight engineers' strike against Eastern Air Lines by the end of the week was seen today as a strong possibility.
The country's gasoline stocks declined 449,000 barrels in the week ended Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

The Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will be the beneficiary of a theatre party at the Nov. 14 evening performance of Irving Berlin's musical "Mr. President" at the St. James Theatre.
Andrew H. Phelps, retired vice president for purchases and traffic for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, died Tuesday in Allegheny General Hospital, Pittsburgh. He was 73 years old.
Fifty Negro women from various parts of the United States will leave New York International Airport this morning for a visit to eight African countries.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 25 Harlan Cleveland, Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, conferred today with U Thant, Acting Secretary General, on ways to exert economic pressure on Moise Tshombe, President of secessionist Katanga.

GENEVA, July 25 Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, did not telephone, so Secretary of State Dean Rusk packed his bags today and flew home to Washington from the latest fruitless round of talks on Berlin.
Miner Industries, Inc., a toy manufacturer, announced yesterday the acquisition of Bayshore Industries, Inc., of Amsterdam, N.Y. The consideration was stock, the amount of which was not disclosed.
LONDON, July 25 The Queen's Gallery opened its doors this morning to an enthusiastic crowd that began to line up outside Buckingham Palace at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

The Inland Steel Company reported yesterday that secondquarter earnings declined to $13,456,869, or 75 cents a share, from $16,639,602, or 94 cents a share, in the first quarter and $13,605,988, or 77 cents a share in the 1961 June quarter.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) A Senate-House conference committee approved today a defense appropriation bill of $48,136,247,000, or $229,000,000 more than the Administration had requested.

Tel-A-Sign, Inc., Chicago-based producer of signs and point-of-purchase advertising material, is bidding for control of the Bon Ami Company, makers of cleaning com pounds. Bon Ami was raided six years ago for its entire $3,000,000 cash holdings by Alexander L. Guterma, who was then chairman, Guterma
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) The chairman of a House Foreign Aid Appropriations subcommittee called today for a cut of nearly 50 per cent in President Kennedy's $4,000,000,000 foreign aid money bill.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) The Agriculture Department was warned early in 1961 that transactions like those of Billie Sol Estes were illegal, a Senate subcommittee was told today.

With short interest at a forty-six-month high, some of the bears of Wall Street have been getting squeezed. It was nearly impossible yesterday to borrow stock for short sellers in the Xerox Corporation and the Polaroid Corporation. It has been difficult for days to borrow warrants of the Molybdenum Corporation of America.
WASHINGTON, July 25 Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said today that he expected some members of the New York Congressional delegation to propose making Fire Island a national seashore.
WASHINGTON, July 25 Twelve experts will begin a study this fall into the impact of smoking and air pollution upon health.

Saw Gens. Lyman L. Lemnitzer and Maxwell D. Taylor; received farewell call from William Halm, Ambassador from Ghana; saw British Ambassador Sir David Ormsby Gore; saw John D. Jernegan, former ambassador to Iraq; saw A.F.L.-C.I.O.
WASHINGTON, July 25 Detroit's decision,to put the country in bucket seats next year comes as one more saddening reminder of American technology's genius for getting in people's way.

The Ford Motor Company rolled up record half-year sales and the second best earnings in the six months ended with June. Second-quarter results were also well ahead of the 1961 period, despite a strike that closed down assembly lines for two weeks.

Business in high-grade debt investments continued to be inhibited yesterday by the imminence of a Washington decision of terms for the Treasury's August refunding operation. An announcement of the Treasury's plans is expected to be made today.
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) The American Basketball League said today it would operate with six teams in 1962-63 and might sue the rival National Basketball Association.
Rush-hour traffic moved smoothly through Fifty-fifth and Fifty-sixth Streets yesterday, the police reported, on the first day that summonses were issued for violation of new traffic rules.
LONDON, July 25 The Earl of Home, Britain's Foreign Secretary, said today he believed that "substantial modification" of the West's nuclear test-ban proposlas could be made soon.
Representative Leonard Farbstein of Manhattan, who is running for re-election, made public yesterday a letter from President Kennedy praising him for his work in Congress.
WASHINGTON, July 25 President Kennedy has decided that the economy needs an early cut in corporate and personal income taxes, well-placed sources said today.
Divers, with and without air tanks, will soon start cavorting regularly in a pool with the New York Aquarium's three little white whales.
PARIS, July 25 Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer of the United States was formally accepted today as Supreme Commander of Allied Forces in Europe to succeed Gen. Lauris Norstad about Nov.1.
Acting Mayor Paul R. Screvane said yesterday that the Board of Estimate "probably" would decide today whether to accept the retirement application of Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 25 As an illustration of the highly speculative nature of the gold and foreign exchange markets, and the power of television, the visual impact of the President and his words appears to have done in a few seconds what a whole series of Treasury statements and profound analyses could not do.

DESPITE the fact that Weaver Adams, author of "White to Play and Win," uses only the Vienna Opening in an attempt to prove the absolute truth of his theme, this debut is rarely seen these days in tournament play.

The Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads, the nation's two leading carriers, reported yesterday an improvement in operations in the second quarter from a year earlier. But both roads still showed large deficits.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) The Senate Antitrust subcommittee approved by a party-line vote today a bill to force a limited moratorium on railroad mergers for about eighteen months.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 25 After second-place finishes in the first two legs of the thirty-first annual American Yacht Club cruise, Patrick O'Gorman's forty-foot grayhulled yawl Wahini won today's first-division race.

The treaty-signing to provide for the neutrality of Laos brought the foreign ministers of the major powers to Geneva this past week. The treaty was disposed of on schedule, but on the two other matters that engaged much of the foreign ministers' attention, Berlin and disarmament, the result was continued deadlock.
MILWAUKEE, July 25 Joel Adcock and Eddie Mathews crashed two home runs apiece tonight making it a simple chore fox the Milwaukee Braves to hand the Mets their tenth straight loss. The score was 11 5.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 25 The tobacco business was denounced here today by a doctor.
"Those who speculate against the dollar are going to lose the United States will not devalue its dollar."
World sugar resisted midday selling pressures to end on a firm note. In other trading, cottonseed, oil, potatoes and copper rose in moderate trading on the New York Commodity Exchanges yesterday.
William F. Bohner, a commission broker with Hayden, Stone Co., was nominated by independent petition as a candidate for the new board of governors.

WASHINGTON, July 25 President Kennedy has called a meeting of his diplomatic and military advisers for Friday to consider what modifications the United States can make in its proposals for a nuclear test-ban treaty.
GENEVA, July 25 Brazil called today for a ban on nuclear explosions in the atmosphere and space as a first step toward an accord to outlaw all testing of atomic weapons.
SAN JUAN, P.R., July 25 Gov. Luis Munoz Marin's proposal for a plebiscite received a mixed reaction here today.
PARIS, July 25 Ten noncommunist nations met here today to compare and coordinate their aid policies toward under-developed nations.
ALGIERS, July 25 Fear of civil war gripped Algeria tonight.
The presence here of Thalidomide, a tranquilizer drug that has caused birth defects in thousands of babies in Europe, was declared yesterday by the City Health Department.

LAGOS, Nigeria, July 25 Dick Tiger, whose African village birthplace never has appeared on any maps, left by jet for America tonight hoping to make a modest name for his family, his hometown and his country by becoming Nigeria's first middleweight champion of the world.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) Four new British-made jetliners are on order for the Mohawk Airlines for delivery in 1965.
The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation reported yesterday new highs in manufacturing sales, telephone revenues and net income for the first half and second quarter.
A reversal in the usual flow of foreign investments, involving French participation in United States production, was announced here yesterday.

The Louisiana Fiscal Authority borrowed yesterday $20,000,000 on series. A revenue bonds due 1965 to 1987 at an interest cost of 4.2715 per cent. The only bid came from Blyth Co., Inc., C.J. Devine Co. and Ira Haupt Co. The group offered the bonds to the public priced to yield 2.75 to 4.25 per cent. A spokesman said that the issue was "going well" and that the issue was over half sold.

OSAKA, Japan, July 25 (AP) Louis Vitucci of Hollywood, Fla., and Ron O'Brien, a former Ohio State star, gave the visiting United States, team a onetwo sweep today in the threemeter spring-board dive of the Japanese national swimming championships.

WASHINGTON, July 25 The Senate Agriculture Committee set the stage today for another battle over farm legislation by turning down for the second time the Administration's proposals for strict controls on grain production.

Investing clients of Walter Scott Co. have added the fivestory store and apartment building at 694 Ninth Avenue to a plot they are assembling at the southeast corner of the avenue and Forty-eighth Street. They bought the parcel from Santo Trubia and others through Joseph O'Gara Co., brokers.

WASHINGTON, July 25 The Government's Consumer Price Index rose to a record in June. The increase of one-tenth of 1 per cent since May, however, was "strictly seasonal," according to Labor Department price experts.

BERLIN, July 25 East German guards opened fire early this morning on three Berliners who attempted to get across the Communist-built barbed-wire fence and escape to the West. One refugee was hit and is believed dead, according to the West Berlin police.
Some Soviet ballistic missile sites are now being "hardened" protected by concrete according to reliable reports reaching Washington. The hardening, so far, is

WEST CALDWELL, N.J., July 25 Wes Ellis of the home club and Stan Mosel of neighboring Essex Fells shot threeunder-par 68's today and tied for the lead in the first round of the thirty-sixth annual New Jersey Professional Golfers' Association championship at the Mountain Ridge Country Club.
LIMA, Peru, July 25 The top leadership of the American Popular Revolutionary Alliance (Apra party) has reached an understanding with the Peruvian military junta, it was reported reliably today.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 25 Whitney Reed had the touch on turf today as he has not had it on any surface all season and won, 6 2, 6 2, from Clark Graebner of Cleveland in the Pennsylvania grass-court tennis championship at the Merion Cricket Club.

ONE day recently Mrs. Nika Hazelton received a letter from her 17-year-old son Julian, temporarily employed as a "general boy" in a Norwegian hotel, the Brakanes at Ulvik in Hardanger. He indicated that he was a touch homesick.
A three-alarm fire at St. Mary's Hospital in Brooklyn caused the evacuation yesterday of all its 199 patients, including thirty-two newborn babies and seven expectant mothers, Four of the infants

MOSCOW, July 25 Ambassador Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr., who is ending his tour of duty in Moscow, paid a farewell call on Premier Khrushchev today and spent a total of five hours with the Soviet leader.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 25 Nassau County is considering the regulation of its 1,000 taxicabs as a result of investigation that have uncovered many instances of fare-gouging.
Two large vessels the first new ones for long-distance ocean transportation of refrigerated liquid ammonia were ordered yesterday from a Dutch shipyard.

Grand Concourse Syndicate, a group represented by Jacob Nass, lawyer, has bought the five-and-a-half-story apartment building at 1464-66 Grand Concourse, corner of 172d Street, the Bronx. The property,

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 25 (AP) The President of the ruling Council of State said today that his Government would formally accuse Cuba of "subversion and interference" in Dominican internal affairs.
VILLANOVA, Pa., July 25 An early autumn wedding is planned by Miss Alexandra Montgomery and Nathaniel Victor Dial. Mrs. T.F Dixon Wainwright and R. Alexander Montgomery, both of Villanova,

Harry B. Rutkins of 40 West Seventy-seventh Street, an associate member of Eggers Higgins, architects at 100 East Forty-second Street, died yesterday of a heart attack in the Municipal Building. His age was 58.
LONDON, July 25 Prime Minister Macmillan came through another test of his leadership today with marked success.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 25 (AP) Richard T. Staples, president and senior partner of James Staples Co., oldest private banking concern here, died yesterday in Bridgeport Hospital. He was 77 years old.

ST. LOUIS, July 25 (AP) An executive of Stix, Baer Fuller Company said today that the St. Louis department store concern was considering a purchase offer by the New York discount store chain of E.J. Korvette, Inc.

Appointment of Lieut. Gen. David W. Traub as general manager of the State University Construction Fund should serve as a reminder that the pace of expansion of New York's state-financed higher education must be stepped up dramatically before it is too late.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 25 Because it took so long this morning to hear protests from yesterday's races, no decisions were made by the committee regarding the leaders of several of the classes in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's Cruise Week championships.
AUGUSTA, Ga., July 25 A 20-year-old Negro was sentenced to life imprisonment today in the slaying of a white youth during a week of racial strife here.
The stigma attached to making profits was termed by a General Foods Corporation executive as "a grave and growing threat to the entire economic structure of our country."

Montpelier Farm's Mongo made the first stakes start of his career a victory yesterday. No stranger to the winner's circle in allowance competition the 3-year-old son of Royal Charger-won the $29,000 Lexington Handicap at Aqueduct by a neck over Bruce Campbell's Dedimoud, with the Brookfield Farms' In Force next.
A block of General Motors Corporation stock, with a market value of more than $7,350,000, was offered to the public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 25 A(P) Farm organization officials told the Senate Finance Committee today that new powers should be included in the trade bill, to try to prevent Western Europe from shutting off imports of United States agricultural products.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) New York and California Senators sparred in the Senate today over the division of defense contracts between the two states.

IN an evening of bridge one usually plays about fifty hands, and since the statistical definition of a regular bridge player is one who plays two or three times a month, a regular bridge player may be expected to hold about 1,500 hands a year.

JERSEY CITY, July 25 Mayor Thomas Gangemi today dismissed Thomas Finn, the $20,000-a-year administrator of the Jersey City Medical Center, several hours before Mr. Finn announced at a press conference that he was "resigning as of Sept. 15."
WASHINGTON, July 25 The Administration called Ambassador James Loeb back from Peru today to help decide how far and how long it can apply economic sanctions against Peru's new military junta.

PARIS, July 25 A former French Army colonel, better known for his missionary zeal as an estreme Rightist than for his sense of humor, has fallen into the satiric trap of one of France's most redoubtable journalistic institutions, Le Canard Enchaine.

RABAT, Morocco, July 25 Algerian National Liberation Front organizations in Morocco began to rally today to the new political bureau proclaimed Sunday by Vice Premier Ben Bella and the liberation Army chiefs.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation realized a 31 per cent increase in second-quarter earnings on a sales gain of 2.5 per cent. Half-year earnings rose 30.4 per cent on a 4 per cent sales improvement, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 25 President Kennedy was told to night that efforts to hold the Congo together required urgent action against secessionist Ka tanga despite the opposition of Britain.
HICKSVILLE, L.I., July 25 Petitions are being circulated for a referendum on the use of part of the fourth stanza of the National Anthem as a prayer in public schools here.
WASHINGTON, July 25 What explains the extraordinary persistence of Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg and his associates in attempting to resolve the airlines labor controversy?
LONDON, July 25 The stock market rose today on cheerful company news and growing optimism that the new Chancellor of the Exchequer, Reginald Maulding, would act to stimulate the economy.

A new ultra-high frequency television tuner was announced yesterday by the General Instrument Corporation. The company said the tuner gives up to four times longer tube life and has greater ability to stay on a station than any present U.H.F. tuner.

Alan Jack Pomeranz was held in $100,000 bail yesterday after he was described in Felony Court as "the fountainhead of distribution for more than $1,000,000 in stock to persons now considered part of the underworld."
The Fire Department announced yesterday that all cars parked in front of fire hydrants, including diplomats' cars, which are normally immune to traffic regulations, would be towed away.

WHITE PLAINS, July 25 The marriage of Miss Barbara Elsie Jacobs, daughter of Mrs. Frances Cullman Jacobs of New York and Stamford, Conn., and Robert Allan Jacobs of New York, to John Samuel Tamerin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Tamerin of New York, took place here this evening.
A maiden-voyage welcome was given yesterday to the smallest ocean liner ever to call at the Port of New York.

The economic needs of the entire Port of New York area far outweigh the objections of a relatively small group of business men to the projected World Trade Center, the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association said yesterday.

PARIS, July 25 A satellite has shattered fashion protocol here. It threatens to demolish the established rule that newspapers or magazines may not show photographs or detailed sketches of Paris couture clothes to the public until one month after the semi-annual fashion collections take Place.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was described by Senate investigators today as a man with a callous disregard of whether his own union members were robbed by their officers.

The International Longshoremen's Association asked the National Labor Relations Board yesterday to refuse the request of Brooklyn Local 1814 to negotiate a separate three-year contract with the New York Shipping Association.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) Several Senators urged today that Congress act to overcome last month's Supreme Court decision holding that officially prescribed prayers in the public schools are unconstitutional.
The Board of Estimate unanimously rejected the retirement application of Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, July 26 Warren Spahn, at the age of 41, continues to be amazing, even if his latest achievement was gained at the expense of the lowly Mets today. The lefthander pitched his 319th major league victory and tenth of the season as the Braves whipped the Mets, 6 1, before 14,773 (9,749 paying) fans at County Stadium.
Jose Quintero, director and co-sponsor of the Circle in the Square, an off-Broadway theater, has expanded his career to encompass a commercial television series.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 26 Americans were in possession of the semi-final brackets of the Pennsylvania grass court men's tennis championship today following the defeat of Fred Stolle of Australia and Clifff Drysdale of South Africa at the Merion Cricket Club.

WASHINGTON, July 26 President Kennedy has the reputation of being a "pragmatic man" who deals with things as they are rather than as he would like them to be, but there is nothing very pragmatic about his diplomacy in the Western Hemisphere.
The Conservative party of New York yesterday named Kieran O'Doherty, a 35-year-old Manhattan lawyer, as its candidate for the United States Senate.

TOMORROW the American Contract Bridge League will have a nationwide tournament for the benefit of its beneficial causes for this year, which are the National Multiple Sclerosis Society and the Institute of Logopedics.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 26 The admission to membership of the two new African countries of Rwanda and Burundi was recommended unanimously today by the Security Council.
The Board of Estimate approved yesterday an appropriation of $1,781,612 for the expansion of graduate education by the City University.
LONDON, July. 26 The Premise, a topical revue by four American improvisers, moved into the West End tonight to the cheers of an opening-night audience.
BERLIN, N.Y., July 26 Gaily-dressed sightseers crowded, into this Lebanon Valley community today to take a look at the scene of a tank truck explosion that left two dead and eighteen injured.

PARIS, July 26 The fashion world expects fire works from Dior. They did not go off this morning.

The Norwegian America Line announced here yesterday the placing of an order for a new passenger liner with a French shipyard.
WASHINGTON, July 26 President Kennedy announced today that he had signed a sweeping welfare reform bill.

The machine tool industry's future appears bright. Builders in this country are reporting a sharp spurt of interest in machine-making equipment now that buyers of the tools can write off the cost for tax purposes in a shorter period.

The wholesale commodity price index rose to 80.1 Wednesday from 79.9 Tuesday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 84.2 on July 19, 1961.

PARIS, July 26 The French Government views the current near-anarchy in Algeria with anguish, but with a determination to avoid, if possible, any new direct involvement that could have tragic consequences.

That was the era when mothers held food up to their children's clenched teeth, reminded them of the hungry millions in Europe and Asia, and implored: "Have another bite for Grandma."

Like battered boxers too proud to quit, the Red Sox staggered the scheduled distance against the Yankees in yesterday's ball game at the Stadium.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) The House passed by voice vote today the $48,136,247,000 measure to finance the national defense this year.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 26 The three-sided, mud-walled forts that dot South Vietnam's countryside have become symbols of frustration to United States officers training Vietnam's armed forces in the war against Communist rebels.
Three, and perhaps four, babies born to New York women recently were deformed as a result of the mothers' having taken the drug Thalidomide, the city Health Department reported yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 26 Rice in Thailand is far more than a staple food for millions. It is also the country's top export commodity and chief source of foreign exchange, as well as the livelihood for a major part of the rural population.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) Losses were steep and general under an increasing volume of selling pressure in final dealings today on the Board of Trade.

LAWRENCEBURG, Tenn., July 26 (AP) Pat Sutton, a former United States Representative, was arrested today by Secret Service agents. He was charged with conspiracy and transporting counterfeit bills.
The Port of New York Authority took over the bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad yesterday over the protests of tradesmen who operate shops in the line's Manhattan terminal buildings.

Eliot L. Ward, a partner in the real estate firm of Vought, Ward and Nicholls, 48 East Forty-third Street, died in his office yesterday afternoon. His age was 72. He lived at 580 Park Avenue.

Miss Constance Barber Mellon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard King Mellon of Huntland Downs, Ligonier, Pa., was married here yesterday afternoon to William Russell Grace Byers. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Frederic Byers Jr. of old Westbury, L.I.

DETROIT, July 26 (AP) New car sales in mid-July failed to match those of the 1961 period, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. This was the first time this year sales have fallen behind the 1961 pace.

If the dull trading session in the bond market had any meaning yesterday, it was vetoed by the implications of the Treasury's August financing. The terms of the offering were announced after the market closed.

WASHINGTON, July 26 Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg worked for almost twelve hours today to end the thirty-four-day-old flight engineers' strike against Eastern Airlines. He will continue his efforts tomorrow.

RESOLUTE, Northwest Territories, July 26 (AP) An Arctic expedition reported today the deepest permafrost measurement ever made in North America.

PARIS, July 26 The power struggle in Algeria appears to stem largely from rivalries of individuals and clans rather than from any clear-cut ideological differences.
Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System fell $104,000,000 to $59,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

The Chrysler Corporation operated in the black for the third successive quarter in the three months ended June 30. Its half-year profit, consequently, was a dramatic comeback from the loss of more than $15,000,000 in the 1961 period.

BERLIN, July 26 A Soviet fighter approached a United States military courier plane today in the airspace over Berlin, United States authorities announced.

Dr. Roy L. Reierson, senior vice president and chief economist of Bankers Trust Company, had some cheerless words yesterday for gold speculators. Any speculation that the United States gold price will be raised will be "as unrewarding today as in the past fifteen years or more," he said. Dr. Reierson added that he was confident the dollar would not be devalued.

OSAKA, Japan, July 26 (AP) Two California schoolgirls smashed a world record but a Japanese diver was the sensation of the day in winning the men's platform title at Japan's outdoor swimming and diving championships.

A Roslyn, L.I., mother of three children was fined $1,000 yesterday in the Federal Court, Brooklyn, for telling airline employer she had a time bomb in her luggage.

WASHINGTON, July 26 The United States failed again today in an attempt to conduct a high-altitude nuclear test over Johnston Island in the Pacific. A Thor rocket burst into flames and was destroyed on the launching pad.

ALGIERS, July 26 The Algerian political pendulum swung back toward peace and compromise today, impelled in part by the fear of civil war that gripped the country during the previous twenty-four hours.
WASHINGTON, July 26 The House Ways and Means Committee began closed hearings today to determine whether the national economy needs the stimulus of a tax cut.

For ten years, as the public was reminded this week, Puerto Rico has had a unique relationship with the United States. It has been a "commonwealth" owing allegiance on terms that have never been applicable to a state or to a territory.

WASHINGTON, July 26 Representative John V. Lindsay of New York said today that Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall was "hedging" in his talk about wanting a national seashore on Fire Island.

NEW DELHI, India, July 26 An Indian Air Force team is likely to visit Moscow in the next few days to open negotiations with the Soviet Union for the long-expected acquisition of MIG 21 fighter planes.

WASHINGTON, July 26--Plans for a $70,000,000 modernization of New York City's postal system were announced today by Postmaster General J. Edward Day.

KABUL, Afghanistan, July 26 Reuters) Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran arrived today on a five-day visit aimed at easing tensions between Afghanistan and Pakistan.
LONDON, July 26 Prices advanced in almost every section of the stock market today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP) The Justice Department has filed a civil antitrust suit against the Keasbey and Mattison Company of Ambler, Pa., and the Johns-Manville Corporation of New York. Both also are under indictment on criminal antitrust charges.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 26 Matt Cvetic, a former counterspy for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, died of a heart attack today at the State Motor Vehicle office while taking a driving examination. He was 53 years old.
PARIS, July 27 Mme. Jules Moch, wife of a prominent French Socialist leader, was killed early this morning when she fell or jumped from the bedroom window of their apartment in suburban Neuilly.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) in the first six months of this year had estimated earnings of $425,000,000, M.J. Rathbone, president, reported yesterday. This is equivalent to $1.96 on each of the 216,533,000 shares outstanding.

The Board of Estimate yesterday approved an agreement to sell and lease to Westchester County 534 acres of land for parks and institutions. In return, the city will be relieved of further pollution of its water supply at Mount Kisco.
GENEVA, July 27--The Soviet Union asserted today that its first-stage disarmament plan would make impossible another surprise attack such as the United States suffered at Pearl Harbor.

The freight revenues of domestic water carriers were up 6.2 per cent during the first quarter of this year when compared with the same period last year, according to Interstate Commerce Commission statistics.

A spectacular change in the decor of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel's grand ballroom was disclosed yesterday.

The market for new dept capital will be moderately active next week with nearly $137,000,000 in fixed-interest securities scheduled for offering at competitive bidding. The issues are about equally divided in number between municipals and corporates, but the corporates account for most of the bonds.

"HANDLE with care" is a label that might well be attached to okra. When it is picked, kid or other gloves are necessary to prevent the hands from feeling as though they have been stung by a thousand nettles.

LONDON, July 27 (UPI)-- Capt. Raymond D'Inzeo of Italy today won the third qualifying contest for the European show jumping championship on Gowran Girl. The championship will be decided tomorrow.

Everybody in Yankee Stadium knew that Dale Long of the Yankees would be swinging for the fences when he went to bat in the twelfth inning of last night's game with the White Sox.

A "surprise" booking at a midtown theatre has provided a fresh indication of the increasing interest in independently made local movies.

LONDON, July 27--(Reuters)--Three Appeal Court judges refused today to allow Somerset Maugham to transfer to New York 229,581 ($642,826) netted from an auction of nine of his pictures by Sotheby's here in April.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 27-- The Merion Cricket Club will stage tomorrow the prize women's tennis match of the American season.
MADISON, Wis., July 27 (AP)--Dr. C.A. Elvehjem, scientist, and president of the University of Wisconsin since 1958, died today in Madison General Hospital of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 27 UPI--The Washington Senators made thirty-two hits, including seven homers, and trounced the Boston Red Sox tonight, 11--2 and 14--1.

The Kennedy Administration has taken another constructive step in its program for the dependent territories of the United States in deciding to ask Congressional approval for increased home rule on Guam. It recently proposed that the Virgin Islands elect their own Governor --now appointed by the President--and a Secretary. The same arrangement will now be sought for the 70,000 American mainland and indigenous residents of Guam.

Chicago and North Western Railway in the second quarter of this year had a net income of $250,912, including special credits of $638,627 resulting from sales of land and refund of taxes. Gross operating revenues were $55,513,015.

LONDON, July 27--Nubar Sarkis Gulbenkian, a wealthy and familiar figure about London, won a nominal award of 2 ($5.60) from the British Broadcasting Corporation in High Court today.

The President of Ecuador, Carlos Julio Arosemena, is ending his trip to New York today after talks in Washington. For North Americans, Ecuador is one of the least known countries of the hemisphere, and it was useful and pleasant to have its President here.

Credits of $500,000,000 to Argentina from United States and world institutions were announced yesterday by Dr. Alvaro C. Alsogaray, Argentine Minister of Economics.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 28 ----A big bloc of undecided and largely indifferent voters holds the key to the selection of a Democratic nominee for Governor in Tennessee next Thursday.

CONCORD, Mass., July 28-- Mr. and Mrs. Eugene G. Kraetzer Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Ann Kraetzer, to Lieut. George Mifflin Dallas 4th, U.S.N.R. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Mifflin Dallas of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia.
WASHINGTON, July 28-- Senate leaders won an unusual ten-hour battle tonight over foes of a bill to set up a privately owned communications satellite corporation.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 28 --Bruce Bedford Sr. of 36 Boudinot Street, chairman of the board and former president of the Trenton Savings Fund Society, died today in Princeton Hospital. His age was 85.
NEWARK, July 28--Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio announced today that he would ask for an ordinance to strengthen and expand the nine-year-old Mayor's Commission on Group Relations.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28 (AP)--Art Mahaffey of the Phillies pitched five perfect innings and had a no-hitter for six and a third innings against Pittsburgh tonight, but he had to settle for a four-hitter as the Phils beat the Pirates, 9--2.

Sixteen houses, including a ranch model with seven rooms and two and a half bathrooms, are under construction at Skytop Glen on Skytop Road, off Fairview Avenue, in Cedar Grove, N.J. The ranch is priced at $32,900.

More myths probably have been written about ball players than about anyone since the original Olympians, but nobody minds because baseball loves its ancient heroes who contributed so heavily to the lore of the diamond.
LOS ANGELES, July 28-- One of the nation's largest unions is giving up a three-year battle to oust two members who publicly differed with its political policies.

CENTERPORT, L.I., July 28 Sally Porterfield, Stan Doepke Jr. and Bruce Wessinger won twice each today in the TriClub open junior regatta on Northport Bay.
